taciturn, this worthy signor. Be it understood we are speaking of	491.3166496012253
Athos. During the five or six years that he had lived in the strictest	416.69841534516166
intimacy with his companions, Porthos and Aramis, they could remember	406.25182104780754
having often seen him smile, but had never heard him laugh. His words	415.0919003558664
were brief and expressive, conveying all that was meant, and no more;	324.1484537344555
no embellishments, no embroidery, no arabesques. His conversation was a	333.32149023334017
matter of fact, without a single romance.	304.0827928161748
Although Athos was scarcely thirty years old, and was of great personal	422.44118981707345
beauty and intelligence of mind, no one knew whether he had ever had a	323.27879726859044
mistress. He never spoke of women. He certainly did not prevent others	359.65392810900397
from speaking of them before him, although it was easy to perceive that	336.20070281654785
this kind of conversation, in which he only mingled by bitter words and	336.0284442494853
misanthropic remarks, was very disagreeable to him. His reserve, his	346.19759265164043
roughness, and his silence made almost an old man of him. He had, then,	426.77114026494684
in order not to disturb his habits, accustomed Grimaud to obey him upon	460.18736061510697
a simple gesture or upon a simple movement of his lips. He never spoke	395.1161164982432
to him, except under the most extraordinary occasions.	411.3103815443353
Sometimes, Grimaud, who feared his master as he did fire, while	400.8733487372824
entertaining a strong attachment to his person and a great veneration	405.8149342708076
for his talents, believed he perfectly understood what he wanted, flew	435.953205818722
to execute the order received, and did precisely the contrary. Athos	353.3708425839697
then shrugged his shoulders, and, without putting himself in a passion,	421.9869990556375
thrashed Grimaud. On these days he spoke a little.	463.18742339231653
Porthos, as we have seen, had a character exactly opposite to that of	351.7356087964715
Athos. He not only talked much, but he talked loudly, little caring, we	296.47079442552416
must render him that justice, whether anybody listened to him or not.	414.680122941555
He talked for the pleasure of talking and for the pleasure of hearing	488.4697598514598
himself talk. He spoke upon all subjects except the sciences, alleging	402.0552884576269
in this respect the inveterate hatred he had borne to scholars from his	372.2002701017996
childhood. He had not so noble an air as Athos, and the commencement of	308.68574756692055
their intimacy often rendered him unjust toward that gentleman, whom he	474.73407702842417
endeavored to eclipse by his splendid dress. But with his simple	417.0209123161943
Musketeer’s uniform and nothing but the manner in which he threw back	323.0030725663074
his head and advanced his foot, Athos instantly took the place which	383.81637132529244
was his due and consigned the ostentatious Porthos to the second rank.	338.5538395238047
Porthos consoled himself by filling the antechamber of M. de Tréville	424.9043375255725
and the guardroom of the Louvre with the accounts of his love scrapes,	332.74306986500596
after having passed from professional ladies to military ladies, from	440.8189615563547
the lawyer’s dame to the baroness, there was question of nothing less	477.29627396856984
with Porthos than a foreign princess, who was enormously fond of him.	399.25971543845185
An old proverb says, “Like master, like man.” Let us pass, then, from	297.8048863385418
the valet of Athos to the valet of Porthos, from Grimaud to Mousqueton.	304.82136078870235
Mousqueton was a Norman, whose pacific name of Boniface his master had	292.4999334885051
changed into the infinitely more sonorous name of Mousqueton. He had	330.2023685269661
entered the service of Porthos upon condition that he should only be	351.16041309391903
clothed and lodged, though in a handsome manner; but he claimed two	356.16304365763204
hours a day to himself, consecrated to an employment which would	437.0694276265998
provide for his other wants. Porthos agreed to the bargain; the thing	389.29023434097445
suited him wonderfully well. He had doublets cut out of his old clothes	331.5553475797166
and cast-off cloaks for Mousqueton, and thanks to a very intelligent	360.3770131011196
tailor, who made his clothes look as good as new by turning them, and	327.3071041049476
whose wife was suspected of wishing to make Porthos descend from his	433.3765789806615
aristocratic habits, Mousqueton made a very good figure when attending	322.5370847111281
on his master.	356.53478881023966
As for Aramis, of whom we believe we have sufficiently explained the	403.5903812710532
character—a character which, like that of his companions, we shall be	415.24207122711914
able to follow in its development—his lackey was called Bazin. Thanks	377.1619638543475
to the hopes which his master entertained of someday entering into	320.93832185004743
orders, he was always clothed in black, as became the servant of a	341.1470829253707
churchman. He was a Berrichon, thirty-five or forty years old, mild,	487.0309177612708
peaceable, sleek, employing the leisure his master left him in the	419.5354420023111
perusal of pious works, providing rigorously for two a dinner of few	360.52905664272043
dishes, but excellent. For the rest, he was dumb, blind, and deaf, and	399.1976773290694
of unimpeachable fidelity.	482.9507248812258
And now that we are acquainted, superficially at least, with the	373.9723137110299
masters and the valets, let us pass on to the dwellings occupied by	450.57057091144037
each of them.	366.55744260141597
Athos dwelt in the Rue Férou, within two steps of the Luxembourg. His	393.97644554737633
apartment consisted of two small chambers, very nicely fitted up, in a	329.7688691386906
furnished house, the hostess of which, still young and still really	459.9346757285092
handsome, cast tender glances uselessly at him. Some fragments of past	341.8348233826617
splendor appeared here and there upon the walls of this modest lodging;	347.1933016757673
a sword, for example, richly embossed, which belonged by its make to	463.2281265743541
the times of Francis I, the hilt of which alone, encrusted with	330.8618845036912
precious stones, might be worth two hundred pistoles, and which,	479.56219335535206
nevertheless, in his moments of greatest distress Athos had never	450.1396053518248
pledged or offered for sale. It had long been an object of ambition for	360.9188891918041
Porthos. Porthos would have given ten years of his life to possess this	408.7875940104375
sword.	343.70055243257866
One day, when he had an appointment with a duchess, he endeavored even	461.5265853208484
to borrow it of Athos. Athos, without saying anything, emptied his	462.9412546693958
pockets, got together all his jewels, purses, aiguillettes, and gold	343.3991249653334
chains, and offered them all to Porthos; but as to the sword, he said	366.16705790441324
it was sealed to its place and should never quit it until its master	385.413959784383
should himself quit his lodgings. In addition to the sword, there was a	410.43027083520894
portrait representing a nobleman of the time of Henry III., dressed with	402.1891811891101
the greatest elegance, and who wore the Order of the Holy Ghost; and	350.48235453676836
this portrait had certain resemblances of lines with Athos, certain	416.15132310283786
family likenesses which indicated that this great noble, a knight of	318.9011615353193
the Order of the King, was his ancestor.	425.42725267827126
Besides these, a casket of magnificent goldwork, with the same arms as	306.58448349233026
the sword and the portrait, formed a middle ornament to the	307.9989896333361
mantelpiece, and assorted badly with the rest of the furniture. Athos	424.43366754206727
always carried the key of this coffer about him; but he one day opened	402.2709217847024
it before Porthos, and Porthos was convinced that this coffer contained	369.97118833917136
nothing but letters and papers—love letters and family papers, no	488.3758573849807
doubt.	453.1031512540373
Porthos lived in an apartment, large in size and of very sumptuous	490.6404020921324
appearance, in the Rue du Vieux-Colombier. Every time he passed with a	335.9699514917265
friend before his windows, at one of which Mousqueton was sure to be	366.81833411141855
placed in full livery, Porthos raised his head and his hand, and said,	478.9035257493989
“That is my abode!” But he was never to be found at home; he never	320.49065076827566
invited anybody to go up with him, and no one could form an idea of	443.38182726552
what his sumptuous apartment contained in the shape of real riches.	384.5747407517038
As to Aramis, he dwelt in a little lodging composed of a boudoir, an	374.43478950469455
eating room, and a bedroom, which room, situated, as the others were,	415.03053543348744
on the ground floor, looked out upon a little fresh green garden, shady	302.47454532599295
and impenetrable to the eyes of his neighbors.	312.4701765841327
With regard to D’Artagnan, we know how he was lodged, and we have	454.7254868842555
already made acquaintance with his lackey, Master Planchet.	457.19283754882565
D’Artagnan, who was by nature very curious—as people generally are who	423.3273341883264
possess the genius of intrigue—did all he could to make out who Athos,	375.3605532943687
Porthos, and Aramis really were (for under these pseudonyms each of	412.2497683948101
these young men concealed his family name)—Athos in particular, who, a	393.33257630913204
league away, savored of nobility. He addressed himself then to Porthos	330.43363554308513
to gain information respecting Athos and Aramis, and to Aramis in order	448.530411430654
to learn something of Porthos.	328.40429553774743
Unfortunately Porthos knew nothing of the life of his silent companion	483.3295239975376
but what revealed itself. It was said Athos had met with great crosses	472.8518619937532
in love, and that a frightful treachery had forever poisoned the life	328.6871264825153
of this gallant man. What could this treachery be? All the world was	306.67184860635496
ignorant of it.	470.8254716021363
As to Porthos, except his real name (as was the case with those of his	481.5350559784163
two comrades), his life was very easily known. Vain and indiscreet, it	445.2111843248488
was as easy to see through him as through a crystal. The only thing to	404.57409386228716
mislead the investigator would have been belief in all the good things	463.01292005118364
he said of himself.	455.7997395530705
With respect to Aramis, though having the air of having nothing secret	354.3612429536371
about him, he was a young fellow made up of mysteries, answering little	297.6378606619039
to questions put to him about others, and having learned from him the	401.1528686496771
report which prevailed concerning the success of the Musketeer with a	376.8304248989857
princess, wished to gain a little insight into the amorous adventures	352.947560413516
of his interlocutor. “And you, my dear companion,” said he, “you speak	347.3415028991403
of the baronesses, countesses, and princesses of others?”	405.99005920051326
“_Pardieu!_ I spoke of them because Porthos talked of them himself,	328.62415878582584
because he had paraded all these fine things before me. But be assured,	342.38633448405955
my dear Monsieur d’Artagnan, that if I had obtained them from any other	393.94938275525334
source, or if they had been confided to me, there exists no confessor	360.1374774329606
more discreet than myself.”	294.11952955810324
“Oh, I don’t doubt that,” replied D’Artagnan; “but it seems to me that	468.48943554497134
you are tolerably familiar with coats of arms—a certain embroidered	398.86485747494424
handkerchief, for instance, to which I owe the honor of your	457.3457817430019
acquaintance?”	459.89736390094544
This time Aramis was not angry, but assumed the most modest air and	334.9115098158654
replied in a friendly tone, “My dear friend, do not forget that I wish	318.39184118842496
to belong to the Church, and that I avoid all mundane opportunities.	443.15503869384156
The handkerchief you saw had not been given to me, but it had been	385.620437201149
forgotten and left at my house by one of my friends. I was obliged to	405.38879169945466
pick it up in order not to compromise him and the lady he loves. As for	373.33105603453157
myself, I neither have, nor desire to have, a mistress, following in	322.4224252020001
that respect the very judicious example of Athos, who has none any more	392.9817570872955
than I have.”	448.94018308015904
“But what the devil! You are not a priest, you are a Musketeer!”	422.04005786987113
“A Musketeer for a time, my friend, as the cardinal says, a Musketeer	302.5110146009385
against my will, but a churchman at heart, believe me. Athos and	322.4922812513834
Porthos dragged me into this to occupy me. I had, at the moment of	409.1836593677445
being ordained, a little difficulty with—But that would not interest	465.7337800670288
you, and I am taking up your valuable time.”	451.21912536338596
“Not at all; it interests me very much,” cried D’Artagnan; “and at this	315.0466210783
moment I have absolutely nothing to do.”	355.1808500953475
“Yes, but I have my breviary to repeat,” answered Aramis; “then some	386.97860187327996
verses to compose, which Madame d’Aiguillon begged of me. Then I must	303.8955982398541
go to the Rue St. Honoré in order to purchase some rouge for Madame de	482.90572937589354
Chevreuse. So you see, my dear friend, that if you are not in a hurry,	310.89849675932766
I am very much in a hurry.”	489.8888640376141
Aramis held out his hand in a cordial manner to his young companion,	355.3593521867735
and took leave of him.	423.3487964742676
Notwithstanding all the pains he took, D’Artagnan was unable to learn	359.16880804940206
any more concerning his three new-made friends. He formed, therefore,	445.1132045493854
the resolution of believing for the present all that was said of their	410.72924204117726
past, hoping for more certain and extended revelations in the future.	342.213446608148
In the meanwhile, he looked upon Athos as an Achilles, Porthos as an	387.26390467370743
Ajax, and Aramis as a Joseph.	348.67811041839775
As to the rest, the life of the four young friends was joyous enough.	357.1119118393068
Athos played, and that as a rule unfortunately. Nevertheless, he never	484.81227627558246
borrowed a sou of his companions, although his purse was ever at their	405.7417415790111
service; and when he had played upon honor, he always awakened his	355.97395171211946
creditor by six o’clock the next morning to pay the debt of the	314.7641046257779
preceding evening.	433.69566137710024
Porthos had his fits. On the days when he won he was insolent and	484.4720651692244
ostentatious; if he lost, he disappeared completely for several days,	456.62507696348666
after which he reappeared with a pale face and thinner person, but with	358.61332689003774
money in his purse.	348.01799250092193
As to Aramis, he never played. He was the worst Musketeer and the most	476.3812632251853
unconvivial companion imaginable. He had always something or other to	363.4466038784665
do. Sometimes in the midst of dinner, when everyone, under the	328.80385330401253
attraction of wine and in the warmth of conversation, believed they had	467.7764636552648
two or three hours longer to enjoy themselves at table, Aramis looked	437.5128182648449
at his watch, arose with a bland smile, and took leave of the company,	459.3520778938331
to go, as he said, to consult a casuist with whom he had an	378.2411334292228
appointment. At other times he would return home to write a treatise,	385.4152386276389
and requested his friends not to disturb him.	422.40142099073205
At this Athos would smile, with his charming, melancholy smile, which	312.34376770816914
so became his noble countenance, and Porthos would drink, swearing that	316.0883378332061
Aramis would never be anything but a village _curé_.	460.4066979453247
Planchet, D’Artagnan’s valet, supported his good fortune nobly. He	437.1554518694982
received thirty sous per day, and for a month he returned to his	397.4212018041547
lodgings gay as a chaffinch, and affable toward his master. When the	475.6028020515935
wind of adversity began to blow upon the housekeeping of the Rue des	345.51933275859756
Fossoyeurs—that is to say, when the forty pistoles of King Louis XIII.	437.78966366519
were consumed or nearly so—he commenced complaints which Athos thought	396.8718462037368
nauseous, Porthos indecent, and Aramis ridiculous. Athos counseled	476.65242101559
D’Artagnan to dismiss the fellow; Porthos was of the opinion that he	373.39329810060553
should give him a good thrashing first; and Aramis contended that a	318.5000225116927
master should never attend to anything but the civilities paid to him.	451.73474015747087
“This is all very easy for you to say,” replied D’Artagnan, “for you,	301.0833402989759
Athos, who live like a dumb man with Grimaud, who forbid him to speak,	315.77896328676235
and consequently never exchange ill words with him; for you, Porthos,	421.8548884462623
who carry matters in such a magnificent style, and are a god to your	327.91337196796894
valet, Mousqueton; and for you, Aramis, who, always abstracted by your	326.1611518326769
theological studies, inspire your servant, Bazin, a mild, religious	450.8971159717803
man, with a profound respect; but for me, who am without any settled	359.55153281756884
means and without resources—for me, who am neither a Musketeer nor even	410.68196829109775
a Guardsman, what am I to do to inspire either the affection, the	303.55757601046895
terror, or the respect in Planchet?”	388.73290954926733
“This is serious,” answered the three friends; “it is a family affair.	342.0193781134831
It is with valets as with wives, they must be placed at once upon the	442.8538527071475
footing in which you wish them to remain. Reflect upon it.”	302.6279474981921
D’Artagnan did reflect, and resolved to thrash Planchet provisionally;	341.868466758097
which he did with the conscientiousness that D’Artagnan carried into	319.8317333158465
everything. After having well beaten him, he forbade him to leave his	430.1177590857328
service without his permission. “For,” added he, “the future cannot	411.96384046755827
fail to mend; I inevitably look for better times. Your fortune is	439.7116312927252
therefore made if you remain with me, and I am too good a master to	359.77071097969065
allow you to miss such a chance by granting you the dismissal you	303.0636691353861
require.”	463.52796681785514
This manner of acting roused much respect for D’Artagnan’s policy among	402.2064571717594
the Musketeers. Planchet was equally seized with admiration, and said	374.12669108654165
no more about going away.	436.93498039562303
The life of the four young men had become fraternal. D’Artagnan, who	309.6024718903072
had no settled habits of his own, as he came from his province into the	309.18545314957504
midst of a world quite new to him, fell easily into the habits of his	396.0769942074157
friends.	461.2820830524849
They rose about eight o’clock in the winter, about six in summer, and	397.8520952196125
went to take the countersign and see how things went on at M. de	402.8520935136364
Tréville’s. D’Artagnan, although he was not a Musketeer, performed the	381.6691056916967
duty of one with remarkable punctuality. He went on guard because he	424.1590490803285
always kept company with whoever of his friends was on duty. He was	487.68483250509644
well known at the Hôtel of the Musketeers, where everyone considered	311.14481345008096
him a good comrade. M. de Tréville, who had appreciated him at the	465.8044291829324
first glance and who bore him a real affection, never ceased	319.70613996465744
recommending him to the king.	459.8148688016386
On their side, the three Musketeers were much attached to their young	353.7446566795555
comrade. The friendship which united these four men, and the need they	326.9839829069124
felt of seeing another three or four times a day, whether for dueling,	412.08196336056193
business, or pleasure, caused them to be continually running after one	389.05712825468623
another like shadows; and the Inseparables were constantly to be met	406.14418072841454
with seeking one another, from the Luxembourg to the Place St. Sulpice,	375.18342198231267
or from the Rue du Vieux-Colombier to the Luxembourg.	423.82755869414746
In the meanwhile the promises of M. de Tréville went on prosperously.	301.3486481968089
One fine morning the king commanded M. de Chevalier Dessessart to admit	446.45090772148023
D’Artagnan as a cadet in his company of Guards. D’Artagnan, with a	482.83154845574677
sigh, donned his uniform, which he would have exchanged for that of a	371.3716438551754
Musketeer at the expense of ten years of his existence. But M. de	292.80473405044745
Tréville promised this favor after a novitiate of two years—a novitiate	386.17049510306254
which might besides be abridged if an opportunity should present itself	376.40958970352517
for D’Artagnan to render the king any signal service, or to distinguish	346.01556868441963
himself by some brilliant action. Upon this promise D’Artagnan	386.1055991742453
withdrew, and the next day he began service.	438.5121823416942
Then it became the turn of Athos, Porthos, and Aramis to mount guard	455.2667814945348
with D’Artagnan when he was on duty. The company of M. le Chevalier	379.7863714756371
Dessessart thus received four instead of one when it admitted	434.96502294833476
D’Artagnan.	436.1096327449953
Chapter VIII.	442.1540237749904
CONCERNING A COURT INTRIGUE	469.51899530542244
In the meantime, the forty pistoles of King Louis XIII., like all other	309.6096305579475
things of this world, after having had a beginning had an end, and	411.32531269180504
after this end our four companions began to be somewhat embarrassed. At	476.7481268883009
first, Athos supported the association for a time with his own means.	446.32152537041543
Porthos succeeded him; and thanks to one of those disappearances to	421.73932325792384
which he was accustomed, he was able to provide for the wants of all	365.13016654344653
for a fortnight. At last it became Aramis’s turn, who performed it with	447.8071385577583
a good grace and who succeeded—as he said, by selling some theological	322.9917057017488
books—in procuring a few pistoles.	480.5801774148813
Then, as they had been accustomed to do, they had recourse to M. de	347.4322666467676
Tréville, who made some advances on their pay; but these advances could	340.9980140152735
not go far with three Musketeers who were already much in arrears and a	357.7231563710725
Guardsman who as yet had no pay at all.	407.35208390977164
At length when they found they were likely to be really in want, they	413.7245870590631
got together, as a last effort, eight or ten pistoles, with which	471.03301600154225
Porthos went to the gaming table. Unfortunately he was in a bad vein;	401.91526525627626
he lost all, together with twenty-five pistoles for which he had given	299.20000952266764
his word.	373.75340467146907
Then the inconvenience became distress. The hungry friends, followed by	307.8841363558961
their lackeys, were seen haunting the quays and Guard rooms, picking up	475.7597928901258
among their friends abroad all the dinners they could meet with; for	368.2913683406079
according to the advice of Aramis, it was prudent to sow repasts right	443.39441980762035
and left in prosperity, in order to reap a few in time of need.	396.8577759407792
Athos was invited four times, and each time took his friends and their	471.83397670165687
lackeys with him. Porthos had six occasions, and contrived in the same	340.1144354388359
manner that his friends should partake of them; Aramis had eight of	345.9414902756008
them. He was a man, as must have been already perceived, who made but	474.1441930731837
little noise, and yet was much sought after.	415.19804738130404
As to D’Artagnan, who as yet knew nobody in the capital, he only found	409.8171441022339
one chocolate breakfast at the house of a priest of his own province,	444.9958077827113
and one dinner at the house of a cornet of the Guards. He took his army	344.9726414117641
to the priest’s, where they devoured as much provision as would have	298.44494238983543
lasted him for two months, and to the cornet’s, who performed wonders;	301.35748016809225
but as Planchet said, “People do not eat at once for all time, even	436.5346347254954
when they eat a good deal.”	317.99218550574295
D’Artagnan thus felt himself humiliated in having only procured one	458.9709022668824
meal and a half for his companions—as the breakfast at the priest’s	459.7335140851866
could only be counted as half a repast—in return for the feasts which	366.2067142611328
Athos, Porthos, and Aramis had procured him. He fancied himself a	375.1445569898479
burden to the society, forgetting in his perfectly juvenile good faith	322.25519489342946
that he had fed this society for a month; and he set his mind actively	384.6960400383525
to work. He reflected that this coalition of four young, brave,	447.2653583339787
enterprising, and active men ought to have some other object than	445.64765534745277
swaggering walks, fencing lessons, and practical jokes, more or less	383.2689561435154
witty.	380.57418573668167
In fact, four men such as they were—four men devoted to one another,	323.26154259564396
from their purses to their lives; four men always supporting one	470.36743407759553
another, never yielding, executing singly or together the resolutions	319.41235071109276
formed in common; four arms threatening the four cardinal points, or	415.98136183817195
turning toward a single point—must inevitably, either subterraneously,	321.8759233723886
in open day, by mining, in the trench, by cunning, or by force, open	398.06381418834985
themselves a way toward the object they wished to attain, however well	481.82312235417226
it might be defended, or however distant it may seem. The only thing	431.33528482873226
that astonished D’Artagnan was that his friends had never thought of	391.4552041132522
this.	303.33650451279254
He was thinking by himself, and even seriously racking his brain to	418.1762135636019
find a direction for this single force four times multiplied, with	313.56051017642307
which he did not doubt, as with the lever for which Archimedes sought,	366.2952419162102
they should succeed in moving the world, when someone tapped gently at	457.3595399164741
his door. D’Artagnan awakened Planchet and ordered him to open it.	364.8282955527258
From this phrase, “D’Artagnan awakened Planchet,” the reader must not	435.4182184128256
suppose it was night, or that day was hardly come. No, it had just	470.7502675077647
struck four. Planchet, two hours before, had asked his master for some	315.95157844981986
dinner, and he had answered him with the proverb, “He who sleeps,	491.17299458412833
dines.” And Planchet dined by sleeping.	385.8339024425263
A man was introduced of simple mien, who had the appearance of a	472.4100464204363
tradesman. Planchet, by way of dessert, would have liked to hear the	368.77196099611797
conversation; but the citizen declared to D’Artagnan that, what he had	333.48012003666065
to say being important and confidential, he desired to be left alone	440.2741214403769
with him.	477.8265883913717
D’Artagnan dismissed Planchet, and requested his visitor to be seated.	368.01319500184866
There was a moment of silence, during which the two men looked at each	325.93276516955365
other, as if to make a preliminary acquaintance, after which D’Artagnan	292.88899396280976
bowed, as a sign that he listened.	451.9840557928308
“I have heard Monsieur d’Artagnan spoken of as a very brave young man,”	353.68013553540766
said the citizen; “and this reputation which he justly enjoys had	381.9168400466466
decided me to confide a secret to him.”	487.78564860128364
“Speak, monsieur, speak,” said D’Artagnan, who instinctively scented	340.08059532191527
something advantageous.	340.038497560505
The citizen made a fresh pause and continued, “I have a wife who is	362.21810278950494
seamstress to the queen, monsieur, and who is not deficient in either	349.6924523856047
virtue or beauty. I was induced to marry her about three years ago,	329.5411101509382
although she had but very little dowry, because Monsieur Laporte, the	392.49594002205527
queen’s cloak bearer, is her godfather, and befriends her.”	383.27517300650334
“Well, monsieur?” asked D’Artagnan.	328.2621778338394
“Well!” resumed the citizen, “well, monsieur, my wife was abducted	350.13373944053893
yesterday morning, as she was coming out of her workroom.”	399.56324209365306
“And by whom was your wife abducted?”	478.260567778506
“I know nothing surely, monsieur, but I suspect someone.”	404.3193307201691
“And who is the person whom you suspect?”	392.6109564847843
“A man who has pursued her a long time.”	482.32864662303575
“The devil!”	448.21174692939337
“But allow me to tell you, monsieur,” continued the citizen, “that I am	383.0798391186936
convinced that there is less love than politics in all this.”	348.57734075316336
“Less love than politics,” replied D’Artagnan, with a reflective air;	461.82899736453453
“and what do you suspect?”	482.007257275503
“I do not know whether I ought to tell you what I suspect.”	469.41856033302616
“Monsieur, I beg you to observe that I ask you absolutely nothing. It	365.6635977118173
is you who have come to me. It is you who have told me that you had a	410.8769992868599
secret to confide in me. Act, then, as you think proper; there is still	425.00183476740153
time to withdraw.”	295.41041586395056
“No, monsieur, no; you appear to be an honest young man, and I will	296.9983500919599
have confidence in you. I believe, then, that it is not on account of	466.45446903139225
any intrigues of her own that my wife has been arrested, but because of	358.541081142958
those of a lady much greater than herself.”	305.49335093734857
“Ah, ah! Can it be on account of the amours of Madame de Bois-Tracy?”	350.935430388437
said D’Artagnan, wishing to have the air, in the eyes of the citizen,	483.496287877486
of being posted as to court affairs.	307.03375212970377
“Higher, monsieur, higher.”	411.70431680305717
“Of Madame d’Aiguillon?”	401.29225163608237
“Still higher.”	464.80865322347074
“Of Madame de Chevreuse?”	328.3361973376214
“Higher, much higher.”	397.7014680683749
“Of the—” D’Artagnan checked himself.	436.802037181363
“Yes, monsieur,” replied the terrified citizen, in a tone so low that	322.8653836982677
he was scarcely audible.	315.7869483268946
“And with whom?”	394.34909071752804
“With whom can it be, if not the Duke of—”	311.9922546159294
“The Duke of—”	326.91771505919917
“Yes, monsieur,” replied the citizen, giving a still fainter intonation	381.4450282325213
to his voice.	383.9924261624626
“But how do you know all this?”	463.36811405839177
“How do I know it?”	394.25120921934774
“Yes, how do you know it? No half-confidence, or—you understand!”	380.5129626323938
“I know it from my wife, monsieur—from my wife herself.”	430.2421563870065
“Who learns it from whom?”	339.08959599628724
“From Monsieur Laporte. Did I not tell you that she was the goddaughter	379.6622873866395
of Monsieur Laporte, the confidential man of the queen? Well, Monsieur	322.5785743159103
Laporte placed her near her Majesty in order that our poor queen might	482.61482136761913
at least have someone in whom she could place confidence, abandoned as	488.690388344431
she is by the king, watched as she is by the cardinal, betrayed as she	338.0103321448598
is by everybody.”	399.1320230619647
“Ah, ah! It begins to develop itself,” said D’Artagnan.	301.90996730937877
“Now, my wife came home four days ago, monsieur. One of her conditions	410.1975489391335
was that she should come and see me twice a week; for, as I had the	456.35325454873686
honor to tell you, my wife loves me dearly—my wife, then, came and	404.4650591631241
confided to me that the queen at that very moment entertained great	384.59904230003053
fears.”	309.2503585804395
“Truly!”	392.5442070104944
“Yes. The cardinal, as it appears, pursues her and persecutes her more	348.4030361949593
than ever. He cannot pardon her the history of the Saraband. You know	406.31977607605904
the history of the Saraband?”	445.8794132718825
“_Pardieu!_ Know it!” replied D’Artagnan, who knew nothing about it,	351.961884536219
but who wished to appear to know everything that was going on.	394.78477573527533
“So that now it is no longer hatred, but vengeance.”	390.4136560988905
“Indeed!”	479.28512792884084
“And the queen believes—”	471.5446064068316
“Well, what does the queen believe?”	354.470985658234
“She believes that someone has written to the Duke of Buckingham in her	403.24315255529865
name.”	478.404768632593
“In the queen’s name?”	473.5245337652568
“Yes, to make him come to Paris; and when once come to Paris, to draw	398.75705702816964
him into some snare.”	327.0198937678833
“The devil! But your wife, monsieur, what has she to do with all this?”	406.7572271235794
“Her devotion to the queen is known; and they wish either to remove her	412.6616177366898
from her mistress, or to intimidate her, in order to obtain her	480.8237618307138
Majesty’s secrets, or to seduce her and make use of her as a spy.”	430.71774947533316
“That is likely,” said D’Artagnan; “but the man who has abducted her—do	402.15898483931596
you know him?”	399.4731363205917
“I have told you that I believe I know him.”	479.61298729537396
“His name?”	405.53239520233365
“I do not know that; what I do know is that he is a creature of the	323.3120196403126
cardinal, his evil genius.”	419.8247057231697
“But you have seen him?”	483.4925976378454
“Yes, my wife pointed him out to me one day.”	341.4583623539485
“Has he anything remarkable about him by which one may recognize him?”	469.7399366060194
“Oh, certainly; he is a noble of very lofty carriage, black hair,	460.1636974434225
swarthy complexion, piercing eye, white teeth, and has a scar on his	477.90876537038343
temple.”	401.066167402213
“A scar on his temple!” cried D’Artagnan; “and with that, white teeth,	392.8090363066724
a piercing eye, dark complexion, black hair, and haughty carriage—why,	344.48712504716315
that’s my man of Meung.”	445.4991161536392
“He is your man, do you say?”	379.08403361282933
“Yes, yes; but that has nothing to do with it. No, I am wrong. On the	428.4294867828977
contrary, that simplifies the matter greatly. If your man is mine, with	430.9991257191217
one blow I shall obtain two revenges, that’s all; but where to find	460.77837508982446
this man?”	397.88649679749085
“I know not.”	397.47558884768745
“Have you no information as to his abiding place?”	484.42505691868337
“None. One day, as I was conveying my wife back to the Louvre, he was	297.0463623613515
coming out as she was going in, and she showed him to me.”	377.06268952193324
“The devil! The devil!” murmured D’Artagnan; “all this is vague enough.	455.78318997808213
From whom have you learned of the abduction of your wife?”	439.62241957748824
“From Monsieur Laporte.”	379.21559325389705
“Did he give you any details?”	328.4432478394249
“He knew none himself.”	490.97742309914435
“And you have learned nothing from any other quarter?”	332.2038157703529
“Yes, I have received—”	482.4866935227197
“What?”	319.4163555283485
“I fear I am committing a great imprudence.”	458.76884965629495
“You always come back to that; but I must make you see this time that	473.0699642514667
it is too late to retreat.”	421.394380521102
“I do not retreat, _mordieu!_” cried the citizen, swearing in order to	403.6171059769879
rouse his courage. “Besides, by the faith of Bonacieux—”	394.175305208164
“You call yourself Bonacieux?” interrupted D’Artagnan.	426.7205823848633
“Yes, that is my name.”	462.74958549157736
“You said, then, by the word of Bonacieux. Pardon me for interrupting	298.9623945973592
you, but it appears to me that that name is familiar to me.”	479.07027026076526
“Possibly, monsieur. I am your landlord.”	293.4574935950764
“Ah, ah!” said D’Artagnan, half rising and bowing; “you are my	465.30802005436715
landlord?”	312.13709351352236
“Yes, monsieur, yes. And as it is three months since you have been	313.6953270092578
here, and though, distracted as you must be in your important	369.5054719496312
occupations, you have forgotten to pay me my rent—as, I say, I have not	325.1612866191876
tormented you a single instant, I thought you would appreciate my	457.8917117680153
delicacy.”	391.57566440054404
“How can it be otherwise, my dear Bonacieux?” replied D’Artagnan;	392.7265108372201
“trust me, I am fully grateful for such unparalleled conduct, and if,	461.06079967383675
as I told you, I can be of any service to you—”	453.6218853900235
“I believe you, monsieur, I believe you; and as I was about to say, by	434.2880191144677
the word of Bonacieux, I have confidence in you.”	476.3820400170707
“Finish, then, what you were about to say.”	382.4473326307833
The citizen took a paper from his pocket, and presented it to	328.5350248865223
D’Artagnan.	315.39028054132393
“A letter?” said the young man.	312.86261394895
“Which I received this morning.”	415.44554450335477
D’Artagnan opened it, and as the day was beginning to decline, he	394.2342460124183
approached the window to read it. The citizen followed him.	403.63696052751345
“‘Do not seek your wife,’” read D’Artagnan; “‘she will be restored to	463.41920191081863
you when there is no longer occasion for her. If you make a single step	388.1902124802417
to find her you are lost.’	298.88826335245943
“That’s pretty positive,” continued D’Artagnan; “but after all, it is	445.6960055535913
but a menace.”	335.6382932262958
“Yes; but that menace terrifies me. I am not a fighting man at all,	451.0366920737003
monsieur, and I am afraid of the Bastille.”	459.00807786667195
“Hum!” said D’Artagnan. “I have no greater regard for the Bastille than	305.06313274017117
you. If it were nothing but a sword thrust, why then—”	376.670960022083
“I have counted upon you on this occasion, monsieur.”	473.6134601408387
“Yes?”	418.04979819180835
“Seeing you constantly surrounded by Musketeers of a very superb	410.5850825919744
appearance, and knowing that these Musketeers belong to Monsieur de	452.937878058832
Tréville, and were consequently enemies of the cardinal, I thought that	416.17823747299263
you and your friends, while rendering justice to your poor queen, would	432.41413879778514
be pleased to play his Eminence an ill turn.”	452.81313278145217
“Without doubt.”	428.93807595639134
“And then I have thought that considering three months’ lodging, about	408.36043622028393
which I have said nothing—”	447.0053329960177
“Yes, yes; you have already given me that reason, and I find it	433.1338706767691
excellent.”	322.74862352123694
“Reckoning still further, that as long as you do me the honor to remain	393.9383386430252
in my house I shall never speak to you about rent—”	335.9813249294301
“Very kind!”	454.5768300321309
“And adding to this, if there be need of it, meaning to offer you fifty	351.9805237828504
pistoles, if, against all probability, you should be short at the	448.154715388617
present moment.”	332.5405415040713
“Admirable! You are rich then, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux?”	320.14541341843267
“I am comfortably off, monsieur, that’s all; I have scraped together	422.41560284157856
some such things as an income of two or three thousand crowns in the	356.92911613834224
haberdashery business, but more particularly in venturing some funds in	310.3720442663114
the last voyage of the celebrated navigator Jean Moquet; so that you	480.37443050796776
understand, monsieur—But!—” cried the citizen.	442.81698602754534
“What!” demanded D’Artagnan.	438.02546578037504
“Whom do I see yonder?”	343.3686101755532
“Where?”	295.6184193579385
“In the street, facing your window, in the embrasure of that door—a man	400.8995548761876
wrapped in a cloak.”	307.85842111676527
“It is he!” cried D’Artagnan and the citizen at the same time, each	328.9599059418966
having recognized his man.	348.93596446060985
“Ah, this time,” cried D’Artagnan, springing to his sword, “this time	430.1315087412014
he will not escape me!”	451.9097773882128
Drawing his sword from its scabbard, he rushed out of the apartment. On	433.20048739601293
the staircase he met Athos and Porthos, who were coming to see him.	304.3407687075678
They separated, and D’Artagnan rushed between them like a dart.	370.8567954018134
“Pah! Where are you going?” cried the two Musketeers in a breath.	382.1444552921705
“The man of Meung!” replied D’Artagnan, and disappeared.	438.02589589847173
D’Artagnan had more than once related to his friends his adventure with	478.8879696215972
the stranger, as well as the apparition of the beautiful foreigner, to	485.28346234988027
whom this man had confided some important missive.	440.19122373886677
The opinion of Athos was that D’Artagnan had lost his letter in the	433.8040461114029
skirmish. A gentleman, in his opinion—and according to D’Artagnan’s	468.9651517586367
portrait of him, the stranger must be a gentleman—would be incapable of	424.85720545112355
the baseness of stealing a letter.	475.4901407906517
Porthos saw nothing in all this but a love meeting, given by a lady to	478.50879676778936
a cavalier, or by a cavalier to a lady, which had been disturbed by the	327.461953688903
presence of D’Artagnan and his yellow horse.	471.4802783988624
Aramis said that as these sorts of affairs were mysterious, it was	448.5476606984687
better not to fathom them.	371.13635610681393
They understood, then, from the few words which escaped from	460.24551432729163
D’Artagnan, what affair was in hand, and as they thought that	374.89175912273464
overtaking his man, or losing sight of him, D’Artagnan would return to	362.7425008019946
his rooms, they kept on their way.	400.7452507298076
When they entered D’Artagnan’s chamber, it was empty; the landlord,	398.1649615208131
dreading the consequences of the encounter which was doubtless about to	313.8917576574278
take place between the young man and the stranger, had, consistent with	356.0806343440431
the character he had given himself, judged it prudent to decamp.	328.6418774368038
Chapter IX.	456.44292800974324
D’ARTAGNAN SHOWS HIMSELF	364.31849605616003
As Athos and Porthos had foreseen, at the expiration of a half hour,	316.6229693511151
D’Artagnan returned. He had again missed his man, who had disappeared	409.1371475292408
as if by enchantment. D’Artagnan had run, sword in hand, through all	337.7491915592522
the neighboring streets, but had found nobody resembling the man he	424.6025307894177
sought for. Then he came back to the point where, perhaps, he ought to	400.17595550460516
have begun, and that was to knock at the door against which the	436.5296056556262
stranger had leaned; but this proved useless—for though he knocked ten	319.43418921904225
or twelve times in succession, no one answered, and some of the	299.81060417631835
neighbors, who put their noses out of their windows or were brought to	333.9776129679994
their doors by the noise, had assured him that that house, all the	355.3717709686124
openings of which were tightly closed, had not been inhabited for six	321.38522132656294
months.	340.9876473324965
While D’Artagnan was running through the streets and knocking at doors,	479.90692604956234
Aramis had joined his companions; so that on returning home D’Artagnan	435.7018719516793
found the reunion complete.	369.40639124943885
“Well!” cried the three Musketeers all together, on seeing D’Artagnan	472.05235381632065
enter with his brow covered with perspiration and his countenance upset	446.6181761514154
with anger.	312.2388435389918
“Well!” cried he, throwing his sword upon the bed, “this man must be	327.38732808909026
the devil in person; he has disappeared like a phantom, like a shade,	302.8330641902268
like a specter.”	482.77883756600244
“Do you believe in apparitions?” asked Athos of Porthos.	417.4731048531041
“I never believe in anything I have not seen, and as I never have seen	452.13408819679694
apparitions, I don’t believe in them.”	431.7316977540558
“The Bible,” said Aramis, “makes our belief in them a law; the ghost of	423.89294404751183
Samuel appeared to Saul, and it is an article of faith that I should be	363.65534652165127
very sorry to see any doubt thrown upon, Porthos.”	453.142759049334
“At all events, man or devil, body or shadow, illusion or reality, this	459.966453564537
man is born for my damnation; for his flight has caused us to miss a	337.5227614142914
glorious affair, gentlemen—an affair by which there were a hundred	352.0862989257176
pistoles, and perhaps more, to be gained.”	394.5878723225692
“How is that?” cried Porthos and Aramis in a breath.	392.85808621342625
As to Athos, faithful to his system of reticence, he contented himself	456.9142977665549
with interrogating D’Artagnan by a look.	299.6504218165137
“Planchet,” said D’Artagnan to his domestic, who just then insinuated	346.5029293990993
his head through the half-open door in order to catch some fragments of	445.9878166499892
the conversation, “go down to my landlord, Monsieur Bonacieux, and ask	479.99397787852354
him to send me half a dozen bottles of Beaugency wine; I prefer that.”	421.53868766043286
“Ah, ah! You have credit with your landlord, then?” asked Porthos.	443.8274422813678
“Yes,” replied D’Artagnan, “from this very day; and mind, if the wine	448.66622688773907
is bad, we will send him to find better.”	350.82373143845365
“We must use, and not abuse,” said Aramis, sententiously.	440.8516525879305
“I always said that D’Artagnan had the longest head of the four,” said	463.1075508728178
Athos, who, having uttered his opinion, to which D’Artagnan replied	349.9888051647512
with a bow, immediately resumed his accustomed silence.	390.6446494920926
“But come, what is this about?” asked Porthos.	307.81995990723107
“Yes,” said Aramis, “impart it to us, my dear friend, unless the honor	344.29717255501885
of any lady be hazarded by this confidence; in that case you would do	320.58399261135554
better to keep it to yourself.”	402.23198462070155
“Be satisfied,” replied D’Artagnan; “the honor of no one will have	445.4022178770689
cause to complain of what I have to tell.”	456.68632085485035
He then related to his friends, word for word, all that had passed	325.2497431713071
between him and his host, and how the man who had abducted the wife of	416.2216280263226
his worthy landlord was the same with whom he had had the difference at	312.1089018138834
the hostelry of the Jolly Miller.	475.3605171618574
“Your affair is not bad,” said Athos, after having tasted like a	379.08297623703027
connoisseur and indicated by a nod of his head that he thought the wine	422.55440207751565
good; “and one may draw fifty or sixty pistoles from this good man.	415.3492482242191
Then there only remains to ascertain whether these fifty or sixty	405.43636972548035
pistoles are worth the risk of four heads.”	330.64558869545283
“But observe,” cried D’Artagnan, “that there is a woman in the affair—a	392.61505619489424
woman carried off, a woman who is doubtless threatened, tortured	461.97799103077625
perhaps, and all because she is faithful to her mistress.”	471.0498435336866
“Beware, D’Artagnan, beware,” said Aramis. “You grow a little too warm,	428.5218961985328
in my opinion, about the fate of Madame Bonacieux. Woman was created	453.2900874655048
for our destruction, and it is from her we inherit all our miseries.”	361.3765375764964
At this speech of Aramis, the brow of Athos became clouded and he bit	321.72849036526776
his lips.	389.93620149639173
“It is not Madame Bonacieux about whom I am anxious,” cried D’Artagnan,	351.7466910740688
“but the queen, whom the king abandons, whom the cardinal persecutes,	446.5968924361905
and who sees the heads of all her friends fall, one after the other.”	390.0958234677796
“Why does she love what we hate most in the world, the Spaniards and	405.087817814684
the English?”	400.11072611595836
“Spain is her country,” replied D’Artagnan; “and it is very natural	373.91173407425305
that she should love the Spanish, who are the children of the same soil	482.884179447874
as herself. As to the second reproach, I have heard it said that she	294.789697806236
does not love the English, but an Englishman.”	479.78906675867916
“Well, and by my faith,” said Athos, “it must be acknowledged that this	488.9909512695976
Englishman is worthy of being loved. I never saw a man with a nobler	437.49917856314903
air than his.”	416.9070421653354
“Without reckoning that he dresses as nobody else can,” said Porthos.	325.30188441244513
“I was at the Louvre on the day when he scattered his pearls; and,	426.3491652313232
_pardieu_, I picked up two that I sold for ten pistoles each. Do you	308.03037807699644
know him, Aramis?”	300.99572196723346
“As well as you do, gentlemen; for I was among those who seized him in	375.1330743498731
the garden at Amiens, into which Monsieur Putange, the queen’s equerry,	365.89304975632797
introduced me. I was at school at the time, and the adventure appeared	317.7549205187824
to me to be cruel for the king.”	430.01028820131484
“Which would not prevent me,” said D’Artagnan, “if I knew where the	370.570247773148
Duke of Buckingham was, from taking him by the hand and conducting him	472.8989257504411
to the queen, were it only to enrage the cardinal, and if we could find	437.43484211552146
means to play him a sharp turn, I vow that I would voluntarily risk my	306.3398434246628
head in doing it.”	406.2523197236518
“And did the mercer*,” rejoined Athos, “tell you, D’Artagnan, that the	343.7056682102751
queen thought that Buckingham had been brought over by a forged	451.9287435545067
letter?”	409.2642101851291
* Haberdasher	415.49242671091923
“She is afraid so.”	399.80638773892707
“Wait a minute, then,” said Aramis.	414.9414997874479
“What for?” demanded Porthos.	393.5582743166449
“Go on, while I endeavor to recall circumstances.”	436.8378081083871
“And now I am convinced,” said D’Artagnan, “that this abduction of the	312.3232287212203
queen’s woman is connected with the events of which we are speaking,	320.1351491323219
and perhaps with the presence of Buckingham in Paris.”	480.02735514887854
“The Gascon is full of ideas,” said Porthos, with admiration.	481.85275453569943
“I like to hear him talk,” said Athos; “his dialect amuses me.”	401.4228309155026
“Gentlemen,” cried Aramis, “listen to this.”	408.14133672726683
“Listen to Aramis,” said his three friends.	467.4462443750265
“Yesterday I was at the house of a doctor of theology, whom I sometimes	449.04116678039816
consult about my studies.”	417.39035503407626
Athos smiled.	424.77176046278527
“He resides in a quiet quarter,” continued Aramis; “his tastes and his	317.3544334141205
profession require it. Now, at the moment when I left his house—”	490.8811346130538
Here Aramis paused.	366.9317774847333
“Well,” cried his auditors; “at the moment you left his house?”	306.8424869690627
Aramis appeared to make a strong inward effort, like a man who, in the	408.96455811673934
full relation of a falsehood, finds himself stopped by some unforeseen	425.48792733199895
obstacle; but the eyes of his three companions were fixed upon him,	345.0976485011075
their ears were wide open, and there were no means of retreat.	310.6324296234169
“This doctor has a niece,” continued Aramis.	471.8100892934591
“Ah, he has a niece!” interrupted Porthos.	415.08663818561
“A very respectable lady,” said Aramis.	418.1451690465824
The three friends burst into laughter.	354.1522464320329
“Ah, if you laugh, if you doubt me,” replied Aramis, “you shall know	422.3746651685003
nothing.”	455.2329460286827
“We believe like Mohammedans, and are as mute as tombstones,” said	451.4607855762822
Athos.	447.3503588153155
“I will continue, then,” resumed Aramis. “This niece comes sometimes to	411.87617821343855
see her uncle; and by chance was there yesterday at the same time that	376.03740595479826
I was, and it was my duty to offer to conduct her to her carriage.”	303.9838661854074
“Ah! She has a carriage, then, this niece of the doctor?” interrupted	401.7881539200358
Porthos, one of whose faults was a great looseness of tongue. “A nice	351.6416622620255
acquaintance, my friend!”	468.9005649360696
“Porthos,” replied Aramis, “I have had the occasion to observe to you	342.0030823030118
more than once that you are very indiscreet; and that is injurious to	343.3638289782553
you among the women.”	435.2933784826008
“Gentlemen, gentlemen,” cried D’Artagnan, who began to get a glimpse of	304.2266300137797
the result of the adventure, “the thing is serious. Let us try not to	462.58741334941067
jest, if we can. Go on Aramis, go on.”	323.58235299568634
“All at once, a tall, dark gentleman—just like yours, D’Artagnan.”	316.853221165743
“The same, perhaps,” said he.	423.0190376849928
“Possibly,” continued Aramis, “came toward me, accompanied by five or	486.62682490527635
six men who followed about ten paces behind him; and in the politest	406.12946718536926
tone, ‘Monsieur Duke,’ said he to me, ‘and you madame,’ continued he,	450.54541762640514
addressing the lady on my arm—”	315.9749543424169
“The doctor’s niece?”	457.7166904972042
“Hold your tongue, Porthos,” said Athos; “you are insupportable.”	384.00025433964913
“‘—will you enter this carriage, and that without offering the least	322.93174633982346
resistance, without making the least noise?’”	331.0610875985418
“He took you for Buckingham!” cried D’Artagnan.	421.8873666963841
“I believe so,” replied Aramis.	360.7298385146966
“But the lady?” asked Porthos.	482.56750255380643
“He took her for the queen!” said D’Artagnan.	456.4239668203637
“Just so,” replied Aramis.	451.74236463533146
“The Gascon is the devil!” cried Athos; “nothing escapes him.”	353.242386552607
“The fact is,” said Porthos, “Aramis is of the same height, and	413.32322073212833
something of the shape of the duke; but it nevertheless appears to me	338.0368647525048
that the dress of a Musketeer—”	316.2456217352672
“I wore an enormous cloak,” said Aramis.	350.20538090741445
“In the month of July? The devil!” said Porthos. “Is the doctor afraid	405.351537308479
that you may be recognized?”	297.56234819463043
“I can comprehend that the spy may have been deceived by the person;	323.44726444972997
but the face—”	402.96007756614983
“I had a large hat,” said Aramis.	375.323376578913
“Oh, good lord,” cried Porthos, “what precautions for the study of	397.472070025147
theology!”	319.16750268757045
“Gentlemen, gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, “do not let us lose our time	437.2708967628871
in jesting. Let us separate, and let us seek the mercer’s wife—that is	348.0634885338836
the key of the intrigue.”	447.9790151176335
“A woman of such inferior condition! Can you believe so?” said Porthos,	372.8571103687684
protruding his lips with contempt.	480.36530006732335
“She is goddaughter to Laporte, the confidential valet of the queen.	478.74249906162584
Have I not told you so, gentlemen? Besides, it has perhaps been her	441.56545967935267
Majesty’s calculation to seek on this occasion for support so lowly.	330.97704242072496
High heads expose themselves from afar, and the cardinal is	358.44292417290285
longsighted.”	353.03090015231624
“Well,” said Porthos, “in the first place make a bargain with the	296.40026362998213
mercer, and a good bargain.”	322.01273346005934
“That’s useless,” said D’Artagnan; “for I believe if he does not pay	410.32183934081115
us, we shall be well enough paid by another party.”	370.97152988699037
At this moment a sudden noise of footsteps was heard upon the stairs;	426.89733243392857
the door was thrown violently open, and the unfortunate mercer rushed	352.6425279871345
into the chamber in which the council was held.	348.05656778209374
“Save me, gentlemen, for the love of heaven, save me!” cried he. “There	420.6218643760704
are four men come to arrest me. Save me! Save me!”	461.02323786119086
Porthos and Aramis arose.	426.08567442973816
“A moment,” cried D’Artagnan, making them a sign to replace in the	487.1976776144723
scabbard their half-drawn swords. “It is not courage that is needed; it	342.3222366069849
is prudence.”	300.1263661864298
“And yet,” cried Porthos, “we will not leave—”	306.2899123366413
“You will leave D’Artagnan to act as he thinks proper,” said Athos. “He	423.78592238047725
has, I repeat, the longest head of the four, and for my part I declare	295.005521695369
that I will obey him. Do as you think best, D’Artagnan.”	347.44076636385154
At this moment the four Guards appeared at the door of the antechamber,	316.3394278606776
but seeing four Musketeers standing, and their swords by their sides,	333.89303578840935
they hesitated about going farther.	314.9146213477036
“Come in, gentlemen, come in,” called D’Artagnan; “you are here in my	407.0003736822823
apartment, and we are all faithful servants of the king and cardinal.”	397.43467489412166
“Then, gentlemen, you will not oppose our executing the orders we have	407.841712985079
received?” asked one who appeared to be the leader of the party.	381.6975012495625
“On the contrary, gentlemen, we would assist you if it were necessary.”	348.4878530360933
“What does he say?” grumbled Porthos.	303.88660027991824
“You are a simpleton,” said Athos. “Silence!”	301.9229081132757
“But you promised me—” whispered the poor mercer.	386.0964453965538
“We can only save you by being free ourselves,” replied D’Artagnan, in	348.8662057709932
a rapid, low tone; “and if we appear inclined to defend you, they will	357.812283153525
arrest us with you.”	386.9852768605317
“It seems, nevertheless—”	378.37422818538687
“Come, gentlemen, come!” said D’Artagnan, aloud; “I have no motive for	414.84644563654035
defending Monsieur. I saw him today for the first time, and he can tell	364.6116944166713
you on what occasion; he came to demand the rent of my lodging. Is that	394.38182557011623
not true, Monsieur Bonacieux? Answer!”	331.0636542166017
“That is the very truth,” cried the mercer; “but Monsieur does not tell	336.5068151384543
you—”	358.1979720997378
“Silence, with respect to me, silence, with respect to my friends;	434.8103152861898
silence about the queen, above all, or you will ruin everybody without	336.88574359512086
saving yourself! Come, come, gentlemen, remove the fellow.” And	314.92528078881696
D’Artagnan pushed the half-stupefied mercer among the Guards, saying to	398.6165220985754
him, “You are a shabby old fellow, my dear. You come to demand money of	416.3662865382961
me—of a Musketeer! To prison with him! Gentlemen, once more, take him	465.4213568145159
to prison, and keep him under key as long as possible; that will give	485.4398141840079
me time to pay him.”	489.92886544707244
The officers were full of thanks, and took away their prey. As they	441.75377110332164
were going down D’Artagnan laid his hand on the shoulder of their	304.94107772046556
leader.	453.34838714228556
“May I not drink to your health, and you to mine?” said D’Artagnan,	382.6294997924441
filling two glasses with the Beaugency wine which he had obtained from	338.1752420942453
the liberality of M. Bonacieux.	465.65113667711955
“That will do me great honor,” said the leader of the posse, “and I	344.8338787123749
accept thankfully.”	491.44481123092453
“Then to yours, monsieur—what is your name?”	412.5596709831974
“Boisrenard.”	420.59997777952725
“Monsieur Boisrenard.”	342.13866415950787
“To yours, my gentlemen! What is your name, in your turn, if you	417.69107173808845
please?”	478.2911939359569
“D’Artagnan.”	361.6943839423995
“To yours, monsieur.”	428.4690374947196
“And above all others,” cried D’Artagnan, as if carried away by his	451.44016798805774
enthusiasm, “to that of the king and the cardinal.”	450.09272135582114
The leader of the posse would perhaps have doubted the sincerity of	490.6047795027606
D’Artagnan if the wine had been bad; but the wine was good, and he was	336.6724789841653
convinced.	366.23078764878125
“What diabolical villainy you have performed here,” said Porthos, when	317.3010828781355
the officer had rejoined his companions and the four friends found	454.4977742780364
themselves alone. “Shame, shame, for four Musketeers to allow an	305.1435766913541
unfortunate fellow who cried for help to be arrested in their midst!	370.7194695362912
And a gentleman to hobnob with a bailiff!”	315.4150778142398
“Porthos,” said Aramis, “Athos has already told you that you are a	424.72208483236795
simpleton, and I am quite of his opinion. D’Artagnan, you are a great	358.49898325535105
man; and when you occupy Monsieur de Tréville’s place, I will come and	382.09234622176837
ask your influence to secure me an abbey.”	331.18608074266024
“Well, I am in a maze,” said Porthos; “do _you_ approve of what	369.38986147194674
D’Artagnan has done?”	304.8256113619179
“_Parbleu!_ Indeed I do,” said Athos; “I not only approve of what he	439.27295509912125
has done, but I congratulate him upon it.”	385.3878785843888
“And now, gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, without stopping to explain his	344.903770598834
conduct to Porthos, “All for one, one for all—that is our motto, is it	362.8678807118106
not?”	420.60556776500437
“And yet—” said Porthos.	337.2040240078661
“Hold out your hand and swear!” cried Athos and Aramis at once.	453.8308495461706
Overcome by example, grumbling to himself, nevertheless, Porthos	333.34971223678514
stretched out his hand, and the four friends repeated with one voice	376.67967707845617
the formula dictated by D’Artagnan:	489.4296864523525
“All for one, one for all.”	381.95572383627143
“That’s well! Now let us everyone retire to his own home,” said	487.45955554236036
D’Artagnan, as if he had done nothing but command all his life; “and	360.2559216747194
attention! For from this moment we are at feud with the cardinal.”	323.71126969979525
Chapter X.	422.8163046384867
A MOUSETRAP IN THE SEVENTEENTH CENTURY	377.6000043324111
The invention of the mousetrap does not date from our days; as soon as	295.9000425960102
societies, in forming, had invented any kind of police, that police	404.22815128318126
invented mousetraps.	341.2269307520968
As perhaps our readers are not familiar with the slang of the Rue de	468.7043911638815
Jerusalem, and as it is fifteen years since we applied this word for	337.6887726838208
the first time to this thing, allow us to explain to them what is a	458.444807170951
mousetrap.	420.9175557337308
When in a house, of whatever kind it may be, an individual suspected of	489.85333104977985
any crime is arrested, the arrest is held secret. Four or five men are	480.8735872643105
placed in ambuscade in the first room. The door is opened to all who	428.12237206334146
knock. It is closed after them, and they are arrested; so that at the	361.8037199832069
end of two or three days they have in their power almost all the	373.577189205146
_habitués_ of the establishment. And that is a mousetrap.	339.6185888348854
The apartment of M. Bonacieux, then, became a mousetrap; and whoever	335.9354361679752
appeared there was taken and interrogated by the cardinal’s people. It	311.0851982486136
must be observed that as a separate passage led to the first floor, in	369.8067913715943
which D’Artagnan lodged, those who called on him were exempted from	458.62757558645285
this detention.	364.5965634699872
Besides, nobody came thither but the three Musketeers; they had all	360.93338488161254
been engaged in earnest search and inquiries, but had discovered	396.6204962454788
nothing. Athos had even gone so far as to question M. de Tréville—a	444.1397896088365
thing which, considering the habitual reticence of the worthy	472.3489927511058
Musketeer, had very much astonished his captain. But M. de Tréville	350.89885481493513
knew nothing, except that the last time he had seen the cardinal, the	391.42549136284515
king, and the queen, the cardinal looked very thoughtful, the king	385.7574140366273
uneasy, and the redness of the queen’s eyes donated that she had been	459.99342861199943
sleepless or tearful. But this last circumstance was not striking, as	380.3011421841428
the queen since her marriage had slept badly and wept much.	462.2670508786787
M. de Tréville requested Athos, whatever might happen, to be observant	430.9967770270515
of his duty to the king, but particularly to the queen, begging him to	432.32609258473263
convey his desires to his comrades.	366.6676888791176
As to D’Artagnan, he did not budge from his apartment. He converted his	480.13425860702694
chamber into an observatory. From his windows he saw all the visitors	396.4683558647157
who were caught. Then, having removed a plank from his floor, and	454.43192031086903
nothing remaining but a simple ceiling between him and the room	432.2997223032406
beneath, in which the interrogatories were made, he heard all that	333.0039563146721
passed between the inquisitors and the accused.	451.8205229570734
The interrogatories, preceded by a minute search operated upon the	415.90869722592254
persons arrested, were almost always framed thus: “Has Madame Bonacieux	336.02594049631455
sent anything to you for her husband, or any other person? Has Monsieur	350.2320728669371
Bonacieux sent anything to you for his wife, or for any other person?	431.9617326907444
Has either of them confided anything to you by word of mouth?”	354.67766621557644
“If they knew anything, they would not question people in this manner,”	441.2137786829198
said D’Artagnan to himself. “Now, what is it they want to know? Why,	344.5654855422847
they want to know if the Duke of Buckingham is in Paris, and if he has	318.419927832594
had, or is likely to have, an interview with the queen.”	426.96741238403234
D’Artagnan held onto this idea, which, from what he had heard, was not	417.19258427805653
wanting in probability.	465.55212250902207
In the meantime, the mousetrap continued in operation, and likewise	411.16551198492107
D’Artagnan’s vigilance.	478.6111050690055
On the evening of the day after the arrest of poor Bonacieux, as Athos	462.3864553304486
had just left D’Artagnan to report at M. de Tréville’s, as nine o’clock	464.0331798031019
had just struck, and as Planchet, who had not yet made the bed, was	354.92743701249486
beginning his task, a knocking was heard at the street door. The door	430.2983631362235
was instantly opened and shut; someone was taken in the mousetrap.	450.02644086655926
D’Artagnan flew to his hole, laid himself down on the floor at full	442.7983441430906
length, and listened.	320.5894073547445
Cries were soon heard, and then moans, which someone appeared to be	432.47776133557664
endeavoring to stifle. There were no questions.	335.34782272362145
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan to himself. “It seems like a woman! They	338.934141414804
search her; she resists; they use force—the scoundrels!”	365.8388232438551
In spite of his prudence, D’Artagnan restrained himself with great	490.81385386533486
difficulty from taking a part in the scene that was going on below.	422.7574421724896
“But I tell you that I am the mistress of the house, gentlemen! I tell	371.99400292492226
you I am Madame Bonacieux; I tell you I belong to the queen!” cried the	362.7120310261728
unfortunate woman.	381.53036176894267
“Madame Bonacieux!” murmured D’Artagnan. “Can I be so lucky as to find	476.55949907354625
what everybody is seeking for?”	296.6869991036678
The voice became more and more indistinct; a tumultuous movement shook	295.90668192593245
the partition. The victim resisted as much as a woman could resist four	345.95472707509896
men.	476.52155217901475
“Pardon, gentlemen—par—” murmured the voice, which could now only be	474.0904727437893
heard in inarticulate sounds.	401.3907366339343
“They are binding her; they are going to drag her away,” cried	392.1567131218095
D’Artagnan to himself, springing up from the floor. “My sword! Good, it	361.76078578739083
is by my side! Planchet!”	440.80912475174216
“Monsieur.”	322.8529556202867
“Run and seek Athos, Porthos and Aramis. One of the three will	347.2403537504401
certainly be at home, perhaps all three. Tell them to take arms, to	467.96222466501115
come here, and to run! Ah, I remember, Athos is at Monsieur de	376.39677305386084
Tréville’s.”	302.84740132295076
“But where are you going, monsieur, where are you going?”	368.8332201109612
“I am going down by the window, in order to be there the sooner,” cried	447.73408276422015
D’Artagnan. “You put back the boards, sweep the floor, go out at the	470.7265477428665
door, and run as I told you.”	480.48295390783403
“Oh, monsieur! Monsieur! You will kill yourself,” cried Planchet.	354.637659090379
“Hold your tongue, stupid fellow,” said D’Artagnan; and laying hold of	373.85314607526595
the casement, he let himself gently down from the first story, which	363.7258158145754
fortunately was not very elevated, without doing himself the slightest	483.848222680151
injury.	318.17584566484953
He then went straight to the door and knocked, murmuring, “I will go	344.2082958852678
myself and be caught in the mousetrap, but woe be to the cats that	487.22827572519907
shall pounce upon such a mouse!”	478.8560532960564
The knocker had scarcely sounded under the hand of the young man before	474.3383293206005
the tumult ceased, steps approached, the door was opened, and	432.8901911313436
D’Artagnan, sword in hand, rushed into the rooms of M. Bonacieux, the	416.1859731392939
door of which, doubtless acted upon by a spring, closed after him.	456.82009832631866
Then those who dwelt in Bonacieux’s unfortunate house, together with	333.5599890400242
the nearest neighbors, heard loud cries, stamping of feet, clashing of	416.416814440238
swords, and breaking of furniture. A moment after, those who, surprised	310.16623530456565
by this tumult, had gone to their windows to learn the cause of it, saw	391.8544800524405
the door open, and four men, clothed in black, not _come_ out of it,	313.986640031333
but _fly_, like so many frightened crows, leaving on the ground and on	402.81606009648476
the corners of the furniture, feathers from their wings; that is to	298.4700627086903
say, patches of their clothes and fragments of their cloaks.	370.5199121381742
D’Artagnan was conqueror—without much effort, it must be confessed, for	316.28695714873226
only one of the officers was armed, and even he defended himself for	484.0079817487757
form’s sake. It is true that the three others had endeavored to knock	309.862395749935
the young man down with chairs, stools, and crockery; but two or three	334.45513067944955
scratches made by the Gascon’s blade terrified them. Ten minutes	438.76892182033794
sufficed for their defeat, and D’Artagnan remained master of the field	432.05119595790495
of battle.	442.6777651002509
The neighbors who had opened their windows, with the coolness peculiar	403.41569946230857
to the inhabitants of Paris in these times of perpetual riots and	448.79468234220394
disturbances, closed them again as soon as they saw the four men in	376.063271924049
black flee—their instinct telling them that for the time all was over.	385.53269976049455
Besides, it began to grow late, and then, as today, people went to bed	384.99101561518796
early in the quarter of the Luxembourg.	472.72486079173984
On being left alone with Mme. Bonacieux, D’Artagnan turned toward her;	408.25467365050145
the poor woman reclined where she had been left, half-fainting upon an	478.38639819719583
armchair. D’Artagnan examined her with a rapid glance.	375.95329415851336
She was a charming woman of twenty-five or twenty-six years, with dark	444.9889913245288
hair, blue eyes, and a nose slightly turned up, admirable teeth, and a	422.7291929941922
complexion marbled with rose and opal. There, however, ended the signs	315.0166899655243
which might have confounded her with a lady of rank. The hands were	389.6125670782598
white, but without delicacy; the feet did not bespeak the woman of	456.26488361246686
quality. Happily, D’Artagnan was not yet acquainted with such niceties.	473.0894485277462
While D’Artagnan was examining Mme. Bonacieux, and was, as we have	366.28743899556093
said, close to her, he saw on the ground a fine cambric handkerchief,	371.50520272234826
which he picked up, as was his habit, and at the corner of which he	362.5403917440933
recognized the same cipher he had seen on the handkerchief which had	292.4850615969165
nearly caused him and Aramis to cut each other’s throat.	449.1480002666149
From that time, D’Artagnan had been cautious with respect to	466.1220029211713
handkerchiefs with arms on them, and he therefore placed in the pocket	403.82745656890796
of Mme. Bonacieux the one he had just picked up.	324.4430933072946
At that moment Mme. Bonacieux recovered her senses. She opened her	351.4966450638767
eyes, looked around her with terror, saw that the apartment was empty	310.47740858099445
and that she was alone with her liberator. She extended her hands to	322.5096486672814
him with a smile. Mme. Bonacieux had the sweetest smile in the world.	378.48842804358964
“Ah, monsieur!” said she, “you have saved me; permit me to thank you.”	356.9508326099054
“Madame,” said D’Artagnan, “I have only done what every gentleman would	447.96878609799467
have done in my place; you owe me no thanks.”	372.2876117193737
“Oh, yes, monsieur, oh, yes; and I hope to prove to you that you have	480.73041923557855
not served an ingrate. But what could these men, whom I at first took	318.5785835796185
for robbers, want with me, and why is Monsieur Bonacieux not here?”	345.2954562339113
“Madame, those men were more dangerous than any robbers could have	370.95982173644927
been, for they are the agents of the cardinal; and as to your husband,	408.8761731221485
Monsieur Bonacieux, he is not here because he was yesterday evening	459.9146232121425
conducted to the Bastille.”	360.4025869467242
“My husband in the Bastille!” cried Mme. Bonacieux. “Oh, my God! What	298.1177402194352
has he done? Poor dear man, he is innocence itself!”	355.478327857762
And something like a faint smile lighted the still-terrified features	361.90055705995815
of the young woman.	487.742490015911
“What has he done, madame?” said D’Artagnan. “I believe that his only	464.0613934062965
crime is to have at the same time the good fortune and the misfortune	412.59371122113794
to be your husband.”	405.05437993775206
“But, monsieur, you know then—”	293.1992481284877
“I know that you have been abducted, madame.”	317.91689954704935
“And by whom? Do you know him? Oh, if you know him, tell me!”	303.45605294731587
“By a man of from forty to forty-five years, with black hair, a dark	468.9483957107678
complexion, and a scar on his left temple.”	315.11733247763624
“That is he, that is he; but his name?”	371.14349241084744
“Ah, his name? I do not know that.”	326.5255405348779
“And did my husband know I had been carried off?”	376.25976618509054
“He was informed of it by a letter, written to him by the abductor	491.38551493120315
himself.”	334.5641911638954
“And does he suspect,” said Mme. Bonacieux, with some embarrassment,	483.19571140679045
“the cause of this event?”	324.7836819055724
“He attributed it, I believe, to a political cause.”	343.10296393089436
“I doubted from the first; and now I think entirely as he does. Then my	348.6329928819985
dear Monsieur Bonacieux has not suspected me a single instant?”	465.11260561130916
“So far from it, madame, he was too proud of your prudence, and above	435.6349849748111
all, of your love.”	403.67669214587033
A second smile, almost imperceptible, stole over the rosy lips of the	453.75575408796976
pretty young woman.	318.29915282145305
“But,” continued D’Artagnan, “how did you escape?”	393.4950560972866
“I took advantage of a moment when they left me alone; and as I had	476.25790087219474
known since morning the reason of my abduction, with the help of the	367.49642630456003
sheets I let myself down from the window. Then, as I believed my	459.0070918753456
husband would be at home, I hastened hither.”	425.9571898537263
“To place yourself under his protection?”	293.08898375528656
“Oh, no, poor dear man! I knew very well that he was incapable of	313.5567870745011
defending me; but as he could serve us in other ways, I wished to	452.8819765780901
inform him.”	399.18685547885974
“Of what?”	309.4282902003561
“Oh, that is not my secret; I must not, therefore, tell you.”	294.2529891223175
“Besides,” said D’Artagnan, “pardon me, madame, if, guardsman as I am,	358.50331597754234
I remind you of prudence—besides, I believe we are not here in a very	354.9117914604147
proper place for imparting confidences. The men I have put to flight	450.38861075096645
will return reinforced; if they find us here, we are lost. I have sent	479.3340023508803
for three of my friends, but who knows whether they were at home?”	483.5580366627268
“Yes, yes! You are right,” cried the affrighted Mme. Bonacieux; “let us	441.83263421421213
fly! Let us save ourselves.”	363.32361770020805
At these words she passed her arm under that of D’Artagnan, and urged	342.44460313952567
him forward eagerly.	397.8945102735697
“But whither shall we fly—whither escape?”	377.58455611363445
“Let us first withdraw from this house; afterward we shall see.”	357.2834485683153
The young woman and the young man, without taking the trouble to shut	424.8375937627527
the door after them, descended the Rue des Fossoyeurs rapidly, turned	428.2500337925044
into the Rue des Fossés-Monsieur-le-Prince, and did not stop till they	472.23787877640245
came to the Place St. Sulpice.	308.4140008236209
“And now what are we to do, and where do you wish me to conduct you?”	490.32482825883346
asked D’Artagnan.	381.2520876222725
“I am at quite a loss how to answer you, I admit,” said Mme. Bonacieux.	452.57759781244226
“My intention was to inform Monsieur Laporte, through my husband, in	337.5949014358334
order that Monsieur Laporte might tell us precisely what had taken	333.26257190427907
place at the Louvre in the last three days, and whether there is any	369.04445936941534
danger in presenting myself there.”	431.2403666207822
“But I,” said D’Artagnan, “can go and inform Monsieur Laporte.”	318.27606389605
“No doubt you could, only there is one misfortune, and that is that	356.84537804402044
Monsieur Bonacieux is known at the Louvre, and would be allowed to	314.412275281621
pass; whereas you are not known there, and the gate would be closed	329.07155560862367
against you.”	447.2720151670072
“Ah, bah!” said D’Artagnan; “you have at some wicket of the Louvre a	388.76901537329326
_concierge_ who is devoted to you, and who, thanks to a password,	305.89228939694766
would—”	405.92023342783284
Mme. Bonacieux looked earnestly at the young man.	463.90099656003395
“And if I give you this password,” said she, “would you forget it as	335.2722839379563
soon as you used it?”	298.79973666738226
“By my honor, by the faith of a gentleman!” said D’Artagnan, with an	378.7167388110613
accent so truthful that no one could mistake it.	440.53256848407784
“Then I believe you. You appear to be a brave young man; besides, your	426.6240091403723
fortune may perhaps be the result of your devotedness.”	325.70106554798986
“I will do, without a promise and voluntarily, all that I can do to	379.82147158460066
serve the king and be agreeable to the queen. Dispose of me, then, as a	345.82617790961893
friend.”	369.6074444448884
“But I—where shall I go meanwhile?”	383.19074623511705
“Is there nobody from whose house Monsieur Laporte can come and fetch	377.8542599780568
you?”	308.4408642757076
“No, I can trust nobody.”	474.57817867272854
“Stop,” said D’Artagnan; “we are near Athos’s door. Yes, here it is.”	414.95910057570984
“Who is this Athos?”	379.41824782405547
