“One of my friends.”	331.5132951841839
“But if he should be at home and see me?”	329.17718221762993
“He is not at home, and I will carry away the key, after having placed	342.0451240443605
you in his apartment.”	456.64916103794445
“But if he should return?”	462.07687090887464
“Oh, he won’t return; and if he should, he will be told that I have	412.8544276486689
brought a woman with me, and that woman is in his apartment.”	444.42820004798784
“But that will compromise me sadly, you know.”	343.5391922300317
“Of what consequence? Nobody knows you. Besides, we are in a situation	449.65281736194345
to overlook ceremony.”	351.14928781814854
“Come, then, let us go to your friend’s house. Where does he live?”	474.9569002739041
“Rue Férou, two steps from here.”	419.08815366307215
“Let us go!”	436.6321423058706
Both resumed their way. As D’Artagnan had foreseen, Athos was not	312.24121685599795
within. He took the key, which was customarily given him as one of the	443.47916604312684
family, ascended the stairs, and introduced Mme. Bonacieux into the	334.3082821266225
little apartment of which we have given a description.	370.3871237183931
“You are at home,” said he. “Remain here, fasten the door inside, and	343.21316124714417
open it to nobody unless you hear three taps like this;” and he tapped	298.07227758844573
thrice—two taps close together and pretty hard, the other after an	412.859170174125
interval, and lighter.	473.2857674408883
“That is well,” said Mme. Bonacieux. “Now, in my turn, let me give you	369.3315246588752
my instructions.”	461.8469445494208
“I am all attention.”	478.3405531358627
“Present yourself at the wicket of the Louvre, on the side of the Rue	473.11486041831836
de l’Echelle, and ask for Germain.”	413.5850637532267
“Well, and then?”	313.04190048143414
“He will ask you what you want, and you will answer by these two words,	393.1461085836384
‘Tours’ and ‘Bruxelles.’ He will at once put himself at your orders.”	456.4487277230807
“And what shall I command him?”	465.98518698995576
“To go and fetch Monsieur Laporte, the queen’s _valet de chambre_.”	355.82513280267113
“And when he shall have informed him, and Monsieur Laporte is come?”	358.34698155465446
“You will send him to me.”	425.3303190618122
“That is well; but where and how shall I see you again?”	314.6450215892221
“Do you wish to see me again?”	340.38519915985523
“Certainly.”	345.53449403499815
“Well, let that care be mine, and be at ease.”	343.25851461713944
“I depend upon your word.”	411.6385921826786
“You may.”	399.9202670709278
D’Artagnan bowed to Mme. Bonacieux, darting at her the most loving	442.26828010984127
glance that he could possibly concentrate upon her charming little	455.6875450335779
person; and while he descended the stairs, he heard the door closed and	472.4475096457163
double-locked. In two bounds he was at the Louvre; as he entered the	432.31184597546076
wicket of L’Echelle, ten o’clock struck. All the events we have	478.1477429576766
described had taken place within a half hour.	304.67591243444895
Everything fell out as Mme. Bonacieux prophesied. On hearing the	297.44212956358786
password, Germain bowed. In a few minutes, Laporte was at the lodge; in	487.9293856877341
two words D’Artagnan informed him where Mme. Bonacieux was. Laporte	429.2173205254529
assured himself, by having it twice repeated, of the accurate address,	392.39203840557286
and set off at a run. Hardly, however, had he taken ten steps before he	396.0590183675123
returned.	387.17089151871073
“Young man,” said he to D’Artagnan, “a suggestion.”	402.3760619670237
“What?”	442.1037794121449
“You may get into trouble by what has taken place.”	339.8989611432708
“You believe so?”	442.05414958886956
“Yes. Have you any friend whose clock is too slow?”	451.5729917041864
“Well?”	443.8943930272021
“Go and call upon him, in order that he may give evidence of your	444.4843790837824
having been with him at half past nine. In a court of justice that is	447.97000925043716
called an alibi.”	308.19776116119795
D’Artagnan found his advice prudent. He took to his heels, and was soon	411.27210155688704
at M. de Tréville’s; but instead of going into the saloon with the rest	326.88753130103527
of the crowd, he asked to be introduced to M. de Tréville’s office. As	388.6753817735534
D’Artagnan so constantly frequented the hôtel, no difficulty was made	411.65097487410196
in complying with his request, and a servant went to inform M. de	301.63904856811234
Tréville that his young compatriot, having something important to	466.10156625832053
communicate, solicited a private audience. Five minutes after, M. de	467.98219780666875
Tréville was asking D’Artagnan what he could do to serve him, and what	374.47744801577085
caused his visit at so late an hour.	459.836787954729
“Pardon me, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan, who had profited by the moment	331.45943467475456
he had been left alone to put back M. de Tréville’s clock	374.09338641749616
three-quarters of an hour, “but I thought, as it was yet only	341.42241221258917
twenty-five minutes past nine, it was not too late to wait upon you.”	354.62062904693965
“Twenty-five minutes past nine!” cried M. de Tréville, looking at the	445.8174471543592
clock; “why, that’s impossible!”	431.2274473824931
“Look, rather, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan, “the clock shows it.”	481.17747070912435
“That’s true,” said M. de Tréville; “I believed it later. But what can	472.8319640090814
I do for you?”	473.4666477879749
Then D’Artagnan told M. de Tréville a long history about the queen. He	423.6220338630226
expressed to him the fears he entertained with respect to her Majesty;	369.2292776818573
he related to him what he had heard of the projects of the cardinal	311.53553664946196
with regard to Buckingham, and all with a tranquillity and candor of	477.04246912804393
which M. de Tréville was the more the dupe, from having himself, as we	340.8583674556156
have said, observed something fresh between the cardinal, the king, and	379.6926802296189
the queen.	440.16372990708555
As ten o’clock was striking, D’Artagnan left M. de Tréville, who	345.48798303825987
thanked him for his information, recommended him to have the service of	408.6344379065791
the king and queen always at heart, and returned to the saloon; but at	326.60115688387435
the foot of the stairs, D’Artagnan remembered he had forgotten his	434.35143154643185
cane. He consequently sprang up again, re-entered the office, with a	446.644626456537
turn of his finger set the clock right again, that it might not be	480.8903104937724
perceived the next day that it had been put wrong, and certain from	483.7020359810173
that time that he had a witness to prove his alibi, he ran downstairs	385.89278267134705
and soon found himself in the street.	452.81025937393144
Chapter XI.	437.4980219842873
IN WHICH THE PLOT THICKENS	303.33554682355157
His visit to M. de Tréville being paid, the pensive D’Artagnan took the	314.1113935892764
longest way homeward.	415.26438778172746
On what was D’Artagnan thinking, that he strayed thus from his path,	424.4090423954069
gazing at the stars of heaven, and sometimes sighing, sometimes	335.6327324682552
smiling?	458.9446883623947
He was thinking of Mme. Bonacieux. For an apprentice Musketeer the	316.53089575262777
young woman was almost an ideal of love. Pretty, mysterious, initiated	425.95772744554665
in almost all the secrets of the court, which reflected such a charming	439.7333088367604
gravity over her pleasing features, it might be surmised that she was	419.7231254630311
not wholly unmoved; and this is an irresistible charm to novices in	395.98662668277706
love. Moreover, D’Artagnan had delivered her from the hands of the	345.4644548572772
demons who wished to search and ill treat her; and this important	293.8533866733024
service had established between them one of those sentiments of	418.5553174184516
gratitude which so easily assume a more tender character.	394.997569081031
D’Artagnan already fancied himself, so rapid is the flight of our	342.0631618612403
dreams upon the wings of imagination, accosted by a messenger from the	363.3936428283764
young woman, who brought him some billet appointing a meeting, a gold	319.3366026144284
chain, or a diamond. We have observed that young cavaliers received	396.85988458388783
presents from their king without shame. Let us add that in these times	421.2073863264709
of lax morality they had no more delicacy with respect to the	296.3433989480084
mistresses; and that the latter almost always left them valuable and	347.33388240931504
durable remembrances, as if they essayed to conquer the fragility of	402.45915672849105
their sentiments by the solidity of their gifts.	317.4271283373561
Without a blush, men made their way in the world by the means of women	448.67081941093124
blushing. Such as were only beautiful gave their beauty, whence,	446.9865679134215
without doubt, comes the proverb, “The most beautiful girl in the world	411.68502804641
can only give what she has.” Such as were rich gave in addition a part	380.410371563524
of their money; and a vast number of heroes of that gallant period may	322.6829989555816
be cited who would neither have won their spurs in the first place, nor	399.3807655446461
their battles afterward, without the purse, more or less furnished,	400.579549906156
which their mistress fastened to the saddle bow.	363.33558940068895
D’Artagnan owned nothing. Provincial diffidence, that slight varnish,	454.16056121934025
the ephemeral flower, that down of the peach, had evaporated to the	408.8379178391813
winds through the little orthodox counsels which the three Musketeers	294.1299125818476
gave their friend. D’Artagnan, following the strange custom of the	359.81174212743804
times, considered himself at Paris as on a campaign, neither more nor	363.05721445711515
less than if he had been in Flanders—Spain yonder, woman here. In each	427.2721325149463
there was an enemy to contend with, and contributions to be levied.	452.8877402956447
But, we must say, at the present moment D’Artagnan was ruled by a	305.1654251535507
feeling much more noble and disinterested. The mercer had said that he	292.47672955648727
was rich; the young man might easily guess that with so weak a man as	456.3279527202857
M. Bonacieux; and interest was almost foreign to this commencement of	380.12704013632765
love, which had been the consequence of it. We say _almost_, for the	451.5343427640331
idea that a young, handsome, kind, and witty woman is at the same time	463.8225603044913
rich takes nothing from the beginning of love, but on the contrary	386.0222026594781
strengthens it.	411.9410937117633
There are in affluence a crowd of aristocratic cares and caprices which	433.3026365969074
are highly becoming to beauty. A fine and white stocking, a silken	392.7806462611607
robe, a lace kerchief, a pretty slipper on the foot, a tasty ribbon on	311.18289035594034
the head do not make an ugly woman pretty, but they make a pretty woman	350.799871110342
beautiful, without reckoning the hands, which gain by all this; the	439.08664163216673
hands, among women particularly, to be beautiful must be idle.	460.22112337032036
Then D’Artagnan, as the reader, from whom we have not concealed the	413.4748311574664
state of his fortune, very well knows—D’Artagnan was not a millionaire;	437.09570610375033
he hoped to become one someday, but the time which in his own mind he	330.32155660652126
fixed upon for this happy change was still far distant. In the	295.34382341524537
meanwhile, how disheartening to see the woman one loves long for those	403.893887244728
thousands of nothings which constitute a woman’s happiness, and be	422.7283024586822
unable to give her those thousands of nothings. At least, when the	491.1650850023584
woman is rich and the lover is not, that which he cannot offer she	303.89253866222043
offers to herself; and although it is generally with her husband’s	314.64441012085274
money that she procures herself this indulgence, the gratitude for it	367.3018638409844
seldom reverts to him.	324.83633601639974
Then D’Artagnan, disposed to become the most tender of lovers, was at	484.44273213865307
the same time a very devoted friend. In the midst of his amorous	369.1181879226714
projects for the mercer’s wife, he did not forget his friends. The	328.177737383738
pretty Mme. Bonacieux was just the woman to walk with in the Plain St.	390.6132050227213
Denis or in the fair of St. Germain, in company with Athos, Porthos,	454.96811167499663
and Aramis, to whom D’Artagnan had often remarked this. Then one could	317.9799720087541
enjoy charming little dinners, where one touches on one side the hand	307.36258622244605
of a friend, and on the other the foot of a mistress. Besides, on	295.35422729189344
pressing occasions, in extreme difficulties, D’Artagnan would become	310.2639723876447
the preserver of his friends.	404.74573971650506
And M. Bonacieux, whom D’Artagnan had pushed into the hands of the	316.2573234268451
officers, denying him aloud although he had promised in a whisper to	376.1719417478599
save him? We are compelled to admit to our readers that D’Artagnan	347.2833342780276
thought nothing about him in any way; or that if he did think of him,	397.6969929362477
it was only to say to himself that he was very well where he was,	478.5356048516859
wherever it might be. Love is the most selfish of all the passions.	404.740946063417
Let our readers reassure themselves. If D’Artagnan forgets his host, or	397.1007552625584
appears to forget him, under the pretense of not knowing where he has	342.46701973379754
been carried, we will not forget him, and we know where he is. But for	444.54071966258937
the moment, let us do as did the amorous Gascon; we will see after the	404.3067077637266
worthy mercer later.	349.97247106368735
D’Artagnan, reflecting on his future amours, addressing himself to the	304.9223243821471
beautiful night, and smiling at the stars, ascended the Rue	446.5234355204357
Cherish-Midi, or Chase-Midi, as it was then called. As he found himself	353.12764050424346
in the quarter in which Aramis lived, he took it into his head to pay	488.6502753404466
his friend a visit in order to explain the motives which had led him to	299.00907162109314
send Planchet with a request that he would come instantly to the	489.35312418321547
mousetrap. Now, if Aramis had been at home when Planchet came to his	345.4749564959382
abode, he had doubtless hastened to the Rue des Fossoyeurs, and finding	434.6275440062118
nobody there but his other two companions perhaps, they would not be	389.41816620418706
able to conceive what all this meant. This mystery required an	402.06895283625244
explanation; at least, so D’Artagnan declared to himself.	434.469270237768
He likewise thought this was an opportunity for talking about pretty	491.0523518310475
little Mme. Bonacieux, of whom his head, if not his heart, was already	299.1106049756102
full. We must never look for discretion in first love. First love is	388.43383221897295
accompanied by such excessive joy that unless the joy be allowed to	342.26797832081263
overflow, it will stifle you.	391.55358369978245
Paris for two hours past had been dark, and seemed a desert. Eleven	484.33925904028206
o’clock sounded from all the clocks of the Faubourg St. Germain. It was	421.4768557151913
delightful weather. D’Artagnan was passing along a lane on the spot	436.88565549759255
where the Rue d’Assas is now situated, breathing the balmy emanations	323.6779909423022
which were borne upon the wind from the Rue de Vaugirard, and which	456.0732745913605
arose from the gardens refreshed by the dews of evening and the breeze	354.2302169011413
of night. From a distance resounded, deadened, however, by good	435.6716555758274
shutters, the songs of the tipplers, enjoying themselves in the	413.5275917166908
cabarets scattered along the plain. Arrived at the end of the lane,	442.70358798767984
D’Artagnan turned to the left. The house in which Aramis dwelt was	430.90949160596125
situated between the Rue Cassette and the Rue Servandoni.	310.31670233851395
D’Artagnan had just passed the Rue Cassette, and already perceived the	371.66833913628403
door of his friend’s house, shaded by a mass of sycamores and clematis	372.6244228764579
which formed a vast arch opposite the front of it, when he perceived	356.32410110184145
something like a shadow issuing from the Rue Servandoni. This something	470.25725097154674
was enveloped in a cloak, and D’Artagnan at first believed it was a	320.93391877409005
man; but by the smallness of the form, the hesitation of the walk, and	339.48574890684165
the indecision of the step, he soon discovered that it was a woman.	354.18653794324575
Further, this woman, as if not certain of the house she was seeking,	324.90510030828636
lifted up her eyes to look around her, stopped, went backward, and then	325.37247001465494
returned again. D’Artagnan was perplexed.	431.1861007700009
“Shall I go and offer her my services?” thought he. “By her step she	420.00071429494494
must be young; perhaps she is pretty. Oh, yes! But a woman who wanders	415.5078343859919
in the streets at this hour only ventures out to meet her lover. If I	472.57272694830976
should disturb a rendezvous, that would not be the best means of	421.2846862020959
commencing an acquaintance.”	298.1440761432427
Meantime the young woman continued to advance, counting the houses and	327.2399282707667
windows. This was neither long nor difficult. There were but three	482.56957468874054
hôtels in this part of the street; and only two windows looking toward	318.0484717985552
the road, one of which was in a pavilion parallel to that which Aramis	311.9881711223968
occupied, the other belonging to Aramis himself.	337.56525593230623
“_Pardieu!_” said D’Artagnan to himself, to whose mind the niece of the	430.04836102636364
theologian reverted, “_pardieu_, it would be droll if this belated dove	463.09024038585693
should be in search of our friend’s house. But on my soul, it looks so.	482.4235736046155
Ah, my dear Aramis, this time I shall find you out.” And D’Artagnan,	472.78150963505027
making himself as small as he could, concealed himself in the darkest	345.50582281133757
side of the street near a stone bench placed at the back of a niche.	310.519016272132
The young woman continued to advance; and in addition to the lightness	466.6840153041667
of her step, which had betrayed her, she emitted a little cough which	487.3046838911496
denoted a sweet voice. D’Artagnan believed this cough to be a signal.	442.8707529271311
Nevertheless, whether the cough had been answered by a similar signal	484.68976858051394
which had fixed the irresolution of the nocturnal seeker, or whether	411.8683765436125
without this aid she saw that she had arrived at the end of her	452.0812889401343
journey, she resolutely drew near to Aramis’s shutter, and tapped, at	393.8494240083322
three equal intervals, with her bent finger.	480.53014650234934
“This is all very fine, dear Aramis,” murmured D’Artagnan. “Ah,	310.872112811831
Monsieur Hypocrite, I understand how you study theology.”	323.33630357709853
The three blows were scarcely struck, when the inside blind was opened	463.3571150162139
and a light appeared through the panes of the outside shutter.	317.40452160857814
“Ah, ah!” said the listener, “not through doors, but through windows!	431.6071283890268
Ah, this visit was expected. We shall see the windows open, and the	477.546055196137
lady enter by escalade. Very pretty!”	482.2156954542279
But to the great astonishment of D’Artagnan, the shutter remained	314.8687393309697
closed. Still more, the light which had shone for an instant	469.01687719987086
disappeared, and all was again in obscurity.	340.3060794003107
D’Artagnan thought this could not last long, and continued to look with	488.7224685946111
all his eyes and listen with all his ears.	413.2355803759582
He was right; at the end of some seconds two sharp taps were heard	414.56145668835046
inside. The young woman in the street replied by a single tap, and the	367.2039385907579
shutter was opened a little way.	382.8048593654571
It may be judged whether D’Artagnan looked or listened with avidity.	331.84802877257636
Unfortunately the light had been removed into another chamber; but the	325.3654287026582
eyes of the young man were accustomed to the night. Besides, the eyes	295.5372419834499
of the Gascons have, as it is asserted, like those of cats, the faculty	379.2278051069287
of seeing in the dark.	460.2414140555526
D’Artagnan then saw that the young woman took from her pocket a white	440.8727158415402
object, which she unfolded quickly, and which took the form of a	374.72684809665
handkerchief. She made her interlocutor observe the corner of this	357.16017932455725
unfolded object.	295.3009739611853
This immediately recalled to D’Artagnan’s mind the handkerchief which	324.04251204792763
he had found at the feet of Mme. Bonacieux, which had reminded him of	467.55615773226737
that which he had dragged from under the feet of Aramis.	307.742685132168
“What the devil could that handkerchief signify?”	403.69658228770425
Placed where he was, D’Artagnan could not perceive the face of Aramis.	306.987792718931
We say Aramis, because the young man entertained no doubt that it was	400.455094544975
his friend who held this dialogue from the interior with the lady of	452.22604674468334
the exterior. Curiosity prevailed over prudence; and profiting by the	344.9068863119547
preoccupation into which the sight of the handkerchief appeared to have	446.0340576348448
plunged the two personages now on the scene, he stole from his hiding	462.1531860989738
place, and quick as lightning, but stepping with utmost caution, he ran	341.2068735867555
and placed himself close to the angle of the wall, from which his eye	482.80089174640597
could pierce the interior of Aramis’s room.	355.97889199483416
Upon gaining this advantage D’Artagnan was near uttering a cry of	452.1304581942969
surprise; it was not Aramis who was conversing with the nocturnal	429.813202476535
visitor, it was a woman! D’Artagnan, however, could only see enough to	406.44572196655
recognize the form of her vestments, not enough to distinguish her	314.4611155575102
features.	338.7969678664176
At the same instant the woman inside drew a second handkerchief from	402.5842061249323
her pocket, and exchanged it for that which had just been shown to her.	317.62787178907695
Then some words were spoken by the two women. At length the shutter	378.65536723693685
closed. The woman who was outside the window turned round, and passed	342.87032043409175
within four steps of D’Artagnan, pulling down the hood of her mantle;	478.6731662196271
but the precaution was too late, D’Artagnan had already recognized Mme.	486.8875623256805
Bonacieux.	343.30524509854297
Mme. Bonacieux! The suspicion that it was she had crossed the mind of	392.76415140720906
D’Artagnan when she drew the handkerchief from her pocket; but what	489.09463674753147
probability was there that Mme. Bonacieux, who had sent for M. Laporte	422.0445452226618
in order to be reconducted to the Louvre, should be running about the	352.1847670757074
streets of Paris at half past eleven at night, at the risk of being	340.7625278911102
abducted a second time?	436.22045775271454
This must be, then, an affair of importance; and what is the most	451.85533051408646
important affair to a woman of twenty-five! Love.	472.76489913728625
But was it on her own account, or on account of another, that she	372.5375336252586
exposed herself to such hazards? This was a question the young man	307.67902348134726
asked himself, whom the demon of jealousy already gnawed, being in	448.3966715171003
heart neither more nor less than an accepted lover.	419.0546052111167
There was a very simple means of satisfying himself whither Mme.	411.8591190020338
Bonacieux was going; that was to follow her. This method was so simple	303.9345227824939
that D’Artagnan employed it quite naturally and instinctively.	355.74408018771993
But at the sight of the young man, who detached himself from the wall	305.3670990137442
like a statue walking from its niche, and at the noise of the steps	419.43216056781
which she heard resound behind her, Mme. Bonacieux uttered a little cry	423.5966896953412
and fled.	324.6630874713234
D’Artagnan ran after her. It was not difficult for him to overtake a	460.8552407819211
woman embarrassed with her cloak. He came up with her before she had	398.48878470634025
traversed a third of the street. The unfortunate woman was exhausted,	392.14695870856264
not by fatigue, but by terror, and when D’Artagnan placed his hand upon	383.0548701148564
her shoulder, she sank upon one knee, crying in a choking voice, “Kill	462.0971272535665
me, if you please, you shall know nothing!”	437.04092902823913
D’Artagnan raised her by passing his arm round her waist; but as he	452.47004096016497
felt by her weight she was on the point of fainting, he made haste to	381.0769555428306
reassure her by protestations of devotedness. These protestations were	466.8776190401851
nothing for Mme. Bonacieux, for such protestations may be made with the	409.5085514844766
worst intentions in the world; but the voice was all. Mme. Bonacieux	473.4659961360594
thought she recognized the sound of that voice; she reopened her eyes,	391.2065368173608
cast a quick glance upon the man who had terrified her so, and at once	456.1361232528632
perceiving it was D’Artagnan, she uttered a cry of joy, “Oh, it is you,	307.4221433400358
it is you! Thank God, thank God!”	366.83580545789374
“Yes, it is I,” said D’Artagnan, “it is I, whom God has sent to watch	333.7948246484133
over you.”	403.1768135190199
“Was it with that intention you followed me?” asked the young woman,	447.46272600890336
with a coquettish smile, whose somewhat bantering character resumed its	359.43704953051173
influence, and with whom all fear had disappeared from the moment in	404.532175826236
which she recognized a friend in one she had taken for an enemy.	431.43967485924315
“No,” said D’Artagnan; “no, I confess it. It was chance that threw me	396.20553084795466
in your way; I saw a woman knocking at the window of one of my	318.46479360528394
friends.”	360.40858721904766
“One of your friends?” interrupted Mme. Bonacieux.	323.8554204658445
“Without doubt; Aramis is one of my best friends.”	393.8740261223665
“Aramis! Who is he?”	439.8889506331259
“Come, come, you won’t tell me you don’t know Aramis?”	474.5115713827394
“This is the first time I ever heard his name pronounced.”	482.6412038644072
“It is the first time, then, that you ever went to that house?”	421.0730139439479
“Undoubtedly.”	458.4972915834133
“And you did not know that it was inhabited by a young man?”	490.94302701354343
“No.”	450.55058312292306
“By a Musketeer?”	478.366334090139
“No, indeed!”	355.49415796621196
“It was not he, then, you came to seek?”	339.3263556723101
“Not the least in the world. Besides, you must have seen that the	364.24082059839543
person to whom I spoke was a woman.”	438.72552204656614
“That is true; but this woman is a friend of Aramis—”	368.33290136170694
“I know nothing of that.”	449.53051402126016
“—since she lodges with him.”	413.9633814268459
“That does not concern me.”	424.39861634573793
“But who is she?”	410.34727399486536
“Oh, that is not my secret.”	391.00992866933416
“My dear Madame Bonacieux, you are charming; but at the same time you	295.73328558693964
are one of the most mysterious women.”	368.60506207976107
“Do I lose by that?”	383.76565226251483
“No; you are, on the contrary, adorable.”	414.121148272238
“Give me your arm, then.”	450.9735252553213
“Most willingly. And now?”	458.07284195267454
“Now escort me.”	362.5377918813698
“Where?”	368.46069461298185
“Where I am going.”	413.48064019041266
“But where are you going?”	320.4659493023579
“You will see, because you will leave me at the door.”	482.9090166994397
“Shall I wait for you?”	427.5527223702792
“That will be useless.”	349.02295594432167
“You will return alone, then?”	416.1521827076947
“Perhaps yes, perhaps no.”	365.4718400530668
“But will the person who shall accompany you afterward be a man or a	404.7906640824437
woman?”	327.0292617661391
“I don’t know yet.”	402.78069261983535
“But I will know it!”	416.66852570408156
“How so?”	398.06046918597457
“I will wait until you come out.”	331.37203983360104
“In that case, adieu.”	432.79218368020395
“Why so?”	490.0775641704101
“I do not want you.”	318.7451049115964
“But you have claimed—”	309.7150083666368
“The aid of a gentleman, not the watchfulness of a spy.”	375.1790158610126
“The word is rather hard.”	481.157066813464
“How are they called who follow others in spite of them?”	384.8852704126058
“They are indiscreet.”	336.9680501125247
“The word is too mild.”	440.46147058019824
“Well, madame, I perceive I must do as you wish.”	429.01782787329773
“Why did you deprive yourself of the merit of doing so at once?”	359.75463090550363
“Is there no merit in repentance?”	437.99486608434336
“And do you really repent?”	417.5055399421045
“I know nothing about it myself. But what I know is that I promise to	473.14615286290575
do all you wish if you allow me to accompany you where you are going.”	406.7759001606166
“And you will leave me then?”	419.59125481337395
“Yes.”	317.70580033584287
“Without waiting for my coming out again?”	453.79459378480226
“Yes.”	349.8993222046448
“Word of honor?”	440.149282862319
“By the faith of a gentleman. Take my arm, and let us go.”	405.07863190909103
D’Artagnan offered his arm to Mme. Bonacieux, who willingly took it,	486.7924386494109
half laughing, half trembling, and both gained the top of Rue de la	383.39415785661447
Harpe. Arriving there, the young woman seemed to hesitate, as she had	423.2206308686832
before done in the Rue Vaugirard. She seemed, however, by certain	305.37616242449764
signs, to recognize a door, and approaching that door, “And now,	354.049691147465
monsieur,” said she, “it is here I have business; a thousand thanks for	433.33399141721753
your honorable company, which has saved me from all the dangers to	385.27941030978
which, alone, I was exposed. But the moment is come to keep your word;	372.16000705664874
I have reached my destination.”	322.8775637304368
“And you will have nothing to fear on your return?”	373.23646088627714
“I shall have nothing to fear but robbers.”	450.3247462424541
“And that is nothing?”	430.16343218815797
“What could they take from me? I have not a penny about me.”	381.4663901884166
“You forget that beautiful handkerchief with the coat of arms.”	404.71664033986156
“Which?”	305.91085172888387
“That which I found at your feet, and replaced in your pocket.”	365.31440343192907
“Hold your tongue, imprudent man! Do you wish to destroy me?”	450.273571530519
“You see very plainly that there is still danger for you, since a	357.4133579882413
single word makes you tremble; and you confess that if that word were	297.2486302278699
heard you would be ruined. Come, come, madame!” cried D’Artagnan,	388.734618329476
seizing her hands, and surveying her with an ardent glance, “come, be	370.7091656423569
more generous. Confide in me. Have you not read in my eyes that there	440.97058201961806
is nothing but devotion and sympathy in my heart?”	334.3853240675092
“Yes,” replied Mme. Bonacieux; “therefore, ask my own secrets, and I	344.6352808816463
will reveal them to you; but those of others—that is quite another	378.46269958878145
thing.”	455.80027333774694
“Very well,” said D’Artagnan, “I shall discover them; as these secrets	443.5455868655521
may have an influence over your life, these secrets must become mine.”	420.5237793567063
“Beware of what you do!” cried the young woman, in a manner so serious	436.0481150371367
as to make D’Artagnan start in spite of himself. “Oh, meddle in nothing	351.4014958125103
which concerns me. Do not seek to assist me in that which I am	427.188683102152
accomplishing. This I ask of you in the name of the interest with which	378.4109738542662
I inspire you, in the name of the service you have rendered me and	439.3372520740303
which I never shall forget while I have life. Rather, place faith in	330.66502437436543
what I tell you. Have no more concern about me; I exist no longer for	450.9273151308752
you, any more than if you had never seen me.”	474.8490347153518
“Must Aramis do as much as I, madame?” said D’Artagnan, deeply piqued.	468.4286897271379
“This is the second or third time, monsieur, that you have repeated	313.43859642928294
that name, and yet I have told you that I do not know him.”	451.52295912208444
“You do not know the man at whose shutter you have just knocked?	424.6453857979394
Indeed, madame, you believe me too credulous!”	433.8060126522663
“Confess that it is for the sake of making me talk that you invent this	420.6256214932885
story and create this personage.”	392.2755910409807
“I invent nothing, madame; I create nothing. I only speak that exact	455.380687596308
truth.”	410.4106091693582
“And you say that one of your friends lives in that house?”	297.75781704560944
“I say so, and I repeat it for the third time; that house is one	480.0362327989993
inhabited by my friend, and that friend is Aramis.”	450.57437771769094
“All this will be cleared up at a later period,” murmured the young	432.4487852789195
woman; “no, monsieur, be silent.”	465.1159236121756
“If you could see my heart,” said D’Artagnan, “you would there read so	395.75214396243405
much curiosity that you would pity me and so much love that you would	442.234962968633
instantly satisfy my curiosity. We have nothing to fear from those who	415.8945901071201
love us.”	436.5131319885493
“You speak very suddenly of love, monsieur,” said the young woman,	312.44955972176245
shaking her head.	487.94287212816323
“That is because love has come suddenly upon me, and for the first	363.8252282609043
time; and because I am only twenty.”	368.8086518558275
The young woman looked at him furtively.	441.3532581813548
“Listen; I am already upon the scent,” resumed D’Artagnan. “About three	298.5982618644419
months ago I was near having a duel with Aramis concerning a	358.89536743312703
handkerchief resembling the one you showed to the woman in his	337.407292744605
house—for a handkerchief marked in the same manner, I am sure.”	361.2788685779603
“Monsieur,” said the young woman, “you weary me very much, I assure	322.82623821764906
you, with your questions.”	464.96136326147223
“But you, madame, prudent as you are, think, if you were to be arrested	423.16240934040695
with that handkerchief, and that handkerchief were to be seized, would	335.44563403561415
you not be compromised?”	395.3273713445072
“In what way? The initials are only mine—C. B., Constance Bonacieux.”	471.39628840515445
“Or Camille de Bois-Tracy.”	387.5417189923817
“Silence, monsieur! Once again, silence! Ah, since the dangers I incur	371.3872341552552
on my own account cannot stop you, think of those you may yourself	305.1333860453748
run!”	419.358194070022
“Me?”	302.9414507613478
“Yes; there is peril of imprisonment, risk of life in knowing me.”	447.24284315559305
“Then I will not leave you.”	300.4034433900624
“Monsieur!” said the young woman, supplicating him and clasping her	360.5037479267812
hands together, “monsieur, in the name of heaven, by the honor of a	387.8645277210322
soldier, by the courtesy of a gentleman, depart! There, there midnight	314.5303050879436
sounds! That is the hour when I am expected.”	310.5037860832023
“Madame,” said the young man, bowing; “I can refuse nothing asked of me	299.008247935252
thus. Be content; I will depart.”	482.68356714496144
“But you will not follow me; you will not watch me?”	482.3944305772253
“I will return home instantly.”	338.121165502903
“Ah, I was quite sure you were a good and brave young man,” said Mme.	471.12330260574726
Bonacieux, holding out her hand to him, and placing the other upon the	433.4235127850633
knocker of a little door almost hidden in the wall.	436.236891906796
D’Artagnan seized the hand held out to him, and kissed it ardently.	296.5019460904203
“Ah! I wish I had never seen you!” cried D’Artagnan, with that	395.0966371965508
ingenuous roughness which women often prefer to the affectations of	458.582147096594
politeness, because it betrays the depths of the thought and proves	488.30920580096404
that feeling prevails over reason.	304.6862252146426
“Well!” resumed Mme. Bonacieux, in a voice almost caressing, and	457.11781492236923
pressing the hand of D’Artagnan, who had not relinquished hers, “well:	477.3212606388295
I will not say as much as you do; what is lost for today may not be	397.05214617364004
lost forever. Who knows, when I shall be at liberty, that I may not	306.76237004291414
satisfy your curiosity?”	383.6190924133737
“And will you make the same promise to my love?” cried D’Artagnan,	395.2911643572514
beside himself with joy.	363.8155219412838
“Oh, as to that, I do not engage myself. That depends upon the	370.8539738717201
sentiments with which you may inspire me.”	379.0196669244971
“Then today, madame—”	335.5835652659384
“Oh, today, I am no further than gratitude.”	324.6406672417089
“Ah! You are too charming,” said D’Artagnan, sorrowfully; “and you	303.96437272035973
abuse my love.”	334.3282819087088
“No, I use your generosity, that’s all. But be of good cheer; with	365.5704181920225
certain people, everything comes round.”	490.1230577343808
“Oh, you render me the happiest of men! Do not forget this evening—do	443.2198245485324

“Be satisfied. In the proper time and place I will remember everything.	388.43583283369696
Now then, go, go, in the name of heaven! I was expected at sharp	468.8241209482075
midnight, and I am late.”	330.6588098026891
“By five minutes.”	333.797575457443
“Yes; but in certain circumstances five minutes are five ages.”	447.0005779985943
“When one loves.”	341.3619963667991
“Well! And who told you I had no affair with a lover?”	389.43440270102656
“It is a man, then, who expects you?” cried D’Artagnan. “A man!”	342.63495615603756
“The discussion is going to begin again!” said Mme. Bonacieux, with a	395.79580104804654
half-smile which was not exempt from a tinge of impatience.	465.4123365620621
“No, no; I go, I depart! I believe in you, and I would have all the	305.49530637572883
merit of my devotion, even if that devotion were stupidity. Adieu,	312.3333947895135
madame, adieu!”	368.2112089775858
And as if he only felt strength to detach himself by a violent effort	491.7832498641402
from the hand he held, he sprang away, running, while Mme. Bonacieux	388.6137955301197
knocked, as at the shutter, three light and regular taps. When he had	400.86348208640936
gained the angle of the street, he turned. The door had been opened,	487.2395211556735
and shut again; the mercer’s pretty wife had disappeared.	368.2586621268664
D’Artagnan pursued his way. He had given his word not to watch Mme.	324.58979401493514
Bonacieux, and if his life had depended upon the spot to which she was	391.2800620541293
going or upon the person who should accompany her, D’Artagnan would	366.87874126450646
have returned home, since he had so promised. Five minutes later he was	458.0616934153918
in the Rue des Fossoyeurs.	411.375470391147
“Poor Athos!” said he; “he will never guess what all this means. He	346.403296058415
will have fallen asleep waiting for me, or else he will have returned	445.7058586218342
home, where he will have learned that a woman had been there. A woman	434.1946290347602
with Athos! After all,” continued D’Artagnan, “there was certainly one	488.71726404011974
with Aramis. All this is very strange; and I am curious to know how it	336.7466136408272
will end.”	401.56164429773753
“Badly, monsieur, badly!” replied a voice which the young man	344.286762179383
recognized as that of Planchet; for, soliloquizing aloud, as very	293.83237827847364
preoccupied people do, he had entered the alley, at the end of which	448.7842173146203
were the stairs which led to his chamber.	295.4382069606845
“How, badly? What do you mean by that, you idiot?” asked D’Artagnan.	491.54096176845735
“What has happened?”	352.556138966714
“All sorts of misfortunes.”	313.47833245158455
“What?”	366.9946164611611
“In the first place, Monsieur Athos is arrested.”	475.4098041097013
“Arrested! Athos arrested! What for?”	456.5053703603252
“He was found in your lodging; they took him for you.”	345.28834315057486
“And by whom was he arrested?”	347.39716139255506
“By Guards brought by the men in black whom you put to flight.”	478.2829910684321
“Why did he not tell them his name? Why did he not tell them he knew	396.8710633091117
nothing about this affair?”	440.49835002997463
“He took care not to do so, monsieur; on the contrary, he came up to me	404.16979851090395
and said, ‘It is your master that needs his liberty at this moment and	411.0799707453539
not I, since he knows everything and I know nothing. They will believe	430.1202890155364
he is arrested, and that will give him time; in three days I will tell	358.8679641391384
them who I am, and they cannot fail to let me go.’”	480.08692758704393
“Bravo, Athos! Noble heart!” murmured D’Artagnan. “I know him well	416.66314775349616
there! And what did the officers do?”	307.62511416174254
“Four conveyed him away, I don’t know where—to the Bastille or Fort	482.79339961866447
l’Evêque. Two remained with the men in black, who rummaged every place	336.39067431718536
and took all the papers. The last two mounted guard at the door during	424.4653979878044
this examination; then, when all was over, they went away, leaving the	410.2728056163355
house empty and exposed.”	415.6391017443417
“And Porthos and Aramis?”	299.52766793127813
“I could not find them; they did not come.”	390.61457354771915
“But they may come any moment, for you left word that I awaited them?”	305.9904692187172
“Yes, monsieur.”	454.52277823698654
“Well, don’t budge, then; if they come, tell them what has happened.	387.87681447865987
Let them wait for me at the Pomme-de-Pin. Here it would be dangerous;	442.43422781255794
the house may be watched. I will run to Monsieur de Tréville to tell	339.6657710105348
them all this, and will meet them there.”	448.7924664046929
“Very well, monsieur,” said Planchet.	339.65783849353477
“But you will remain; you are not afraid?” said D’Artagnan, coming back	412.04280827717747
to recommend courage to his lackey.	443.0320467396541
“Be easy, monsieur,” said Planchet; “you do not know me yet. I am brave	449.3851154536259
when I set about it. It is all in beginning. Besides, I am a Picard.”	300.746944833893
“Then it is understood,” said D’Artagnan; “you would rather be killed	428.7582335155123
than desert your post?”	317.5722013985997
“Yes, monsieur; and there is nothing I would not do to prove to	366.9261227627504
Monsieur that I am attached to him.”	359.4182331244843
“Good!” said D’Artagnan to himself. “It appears that the method I have	421.40600468840495
adopted with this boy is decidedly the best. I shall use it again upon	292.9583457717164
occasion.”	391.21701587558334
And with all the swiftness of his legs, already a little fatigued,	313.6015519193055
however, with the perambulations of the day, D’Artagnan directed his	425.89642041338266
course toward M. de Tréville’s.	491.1988900481184
M. de Tréville was not at his hôtel. His company was on guard at the	423.1842641143652
Louvre; he was at the Louvre with his company.	397.86326698395305
It was necessary to reach M. de Tréville; it was important that he	394.92222994034285
should be informed of what was passing. D’Artagnan resolved to try and	381.5600157701307
enter the Louvre. His costume of Guardsman in the company of M.	311.2792291353543
Dessessart ought to be his passport.	381.13478151616386
He therefore went down the Rue des Petits Augustins, and came up to the	354.760112610802
quay, in order to take the New Bridge. He had at first an idea of	398.4300692403481
crossing by the ferry; but on gaining the riverside, he had	377.39318570278357
mechanically put his hand into his pocket, and perceived that he had	319.31428106089135
not wherewithal to pay his passage.	400.1898644397081
As he gained the top of the Rue Guénegaud, he saw two persons coming	346.76381346744347
out of the Rue Dauphine whose appearance very much struck him. Of the	303.96887526140296
two persons who composed this group, one was a man and the other a	328.9362227572813
woman. The woman had the outline of Mme. Bonacieux; the man resembled	389.2443752779394
Aramis so much as to be mistaken for him.	353.92351072585654
Besides, the woman wore that black mantle which D’Artagnan could still	321.9408504670514
see outlined on the shutter of the Rue de Vaugirard and on the door of	307.1779464666677
the Rue de la Harpe; still further, the man wore the uniform of a	376.4784627094145
Musketeer.	438.050819894066
The woman’s hood was pulled down, and the man held a handkerchief to	413.40076992550865
his face. Both, as this double precaution indicated, had an interest in	325.92516362678793
not being recognized.	357.9639003572006
They took the bridge. That was D’Artagnan’s road, as he was going to	332.71051939985296
the Louvre. D’Artagnan followed them.	374.50139034326673
He had not gone twenty steps before he became convinced that the woman	413.7697201194993
was really Mme. Bonacieux and that the man was Aramis.	317.54771523229726
He felt at that instant all the suspicions of jealousy agitating his	339.9239638402612
heart. He felt himself doubly betrayed, by his friend and by her whom	380.3035710996839
he already loved like a mistress. Mme. Bonacieux had declared to him,	316.0527986690858
by all the gods, that she did not know Aramis; and a quarter of an hour	394.4151465764018
after having made this assertion, he found her hanging on the arm of	491.78080006651703
Aramis.	459.0117933810434
D’Artagnan did not reflect that he had only known the mercer’s pretty	297.5106433967697
wife for three hours; that she owed him nothing but a little gratitude	320.22055010548684
for having delivered her from the men in black, who wished to carry her	297.0455638997776
off, and that she had promised him nothing. He considered himself an	487.1083906798615
outraged, betrayed, and ridiculed lover. Blood and anger mounted to his	349.29276844691003
face; he was resolved to unravel the mystery.	345.0172459557505
The young man and young woman perceived they were watched, and	311.6539163727647
redoubled their speed. D’Artagnan determined upon his course. He passed	447.7046144707845
them, then returned so as to meet them exactly before the Samaritaine,	336.21624941608366
which was illuminated by a lamp which threw its light over all that	466.345498498535
part of the bridge.	345.10413530858574
D’Artagnan stopped before them, and they stopped before him.	319.1637616251317
“What do you want, monsieur?” demanded the Musketeer, recoiling a step,	320.133330917872
and with a foreign accent, which proved to D’Artagnan that he was	476.61161300762467
deceived in one of his conjectures.	421.22906227426745
“It is not Aramis!” cried he.	430.7225581906131
“No, monsieur, it is not Aramis; and by your exclamation I perceive you	415.63758531605265
have mistaken me for another, and pardon you.”	356.2975677457495
“You pardon me?” cried D’Artagnan.	482.32056726740007
“Yes,” replied the stranger. “Allow me, then, to pass on, since it is	401.13059025254165
not with me you have anything to do.”	445.91120751037465
“You are right, monsieur, it is not with you that I have anything to	404.4662470215096
do; it is with Madame.”	459.37508773546386
“With Madame! You do not know her,” replied the stranger.	376.4651978418322
“You are deceived, monsieur; I know her very well.”	439.2025977458848
“Ah,” said Mme. Bonacieux; in a tone of reproach, “ah, monsieur, I had	377.11207118616176
your promise as a soldier and your word as a gentleman. I hoped to be	486.6512120058079
able to rely upon that.”	430.96587661659294
“And I, madame!” said D’Artagnan, embarrassed; “you promised me—”	360.24765229236505
“Take my arm, madame,” said the stranger, “and let us continue our	386.0745660387418
way.”	403.0310212642338
D’Artagnan, however, stupefied, cast down, annihilated by all that	336.65137920995085
happened, stood, with crossed arms, before the Musketeer and Mme.	378.7352562066258
Bonacieux.	466.67251996429064
The Musketeer advanced two steps, and pushed D’Artagnan aside with his	479.44596316438765
hand. D’Artagnan made a spring backward and drew his sword. At the same	345.69975702727714
time, and with the rapidity of lightning, the stranger drew his.	317.93929063266415
“In the name of heaven, my Lord!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, throwing	476.72689806470896
herself between the combatants and seizing the swords with her hands.	326.05353419692744
“My Lord!” cried D’Artagnan, enlightened by a sudden idea, “my Lord!	433.4270967343411
Pardon me, monsieur, but you are not—”	473.2051797459456
“My Lord the Duke of Buckingham,” said Mme. Bonacieux, in an undertone;	331.0003450113885
“and now you may ruin us all.”	319.5934126587297
“My Lord, Madame, I ask a hundred pardons! But I love her, my Lord, and	463.63169839376997
was jealous. You know what it is to love, my Lord. Pardon me, and then	311.3061903381557
tell me how I can risk my life to serve your Grace?”	488.90317034314734
“You are a brave young man,” said Buckingham, holding out his hand to	424.378708670847
D’Artagnan, who pressed it respectfully. “You offer me your services;	417.7051428774094
with the same frankness I accept them. Follow us at a distance of	363.77178397152335
twenty paces, as far as the Louvre, and if anyone watches us, slay	353.5416873581295
him!”	324.71192745887345
D’Artagnan placed his naked sword under his arm, allowed the duke and	472.55006433000653
Mme. Bonacieux to take twenty steps ahead, and then followed them,	417.3379371791784
ready to execute the instructions of the noble and elegant minister of	318.0272096580673
Charles I.	388.5262689601013
Fortunately, he had no opportunity to give the duke this proof of his	442.62381209446335
devotion, and the young woman and the handsome Musketeer entered the	340.0038878744681
Louvre by the wicket of the Echelle without any interference.	366.32306261932786
As for D’Artagnan, he immediately repaired to the cabaret of the	453.9813849981168
Pomme-de-Pin, where he found Porthos and Aramis awaiting him. Without	350.07406330997856
giving them any explanation of the alarm and inconvenience he had	440.0335391427377
caused them, he told them that he had terminated the affair alone in	418.7171819783698
which he had for a moment believed he should need their assistance.	376.4797258869114
Meanwhile, carried away as we are by our narrative, we must leave our	335.5463397853408
three friends to themselves, and follow the Duke of Buckingham and his	300.1068529035092
guide through the labyrinths of the Louvre.	415.23350303500445
Chapter XII.	405.3263912020534
GEORGE VILLIERS, DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM	464.7390421638131
Mme. Bonacieux and the duke entered the Louvre without difficulty. Mme.	347.488446288896
Bonacieux was known to belong to the queen; the duke wore the uniform	321.145285256319
of the Musketeers of M. de Tréville, who, as we have said, were that	329.20932153539115
evening on guard. Besides, Germain was in the interests of the queen;	352.7185506139653
and if anything should happen, Mme. Bonacieux would be accused of	455.86374740904506
having introduced her lover into the Louvre, that was all. She took the	481.7444861702767
risk upon herself. Her reputation would be lost, it is true; but of	303.6316325664105
what value in the world was the reputation of the little wife of a	343.8118969238293
mercer?	393.49380408914317
Once within the interior of the court, the duke and the young woman	449.359139918589
followed the wall for the space of about twenty-five steps. This space	327.6886736043564
passed, Mme. Bonacieux pushed a little servants’ door, open by day but	391.2193453259947
generally closed at night. The door yielded. Both entered, and found	472.2544413982589
themselves in darkness; but Mme. Bonacieux was acquainted with all the	316.78523539323055
turnings and windings of this part of the Louvre, appropriated for the	302.6618987844235
people of the household. She closed the door after her, took the duke	444.5294079027827
by the hand, and after a few experimental steps, grasped a balustrade,	444.71835186560554
put her foot upon the bottom step, and began to ascend the staircase.	339.31366821408585
The duke counted two stories. She then turned to the right, followed	385.1608545380382
the course of a long corridor, descended a flight, went a few steps	326.20520166412854
farther, introduced a key into a lock, opened a door, and pushed the	362.09797651596546
duke into an apartment lighted only by a lamp, saying, “Remain here, my	318.21039638515737
Lord Duke; someone will come.” She then went out by the same door,	328.37277761712335
which she locked, so that the duke found himself literally a prisoner.	327.45638138061787
Nevertheless, isolated as he was, we must say that the Duke of	385.66561609835236
Buckingham did not experience an instant of fear. One of the salient	378.6188545738332
points of his character was the search for adventures and a love of	420.63837708671633
romance. Brave, rash, and enterprising, this was not the first time he	407.6257735088396
had risked his life in such attempts. He had learned that the pretended	451.5715137584333
message from Anne of Austria, upon the faith of which he had come to	414.8266587905967
Paris, was a snare; but instead of regaining England, he had, abusing	319.8710061278383
the position in which he had been placed, declared to the queen that he	356.53260378943156
would not depart without seeing her. The queen had at first positively	412.32927502431556
refused; but at length became afraid that the duke, if exasperated,	383.39290578154805
would commit some folly. She had already decided upon seeing him and	399.22527982555187
urging his immediate departure, when, on the very evening of coming to	463.61932493054815
this decision, Mme. Bonacieux, who was charged with going to fetch the	429.1565070775881
duke and conducting him to the Louvre, was abducted. For two days no	356.9334647063978
one knew what had become of her, and everything remained in suspense;	394.97718165571587
but once free, and placed in communication with Laporte, matters	433.74122101267136
resumed their course, and she accomplished the perilous enterprise	457.0134910673256
which, but for her arrest, would have been executed three days earlier.	480.63846207704603
Buckingham, left alone, walked toward a mirror. His Musketeer’s uniform	309.0554896663368
became him marvelously.	324.90026756683665
At thirty-five, which was then his age, he passed, with just title, for	405.6924741039985
the handsomest gentleman and the most elegant cavalier of France or	404.63706277966435
England.	296.54371085073086
The favorite of two kings, immensely rich, all-powerful in a kingdom	481.6235500041862
which he disordered at his fancy and calmed again at his caprice,	480.436056353719
George Villiers, Duke of Buckingham, had lived one of those fabulous	459.7586838965535
existences which survive, in the course of centuries, to astonish	405.5880805694766
posterity.	377.2602854122047
Sure of himself, convinced of his own power, certain that the laws	484.5616486658209
which rule other men could not reach him, he went straight to the	410.1213439283607
object he aimed at, even were this object so elevated and so dazzling	309.9573515871753
that it would have been madness for any other even to have contemplated	464.6650588488907
it. It was thus he had succeeded in approaching several times the	295.9321060760093
beautiful and proud Anne of Austria, and in making himself loved by	422.85932610687746
dazzling her.	292.9298363535491
George Villiers placed himself before the glass, as we have said,	351.750692590838
restored the undulations to his beautiful hair, which the weight of his	490.10404938143006
hat had disordered, twisted his mustache, and, his heart swelling with	343.1853054033145
joy, happy and proud at being near the moment he had so long sighed	420.1789155989183
for, he smiled upon himself with pride and hope.	433.66161245086244
At this moment a door concealed in the tapestry opened, and a woman	315.36017371624314
appeared. Buckingham saw this apparition in the glass; he uttered a	302.5958976255713
cry. It was the queen!	299.9764237341716
Anne of Austria was then twenty-six or twenty-seven years of age; that	385.6755401882356
is to say, she was in the full splendor of her beauty.	346.5015430222415
Her carriage was that of a queen or a goddess; her eyes, which cast the	476.5033347599673
brilliancy of emeralds, were perfectly beautiful, and yet were at the	349.9744218130268
same time full of sweetness and majesty.	468.99569988487224
Her mouth was small and rosy; and although her underlip, like that of	390.9815952625852
all princes of the House of Austria, protruded slightly beyond the	386.94537629220895
other, it was eminently lovely in its smile, but as profoundly	369.3339559090182
disdainful in its contempt.	331.5917593933366
Her skin was admired for its velvety softness; her hands and arms were	470.99923277283295
of surpassing beauty, all the poets of the time singing them as	359.15296441383396
incomparable.	476.1961682795397
Lastly, her hair, which, from being light in her youth, had become	325.9873079311037
chestnut, and which she wore curled very plainly, and with much powder,	351.5213975996854
admirably set off her face, in which the most rigid critic could only	358.1523182063831
have desired a little less rouge, and the most fastidious sculptor a	317.5299854831268
little more fineness in the nose.	335.29105855486733
Buckingham remained for a moment dazzled. Never had Anne of Austria	370.80598134621005
appeared to him so beautiful, amid balls, fêtes, or carousals, as she	340.23676072806535
appeared to him at this moment, dressed in a simple robe of white	362.52806978336037
satin, and accompanied by Donna Estafania—the only one of her Spanish	447.876441730676
women who had not been driven from her by the jealousy of the king or	389.0953353939044
by the persecutions of Richelieu.	438.25441141435834
Anne of Austria took two steps forward. Buckingham threw himself at her	323.83429538279927
feet, and before the queen could prevent him, kissed the hem of her	450.1712463864369
robe.	430.1136316829944
“Duke, you already know that it is not I who caused you to be written	475.54292804618046
to.”	437.0517553279259
“Yes, yes, madame! Yes, your Majesty!” cried the duke. “I know that I	330.08716925121394
must have been mad, senseless, to believe that snow would become	317.04991093695844
animated or marble warm; but what then! They who love believe easily in	338.3224421080197
love. Besides, I have lost nothing by this journey because I see you.”	400.84950908111205
“Yes,” replied Anne, “but you know why and how I see you; because,	388.51610871409616
insensible to all my sufferings, you persist in remaining in a city	432.64298731333645
where, by remaining, you run the risk of your life, and make me run the	302.58027467565637
risk of my honor. I see you to tell you that everything separates	420.0075514594064
us—the depths of the sea, the enmity of kingdoms, the sanctity of vows.	424.7663297772939
It is sacrilege to struggle against so many things, my Lord. In short,	409.8112528571029
I see you to tell you that we must never see each other again.”	391.90223481448743
“Speak on, madame, speak on, Queen,” said Buckingham; “the sweetness of	337.46257080594637
your voice covers the harshness of your words. You talk of sacrilege!	342.1451154751929
Why, the sacrilege is the separation of two hearts formed by God for	299.1022809081752
each other.”	294.15335052194865
“My Lord,” cried the queen, “you forget that I have never said that I	461.419260746291
love you.”	394.231191802781
“But you have never told me that you did not love me; and truly, to	370.9160734553394
speak such words to me would be, on the part of your Majesty, too great	411.4582797863285
an ingratitude. For tell me, where can you find a love like mine—a love	488.4603973973331
which neither time, nor absence, nor despair can extinguish, a love	406.5951028733521
which contents itself with a lost ribbon, a stray look, or a chance	488.1244949349606
word? It is now three years, madame, since I saw you for the first	319.2250967195805
time, and during those three years I have loved you thus. Shall I tell	449.6359273277845
you each ornament of your toilet? Mark! I see you now. You were seated	426.545726110989
upon cushions in the Spanish fashion; you wore a robe of green satin	410.21091778886426
embroidered with gold and silver, hanging sleeves knotted upon your	381.3412727270002
beautiful arms—those lovely arms—with large diamonds. You wore a close	409.4516227164143
ruff, a small cap upon your head of the same color as your robe, and in	408.8575972812852
that cap a heron’s feather. Hold! Hold! I shut my eyes, and I can see	318.18175975616276
you as you then were; I open them again, and I see what you are now—a	488.4709834845628
hundred times more beautiful!”	437.2520351142597
“What folly,” murmured Anne of Austria, who had not the courage to find	431.04844980872235
fault with the duke for having so well preserved her portrait in his	316.91978543367213
heart, “what folly to feed a useless passion with such remembrances!”	342.1504840074336
“And upon what then must I live? I have nothing but memory. It is my	293.4105035705203
happiness, my treasure, my hope. Every time I see you is a fresh	462.524667240064
diamond which I enclose in the casket of my heart. This is the fourth	303.097607505228
which you have let fall and I have picked up; for in three years,	418.2776820641086
madame, I have only seen you four times—the first, which I have	405.39151596719705
described to you; the second, at the mansion of Madame de Chevreuse;	383.53027347669376
the third, in the gardens of Amiens.”	410.7029888588391
“Duke,” said the queen, blushing, “never speak of that evening.”	390.63143558849526
“Oh, let us speak of it; on the contrary, let us speak of it! That is	474.8386051528415
the most happy and brilliant evening of my life! You remember what a	367.2469376739724
beautiful night it was? How soft and perfumed was the air; how lovely	292.50653476554356
the blue heavens and star-enameled sky! Ah, then, madame, I was able	488.7519996975326
for one instant to be alone with you. Then you were about to tell me	302.39064779391657
all—the isolation of your life, the griefs of your heart. You leaned	418.1857633416681
upon my arm—upon this, madame! I felt, in bending my head toward you,	388.5509449116453
your beautiful hair touch my cheek; and every time that it touched me I	359.4861197158543
trembled from head to foot. Oh, Queen! Queen! You do not know what	351.1652917738134
felicity from heaven, what joys from paradise, are comprised in a	366.77747775291135
moment like that. Take my wealth, my fortune, my glory, all the days I	316.7922803940156
have to live, for such an instant, for a night like that. For that	296.90499557363677
night, madame, that night you loved me, I will swear it.”	345.27914352486545
“My Lord, yes; it is possible that the influence of the place, the	377.0615282779458
charm of the beautiful evening, the fascination of your look—the	407.8107012218397
thousand circumstances, in short, which sometimes unite to destroy a	471.053033397921
woman—were grouped around me on that fatal evening; but, my Lord, you	435.76036107163617
saw the queen come to the aid of the woman who faltered. At the first	478.38087356936535
word you dared to utter, at the first freedom to which I had to reply,	464.02362586088867
I called for help.”	312.0128771746774
“Yes, yes, that is true. And any other love but mine would have sunk	483.7714646707843
beneath this ordeal; but my love came out from it more ardent and more	423.4563218211358
eternal. You believed that you would fly from me by returning to Paris;	440.363300494634
you believed that I would not dare to quit the treasure over which my	376.2425226272604
master had charged me to watch. What to me were all the treasures in	427.1019247069472
the world, or all the kings of the earth! Eight days after, I was back	417.37150180014675
again, madame. That time you had nothing to say to me; I had risked my	476.98834793474515
life and favor to see you but for a second. I did not even touch your	477.4274845210963
hand, and you pardoned me on seeing me so submissive and so repentant.”	433.2855070956442
“Yes, but calumny seized upon all those follies in which I took no	308.2390478998576
part, as you well know, my Lord. The king, excited by the cardinal,	398.06835797585734
made a terrible clamor. Madame de Vernet was driven from me, Putange	474.97743110515125
was exiled, Madame de Chevreuse fell into disgrace, and when you wished	395.6178724480045
to come back as ambassador to France, the king himself—remember, my	309.688451436028
lord—the king himself opposed it.”	446.1512792626113
“Yes, and France is about to pay for her king’s refusal with a war. I	367.3514252203604
am not allowed to see you, madame, but you shall every day hear of me.	422.32718307085975
What object, think you, have this expedition to Ré and this league with	453.12190993000956
the Protestants of La Rochelle which I am projecting? The pleasure of	398.1963385364873
seeing you. I have no hope of penetrating, sword in hand, to Paris, I	353.1544061493007
know that well. But this war may bring round a peace; this peace will	342.83860316716294
require a negotiator; that negotiator will be me. They will not dare to	455.35444428996135
refuse me then; and I will return to Paris, and will see you again, and	400.07847951121
will be happy for an instant. Thousands of men, it is true, will have	297.80991602910166
to pay for my happiness with their lives; but what is that to me,	403.38835214062027
provided I see you again! All this is perhaps folly—perhaps insanity;	481.6786515766372
but tell me what woman has a lover more truly in love; what queen a	426.7051273736259
servant more ardent?”	422.7951809829067
“My Lord, my Lord, you invoke in your defense things which accuse you	405.6573502033439
more strongly. All these proofs of love which you would give me are	433.68309525556595
almost crimes.”	302.829908416914
“Because you do not love me, madame! If you loved me, you would view	464.66164142381547
all this otherwise. If you loved me, oh, if you loved me, that would be	418.4087886522472
too great happiness, and I should run mad. Ah, Madame de Chevreuse was	447.954276913258
less cruel than you. Holland loved her, and she responded to his love.”	371.21582962695254
“Madame de Chevreuse was not queen,” murmured Anne of Austria,	299.4121103770678
overcome, in spite of herself, by the expression of so profound a	339.54098726577047
passion.	474.4833150549903
“You would love me, then, if you were not queen! Madame, say that you	435.7396937964331
would love me then! I can believe that it is the dignity of your rank	346.30719492690224
alone which makes you cruel to me; I can believe that, had you been	346.35042285789484
Madame de Chevreuse, poor Buckingham might have hoped. Thanks for those	377.17592038894014
sweet words! Oh, my beautiful sovereign, a hundred times, thanks!”	305.1562483003676
“Oh, my Lord! You have ill understood, wrongly interpreted; I did not	411.88302915929387
mean to say—”	338.17184848584105
“Silence, silence!” cried the duke. “If I am happy in an error, do not	368.9629242878031
have the cruelty to lift me from it. You have told me yourself, madame,	383.1480287267074
that I have been drawn into a snare; I, perhaps, may leave my life in	390.75083524081333
it—for, although it may be strange, I have for some time had a	387.7025862829519
presentiment that I should shortly die.” And the duke smiled, with a	454.7372372859602
smile at once sad and charming.	334.4634101591993
“Oh, my God!” cried Anne of Austria, with an accent of terror which	368.3806956546789
proved how much greater an interest she took in the duke than she	295.4131416623288
ventured to tell.	325.2538915895192
“I do not tell you this, madame, to terrify you; no, it is even	440.66493693853977
ridiculous for me to name it to you, and, believe me, I take no heed of	336.5649788398306
such dreams. But the words you have just spoken, the hope you have	359.0412245860813
almost given me, will have richly paid all—were it my life.”	330.1447064229893
“Oh, but I,” said Anne, “I also, duke, have had presentiments; I also	312.0349902630208
have had dreams. I dreamed that I saw you lying bleeding, wounded.”	394.7829322459533
“In the left side, was it not, and with a knife?” interrupted	404.7912261361878
Buckingham.	293.7066236909255
“Yes, it was so, my Lord, it was so—in the left side, and with a knife.	396.3670278704892
Who can possibly have told you I had had that dream? I have imparted it	456.4650286782705
to no one but my God, and that in my prayers.”	398.7625463862872
“I ask for no more. You love me, madame; it is enough.”	351.8575304081063
“I love you, I?”	407.38753338528034
“Yes, yes. Would God send the same dreams to you as to me if you did	391.3110511067469
not love me? Should we have the same presentiments if our existences	370.79214812856276
did not touch at the heart? You love me, my beautiful queen, and you	437.6183276304711
will weep for me?”	302.05758942971084
“Oh, my God, my God!” cried Anne of Austria, “this is more than I can	452.7732792595035
bear. In the name of heaven, Duke, leave me, go! I do not know whether	462.84680835131826
I love you or love you not; but what I know is that I will not be	454.4952114580675
perjured. Take pity on me, then, and go! Oh, if you are struck in	354.3300642811577
France, if you die in France, if I could imagine that your love for me	303.0232374510965
was the cause of your death, I could not console myself; I should run	310.0768754922479
mad. Depart then, depart, I implore you!”	318.49005404630975
“Oh, how beautiful you are thus! Oh, how I love you!” said Buckingham.	459.62685675459716
“Go, go, I implore you, and return hereafter! Come back as ambassador,	436.22754293523064
come back as minister, come back surrounded with guards who will defend	292.9643786730078
you, with servants who will watch over you, and then I shall no longer	357.9901756045743
fear for your days, and I shall be happy in seeing you.”	471.86076418909374
“Oh, is this true what you say?”	346.6825991556246
“Yes.”	416.324445670478
“Oh, then, some pledge of your indulgence, some object which came from	316.2567512912393
you, and may remind me that I have not been dreaming; something you	336.17414638369763
have worn, and that I may wear in my turn—a ring, a necklace, a chain.”	392.2033465818712
“Will you depart—will you depart, if I give you that you demand?”	362.9914201546817
“Yes.”	454.1216776161714
“This very instant?”	449.48714851069644
“Yes.”	401.5141263511483
“You will leave France, you will return to England?”	485.44461800535737
“I will, I swear to you.”	312.8181654979794
“Wait, then, wait.”	371.49866720351446
Anne of Austria re-entered her apartment, and came out again almost	482.12295183239985
immediately, holding a rosewood casket in her hand, with her cipher	412.18040936883864
encrusted with gold.	370.81239937155425
“Here, my Lord, here,” said she, “keep this in memory of me.”	313.76528534469566
Buckingham took the casket, and fell a second time on his knees.	450.78488070509536
“You have promised me to go,” said the queen.	316.9647304614482
“And I keep my word. Your hand, madame, your hand, and I depart!”	472.1910864032154
Anne of Austria stretched forth her hand, closing her eyes, and leaning	456.6220589669068
with the other upon Estafania, for she felt that her strength was about	435.55691750886797
to fail her.	406.622379638991
Buckingham pressed his lips passionately to that beautiful hand, and	448.17659612283876
then rising, said, “Within six months, if I am not dead, I shall have	451.00811703877457
seen you again, madame—even if I have to overturn the world.” And	336.999509448771
faithful to the promise he had made, he rushed out of the apartment.	315.88112100207513
In the corridor he met Mme. Bonacieux, who waited for him, and who,	332.10101619245245
with the same precautions and the same good luck, conducted him out of	351.9559174327855
the Louvre.	339.8736301022636
Chapter XIII.	405.733037059706
MONSIEUR BONACIEUX	480.3201216681692
There was in all this, as may have been observed, one personage	414.6635776509873
concerned, of whom, notwithstanding his precarious position, we have	360.6353550635938
appeared to take but very little notice. This personage was M.	446.0407973537299
Bonacieux, the respectable martyr of the political and amorous	464.7424556985585
intrigues which entangled themselves so nicely together at this gallant	355.8977467014154
and chivalric period.	483.98960668642894
Fortunately, the reader may remember, or may not remember—fortunately	432.8053014534819
we have promised not to lose sight of him.	387.2774708565357
The officers who arrested him conducted him straight to the Bastille,	480.14445637222826
where he passed trembling before a party of soldiers who were loading	441.0029440669956
their muskets. Thence, introduced into a half-subterranean gallery, he	475.03552292040456
became, on the part of those who had brought him, the object of the	389.48768959187305
grossest insults and the harshest treatment. The officers perceived	379.97885537189865
that they had not to deal with a gentleman, and they treated him like a	401.43478471295174
very peasant.	404.5666506812912
At the end of half an hour or thereabouts, a clerk came to put an end	317.50649466985163
to his tortures, but not to his anxiety, by giving the order to conduct	369.6560329581812
M. Bonacieux to the Chamber of Examination. Ordinarily, prisoners were	310.5699929256669
interrogated in their cells; but they did not do so with M. Bonacieux.	328.75797328037515
Two guards attended the mercer who made him traverse a court and enter	303.50133922464215
a corridor in which were three sentinels, opened a door and pushed him	459.91198430450015
unceremoniously into a low room, where the only furniture was a table,	376.0258381105047
a chair, and a commissary. The commissary was seated in the chair, and	449.45730126768
was writing at the table.	385.3599486167215
The two guards led the prisoner toward the table, and upon a sign from	316.34138965177965
the commissary drew back so far as to be unable to hear anything.	381.0067384558246
The commissary, who had till this time held his head down over his	476.9563693603461
papers, looked up to see what sort of person he had to do with. This	426.0152515871531
commissary was a man of very repulsive mien, with a pointed nose, with	445.17428313260393
yellow and salient cheek bones, with eyes small but keen and	400.4885580908479
penetrating, and an expression of countenance resembling at once the	342.28373936125564
polecat and the fox. His head, supported by a long and flexible neck,	385.68629592278097
issued from his large black robe, balancing itself with a motion very	469.9251300419209
much like that of the tortoise thrusting his head out of his shell. He	351.01873258664295
began by asking M. Bonacieux his name, age, condition, and abode.	399.6577219436022
The accused replied that his name was Jacques Michel Bonacieux, that he	353.9369143504167
was fifty-one years old, a retired mercer, and lived Rue des	321.4581079783775
Fossoyeurs, No. 14.	368.01349164583155
The commissary then, instead of continuing to interrogate him, made him	418.9826891353406
a long speech upon the danger there is for an obscure citizen to meddle	371.08034734961694
with public matters. He complicated this exordium by an exposition in	483.75886644723954
which he painted the power and the deeds of the cardinal, that	355.1180102487002
incomparable minister, that conqueror of past ministers, that example	410.98437756728237
for ministers to come—deeds and power which none could thwart with	479.5066178626531
impunity.	433.5131379895464
After this second part of his discourse, fixing his hawk’s eye upon	302.884539085931
poor Bonacieux, he bade him reflect upon the gravity of his situation.	392.66746130420717
The reflections of the mercer were already made; he cursed the instant	427.6902526683407
when M. Laporte formed the idea of marrying him to his goddaughter, and	320.2240883808356
particularly the moment when that goddaughter had been received as Lady	306.18944046124943
of the Linen to her Majesty.	303.7530311319016
At bottom the character of M. Bonacieux was one of profound selfishness	482.8907117892819
mixed with sordid avarice, the whole seasoned with extreme cowardice.	436.00696371328127
The love with which his young wife had inspired him was a secondary	488.2316673035939
sentiment, and was not strong enough to contend with the primitive	386.4223211992131
feelings we have just enumerated. Bonacieux indeed reflected on what	333.43905150862867
had just been said to him.	385.90552486861736
“But, Monsieur Commissary,” said he, calmly, “believe that I know and	321.006159821372
appreciate, more than anybody, the merit of the incomparable eminence	354.08976132784625
by whom we have the honor to be governed.”	390.79539390925186
“Indeed?” asked the commissary, with an air of doubt. “If that is	327.7637624418457
really so, how came you in the Bastille?”	481.27962165692804
“How I came there, or rather why I am there,” replied Bonacieux, “that	421.25269273885897
is entirely impossible for me to tell you, because I don’t know myself;	344.39270792194833
but to a certainty it is not for having, knowingly at least, disobliged	331.5083087759326
Monsieur the Cardinal.”	469.5406736714556
“You must, nevertheless, have committed a crime, since you are here and	408.0744172836184
are accused of high treason.”	348.5458934992448
“Of high treason!” cried Bonacieux, terrified; “of high treason! How is	466.9890116926191
it possible for a poor mercer, who detests Huguenots and who abhors	304.33488692122836
Spaniards, to be accused of high treason? Consider, monsieur, the thing	470.1941526987861
is absolutely impossible.”	432.8522886183197
“Monsieur Bonacieux,” said the commissary, looking at the accused as if	394.8999605814971
his little eyes had the faculty of reading to the very depths of	456.9807981695061
hearts, “you have a wife?”	445.60406221553137
“Yes, monsieur,” replied the mercer, in a tremble, feeling that it was	366.1885865219316
at this point affairs were likely to become perplexing; “that is to	439.08621124417886
say, I _had_ one.”	364.2064821660507
“What, you ‘_had_ one’? What have you done with her, then, if you have	435.62154070596966
her no longer?”	316.2905588404723
“They have abducted her, monsieur.”	480.8845732571948
“They have abducted her? Ah!”	472.5993737521462
Bonacieux inferred from this “Ah” that the affair grew more and more	338.5652553551285
intricate.	382.34379847545176
“They have abducted her,” added the commissary; “and do you know the	413.65073410333946
man who has committed this deed?”	351.46523339389097
“I think I know him.”	368.400516522887
“Who is he?”	447.99317488451754
“Remember that I affirm nothing, Monsieur the Commissary, and that I	440.49672227067407
only suspect.”	427.3907142599629
“Whom do you suspect? Come, answer freely.”	292.68226241811124
M. Bonacieux was in the greatest perplexity possible. Had he better	477.8824057116069
deny everything or tell everything? By denying all, it might be	336.3534389921983
suspected that he must know too much to avow; by confessing all he	465.11129291174586
might prove his good will. He decided, then, to tell all.	362.47624210998686
“I suspect,” said he, “a tall, dark man, of lofty carriage, who has the	460.9825394173584
