air of a great lord. He has followed us several times, as I think, when	340.3287654117475
I have waited for my wife at the wicket of the Louvre to escort her	310.8475358060412
home.”	409.76233718574395
The commissary now appeared to experience a little uneasiness.	349.7795953406253
“And his name?” said he.	475.35309101880614
“Oh, as to his name, I know nothing about it; but if I were ever to	359.6616263064996
meet him, I should recognize him in an instant, I will answer for it,	408.37505588488017
were he among a thousand persons.”	464.76336665923293
The face of the commissary grew still darker.	384.882728017169
“You should recognize him among a thousand, say you?” continued he.	400.03925873012327
“That is to say,” cried Bonacieux, who saw he had taken a false step,	328.9357814539289
“that is to say—”	462.4383695906113
“You have answered that you should recognize him,” said the commissary.	340.1051128128137
“That is all very well, and enough for today; before we proceed	292.96574557819076
further, someone must be informed that you know the ravisher of your	456.24441802538104
wife.”	472.87410970177575
“But I have not told you that I know him!” cried Bonacieux, in despair.	377.428599452914
“I told you, on the contrary—”	438.9819978793324
“Take away the prisoner,” said the commissary to the two guards.	341.33331957134857
“Where must we place him?” demanded the chief.	407.3591889087726
“In a dungeon.”	465.5124574795253
“Which?”	422.3040138125367
“Good Lord! In the first one handy, provided it is safe,” said the	396.16743399081395
commissary, with an indifference which penetrated poor Bonacieux with	455.47673239152596
horror.	434.0804926158389
“Alas, alas!” said he to himself, “misfortune is over my head; my wife	463.9930017478416
must have committed some frightful crime. They believe me her	463.3753269087511
accomplice, and will punish me with her. She must have spoken; she must	446.1679196062031
have confessed everything—a woman is so weak! A dungeon! The first he	417.50981621595224
comes to! That’s it! A night is soon passed; and tomorrow to the wheel,	367.44171807494155
to the gallows! Oh, my God, my God, have pity on me!”	316.3957835117834
Without listening the least in the world to the lamentations of M.	381.16525141069144
Bonacieux—lamentations to which, besides, they must have been pretty	292.0144406261617
well accustomed—the two guards took the prisoner each by an arm, and	370.76434227348943
led him away, while the commissary wrote a letter in haste and	382.2021564927208
dispatched it by an officer in waiting.	486.9644650500164
Bonacieux could not close his eyes; not because his dungeon was so very	340.2969057500802
disagreeable, but because his uneasiness was so great. He sat all night	449.3557251314812
on his stool, starting at the least noise; and when the first rays of	447.5711743769014
the sun penetrated into his chamber, the dawn itself appeared to him to	491.8745580360837
have taken funereal tints.	458.80629660257694
All at once he heard his bolts drawn, and made a terrified bound. He	432.85468298838174
believed they were come to conduct him to the scaffold; so that when he	444.57918580615956
saw merely and simply, instead of the executioner he expected, only his	449.78819418767387
commissary of the preceding evening, attended by his clerk, he was	301.6259964360003
ready to embrace them both.	468.721096979503
“Your affair has become more complicated since yesterday evening, my	352.88740226073674
good man, and I advise you to tell the whole truth; for your repentance	428.81659102770357
alone can remove the anger of the cardinal.”	487.68668842824354
“Why, I am ready to tell everything,” cried Bonacieux, “at least, all	453.72445904314486
that I know. Interrogate me, I entreat you!”	318.28324671174767
“Where is your wife, in the first place?”	452.87638218129973
“Why, did not I tell you she had been stolen from me?”	375.5995846218001
“Yes, but yesterday at five o’clock in the afternoon, thanks to you,	393.9740103824714
she escaped.”	447.9709341479631
“My wife escaped!” cried Bonacieux. “Oh, unfortunate creature!	430.3414312309786
Monsieur, if she has escaped, it is not my fault, I swear.”	334.24490435720253
“What business had you, then, to go into the chamber of Monsieur	417.74688731548446
d’Artagnan, your neighbor, with whom you had a long conference during	378.9143106506789
the day?”	465.0306877752873
“Ah, yes, Monsieur Commissary; yes, that is true, and I confess that I	469.00144284736825
was in the wrong. I did go to Monsieur d’Artagnan’s.”	321.0498952414684
“What was the aim of that visit?”	466.3642015045077
“To beg him to assist me in finding my wife. I believed I had a right	429.60921593886167
to endeavor to find her. I was deceived, as it appears, and I ask your	440.5785221602322
pardon.”	448.87028281682524
“And what did Monsieur d’Artagnan reply?”	437.25702833480716
“Monsieur d’Artagnan promised me his assistance; but I soon found out	445.83106766539186
that he was betraying me.”	442.73315966346354
“You impose upon justice. Monsieur d’Artagnan made a compact with you;	480.66205888094373
and in virtue of that compact put to flight the police who had arrested	322.0489578367902
your wife, and has placed her beyond reach.”	469.0316213949918
“M. d’Artagnan has abducted my wife! Come now, what are you telling	343.8880411411431
me?”	313.20036164655477
“Fortunately, Monsieur d’Artagnan is in our hands, and you shall be	419.65752301185717
confronted with him.”	410.89850092104643
“By my faith, I ask no better,” cried Bonacieux; “I shall not be sorry	327.45573158004515
to see the face of an acquaintance.”	372.88426319142513
“Bring in the Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said the commissary to the guards.	339.3089827690882
The two guards led in Athos.	486.45814448412017
“Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said the commissary, addressing Athos, “declare	303.2586032876321
all that passed yesterday between you and Monsieur.”	378.9805744148389
“But,” cried Bonacieux, “this is not Monsieur d’Artagnan whom you show	338.25889554968063
me.”	441.25089356072385
“What! Not Monsieur d’Artagnan?” exclaimed the commissary.	439.73375651356554
“Not the least in the world,” replied Bonacieux.	384.34729394696217
“What is this gentleman’s name?” asked the commissary.	456.7112685978501
“I cannot tell you; I don’t know him.”	485.15306304528565
“How! You don’t know him?”	403.00727031405324
“No.”	478.48158365408676
“Did you never see him?”	486.5232977251344
“Yes, I have seen him, but I don’t know what he calls himself.”	377.6110994632695
“Your name?” replied the commissary.	466.9385975859477
“Athos,” replied the Musketeer.	425.2240183500951
“But that is not a man’s name; that is the name of a mountain,” cried	380.0594924290504
the poor questioner, who began to lose his head.	396.8941276139327
“That is my name,” said Athos, quietly.	381.75320508064664
“But you said that your name was D’Artagnan.”	433.17077268464163
“Who, I?”	318.3301758165465
“Yes, you.”	356.15829848155715
“Somebody said to me, ‘You are Monsieur d’Artagnan?’ I answered, ‘You	480.79029510395725
think so?’ My guards exclaimed that they were sure of it. I did not	404.49523522701384
wish to contradict them; besides, I might be deceived.”	452.91147243799276
“Monsieur, you insult the majesty of justice.”	490.8284916581266
“Not at all,” said Athos, calmly.	343.9708180997335
“You are Monsieur d’Artagnan.”	424.28544029991326
“You see, monsieur, that you say it again.”	393.81000281812254
“But I tell you, Monsieur Commissary,” cried Bonacieux, in his turn,	390.23147617471597
“there is not the least doubt about the matter. Monsieur d’Artagnan is	462.16751119571813
my tenant, although he does not pay me my rent—and even better on that	329.22783972278404
account ought I to know him. Monsieur d’Artagnan is a young man,	430.86669847650217
scarcely nineteen or twenty, and this gentleman must be thirty at	301.07546915273565
least. Monsieur d’Artagnan is in Monsieur Dessessart’s Guards, and this	375.5630176181313
gentleman is in the company of Monsieur de Tréville’s Musketeers. Look	341.6958418787863
at his uniform, Monsieur Commissary, look at his uniform!”	360.5922610995635
“That’s true,” murmured the commissary; “_pardieu_, that’s true.”	324.6925449052846
At this moment the door was opened quickly, and a messenger, introduced	341.3614846165618
by one of the gatekeepers of the Bastille, gave a letter to the	338.2813139014697
commissary.	440.07107819731914
“Oh, unhappy woman!” cried the commissary.	397.22974806568277
“How? What do you say? Of whom do you speak? It is not of my wife, I	418.19067549517996
hope!”	387.6659286195869
“On the contrary, it is of her. Yours is a pretty business.”	471.1449512850077
“But,” said the agitated mercer, “do me the pleasure, monsieur, to tell	467.0404572782602
me how my own proper affair can become worse by anything my wife does	377.1228028901002
while I am in prison?”	298.42649685200274
“Because that which she does is part of a plan concerted between you—of	314.1466306709193
an infernal plan.”	325.32737149238244
“I swear to you, Monsieur Commissary, that you are in the profoundest	405.01456941088725
error, that I know nothing in the world about what my wife had to do,	333.69388367163594
that I am entirely a stranger to what she has done; and that if she has	387.87876788239885
committed any follies, I renounce her, I abjure her, I curse her!”	482.4200343431355
“Bah!” said Athos to the commissary, “if you have no more need of me,	382.4433648952055
send me somewhere. Your Monsieur Bonacieux is very tiresome.”	395.2313896967948
The commissary designated by the same gesture Athos and Bonacieux, “Let	367.0338965464164
them be guarded more closely than ever.”	367.35457644689876
“And yet,” said Athos, with his habitual calmness, “if it be Monsieur	327.55629479036355
d’Artagnan who is concerned in this matter, I do not perceive how I can	473.074103645592
take his place.”	371.99019830806697
“Do as I bade you,” cried the commissary, “and preserve absolute	375.4859226769848
secrecy. You understand!”	300.88531857587554
Athos shrugged his shoulders, and followed his guards silently, while	475.99586912405357
M. Bonacieux uttered lamentations enough to break the heart of a tiger.	480.27617857212346
They locked the mercer in the same dungeon where he had passed the	453.57035309949333
night, and left him to himself during the day. Bonacieux wept all day,	382.718287112092
like a true mercer, not being at all a military man, as he himself	374.5080172528469
informed us. In the evening, about nine o’clock, at the moment he had	305.02034971410956
made up his mind to go to bed, he heard steps in his corridor. These	418.8810170441299
steps drew near to his dungeon, the door was thrown open, and the	426.11355035425686
guards appeared.	358.080852687178
“Follow me,” said an officer, who came up behind the guards.	387.742037411005
“Follow you!” cried Bonacieux, “follow you at this hour! Where, my	358.0370666075855
God?”	386.8777514464524
“Where we have orders to lead you.”	403.7090123165535
“But that is not an answer.”	361.17152802016574
“It is, nevertheless, the only one we can give.”	359.4473444671601
“Ah, my God, my God!” murmured the poor mercer, “now, indeed, I am	317.79661004694555
lost!” And he followed the guards who came for him, mechanically and	415.94427942668295
without resistance.	476.3203626727719
He passed along the same corridor as before, crossed one court, then a	459.97577317108744
second side of a building; at length, at the gate of the entrance court	432.13687228509036
he found a carriage surrounded by four guards on horseback. They made	403.7632451665869
him enter this carriage, the officer placed himself by his side, the	389.4717715233702
door was locked, and they were left in a rolling prison. The carriage	471.23688631220546
was put in motion as slowly as a funeral car. Through the closely	489.95841343073334
fastened windows the prisoner could perceive the houses and the	320.687123496196
pavement, that was all; but, true Parisian as he was, Bonacieux could	350.3048955111774
recognize every street by the milestones, the signs, and the lamps. At	359.69746107839035
the moment of arriving at St. Paul—the spot where such as were	408.07582288914296
condemned at the Bastille were executed—he was near fainting and	373.3293751576612
crossed himself twice. He thought the carriage was about to stop there.	406.4666095556762
The carriage, however, passed on.	313.69349020357475
Farther on, a still greater terror seized him on passing by the	413.3274881536554
cemetery of St. Jean, where state criminals were buried. One thing,	315.39105055270517
however, reassured him; he remembered that before they were buried	380.18561481270075
their heads were generally cut off, and he felt that his head was still	386.7627698801569
on his shoulders. But when he saw the carriage take the way to La	455.3341722270104
Grêve, when he perceived the pointed roof of the Hôtel de Ville, and	347.60032902044844
the carriage passed under the arcade, he believed it was over with him.	443.38747015022767
He wished to confess to the officer, and upon his refusal, uttered such	392.9177661548591
pitiable cries that the officer told him that if he continued to deafen	453.27317273624266
him thus, he should put a gag in his mouth.	463.0674577132653
This measure somewhat reassured Bonacieux. If they meant to execute him	485.2650104333365
at La Grêve, it could scarcely be worth while to gag him, as they had	469.576016573139
nearly reached the place of execution. Indeed, the carriage crossed the	295.38522269602777
fatal spot without stopping. There remained, then, no other place to	327.74789685214137
fear but the Traitor’s Cross; the carriage was taking the direct road	417.3313693593138
to it.	449.9830585249762
This time there was no longer any doubt; it was at the Traitor’s Cross	453.9295600191832
that lesser criminals were executed. Bonacieux had flattered himself in	380.30969983399746
believing himself worthy of St. Paul or of the Place de Grêve; it was	485.14630059801266
at the Traitor’s Cross that his journey and his destiny were about to	344.7265322086135
end! He could not yet see that dreadful cross, but he felt somehow as	402.1221434203654
if it were coming to meet him. When he was within twenty paces of it,	421.869203351348
he heard a noise of people and the carriage stopped. This was more than	393.52189850634454
poor Bonacieux could endure, depressed as he was by the successive	347.297783736882
emotions which he had experienced; he uttered a feeble groan which	461.2372106178865
might have been taken for the last sigh of a dying man, and fainted.	308.10528303000433
Chapter XIV.	370.2627800530046
THE MAN OF MEUNG	365.4609076803166
The crowd was caused, not by the expectation of a man to be hanged, but	430.525069024087
by the contemplation of a man who was hanged.	350.939896728023
The carriage, which had been stopped for a minute, resumed its way,	447.0615651297427
passed through the crowd, threaded the Rue St. Honoré, turned into the	445.99825349903404
Rue des Bons Enfants, and stopped before a low door.	353.01313236075805
The door opened; two guards received Bonacieux in their arms from the	322.6758058666732
officer who supported him. They carried him through an alley, up a	365.5927932339939
flight of stairs, and deposited him in an antechamber.	403.63642388712276
All these movements had been effected mechanically, as far as he was	468.1475086431584
concerned. He had walked as one walks in a dream; he had a glimpse of	368.25531952901196
objects as through a fog. His ears had perceived sounds without	321.85445347425326
comprehending them; he might have been executed at that moment without	380.6421342643508
his making a single gesture in his own defense or uttering a cry to	448.02102525097143
implore mercy.	303.72033015825036
He remained on the bench, with his back leaning against the wall and	379.8571974182956
his hands hanging down, exactly on the spot where the guards placed	336.7782055605959
him.	407.09158239472407
On looking around him, however, as he could perceive no threatening	465.2070864247946
object, as nothing indicated that he ran any real danger, as the bench	340.2754282875119
was comfortably covered with a well-stuffed cushion, as the wall was	433.89064259510997
ornamented with a beautiful Cordova leather, and as large red damask	359.2801746365421
curtains, fastened back by gold clasps, floated before the window, he	479.61031632733005
perceived by degrees that his fear was exaggerated, and he began to	371.190244192891
turn his head to the right and the left, upward and downward.	409.7838318409928
At this movement, which nobody opposed, he resumed a little courage,	359.46950878796315
and ventured to draw up one leg and then the other. At length, with the	483.2907764101119
help of his two hands he lifted himself from the bench, and found	389.12217435897617
himself on his feet.	418.72466130867116
At this moment an officer with a pleasant face opened a door, continued	422.23068138133186
to exchange some words with a person in the next chamber and then came	397.2792277892253
up to the prisoner. “Is your name Bonacieux?” said he.	316.6976259318673
“Yes, Monsieur Officer,” stammered the mercer, more dead than alive,	435.29748312454734
“at your service.”	485.1960278962615
“Come in,” said the officer.	435.5963342581987
And he moved out of the way to let the mercer pass. The latter obeyed	382.92066165167296
without reply, and entered the chamber, where he appeared to be	355.5799243701051
expected.	363.33044555874505
It was a large cabinet, close and stifling, with the walls furnished	429.8118052374381
with arms offensive and defensive, and in which there was already a	386.9079547398391
fire, although it was scarcely the end of the month of September. A	431.4443167741426
square table, covered with books and papers, upon which was unrolled an	367.3998558307233
immense plan of the city of La Rochelle, occupied the center of the	471.0076698113412
room.	441.5645123952787
Standing before the chimney was a man of middle height, of a haughty,	455.17959278799026
proud mien; with piercing eyes, a large brow, and a thin face, which	302.0796036476456
was made still longer by a _royal_ (or _imperial_, as it is now	333.18599279885257
called), surmounted by a pair of mustaches. Although this man was	483.32310583370213
scarcely thirty-six or thirty-seven years of age, hair, mustaches, and	399.9139168674149
royal, all began to be gray. This man, except a sword, had all the	382.089795671689
appearance of a soldier; and his buff boots, still slightly covered	346.0068695014372
with dust, indicated that he had been on horseback in the course of the	358.16422060461383
day.	449.5618944049535
This man was Armand Jean Duplessis, Cardinal de Richelieu; not such as	426.98130215600236
he is now represented—broken down like an old man, suffering like a	311.7825803585065
martyr, his body bent, his voice failing, buried in a large armchair as	358.00684710333167
in an anticipated tomb; no longer living but by the strength of his	306.85118373142006
genius, and no longer maintaining the struggle with Europe but by the	485.3734294192809
eternal application of his thoughts—but such as he really was at this	327.0753384382247
period; that is to say, an active and gallant cavalier, already weak of	385.45825061080865
body, but sustained by that moral power which made of him one of the	389.15665446225455
most extraordinary men that ever lived, preparing, after having	320.3354181835632
supported the Duc de Nevers in his duchy of Mantua, after having taken	404.1247029826477
Nîmes, Castres, and Uzes, to drive the English from the Isle of Ré and	459.6691011860188
lay siege to La Rochelle.	353.29058500238745
At first sight, nothing denoted the cardinal; and it was impossible for	389.5806264507403
those who did not know his face to guess in whose presence they were.	412.43404024827475
The poor mercer remained standing at the door, while the eyes of the	440.7669393694555
personage we have just described were fixed upon him, and appeared to	449.4451470690436
wish to penetrate even into the depths of the past.	456.45919069067133
“Is this that Bonacieux?” asked he, after a moment of silence.	394.7575452951859
“Yes, monseigneur,” replied the officer.	319.8756504233446
“That’s well. Give me those papers, and leave us.”	423.52000042963687
The officer took from the table the papers pointed out, gave them to	372.3824894287362
him who asked for them, bowed to the ground, and retired.	331.885558695334
Bonacieux recognized in these papers his interrogatories of the	458.5278960778405
Bastille. From time to time the man by the chimney raised his eyes from	433.81262020445126
the writings, and plunged them like poniards into the heart of the poor	299.2948328663332
mercer.	457.99164954002566
At the end of ten minutes of reading and ten seconds of examination,	407.3675287534682
the cardinal was satisfied.	487.0029788516507
“That head has never conspired,” murmured he, “but it matters not; we	345.586568725681
will see.”	440.77029564617874
“You are accused of high treason,” said the cardinal, slowly.	307.40640529430664
“So I have been told already, monseigneur,” cried Bonacieux, giving his	408.8515518619207
interrogator the title he had heard the officer give him, “but I swear	423.78559799361017
to you that I know nothing about it.”	312.7526298764914
The cardinal repressed a smile.	314.24830264080043
“You have conspired with your wife, with Madame de Chevreuse, and with	321.99877896673524
my Lord Duke of Buckingham.”	430.1563031382631
“Indeed, monseigneur,” responded the mercer, “I have heard her	379.2358345722492
pronounce all those names.”	367.2271100798498
“And on what occasion?”	316.4805296871852
“She said that the Cardinal de Richelieu had drawn the Duke of	353.9293057074335
Buckingham to Paris to ruin him and to ruin the queen.”	336.3398000046876
“She said that?” cried the cardinal, with violence.	357.7112310412756
“Yes, monseigneur, but I told her she was wrong to talk about such	464.9801142947102
things; and that his Eminence was incapable—”	302.5963621720858
“Hold your tongue! You are stupid,” replied the cardinal.	364.5822708257021
“That’s exactly what my wife said, monseigneur.”	449.58074149668414
“Do you know who carried off your wife?”	437.7578221494347
“No, monseigneur.”	473.29337747423165
“You have suspicions, nevertheless?”	337.31035982311164
“Yes, monseigneur; but these suspicions appeared to be disagreeable to	425.33621704606685
Monsieur the Commissary, and I no longer have them.”	346.7005041892065
“Your wife has escaped. Did you know that?”	372.2922841536092
“No, monseigneur. I learned it since I have been in prison, and that	448.8798488859537
from the conversation of Monsieur the Commissary—an amiable man.”	373.08508892012173
The cardinal repressed another smile.	356.7569693401125
“Then you are ignorant of what has become of your wife since her	418.987419558179
flight.”	316.66911953176316
“Absolutely, monseigneur; but she has most likely returned to the	337.60556641666875
Louvre.”	366.8895399544893
“At one o’clock this morning she had not returned.”	342.0149532486859
“My God! What can have become of her, then?”	392.9337018278601
“We shall know, be assured. Nothing is concealed from the cardinal; the	404.9598137281325
cardinal knows everything.”	447.36476649337544
“In that case, monseigneur, do you believe the cardinal will be so kind	397.78713619508585
as to tell me what has become of my wife?”	362.93266800397544
“Perhaps he may; but you must, in the first place, reveal to the	441.9484678680436
cardinal all you know of your wife’s relations with Madame de	475.4040130481759
Chevreuse.”	425.11088816461654
“But, monseigneur, I know nothing about them; I have never seen her.”	416.5309455439076
“When you went to fetch your wife from the Louvre, did you always	306.54681349343764
return directly home?”	411.9070278390557
“Scarcely ever; she had business to transact with linen drapers, to	478.38484971214825
whose houses I conducted her.”	475.01921708912795
“And how many were there of these linen drapers?”	459.3856621682352
“Two, monseigneur.”	342.36150143876495
“And where did they live?”	417.3594651694873
“One in Rue de Vaugirard, the other Rue de la Harpe.”	431.8110521048089
“Did you go into these houses with her?”	463.34347127403606
“Never, monseigneur; I waited at the door.”	480.5404871251367
“And what excuse did she give you for entering all alone?”	332.8663609195389
“She gave me none; she told me to wait, and I waited.”	293.1945718252843
“You are a very complacent husband, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux,” said	416.1397901962228
the cardinal.	314.0443060285484
“He calls me his dear Monsieur,” said the mercer to himself. “_Peste!_	364.29069762708286
Matters are going all right.”	439.42125481642324
“Should you know those doors again?”	474.6234304963983
“Yes.”	475.3238271257104
“Do you know the numbers?”	396.58870250843165
“Yes.”	341.3688218129678
“What are they?”	490.3350626386406
“No. 25 in the Rue de Vaugirard; 75 in the Rue de la Harpe.”	401.8532952492651
“That’s well,” said the cardinal.	488.8062997803616
At these words he took up a silver bell, and rang it; the officer	416.59933003716606
entered.	368.52185408250193
“Go,” said he, in a subdued voice, “and find Rochefort. Tell him to	292.83720901262944
come to me immediately, if he has returned.”	312.1258207407815
“The count is here,” said the officer, “and requests to speak with your	392.5425467484729
Eminence instantly.”	365.6576172382349
“Let him come in, then!” said the cardinal, quickly.	408.2031714323649
The officer sprang out of the apartment with that alacrity which all	456.24901060835305
the servants of the cardinal displayed in obeying him.	387.57318770644395
“To your Eminence!” murmured Bonacieux, rolling his eyes round in	356.46804991927587
astonishment.	450.6226122676511
Five seconds has scarcely elapsed after the disappearance of the	412.73077916498926
officer, when the door opened, and a new personage entered.	481.92484808650136
“It is he!” cried Bonacieux.	388.6745475053368
“He! What he?” asked the cardinal.	448.41184167785013
“The man who abducted my wife.”	488.0036145989868
The cardinal rang a second time. The officer reappeared.	334.63167178547826
“Place this man in the care of his guards again, and let him wait till	430.8607030206217
I send for him.”	365.56887601015075
“No, monseigneur, no, it is not he!” cried Bonacieux; “no, I was	361.58923782266913
deceived. This is quite another man, and does not resemble him at all.	348.31238414065
Monsieur is, I am sure, an honest man.”	466.952311071654
“Take away that fool!” said the cardinal.	396.77182273117387
The officer took Bonacieux by the arm, and led him into the	396.858448346324
antechamber, where he found his two guards.	341.9823161162616
The newly introduced personage followed Bonacieux impatiently with his	465.7317342743751
eyes till he had gone out; and the moment the door closed, “They have	484.81505914948775
seen each other;” said he, approaching the cardinal eagerly.	442.554220368071
“Who?” asked his Eminence.	442.49436371357694
“He and she.”	434.66948289154215
“The queen and the duke?” cried Richelieu.	398.4592205110987
“Yes.”	346.2023320208362
“Where?”	340.1559116902682
“At the Louvre.”	365.9134569596364
“Are you sure of it?”	354.1349219754717
“Perfectly sure.”	428.7269272068585
“Who told you of it?”	377.43388867144824
“Madame de Lannoy, who is devoted to your Eminence, as you know.”	483.60313750995397
“Why did she not let me know sooner?”	414.84247684655935
“Whether by chance or mistrust, the queen made Madame de Surgis sleep	355.04068301416527
in her chamber, and detained her all day.”	428.66848575259087
“Well, we are beaten! Now let us try to take our revenge.”	460.1058565555145
“I will assist you with all my heart, monseigneur; be assured of that.”	361.52408255206785
“How did it come about?”	371.43652191226806
“At half past twelve the queen was with her women—”	438.688697631437
“Where?”	416.05522004600505
“In her bedchamber—”	425.20427204886516
“Go on.”	330.00144812972945
“When someone came and brought her a handkerchief from her laundress.”	425.2728584668656
“And then?”	365.3692979711763
“The queen immediately exhibited strong emotion; and despite the rouge	343.16712268418155
with which her face was covered evidently turned pale—”	409.6393930157167
“And then, and then?”	303.10048351809405
“She then arose, and with altered voice, ‘Ladies,’ said she, ‘wait for	319.96443238694474
me ten minutes, I shall soon return.’ She then opened the door of her	400.545630697869
alcove, and went out.”	481.8605404657942
“Why did not Madame de Lannoy come and inform you instantly?”	361.6157290488671
“Nothing was certain; besides, her Majesty had said, ‘Ladies, wait for	353.4505499237613
me,’ and she did not dare to disobey the queen.”	344.5989360115149
“How long did the queen remain out of the chamber?”	395.33691324157394
“Three-quarters of an hour.”	323.70459840742103
“None of her women accompanied her?”	436.4537602464717
“Only Donna Estafania.”	329.872277680199
“Did she afterward return?”	417.8367094137891
“Yes; but only to take a little rosewood casket, with her cipher upon	473.94964211990504
it, and went out again immediately.”	295.6687195568121
“And when she finally returned, did she bring that casket with her?”	301.3800069763133
“No.”	350.43121401859
“Does Madame de Lannoy know what was in that casket?”	359.840842466167
“Yes; the diamond studs which his Majesty gave the queen.”	437.8191679743543
“And she came back without this casket?”	387.87275751638526
“Yes.”	488.78811425796266
“Madame de Lannoy, then, is of opinion that she gave them to	386.82059528271066
Buckingham?”	424.5704729708715
“She is sure of it.”	465.55781358613694
“How can she be so?”	342.2260616172006
“In the course of the day Madame de Lannoy, in her quality of	457.1784519931398
tire-woman of the queen, looked for this casket, appeared uneasy at not	404.708444725723
finding it, and at length asked information of the queen.”	326.14460037726195
“And then the queen?”	375.5911694503044
“The queen became exceedingly red, and replied that having in the	412.68295563936
evening broken one of those studs, she had sent it to her goldsmith to	467.6617867399908
be repaired.”	423.53972707695846
“He must be called upon, and so ascertain if the thing be true or not.”	413.81322964680623
“I have just been with him.”	458.4161025100585
“And the goldsmith?”	390.0663102806145
“The goldsmith has heard nothing of it.”	414.05086125283106
“Well, well! Rochefort, all is not lost; and perhaps—perhaps everything	299.8845848147367
is for the best.”	426.83326050270784
“The fact is that I do not doubt your Eminence’s genius—”	332.91415993480996
“Will repair the blunders of his agent—is that it?”	397.36979490999136
“That is exactly what I was going to say, if your Eminence had let me	428.2419481880931
finish my sentence.”	343.2424392037133
“Meanwhile, do you know where the Duchesse de Chevreuse and the Duke of	342.0332026882866
Buckingham are now concealed?”	318.1897546160105
“No, monseigneur; my people could tell me nothing on that head.”	349.31341579544085
“But I know.”	397.3517431866464
“You, monseigneur?”	433.101796642308
“Yes; or at least I guess. They were, one in the Rue de Vaugirard, No.	415.1768580173651
25; the other in the Rue de la Harpe, No. 75.”	357.850612310439
“Does your Eminence command that they both be instantly arrested?”	421.4391655597813
“It will be too late; they will be gone.”	368.6361189493348
“But still, we can make sure that they are so.”	419.4565847938211
“Take ten men of my Guardsmen, and search the two houses thoroughly.”	346.02444310660087
“Instantly, monseigneur.” And Rochefort went hastily out of the	454.9964649609113
apartment.	448.2246145659791
The cardinal, being left alone, reflected for an instant and then rang	294.0684157265353
the bell a third time. The same officer appeared.	336.0906124503841
“Bring the prisoner in again,” said the cardinal.	346.70528955248386
M. Bonacieux was introduced afresh, and upon a sign from the cardinal,	332.3383442480099
the officer retired.	394.915595401507
“You have deceived me!” said the cardinal, sternly.	345.4385845333743
“I,” cried Bonacieux, “I deceive your Eminence!”	396.0829458132719
“Your wife, in going to Rue de Vaugirard and Rue de la Harpe, did not	356.63023320918984
go to find linen drapers.”	369.1385542496473
“Then why did she go, just God?”	382.4822216540232
“She went to meet the Duchesse de Chevreuse and the Duke of	482.6836019598908
Buckingham.”	354.3853495452019
“Yes,” cried Bonacieux, recalling all his remembrances of the	301.1417071768319
circumstances, “yes, that’s it. Your Eminence is right. I told my wife	488.20959675564313
several times that it was surprising that linen drapers should live in	302.5963885490397
such houses as those, in houses that had no signs; but she always	470.12871834064043
laughed at me. Ah, monseigneur!” continued Bonacieux, throwing himself	347.83693948145293
at his Eminence’s feet, “ah, how truly you are the cardinal, the great	440.7775765928818
cardinal, the man of genius whom all the world reveres!”	411.583965491183
The cardinal, however contemptible might be the triumph gained over so	442.5300918810341
vulgar a being as Bonacieux, did not the less enjoy it for an instant;	482.5067912790267
then, almost immediately, as if a fresh thought has occurred, a smile	302.7450044502498
played upon his lips, and he said, offering his hand to the mercer,	394.7475965361241
“Rise, my friend, you are a worthy man.”	438.68467806388213
“The cardinal has touched me with his hand! I have touched the hand of	352.3825231115315
the great man!” cried Bonacieux. “The great man has called me his	474.98779154532565
friend!”	308.7628733043306
“Yes, my friend, yes,” said the cardinal, with that paternal tone which	342.1727182802956
he sometimes knew how to assume, but which deceived none who knew him;	483.9684224712847
“and as you have been unjustly suspected, well, you must be	430.74324147347454
indemnified. Here, take this purse of a hundred pistoles, and pardon	323.5305509770659
me.”	333.59918766483827
“I pardon you, monseigneur!” said Bonacieux, hesitating to take the	485.6955824731879
purse, fearing, doubtless, that this pretended gift was but a	332.6119777034745
pleasantry. “But you are able to have me arrested, you are able to have	359.68999460244834
me tortured, you are able to have me hanged; you are the master, and I	306.1831485752738
could not have the least word to say. Pardon you, monseigneur! You	416.6598856714676
cannot mean that!”	359.55282000962984
“Ah, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, you are generous in this matter. I see	384.16672306909095
it and I thank you for it. Thus, then, you will take this bag, and you	356.4119105469471
will go away without being too malcontent.”	335.62744092496996
“I go away enchanted.”	481.58699630377413
“Farewell, then, or rather, _au revoir_, for I hope we shall meet	396.4484029849033
again.”	296.8545571446443
“Whenever Monseigneur wishes, I am always at at his Eminence’s orders.”	437.4538264059444
“That will be frequently, I assure you, for I have found something	404.3722020396066
extremely agreeable in your conversation.”	434.8218156573794
“Oh! Monseigneur!”	357.7618259640912
“_Au revoir_, Monsieur Bonacieux, _au revoir!_”	328.3574174624328
And the cardinal made him a sign with his hand, to which Bonacieux	334.87129925858414
replied by bowing to the ground. He then went out backward, and when he	473.92768973880743
was in the antechamber the cardinal heard him, in his enthusiasm,	403.01580666447
crying aloud, “Long life to the Monseigneur! Long life to his Eminence!	454.7125642085357
Long life to the great cardinal!” The cardinal listened with a smile to	416.4415584054478
this vociferous manifestation of the feelings of M. Bonacieux; and	347.52966695206635
then, when Bonacieux’s cries were no longer audible, “Good!” said he,	359.52107445874304
“that man would henceforward lay down his life for me.” And the	402.20684472043024
cardinal began to examine with the greatest attention the map of La	379.72191767146086
Rochelle, which, as we have said, lay open on the desk, tracing with a	399.8270703073401
pencil the line in which the famous dyke was to pass which, eighteen	457.7369096896091
months later, shut up the port of the besieged city. As he was in the	319.1444047513797
deepest of his strategic meditations, the door opened, and Rochefort	318.88925508301674
returned.	452.90587363452505
“Well?” said the cardinal, eagerly, rising with a promptitude which	429.22862256248834
proved the degree of importance he attached to the commission with	353.14257783051323
which he had charged the count.	461.8782879043547
“Well,” said the latter, “a young woman of about twenty-six or	367.0005068617279
twenty-eight years of age, and a man of from thirty-five to forty, have	293.3946462422226
indeed lodged at the two houses pointed out by your Eminence; but the	398.55576154869607
woman left last night, and the man this morning.”	490.50997048117245
“It was they!” cried the cardinal, looking at the clock; “and now it is	440.48245331418906
too late to have them pursued. The duchess is at Tours, and the duke at	373.07873684232345
Boulogne. It is in London they must be found.”	454.99452478926804
“What are your Eminence’s orders?”	318.27065012435344
“Not a word of what has passed. Let the queen remain in perfect	335.5805631382307
security; let her be ignorant that we know her secret. Let her believe	417.4421061869982
that we are in search of some conspiracy or other. Send me the keeper	326.7811847218755
of the seals, Séguier.”	314.53751105473145
“And that man, what has your Eminence done with him?”	394.8262973704059
“What man?” asked the cardinal.	427.8022608596541
“That Bonacieux.”	467.04231836712233
“I have done with him all that could be done. I have made him a spy	475.97737757696905
upon his wife.”	308.5756023254673
The Comte de Rochefort bowed like a man who acknowledges the	370.1752544165093
superiority of the master as great, and retired.	334.65071983791586
Left alone, the cardinal seated himself again and wrote a letter, which	385.3450977696882
he secured with his special seal. Then he rang. The officer entered for	406.56723330895704
the fourth time.	336.57208659770447
“Tell Vitray to come to me,” said he, “and tell him to get ready for a	374.83636118785955
journey.”	329.25124163233676
An instant after, the man he asked for was before him, booted and	481.7134738968891
spurred.	359.61912126764196
“Vitray,” said he, “you will go with all speed to London. You must not	466.1358192159694
stop an instant on the way. You will deliver this letter to Milady.	364.67116883150317
Here is an order for two hundred pistoles; call upon my treasurer and	319.2743543972161
get the money. You shall have as much again if you are back within six	399.5400313476875
days, and have executed your commission well.”	446.3544508761581
The messenger, without replying a single word, bowed, took the letter,	327.2214305718771
with the order for the two hundred pistoles, and retired.	365.1728614948534
Here is what the letter contained:	323.37517726931947
MILADY, Be at the first ball at which the Duke of Buckingham shall be	484.48378274252195
present. He will wear on his doublet twelve diamond studs; get as near	320.6473528145802
to him as you can, and cut off two.	373.5502396896977
As soon as these studs shall be in your possession, inform me.	398.6982217860673
Chapter XV.	447.36677116638054
MEN OF THE ROBE AND MEN OF THE SWORD	333.6895845938078
On the day after these events had taken place, Athos not having	456.94741677168565
reappeared, M. de Tréville was informed by D’Artagnan and Porthos of	409.606846825395
the circumstance. As to Aramis, he had asked for leave of absence for	437.71336643284883
five days, and was gone, it was said, to Rouen on family business.	449.9706525719258
M. de Tréville was the father of his soldiers. The lowest or the least	296.57925627024935
known of them, as soon as he assumed the uniform of the company, was as	424.7011266761242
sure of his aid and support as if he had been his own brother.	482.3775663518744
He repaired, then, instantly to the office of the	303.1634096090791
_lieutenant-criminel_. The officer who commanded the post of the Red	481.7732471361236
Cross was sent for, and by successive inquiries they learned that Athos	321.51548659796697
was then lodged in Fort l’Evêque.	400.4757795631978
Athos had passed through all the examinations we have seen Bonacieux	445.02942556698827
undergo.	485.59225569398006
We were present at the scene in which the two captives were confronted	420.77250018335826
with each other. Athos, who had till that time said nothing for fear	313.92843662445955
that D’Artagnan, interrupted in his turn, should not have the time	300.39296714665335
necessary, from this moment declared that his name was Athos, and not	298.13577849112636
D’Artagnan. He added that he did not know either M. or Mme. Bonacieux;	430.9735372509975
that he had never spoken to the one or the other; that he had come, at	441.1827719507606
about ten o’clock in the evening, to pay a visit to his friend M.	429.8547045871808
d’Artagnan, but that till that hour he had been at M. de Tréville’s,	410.9713198549319
where he had dined. “Twenty witnesses,” added he, “could attest the	375.7405288544961
fact”; and he named several distinguished gentlemen, and among them was	378.9123274965216
M. le Duc de la Trémouille.	361.34708675876703
The second commissary was as much bewildered as the first had been by	432.42908585142334
the simple and firm declaration of the Musketeer, upon whom he was	312.40307502584204
anxious to take the revenge which men of the robe like at all times to	335.2976285354992
gain over men of the sword; but the name of M. de Tréville, and that of	407.66986500870803
M. de la Trémouille, commanded a little reflection.	397.7016892066998
Athos was then sent to the cardinal; but unfortunately the cardinal was	470.3091320446034
at the Louvre with the king.	415.9837556062541
It was precisely at this moment that M. de Tréville, on leaving the	313.54090212301503
residence of the _lieutenant-criminel_ and the governor of Fort	476.3529499224634
l’Evêque without being able to find Athos, arrived at the palace.	331.7243082933508
As captain of the Musketeers, M. de Tréville had the right of entry at	292.1521936206048
all times.	432.77416525612745
It is well known how violent the king’s prejudices were against the	317.23003989065927
queen, and how carefully these prejudices were kept up by the cardinal,	411.5480880011304
who in affairs of intrigue mistrusted women infinitely more than men.	424.7508918146448
One of the grand causes of this prejudice was the friendship of Anne of	444.54666355877043
Austria for Mme. de Chevreuse. These two women gave him more uneasiness	335.50119237458085
than the war with Spain, the quarrel with England, or the embarrassment	347.2348200012717
of the finances. In his eyes and to his conviction, Mme. de Chevreuse	465.77583569149874
not only served the queen in her political intrigues, but, what	382.3654406829835
tormented him still more, in her amorous intrigues.	444.4180113925502
At the first word the cardinal spoke of Mme. de Chevreuse—who, though	442.7525925274439
exiled to Tours and believed to be in that city, had come to Paris,	299.81803627410983
remained there five days, and outwitted the police—the king flew into a	378.35115786117984
furious passion. Capricious and unfaithful, the king wished to be	337.7208731769452
called Louis the Just and Louis the Chaste. Posterity will find a	437.7301446318833
difficulty in understanding this character, which history explains only	363.25905348793196
by facts and never by reason.	413.72447359591723
But when the cardinal added that not only Mme. de Chevreuse had been in	461.5402670256524
Paris, but still further, that the queen had renewed with her one of	344.13332678017485
those mysterious correspondences which at that time was named a	410.2525276938759
_cabal;_ when he affirmed that he, the cardinal, was about to unravel	429.57848697701377
the most closely twisted thread of this intrigue; that at the moment of	368.12352904887075
arresting in the very act, with all the proofs about her, the queen’s	381.36695725023054
emissary to the exiled duchess, a Musketeer had dared to interrupt the	306.3092389226972
course of justice violently, by falling sword in hand upon the honest	322.51497633744236
men of the law, charged with investigating impartially the whole affair	430.04278906144935
in order to place it before the eyes of the king—Louis XIII. could not	482.25356379540926
contain himself, and he made a step toward the queen’s apartment with	374.65120880473364
that pale and mute indignation which, when it broke out, led this	294.1689727260907
prince to the commission of the most pitiless cruelty. And yet, in all	456.91285215756034
this, the cardinal had not yet said a word about the Duke of	324.2751043735298
Buckingham.	362.38259223099953
At this instant M. de Tréville entered, cool, polite, and in	364.25365776972455
irreproachable costume.	487.4926372955506
Informed of what had passed by the presence of the cardinal and the	462.76232548151273
alteration in the king’s countenance, M. de Tréville felt himself	409.7452741232107
something like Samson before the Philistines.	304.6388072814065
Louis XIII. had already placed his hand on the knob of the door; at the	467.2764284304453
noise of M. de Tréville’s entrance he turned round. “You arrive in good	419.70685515348936
time, monsieur,” said the king, who, when his passions were raised to a	484.0626679567665
certain point, could not dissemble; “I have learned some fine things	356.97785237042297
concerning your Musketeers.”	392.8209730561989
“And I,” said Tréville, coldly, “I have some pretty things to tell your	336.148739827549
Majesty concerning these gownsmen.”	386.02881472119077
“What?” said the king, with hauteur.	298.1492827543605
“I have the honor to inform your Majesty,” continued M. de Tréville, in	328.7463151302418
the same tone, “that a party of _procureurs_, commissaries, and men of	477.1501058603534
the police—very estimable people, but very inveterate, as it appears,	478.11917386446703
against the uniform—have taken upon themselves to arrest in a house, to	450.7865398243547
lead away through the open street, and throw into Fort l’Evêque, all	455.49835488188216
upon an order which they have refused to show me, one of my, or rather	432.0629657977869
your Musketeers, sire, of irreproachable conduct, of an almost	313.60437423204644
illustrious reputation, and whom your Majesty knows favorably, Monsieur	373.10745740207517
Athos.”	467.60761565248913
“Athos,” said the king, mechanically; “yes, certainly I know that	420.02552683223416
name.”	305.3605249247324
“Let your Majesty remember,” said Tréville, “that Monsieur Athos is the	456.1709148779813
Musketeer who, in the annoying duel which you are acquainted with, had	443.3726154263385
the misfortune to wound Monsieur de Cahusac so seriously. _A propos_,	308.4343604614257
monseigneur,” continued Tréville, addressing the cardinal, “Monsieur de	399.6380879520859
Cahusac is quite recovered, is he not?”	323.2155412253124
“Thank you,” said the cardinal, biting his lips with anger.	328.9473172402884
“Athos, then, went to pay a visit to one of his friends absent at the	314.0074662585238
time,” continued Tréville, “to a young Béarnais, a cadet in his	317.1733406263025
Majesty’s Guards, the company of Monsieur Dessessart, but scarcely had	342.0788075110844
he arrived at his friend’s and taken up a book, while waiting his	431.25844361979966
return, when a mixed crowd of bailiffs and soldiers came and laid siege	453.1446350463043
to the house, broke open several doors—”	366.4557625621642
The cardinal made the king a sign, which signified, “That was on	367.79142652478225
account of the affair about which I spoke to you.”	350.91386712392045
“We all know that,” interrupted the king; “for all that was done for	370.9400211916393
our service.”	387.8462453004566
“Then,” said Tréville, “it was also for your Majesty’s service that one	342.8950224840504
of my Musketeers, who was innocent, has been seized, that he has been	299.2026826357863
placed between two guards like a malefactor, and that this gallant man,	469.1803324698427
who has ten times shed his blood in your Majesty’s service and is ready	312.58709060968874
to shed it again, has been paraded through the midst of an insolent	420.42274301224984
populace?”	400.7243328135412
“Bah!” said the king, who began to be shaken, “was it so managed?”	301.4389811733565
“Monsieur de Tréville,” said the cardinal, with the greatest phlegm,	323.8649733433786
“does not tell your Majesty that this innocent Musketeer, this gallant	427.2465507584709
man, had only an hour before attacked, sword in hand, four commissaries	451.7526290428075
of inquiry, who were delegated by myself to examine into an affair of	293.76751755999794
the highest importance.”	381.7119548133787
“I defy your Eminence to prove it,” cried Tréville, with his Gascon	346.4150104235838
freedom and military frankness; “for one hour before, Monsieur Athos,	379.306043310012
who, I will confide it to your Majesty, is really a man of the highest	398.1495467147581
quality, did me the honor after having dined with me to be conversing	358.1304636013537
in the saloon of my hôtel, with the Duc de la Trémouille and the Comte	476.2157019530995
de Châlus, who happened to be there.”	454.0235787772118
The king looked at the cardinal.	438.629589763652
“A written examination attests it,” said the cardinal, replying aloud	337.84551029105626
to the mute interrogation of his Majesty; “and the ill-treated people	445.1286261009509
have drawn up the following, which I have the honor to present to your	469.7872845082609
Majesty.”	487.1112170470845
“And is the written report of the gownsmen to be placed in comparison	297.4847136623324
with the word of honor of a swordsman?” replied Tréville haughtily.	355.46912486149665
“Come, come, Tréville, hold your tongue,” said the king.	321.25895496833317
“If his Eminence entertains any suspicion against one of my	439.71182319019357
Musketeers,” said Tréville, “the justice of Monsieur the Cardinal is so	448.2824450542306
well known that I demand an inquiry.”	294.3949496286021
“In the house in which the judicial inquiry was made,” continued the	375.34066409021136
impassive cardinal, “there lodges, I believe, a young Béarnais, a	468.69062599328043
friend of the Musketeer.”	441.64784416935606
“Your Eminence means Monsieur d’Artagnan.”	432.08615311318323
“I mean a young man whom you patronize, Monsieur de Tréville.”	410.53206497217417
“Yes, your Eminence, it is the same.”	406.33528299622265
“Do you not suspect this young man of having given bad counsel?”	296.140980689023
“To Athos, to a man double his age?” interrupted Tréville. “No,	424.85991086106105
monseigneur. Besides, D’Artagnan passed the evening with me.”	395.2543537719714
“Well,” said the cardinal, “everybody seems to have passed the evening	395.6478594255652
with you.”	461.80564915952186
“Does your Eminence doubt my word?” said Tréville, with a brow flushed	397.5908871292817
with anger.	451.13678550051037
“No, God forbid,” said the cardinal; “only, at what hour was he with	334.32395317051703
you?”	305.7957817148241
“Oh, as to that I can speak positively, your Eminence; for as he came	481.0201117457063
in I remarked that it was but half past nine by the clock, although I	307.7954057183122
had believed it to be later.”	488.2246952283773
“At what hour did he leave your hôtel?”	307.302460040523
“At half past ten—an hour after the event.”	435.12998629590703
“Well,” replied the cardinal, who could not for an instant suspect the	420.964953250597
loyalty of Tréville, and who felt that the victory was escaping him,	437.82931582889927
“well, but Athos _was_ taken in the house in the Rue des Fossoyeurs.”	396.3569299726506
“Is one friend forbidden to visit another, or a Musketeer of my company	341.48157227001064
to fraternize with a Guard of Dessessart’s company?”	442.0077283456051
“Yes, when the house where he fraternizes is suspected.”	319.80890608965257
“That house is suspected, Tréville,” said the king; “perhaps you did	301.7137185367722
not know it?”	377.5215614782221
“Indeed, sire, I did not. The house may be suspected; but I deny that	397.6648021440896
it is so in the part of it inhabited by Monsieur d’Artagnan, for I can	296.25689564946646
affirm, sire, if I can believe what he says, that there does not exist	425.0220419920134
a more devoted servant of your Majesty, or a more profound admirer of	385.2629470743153
Monsieur the Cardinal.”	365.7192615501159
“Was it not this D’Artagnan who wounded Jussac one day, in that	304.7960807809716
unfortunate encounter which took place near the Convent of the	458.05551263838356
Carmes-Déchaussés?” asked the king, looking at the cardinal, who	397.3345567025125
colored with vexation.	434.413006111114
“And the next day, Bernajoux. Yes, sire, yes, it is the same; and your	420.0943633400914
Majesty has a good memory.”	435.85020868790434
“Come, how shall we decide?” said the king.	327.62395285759857
“That concerns your Majesty more than me,” said the cardinal. “I should	379.2464393170088
affirm the culpability.”	422.4031184901771
“And I deny it,” said Tréville. “But his Majesty has judges, and these	400.90621823341525
judges will decide.”	292.39975312134476
“That is best,” said the king. “Send the case before the judges; it is	415.4152625728142
their business to judge, and they shall judge.”	327.0137411493828
“Only,” replied Tréville, “it is a sad thing that in the unfortunate	457.9694436380156
times in which we live, the purest life, the most incontestable virtue,	449.61791228512465
cannot exempt a man from infamy and persecution. The army, I will	384.0351969192309
answer for it, will be but little pleased at being exposed to rigorous	388.51500810366787
treatment on account of police affairs.”	430.54508647659804
The expression was imprudent; but M. de Tréville launched it with	305.8255278941195
knowledge of his cause. He was desirous of an explosion, because in	436.6763040830506
that case the mine throws forth fire, and fire enlightens.	326.61951719482494
“Police affairs!” cried the king, taking up Tréville’s words, “police	301.09356209194704
affairs! And what do you know about them, Monsieur? Meddle with your	352.37795097664343
Musketeers, and do not annoy me in this way. It appears, according to	466.31122339994477
your account, that if by mischance a Musketeer is arrested, France is	313.1031491057038
in danger. What a noise about a Musketeer! I would arrest ten of them,	330.69989371708925
_ventrebleu_, a hundred, even, all the company, and I would not allow a	467.2731918354341
whisper.”	449.08842218490486
“From the moment they are suspected by your Majesty,” said Tréville,	313.2453413732131
“the Musketeers are guilty; therefore, you see me prepared to surrender	413.0361909321645
my sword—for after having accused my soldiers, there can be no doubt	300.9187772713006
that Monsieur the Cardinal will end by accusing me. It is best to	346.07196811917765
constitute myself at once a prisoner with Athos, who is already	349.3293951764809
arrested, and with D’Artagnan, who most probably will be.”	442.85671992911915
“Gascon-headed man, will you have done?” said the king.	313.87179097508323
“Sire,” replied Tréville, without lowering his voice in the least,	401.52183238830526
“either order my Musketeer to be restored to me, or let him be tried.”	472.2057328374367
“He shall be tried,” said the cardinal.	399.9165204741027
“Well, so much the better; for in that case I shall demand of his	490.85649941330917
Majesty permission to plead for him.”	335.58177769020136
The king feared an outbreak.	368.46189203692285
“If his Eminence,” said he, “did not have personal motives—”	467.23103547409494
The cardinal saw what the king was about to say and interrupted him:	367.986264377305
“Pardon me,” said he; “but the instant your Majesty considers me a	377.7942560589478
prejudiced judge, I withdraw.”	364.83594331071845
“Come,” said the king, “will you swear, by my father, that Athos was at	434.12973947948456
your residence during the event and that he took no part in it?”	302.8185053173876
“By your glorious father, and by yourself, whom I love and venerate	296.0418471856381
above all the world, I swear it.”	464.10702496678766
“Be so kind as to reflect, sire,” said the cardinal. “If we release the	471.54202208781237
prisoner thus, we shall never know the truth.”	472.03255100318296
“Athos may always be found,” replied Tréville, “ready to answer, when	334.0840383656491
it shall please the gownsmen to interrogate him. He will not desert,	343.2167482692662
Monsieur the Cardinal, be assured of that; I will answer for him.”	299.44213387931893
“No, he will not desert,” said the king; “he can always be found, as	371.3830513621873
Tréville says. Besides,” added he, lowering his voice and looking with	353.3540464420557
a suppliant air at the cardinal, “let us give them apparent security;	295.4781033090482
that is policy.”	405.89835826878823
This policy of Louis XIII. made Richelieu smile.	303.7979730929665
“Order it as you please, sire; you possess the right of pardon.”	319.01930018152865
“The right of pardoning only applies to the guilty,” said Tréville, who	463.92399982622305
was determined to have the last word, “and my Musketeer is innocent. It	323.14991056832764
is not mercy, then, that you are about to accord, sire, it is justice.”	383.2262106499973
“And he is in the Fort l’Evêque?” said the king.	377.8931536956762
“Yes, sire, in solitary confinement, in a dungeon, like the lowest	410.81225807599435
criminal.”	415.47130538658575
“The devil!” murmured the king; “what must be done?”	358.9787932065118
“Sign an order for his release, and all will be said,” replied the	332.5531951222665
cardinal. “I believe with your Majesty that Monsieur de Tréville’s	384.0342896185967
guarantee is more than sufficient.”	463.2678131874591
Tréville bowed very respectfully, with a joy that was not unmixed with	348.43775369481745
fear; he would have preferred an obstinate resistance on the part of	357.16631066119453
the cardinal to this sudden yielding.	330.2704477918379
The king signed the order for release, and Tréville carried it away	435.4939010685212
without delay. As he was about to leave the presence, the cardinal gave	459.45372908317944
him a friendly smile, and said, “A perfect harmony reigns, sire,	465.22281816656476
between the leaders and the soldiers of your Musketeers, which must be	335.50026341515024
profitable for the service and honorable to all.”	444.4408045441013
“He will play me some dog’s trick or other, and that immediately,” said	347.66074666547786
Tréville. “One has never the last word with such a man. But let us be	348.0229759327618
quick—the king may change his mind in an hour; and at all events it is	299.8429797083866
more difficult to replace a man in the Fort l’Evêque or the Bastille	307.3030085437601
who has got out, than to keep a prisoner there who is in.”	477.01490551505276
M. de Tréville made his entrance triumphantly into the Fort l’Evêque,	417.25598579538394
whence he delivered the Musketeer, whose peaceful indifference had not	354.71790612209804
for a moment abandoned him.	452.04478974669735
The first time he saw D’Artagnan, “You have come off well,” said he to	299.1340587240964
him; “there is your Jussac thrust paid for. There still remains that of	323.09247906686477
Bernajoux, but you must not be too confident.”	306.3686057953773
As to the rest, M. de Tréville had good reason to mistrust the cardinal	354.0069448244173
and to think that all was not over, for scarcely had the captain of the	459.85637572065076
Musketeers closed the door after him, than his Eminence said to the	361.4340073876896
king, “Now that we are at length by ourselves, we will, if your Majesty	441.7345722053491
pleases, converse seriously. Sire, Buckingham has been in Paris five	396.5725145421197
days, and only left this morning.”	473.8092891638063
Chapter XVI.	432.17896158888146
IN WHICH M. SÉGUIER, KEEPER OF THE SEALS, LOOKS MORE THAN ONCE FOR THE	458.40151749605144
BELL	486.04314209511347
It is impossible to form an idea of the impression these few words made	484.10466194319827
upon Louis XIII. He grew pale and red alternately; and the cardinal saw	437.1555096126756
at once that he had recovered by a single blow all the ground he had	491.3202767685323
lost.	312.2722601913392
“Buckingham in Paris!” cried he, “and why does he come?”	438.57255025791846
“To conspire, no doubt, with your enemies, the Huguenots and the	479.23647605950566
Spaniards.”	304.1156332004402
“No, _pardieu_, no! To conspire against my honor with Madame de	486.8170401148075
Chevreuse, Madame de Longueville, and the Condés.”	334.5988882416691
“Oh, sire, what an idea! The queen is too virtuous; and besides, loves	482.25100024451467
your Majesty too well.”	365.2894570852839
“Woman is weak, Monsieur Cardinal,” said the king; “and as to loving me	453.03523344691575
much, I have my own opinion as to that love.”	438.0970869937948
“I not the less maintain,” said the cardinal, “that the Duke of	407.3409433898282
Buckingham came to Paris for a project wholly political.”	361.7150499290458
“And I am sure that he came for quite another purpose, Monsieur	458.1854639960833
Cardinal; but if the queen be guilty, let her tremble!”	327.8694522158082
“Indeed,” said the cardinal, “whatever repugnance I may have to	413.8134674887142
directing my mind to such a treason, your Majesty compels me to think	355.7175181680662
of it. Madame de Lannoy, whom, according to your Majesty’s command, I	384.3308163912844
have frequently interrogated, told me this morning that the night	332.0847039634709
before last her Majesty sat up very late, that this morning she wept	371.4789736622595
much, and that she was writing all day.”	458.7877396806497
“That’s it!” cried the king; “to him, no doubt. Cardinal, I must have	332.16263347828624
the queen’s papers.”	300.2744058398444
“But how to take them, sire? It seems to me that it is neither your	414.32792642255345
Majesty nor myself who can charge himself with such a mission.”	376.58015489932427
“How did they act with regard to the Maréchale d’Ancre?” cried the	312.64041541069054
king, in the highest state of choler; “first her closets were	377.05587619188503
thoroughly searched, and then she herself.”	431.0803913273363
“The Maréchale d’Ancre was no more than the Maréchale d’Ancre. A	396.04950073115185
Florentine adventurer, sire, and that was all; while the august spouse	302.48637153135866
of your Majesty is Anne of Austria, Queen of France—that is to say, one	316.4685767538102
of the greatest princesses in the world.”	476.16773443244347
“She is not the less guilty, Monsieur Duke! The more she has forgotten	305.57282573978927
the high position in which she was placed, the more degrading is her	437.5936879699113
fall. Besides, I long ago determined to put an end to all these petty	440.95560039485656
intrigues of policy and love. She has near her a certain Laporte.”	360.2990982655796
“Who, I believe, is the mainspring of all this, I confess,” said the	465.1520432245129
cardinal.	350.4645489456061
“You think then, as I do, that she deceives me?” said the king.	321.24761914351797
“I believe, and I repeat it to your Majesty, that the queen conspires	340.3461520828601
against the power of the king, but I have not said against his honor.”	454.498858081398
“And I—I tell you against both. I tell you the queen does not love me;	428.9934392309224
I tell you she loves another; I tell you she loves that infamous	387.41588690447315
Buckingham! Why did you not have him arrested while in Paris?”	389.4863688682437
“Arrest the Duke! Arrest the prime minister of King Charles I.! Think	296.170349682779
of it, sire! What a scandal! And if the suspicions of your Majesty,	408.1562629117626
which I still continue to doubt, should prove to have any foundation,	387.2843464569937
what a terrible disclosure, what a fearful scandal!”	353.15409614832055
“But as he exposed himself like a vagabond or a thief, he should have	318.462726660745
been—”	363.136573075558
Louis XIII. stopped, terrified at what he was about to say, while	486.0216629281124
Richelieu, stretching out his neck, waited uselessly for the word which	294.4511703321369
had died on the lips of the king.	365.07947193291506
“He should have been—?”	374.9889273476432
“Nothing,” said the king, “nothing. But all the time he was in Paris,	392.98734158260197
you, of course, did not lose sight of him?”	449.80643886379573
“No, sire.”	474.0920466219684
“Where did he lodge?”	350.18444809721456
“Rue de la Harpe. No. 75.”	370.7164068685339
“Where is that?”	444.12304257465405
“By the side of the Luxembourg.”	439.1686154362651
“And you are certain that the queen and he did not see each other?”	357.0270793051496
“I believe the queen to have too high a sense of her duty, sire.”	427.4824137402916
“But they have corresponded; it is to him that the queen has been	366.93566706041224
writing all the day. Monsieur Duke, I must have those letters!”	351.7811346145597
“Sire, notwithstanding—”	307.83779288252526
“Monsieur Duke, at whatever price it may be, I will have them.”	344.95877440176366
“I would, however, beg your Majesty to observe—”	369.5057907298635
“Do you, then, also join in betraying me, Monsieur Cardinal, by thus	300.8255075585049
always opposing my will? Are you also in accord with Spain and England,	433.5534676692225
with Madame de Chevreuse and the queen?”	451.0711117753864
“Sire,” replied the cardinal, sighing, “I believed myself secure from	389.35434649927396
such a suspicion.”	306.3916500007704
“Monsieur Cardinal, you have heard me; I will have those letters.”	331.8924141275764
“There is but one way.”	382.7465960230767
“What is that?”	359.4209893931828
“That would be to charge Monsieur de Séguier, the keeper of the seals,	390.7136060586543
with this mission. The matter enters completely into the duties of the	411.90926479507505
post.”	394.180758261107
“Let him be sent for instantly.”	330.8288425781793
“He is most likely at my hôtel. I requested him to call, and when I	350.84271099562693
came to the Louvre I left orders if he came, to desire him to wait.”	325.8565267751722
“Let him be sent for instantly.”	438.7123079317007
“Your Majesty’s orders shall be executed; but—”	304.7654994149796
“But what?”	355.3819923685718
“But the queen will perhaps refuse to obey.”	371.0920177157904
“My orders?”	351.07945894629233
“Yes, if she is ignorant that these orders come from the king.”	361.8353676737136
“Well, that she may have no doubt on that head, I will go and inform	443.2030268794372
her myself.”	430.9626168627614
“Your Majesty will not forget that I have done everything in my power	459.4160778942261
to prevent a rupture.”	314.51012290952826
“Yes, Duke, yes, I know you are very indulgent toward the queen, too	442.77637496719296
indulgent, perhaps; we shall have occasion, I warn you, at some future	324.537341234564
period to speak of that.”	317.07692883475323
“Whenever it shall please your Majesty; but I shall be always happy and	425.0929609524177
proud, sire, to sacrifice myself to the harmony which I desire to see	392.51015438391136
reign between you and the Queen of France.”	392.27813718981935
“Very well, Cardinal, very well; but, meantime, send for Monsieur the	314.04269526115223
Keeper of the Seals. I will go to the queen.”	446.810604195112
And Louis XIII., opening the door of communication, passed into the	390.489144037683
corridor which led from his apartments to those of Anne of Austria.	320.62673175836926
The queen was in the midst of her women—Mme. de Guitaut, Mme. de Sable,	435.00348197558446
Mme. de Montbazon, and Mme. de Guémené. In a corner was the Spanish	359.4760529351564
companion, Donna Estafania, who had followed her from Madrid. Mme.	477.42107794591925
Guémené was reading aloud, and everybody was listening to her with	395.2954106027926
attention with the exception of the queen, who had, on the contrary,	482.8488085216675
desired this reading in order that she might be able, while feigning to	423.20962421389356
listen, to pursue the thread of her own thoughts.	452.34881649465694
These thoughts, gilded as they were by a last reflection of love, were	382.8877617916868
not the less sad. Anne of Austria, deprived of the confidence of her	328.5621097621696
husband, pursued by the hatred of the cardinal, who could not pardon	396.67249433335064
her for having repulsed a more tender feeling, having before her eyes	346.0907625896614
the example of the queen-mother whom that hatred had tormented all her	294.7152999237489
life—though Marie de Médicis, if the memoirs of the time are to be	456.9305492681244
believed, had begun by according to the cardinal that sentiment which	388.5680340429816
Anne of Austria always refused him—Anne of Austria had seen her most	418.6749906155249
devoted servants fall around her, her most intimate confidants, her	481.12994744751524
dearest favorites. Like those unfortunate persons endowed with a fatal	338.18898072708265
gift, she brought misfortune upon everything she touched. Her	319.1142841290697
friendship was a fatal sign which called down persecution. Mme. de	373.93813583062024
Chevreuse and Mme. de Bernet were exiled, and Laporte did not conceal	434.93286049043667
from his mistress that he expected to be arrested every instant.	487.5194288357035
It was at the moment when she was plunged in the deepest and darkest of	312.94453159660895
these reflections that the door of the chamber opened, and the king	361.44147328474446
entered.	392.95820403410715
The reader hushed herself instantly. All the ladies rose, and there was	457.98559790009267
a profound silence. As to the king, he made no demonstration of	299.9977956054144
politeness, only stopping before the queen. “Madame,” said he, “you are	435.60803725582446
about to receive a visit from the chancellor, who will communicate	295.91679400856765
certain matters to you with which I have charged him.”	445.64521583031785
The unfortunate queen, who was constantly threatened with divorce,	367.2521380141344
exile, and trial even, turned pale under her rouge, and could not	452.26864270871516
refrain from saying, “But why this visit, sire? What can the chancellor	457.9191486494408
have to say to me that your Majesty could not say yourself?”	489.12424832789077
The king turned upon his heel without reply, and almost at the same	362.1617008370598
instant the captain of the Guards, M. de Guitant, announced the visit	335.18528330358174
of the chancellor.	446.21211713078833
When the chancellor appeared, the king had already gone out by another	417.38587011770414
door.	475.8233670657755
The chancellor entered, half smiling, half blushing. As we shall	365.7733447154443
probably meet with him again in the course of our history, it may be	484.2194494659862
well for our readers to be made at once acquainted with him.	313.38517751456914
This chancellor was a pleasant man. He was Des Roches le Masle, canon	332.4441304988029
of Notre Dame, who had formerly been valet of a bishop, who introduced	306.50589091160623
him to his Eminence as a perfectly devout man. The cardinal trusted	465.9342440528221
him, and therein found his advantage.	317.35631938317647
There are many stories related of him, and among them this. After a	347.5710997422278
wild youth, he had retired into a convent, there to expiate, at least	388.1222698712213
for some time, the follies of adolescence. On entering this holy place,	480.7415488716375
the poor penitent was unable to shut the door so close as to prevent	419.0113603514468
the passions he fled from entering with him. He was incessantly	313.49783975379034
attacked by them, and the superior, to whom he had confided this	365.7899730424456
misfortune, wishing as much as in him lay to free him from them, had	347.62482277103385
advised him, in order to conjure away the tempting demon, to have	368.45024930551835
recourse to the bell rope, and ring with all his might. At the	452.6560701073556
denunciating sound, the monks would be rendered aware that temptation	405.0413313159547
was besieging a brother, and all the community would go to prayers.	299.60281359573554
This advice appeared good to the future chancellor. He conjured the	351.0521395648028
evil spirit with abundance of prayers offered up by the monks. But the	440.0221786126916
devil does not suffer himself to be easily dispossessed from a place in	319.9163294979611
which he has fixed his garrison. In proportion as they redoubled the	325.9512312845678
exorcisms he redoubled the temptations; so that day and night the bell	382.55848856050943
was ringing full swing, announcing the extreme desire for mortification	301.3617570341237
which the penitent experienced.	321.93480665240594
The monks had no longer an instant of repose. By day they did nothing	412.9352845074843
but ascend and descend the steps which led to the chapel; at night, in	298.4512857273144
addition to complines and matins, they were further obliged to leap	413.9007233466581
twenty times out of their beds and prostrate themselves on the floor of	311.0459246843314
their cells.	415.21221069640023
It is not known whether it was the devil who gave way, or the monks who	468.60227762002125
grew tired; but within three months the penitent reappeared in the	356.92471769366847
world with the reputation of being the most terrible _possessed_ that	360.91505243415975
ever existed.	308.51079787591306
On leaving the convent he entered into the magistracy, became president	423.7539697914117
on the place of his uncle, embraced the cardinal’s party, which did not	325.83043610881526
prove want of sagacity, became chancellor, served his Eminence with	325.6278817843795
zeal in his hatred against the queen-mother and his vengeance against	343.7771599869463
Anne of Austria, stimulated the judges in the affair of Calais,	438.2572753852405
encouraged the attempts of M. de Laffemas, chief gamekeeper of France;	300.9898041807546
then, at length, invested with the entire confidence of the cardinal—a	445.87450037349674
confidence which he had so well earned—he received the singular	395.4065957458483
commission for the execution of which he presented himself in the	477.83293743950134
queen’s apartments.	307.28637562264146
The queen was still standing when he entered; but scarcely had she	338.4690782676377
perceived him then she reseated herself in her armchair, and made a	319.4271436160144
sign to her women to resume their cushions and stools, and with an air	433.2292121104723
of supreme hauteur, said, “What do you desire, monsieur, and with what	338.8322409623841
object do you present yourself here?”	350.10229477688785
“To make, madame, in the name of the king, and without prejudice to the	338.19162831396767
respect which I have the honor to owe to your Majesty a close	476.2098979888884
examination into all your papers.”	293.4708728073963
“How, monsieur, an investigation of my papers—mine! Truly, this is an	331.03621814587893
indignity!”	361.06927880021914
“Be kind enough to pardon me, madame; but in this circumstance I am but	325.6761415154048
the instrument which the king employs. Has not his Majesty just left	416.64445380201596
you, and has he not himself asked you to prepare for this visit?”	342.5218457601696
“Search, then, monsieur! I am a criminal, as it appears. Estafania,	474.75024290904946
give up the keys of my drawers and my desks.”	442.4919777318462
For form’s sake the chancellor paid a visit to the pieces of furniture	331.32252909326235
named; but he well knew that it was not in a piece of furniture that	347.878806416846
the queen would place the important letter she had written that day.	440.0938819343697
When the chancellor had opened and shut twenty times the drawers of the	300.0161421481491
secretaries, it became necessary, whatever hesitation he might	306.7125385934225
experience—it became necessary, I say, to come to the conclusion of the	464.6393374948099
affair; that is to say, to search the queen herself. The chancellor	423.9871926028087
advanced, therefore, toward Anne of Austria, and said with a very	341.0083437347573
perplexed and embarrassed air, “And now it remains for me to make the	491.1684626295852
principal examination.”	450.3036351472199
“What is that?” asked the queen, who did not understand, or rather was	408.2271461239751
not willing to understand.	326.99779939720105
“His majesty is certain that a letter has been written by you during	472.24827077222596
the day; he knows that it has not yet been sent to its address. This	417.15187040206945
letter is not in your table nor in your secretary; and yet this letter	314.73423866572944
must be somewhere.”	314.50453484293854
“Would you dare to lift your hand to your queen?” said Anne of Austria,	350.1481802853588
drawing herself up to her full height, and fixing her eyes upon the	335.67266621352996
chancellor with an expression almost threatening.	371.2689096326897
“I am a faithful subject of the king, madame, and all that his Majesty	309.0763609063729
commands I shall do.”	450.70468487480105
“Well, it is true!” said Anne of Austria; “and the spies of the	426.83086087218715
cardinal have served him faithfully. I have written a letter today;	362.12525333548297
that letter is not yet gone. The letter is here.” And the queen laid	426.66214736677404
her beautiful hand on her bosom.	304.89728837964765
“Then give me that letter, madame,” said the chancellor.	427.93500108081616
“I will give it to none but the king, monsieur,” said Anne.	374.7012268881465
“If the king had desired that the letter should be given to him,	423.0280472315595
madame, he would have demanded it of you himself. But I repeat to you,	395.74549473997
I am charged with reclaiming it; and if you do not give it up—”	489.84864808851313
“Well?”	329.5983146511203
“He has, then, charged me to take it from you.”	317.0465421904175
“How! What do you say?”	327.14012630780064
“That my orders go far, madame; and that I am authorized to seek for	421.01479001447194
the suspected paper, even on the person of your Majesty.”	450.49769607348406
“What horror!” cried the queen.	365.4934409895693
“Be kind enough, then, madame, to act more compliantly.”	424.5622087149344
“The conduct is infamously violent! Do you know that, monsieur?”	462.8761129034759
“The king commands it, madame; excuse me.”	488.3318805021213
“I will not suffer it! No, no, I would rather die!” cried the queen, in	327.52624868846664
whom the imperious blood of Spain and Austria began to rise.	337.72293943633935
The chancellor made a profound reverence. Then, with the intention	340.5791605653869
quite patent of not drawing back a foot from the accomplishment of the	401.6188169959592
commission with which he was charged, and as the attendant of an	319.74584213662894
executioner might have done in the chamber of torture, he approached	446.183550868122
Anne of Austria, from whose eyes at the same instant sprang tears of	456.1362435126671
rage.	383.6336103791872
The queen was, as we have said, of great beauty. The commission might	475.2289779770173
well be called delicate; and the king had reached, in his jealousy of	392.4506022592519
Buckingham, the point of not being jealous of anyone else.	433.419899419178
Without doubt the chancellor Séguier looked about at that moment for	305.9362668704757
the rope of the famous bell; but not finding it he summoned his	441.4006881044904
resolution, and stretched forth his hands toward the place where the	391.2072098367506
queen had acknowledged the paper was to be found.	361.457753525827
Anne of Austria took one step backward, became so pale that it might be	412.6660639624449
