said she was dying, and leaning with her left hand upon a table behind	384.0009360115474
her to keep herself from falling, she with her right hand drew the	414.6318165940244
paper from her bosom and held it out to the keeper of the seals.	402.9221405515102
“There, monsieur, there is that letter!” cried the queen, with a broken	489.9536796594539
and trembling voice; “take it, and deliver me from your odious	344.7166642705518
presence.”	470.7907723405377
The chancellor, who, on his part, trembled with an emotion easily to be	325.6494295003183
conceived, took the letter, bowed to the ground, and retired. The door	316.76435418332835
was scarcely closed upon him, when the queen sank, half fainting, into	436.4947038624882
the arms of her women.	374.41808934398176
The chancellor carried the letter to the king without having read a	441.85557725544055
single word of it. The king took it with a trembling hand, looked for	443.73164815684765
the address, which was wanting, became very pale, opened it slowly,	295.0885115560855
then seeing by the first words that it was addressed to the King of	305.9777536377852
Spain, he read it rapidly.	314.79721315707957
It was nothing but a plan of attack against the cardinal. The queen	443.2548130357019
pressed her brother and the Emperor of Austria to appear to be wounded,	379.4267847812729
as they really were, by the policy of Richelieu—the eternal object of	344.951728164197
which was the abasement of the house of Austria—to declare war against	357.9606844801979
France, and as a condition of peace, to insist upon the dismissal of	370.6812947121258
the cardinal; but as to love, there was not a single word about it in	321.7798473504044
all the letter.	375.2175806024042
The king, quite delighted, inquired if the cardinal was still at the	320.92941427096974
Louvre; he was told that his Eminence awaited the orders of his Majesty	454.24975859923643
in the business cabinet.	431.4401281764427
The king went straight to him.	428.78088835524306
“There, Duke,” said he, “you were right and I was wrong. The whole	298.0067280322174
intrigue is political, and there is not the least question of love in	431.2422921705827
this letter; but, on the other hand, there is abundant question of	368.3713378013551
you.”	372.57324928377693
The cardinal took the letter, and read it with the greatest attention;	447.3778065707509
then, when he had arrived at the end of it, he read it a second time.	462.00581180090796
“Well, your Majesty,” said he, “you see how far my enemies go; they	392.8283448368585
menace you with two wars if you do not dismiss me. In your place, in	348.04801487466506
truth, sire, I should yield to such powerful instance; and on my part,	292.2058245205508
it would be a real happiness to withdraw from public affairs.”	341.89671884087613
“What say you, Duke?”	414.9590588969693
“I say, sire, that my health is sinking under these excessive struggles	366.9111908392136
and these never-ending labors. I say that according to all probability	486.8701633701065
I shall not be able to undergo the fatigues of the siege of La	387.66963331562204
Rochelle, and that it would be far better that you should appoint there	337.5801291603834
either Monsieur de Condé, Monsieur de Bassopierre, or some valiant	411.63093526108844
gentleman whose business is war, and not me, who am a churchman, and	402.3446991540269
who am constantly turned aside for my real vocation to look after	373.93462564263785
matters for which I have no aptitude. You would be the happier for it	453.94604041980324
at home, sire, and I do not doubt you would be the greater for it	359.7816754994168
abroad.”	358.2226735034452
“Monsieur Duke,” said the king, “I understand you. Be satisfied, all	308.8449955692602
who are named in that letter shall be punished as they deserve, even	448.83144572640276
the queen herself.”	445.14739303942065
“What do you say, sire? God forbid that the queen should suffer the	343.6031431720342
least inconvenience or uneasiness on my account! She has always	420.20654667482313
believed me, sire, to be her enemy; although your Majesty can bear	383.7917610622641
witness that I have always taken her part warmly, even against you. Oh,	462.09460735949074
if she betrayed your Majesty on the side of your honor, it would be	408.7847306773316
quite another thing, and I should be the first to say, ‘No grace,	385.19338837938756
sire—no grace for the guilty!’ Happily, there is nothing of the kind,	483.5699313517947
and your Majesty has just acquired a new proof of it.”	440.06967311421613
“That is true, Monsieur Cardinal,” said the king, “and you were right,	482.0197044351105
as you always are; but the queen, not the less, deserves all my anger.”	371.23220958996774
“It is you, sire, who have now incurred hers. And even if she were to	426.5308895516115
be seriously offended, I could well understand it; your Majesty has	361.5882538877858
treated her with a severity—”	353.5490659428872
“It is thus I will always treat my enemies and yours, Duke, however	384.23771492142953
high they may be placed, and whatever peril I may incur in acting	449.16964746806957
severely toward them.”	296.9819817449059
“The queen is my enemy, but is not yours, sire; on the contrary, she is	430.8519276927608
a devoted, submissive, and irreproachable wife. Allow me, then, sire,	293.0969590059864
to intercede for her with your Majesty.”	481.03770873115985
“Let her humble herself, then, and come to me first.”	415.1929729737872
“On the contrary, sire, set the example. You have committed the first	418.39153479710285
wrong, since it was you who suspected the queen.”	437.5025761784578
“What! I make the first advances?” said the king. “Never!”	334.5222407322398
“Sire, I entreat you to do so.”	471.67957814592205
“Besides, in what manner can I make advances first?”	455.93956590147786
“By doing a thing which you know will be agreeable to her.”	458.9772076070284
“What is that?”	388.00094374289324
“Give a ball; you know how much the queen loves dancing. I will answer	313.50385905760913
for it, her resentment will not hold out against such an attention.”	325.75183046507107
“Monsieur Cardinal, you know that I do not like worldly pleasures.”	312.6104867476983
“The queen will only be the more grateful to you, as she knows your	487.4444935825429
antipathy for that amusement; besides, it will be an opportunity for	418.06073344362545
her to wear those beautiful diamonds which you gave her recently on her	405.88711714937824
birthday and with which she has since had no occasion to adorn	491.6652693941338
herself.”	402.4213678985538
“We shall see, Monsieur Cardinal, we shall see,” said the king, who, in	310.3331896140837
his joy at finding the queen guilty of a crime which he cared little	303.05281393286
about, and innocent of a fault of which he had great dread, was ready	309.0486318728634
to make up all differences with her, “we shall see, but upon my honor,	453.1773032552331
you are too indulgent toward her.”	460.94349632084777
“Sire,” said the cardinal, “leave severity to your ministers. Clemency	351.96732345574367
is a royal virtue; employ it, and you will find that you derive	293.04639006434326
advantage therein.”	419.43203407791634
Thereupon the cardinal, hearing the clock strike eleven, bowed low,	351.3572345525676
asking permission of the king to retire, and supplicating him to come	397.7113077514844
to a good understanding with the queen.	410.10719837481065
Anne of Austria, who, in consequence of the seizure of her letter,	358.12195823670015
expected reproaches, was much astonished the next day to see the king	418.0515118315115
make some attempts at reconciliation with her. Her first movement was	474.07816574811
repellent. Her womanly pride and her queenly dignity had both been so	457.93716090336363
cruelly offended that she could not come round at the first advance;	369.6749141846991
but, overpersuaded by the advice of her women, she at last had the	404.2550563045431
appearance of beginning to forget. The king took advantage of this	469.43540393662903
favorable moment to tell her that he had the intention of shortly	387.89211652418135
giving a fête.	444.79101508755986
A fête was so rare a thing for poor Anne of Austria that at this	461.79288942481605
announcement, as the cardinal had predicted, the last trace of her	394.20049623404435
resentment disappeared, if not from her heart, at least from her	340.22932778361167
countenance. She asked upon what day this fête would take place, but	414.0429764617077
the king replied that he must consult the cardinal upon that head.	436.26699093477635
Indeed, every day the king asked the cardinal when this fête should	457.5606821651961
take place; and every day the cardinal, under some pretext, deferred	319.1476212315929
fixing it. Ten days passed away thus.	347.6696040351578
On the eighth day after the scene we have described, the cardinal	386.98478041533843
received a letter with the London stamp which only contained these	395.6485128717338
lines: “I have them; but I am unable to leave London for want of money.	348.89909272256136
Send me five hundred pistoles, and four or five days after I have	437.49008086358293
received them I shall be in Paris.”	389.64291209018154
On the same day the cardinal received this letter the king put his	433.1532341546912
customary question to him.	328.2300612408291
Richelieu counted on his fingers, and said to himself, “She will	317.0365556454719
arrive, she says, four or five days after having received the money. It	465.1978988039075
will require four or five days for the transmission of the money, four	430.9725114041664
or five days for her to return; that makes ten days. Now, allowing for	357.1193109780917
contrary winds, accidents, and a woman’s weakness, there are twelve	445.44052546074704
days.”	412.99377578619135
“Well, Monsieur Duke,” said the king, “have you made your	455.48186829472957
calculations?”	322.12723518342625
“Yes, sire. Today is the twentieth of September. The aldermen of the	436.6300075595882
city give a fête on the third of October. That will fall in wonderfully	462.47254605601427
well; you will not appear to have gone out of your way to please the	295.23608681655753
queen.”	295.5554980874772
Then the cardinal added, “_A propos_, sire, do not forget to tell her	396.26408757724244
Majesty the evening before the fête that you should like to see how her	366.1851162679142
diamond studs become her.”	353.2086662965696
Chapter XVII.	478.9536347349213
BONACIEUX AT HOME	312.7158663564785
It was the second time the cardinal had mentioned these diamond studs	480.74910114398836
to the king. Louis XIII. was struck with this insistence, and began to	442.0469910184821
fancy that this recommendation concealed some mystery.	463.3313585456698
More than once the king had been humiliated by the cardinal, whose	330.7202728643366
police, without having yet attained the perfection of the modern	331.0178965517917
police, were excellent, being better informed than himself, even upon	324.7009722141737
what was going on in his own household. He hoped, then, in a	466.74057817516007
conversation with Anne of Austria, to obtain some information from that	393.8529359357223
conversation, and afterward to come upon his Eminence with some secret	344.54738660609917
which the cardinal either knew or did not know, but which, in either	305.9777440258781
case, would raise him infinitely in the eyes of his minister.	380.59932640490536
He went then to the queen, and according to custom accosted her with	345.9440587082258
fresh menaces against those who surrounded her. Anne of Austria lowered	296.20180166150453
her head, allowed the torrent to flow on without replying, hoping that	334.20893095687495
it would cease of itself; but this was not what Louis XIII. meant. Louis	358.4254854722915
XIII. wanted a discussion from which some light or other might break,	302.45740301572204
convinced as he was that the cardinal had some afterthought and was	454.59411813363926
preparing for him one of those terrible surprises which his Eminence	479.85240643592874
was so skillful in getting up. He arrived at this end by his	429.55982379442565
persistence in accusation.	317.4143805090905
“But,” cried Anne of Austria, tired of these vague attacks, “but, sire,	457.8162063385267
you do not tell me all that you have in your heart. What have I done,	432.11550253640587
then? Let me know what crime I have committed. It is impossible that	446.74058302360623
your Majesty can make all this ado about a letter written to my	304.77104812771597
brother.”	356.5437096197414
The king, attacked in a manner so direct, did not know what to answer;	365.5147765030762
and he thought that this was the moment for expressing the desire which	339.6797176931626
he was not going to have made until the evening before the fête.	344.0014745762233
“Madame,” said he, with dignity, “there will shortly be a ball at the	367.8929424007824
Hôtel de Ville. I wish, in order to honor our worthy aldermen, you	309.47476485043524
should appear in ceremonial costume, and above all, ornamented with the	364.54312160377725
diamond studs which I gave you on your birthday. That is my answer.”	338.8742517517037
The answer was terrible. Anne of Austria believed that Louis XIII. knew	435.6760077584683
all, and that the cardinal had persuaded him to employ this long	370.08104981136074
dissimulation of seven or eight days, which, likewise, was	319.55851294222754
characteristic. She became excessively pale, leaned her beautiful hand	353.1268671095068
upon a _console_, which hand appeared then like one of wax, and looking	427.2044295370762
at the king with terror in her eyes, she was unable to reply by a	329.49476518758564
single syllable.	299.14432756417085
“You hear, madame,” said the king, who enjoyed the embarrassment to its	356.9383850152994
full extent, but without guessing the cause. “You hear, madame?”	342.174611527848
“Yes, sire, I hear,” stammered the queen.	382.7850197277554
“You will appear at this ball?”	469.05778875146746
“Yes.”	435.1758252818055
“With those studs?”	415.14185026979453
“Yes.”	364.46408798233904
The queen’s paleness, if possible, increased; the king perceived it,	478.55147010858343
and enjoyed it with that cold cruelty which was one of the worst sides	370.18585735391673
of his character.	377.93689125057443
“Then that is agreed,” said the king, “and that is all I had to say to	314.82666768255075
you.”	428.41104117550634
“But on what day will this ball take place?” asked Anne of Austria.	454.5331563163073
Louis XIII. felt instinctively that he ought not to reply to this	453.2748500979566
question, the queen having put it in an almost dying voice.	382.1219873943087
“Oh, very shortly, madame,” said he; “but I do not precisely recollect	336.5782971912354
the date of the day. I will ask the cardinal.”	319.2319485706527
“It was the cardinal, then, who informed you of this fête?”	486.81345163865876
“Yes, madame,” replied the astonished king; “but why do you ask that?”	414.60404265408147
“It was he who told you to invite me to appear with these studs?”	340.3460498605386
“That is to say, madame—”	397.34119537561037
“It was he, sire, it was he!”	471.3339735487356
“Well, and what does it signify whether it was he or I? Is there any	365.5662414986285
crime in this request?”	356.5191051144436
“No, sire.”	490.7694733064825
“Then you will appear?”	485.67267965389533
“Yes, sire.”	389.5121116532847
“That is well,” said the king, retiring, “that is well; I count upon	442.0874915904045
it.”	337.3699016272996
The queen made a curtsy, less from etiquette than because her knees	441.94892418427065
were sinking under her. The king went away enchanted.	470.23013283037653
“I am lost,” murmured the queen, “lost!—for the cardinal knows all, and	298.9107246614153
it is he who urges on the king, who as yet knows nothing but will soon	438.196440334616
know everything. I am lost! My God, my God, my God!”	326.2105276201763
She knelt upon a cushion and prayed, with her head buried between her	400.330233783081
palpitating arms.	431.4489337097019
In fact, her position was terrible. Buckingham had returned to London;	292.53885317398795
Mme. de Chevreuse was at Tours. More closely watched than ever, the	430.72367295925403
queen felt certain, without knowing how to tell which, that one of her	474.0168842953558
women had betrayed her. Laporte could not leave the Louvre; she had not	339.9863129909091
a soul in the world in whom she could confide. Thus, while	491.4422819678964
contemplating the misfortune which threatened her and the abandonment	373.48807903524437
in which she was left, she broke out into sobs and tears.	478.3405045479909
“Can I be of service to your Majesty?” said all at once a voice full of	459.8322491593667
sweetness and pity.	322.7825592857054
The queen turned sharply round, for there could be no deception in the	490.01913886337115
expression of that voice; it was a friend who spoke thus.	391.8382808367893
In fact, at one of the doors which opened into the queen’s apartment	350.9959457335565
appeared the pretty Mme. Bonacieux. She had been engaged in arranging	470.91994401353713
the dresses and linen in a closet when the king entered; she could not	325.4788538426862
get out and had heard all.	389.9723167553722
The queen uttered a piercing cry at finding herself surprised—for in	300.46660428014974
her trouble she did not at first recognize the young woman who had been	446.3502450296769
given to her by Laporte.	358.3736169943089
“Oh, fear nothing, madame!” said the young woman, clasping her hands	453.53374007692526
and weeping herself at the queen’s sorrows; “I am your Majesty’s, body	441.158127820774
and soul, and however far I may be from you, however inferior may be my	399.4824488243669
position, I believe I have discovered a means of extricating your	378.82769313386007
Majesty from your trouble.”	295.2461214234528
“You, oh, heaven, you!” cried the queen; “but look me in the face. I am	409.0141465075384
betrayed on all sides. Can I trust in you?”	431.5025775377699
“Oh, madame!” cried the young woman, falling on her knees; “upon my	373.0339321329326
soul, I am ready to die for your Majesty!”	368.36843686987027
This expression sprang from the very bottom of the heart, and, like the	403.1057658429484
first, there was no mistaking it.	353.0908723633363
“Yes,” continued Mme. Bonacieux, “yes, there are traitors here; but by	335.62463775878314
the holy name of the Virgin, I swear that no one is more devoted to	463.62865782141324
your Majesty than I am. Those studs which the king speaks of, you gave	356.26976225784756
them to the Duke of Buckingham, did you not? Those studs were enclosed	317.80106343373853
in a little rosewood box which he held under his arm? Am I deceived? Is	486.1149093850836
it not so, madame?”	373.8458254738519
“Oh, my God, my God!” murmured the queen, whose teeth chattered with	489.96125753857194
fright.	435.7651334995439
“Well, those studs,” continued Mme. Bonacieux, “we must have them back	348.66422183362556
again.”	329.4298853046115
“Yes, without doubt, it is necessary,” cried the queen; “but how am I	478.78956646732485
to act? How can it be effected?”	470.91608277591513
“Someone must be sent to the duke.”	466.4896761671234
“But who, who? In whom can I trust?”	362.11902067283313
“Place confidence in me, madame; do me that honor, my queen, and I will	449.5218978571695
find a messenger.”	489.0894380357446
“But I must write.”	456.2346193038583
“Oh, yes; that is indispensable. Two words from the hand of your	432.36296974811273
Majesty and your private seal.”	385.0267381649531
“But these two words would bring about my condemnation, divorce,	440.08365642938696
exile!”	448.34936708508155
“Yes, if they fell into infamous hands. But I will answer for these two	435.0892362591703
words being delivered to their address.”	341.99519977330385
“Oh, my God! I must then place my life, my honor, my reputation, in	350.9210402881756
your hands?”	331.25586866356684
“Yes, yes, madame, you must; and I will save them all.”	422.83457647300327
“But how? Tell me at least the means.”	319.8226225321477
“My husband had been at liberty these two or three days. I have not yet	342.48776487172245
had time to see him again. He is a worthy, honest man who entertains	429.071573459717
neither love nor hatred for anybody. He will do anything I wish. He	372.93043407743806
will set out upon receiving an order from me, without knowing what he	344.2083028853609
carries, and he will carry your Majesty’s letter, without even knowing	326.6719795973871
it is from your Majesty, to the address which is on it.”	421.1741107289462
The queen took the two hands of the young woman with a burst of	355.45032667955775
emotion, gazed at her as if to read her very heart, and, seeing nothing	439.8723552596008
but sincerity in her beautiful eyes, embraced her tenderly.	445.98986503332867
“Do that,” cried she, “and you will have saved my life, you will have	330.65381305824536
saved my honor!”	320.497666196674
“Do not exaggerate the service I have the happiness to render your	460.1490021880064
Majesty. I have nothing to save for your Majesty; you are only the	484.90888574555333
victim of perfidious plots.”	421.63595114476516
“That is true, that is true, my child,” said the queen, “you are	310.48728272367026
right.”	306.3458701671715
“Give me then, that letter, madame; time presses.”	330.8885761379535
The queen ran to a little table, on which were ink, paper, and pens.	459.78920947111953
She wrote two lines, sealed the letter with her private seal, and gave	362.02338185567544
it to Mme. Bonacieux.	351.1727425385257
“And now,” said the queen, “we are forgetting one very necessary	411.2409928084456
thing.”	490.00339413536074
“What is that, madame?”	401.79884245213134
“Money.”	479.6867073218152
Mme. Bonacieux blushed.	340.60054688764984
“Yes, that is true,” said she, “and I will confess to your Majesty that	487.6205642216871
my husband—”	488.90894538642726
“Your husband has none. Is that what you would say?”	465.6924131126368
“He has some, but he is very avaricious; that is his fault.	341.92095118639406
Nevertheless, let not your Majesty be uneasy, we will find means.”	294.35125871375317
“And I have none, either,” said the queen. Those who have read the	383.3319080056576
_Memoirs_ of Mme. de Motteville will not be astonished at this reply.	300.0582946310964
“But wait a minute.”	456.82541021195016
Anne of Austria ran to her jewel case.	341.9424473830735
“Here,” said she, “here is a ring of great value, as I have been	445.76889743712695
assured. It came from my brother, the King of Spain. It is mine, and I	326.5106585564707
am at liberty to dispose of it. Take this ring; raise money with it,	337.61383006175714
and let your husband set out.”	296.87028643783515
“In an hour you shall be obeyed.”	424.42578285239523
“You see the address,” said the queen, speaking so low that Mme.	399.31965780565304
Bonacieux could hardly hear what she said, “To my Lord Duke of	411.3266893523479
Buckingham, London.”	384.66882160134037
“The letter shall be given to himself.”	423.76174586493755
“Generous girl!” cried Anne of Austria.	465.8313847208175
Mme. Bonacieux kissed the hands of the queen, concealed the paper in	296.4280730977989
the bosom of her dress, and disappeared with the lightness of a bird.	419.39646679887136
Ten minutes afterward she was at home. As she told the queen, she had	394.5851497225342
not seen her husband since his liberation; she was ignorant of the	414.57032071831543
change that had taken place in him with respect to the cardinal—a	420.2401154087114
change which had since been strengthened by two or three visits from	293.0463441377376
the Comte de Rochefort, who had become the best friend of Bonacieux,	373.78839897924735
and had persuaded him, without much trouble, that no culpable	468.3120280104363
sentiments had prompted the abduction of his wife, but that it was only	436.25370168657923
a political precaution.	477.24938981840165
She found M. Bonacieux alone; the poor man was recovering with	487.76835955656094
difficulty the order in his house, in which he had found most of the	310.78818362451983
furniture broken and the closets nearly emptied—justice not being one	321.1698698545692
of the three things which King Solomon names as leaving no traces of	419.91817854049054
their passage. As to the servant, she had run away at the moment of her	488.56240837077394
master’s arrest. Terror had had such an effect upon the poor girl that	431.86070866774196
she had never ceased walking from Paris till she reached Burgundy, her	490.2050079417436
native place.	486.15450592643896
The worthy mercer had, immediately upon re-entering his house, informed	307.1220880405798
his wife of his happy return, and his wife had replied by	369.18544037658194
congratulating him, and telling him that the first moment she could	408.28783481840134
steal from her duties should be devoted to paying him a visit.	358.87083953640774
This first moment had been delayed five days, which, under any other	442.8153592382422
circumstances, might have appeared rather long to M. Bonacieux; but he	343.2796809082528
had, in the visit he had made to the cardinal and in the visits	299.37613229926876
Rochefort had made him, ample subjects for reflection, and as everybody	328.5646305282313
knows, nothing makes time pass more quickly than reflection.	378.55395181744933
This was the more so because Bonacieux’s reflections were all	342.9055268240254
rose-colored. Rochefort called him his friend, his dear Bonacieux, and	294.06218690247897
never ceased telling him that the cardinal had a great respect for him.	425.524688527184
The mercer fancied himself already on the high road to honors and	295.5818056951221
fortune.	405.5924470138648
On her side Mme. Bonacieux had also reflected; but, it must be	460.5596756369421
admitted, upon something widely different from ambition. In spite of	312.04991729834524
herself her thoughts constantly reverted to that handsome young man who	388.9328778504676
was so brave and appeared to be so much in love. Married at eighteen to	410.91751459094866
M. Bonacieux, having always lived among her husband’s friends—people	300.85372191228043
little capable of inspiring any sentiment whatever in a young woman	319.7781607333898
whose heart was above her position—Mme. Bonacieux had remained	414.6597700997606
insensible to vulgar seductions; but at this period the title of	330.94163033914003
gentleman had great influence with the citizen class, and D’Artagnan	478.1687623581099
was a gentleman. Besides, he wore the uniform of the Guards, which,	386.4024149990129
next to that of the Musketeers, was most admired by the ladies. He was,	462.8472361123736
we repeat, handsome, young, and bold; he spoke of love like a man who	475.0273414618858
did love and was anxious to be loved in return. There was certainly	356.6386544319894
enough in all this to turn a head only twenty-three years old, and Mme.	337.47098749239433
Bonacieux had just attained that happy period of life.	296.8248397400784
The couple, then, although they had not seen each other for eight days,	469.1076021541371
and during that time serious events had taken place in which both were	319.5855964674799
concerned, accosted each other with a degree of preoccupation.	381.32133808831964
Nevertheless, Bonacieux manifested real joy, and advanced toward his	316.6429448453747
wife with open arms. Madame Bonacieux presented her cheek to him.	392.6172387164943
“Let us talk a little,” said she.	305.3844494897805
“How!” said Bonacieux, astonished.	383.82688845715154
“Yes, I have something of the highest importance to tell you.”	366.3827421895804
“True,” said he, “and I have some questions sufficiently serious to put	321.0015893086954
to you. Describe to me your abduction, I pray you.”	417.82315377626605
“Oh, that’s of no consequence just now,” said Mme. Bonacieux.	339.46545233416833
“And what does it concern, then—my captivity?”	385.5317085860081
“I heard of it the day it happened; but as you were not guilty of any	328.9093106144858
crime, as you were not guilty of any intrigue, as you, in short, knew	487.41671559591384
nothing that could compromise yourself or anybody else, I attached no	401.7382897215542
more importance to that event than it merited.”	434.44502471731744
“You speak very much at your ease, madame,” said Bonacieux, hurt at the	460.2387537779174
little interest his wife showed in him. “Do you know that I was plunged	484.6405953176078
during a day and night in a dungeon of the Bastille?”	422.31821519181824
“Oh, a day and night soon pass away. Let us return to the object that	392.58660803420787
brings me here.”	477.53712047564966
“What, that which brings you home to me? Is it not the desire of seeing	313.79367143714364
a husband again from whom you have been separated for a week?” asked	463.09975229161705
the mercer, piqued to the quick.	311.06923588374747
“Yes, that first, and other things afterward.”	350.8004731962186
“Speak.”	331.7368886448466
“It is a thing of the highest interest, and upon which our future	408.3983688781872
fortune perhaps depends.”	482.1567741806888
“The complexion of our fortune has changed very much since I saw you,	395.3303637634681
Madame Bonacieux, and I should not be astonished if in the course of a	420.1379331017701
few months it were to excite the envy of many folks.”	398.5321091881434
“Yes, particularly if you follow the instructions I am about to give	449.6836594481422
you.”	430.96763605460717
“Me?”	388.4495993254575
“Yes, you. There is good and holy action to be performed, monsieur, and	356.06316434655133
much money to be gained at the same time.”	339.8474213198142
Mme. Bonacieux knew that in talking of money to her husband, she took	404.85751611322985
him on his weak side. But a man, were he even a mercer, when he had	333.3973249310071
talked for ten minutes with Cardinal Richelieu, is no longer the same	454.31694711659975
man.	359.0275120521036
“Much money to be gained?” said Bonacieux, protruding his lip.	486.4079594109875
“Yes, much.”	312.1894678604374
“About how much?”	342.22480638549695
“A thousand pistoles, perhaps.”	294.94523305829193
“What you demand of me is serious, then?”	454.51556787869936
“It is indeed.”	297.03763131742545
“What must be done?”	319.1359628382195
“You must go away immediately. I will give you a paper which you must	379.8053213409986
not part with on any account, and which you will deliver into the	481.12046685158236
proper hands.”	378.1617651259702
“And whither am I to go?”	419.1408616555344
“To London.”	362.7796342918417
“I go to London? Go to! You jest! I have no business in London.”	428.21641355339807
“But others wish that you should go there.”	481.02043083653416
“But who are those others? I warn you that I will never again work in	473.8973221021236
the dark, and that I will know not only to what I expose myself, but	373.6920465994957
for whom I expose myself.”	316.2518314728129
“An illustrious person sends you; an illustrious person awaits you. The	457.1958761579001
recompense will exceed your expectations; that is all I promise you.”	387.3755566118457
“More intrigues! Nothing but intrigues! Thank you, madame, I am aware	335.89080963350773
of them now; Monsieur Cardinal has enlightened me on that head.”	346.1435782995352
“The cardinal?” cried Mme. Bonacieux. “Have you seen the cardinal?”	388.05211533973807
“He sent for me,” answered the mercer, proudly.	395.27868011662747
“And you responded to his bidding, you imprudent man?”	295.3452092764941
“Well, I can’t say I had much choice of going or not going, for I was	417.0934214559932
taken to him between two guards. It is true also, that as I did not	404.35860278864885
then know his Eminence, if I had been able to dispense with the visit,	430.11546449294116
I should have been enchanted.”	339.85670733789243
“He ill-treated you, then; he threatened you?”	484.80989374092337
“He gave me his hand, and called me his friend. His friend! Do you hear	383.3450788251798
that, madame? I am the friend of the great cardinal!”	480.92646172850766
“Of the great cardinal!”	399.7376266917796
“Perhaps you would contest his right to that title, madame?”	355.4556670360873
“I would contest nothing; but I tell you that the favor of a minister	335.5472606528295
is ephemeral, and that a man must be mad to attach himself to a	411.28933685390047
minister. There are powers above his which do not depend upon a man or	338.4391486058781
the issue of an event; it is to these powers we should rally.”	432.5940089223708
“I am sorry for it, madame, but I acknowledge no other power but that	451.25960070704866
of the great man whom I have the honor to serve.”	484.73929679391495
“You serve the cardinal?”	379.38975035771693
“Yes, madame; and as his servant, I will not allow you to be concerned	299.32608141612303
in plots against the safety of the state, or to serve the intrigues of	481.9642663834758
a woman who is not French and who has a Spanish heart. Fortunately we	331.76400952446016
have the great cardinal; his vigilant eye watches over and penetrates	449.09042625199515
to the bottom of the heart.”	464.42825066958426
Bonacieux was repeating, word for word, a sentence which he had heard	455.4354735014582
from the Comte de Rochefort; but the poor wife, who had reckoned on her	482.4718583124478
husband, and who, in that hope, had answered for him to the queen, did	309.04106540447066
not tremble the less, both at the danger into which she had nearly cast	360.1937827995392
herself and at the helpless state to which she was reduced.	323.78418194574897
Nevertheless, knowing the weakness of her husband, and more	371.0586635077767
particularly his cupidity, she did not despair of bringing him round to	348.5307808295445
her purpose.	433.26511537526073
“Ah, you are a cardinalist, then, monsieur, are you?” cried she; “and	327.3077641413152
you serve the party of those who maltreat your wife and insult your	391.55397861695127
queen?”	370.2788137713911
“Private interests are as nothing before the interests of all. I am for	459.6273365212759
those who save the state,” said Bonacieux, emphatically.	350.51332400655986
“And what do you know about the state you talk of?” said Mme.	390.9298422733
Bonacieux, shrugging her shoulders. “Be satisfied with being a plain,	444.77998404348955
straightforward citizen, and turn to that side which offers the most	478.61109155180145
advantages.”	312.50830260024685
“Eh, eh!” said Bonacieux, slapping a plump, round bag, which returned	396.41077596059057
of sound a money; “what do you think of this, Madame Preacher?”	413.3089883787303
“Whence comes that money?”	406.7682018868369
“You do not guess?”	359.70428957473825
“From the cardinal?”	372.99487287149304
“From him, and from my friend the Comte de Rochefort.”	297.5956824069012
“The Comte de Rochefort! Why, it was he who carried me off!”	446.0276807121194
“That may be, madame!”	452.39432486034
“And you receive silver from that man?”	429.26954866812565
“Have you not said that that abduction was entirely political?”	346.6492965899939
“Yes; but that abduction had for its object the betrayal of my	449.26945262101583
mistress, to draw from me by torture confessions that might compromise	326.4682606999579
the honor, and perhaps the life, of my august mistress.”	431.9443636021464
“Madame,” replied Bonacieux, “your august mistress is a perfidious	329.02053070456407
Spaniard, and what the cardinal does is well done.”	386.1017680058533
“Monsieur,” said the young woman, “I know you to be cowardly,	437.2009278042981
avaricious, and foolish, but I never till now believed you infamous!”	349.65766094918865
“Madame,” said Bonacieux, who had never seen his wife in a passion, and	449.0324797814717
who recoiled before this conjugal anger, “madame, what do you say?”	388.1949870214064
“I say you are a miserable creature!” continued Mme. Bonacieux, who saw	421.42981296927917
she was regaining some little influence over her husband. “You meddle	442.77498037942325
with politics, do you—and still more, with cardinalist politics? Why,	472.0655454113638
you sell yourself, body and soul, to the demon, the devil, for money!”	448.7857316731242
“No, to the cardinal.”	408.7469620670464
“It’s the same thing,” cried the young woman. “Who calls Richelieu	361.6348265589296
calls Satan.”	444.54870272837684
“Hold your tongue, hold your tongue, madame! You may be overheard.”	329.61790683238627
“Yes, you are right; I should be ashamed for anyone to know your	441.67566032575155
baseness.”	467.67963689558064
“But what do you require of me, then? Let us see.”	463.6251252147489
“I have told you. You must depart instantly, monsieur. You must	437.4786531934203
accomplish loyally the commission with which I deign to charge you, and	452.88149680964347
on that condition I pardon everything, I forget everything; and what is	300.41678648002346
more,” and she held out her hand to him, “I restore my love.”	301.49799416251483
Bonacieux was cowardly and avaricious, but he loved his wife. He was	365.8451742291001
softened. A man of fifty cannot long bear malice with a wife of	358.7328327021076
twenty-three. Mme. Bonacieux saw that he hesitated.	297.27516001955615
“Come! Have you decided?” said she.	399.42614417672564
“But, my dear love, reflect a little upon what you require of me.	309.16402592143
London is far from Paris, very far, and perhaps the commission with	300.3750398106403
which you charge me is not without dangers?”	320.08638268217317
“What matters it, if you avoid them?”	447.35001405890364
“Hold, Madame Bonacieux,” said the mercer, “hold! I positively refuse;	300.1702781846866
intrigues terrify me. I have seen the Bastille. My! Whew! That’s a	308.1711098183054
frightful place, that Bastille! Only to think of it makes my flesh	402.251719509044
crawl. They threatened me with torture. Do you know what torture is?	369.4281079257993
Wooden points that they stick in between your legs till your bones	413.78536302973794
stick out! No, positively I will not go. And, _morbleu_, why do you not	344.7900152765019
go yourself? For in truth, I think I have hitherto been deceived in	447.5765724679256
you. I really believe you are a man, and a violent one, too.”	451.44808210167866
“And you, you are a woman—a miserable woman, stupid and brutal. You are	419.8653853646849
afraid, are you? Well, if you do not go this very instant, I will have	398.2127164236276
you arrested by the queen’s orders, and I will have you placed in the	315.26981029858774
Bastille which you dread so much.”	368.6032679981047
Bonacieux fell into a profound reflection. He weighed the two angers in	355.58552944202904
his brain—that of the cardinal and that of the queen; that of the	394.4817435743746
cardinal predominated enormously.	393.08078552806455
“Have me arrested on the part of the queen,” said he, “and I—I will	339.15484788321356
appeal to his Eminence.”	293.73914021952424
At once Mme. Bonacieux saw that she had gone too far, and she was	371.9370079622689
terrified at having communicated so much. She for a moment contemplated	462.61495011435863
with fright that stupid countenance, impressed with the invincible	382.9369791991111
resolution of a fool that is overcome by fear.	312.4859358601515
“Well, be it so!” said she. “Perhaps, when all is considered, you are	423.0721219394386
right. In the long run, a man knows more about politics than a woman,	394.3684144976761
particularly such as, like you, Monsieur Bonacieux, have conversed with	488.36658275994904
the cardinal. And yet it is very hard,” added she, “that a man upon	452.17501040920956
whose affection I thought I might depend, treats me thus unkindly and	446.0092018189098
will not comply with any of my fancies.”	374.01186122530436
“That is because your fancies go too far,” replied the triumphant	460.80984714414114
Bonacieux, “and I mistrust them.”	320.8383161070229
“Well, I will give it up, then,” said the young woman, sighing. “It is	298.87360834032233
well as it is; say no more about it.”	451.3349029381544
“At least you should tell me what I should have to do in London,”	401.46888442184525
replied Bonacieux, who remembered a little too late that Rochefort had	406.36470054903225
desired him to endeavor to obtain his wife’s secrets.	364.4735503722274
“It is of no use for you to know anything about it,” said the young	404.94353565264015
woman, whom an instinctive mistrust now impelled to draw back. “It was	424.83868117313665
about one of those purchases that interest women—a purchase by which	421.97912283469896
much might have been gained.”	474.7527341610657
But the more the young woman excused herself, the more important	429.9008372874699
Bonacieux thought the secret which she declined to confide to him. He	484.377689710177
resolved then to hasten immediately to the residence of the Comte de	416.3460644578166
Rochefort, and tell him that the queen was seeking for a messenger to	452.7097142278609
send to London.	491.8141584002533
“Pardon me for quitting you, my dear Madame Bonacieux,” said he; “but,	394.63959999432996
not knowing you would come to see me, I had made an engagement with a	400.8489532851987
friend. I shall soon return; and if you will wait only a few minutes	406.66274584061114
for me, as soon as I have concluded my business with that friend, as it	361.8879709763575
is growing late, I will come back and reconduct you to the Louvre.”	396.46226391081143
“Thank you, monsieur, you are not brave enough to be of any use to me	302.7125618688734
whatever,” replied Mme. Bonacieux. “I shall return very safely to the	397.82242330356667
Louvre all alone.”	404.6891162873668
“As you please, Madame Bonacieux,” said the ex-mercer. “Shall I see you	427.66978022634294
again soon?”	295.6888453223473
“Next week I hope my duties will afford me a little liberty, and I will	487.5756863146089
take advantage of it to come and put things in order here, as they must	350.10880745710796
necessarily be much deranged.”	357.1898002332458
“Very well; I shall expect you. You are not angry with me?”	408.50631906195713
“Not the least in the world.”	343.4316332917639
“Till then, then?”	387.15023433036384
“Till then.”	413.63122221320475
Bonacieux kissed his wife’s hand, and set off at a quick pace.	366.8397644128785
“Well,” said Mme. Bonacieux, when her husband had shut the street door	402.850527430576
and she found herself alone; “that imbecile lacked but one thing: to	418.6272352781999
become a cardinalist. And I, who have answered for him to the queen—I,	347.327832871277
who have promised my poor mistress—ah, my God, my God! She will take me	339.9400183688818
for one of those wretches with whom the palace swarms and who are	302.7075176302765
placed about her as spies! Ah, Monsieur Bonacieux, I never did love you	372.9469444270713
much, but now it is worse than ever. I hate you, and on my word you	429.12385119352837
shall pay for this!”	384.68086788945214
At the moment she spoke these words a rap on the ceiling made her raise	371.5524568126963
her head, and a voice which reached her through the ceiling cried,	355.7197987069746
“Dear Madame Bonacieux, open for me the little door on the alley, and I	448.10527770464364
will come down to you.”	427.8576619725742
Chapter XVIII.	430.4469139080314
LOVER AND HUSBAND	332.48761761799784
Ah, Madame,” said D’Artagnan, entering by the door which the young	491.54150969756415
woman opened for him, “allow me to tell you that you have a bad sort of	374.5751455455367
a husband.”	485.7281160217814
“You have, then, overheard our conversation?” asked Mme. Bonacieux,	386.1403831463283
eagerly, and looking at D’Artagnan with disquiet.	478.3282014440566
“The whole.”	302.38530131246915
“But how, my God?”	307.6696259667349
“By a mode of proceeding known to myself, and by which I likewise	473.84468327300254
overheard the more animated conversation which he had with the	479.29519180191875
cardinal’s police.”	330.09365972388093
“And what did you understand by what we said?”	334.0776391104145
“A thousand things. In the first place, that, unfortunately, your	460.1906948585119
husband is a simpleton and a fool; in the next place, you are in	431.59466928392135
trouble, of which I am very glad, as it gives me an opportunity of	311.3787187310354
placing myself at your service, and God knows I am ready to throw	302.1501861508116
myself into the fire for you; finally, that the queen wants a brave,	420.27394718523567
intelligent, devoted man to make a journey to London for her. I have at	407.369817574798
least two of the three qualities you stand in need of, and here I am.”	324.54334611889277
Mme. Bonacieux made no reply; but her heart beat with joy and secret	421.7433668697961
hope shone in her eyes.	314.34949958318344
“And what guarantee will you give me,” asked she, “if I consent to	299.2300237131773
confide this message to you?”	402.71671739732216
“My love for you. Speak! Command! What is to be done?”	424.7612444685707
“My God, my God!” murmured the young woman, “ought I to confide such a	359.9853975954905
secret to you, monsieur? You are almost a boy.”	413.12134897490944
“I see that you require someone to answer for me?”	485.34307726125473
“I admit that would reassure me greatly.”	324.2585260821545
“Do you know Athos?”	310.18826136158845
“No.”	405.36452552843826
“Porthos?”	460.202640632825
“No.”	349.18858332307144
“Aramis?”	317.23883452301493
“No. Who are these gentleman?”	482.2234708413698
“Three of the king’s Musketeers. Do you know Monsieur de Tréville,	304.6070655535161
their captain?”	477.1913814762023
“Oh, yes, him! I know him; not personally, but from having heard the	401.8184797369304
queen speak of him more than once as a brave and loyal gentleman.”	330.44605899519706
“You do not fear lest he should betray you to the cardinal?”	403.7347288656004
“Oh, no, certainly not!”	340.4943933885209
“Well, reveal your secret to him, and ask him whether, however	436.96644274377303
important, however valuable, however terrible it may be, you may not	435.6992143092242
confide it to me.”	320.3064376282679
“But this secret is not mine, and I cannot reveal it in this manner.”	474.435975386129
“You were about to confide it to Monsieur Bonacieux,” said D’Artagnan,	308.535256198949
with chagrin.	429.8755677042798
“As one confides a letter to the hollow of a tree, to the wing of a	449.0183723280543
pigeon, to the collar of a dog.”	452.1912985614126
“And yet, me—you see plainly that I love you.”	351.34438444359336
“You say so.”	365.5831328330495
“I am an honorable man.”	403.0336315068474
“You say so.”	344.7219631816766
“I am a gallant fellow.”	401.20627130480773
“I believe it.”	387.4934838279968
“I am brave.”	423.8354377810175
“Oh, I am sure of that!”	319.2510476978668
“Then, put me to the proof.”	445.6812304400543
Mme. Bonacieux looked at the young man, restrained for a minute by a	322.15146895495
last hesitation; but there was such an ardor in his eyes, such	474.74999110057104
persuasion in his voice, that she felt herself constrained to confide	452.8501396980765
in him. Besides, she found herself in circumstances where everything	438.27441098550605
must be risked for the sake of everything. The queen might be as much	385.8112237994538
injured by too much reticence as by too much confidence; and—let us	353.58608956719996
admit it—the involuntary sentiment which she felt for her young	420.81351180915954
protector decided her to speak.	312.6662283806777
“Listen,” said she; “I yield to your protestations, I yield to your	380.7169172229902
assurances. But I swear to you, before God who hears us, that if you	373.59797831780645
betray me, and my enemies pardon me, I will kill myself, while accusing	293.34845901984664
you of my death.”	292.3297996507746
“And I—I swear to you before God, madame,” said D’Artagnan, “that if I	316.0128455259363
am taken while accomplishing the orders you give me, I will die sooner	486.63689261816404
than do anything that may compromise anyone.”	439.84108172057955
Then the young woman confided in him the terrible secret of which	322.96746481758436
chance had already communicated to him a part in front of the	299.7782706560885
Samaritaine. This was their mutual declaration of love.	450.25167731778504
D’Artagnan was radiant with joy and pride. This secret which he	450.9911397324407
possessed, this woman whom he loved! Confidence and love made him a	489.0165073114368
giant.	481.7685884410749
“I go,” said he; “I go at once.”	461.78243890483077
“How, you will go!” said Mme. Bonacieux; “and your regiment, your	363.6101354228731
captain?”	444.70591536875037
“By my soul, you had made me forget all that, dear Constance! Yes, you	296.9124667486784
are right; a furlough is needful.”	422.24519308957167
“Still another obstacle,” murmured Mme. Bonacieux, sorrowfully.	445.3641590935256
“As to that,” cried D’Artagnan, after a moment of reflection, “I shall	357.5004189876553
surmount it, be assured.”	390.0979031442131
“How so?”	352.6909312694869
“I will go this very evening to Tréville, whom I will request to ask	391.7429749204819
this favor for me of his brother-in-law, Monsieur Dessessart.”	433.12048165098946
“But another thing.”	444.3910268249387
“What?” asked D’Artagnan, seeing that Mme. Bonacieux hesitated to	464.4509929452238
continue.	321.7155429382937
“You have, perhaps, no money?”	395.83154329934183
“_Perhaps_ is too much,” said D’Artagnan, smiling.	365.99317386846906
“Then,” replied Mme. Bonacieux, opening a cupboard and taking from it	401.0102951162116
the very bag which a half hour before her husband had caressed so	399.30974241722345
affectionately, “take this bag.”	340.3399235422896
“The cardinal’s?” cried D’Artagnan, breaking into a loud laugh, he	383.6917092721734
having heard, as may be remembered, thanks to the broken boards, every	416.0949588673297
syllable of the conversation between the mercer and his wife.	323.46612880378655
“The cardinal’s,” replied Mme. Bonacieux. “You see it makes a very	422.5029213050319
respectable appearance.”	377.6402387591852
“_Pardieu_,” cried D’Artagnan, “it will be a double amusing affair to	462.34652307327826
save the queen with the cardinal’s money!”	474.86282808439967
“You are an amiable and charming young man,” said Mme. Bonacieux. “Be	414.555275797294
assured you will not find her Majesty ungrateful.”	452.12759917172093
“Oh, I am already grandly recompensed!” cried D’Artagnan. “I love you;	466.97806288257175
you permit me to tell you that I do—that is already more happiness than	297.5348300388768
I dared to hope.”	307.3726467567802
“Silence!” said Mme. Bonacieux, starting.	348.2593574764094
“What!”	383.67759618539435
“Someone is talking in the street.”	347.508179772549
“It is the voice of—”	306.7945368349325
“Of my husband! Yes, I recognize it!”	447.3006966957952
D’Artagnan ran to the door and pushed the bolt.	471.47863019383493
“He shall not come in before I am gone,” said he; “and when I am gone,	376.6283249835382
you can open to him.”	322.0564900093149
“But I ought to be gone, too. And the disappearance of his money; how	385.4217802718508
am I to justify it if I am here?”	396.2991203593839
“You are right; we must go out.”	327.38534198032846
“Go out? How? He will see us if we go out.”	396.88111428540304
“Then you must come up into my room.”	308.17429874744045
“Ah,” said Mme. Bonacieux, “you speak that in a tone that frightens	468.54287475355284
me!”	382.38043868147486
Mme. Bonacieux pronounced these words with tears in her eyes.	377.80501404799384
D’Artagnan saw those tears, and much disturbed, softened, he threw	386.87574215085954
himself at her feet.	308.47426651400514
“With me you will be as safe as in a temple; I give you my word of a	431.08395786569713
gentleman.”	461.7488287199568
“Let us go,” said she, “I place full confidence in you, my friend!”	387.29687623120816
D’Artagnan drew back the bolt with precaution, and both, light as	379.6282318457719
shadows, glided through the interior door into the passage, ascended	321.87608778037827
the stairs as quietly as possible, and entered D’Artagnan’s chambers.	322.26635263541897
Once there, for greater security, the young man barricaded the door.	404.4161171836522
They both approached the window, and through a slit in the shutter they	371.8940748081642
saw Bonacieux talking with a man in a cloak.	433.39743552490177
At sight of this man, D’Artagnan started, and half drawing his sword,	420.7419406559888
sprang toward the door.	399.1891191572481
It was the man of Meung.	399.9302073555366
“What are you going to do?” cried Mme. Bonacieux; “you will ruin us	344.9861958512398
all!”	471.374130417606
“But I have sworn to kill that man!” said D’Artagnan.	441.28569273609685
“Your life is devoted from this moment, and does not belong to you. In	356.0256200697564
the name of the queen I forbid you to throw yourself into any peril	431.27317162327626
which is foreign to that of your journey.”	330.59726481655724
“And do you command nothing in your own name?”	379.236364732886
“In my name,” said Mme. Bonacieux, with great emotion, “in my name I	422.3568822240413
beg you! But listen; they appear to be speaking of me.”	358.6396462421597
D’Artagnan drew near the window, and lent his ear.	445.25459096694385
M. Bonacieux had opened his door, and seeing the apartment, had	388.9289119778942
returned to the man in the cloak, whom he had left alone for an	362.69009288931306
instant.	356.54921192578684
“She is gone,” said he; “she must have returned to the Louvre.”	393.3482888622051
“You are sure,” replied the stranger, “that she did not suspect the	397.93937210724454
intentions with which you went out?”	381.2371013251044
“No,” replied Bonacieux, with a self-sufficient air, “she is too	306.6122473105019
superficial a woman.”	362.82555313493424
“Is the young Guardsman at home?”	443.0788327805103
“I do not think he is; as you see, his shutter is closed, and you can	467.36905268174604
see no light shine through the chinks of the shutters.”	434.862453883704
“All the same, it is well to be certain.”	348.823393840629
“How so?”	386.72168611397103
“By knocking at his door. Go.”	351.17737206363955
“I will ask his servant.”	324.11570412663986
Bonacieux re-entered the house, passed through the same door that had	318.1689205989286
afforded a passage for the two fugitives, went up to D’Artagnan’s door,	320.8051132088113
and knocked.	309.76796096143715
No one answered. Porthos, in order to make a greater display, had that	443.5989392878669
evening borrowed Planchet. As to D’Artagnan, he took care not to give	376.5773283431042
the least sign of existence.	399.5204770593358
The moment the hand of Bonacieux sounded on the door, the two young	378.953223467442
people felt their hearts bound within them.	352.4765757508089
“There is nobody within,” said Bonacieux.	299.2810695398464
“Never mind. Let us return to your apartment. We shall be safer there	466.25679503008973
than in the doorway.”	432.623885805622
“Ah, my God!” whispered Mme. Bonacieux, “we shall hear no more.”	448.1754929267793
“On the contrary,” said D’Artagnan, “we shall hear better.”	372.7620299788195
D’Artagnan raised the three or four boards which made his chamber	366.3456259843295
another ear of Dionysius, spread a carpet on the floor, went upon his	386.5046421266452
knees, and made a sign to Mme. Bonacieux to stoop as he did toward the	471.05118087461847
opening.	444.08787315670133
“You are sure there is nobody there?” said the stranger.	469.50167424546476
“I will answer for it,” said Bonacieux.	416.6267039642135
“And you think that your wife—”	467.55170333271826
“Has returned to the Louvre.”	442.8899480432126
“Without speaking to anyone but yourself?”	378.770116458368
“I am sure of it.”	399.69034956305876
“That is an important point, do you understand?”	397.977868936161
“Then the news I brought you is of value?”	470.5302793723225
“The greatest, my dear Bonacieux; I don’t conceal this from you.”	457.1182824383111
“Then the cardinal will be pleased with me?”	299.4382322986082
“I have no doubt of it.”	334.1052181353298
“The great cardinal!”	430.5401997096095
“Are you sure, in her conversation with you, that your wife mentioned	407.9581518945346
no names?”	400.29576418930384
“I think not.”	370.66476437526774
“She did not name Madame de Chevreuse, the Duke of Buckingham, or	328.2350467380624
Madame de Vernet?”	381.1045615783408
“No; she only told me she wished to send me to London to serve the	378.5895694118311
interests of an illustrious personage.”	458.51522753714653
“The traitor!” murmured Mme. Bonacieux.	354.17131499049884
“Silence!” said D’Artagnan, taking her hand, which, without thinking of	456.92636103832945
it, she abandoned to him.	422.77655179655596
“Never mind,” continued the man in the cloak; “you were a fool not to	438.42360758932136
have pretended to accept the mission. You would then be in present	439.6181621715196
possession of the letter. The state, which is now threatened, would be	439.7613166478466
safe, and you—”	408.8076746417786
“And I?”	362.1337041480623
“Well you—the cardinal would have given you letters of nobility.”	442.5463271561616
“Did he tell you so?”	334.53708525523905
“Yes, I know that he meant to afford you that agreeable surprise.”	471.07875709793143
“Be satisfied,” replied Bonacieux; “my wife adores me, and there is yet	293.3838260417141
time.”	304.6204212141897
“The ninny!” murmured Mme. Bonacieux.	352.8415022781528
“Silence!” said D’Artagnan, pressing her hand more closely.	353.51215606831266
“How is there still time?” asked the man in the cloak.	384.0224756167535
“I go to the Louvre; I ask for Mme. Bonacieux; I say that I have	457.45668394601466
reflected; I renew the affair; I obtain the letter, and I run directly	377.7891589139196
to the cardinal.”	454.9083106736331
“Well, go quickly! I will return soon to learn the result of your	453.50502271909494
trip.”	432.84315301726656
The stranger went out.	459.49367988306903
“Infamous!” said Mme. Bonacieux, addressing this epithet to her	327.56333608745047
husband.	431.1007186182318
“Silence!” said D’Artagnan, pressing her hand still more warmly.	464.5518418651734
A terrible howling interrupted these reflections of D’Artagnan and Mme.	433.4225290951124
Bonacieux. It was her husband, who had discovered the disappearance of	430.48094769799343
the moneybag, and was crying “Thieves!”	335.78397503273294
“Oh, my God!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, “he will rouse the whole quarter.”	463.68305693358116
Bonacieux called a long time; but as such cries, on account of their	328.8482574613693
frequency, brought nobody in the Rue des Fossoyeurs, and as lately the	347.2110644891207
mercer’s house had a bad name, finding that nobody came, he went out	303.8287811563631
continuing to call, his voice being heard fainter and fainter as he	423.7419734685561
went in the direction of the Rue du Bac.	483.1610785856332
“Now he is gone, it is your turn to get out,” said Mme. Bonacieux.	415.49636628422536
“Courage, my friend, but above all, prudence, and think what you owe to	306.42431618225044
the queen.”	454.32054338535517
“To her and to you!” cried D’Artagnan. “Be satisfied, beautiful	382.50013862372873
Constance. I shall become worthy of her gratitude; but shall I likewise	421.6139252741863
return worthy of your love?”	474.8427181345545
The young woman only replied by the beautiful glow which mounted to her	418.5001980431837
cheeks. A few seconds afterward D’Artagnan also went out enveloped in a	301.8414183320081
large cloak, which ill-concealed the sheath of a long sword.	457.0426866388324
Mme. Bonacieux followed him with her eyes, with that long, fond look	439.622107073678
with which he had turned the angle of the street, she fell on her	420.7375757624046
knees, and clasping her hands, “Oh, my God,” cried she, “protect the	366.4183954236337
queen, protect me!”	488.2888200667509
Chapter XIX.	348.66371701179247
PLAN OF CAMPAIGN	443.008278461263
D’Artagnan went straight to M. de Tréville’s. He had reflected that in	413.47938009812214
a few minutes the cardinal would be warned by this cursed stranger, who	431.4785592109565
appeared to be his agent, and he judged, with reason, he had not a	407.6244422578605
moment to lose.	386.4128540290063
The heart of the young man overflowed with joy. An opportunity	369.0064303286963
presented itself to him in which there would be at the same time glory	445.4613538497849
to be acquired, and money to be gained; and as a far higher	311.84923798257176
encouragement, it brought him into close intimacy with a woman he	302.8619933499025
adored. This chance did, then, for him at once more than he would have	427.3816116200771
dared to ask of Providence.	329.71937637309
M. de Tréville was in his saloon with his habitual court of gentlemen.	340.8569383768241
D’Artagnan, who was known as a familiar of the house, went straight to	421.0479748099409
his office, and sent word that he wished to see him on something of	318.1284753450454
importance.	302.8259749435498
D’Artagnan had been there scarcely five minutes when M. de Tréville	464.2109671554765
entered. At the first glance, and by the joy which was painted on his	490.33203260003506
countenance, the worthy captain plainly perceived that something new	349.16642175220755
was on foot.	302.8399796848471
All the way along D’Artagnan had been consulting with himself whether	463.92525012267856
he should place confidence in M. de Tréville, or whether he should only	385.53602059517016
ask him to give him _carte blanche_ for some secret affair. But M. de	459.27264421737596
Tréville had always been so thoroughly his friend, had always been so	424.17883880027404
devoted to the king and queen, and hated the cardinal so cordially,	380.4316593126699
that the young man resolved to tell him everything.	366.8734667535998
“Did you ask for me, my good friend?” said M. de Tréville.	421.9266504634937
“Yes, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan, lowering his voice, “and you will	378.5631922381848
pardon me, I hope, for having disturbed you when you know the	394.6744561360017
importance of my business.”	474.32528498847876
“Speak, then, I am all attention.”	302.0928326562127
“It concerns nothing less,” said D’Artagnan, “than the honor, perhaps	357.1918168230986
the life of the queen.”	454.92891126022766
“What did you say?” asked M. de Tréville, glancing round to see if they	363.46809226287763
were surely alone, and then fixing his questioning look upon	393.2756405818119
D’Artagnan.	379.24294261984994
“I say, monsieur, that chance has rendered me master of a secret—”	341.86713972736845
“Which you will guard, I hope, young man, as your life.”	433.54404453054127
“But which I must impart to you, monsieur, for you alone can assist me	392.5524491304518
in the mission I have just received from her Majesty.”	447.04032997091144
“Is this secret your own?”	390.35931335711734
“No, monsieur; it is her Majesty’s.”	464.74918985460374
“Are you authorized by her Majesty to communicate it to me?”	305.57795628088667
“No, monsieur, for, on the contrary, I am desired to preserve the	485.42682684846466
profoundest mystery.”	398.54729511675686
“Why, then, are you about to betray it to me?”	414.9542490055794
“Because, as I said, without you I can do nothing; and I am afraid you	318.7188585427462
will refuse me the favor I come to ask if you do not know to what end I	355.31304774264714
ask it.”	347.12060363461774
“Keep your secret, young man, and tell me what you wish.”	433.6562889445272
“I wish you to obtain for me, from Monsieur Dessessart, leave of	403.6824113834012
absence for fifteen days.”	419.0381441563248
“When?”	317.79728031931484
“This very night.”	483.247125638214
“You leave Paris?”	328.84992700312057
“I am going on a mission.”	352.9338064069236
“May you tell me whither?”	344.11226077054033
“To London.”	410.2399713619393
“Has anyone an interest in preventing your arrival there?”	363.80771023783444
“The cardinal, I believe, would give the world to prevent my success.”	395.73014048884227
“And you are going alone?”	437.21720093290475
“I am going alone.”	448.05109313857014
“In that case you will not get beyond Bondy. I tell you so, by the	313.5523756475428
faith of de Tréville.”	414.70684674249014
“How so?”	489.55640489078587
“You will be assassinated.”	404.32494600122993
“And I shall die in the performance of my duty.”	394.86225703482603
“But your mission will not be accomplished.”	415.6496074122491
“That is true,” replied D’Artagnan.	353.2757811168578
“Believe me,” continued Tréville, “in enterprises of this kind, in	336.5611685737652
order that one may arrive, four must set out.”	334.52698309209205
“Ah, you are right, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan; “but you know Athos,	478.95679532449697
Porthos, and Aramis, and you know if I can dispose of them.”	463.78707363279034
“Without confiding to them the secret which I am not willing to know?”	364.2481751324244
“We are sworn, once for all, to implicit confidence and devotedness	474.6007254921932
against all proof. Besides, you can tell them that you have full	350.58378844041215
confidence in me, and they will not be more incredulous than you.”	356.6843036235921
“I can send to each of them leave of absence for fifteen days, that is	442.7872150606041
all—to Athos, whose wound still makes him suffer, to go to the waters	311.79836246609176
of Forges; to Porthos and Aramis to accompany their friend, whom they	475.96369973931155
are not willing to abandon in such a painful condition. Sending their	342.17712717234684
leave of absence will be proof enough that I authorize their journey.”	332.1533718717552
“Thanks, monsieur. You are a hundred times too good.”	365.94405876988463
“Begone, then, find them instantly, and let all be done tonight! Ha!	415.8460837088689
But first write your request to Dessessart. Perhaps you had a spy at	472.78762716864424
your heels; and your visit, if it should ever be known to the cardinal,	488.55997878456344
will thus seem legitimate.”	335.3955929544378
D’Artagnan drew up his request, and M. de Tréville, on receiving it,	324.92563771024174
assured him that by two o’clock in the morning the four leaves of	384.1470534674268
absence should be at the respective domiciles of the travelers.	418.45968899861634
“Have the goodness to send mine to Athos’s residence. I should dread	378.9114903083276
some disagreeable encounter if I were to go home.”	486.05147440338925
“Be easy. Adieu, and a prosperous voyage. _A propos_,” said M. de	472.5652423780092
Tréville, calling him back.	325.8174977597595
D’Artagnan returned.	435.7224453472926
“Have you any money?”	350.7321109635799
D’Artagnan tapped the bag he had in his pocket.	456.44418028376526
“Enough?” asked M. de Tréville.	329.0049517773272
“Three hundred pistoles.”	318.7811059078453
“Oh, plenty! That would carry you to the end of the world. Begone,	435.9934749439186
then!”	406.9603197460483
D’Artagnan saluted M. de Tréville, who held out his hand to him;	446.1861253280324
D’Artagnan pressed it with a respect mixed with gratitude. Since his	336.1114030820066
first arrival at Paris, he had had constant occasion to honor this	461.1554248343035
excellent man, whom he had always found worthy, loyal, and great.	484.2982410538565
His first visit was to Aramis, at whose residence he had not been since	365.8424722277315
the famous evening on which he had followed Mme. Bonacieux. Still	361.942982957342
further, he had seldom seen the young Musketeer; but every time he had	401.91408026508526
seen him, he had remarked a deep sadness imprinted on his countenance.	467.32951365676746
This evening, especially, Aramis was melancholy and thoughtful.	384.37450524771214
D’Artagnan asked some questions about this prolonged melancholy. Aramis	371.227033970348
pleaded as his excuse a commentary upon the eighteenth chapter of St.	355.07954643304276
Augustine, which he was forced to write in Latin for the following	391.1011298430825
week, and which preoccupied him a good deal.	300.705771264381
After the two friends had been chatting a few moments, a servant from	467.41025059206424
M. de Tréville entered, bringing a sealed packet.	358.91437446848664
“What is that?” asked Aramis.	468.57192457254826
“The leave of absence Monsieur has asked for,” replied the lackey.	462.8266845503944
“For me! I have asked for no leave of absence.”	470.8335070648385
“Hold your tongue and take it!” said D’Artagnan. “And you, my friend,	437.3643374180708
there is a demipistole for your trouble; you will tell Monsieur de	327.8919961045768
Tréville that Monsieur Aramis is very much obliged to him. Go.”	295.874507679928
The lackey bowed to the ground and departed.	323.9468838657334
“What does all this mean?” asked Aramis.	292.6672477396414
“Pack up all you want for a journey of a fortnight, and follow me.”	403.2411109122726
“But I cannot leave Paris just now without knowing—”	394.65757593665154
Aramis stopped.	491.99287175135464
“What is become of her? I suppose you mean—” continued D’Artagnan.	406.8983815296872
“Become of whom?” replied Aramis.	368.45306926627956
“The woman who was here—the woman with the embroidered handkerchief.”	385.27592262281075
“Who told you there was a woman here?” replied Aramis, becoming as pale	434.2738893978143
as death.	452.9399799778547
“I saw her.”	440.4537600518563
“And you know who she is?”	487.14763495403406
“I believe I can guess, at least.”	469.98539595203243
“Listen!” said Aramis. “Since you appear to know so many things, can	460.23528401934783
you tell me what is become of that woman?”	335.56714375804125
“I presume that she has returned to Tours.”	448.6580512567034
“To Tours? Yes, that may be. You evidently know her. But why did she	354.7903939803614
return to Tours without telling me anything?”	432.09408250371547
“Because she was in fear of being arrested.”	413.6080805289362
“Why has she not written to me, then?”	434.9191559193845
“Because she was afraid of compromising you.”	340.12958934558515
“D’Artagnan, you restore me to life!” cried Aramis. “I fancied myself	399.09910092985496
despised, betrayed. I was so delighted to see her again! I could not	303.16224144448853
have believed she would risk her liberty for me, and yet for what other	452.32720276897766
cause could she have returned to Paris?”	471.85908028802896
“For the cause which today takes us to England.”	490.2924985967809
“And what is this cause?” demanded Aramis.	482.05175059514295
“Oh, you’ll know it someday, Aramis; but at present I must imitate the	304.9462870774997
discretion of ‘the doctor’s niece.’”	453.00893992688765
Aramis smiled, as he remembered the tale he had told his friends on a	455.58146993988953
certain evening. “Well, then, since she has left Paris, and you are	383.0864560382805
sure of it, D’Artagnan, nothing prevents me, and I am ready to follow	293.95099127696
you. You say we are going—”	477.8974820663922
“To see Athos now, and if you will come thither, I beg you to make	406.86733772396224
haste, for we have lost much time already. _A propos_, inform Bazin.”	467.4702289985791
“Will Bazin go with us?” asked Aramis.	425.6294740414454
“Perhaps so. At all events, it is best that he should follow us to	405.1607195377094
Athos’s.”	301.09461576502304
Aramis called Bazin, and, after having ordered him to join them at	463.3329018624529
Athos’s residence, said “Let us go then,” at the same time taking his	427.2675341207804
cloak, sword, and three pistols, opening uselessly two or three drawers	345.67217767589636
to see if he could not find stray coin. When well assured this search	412.6465555088563
was superfluous, he followed D’Artagnan, wondering to himself how this	375.9890513519983
young Guardsman should know so well who the lady was to whom he had	462.868809550852
given hospitality, and that he should know better than himself what had	379.9586168528996
become of her.	307.9912647821908
Only as they went out Aramis placed his hand upon the arm of	357.8185402428079
D’Artagnan, and looking at him earnestly, “You have not spoken of this	362.3982730179914
lady?” said he.	335.67298488560823
“To nobody in the world.”	448.11929602098763
“Not even to Athos or Porthos?”	292.84302444708425
“I have not breathed a syllable to them.”	322.14402050500075
“Good enough!”	304.8987988135796
Tranquil on this important point, Aramis continued his way with	306.3770261563585
D’Artagnan, and both soon arrived at Athos’s dwelling. They found him	301.7633202273522
holding his leave of absence in one hand, and M. de Tréville’s note in	328.3876525561576
the other.	336.7321724823096
“Can you explain to me what signify this leave of absence and this	342.9958528624157
letter, which I have just received?” said the astonished Athos.	344.6816016688614
MY DEAR ATHOS,	448.0543873342733
    I wish, as your health absolutely requires it, that you should rest	399.9907847318242
    for a fortnight. Go, then, and take the waters of Forges, or any	352.5173957646547
    that may be more agreeable to you, and recuperate yourself as	442.11222998897324
    quickly as possible.	309.0355543217206
Yours affectionate,	361.88262281985914
DE TRÉVILLE	331.48435270479985
“Well, this leave of absence and that letter mean that you must follow	319.3319824641114
me, Athos.”	383.8676098040659
“To the waters of Forges?”	317.3998421154615
“There or elsewhere.”	417.2524482171774
“In the king’s service?”	429.4553323239306
“Either the king’s or the queen’s. Are we not their Majesties’	474.7761060439981
servants?”	485.28057643728573
At that moment Porthos entered. “_Pardieu!_” said he, “here is a	346.8782278946876
strange thing! Since when, I wonder, in the Musketeers, did they grant	417.4968796214147
men leave of absence without their asking for it?”	475.70564756219744
“Since,” said D’Artagnan, “they have friends who ask it for them.”	294.2426061715501
“Ah, ah!” said Porthos, “it appears there’s something fresh here.”	399.8102499523345
“Yes, we are going—” said Aramis.	311.8806265788023
“To what country?” demanded Porthos.	344.1871423646859
“My faith! I don’t know much about it,” said Athos. “Ask D’Artagnan.”	465.77431210807106
“To London, gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan.	368.21341302757514
“To London!” cried Porthos; “and what the devil are we going to do in	397.85905563084674
London?”	370.2783286918259
“That is what I am not at liberty to tell you, gentlemen; you must	396.6749110481287
trust to me.”	412.9650201165174
“But in order to go to London,” added Porthos, “money is needed, and I	340.12785524661143
have none.”	439.97705480601394
“Nor I,” said Aramis.	331.61718194119146
“Nor I,” said Athos.	346.11717925941963
“I have,” replied D’Artagnan, pulling out his treasure from his pocket,	415.2069383471459
and placing it on the table. “There are in this bag three hundred	475.0522820835219
pistoles. Let each take seventy-five; that is enough to take us to	388.67142555271295
London and back. Besides, make yourselves easy; we shall not all arrive	462.3407016735326
at London.”	360.67514571979046
“Why so?”	393.31724157481835
“Because, in all probability, some one of us will be left on the road.”	349.9757667016348
“Is this, then, a campaign upon which we are now entering?”	331.08844692773954
“One of a most dangerous kind, I give you notice.”	375.1839672499585
“Ah! But if we do risk being killed,” said Porthos, “at least I should	455.1208493661533
like to know what for.”	363.1981122172825
“You would be all the wiser,” said Athos.	316.31432013239197
“And yet,” said Aramis, “I am somewhat of Porthos’s opinion.”	359.94561941335985
“Is the king accustomed to give you such reasons? No. He says to you	442.3231591960591
jauntily, ‘Gentlemen, there is fighting going on in Gascony or in	301.5815769974851
Flanders; go and fight,’ and you go there. Why? You need give	487.7703622205966
yourselves no more uneasiness about this.”	386.37038429189454
“D’Artagnan is right,” said Athos; “here are our three leaves of	376.36957809207746
absence which came from Monsieur de Tréville, and here are three	351.174067166009
hundred pistoles which came from I don’t know where. So let us go and	359.8118025248505
get killed where we are told to go. Is life worth the trouble of so	403.1182678249085
many questions? D’Artagnan, I am ready to follow you.”	304.9041635689506
“And I also,” said Porthos.	424.85533313469773
“And I also,” said Aramis. “And, indeed, I am not sorry to quit Paris;	445.678142570889
I had need of distraction.”	403.3200380964043
“Well, you will have distractions enough, gentlemen, be assured,” said	372.38204774537735
D’Artagnan.	408.7385552149254
“And, now, when are we to go?” asked Athos.	481.56235124052307
“Immediately,” replied D’Artagnan; “we have not a minute to lose.”	342.2530046540544
“Hello, Grimaud! Planchet! Mousqueton! Bazin!” cried the four young	479.7483910504005
men, calling their lackeys, “clean my boots, and fetch the horses from	336.33563618448494
the hôtel.”	326.10681084767043
Each Musketeer was accustomed to leave at the general hôtel, as at a	293.7391468339244
barrack, his own horse and that of his lackey. Planchet, Grimaud,	387.0479517134635
Mousqueton, and Bazin set off at full speed.	324.26826637528717
“Now let us lay down the plan of campaign,” said Porthos. “Where do we	336.16688859491774
go first?”	296.8929337192389
“To Calais,” said D’Artagnan; “that is the most direct line to London.”	473.86609440261196
“Well,” said Porthos, “this is my advice—”	381.8026683622439
“Speak!”	316.38419541261743
“Four men traveling together would be suspected. D’Artagnan will give	380.07586382426024
each of us his instructions. I will go by the way of Boulogne to clear	470.40282622646896
the way; Athos will set out two hours after, by that of Amiens; Aramis	409.14598621267317
will follow us by that of Noyon; as to D’Artagnan, he will go by what	365.51780373204735
route he thinks is best, in Planchet’s clothes, while Planchet will	426.4308806765081
follow us like D’Artagnan, in the uniform of the Guards.”	306.34939331137934
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, “my opinion is that it is not proper to allow	402.0214893438823
lackeys to have anything to do in such an affair. A secret may, by	314.34649627189106
chance, be betrayed by gentlemen; but it is almost always sold by	452.3427509860268
lackeys.”	430.90592195739293
“Porthos’s plan appears to me to be impracticable,” said D’Artagnan,	352.06657439731697
“inasmuch as I am myself ignorant of what instructions I can give you.	349.08748922064245
I am the bearer of a letter, that is all. I have not, and I cannot make	340.5544139629256
three copies of that letter, because it is sealed. We must, then, as it	459.04167230388674
appears to me, travel in company. This letter is here, in this pocket,”	407.50425116444313
and he pointed to the pocket which contained the letter. “If I should	473.1388057112037
be killed, one of you must take it, and continue the route; if he be	464.4827038647179
killed, it will be another’s turn, and so on—provided a single one	393.4130796523714
arrives, that is all that is required.”	433.3880269805368
“Bravo, D’Artagnan, your opinion is mine,” cried Athos, “Besides, we	325.19994477209195
must be consistent; I am going to take the waters, you will accompany	473.53104037314233
me. Instead of taking the waters of Forges, I go and take sea waters; I	471.69124098834124
am free to do so. If anyone wishes to stop us, I will show Monsieur de	368.0609647310605
Tréville’s letter, and you will show your leaves of absence. If we are	341.1240869696576
attacked, we will defend ourselves; if we are tried, we will stoutly	451.0148657912396
maintain that we were only anxious to dip ourselves a certain number of	332.153158561473
times in the sea. They would have an easy bargain of four isolated men;	379.4700951078804
whereas four men together make a troop. We will arm our four lackeys	312.3405815481068
with pistols and musketoons; if they send an army out against us, we	479.6149017795916
will give battle, and the survivor, as D’Artagnan says, will carry the	485.82515806094693
letter.”	470.63342263659126
“Well said,” cried Aramis; “you don’t often speak, Athos, but when you	436.8575800411355
do speak, it is like St. John of the Golden Mouth. I agree to Athos’s	469.7876805410412
plan. And you, Porthos?”	294.7114228770052
