“I agree to it, too,” said Porthos, “if D’Artagnan approves of it.	480.9358302810855
D’Artagnan, being the bearer of the letter, is naturally the head of	323.63869167826726
the enterprise; let him decide, and we will execute.”	433.63642957064144
“Well,” said D’Artagnan, “I decide that we should adopt Athos’s plan,	436.5164884402501
and that we set off in half an hour.”	368.55177859479653
“Agreed!” shouted the three Musketeers in chorus.	427.53214359324863
Each one, stretching out his hand to the bag, took his seventy-five	309.46543797285557
pistoles, and made his preparations to set out at the time appointed.	363.86456313878296
Chapter XX.	300.9326931997017
THE JOURNEY	366.53614654730734
At two o’clock in the morning, our four adventurers left Paris by the	301.98273814379047
Barrière St. Denis. As long as it was dark they remained silent; in	442.0153620987661
spite of themselves they submitted to the influence of the obscurity,	377.3811372925979
and apprehended ambushes on every side.	327.4966655346085
With the first rays of day their tongues were loosened; with the sun	329.41611206110167
gaiety revived. It was like the eve of a battle; the heart beat, the	298.0888753277841
eyes laughed, and they felt that the life they were perhaps going to	439.34376734914764
lose, was, after all, a good thing.	328.97641819124226
Besides, the appearance of the caravan was formidable. The black horses	319.64617862210247
of the Musketeers, their martial carriage, with the regimental step of	468.33745988168073
these noble companions of the soldier, would have betrayed the most	320.34139769633106
strict incognito. The lackeys followed, armed to the teeth.	363.48930167962516
All went well till they arrived at Chantilly, which they reached about	402.6012053047909
eight o’clock in the morning. They needed breakfast, and alighted at	339.5975482607851
the door of an _auberge_, recommended by a sign representing St. Martin	364.7163980658144
giving half his cloak to a poor man. They ordered the lackeys not to	380.7915789657111
unsaddle the horses, and to hold themselves in readiness to set off	416.76675629861165
again immediately.	362.33338042889295
They entered the common hall, and placed themselves at table. A	358.7897561216755
gentleman, who had just arrived by the route of Dammartin, was seated	345.21022775074164
at the same table, and was breakfasting. He opened the conversation	441.1272740219344
about rain and fine weather; the travelers replied. He drank to their	313.49993264577546
good health, and the travelers returned his politeness.	340.58171138685583
But at the moment Mousqueton came to announce that the horses were	365.1216933400925
ready, and they were arising from table, the stranger proposed to	406.33605097643226
Porthos to drink the health of the cardinal. Porthos replied that he	421.20068926903673
asked no better if the stranger, in his turn, would drink the health of	392.0507146534619
the king. The stranger cried that he acknowledged no other king but his	336.8921219989113
Eminence. Porthos called him drunk, and the stranger drew his sword.	481.38657344541906
“You have committed a piece of folly,” said Athos, “but it can’t be	301.9003794500046
helped; there is no drawing back. Kill the fellow, and rejoin us as	297.32571173857184
soon as you can.”	489.1672975034592
All three remounted their horses, and set out at a good pace, while	449.683581382005
Porthos was promising his adversary to perforate him with all the	419.2847671948315
thrusts known in the fencing schools.	318.6937798810983
“There goes one!” cried Athos, at the end of five hundred paces.	374.017902240597
“But why did that man attack Porthos rather than any other one of us?”	333.7885390116178
asked Aramis.	367.2696723875238
“Because, as Porthos was talking louder than the rest of us, he took	406.6789450121471
him for the chief,” said D’Artagnan.	316.8766397864476
“I always said that this cadet from Gascony was a well of wisdom,”	292.55626769940875
murmured Athos; and the travelers continued their route.	382.23273487970124
At Beauvais they stopped two hours, as well to breathe their horses a	379.2920191935676
little as to wait for Porthos. At the end of two hours, as Porthos did	314.0882543487278
not come, not any news of him, they resumed their journey.	341.90003053786216
At a league from Beauvais, where the road was confined between two high	335.95766334629724
banks, they fell in with eight or ten men who, taking advantage of the	490.23455878944276
road being unpaved in this spot, appeared to be employed in digging	432.7320814521421
holes and filling up the ruts with mud.	388.45634218292895
Aramis, not liking to soil his boots with this artificial mortar,	302.1127538709295
apostrophized them rather sharply. Athos wished to restrain him, but it	358.7158164250343
was too late. The laborers began to jeer the travelers and by their	423.59877411667946
insolence disturbed the equanimity even of the cool Athos, who urged on	327.9481305960065
his horse against one of them.	423.25278637035626
Then each of these men retreated as far as the ditch, from which each	485.5250161183925
took a concealed musket; the result was that our seven travelers were	476.7063823196965
outnumbered in weapons. Aramis received a ball which passed through his	305.77295170515333
shoulder, and Mousqueton another ball which lodged in the fleshy part	404.84613151083306
which prolongs the lower portion of the loins. Therefore Mousqueton	485.54250124586645
alone fell from his horse, not because he was severely wounded, but not	467.40471836074187
being able to see the wound, he judged it to be more serious than it	467.8914032880777
really was.	406.12762887229223
“It was an ambuscade!” shouted D’Artagnan. “Don’t waste a charge!	478.2720722837187
Forward!”	403.96148885083994
Aramis, wounded as he was, seized the mane of his horse, which carried	330.7945027391671
him on with the others. Mousqueton’s horse rejoined them, and galloped	388.1217997823642
by the side of his companions.	315.7653152038878
“That will serve us for a relay,” said Athos.	460.38621595004804
“I would rather have had a hat,” said D’Artagnan. “Mine was carried	451.1390807303698
away by a ball. By my faith, it is very fortunate that the letter was	345.01852559700404
not in it.”	434.80054779415127
“They’ll kill poor Porthos when he comes up,” said Aramis.	451.81331726804603
“If Porthos were on his legs, he would have rejoined us by this time,”	481.32975394130005
said Athos. “My opinion is that on the ground the drunken man was not	352.9707251201385
intoxicated.”	466.63546119257455
They continued at their best speed for two hours, although the horses	476.231199518964
were so fatigued that it was to be feared they would soon refuse	472.7676584801197
service.	415.24923797047614
The travelers had chosen crossroads in the hope that they might meet	311.33736754513933
with less interruption; but at Crèvecœur, Aramis declared he could	474.8357851762049
proceed no farther. In fact, it required all the courage which he	364.92105696339695
concealed beneath his elegant form and polished manners to bear him so	320.60325201327396
far. He grew more pale every minute, and they were obliged to support	376.40585149240485
him on his horse. They lifted him off at the door of a cabaret, left	363.1449151611028
Bazin with him, who, besides, in a skirmish was more embarrassing than	362.37658298518454
useful, and set forward again in the hope of sleeping at Amiens.	417.08452583091764
“_Morbleu_,” said Athos, as soon as they were again in motion, “reduced	424.00664261765894
to two masters and Grimaud and Planchet! _Morbleu!_ I won’t be their	482.8063526000723
dupe, I will answer for it. I will neither open my mouth nor draw my	338.7673795505462
sword between this and Calais. I swear by—”	366.6796641550593
“Don’t waste time in swearing,” said D’Artagnan; “let us gallop, if our	301.4686750639165
horses will consent.”	447.9748583101815
And the travelers buried their rowels in their horses’ flanks, who thus	339.017388478458
vigorously stimulated recovered their energies. They arrived at Amiens	473.3336975950202
at midnight, and alighted at the _auberge_ of the Golden Lily.	335.72505918161687
The host had the appearance of as honest a man as any on earth. He	302.66903641828924
received the travelers with his candlestick in one hand and his cotton	298.2020496284397
nightcap in the other. He wished to lodge the two travelers each in a	404.2075031333809
charming chamber; but unfortunately these charming chambers were at the	411.1012835292388
opposite extremities of the hôtel. D’Artagnan and Athos refused them.	472.00112549776816
The host replied that he had no other worthy of their Excellencies; but	347.28183202337533
the travelers declared they would sleep in the common chamber, each on	347.86018460757913
a mattress which might be thrown upon the ground. The host insisted;	389.66220050800734
but the travelers were firm, and he was obliged to do as they wished.	406.7858584000012
They had just prepared their beds and barricaded their door within,	344.71167001328234
when someone knocked at the yard shutter; they demanded who was there,	401.3280171026754
and recognizing the voices of their lackeys, opened the shutter. It was	320.1997159226628
indeed Planchet and Grimaud.	441.04422695510993
“Grimaud can take care of the horses,” said Planchet. “If you are	377.72614296795564
willing, gentlemen, I will sleep across your doorway, and you will then	336.56207364740055
be certain that nobody can reach you.”	378.0319270199181
“And on what will you sleep?” said D’Artagnan.	320.0397745171077
“Here is my bed,” replied Planchet, producing a bundle of straw.	453.1235279782128
“Come, then,” said D’Artagnan, “you are right. Mine host’s face does	316.06480918144456
not please me at all; it is too gracious.”	314.51927728805435
“Nor me either,” said Athos.	403.34710410884975
Planchet mounted by the window and installed himself across the	477.11446530536176
doorway, while Grimaud went and shut himself up in the stable,	339.08689736570886
undertaking that by five o’clock in the morning he and the four horses	307.1389311606624
should be ready.	329.1606407982948
The night was quiet enough. Toward two o’clock in the morning somebody	459.40477749810543
endeavored to open the door; but as Planchet awoke in an instant and	308.94885634309657
cried, “Who goes there?” somebody replied that he was mistaken, and	488.7489295889654
went away.	388.90327547260745
At four o’clock in the morning they heard a terrible riot in the	390.60138498176923
stables. Grimaud had tried to waken the stable boys, and the stable	472.4219248267435
boys had beaten him. When they opened the window, they saw the poor lad	344.4055638011691
lying senseless, with his head split by a blow with a pitchfork.	322.60419926923885
Planchet went down into the yard, and wished to saddle the horses; but	439.2894727991591
the horses were all used up. Mousqueton’s horse which had traveled for	482.99987604221127
five or six hours without a rider the day before, might have been able	391.2686466043286
to pursue the journey; but by an inconceivable error the veterinary	310.49172288600613
surgeon, who had been sent for, as it appeared, to bleed one of the	395.23098083470643
host’s horses, had bled Mousqueton’s.	350.8544800493053
This began to be annoying. All these successive accidents were perhaps	382.58201679941953
the result of chance; but they might be the fruits of a plot. Athos and	451.8503644898149
D’Artagnan went out, while Planchet was sent to inquire if there were	474.9448092396598
not three horses for sale in the neighborhood. At the door stood two	357.630034930686
horses, fresh, strong, and fully equipped. These would just have suited	310.51217878613664
them. He asked where their masters were, and was informed that they had	393.5112222840272
passed the night in the inn, and were then settling their bill with the	308.33502899582345
host.	481.19580857051346
Athos went down to pay the reckoning, while D’Artagnan and Planchet	469.06306641255514
stood at the street door. The host was in a lower and back room, to	438.11130442344574
which Athos was requested to go.	309.94994832756345
Athos entered without the least mistrust, and took out two pistoles to	293.91109088199346
pay the bill. The host was alone, seated before his desk, one of the	437.30998291573815
drawers of which was partly open. He took the money which Athos offered	340.42173407902567
to him, and after turning and turning it over and over in his hands,	375.47943817474794
suddenly cried out that it was bad, and that he would have him and his	322.81012189290703
companions arrested as forgers.	466.42050606095063
“You blackguard!” cried Athos, going toward him, “I’ll cut your ears	357.88686484997834
off!”	417.56284438521465
At the same instant, four men, armed to the teeth, entered by side	346.4709592497129
doors, and rushed upon Athos.	432.1802088657838
“I am taken!” shouted Athos, with all the power of his lungs. “Go on,	457.5190135045411
D’Artagnan! Spur, spur!” and he fired two pistols.	455.5572059839832
D’Artagnan and Planchet did not require twice bidding; they unfastened	399.48304329897445
the two horses that were waiting at the door, leaped upon them, buried	382.5379090398707
their spurs in their sides, and set off at full gallop.	454.96662988406797
“Do you know what has become of Athos?” asked D’Artagnan of Planchet,	388.6600345774052
as they galloped on.	456.36379609252003
“Ah, monsieur,” said Planchet, “I saw one fall at each of his two	348.7632063048726
shots, and he appeared to me, through the glass door, to be fighting	294.48216068276963
with his sword with the others.”	311.8209289848153
“Brave Athos!” murmured D’Artagnan, “and to think that we are compelled	407.6508569448372
to leave him; maybe the same fate awaits us two paces hence. Forward,	484.7326008689488
Planchet, forward! You are a brave fellow.”	389.3947649082191
“As I told you, monsieur,” replied Planchet, “Picards are found out by	300.12018610546545
being used. Besides, I am here in my own country, and that excites me.”	328.0086550128823
And both, with free use of the spur, arrived at St. Omer without	476.25119494353453
drawing bit. At St. Omer they breathed their horses with the bridles	455.30657750679006
passed under their arms for fear of accident, and ate a morsel from	364.5928816769591
their hands on the stones of the street, after they departed again.	330.11997386935604
At a hundred paces from the gates of Calais, D’Artagnan’s horse gave	303.4572324287075
out, and could not by any means be made to get up again, the blood	434.9583417242395
flowing from his eyes and his nose. There still remained Planchet’s	407.4608134273004
horse; but he stopped short, and could not be made to move a step.	342.8064734886809
Fortunately, as we have said, they were within a hundred paces of the	317.2633695242428
city; they left their two nags upon the high road, and ran toward the	308.26628227632597
quay. Planchet called his master’s attention to a gentleman who had	439.81165106725996
just arrived with his lackey, and only preceded them by about fifty	473.09149497076396
paces. They made all speed to come up to this gentleman, who appeared	462.60266259419814
to be in great haste. His boots were covered with dust, and he inquired	313.92678555647024
if he could not instantly cross over to England.	343.0537481778573
“Nothing would be more easy,” said the captain of a vessel ready to set	450.70760287426066
sail, “but this morning came an order to let no one leave without	294.19462811179045
express permission from the cardinal.”	452.5183961311561
“I have that permission,” said the gentleman, drawing the paper from	295.3134515916599
his pocket; “here it is.”	374.6816699304814
“Have it examined by the governor of the port,” said the shipmaster,	429.0519625462104
“and give me the preference.”	335.2877973412205
“Where shall I find the governor?”	481.6525599073955
“At his country house.”	487.3232826367675
“And that is situated?”	333.9526111842871
“At a quarter of a league from the city. Look, you may see it from	467.108825897948
here—at the foot of that little hill, that slated roof.”	409.1312532792539
“Very well,” said the gentleman. And, with his lackey, he took the road	357.44516670270633
to the governor’s country house.	323.67820787437864
D’Artagnan and Planchet followed the gentleman at a distance of five	427.0470177492597
hundred paces. Once outside the city, D’Artagnan overtook the gentleman	319.1711066870597
as he was entering a little wood.	475.0335264527926
“Monsieur, you appear to be in great haste?”	462.32307600218985
“No one can be more so, monsieur.”	475.4143116600323
“I am sorry for that,” said D’Artagnan; “for as I am in great haste	472.432896444395
likewise, I wish to beg you to render me a service.”	392.29970044252883
“What?”	308.7950131604343
“To let me sail first.”	355.3007042685803
“That’s impossible,” said the gentleman; “I have traveled sixty leagues	429.90290944660956
in forty hours, and by tomorrow at midday I must be in London.”	403.9466343214466
“I have performed that same distance in forty hours, and by ten o’clock	354.6187625010293
in the morning I must be in London.”	478.5427438417747
“Very sorry, monsieur; but I was here first, and will not sail second.”	401.61537338938837
“I am sorry, too, monsieur; but I arrived second, and must sail first.”	344.1869092783809
“The king’s service!” said the gentleman.	299.4873353294522
“My own service!” said D’Artagnan.	327.69348314364487
“But this is a needless quarrel you seek with me, as it seems to me.”	349.8939592504068
“_Parbleu!_ What do you desire it to be?”	308.1719660019246
“What do you want?”	323.69704043461326
“Would you like to know?”	294.5596219588497
“Certainly.”	480.7533879029123
“Well, then, I wish that order of which you are bearer, seeing that I	464.3514896661666
have not one of my own and must have one.”	382.28087596599386
“You jest, I presume.”	341.88417286209864
“I never jest.”	421.2865628915387
“Let me pass!”	440.7985679130398
“You shall not pass.”	323.82224480496114
“My brave young man, I will blow out your brains. _Hola_, Lubin, my	352.06370899315516
pistols!”	306.35923239004035
“Planchet,” called out D’Artagnan, “take care of the lackey; I will	330.100574159653
manage the master.”	362.6213511007851
Planchet, emboldened by the first exploit, sprang upon Lubin; and being	367.7798204769554
strong and vigorous, he soon got him on the broad of his back, and	331.20149445988875
placed his knee upon his breast.	442.62359122569075
“Go on with your affair, monsieur,” cried Planchet; “I have finished	401.11055924240395
mine.”	319.6416426327718
Seeing this, the gentleman drew his sword, and sprang upon D’Artagnan;	429.58395161719625
but he had too strong an adversary. In three seconds D’Artagnan had	411.6255848825259
wounded him three times, exclaiming at each thrust, “One for Athos, one	319.5417754805409
for Porthos; and one for Aramis!”	407.3856443442779
At the third hit the gentleman fell like a log. D’Artagnan believed him	357.90543789103504
to be dead, or at least insensible, and went toward him for the purpose	376.7037809187134
of taking the order; but the moment he extended his hand to search for	392.3084806789532
it, the wounded man, who had not dropped his sword, plunged the point	326.1975040243054
into D’Artagnan’s breast, crying, “One for you!”	311.32990627049367
“And one for me—the best for last!” cried D’Artagnan, furious, nailing	411.0197164275462
him to the earth with a fourth thrust through his body.	364.0006187107927
This time the gentleman closed his eyes and fainted. D’Artagnan	462.5388937595817
searched his pockets, and took from one of them the order for the	378.49222837256264
passage. It was in the name of Comte de Wardes.	489.99319505134406
Then, casting a glance on the handsome young man, who was scarcely	481.21591665070184
twenty-five years of age, and whom he was leaving in his gore, deprived	442.17563087950293
of sense and perhaps dead, he gave a sigh for that unaccountable	486.7174322397062
destiny which leads men to destroy each other for the interests of	467.7357834989342
people who are strangers to them and who often do not even know that	390.76081322889416
they exist. But he was soon aroused from these reflections by Lubin,	375.87039866365456
who uttered loud cries and screamed for help with all his might.	338.5559060369199
Planchet grasped him by the throat, and pressed as hard as he could.	384.666083576774
“Monsieur,” said he, “as long as I hold him in this manner, he can’t	366.6115638185514
cry, I’ll be bound; but as soon as I let go he will howl again. I know	314.77801851159626
him for a Norman, and Normans are obstinate.”	437.94944880448736
In fact, tightly held as he was, Lubin endeavored still to cry out.	395.1054900654129
“Stay!” said D’Artagnan; and taking out his handkerchief, he gagged	355.6157134100356
him.	408.1350049981479
“Now,” said Planchet, “let us bind him to a tree.”	438.58460443857336
This being properly done, they drew the Comte de Wardes close to his	328.62529902493395
servant; and as night was approaching, and as the wounded man and the	415.1240281146148
bound man were at some little distance within the wood, it was evident	463.33666477261875
they were likely to remain there till the next day.	350.75509586205123
“And now,” said D’Artagnan, “to the Governor’s.”	445.0405924133281
“But you are wounded, it seems,” said Planchet.	430.2463586307587
“Oh, that’s nothing! Let us attend to what is more pressing first, and	347.9459778093315
then we will attend to my wound; besides, it does not seem very	303.3156070177855
dangerous.”	409.1999659663839
And they both set forward as fast as they could toward the country	415.03621304605053
house of the worthy functionary.	336.9498629768446
The Comte de Wardes was announced, and D’Artagnan was introduced.	372.17308538191173
“You have an order signed by the cardinal?” said the governor.	453.72245198402766
“Yes, monsieur,” replied D’Artagnan; “here it is.”	343.9127925124403
“Ah, ah! It is quite regular and explicit,” said the governor.	472.32897918793714
“Most likely,” said D’Artagnan; “I am one of his most faithful	310.5204054453989
servants.”	308.95468648724903
“It appears that his Eminence is anxious to prevent someone from	417.2933855355407
crossing to England?”	441.62963692962114
“Yes; a certain D’Artagnan, a Béarnese gentleman who left Paris in	374.1197401035665
company with three of his friends, with the intention of going to	476.3711910264591
London.”	477.2431235799979
“Do you know him personally?” asked the governor.	460.4014706947163
“Whom?”	390.73492091249113
“This D’Artagnan.”	358.9225589028657
“Perfectly well.”	464.04877550969303
“Describe him to me, then.”	358.84545493737545
“Nothing more easy.”	365.3502577543717
And D’Artagnan gave, feature for feature, a description of the Comte de	491.83940238853154
Wardes.	449.386944799742
“Is he accompanied?”	461.3790111071123
“Yes; by a lackey named Lubin.”	343.2257977579484
“We will keep a sharp lookout for them; and if we lay hands on them his	490.8651322943731
Eminence may be assured they will be reconducted to Paris under a good	437.3492932683058
escort.”	380.2424927535586
“And by doing so, Monsieur the Governor,” said D’Artagnan, “you will	321.3402780535117
deserve well of the cardinal.”	443.5335664945527
“Shall you see him on your return, Monsieur Count?”	301.9681232052741
“Without a doubt.”	376.69979126055296
“Tell him, I beg you, that I am his humble servant.”	382.4925958060039
“I will not fail.”	486.38641096106915
Delighted with this assurance the governor countersigned the passport	357.356505917602
and delivered it to D’Artagnan. D’Artagnan lost no time in useless	424.3338501615683
compliments. He thanked the governor, bowed, and departed. Once	350.1230144076962
outside, he and Planchet set off as fast as they could; and by making a	311.3118062542961
long detour avoided the wood and reentered the city by another gate.	333.0565864807483
The vessel was quite ready to sail, and the captain was waiting on the	465.61386501640004
wharf. “Well?” said he, on perceiving D’Artagnan.	439.6307754691731
“Here is my pass countersigned,” said the latter.	362.1314844156033
“And that other gentleman?	460.035743361089
“He will not go today,” said D’Artagnan; “but here, I’ll pay you for us	386.52988206518273
two.”	477.4194562182919
“In that case let us go,” said the shipmaster.	362.740462904049
“Let us go,” repeated D’Artagnan.	409.37795472744665
He leaped with Planchet into the boat, and five minutes after they were	448.8220130827854
on board. It was time; for they had scarcely sailed half a league, when	330.16886734477356
D’Artagnan saw a flash and heard a detonation. It was the cannon which	460.9523925141482
announced the closing of the port.	369.4117646207076
He had now leisure to look to his wound. Fortunately, as D’Artagnan had	383.0262229455791
thought, it was not dangerous. The point of the sword had touched a	334.30780615719107
rib, and glanced along the bone. Still further, his shirt had stuck to	378.49943762580045
the wound, and he had lost only a few drops of blood.	342.94012145915286
D’Artagnan was worn out with fatigue. A mattress was laid upon the deck	295.51917304958545
for him. He threw himself upon it, and fell asleep.	349.5877287236142
On the morrow, at break of day, they were still three or four leagues	384.0774406762079
from the coast of England. The breeze had been so light all night, they	346.1828600434025
had made but little progress. At ten o’clock the vessel cast anchor in	325.0345057883295
the harbor of Dover, and at half past ten D’Artagnan placed his foot on	376.1046363942205
English land, crying, “Here I am at last!”	317.89938997077815
But that was not all; they must get to London. In England the post was	386.7514885875577
well served. D’Artagnan and Planchet took each a post horse, and a	304.1771150892215
postillion rode before them. In a few hours they were in the capital.	431.4200691249772
D’Artagnan did not know London; he did not know a word of English; but	491.6581656423838
he wrote the name of Buckingham on a piece of paper, and everyone	390.7766855677724
pointed out to him the way to the duke’s hôtel.	489.2953550803604
The duke was at Windsor hunting with the king. D’Artagnan inquired for	303.78746575249363
the confidential valet of the duke, who, having accompanied him in all	395.96689230230055
his voyages, spoke French perfectly well; he told him that he came from	450.2120797462914
Paris on an affair of life and death, and that he must speak with his	433.8986964462731
master instantly.	312.3917858023079
The confidence with which D’Artagnan spoke convinced Patrick, which was	326.04374849438
the name of this minister of the minister. He ordered two horses to be	483.0564588009338
saddled, and himself went as guide to the young Guardsman. As for	440.29384374983727
Planchet, he had been lifted from his horse as stiff as a rush; the	432.3480728617559
poor lad’s strength was almost exhausted. D’Artagnan seemed iron.	367.5294173485434
On their arrival at the castle they learned that Buckingham and the	440.4327893328319
king were hawking in the marshes two or three leagues away. In twenty	378.846792214791
minutes they were on the spot named. Patrick soon caught the sound of	337.9090660485376
his master’s voice calling his falcon.	325.6670571740295
“Whom must I announce to my Lord Duke?” asked Patrick.	425.5214125889364
“The young man who one evening sought a quarrel with him on the Pont	387.723559725472
Neuf, opposite the Samaritaine.”	434.6074950066948
“A singular introduction!”	300.56360642120325
“You will find that it is as good as another.”	313.9508238061207
Patrick galloped off, reached the duke, and announced to him in the	477.80728837990364
terms directed that a messenger awaited him.	376.05772030724063
Buckingham at once remembered the circumstance, and suspecting that	322.45402552692985
something was going on in France of which it was necessary he should be	408.97292928945626
informed, he only took the time to inquire where the messenger was, and	350.9795815796343
recognizing from afar the uniform of the Guards, he put his horse into	347.25730953754044
a gallop, and rode straight up to D’Artagnan. Patrick discreetly kept	326.9839996510193
in the background.	454.17585893698333
“No misfortune has happened to the queen?” cried Buckingham, the	407.5222865041494
instant he came up, throwing all his fear and love into the question.	473.7190120556579
“I believe not; nevertheless I believe she runs some great peril from	435.2750668570951
which your Grace alone can extricate her.”	476.66755828555375
“I!” cried Buckingham. “What is it? I should be too happy to be of any	305.35838042778823
service to her. Speak, speak!”	479.4128191971349
“Take this letter,” said D’Artagnan.	463.04000834245704
“This letter! From whom comes this letter?”	321.6878234851611
“From her Majesty, as I think.”	427.21291973937605
“From her Majesty!” said Buckingham, becoming so pale that D’Artagnan	431.9997709403064
feared he would faint as he broke the seal.	347.144286430079
“What is this rent?” said he, showing D’Artagnan a place where it had	455.611651098694
been pierced through.	420.52475506173226
“Ah,” said D’Artagnan, “I did not see that; it was the sword of the	421.88289522040634
Comte de Wardes which made that hole, when he gave me a good thrust in	431.81371052680424
the breast.”	418.45637589848764
“You are wounded?” asked Buckingham, as he opened the letter.	400.93001385403
“Oh, nothing but a scratch,” said D’Artagnan.	382.248205998859
“Just heaven, what have I read?” cried the duke. “Patrick, remain here,	479.4889934736315
or rather join the king, wherever he may be, and tell his Majesty that	457.70433587459945
I humbly beg him to excuse me, but an affair of the greatest importance	466.32796673142593
recalls me to London. Come, monsieur, come!” and both set off towards	486.87392455162495
the capital at full gallop.	380.4420020627773
Chapter XXI.	365.04590340414654
THE COUNTESS DE WINTER	456.5166345442554
As they rode along, the duke endeavored to draw from D’Artagnan, not	381.26537492375695
all that had happened, but what D’Artagnan himself knew. By adding all	418.9253175413352
that he heard from the mouth of the young man to his own remembrances,	474.6418067455029
he was enabled to form a pretty exact idea of a position of the	424.6616424195008
seriousness of which, for the rest, the queen’s letter, short but	426.40399949507616
explicit, gave him the clue. But that which astonished him most was	333.77403077132027
that the cardinal, so deeply interested in preventing this young man	299.75950100565314
from setting his foot in England, had not succeeded in arresting him on	320.9670474052
the road. It was then, upon the manifestation of this astonishment,	312.095761935073
that D’Artagnan related to him the precaution taken, and how, thanks to	386.2274815229574
the devotion of his three friends, whom he had left scattered and	322.5484190359255
bleeding on the road, he had succeeded in coming off with a single	326.04513762371215
sword thrust, which had pierced the queen’s letter and for which he had	391.00868286117657
repaid M. de Wardes with such terrible coin. While he was listening to	357.4022108728958
this recital, delivered with the greatest simplicity, the duke looked	433.93516724603046
from time to time at the young man with astonishment, as if he could	444.36715156842524
not comprehend how so much prudence, courage, and devotedness could be	339.19373086020187
allied with a countenance which indicated not more than twenty years.	470.6551750163751
The horses went like the wind, and in a few minutes they were at the	315.31472313123777
gates of London. D’Artagnan imagined that on arriving in town the duke	439.7429383574414
would slacken his pace, but it was not so. He kept on his way at the	341.2068067376405
same rate, heedless about upsetting those whom he met on the road. In	310.54956439288344
fact, in crossing the city two or three accidents of this kind	443.6149279201161
happened; but Buckingham did not even turn his head to see what became	348.50383971505164
of those he had knocked down. D’Artagnan followed him amid cries which	389.80179813215096
strongly resembled curses.	383.80557850858025
On entering the court of his hôtel, Buckingham sprang from his horse,	356.80447925780965
and without thinking what became of the animal, threw the bridle on his	316.5369784482122
neck, and sprang toward the vestibule. D’Artagnan did the same, with a	366.3773650902406
little more concern, however, for the noble creatures, whose merits he	412.274367230904
fully appreciated; but he had the satisfaction of seeing three or four	306.87739249717094
grooms run from the kitchens and the stables, and busy themselves with	462.99477970200394
the steeds.	313.01946008879844
The duke walked so fast that D’Artagnan had some trouble in keeping up	460.6738450121756
with him. He passed through several apartments, of an elegance of which	368.45856802841485
even the greatest nobles of France had not even an idea, and arrived at	419.15312404192224
length in a bedchamber which was at once a miracle of taste and of	426.8857703595289
richness. In the alcove of this chamber was a door concealed in the	460.17224969147685
tapestry which the duke opened with a little gold key which he wore	441.1266357311364
suspended from his neck by a chain of the same metal. With discretion	370.71383979969477
D’Artagnan remained behind; but at the moment when Buckingham crossed	484.5242780055506
the threshold, he turned round, and seeing the hesitation of the young	450.30824144189944
man, “Come in!” cried he, “and if you have the good fortune to be	400.4572316259715
admitted to her Majesty’s presence, tell her what you have seen.”	407.0014923258523
Encouraged by this invitation, D’Artagnan followed the duke, who closed	315.12628752637295
the door after them. The two found themselves in a small chapel covered	388.3087696049116
with a tapestry of Persian silk worked with gold, and brilliantly	321.387739778337
lighted with a vast number of candles. Over a species of altar, and	293.1817225492965
beneath a canopy of blue velvet, surmounted by white and red plumes,	435.586793223999
was a full-length portrait of Anne of Austria, so perfect in its	337.3549002743003
resemblance that D’Artagnan uttered a cry of surprise on beholding it.	343.3052726871124
One might believe the queen was about to speak. On the altar, and	398.38464961928753
beneath the portrait, was the casket containing the diamond studs.	360.52763270998383
The duke approached the altar, knelt as a priest might have done before	393.2513622153262
a crucifix, and opened the casket. “There,” said he, drawing from the	432.03749965702616
casket a large bow of blue ribbon all sparkling with diamonds, “there	344.1769018773198
are the precious studs which I have taken an oath should be buried with	485.45731584002
me. The queen gave them to me, the queen requires them again. Her will	449.4413266106921
be done, like that of God, in all things.”	414.03838161684934
Then, he began to kiss, one after the other, those dear studs with	470.20613274158177
which he was about to part. All at once he uttered a terrible cry.	398.4107525741683
“What is the matter?” exclaimed D’Artagnan, anxiously; “what has	416.5552818586383
happened to you, my Lord?”	338.396203407454
“All is lost!” cried Buckingham, becoming as pale as a corpse; “two of	328.8643337224423
the studs are wanting, there are only ten.”	358.9552430500744
“Can you have lost them, my Lord, or do you think they have been	421.5359067609237
stolen?”	368.3572219154667
“They have been stolen,” replied the duke, “and it is the cardinal who	421.95880671133136
has dealt this blow. Hold; see! The ribbons which held them have been	484.7626126964792
cut with scissors.”	307.8584056991019
“If my Lord suspects they have been stolen, perhaps the person who	368.07753830727614
stole them still has them in his hands.”	358.92243465148067
“Wait, wait!” said the duke. “The only time I have worn these studs was	435.1681983516329
at a ball given by the king eight days ago at Windsor. The Comtesse de	489.26211163104705
Winter, with whom I had quarreled, became reconciled to me at that	407.55508554783523
ball. That reconciliation was nothing but the vengeance of a jealous	476.3085659143634
woman. I have never seen her from that day. The woman is an agent of	434.3931186980297
the cardinal.”	417.2742101892892
“He has agents, then, throughout the world?” cried D’Artagnan.	306.13197921442486
“Oh, yes,” said Buckingham, grating his teeth with rage. “Yes, he is a	332.5392198707567
terrible antagonist. But when is this ball to take place?”	480.0346963971067
“Monday next.”	408.2516123001495
“Monday next! Still five days before us. That’s more time than we want.	329.09367775530694
Patrick!” cried the duke, opening the door of the chapel, “Patrick!”	423.6825604323211
His confidential valet appeared.	362.8032182285844
“My jeweler and my secretary.”	484.4790461090131
The valet went out with a mute promptitude which showed him accustomed	395.0948459800873
to obey blindly and without reply.	293.52627571232284
But although the jeweler had been mentioned first, it was the secretary	481.3412560390135
who first made his appearance. This was simply because he lived in the	458.53480747111104
hôtel. He found Buckingham seated at a table in his bedchamber, writing	466.8014019774804
orders with his own hand.	327.27038574484675
“Mr. Jackson,” said he, “go instantly to the Lord Chancellor, and tell	357.36459022888
him that I charge him with the execution of these orders. I wish them	346.0763926013194
to be promulgated immediately.”	415.665187420426
“But, my Lord, if the Lord Chancellor interrogates me upon the motives	358.83899129487406
which may have led your Grace to adopt such an extraordinary measure,	359.30475971642045
what shall I reply?”	453.011987524823
“That such is my pleasure, and that I answer for my will to no man.”	488.0930967398582
“Will that be the answer,” replied the secretary, smiling, “which he	401.4677613082265
must transmit to his Majesty if, by chance, his Majesty should have the	480.161817168252
curiosity to know why no vessel is to leave any of the ports of Great	351.2214046771308
Britain?”	356.5110100413111
“You are right, Mr. Jackson,” replied Buckingham. “He will say, in that	437.30991827933394
case, to the king that I am determined on war, and that this measure is	328.09300440283516
my first act of hostility against France.”	358.74196991927806
The secretary bowed and retired.	477.7767076340908
“We are safe on that side,” said Buckingham, turning toward D’Artagnan.	399.5159238110365
“If the studs are not yet gone to Paris, they will not arrive till	421.78488637604585
after you.”	390.8788321254766
“How so?”	294.58919901967226
“I have just placed an embargo on all vessels at present in his	431.8185293880641
Majesty’s ports, and without particular permission, not one dare lift	297.7799922549102
an anchor.”	293.97291223931785
D’Artagnan looked with stupefaction at a man who thus employed the	443.4197827311158
unlimited power with which he was clothed by the confidence of a king	339.79637441642933
in the prosecution of his intrigues. Buckingham saw by the expression	373.96811970317043
of the young man’s face what was passing in his mind, and he smiled.	305.89578466425235
“Yes,” said he, “yes, Anne of Austria is my true queen. Upon a word	314.9685391572737
from her, I would betray my country, I would betray my king, I would	466.7806984130985
betray my God. She asked me not to send the Protestants of La Rochelle	470.4630196143863
the assistance I promised them; I have not done so. I broke my word, it	340.62672528131196
is true; but what signifies that? I obeyed my love; and have I not been	412.70568423936834
richly paid for that obedience? It was to that obedience I owe her	460.48482583350966
portrait.”	334.28404786023947
D’Artagnan was amazed to note by what fragile and unknown threads the	483.4916331626398
destinies of nations and the lives of men are suspended. He was lost in	453.0746765369073
these reflections when the goldsmith entered. He was an Irishman—one of	391.0972573691909
the most skillful of his craft, and who himself confessed that he	379.099727800054
gained a hundred thousand livres a year by the Duke of Buckingham.	346.75586335487816
“Mr. O’Reilly,” said the duke, leading him into the chapel, “look at	468.63815379990695
these diamond studs, and tell me what they are worth apiece.”	387.2766761835286
The goldsmith cast a glance at the elegant manner in which they were	408.8178278629117
set, calculated, one with another, what the diamonds were worth, and	460.04796117160464
without hesitation said, “Fifteen hundred pistoles each, my Lord.”	321.93569728655666
“How many days would it require to make two studs exactly like them?	426.15318067337057
You see there are two wanting.”	444.41393588789595
“Eight days, my Lord.”	449.27125853555754
“I will give you three thousand pistoles apiece if I can have them by	450.4790388457727
the day after tomorrow.”	488.5830957717103
“My Lord, they shall be yours.”	324.3528636905167
“You are a jewel of a man, Mr. O’Reilly; but that is not all. These	378.99029932753007
studs cannot be trusted to anybody; it must be done in the palace.”	394.6299217949895
“Impossible, my Lord! There is no one but myself can so execute them	411.6029523962608
that one cannot tell the new from the old.”	342.87691125515505
“Therefore, my dear Mr. O’Reilly, you are my prisoner. And if you wish	452.55515652997764
ever to leave my palace, you cannot; so make the best of it. Name to me	307.44383703408636
such of your workmen as you need, and point out the tools they must	431.47267370033296
bring.”	309.5997446896049
The goldsmith knew the duke. He knew all objection would be useless,	437.4930219530793
and instantly determined how to act.	321.0239206778415
“May I be permitted to inform my wife?” said he.	450.8665380917916
“Oh, you may even see her if you like, my dear Mr. O’Reilly. Your	438.2066417734857
captivity shall be mild, be assured; and as every inconvenience	307.2962838334295
deserves its indemnification, here is, in addition to the price of the	475.54283578112376
studs, an order for a thousand pistoles, to make you forget the	308.70245428207596
annoyance I cause you.”	390.3435088162944
D’Artagnan could not get over the surprise created in him by this	450.0321959001876
minister, who thus open-handed, sported with men and millions.	361.0922460770733
As to the goldsmith, he wrote to his wife, sending her the order for	439.35130299055953
the thousand pistoles, and charging her to send him, in exchange, his	457.75915411236997
most skillful apprentice, an assortment of diamonds, of which he gave	421.9461840792808
the names and the weight, and the necessary tools.	442.08636506597225
Buckingham conducted the goldsmith to the chamber destined for him, and	301.6101171741629
which, at the end of half an hour, was transformed into a workshop.	309.20020497460627
Then he placed a sentinel at each door, with an order to admit nobody	412.6468296955623
upon any pretense but his _valet de chambre_, Patrick. We need not add	380.17479906628523
that the goldsmith, O’Reilly, and his assistant, were prohibited from	478.6389264878901
going out under any pretext. This point, settled, the duke turned to	385.4606117114344
D’Artagnan. “Now, my young friend,” said he, “England is all our own.	350.25716263326524
What do you wish for? What do you desire?”	383.4250649078114
“A bed, my Lord,” replied D’Artagnan. “At present, I confess, that is	295.4807982153563
the thing I stand most in need of.”	366.3796012603369
Buckingham gave D’Artagnan a chamber adjoining his own. He wished to	474.8313300812234
have the young man at hand—not that he at all mistrusted him, but for	366.6955861317432
the sake of having someone to whom he could constantly talk of the	443.784580080484
queen.	412.76363840343333
In one hour after, the ordinance was published in London that no vessel	475.2790024366353
bound for France should leave port, not even the packet boat with	305.06228332255404
letters. In the eyes of everybody this was a declaration of war between	488.2407758595249
the two kingdoms.	365.84772566664185
On the day after the morrow, by eleven o’clock, the two diamond studs	386.74988819141953
were finished, and they were so completely imitated, so perfectly	318.81861594490573
alike, that Buckingham could not tell the new ones from the old ones,	356.6688077864847
and experts in such matters would have been deceived as he was. He	478.92527503601593
immediately called D’Artagnan. “Here,” said he to him, “are the diamond	441.2508982120778
studs that you came to bring; and be my witness that I have done all	292.35762707174035
that human power could do.”	306.76991648715705
“Be satisfied, my Lord, I will tell all that I have seen. But does your	330.2379368456815
Grace mean to give me the studs without the casket?”	464.4632778282848
“The casket would encumber you. Besides, the casket is the more	360.11724343018307
precious from being all that is left to me. You will say that I keep	357.51895006300686
it.”	423.8144726852769
“I will perform your commission, word for word, my Lord.”	382.73682425096945
“And now,” resumed Buckingham, looking earnestly at the young man, “how	359.0120111965324
shall I ever acquit myself of the debt I owe you?”	314.06213650903703
D’Artagnan blushed up to the whites of his eyes. He saw that the duke	323.7124070614292
was searching for a means of making him accept something and the idea	454.03345616455795
that the blood of his friends and himself was about to be paid for with	318.5790260983376
English gold was strangely repugnant to him.	320.6590164729221
“Let us understand each other, my Lord,” replied D’Artagnan, “and let	485.98409771561774
us make things clear beforehand in order that there may be no mistake.	354.1825101686334
I am in the service of the King and Queen of France, and form part of	487.0695529556623
the company of Monsieur Dessessart, who, as well as his brother-in-law,	475.06018802845426
Monsieur de Tréville, is particularly attached to their Majesties. What	451.4318080986342
I have done, then, has been for the queen, and not at all for your	468.3237137968039
Grace. And still further, it is very probable I should not have done	419.6496916062148
anything of this, if it had not been to make myself agreeable to	303.70967191319147
someone who is my lady, as the queen is yours.”	489.3609570444197
“Yes,” said the duke, smiling, “and I even believe that I know that	420.9933691209202
other person; it is—”	447.8516192393794
“My Lord, I have not named her!” interrupted the young man, warmly.	454.30744645409777
“That is true,” said the duke; “and it is to this person I am bound to	467.0351924987999
discharge my debt of gratitude.”	344.60388630938826
“You have said, my Lord; for truly, at this moment when there is	356.19931488158517
question of war, I confess to you that I see nothing in your Grace but	398.03002480890314
an Englishman, and consequently an enemy whom I should have much	448.6116847274691
greater pleasure in meeting on the field of battle than in the park at	450.1592334687409
Windsor or the corridors of the Louvre—all which, however, will not	475.36659476016587
prevent me from executing to the very point my commission or from	309.8285132753433
laying down my life, if there be need of it, to accomplish it; but I	296.03748171798907
repeat it to your Grace, without your having personally on that account	326.6629625363299
more to thank me for in this second interview than for what I did for	386.03985060006136
you in the first.”	438.11443269633526
“We say, ‘Proud as a Scotsman,’” murmured the Duke of Buckingham.	315.3374488811665
“And we say, ‘Proud as a Gascon,’” replied D’Artagnan. “The Gascons are	349.55995486155405
the Scots of France.”	347.1824654544497
D’Artagnan bowed to the duke, and was retiring.	354.9232010689155
“Well, are you going away in that manner? Where, and how?”	324.36369718280315
“That’s true!”	318.91542501266883
“Fore Gad, these Frenchmen have no consideration!”	393.12477768413765
“I had forgotten that England was an island, and that you were the king	378.05036559728586
of it.”	474.0685699100705
“Go to the riverside, ask for the brig _Sund_, and give this letter to	457.33732767468473
the captain; he will convey you to a little port, where certainly you	322.4011083379175
are not expected, and which is ordinarily only frequented by	355.4669855119666
fishermen.”	362.7920717297632
“The name of that port?”	349.97181868283883
“St. Valery; but listen. When you have arrived there you will go to a	471.39316335914395
mean tavern, without a name and without a sign—a mere fisherman’s hut.	350.3400984976239
You cannot be mistaken; there is but one.”	411.4962577534982
“Afterward?”	322.75288833227546
“You will ask for the host, and will repeat to him the word ‘Forward!’”	426.5316076928357
“Which means?”	455.9493109119487
“In French, _En avant_. It is the password. He will give you a horse	333.1840779253199
all saddled, and will point out to you the road you ought to take. You	404.302768032889
will find, in the same way, four relays on your route. If you will give	340.7597484734211
at each of these relays your address in Paris, the four horses will	486.69765462638986
follow you thither. You already know two of them, and you appeared to	313.58410436296134
appreciate them like a judge. They were those we rode on; and you may	478.8507975838504
rely upon me for the others not being inferior to them. These horses	382.8586767498582
are equipped for the field. However proud you may be, you will not	377.33678644302717
refuse to accept one of them, and to request your three companions to	468.00237452143296
accept the others—that is, in order to make war against us. Besides,	304.17784935561855
the end justified the means, as you Frenchmen say, does it not?”	366.7167719015704
“Yes, my Lord, I accept them,” said D’Artagnan; “and if it please God,	293.8824636826872
we will make a good use of your presents.”	360.97121881272835
“Well, now, your hand, young man. Perhaps we shall soon meet on the	465.7917573011727
field of battle; but in the meantime we shall part good friends, I	340.73089443896106
hope.”	424.20377210094426
“Yes, my Lord; but with the hope of soon becoming enemies.”	451.2522839179232
“Be satisfied; I promise you that.”	482.2843265361032
“I depend upon your word, my Lord.”	326.20348982887543
D’Artagnan bowed to the duke, and made his way as quickly as possible	423.55283479294394
to the riverside. Opposite the Tower of London he found the vessel that	487.7126539847171
had been named to him, delivered his letter to the captain, who after	359.21851693819843
having it examined by the governor of the port made immediate	383.55277353184005
preparations to sail.	349.5413502387226
Fifty vessels were waiting to set out. Passing alongside one of them,	393.09835290940526
D’Artagnan fancied he perceived on board it the woman of Meung—the same	491.2704915474794
whom the unknown gentleman had called Milady, and whom D’Artagnan had	396.5719072322827
thought so handsome; but thanks to the current of the stream and a fair	363.67162995096555
wind, his vessel passed so quickly that he had little more than a	391.5887273755774
glimpse of her.	376.3389017526247
The next day about nine o’clock in the morning, he landed at St.	388.0536654808101
Valery. D’Artagnan went instantly in search of the inn, and easily	347.3656204311535
discovered it by the riotous noise which resounded from it. War between	373.0719055768143
England and France was talked of as near and certain, and the jolly	301.7070988707151
sailors were having a carousal.	462.27746052829343
D’Artagnan made his way through the crowd, advanced toward the host,	321.2353757314513
and pronounced the word “Forward!” The host instantly made him a sign	357.40488964262556
to follow, went out with him by a door which opened into a yard, led	318.46350490507587
him to the stable, where a saddled horse awaited him, and asked him if	456.2354734413164
he stood in need of anything else.	444.437790185615
“I want to know the route I am to follow,” said D’Artagnan.	449.9808779527623
“Go from hence to Blangy, and from Blangy to Neufchâtel. At Neufchâtel,	389.3868601051144
go to the tavern of the Golden Harrow, give the password to the	332.03928481621955
landlord, and you will find, as you have here, a horse ready saddled.”	429.47087701991416
“Have I anything to pay?” demanded D’Artagnan.	331.7306492201752
“Everything is paid,” replied the host, “and liberally. Begone, and may	433.6044715177386
God guide you!”	385.383155062078
“Amen!” cried the young man, and set off at full gallop.	435.5801728821198
Four hours later he was in Neufchâtel. He strictly followed the	343.00596953285344
instructions he had received. At Neufchâtel, as at St. Valery, he found	365.3017301558354
a horse quite ready and awaiting him. He was about to remove the	437.81380045181515
pistols from the saddle he had quit to the one he was about to fill,	437.26566518202196
but he found the holsters furnished with similar pistols.	449.91099412377014
“Your address at Paris?”	364.7327965372239
“Hôtel of the Guards, company of Dessessart.”	393.46852561786363
“Enough,” replied the questioner.	302.2249374529836
“Which route must I take?” demanded D’Artagnan, in his turn.	365.92248069167835
“That of Rouen; but you will leave the city on your right. You must	483.4617880693401
stop at the little village of Eccuis, in which there is but one	338.10134017404124
tavern—the Shield of France. Don’t condemn it from appearances; you	307.96720820052917
will find a horse in the stables quite as good as this.”	380.66003385911546
“The same password?”	393.9409195569794
“Exactly.”	437.3336160212921
“Adieu, master!”	349.3308127225994
“A good journey, gentlemen! Do you want anything?”	425.9408990426091
D’Artagnan shook his head, and set off at full speed. At Eccuis, the	484.20197905975044
same scene was repeated. He found as provident a host and a fresh	320.84736894634676
horse. He left his address as he had done before, and set off again at	367.05713598096685
the same pace for Pontoise. At Pontoise he changed his horse for the	316.1029049358102
last time, and at nine o’clock galloped into the yard of Tréville’s	384.5039083066901
hôtel. He had made nearly sixty leagues in little more than twelve	357.39788259163095
hours.	361.82593711093386
M. de Tréville received him as if he had seen him that same morning;	323.13626424827254
only, when pressing his hand a little more warmly than usual, he	445.11665371305116
informed him that the company of Dessessart was on duty at the Louvre,	453.4816173795266
and that he might repair at once to his post.	442.2661364661926
Chapter XXII.	486.7286055626121
THE BALLET OF LA MERLAISON	338.7118042637383
On the morrow, nothing was talked of in Paris but the ball which the	399.47987506645086
aldermen of the city were to give to the king and queen, and in which	437.0383019447529
their Majesties were to dance the famous La Merlaison—the favorite	414.089355427811
ballet of the king.	298.13037918215787
Eight days had been occupied in preparations at the Hôtel de Ville for	374.6898759494378
this important evening. The city carpenters had erected scaffolds upon	426.2776410632463
which the invited ladies were to be placed; the city grocer had	385.7744060212354
ornamented the chambers with two hundred _flambeaux_ of white wax, a	389.1157800499642
piece of luxury unheard of at that period; and twenty violins were	434.9530074213449
ordered, and the price for them fixed at double the usual rate, upon	379.3658354055402
condition, said the report, that they should be played all night.	334.03658804729804
At ten o’clock in the morning the Sieur de la Coste, ensign in the	489.33501902348536
king’s Guards, followed by two officers and several archers of that	341.0744931775383
body, came to the city registrar, named Clement, and demanded of him	426.005002991532
all the keys of the rooms and offices of the hôtel. These keys were	427.9262473619037
given up to him instantly. Each of them had a ticket attached to it, by	337.4603501317003
which it might be recognized; and from that moment the Sieur de la	350.3975424923326
Coste was charged with the care of all the doors and all the avenues.	433.693003829844
At eleven o’clock came in his turn Duhallier, captain of the Guards,	458.9511063695186
bringing with him fifty archers, who were distributed immediately	371.20365634789846
through the Hôtel de Ville, at the doors assigned them.	424.51125625638815
At three o’clock came two companies of the Guards, one French, the	340.6533593418325
other Swiss. The company of French guards was composed of half of M.	358.5198785608789
Duhallier’s men and half of M. Dessessart’s men.	481.5336787040044
At six in the evening the guests began to come. As fast as they	380.1891195740501
entered, they were placed in the grand saloon, on the platforms	386.8325289515629
prepared for them.	460.7603351628002
At nine o’clock Madame la Première Présidente arrived. As next to the	482.41787069787983
queen, she was the most considerable personage of the fête, she was	489.5790713034402
received by the city officials, and placed in a box opposite to that	445.30601926629623
which the queen was to occupy.	348.9676836450889
At ten o’clock, the king’s collation, consisting of preserves and other	482.1718765264145
delicacies, was prepared in the little room on the side of the church	335.6461519712357
of St. Jean, in front of the silver buffet of the city, which was	490.27365134598426
guarded by four archers.	451.9372347555494
At midnight great cries and loud acclamations were heard. It was the	385.14856540928963
king, who was passing through the streets which led from the Louvre to	409.43230452198077
the Hôtel de Ville, and which were all illuminated with colored	454.5587424016933
lanterns.	435.68211076836405
Immediately the aldermen, clothed in their cloth robes and preceded by	312.8536293042985
six sergeants, each holding a _flambeau_ in his hand, went to attend	344.6379514510859
upon the king, whom they met on the steps, where the provost of the	464.11784405052197
merchants made him the speech of welcome—a compliment to which his	340.7473656831155
Majesty replied with an apology for coming so late, laying the blame	378.6369424914371
upon the cardinal, who had detained him till eleven o’clock, talking of	363.7248749029436
affairs of state.	476.44935022807397
His Majesty, in full dress, was accompanied by his royal Highness, M.	468.3175345696127
le Comte de Soissons, by the Grand Prior, by the Duc de Longueville, by	456.1296515919373
the Duc d’Eubœuf, by the Comte d’Harcourt, by the Comte de la	407.15719291581854
Roche-Guyon, by M. de Liancourt, by M. de Baradas, by the Comte de	418.0278751705233
Cramail, and by the Chevalier de Souveray. Everybody noticed that the	467.4257640257519
king looked dull and preoccupied.	365.9600787635739
A private room had been prepared for the king and another for Monsieur.	427.67381672544735
In each of these closets were placed masquerade dresses. The same had	427.0176469673331
been done for the queen and Madame the President. The nobles and ladies	491.982355627364
of their Majesties’ suites were to dress, two by two, in chambers	419.59211369678746
prepared for the purpose. Before entering his closet the king desired	329.6548660431538
to be informed the moment the cardinal arrived.	428.9975830060826
Half an hour after the entrance of the king, fresh acclamations were	491.86043127624015
heard; these announced the arrival of the queen. The aldermen did as	318.0701319048995
they had done before, and preceded by their sergeants, advanced to	322.98437805249523
receive their illustrious guest. The queen entered the great hall; and	407.62595150735996
it was remarked that, like the king, she looked dull and even weary.	477.751952809416
At the moment she entered, the curtain of a small gallery which to that	349.93361057437835
time had been closed, was drawn, and the pale face of the cardinal	401.1385074512486
appeared, he being dressed as a Spanish cavalier. His eyes were fixed	486.10549254980936
upon those of the queen, and a smile of terrible joy passed over his	472.16920860000266
lips; the queen did not wear her diamond studs.	474.27576110702734
The queen remained for a short time to receive the compliments of the	439.8000178685987
city dignitaries and to reply to the salutations of the ladies. All at	399.24454848022174
once the king appeared with the cardinal at one of the doors of the	334.43733730861084
hall. The cardinal was speaking to him in a low voice, and the king was	437.94263225771374
very pale.	457.77532844448314
The king made his way through the crowd without a mask, and the ribbons	328.38185627293916
of his doublet scarcely tied. He went straight to the queen, and in an	355.5983504619722
altered voice said, “Why, madame, have you not thought proper to wear	473.87315089682966
your diamond studs, when you know it would give me so much	479.0663426557983
gratification?”	392.112030899409
The queen cast a glance around her, and saw the cardinal behind, with a	334.3128216099758
diabolical smile on his countenance.	426.8704408551123
“Sire,” replied the queen, with a faltering voice, “because, in the	292.98874326856577
midst of such a crowd as this, I feared some accident might happen to	441.58957260246825
them.”	479.0127409624489
“And you were wrong, madame. If I made you that present it was that you	391.7450603304106
might adorn yourself therewith. I tell you that you were wrong.”	348.3764390889942
The voice of the king was tremulous with anger. Everybody looked and	312.72059876127696
listened with astonishment, comprehending nothing of what passed.	454.65821648458416
“Sire,” said the queen, “I can send for them to the Louvre, where they	350.29443118197554
are, and thus your Majesty’s wishes will be complied with.”	403.67637999319476
“Do so, madame, do so, and that at once; for within an hour the ballet	296.3218658473962
will commence.”	437.9949236463713
The queen bent in token of submission, and followed the ladies who were	322.2250315226923
to conduct her to her room. On his part the king returned to his	402.3267060254393
apartment.	298.2448279348332
There was a moment of trouble and confusion in the assembly. Everybody	325.9306421655796
had remarked that something had passed between the king and queen; but	350.2084247957547
both of them had spoken so low that everybody, out of respect, withdrew	293.0691884849414
several steps, so that nobody had heard anything. The violins began to	355.52221762411125
sound with all their might, but nobody listened to them.	441.1243909130019
The king came out first from his room. He was in a most elegant hunting	477.6652084694448
costume; and Monsieur and the other nobles were dressed like him. This	431.72653916531453
was the costume that best became the king. So dressed, he really	344.24164682240007
appeared the first gentleman of his kingdom.	341.7050592188036
The cardinal drew near to the king, and placed in his hand a small	481.74249007847595
casket. The king opened it, and found in it two diamond studs.	417.2783852514532
“What does this mean?” demanded he of the cardinal.	472.7244686778653
“Nothing,” replied the latter; “only, if the queen has the studs, which	304.48701175913897
I very much doubt, count them, sire, and if you only find ten, ask her	425.01970166083345
Majesty who can have stolen from her the two studs that are here.”	397.07562778740055
The king looked at the cardinal as if to interrogate him; but he had	310.5162149933797
not time to address any question to him—a cry of admiration burst from	380.0256422212158
every mouth. If the king appeared to be the first gentleman of his	374.69723740357307
kingdom, the queen was without doubt the most beautiful woman in	394.8272652489484
France.	469.008530804691
It is true that the habit of a huntress became her admirably. She wore	370.7696160848431
a beaver hat with blue feathers, a surtout of gray-pearl velvet,	317.07959678333526
fastened with diamond clasps, and a petticoat of blue satin,	395.0949423460089
embroidered with silver. On her left shoulder sparkled the diamond	321.86191889977255
studs, on a bow of the same color as the plumes and the petticoat.	395.20881688377517
The king trembled with joy and the cardinal with vexation; although,	442.528270833449
distant as they were from the queen, they could not count the studs.	313.2802116861844
The queen had them. The only question was, had she ten or twelve?	391.95976124764
At that moment the violins sounded the signal for the ballet. The king	428.71843933203706
advanced toward Madame the President, with whom he was to dance, and	303.8818180552008
his Highness Monsieur with the queen. They took their places, and the	295.9119468893866
ballet began.	462.20835262204895
The king danced facing the queen, and every time he passed by her, he	422.78366779434515
devoured with his eyes those studs of which he could not ascertain the	363.5259734025041
number. A cold sweat covered the brow of the cardinal.	390.08516529637996
The ballet lasted an hour, and had sixteen _entrées_. The ballet ended	346.470240704272
amid the applause of the whole assemblage, and everyone reconducted his	475.53280099519526
lady to her place; but the king took advantage of the privilege he had	330.2474951896938
of leaving his lady, to advance eagerly toward the queen.	418.4207006651095
“I thank you, madame,” said he, “for the deference you have shown to my	297.8732382865419
wishes, but I think you want two of the studs, and I bring them back to	334.9702630078567
you.”	421.717025511255
With these words he held out to the queen the two studs the cardinal	378.5619053561677
had given him.	454.4128513368653
“How, sire?” cried the young queen, affecting surprise, “you are giving	379.75534347963304
me, then, two more: I shall have fourteen.”	408.7073532493392
In fact the king counted them, and the twelve studs were all on her	437.30286502991225
Majesty’s shoulder.	377.685824855451
The king called the cardinal.	480.58962556880203
“What does this mean, Monsieur Cardinal?” asked the king in a severe	304.03814745183007
tone.	294.73761478366043
“This means, sire,” replied the cardinal, “that I was desirous of	311.3758877730169
presenting her Majesty with these two studs, and that not daring to	485.9493296433291
offer them myself, I adopted this means of inducing her to accept	301.4230997738011
them.”	380.37320750705857
“And I am the more grateful to your Eminence,” replied Anne of Austria,	311.7396431240831
with a smile that proved she was not the dupe of this ingenious	315.36980779232954
gallantry, “from being certain that these two studs alone have cost you	322.16752872365123
as much as all the others cost his Majesty.”	412.31691179786424
Then saluting the king and the cardinal, the queen resumed her way to	455.07774377328917
the chamber in which she had dressed, and where she was to take off her	456.1390839057043
costume.	453.57505502244277
The attention which we have been obliged to give, during the	301.3717367893485
commencement of the chapter, to the illustrious personages we have	319.82712116451773
introduced into it, has diverted us for an instant from him to whom	345.48041162571536
Anne of Austria owed the extraordinary triumph she had obtained over	325.39229479099555
the cardinal; and who, confounded, unknown, lost in the crowd gathered	449.30447314702224
at one of the doors, looked on at this scene, comprehensible only to	296.4285585185712
four persons—the king, the queen, his Eminence, and himself.	312.71372688145556
The queen had just regained her chamber, and D’Artagnan was about to	355.48880494694527
retire, when he felt his shoulder lightly touched. He turned and saw a	451.400614051611
young woman, who made him a sign to follow her. The face of this young	442.08929755391864
woman was covered with a black velvet mask; but notwithstanding this	370.0312460689919
precaution, which was in fact taken rather against others than against	314.20813399971144
him, he at once recognized his usual guide, the light and intelligent	464.30702015883264
Mme. Bonacieux.	296.99458281029035
On the evening before, they had scarcely seen each other for a moment	371.43661037269345
at the apartment of the Swiss guard, Germain, whither D’Artagnan had	299.81986508733365
sent for her. The haste which the young woman was in to convey to the	424.3510443608018
queen the excellent news of the happy return of her messenger prevented	388.4207821961183
the two lovers from exchanging more than a few words. D’Artagnan	397.9554947419826
therefore followed Mme. Bonacieux moved by a double sentiment—love and	295.70832415831563
curiosity. All the way, and in proportion as the corridors became more	306.55138719178603
deserted, D’Artagnan wished to stop the young woman, seize her and gaze	462.6814117993026
upon her, were it only for a minute; but quick as a bird she glided	367.6110965404445
between his hands, and when he wished to speak to her, her finger	485.53875084607876
placed upon her mouth, with a little imperative gesture full of grace,	304.2519292357339
reminded him that he was under the command of a power which he must	296.61447451134
blindly obey, and which forbade him even to make the slightest	424.14175971883884
complaint. At length, after winding about for a minute or two, Mme.	451.73560192393063
Bonacieux opened the door of a closet, which was entirely dark, and led	339.6722966591161
D’Artagnan into it. There she made a fresh sign of silence, and opened	486.98804243007305
a second door concealed by tapestry. The opening of this door disclosed	345.003185593271
a brilliant light, and she disappeared.	469.1331835602791
D’Artagnan remained for a moment motionless, asking himself where he	402.2069309608131
could be; but soon a ray of light which penetrated through the chamber,	300.2030725582427
together with the warm and perfumed air which reached him from the same	331.0603532592104
aperture, the conversation of two of three ladies in language at once	467.05935105723944
respectful and refined, and the word “Majesty” several times repeated,	337.83051289703945
indicated clearly that he was in a closet attached to the queen’s	425.95438626607034
apartment. The young man waited in comparative darkness and listened.	357.58503392594
The queen appeared cheerful and happy, which seemed to astonish the	351.1104169691483
persons who surrounded her and who were accustomed to see her almost	457.82768993778956
always sad and full of care. The queen attributed this joyous feeling	346.3547500762791
to the beauty of the fête, to the pleasure she had experienced in the	336.6954679888557
ballet; and as it is not permissible to contradict a queen, whether she	341.3624421122244
smile or weep, everybody expatiated on the gallantry of the aldermen of	399.57702026425534
the city of Paris.	385.16142529196213
Although D’Artagnan did not at all know the queen, he soon	393.74470188307527
distinguished her voice from the others, at first by a slightly foreign	430.20129068624806
accent, and next by that tone of domination naturally impressed upon	331.7739174596144
all royal words. He heard her approach and withdraw from the partially	369.939666056717
open door; and twice or three times he even saw the shadow of a person	444.057278434326
intercept the light.	411.19362903303033
At length a hand and an arm, surpassingly beautiful in their form and	441.7676769083498
whiteness, glided through the tapestry. D’Artagnan at once comprehended	483.0405557814853
that this was his recompense. He cast himself on his knees, seized the	351.0906371837101
hand, and touched it respectfully with his lips. Then the hand was	461.434349964504
withdrawn, leaving in his an object which he perceived to be a ring.	341.3002274251343
The door immediately closed, and D’Artagnan found himself again in	440.46624519645513
complete obscurity.	315.36957564953116
D’Artagnan placed the ring on his finger, and again waited; it was	312.0736600035733
evident that all was not yet over. After the reward of his devotion,	462.5980926723526
that of his love was to come. Besides, although the ballet was danced,	463.283334820689
the evening had scarcely begun. Supper was to be served at three, and	366.38166527966496
the clock of St. Jean had struck three quarters past two.	345.82847823760756
The sound of voices diminished by degrees in the adjoining chamber. The	459.77297230102243
company was then heard departing; then the door of the closet in which	338.9346349424764
D’Artagnan was, was opened, and Mme. Bonacieux entered.	402.1567140398535
“You at last?” cried D’Artagnan.	399.1034864952741
“Silence!” said the young woman, placing her hand upon his lips;	365.7934359119055
“silence, and go the same way you came!”	384.78217420043364
“But where and when shall I see you again?” cried D’Artagnan.	300.10573851661144
“A note which you will find at home will tell you. Begone, begone!”	293.01699404881515
At these words she opened the door of the corridor, and pushed	412.8243210586594
D’Artagnan out of the room. D’Artagnan obeyed like a child, without the	447.8712091691491
least resistance or objection, which proved that he was really in love.	338.13522448436106
Chapter XXIII.	353.55117555779543
THE RENDEZVOUS	473.1891671501638
D’Artagnan ran home immediately, and although it was three o’clock in	409.2212108422571
the morning and he had some of the worst quarters of Paris to traverse,	467.70062319214276
he met with no misadventure. Everyone knows that drunkards and lovers	304.7852463386099
have a protecting deity.	460.4072413851113
He found the door of his passage open, sprang up the stairs and knocked	414.807943968658
softly in a manner agreed upon between him and his lackey. Planchet*,	339.7897337463408
whom he had sent home two hours before from the Hôtel de Ville, telling	464.7407398527952
him to sit up for him, opened the door for him.	367.8194498811522
* The reader may ask, “How came Planchet here?” when he was left “stiff	433.36998118028527
as a rush” in London. In the intervening time Buckingham perhaps sent	440.36325177039896
him to Paris, as he did the horses.	479.2483107091122
“Has anyone brought a letter for me?” asked D’Artagnan, eagerly.	471.7774727431405
“No one has _brought_ a letter, monsieur,” replied Planchet; “but one	404.26386705632433
has come of itself.”	479.6821191241414
“What do you mean, blockhead?”	328.1691343859637
“I mean to say that when I came in, although I had the key of your	360.1833867751758
apartment in my pocket, and that key had never quit me, I found a	486.7255591329875
letter on the green table cover in your bedroom.”	387.4473436392978
“And where is that letter?”	417.02671841251623
“I left it where I found it, monsieur. It is not natural for letters to	371.2179120480033
enter people’s houses in this manner. If the window had been open or	432.21320686785714
even ajar, I should think nothing of it; but, no—all was hermetically	306.00931885983476
sealed. Beware, monsieur; there is certainly some magic underneath.”	434.1232312124821
Meanwhile, the young man had darted in to his chamber, and opened the	295.33578939311917
letter. It was from Mme. Bonacieux, and was expressed in these terms:	466.5822279082452
“There are many thanks to be offered to you, and to be transmitted to	476.7054987957978
you. Be this evening about ten o’clock at St. Cloud, in front of the	371.0113975870911
pavilion which stands at the corner of the house of M. d’Estrées.—C.B.”	389.13517045580056
While reading this letter, D’Artagnan felt his heart dilated and	428.9475859071024
compressed by that delicious spasm which tortures and caresses the	447.69614049249526
hearts of lovers.	480.32384440097246
It was the first billet he had received; it was the first rendezvous	369.75005967070956
that had been granted him. His heart, swelled by the intoxication of	445.58502639069627
joy, felt ready to dissolve away at the very gate of that terrestrial	396.1427381213547
paradise called Love!	483.72881284895595
“Well, monsieur,” said Planchet, who had observed his master grow red	360.8344438938901
and pale successively, “did I not guess truly? Is it not some bad	434.98988233351207
affair?”	424.21912623787347
“You are mistaken, Planchet,” replied D’Artagnan; “and as a proof,	366.7451369124504
there is a crown to drink my health.”	317.8963035172791
“I am much obliged to Monsieur for the crown he has given me, and I	391.2850175628522
promise him to follow his instructions exactly; but it is not the less	374.0841717210199
true that letters which come in this way into shut-up houses—”	349.8976305165596
“Fall from heaven, my friend, fall from heaven.”	401.1052999858309
“Then Monsieur is satisfied?” asked Planchet.	321.368739579288
“My dear Planchet, I am the happiest of men!”	491.9734039812075
“And I may profit by Monsieur’s happiness, and go to bed?”	466.3138664463949
“Yes, go.”	478.4221214623044
“May the blessings of heaven fall upon Monsieur! But it is not the less	349.7501985546478
true that that letter—”	440.2854910853373
And Planchet retired, shaking his head with an air of doubt, which the	480.09910297752134
liberality of D’Artagnan had not entirely effaced.	465.53578904051835
Left alone, D’Artagnan read and reread his billet. Then he kissed and	466.3302985313227
rekissed twenty times the lines traced by the hand of his beautiful	350.51626596940423
mistress. At length he went to bed, fell asleep, and had golden dreams.	321.2427037221367
At seven o’clock in the morning he arose and called Planchet, who at	429.7827654562384
the second summons opened the door, his countenance not yet quite freed	340.3370567755007
from the anxiety of the preceding night.	399.90723649733013
“Planchet,” said D’Artagnan, “I am going out for all day, perhaps. You	395.30921214536323
are, therefore, your own master till seven o’clock in the evening; but	314.7533536685875
at seven o’clock you must hold yourself in readiness with two horses.”	356.69583996764425
“There!” said Planchet. “We are going again, it appears, to have our	311.76232261035517
hides pierced in all sorts of ways.”	441.8105654186031
“You will take your musketoon and your pistols.”	433.2867730920811
“There, now! Didn’t I say so?” cried Planchet. “I was sure of it—the	417.22554641799604
cursed letter!”	397.3927162498499
“Don’t be afraid, you idiot; there is nothing in hand but a party of	381.2435543379818
pleasure.”	399.32133761022413
“Ah, like the charming journey the other day, when it rained bullets	326.7135269860737
and produced a crop of steel traps!”	469.1525519788763
“Well, if you are really afraid, Monsieur Planchet,” resumed	318.85184666435265
D’Artagnan, “I will go without you. I prefer traveling alone to having	334.4344928388383
a companion who entertains the least fear.”	475.02081587518796
“Monsieur does me wrong,” said Planchet; “I thought he had seen me at	484.4932325579447
work.”	354.92437408776254
“Yes, but I thought perhaps you had worn out all your courage the first	379.77181600793045
time.”	471.78337839662555
“Monsieur shall see that upon occasion I have some left; only I beg	485.4817311643318
Monsieur not to be too prodigal of it if he wishes it to last long.”	428.6800459959434
“Do you believe you have still a certain amount of it to expend this	350.88536757582125
evening?”	315.51133464887334
“I hope so, monsieur.”	396.61645925715237
“Well, then, I count on you.”	425.0308065709274
“At the appointed hour I shall be ready; only I believed that Monsieur	437.08020022511175
had but one horse in the Guard stables.”	294.24068272724696
“Perhaps there is but one at this moment; but by this evening there	350.27363326592433
will be four.”	472.7807811201508
