“It appears that our journey was a remounting journey, then?”	468.89099856803466
“Exactly so,” said D’Artagnan; and nodding to Planchet, he went out.	411.60144942142483
M. Bonacieux was at his door. D’Artagnan’s intention was to go out	420.59899842671035
without speaking to the worthy mercer; but the latter made so polite	468.65069982021686
and friendly a salutation that his tenant felt obliged, not only to	400.8725179470284
stop, but to enter into conversation with him.	483.345100763833
Besides, how is it possible to avoid a little condescension toward a	340.78872523897206
husband whose pretty wife has appointed a meeting with you that same	309.33903545742385
evening at St. Cloud, opposite D’Estrées’s pavilion? D’Artagnan	387.1509069494052
approached him with the most amiable air he could assume.	320.8511593991917
The conversation naturally fell upon the incarceration of the poor man.	408.96309852484325
M. Bonacieux, who was ignorant that D’Artagnan had overheard his	384.44386197561585
conversation with the stranger of Meung, related to his young tenant	304.21419568735496
the persecutions of that monster, M. de Laffemas, whom he never ceased	326.7286118389639
to designate, during his account, by the title of the “cardinal’s	387.1279924672722
executioner,” and expatiated at great length upon the Bastille, the	306.07973211165796
bolts, the wickets, the dungeons, the gratings, the instruments of	430.0330506340518
torture.	485.12851951260257
D’Artagnan listened to him with exemplary complaisance, and when he had	401.1581586734719
finished said, “And Madame Bonacieux, do you know who carried her	329.4525513926422
off?—For I do not forget that I owe to that unpleasant circumstance the	307.2686215612271
good fortune of having made your acquaintance.”	370.44278302648996
“Ah!” said Bonacieux, “they took good care not to tell me that; and my	327.36703340208214
wife, on her part, has sworn to me by all that’s sacred that she does	435.61928659520237
not know. But you,” continued M. Bonacieux, in a tone of perfect good	461.63700431167126
fellowship, “what has become of you all these days? I have not seen you	386.57951797401245
nor your friends, and I don’t think you could gather all that dust that	432.89900450224064
I saw Planchet brush off your boots yesterday from the pavement of	295.96709438538693
Paris.”	375.3544901946309
“You are right, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, my friends and I have been	390.3641581879635
on a little journey.”	480.47106476804777
“Far from here?”	305.124681050181
“Oh, Lord, no! About forty leagues only. We went to take Monsieur Athos	300.9688027906114
to the waters of Forges, where my friends still remain.”	472.6807958281226
“And you have returned, have you not?” replied M. Bonacieux, giving to	457.9165802957957
his countenance a most sly air. “A handsome young fellow like you does	398.83195684805867
not obtain long leaves of absence from his mistress; and we were	363.92032900106983
impatiently waited for at Paris, were we not?”	461.7076425320697
“My faith!” said the young man, laughing, “I confess it, and so much	382.9178571984535
more the readily, my dear Bonacieux, as I see there is no concealing	400.80783291123834
anything from you. Yes, I was expected, and very impatiently, I	441.822540286513
acknowledge.”	431.00585748392155
A slight shade passed over the brow of Bonacieux, but so slight that	333.2126041212962
D’Artagnan did not perceive it.	343.6059992963951
“And we are going to be recompensed for our diligence?” continued the	384.43008432243613
mercer, with a trifling alteration in his voice—so trifling, indeed,	416.23083304374904
that D’Artagnan did not perceive it any more than he had the momentary	420.5099186709956
shade which, an instant before, had darkened the countenance of the	340.092789369397
worthy man.	375.17389548860683
“Ah, may you be a true prophet!” said D’Artagnan, laughing.	467.1833799576278
“No; what I say,” replied Bonacieux, “is only that I may know whether I	312.05582373322164
am delaying you.”	459.8234430274082
“Why that question, my dear host?” asked D’Artagnan. “Do you intend to	441.91272103813117
sit up for me?”	435.07501637943466
“No; but since my arrest and the robbery that was committed in my	407.0597669315318
house, I am alarmed every time I hear a door open, particularly in the	408.6970824848849
night. What the deuce can you expect? I am no swordsman.”	489.0512261097331
“Well, don’t be alarmed if I return at one, two or three o’clock in the	352.90037587533885
morning; indeed, do not be alarmed if I do not come at all.”	300.6515769620504
This time Bonacieux became so pale that D’Artagnan could not help	442.8639320343645
perceiving it, and asked him what was the matter.	323.0725440912775
“Nothing,” replied Bonacieux, “nothing. Since my misfortunes I have	361.79207330221607
been subject to faintnesses, which seize me all at once, and I have	396.7004400360117
just felt a cold shiver. Pay no attention to it; you have nothing to	407.40450370051207
occupy yourself with but being happy.”	379.2066416875128
“Then I have full occupation, for I am so.”	488.7076931461705
“Not yet; wait a little! This evening, you said.”	393.72783907096124
“Well, this evening will come, thank God! And perhaps you look for it	296.14113416602584
with as much impatience as I do; perhaps this evening Madame Bonacieux	330.9119923727345
will visit the conjugal domicile.”	319.00186809919137
“Madame Bonacieux is not at liberty this evening,” replied the husband,	480.9699531675152
seriously; “she is detained at the Louvre this evening by her duties.”	342.2546593142603
“So much the worse for you, my dear host, so much the worse! When I am	338.48283348086295
happy, I wish all the world to be so; but it appears that is not	430.88874924871095
possible.”	444.5212628074764
The young man departed, laughing at the joke, which he thought he alone	344.6863261145835
could comprehend.	308.610635215987
“Amuse yourself well!” replied Bonacieux, in a sepulchral tone.	323.3278778096878
But D’Artagnan was too far off to hear him; and if he had heard him in	336.957712860988
the disposition of mind he then enjoyed, he certainly would not have	293.384324823887
remarked it.	343.0459170265314
He took his way toward the hôtel of M. de Tréville; his visit of the	366.8638769612804
day before, it is to be remembered, had been very short and very little	372.3293589311627
explicative.	480.9768821798838
He found Tréville in a joyful mood. He had thought the king and queen	395.3962611164478
charming at the ball. It is true the cardinal had been particularly	424.3523030221614
ill-tempered. He had retired at one o’clock under the pretense of being	395.37538012244096
indisposed. As to their Majesties, they did not return to the Louvre	337.96609632407166
till six o’clock in the morning.	350.95433436617475
“Now,” said Tréville, lowering his voice, and looking into every corner	341.10855130960795
of the apartment to see if they were alone, “now let us talk about	328.92517770030304
yourself, my young friend; for it is evident that your happy return has	444.410865368058
something to do with the joy of the king, the triumph of the queen, and	299.06294505055024
the humiliation of his Eminence. You must look out for yourself.”	308.0101206479836
“What have I to fear,” replied D’Artagnan, “as long as I shall have the	490.16529861272966
luck to enjoy the favor of their Majesties?”	445.05961399755654
“Everything, believe me. The cardinal is not the man to forget a	295.39387135723507
mystification until he has settled account with the mystifier; and the	326.5246465784497
mystifier appears to me to have the air of being a certain young Gascon	328.4657770739557
of my acquaintance.”	398.38156605471625
“Do you believe that the cardinal is as well posted as yourself, and	379.3805337951395
knows that I have been to London?”	299.30364135544744
“The devil! You have been to London! Was it from London you brought	478.1065854938912
that beautiful diamond that glitters on your finger? Beware, my dear	374.4835557059964
D’Artagnan! A present from an enemy is not a good thing. Are there not	388.5298369025093
some Latin verses upon that subject? Stop!”	350.1241630534879
“Yes, doubtless,” replied D’Artagnan, who had never been able to cram	388.54001878685455
the first rudiments of that language into his head, and who had by his	464.049423900908
ignorance driven his master to despair, “yes, doubtless there is one.”	375.4624250473755
“There certainly is one,” said M. de Tréville, who had a tincture of	474.5983049940859
literature, “and Monsieur de Benserade was quoting it to me the other	481.40003107555606
day. Stop a minute—ah, this is it: ‘Timeo Danaos et dona ferentes,’	304.01700818553184
which means, ‘Beware of the enemy who makes you presents.”	333.3614462137062
“This diamond does not come from an enemy, monsieur,” replied	430.32805830265323
D’Artagnan, “it comes from the queen.”	328.3017132486386
“From the queen! Oh, oh!” said M. de Tréville. “Why, it is indeed a	416.3418508943802
true royal jewel, which is worth a thousand pistoles if it is worth a	395.497886882119
denier. By whom did the queen send you this jewel?”	311.14431764198366
“She gave it to me herself.”	394.3058630062298
“Where?”	429.187196805369
“In the room adjoining the chamber in which she changed her toilet.”	335.59062524409353
“How?”	448.53617657418505
“Giving me her hand to kiss.”	458.5632933139402
“You have kissed the queen’s hand?” said M. de Tréville, looking	329.6085057355972
earnestly at D’Artagnan.	360.6933794271704
“Her Majesty did me the honor to grant me that favor.”	316.0117856590813
“And that in the presence of witnesses! Imprudent, thrice imprudent!”	328.9854866329785
“No, monsieur, be satisfied; nobody saw her,” replied D’Artagnan, and	470.8610617796064
he related to M. de Tréville how the affair came to pass.	400.6193440109106
“Oh, the women, the women!” cried the old soldier. “I know them by	465.17940007680704
their romantic imagination. Everything that savors of mystery charms	394.6237257489646
them. So you have seen the arm, that was all. You would meet the queen,	396.15536525019843
and she would not know who you are?”	377.3454823707191
“No; but thanks to this diamond,” replied the young man.	372.3868985803451
“Listen,” said M. de Tréville; “shall I give you counsel, good counsel,	479.1049827422071
the counsel of a friend?”	445.7543640098181
“You will do me honor, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan.	425.3869144476681
“Well, then, off to the nearest goldsmith’s, and sell that diamond for	361.2912592912992
the highest price you can get from him. However much of a Jew he may	419.32184654924504
be, he will give you at least eight hundred pistoles. Pistoles have no	343.7087906098069
name, young man, and that ring has a terrible one, which may betray him	474.91351707672607
who wears it.”	334.68148580192
“Sell this ring, a ring which comes from my sovereign? Never!” said	472.10860791385767
D’Artagnan.	332.4468201002539
“Then, at least turn the gem inside, you silly fellow; for everybody	452.9212599092441
must be aware that a cadet from Gascony does not find such stones in	386.2616361427167
his mother’s jewel case.”	435.66767585647176
“You think, then, I have something to dread?” asked D’Artagnan.	486.46692621247075
“I mean to say, young man, that he who sleeps over a mine the match of	490.0426867991704
which is already lighted, may consider himself in safety in comparison	409.6891517851045
with you.”	313.9216069823445
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan, whom the positive tone of M. de Tréville	328.11000408494823
began to disquiet, “the devil! What must I do?”	298.900352755206
“Above all things be always on your guard. The cardinal has a tenacious	443.8471698212561
memory and a long arm; you may depend upon it, he will repay you by	391.66117493148454
some ill turn.”	402.1394367315637
“But of what sort?”	360.38199290066694
“Eh! How can I tell? Has he not all the tricks of a demon at his	423.8486473671694
command? The least that can be expected is that you will be arrested.”	462.8440266577427
“What! Will they dare to arrest a man in his Majesty’s service?”	408.0220633151231
“_Pardieu!_ They did not scruple much in the case of Athos. At all	424.7732047115958
events, young man, rely upon one who has been thirty years at court. Do	457.8636184275698
not lull yourself in security, or you will be lost; but, on the	321.3470202679974
contrary—and it is I who say it—see enemies in all directions. If	307.58585874728175
anyone seeks a quarrel with you, shun it, were it with a child of ten	322.88238908720336
years old. If you are attacked by day or by night, fight, but retreat,	463.7490908459034
without shame; if you cross a bridge, feel every plank of it with your	383.39047080864214
foot, lest one should give way beneath you; if you pass before a house	354.81068195005605
which is being built, look up, for fear a stone should fall upon your	429.88766857631117
head; if you stay out late, be always followed by your lackey, and let	326.99006867078845
your lackey be armed—if, by the by, you can be sure of your lackey.	362.4029458671474
Mistrust everybody, your friend, your brother, your mistress—your	400.2686674462622
mistress above all.”	342.4512142635942
D’Artagnan blushed.	397.85561320629483
“My mistress above all,” repeated he, mechanically; “and why her rather	399.27388803880666
than another?”	451.924490167921
“Because a mistress is one of the cardinal’s favorite means; he has not	339.2651329515324
one that is more expeditious. A woman will sell you for ten pistoles,	471.77054540252544
witness Delilah. You are acquainted with the Scriptures?”	332.42704162350947
D’Artagnan thought of the appointment Mme. Bonacieux had made with him	366.4617606877597
for that very evening; but we are bound to say, to the credit of our	450.73028585648126
hero, that the bad opinion entertained by M. de Tréville of women in	423.66059570861273
general, did not inspire him with the least suspicion of his pretty	335.09496629378884
hostess.	363.94800372063776
“But, _à propos_,” resumed M. de Tréville, “what has become of your	366.98429542384747
three companions?”	463.84572639247733
“I was about to ask you if you had heard any news of them?”	330.42982056653625
“None, monsieur.”	422.06778979412513
“Well, I left them on my road—Porthos at Chantilly, with a duel on his	476.4982628604489
hands; Aramis at Crèvecœur, with a ball in his shoulder; and Athos at	353.3060047939218
Amiens, detained by an accusation of coining.”	466.2253546187105
“See there, now!” said M. de Tréville; “and how the devil did you	401.80132292340386
escape?”	424.6436018078644
“By a miracle, monsieur, I must acknowledge, with a sword thrust in my	440.1219730223644
breast, and by nailing the Comte de Wardes on the byroad to Calais,	480.9658687340807
like a butterfly on a tapestry.”	451.28661078426336
“There again! De Wardes, one of the cardinal’s men, a cousin of	323.5108020045699
Rochefort! Stop, my friend, I have an idea.”	468.5876376123208
“Speak, monsieur.”	392.44315912474383
“In your place, I would do one thing.”	415.7444558202692
“What?”	458.3442789889132
“While his Eminence was seeking for me in Paris, I would take, without	363.4169570716472
sound of drum or trumpet, the road to Picardy, and would go and make	300.6892965228276
some inquiries concerning my three companions. What the devil! They	450.97276162266905
merit richly that piece of attention on your part.”	463.02991929231655
“The advice is good, monsieur, and tomorrow I will set out.”	441.28378210356675
“Tomorrow! Any why not this evening?”	411.4706366032019
“This evening, monsieur, I am detained in Paris by indispensable	372.10685036039547
business.”	375.1455171684585
“Ah, young man, young man, some flirtation or other. Take care, I	376.8025571335085
repeat to you, take care. It is woman who has ruined us, still ruins	474.7142182982418
us, and will ruin us, as long as the world stands. Take my advice and	364.663905786447
set out this evening.”	320.15716698329436
“Impossible, monsieur.”	320.7796357935425
“You have given your word, then?”	401.4378712776676
“Yes, monsieur.”	308.3334428061117
“Ah, that’s quite another thing; but promise me, if you should not be	406.921044151315
killed tonight, that you will go tomorrow.”	353.0327639991067
“I promise it.”	416.7736873842768
“Do you need money?”	334.1727043557932
“I have still fifty pistoles. That, I think, is as much as I shall	442.7018335515693
want.”	470.9094210547176
“But your companions?”	367.2110012474022
“I don’t think they can be in need of any. We left Paris, each with	403.0389538520652
seventy-five pistoles in his pocket.”	398.84108546967656
“Shall I see you again before your departure?”	356.62255818931567
“I think not, monsieur, unless something new should happen.”	344.38354720322184
“Well, a pleasant journey.”	332.2050087791716
“Thanks, monsieur.”	487.42656149931804
D’Artagnan left M. de Tréville, touched more than ever by his paternal	398.361360736174
solicitude for his Musketeers.	482.33795174681825
He called successively at the abodes of Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.	443.1718734170911
Neither of them had returned. Their lackeys likewise were absent, and	293.93043162916416
nothing had been heard of either the one or the other. He would have	371.5685300933909
inquired after them of their mistresses, but he was neither acquainted	318.44723752299785
with Porthos’s nor Aramis’s, and as to Athos, he had none.	299.3641623038571
As he passed the Hôtel des Gardes, he took a glance into the stables.	403.3166133947914
Three of the four horses had already arrived. Planchet, all	463.62903920463714
astonishment, was busy grooming them, and had already finished two.	421.8672596658358
“Ah, monsieur,” said Planchet, on perceiving D’Artagnan, “how glad I am	449.57562389231913
to see you.”	355.5534658017318
“Why so, Planchet?” asked the young man.	478.8439348375915
“Do you place confidence in our landlord—Monsieur Bonacieux?”	326.2086427046424
“I? Not the least in the world.”	331.4530598066962
“Oh, you do quite right, monsieur.”	376.46086782673393
“But why this question?”	465.15586936948085
“Because, while you were talking with him, I watched you without	317.01662854494816
listening to you; and, monsieur, his countenance changed color two or	452.2655663024623
three times!”	337.19182907969844
“Bah!”	471.9358201054366
“Preoccupied as Monsieur was with the letter he had received, he did	410.8258939694422
not observe that; but I, whom the strange fashion in which that letter	448.21630747561926
came into the house had placed on my guard—I did not lose a movement of	408.08041363239954
his features.”	440.5108855440808
“And you found it?”	404.281950649289
“Traitorous, monsieur.”	465.1577291276168
“Indeed!”	293.6181107120974
“Still more; as soon as Monsieur had left and disappeared round the	486.29557494173474
corner of the street, Monsieur Bonacieux took his hat, shut his door,	488.65370870555046
and set off at a quick pace in an opposite direction.”	367.335268453281
“It seems you are right, Planchet; all this appears to be a little	382.2089191852415
mysterious; and be assured that we will not pay him our rent until the	374.05672118855074
matter shall be categorically explained to us.”	307.12134215290115
“Monsieur jests, but Monsieur will see.”	407.1980133691044
“What would you have, Planchet? What must come is written.”	416.393897532875
“Monsieur does not then renounce his excursion for this evening?”	296.46605040090304
“Quite the contrary, Planchet; the more ill will I have toward Monsieur	297.1161900207455
Bonacieux, the more punctual I shall be in keeping the appointment made	417.8249041955748
by that letter which makes you so uneasy.”	383.5934153080127
“Then that is Monsieur’s determination?”	442.738866270435
“Undeniably, my friend. At nine o’clock, then, be ready here at the	311.08481622883806
hôtel, I will come and take you.”	346.57851717419544
Planchet seeing there was no longer any hope of making his master	483.06368745197926
renounce his project, heaved a profound sigh and set to work to groom	487.52018882209836
the third horse.	420.1001952633661
As to D’Artagnan, being at bottom a prudent youth, instead of returning	419.80173437598455
home, went and dined with the Gascon priest, who, at the time of the	475.74368938788183
distress of the four friends, had given them a breakfast of chocolate.	469.4341356255478
Chapter XXIV.	315.1644250560194
THE PAVILION	379.69158164012174
At nine o’clock D’Artagnan was at the Hôtel des Gardes; he found	383.4354062654891
Planchet all ready. The fourth horse had arrived.	403.50646872868487
Planchet was armed with his musketoon and a pistol. D’Artagnan had his	327.5299887056839
sword and placed two pistols in his belt; then both mounted and	323.574275935544
departed quietly. It was quite dark, and no one saw them go out.	313.43806615762657
Planchet took place behind his master, and kept at a distance of ten	328.6278367505287
paces from him.	414.9775007486271
D’Artagnan crossed the quays, went out by the gate of La Conférence and	437.64315709224127
followed the road, much more beautiful then than it is now, which leads	301.6317699540827
to St. Cloud.	451.6946732322875
As long as he was in the city, Planchet kept at the respectful distance	379.46789082529006
he had imposed upon himself; but as soon as the road began to be more	474.16055916753953
lonely and dark, he drew softly nearer, so that when they entered the	396.8037129424772
Bois de Boulogne he found himself riding quite naturally side by side	461.9461653808513
with his master. In fact, we must not dissemble that the oscillation of	335.87832829652143
the tall trees and the reflection of the moon in the dark underwood	305.50043972063844
gave him serious uneasiness. D’Artagnan could not help perceiving that	309.41410519541364
something more than usual was passing in the mind of his lackey and	488.71098789453333
said, “Well, Monsieur Planchet, what is the matter with us now?”	363.01030359721665
“Don’t you think, monsieur, that woods are like churches?”	295.36296681172445
“How so, Planchet?”	445.81015600238095
“Because we dare not speak aloud in one or the other.”	303.49733417938637
“But why did you not dare to speak aloud, Planchet—because you are	459.6141795629121
afraid?”	357.66460447950783
“Afraid of being heard? Yes, monsieur.”	321.2818541945365
“Afraid of being heard! Why, there is nothing improper in our	481.9064239490741
conversation, my dear Planchet, and no one could find fault with it.”	394.7521699755348
“Ah, monsieur!” replied Planchet, recurring to his besetting idea,	359.4952594322306
“that Monsieur Bonacieux has something vicious in his eyebrows, and	335.4409979814347
something very unpleasant in the play of his lips.”	344.3634608080785
“What the devil makes you think of Bonacieux?”	440.34922642362653
“Monsieur, we think of what we can, and not of what we will.”	300.3838969258972
“Because you are a coward, Planchet.”	367.61804324530124
“Monsieur, we must not confound prudence with cowardice; prudence is a	323.05572017384486
virtue.”	314.50839694756075
“And you are very virtuous, are you not, Planchet?”	392.56194994208545
“Monsieur, is not that the barrel of a musket which glitters yonder?	446.87503536847964
Had we not better lower our heads?”	379.2762709891282
“In truth,” murmured D’Artagnan, to whom M. de Tréville’s	400.9826106977063
recommendation recurred, “this animal will end by making me afraid.”	389.4726219923317
And he put his horse into a trot.	463.4751166284482
Planchet followed the movements of his master as if he had been his	489.9680968143134
shadow, and was soon trotting by his side.	396.93853078978157
“Are we going to continue this pace all night?” asked Planchet.	416.50384035479243
“No; you are at your journey’s end.”	391.42598892558885
“How, monsieur! And you?”	351.7934529846366
“I am going a few steps farther.”	312.9502160778611
“And Monsieur leaves me here alone?”	389.3784929581298
“You are afraid, Planchet?”	466.64605870341893
“No; I only beg leave to observe to Monsieur that the night will be	351.1761240800877
very cold, that chills bring on rheumatism, and that a lackey who has	294.9951484885477
the rheumatism makes but a poor servant, particularly to a master as	467.6117826349664
active as Monsieur.”	338.7213693083024
“Well, if you are cold, Planchet, you can go into one of those cabarets	398.40881086371155
that you see yonder, and be in waiting for me at the door by six	366.1607315108977
o’clock in the morning.”	410.9489087989655
“Monsieur, I have eaten and drunk respectfully the crown you gave me	453.0477090478879
this morning, so that I have not a sou left in case I should be cold.”	491.30834002753704
“Here’s half a pistole. Tomorrow morning.”	461.98272293559114
D’Artagnan sprang from his horse, threw the bridle to Planchet, and	487.43424366487955
departed at a quick pace, folding his cloak around him.	468.3169867587687
“Good Lord, how cold I am!” cried Planchet, as soon as he had lost	419.9986600131145
sight of his master; and in such haste was he to warm himself that he	431.2122524248597
went straight to a house set out with all the attributes of a suburban	446.4804370685182
tavern, and knocked at the door.	335.74035823326545
In the meantime D’Artagnan, who had plunged into a bypath, continued	346.79978047990835
his route and reached St. Cloud; but instead of following the main	491.3318690417798
street he turned behind the château, reached a sort of retired lane,	326.64104637091623
and found himself soon in front of the pavilion named. It was situated	334.24223968321456
in a very private spot. A high wall, at the angle of which was the	396.4303904302632
pavilion, ran along one side of this lane, and on the other was a	343.5031900597328
little garden connected with a poor cottage which was protected by a	352.81244909561946
hedge from passers-by.	335.448893477757
He gained the place appointed, and as no signal had been given him by	403.4681601328715
which to announce his presence, he waited.	358.6590935447374
Not the least noise was to be heard; it might be imagined that he was a	372.4938644028241
hundred miles from the capital. D’Artagnan leaned against the hedge,	447.40172883078833
after having cast a glance behind it. Beyond that hedge, that garden,	361.6811413227531
and that cottage, a dark mist enveloped with its folds that immensity	400.49051422725955
where Paris slept—a vast void from which glittered a few luminous	397.0492788683351
points, the funeral stars of that hell!	318.06636126239084
But for D’Artagnan all aspects were clothed happily, all ideas wore a	473.87214294563273
smile, all shades were diaphanous. The appointed hour was about to	390.38689058642296
strike. In fact, at the end of a few minutes the belfry of St. Cloud	470.98284173419984
let fall slowly ten strokes from its sonorous jaws. There was something	428.3913134504667
melancholy in this brazen voice pouring out its lamentations in the	465.51151865151246
middle of the night; but each of those strokes, which made up the	335.8431561517477
expected hour, vibrated harmoniously to the heart of the young man.	338.00530944244537
His eyes were fixed upon the little pavilion situated at the angle of	308.3835874749724
the wall, of which all the windows were closed with shutters, except	299.35624672630405
one on the first story. Through this window shone a mild light which	310.5107862234144
silvered the foliage of two or three linden trees which formed a group	332.02950017280205
outside the park. There could be no doubt that behind this little	404.42962495912104
window, which threw forth such friendly beams, the pretty Mme.	491.4253930724035
Bonacieux expected him.	398.5281984704796
Wrapped in this sweet idea, D’Artagnan waited half an hour without the	346.23056090237407
least impatience, his eyes fixed upon that charming little abode of	482.40868014231273
which he could perceive a part of the ceiling with its gilded moldings,	330.4756561236148
attesting the elegance of the rest of the apartment.	303.035444841309
The belfry of St. Cloud sounded half past ten.	300.3187436713385
This time, without knowing why, D’Artagnan felt a cold shiver run	330.7666808046211
through his veins. Perhaps the cold began to affect him, and he took a	386.55387370309404
perfectly physical sensation for a moral impression.	433.5694521979194
Then the idea seized him that he had read incorrectly, and that the	407.3350685203379
appointment was for eleven o’clock. He drew near to the window, and	298.8121390232098
placing himself so that a ray of light should fall upon the letter as	306.76008194608147
he held it, he drew it from his pocket and read it again; but he had	339.47308654538153
not been mistaken, the appointment was for ten o’clock. He went and	292.5253477829831
resumed his post, beginning to be rather uneasy at this silence and	393.8769698770661
this solitude.	473.2489256150443
Eleven o’clock sounded.	363.4266900537302
D’Artagnan began now really to fear that something had happened to Mme.	341.48149795119184
Bonacieux. He clapped his hands three times—the ordinary signal of	413.1841891909112
lovers; but nobody replied to him, not even an echo.	391.5764468961778
He then thought, with a touch of vexation, that perhaps the young woman	439.26765345296656
had fallen asleep while waiting for him. He approached the wall, and	339.2786006559084
tried to climb it; but the wall had been recently pointed, and	359.1655016441596
D’Artagnan could get no hold.	464.8534036016748
At that moment he thought of the trees, upon whose leaves the light	339.02803795999654
still shone; and as one of them drooped over the road, he thought that	332.8691931179733
from its branches he might get a glimpse of the interior of the	359.9506624335478
pavilion.	408.41777410522064
The tree was easy to climb. Besides, D’Artagnan was but twenty years	350.0415083323736
old, and consequently had not yet forgotten his schoolboy habits. In an	356.05769080898864
instant he was among the branches, and his keen eyes plunged through	340.27191741939896
the transparent panes into the interior of the pavilion.	392.90432680190077
It was a strange thing, and one which made D’Artagnan tremble from the	314.3603321248478
sole of his foot to the roots of his hair, to find that this soft	370.3212734483529
light, this calm lamp, enlightened a scene of fearful disorder. One of	368.8944657632726
the windows was broken, the door of the chamber had been beaten in and	448.09830180441736
hung, split in two, on its hinges. A table, which had been covered with	351.90011226626814
an elegant supper, was overturned. The decanters broken in pieces, and	363.55102287393635
the fruits crushed, strewed the floor. Everything in the apartment gave	422.2059634618675
evidence of a violent and desperate struggle. D’Artagnan even fancied	369.2483580789176
he could recognize amid this strange disorder, fragments of garments,	448.51401762384796
and some bloody spots staining the cloth and the curtains. He hastened	299.65952035398874
to descend into the street, with a frightful beating at his heart; he	353.6304862884093
wished to see if he could find other traces of violence.	352.9238307528918
The little soft light shone on in the calmness of the night. D’Artagnan	327.32422550888134
then perceived a thing that he had not before remarked—for nothing had	324.45862668461774
led him to the examination—that the ground, trampled here and	468.06135227165646
hoofmarked there, presented confused traces of men and horses. Besides,	348.91826902443586
the wheels of a carriage, which appeared to have come from Paris, had	489.0779494707505
made a deep impression in the soft earth, which did not extend beyond	310.9964213024337
the pavilion, but turned again toward Paris.	436.3475672091739
At length D’Artagnan, in pursuing his researches, found near the wall a	470.61336051063756
woman’s torn glove. This glove, wherever it had not touched the muddy	326.99437082161785
ground, was of irreproachable odor. It was one of those perfumed gloves	409.49144072773356
that lovers like to snatch from a pretty hand.	423.85645792453244
As D’Artagnan pursued his investigations, a more abundant and more icy	365.3628618921314
sweat rolled in large drops from his forehead; his heart was oppressed	398.9146978781638
by a horrible anguish; his respiration was broken and short. And yet he	304.89702543661207
said, to reassure himself, that this pavilion perhaps had nothing in	458.1429712069829
common with Mme. Bonacieux; that the young woman had made an	318.5887658714822
appointment with him before the pavilion, and not in the pavilion; that	337.8056209703251
she might have been detained in Paris by her duties, or perhaps by the	372.08005159796215
jealousy of her husband.	335.9527485903417
But all these reasons were combated, destroyed, overthrown, by that	327.9654805688322
feeling of intimate pain which, on certain occasions, takes possession	428.3146209826541
of our being, and cries to us so as to be understood unmistakably that	439.26975367379964
some great misfortune is hanging over us.	486.65456634762995
Then D’Artagnan became almost wild. He ran along the high road, took	409.7357864605906
the path he had before taken, and reaching the ferry, interrogated the	361.01502064516063
boatman.	432.6355170429963
About seven o’clock in the evening, the boatman had taken over a young	319.7031741871958
woman, wrapped in a black mantle, who appeared to be very anxious not	428.1681552402795
to be recognized; but entirely on account of her precautions, the	423.2367890143248
boatman had paid more attention to her and discovered that she was	416.68025044578565
young and pretty.	400.15610529283083
There were then, as now, a crowd of young and pretty women who came to	292.5773889522208
St. Cloud, and who had reasons for not being seen, and yet D’Artagnan	438.40531376748663
did not for an instant doubt that it was Mme. Bonacieux whom the	408.32676018378106
boatman had noticed.	356.1136602791333
D’Artagnan took advantage of the lamp which burned in the cabin of the	340.61275007566076
ferryman to read the billet of Mme. Bonacieux once again, and satisfy	406.7935418932266
himself that he had not been mistaken, that the appointment was at St.	308.2835905548659
Cloud and not elsewhere, before the D’Estrées’s pavilion and not in	340.38293355036706
another street. Everything conspired to prove to D’Artagnan that his	356.8690219324353
presentiments had not deceived him, and that a great misfortune had	361.0855954160375
happened.	310.96963852987085
He again ran back to the château. It appeared to him that something	477.5450789636995
might have happened at the pavilion in his absence, and that fresh	404.02481237656775
information awaited him. The lane was still deserted, and the same calm	445.53550456234075
soft light shone through the window.	337.77983446751045
D’Artagnan then thought of that cottage, silent and obscure, which had	346.27407803652255
no doubt seen all, and could tell its tale. The gate of the enclosure	473.7625380966956
was shut; but he leaped over the hedge, and in spite of the barking of	365.3978481927779
a chained-up dog, went up to the cabin.	416.8048751803116
No one answered to his first knocking. A silence of death reigned in	405.26786220137853
the cabin as in the pavilion; but as the cabin was his last resource,	306.95481759715557
he knocked again.	396.7539983359825
It soon appeared to him that he heard a slight noise within—a timid	375.55951833703324
noise which seemed to tremble lest it should be heard.	338.613292373856
Then D’Artagnan ceased knocking, and prayed with an accent so full of	378.5715269495922
anxiety and promises, terror and cajolery, that his voice was of a	345.47790872473547
nature to reassure the most fearful. At length an old, worm-eaten	300.9228768294782
shutter was opened, or rather pushed ajar, but closed again as soon as	482.1682928485531
the light from a miserable lamp which burned in the corner had shone	471.9859594166844
upon the baldric, sword belt, and pistol pommels of D’Artagnan.	324.0618192706684
Nevertheless, rapid as the movement had been, D’Artagnan had had time	346.5863364038795
to get a glimpse of the head of an old man.	377.2107369754832
“In the name of heaven!” cried he, “listen to me; I have been waiting	475.0356534524493
for someone who has not come. I am dying with anxiety. Has anything	303.8029952515822
particular happened in the neighborhood? Speak!”	437.03749156843753
The window was again opened slowly, and the same face appeared, only it	475.0781095196451
was now still more pale than before.	450.02909638363303
D’Artagnan related his story simply, with the omission of names. He	394.07811765376266
told how he had a rendezvous with a young woman before that pavilion,	402.02918198056125
and how, not seeing her come, he had climbed the linden tree, and by	419.6718574815816
the light of the lamp had seen the disorder of the chamber.	420.8765113440978
The old man listened attentively, making a sign only that it was all	379.70286943357195
so; and then, when D’Artagnan had ended, he shook his head with an air	353.9816483634212
that announced nothing good.	460.1448206146988
“What do you mean?” cried D’Artagnan. “In the name of heaven, explain	474.14359466282355
yourself!”	323.36572005633656
“Oh! Monsieur,” said the old man, “ask me nothing; for if I dared tell	427.92866612723924
you what I have seen, certainly no good would befall me.”	377.516217479995
“You have, then, seen something?” replied D’Artagnan. “In that case, in	390.4704468967453
the name of heaven,” continued he, throwing him a pistole, “tell me	421.5842486450076
what you have seen, and I will pledge you the word of a gentleman that	328.0261942816934
not one of your words shall escape from my heart.”	408.2717739097409
The old man read so much truth and so much grief in the face of the	397.601969456446
young man that he made him a sign to listen, and repeated in a low	307.268596510436
voice: “It was scarcely nine o’clock when I heard a noise in the	297.89798675389943
street, and was wondering what it could be, when on coming to my door,	481.694235899347
I found that somebody was endeavoring to open it. As I am very poor and	323.0362758120403
am not afraid of being robbed, I went and opened the gate and saw three	420.0536238971778
men at a few paces from it. In the shadow was a carriage with two	385.3251076702013
horses, and some saddlehorses. These horses evidently belonged to the	477.26364125737643
three men, who were dressed as cavaliers. ‘Ah, my worthy gentlemen,’	354.2810340914761
cried I, ‘what do you want?’ ‘You must have a ladder?’ said he who	469.0031235044413
appeared to be the leader of the party. ‘Yes, monsieur, the one with	316.5214135383292
which I gather my fruit.’ ‘Lend it to us, and go into your house again;	411.13398519315876
there is a crown for the annoyance we have caused you. Only remember	487.84788416729805
this—if you speak a word of what you may see or what you may hear (for	467.37018469989476
you will look and you will listen, I am quite sure, however we may	388.1024921287649
threaten you), you are lost.’ At these words he threw me a crown, which	404.4720576789332
I picked up, and he took the ladder. After shutting the gate behind	379.26381814146356
them, I pretended to return to the house, but I immediately went out a	295.50123358626297
back door, and stealing along in the shade of the hedge, I gained	434.97002311921017
yonder clump of elder, from which I could hear and see everything. The	469.7081134906906
three men brought the carriage up quietly, and took out of it a little	355.3325951421817
man, stout, short, elderly, and commonly dressed in clothes of a dark	386.70279626188346
color, who ascended the ladder very carefully, looked suspiciously in	426.1499478312219
at the window of the pavilion, came down as quietly as he had gone up,	321.30375543923594
and whispered, ‘It is she!’ Immediately, he who had spoken to me	462.44381976661623
approached the door of the pavilion, opened it with a key he had in his	373.3225200140738
hand, closed the door and disappeared, while at the same time the other	378.979113475865
two men ascended the ladder. The little old man remained at the coach	309.1388826806663
door; the coachman took care of his horses, the lackey held the	314.6272476270837
saddlehorses. All at once great cries resounded in the pavilion, and a	317.0432078169904
woman came to the window, and opened it, as if to throw herself out of	393.82882480573403
it; but as soon as she perceived the other two men, she fell back and	307.0063298236282
they went into the chamber. Then I saw no more; but I heard the noise	392.08984030851843
of breaking furniture. The woman screamed, and cried for help; but her	324.4153759944201
cries were soon stifled. Two of the men appeared, bearing the woman in	460.9293288708769
their arms, and carried her to the carriage, into which the little old	411.02547513749994
man got after her. The leader closed the window, came out an instant	370.33886997970234
after by the door, and satisfied himself that the woman was in the	465.5306184725278
carriage. His two companions were already on horseback. He sprang into	389.447947511395
his saddle; the lackey took his place by the coachman; the carriage	474.2969329475246
went off at a quick pace, escorted by the three horsemen, and all was	361.9935612237924
over. From that moment I have neither seen nor heard anything.”	409.43420504658263
D’Artagnan, entirely overcome by this terrible story, remained	333.11477543616076
motionless and mute, while all the demons of anger and jealousy were	329.9628623175012
howling in his heart.	421.45330730785463
“But, my good gentleman,” resumed the old man, upon whom this mute	427.23867922644433
despair certainly produced a greater effect than cries and tears would	323.28693205333315
have done, “do not take on so; they did not kill her, and that’s a	389.07224318368503
comfort.”	297.9061350451937
“Can you guess,” said D’Artagnan, “who was the man who headed this	322.9460669525029
infernal expedition?”	379.4272306348243
“I don’t know him.”	419.7712660719818
“But as you spoke to him you must have seen him.”	325.5026086905428
“Oh, it’s a description you want?”	428.49138692350516
“Exactly so.”	317.42792953326705
“A tall, dark man, with black mustaches, dark eyes, and the air of a	368.13460321560007
gentleman.”	298.03742531744945
“That’s the man!” cried D’Artagnan, “again he, forever he! He is my	468.91728395525433
demon, apparently. And the other?”	389.99560731057204
“Which?”	463.25550358025544
“The short one.”	394.08693024371865
“Oh, he was not a gentleman, I’ll answer for it; besides, he did not	355.77951736741795
wear a sword, and the others treated him with small consideration.”	344.7509857454529
“Some lackey,” murmured D’Artagnan. “Poor woman, poor woman, what have	307.803782937418
they done with you?”	318.49805130765776
“You have promised to be secret, my good monsieur?” said the old man.	439.74714369817923
“And I renew my promise. Be easy, I am a gentleman. A gentleman has but	339.30976098788807
his word, and I have given you mine.”	372.3414127987148
With a heavy heart, D’Artagnan again bent his way toward the ferry.	425.11464695387485
Sometimes he hoped it could not be Mme. Bonacieux, and that he should	296.99534856113917
find her next day at the Louvre; sometimes he feared she had had an	383.4692458502213
intrigue with another, who, in a jealous fit, had surprised her and	430.8482441745766
carried her off. His mind was torn by doubt, grief, and despair.	372.080733505583
“Oh, if I had my three friends here,” cried he, “I should have, at	418.0989270685527
least, some hopes of finding her; but who knows what has become of	371.6275553405759
them?”	322.7283079035724
It was past midnight; the next thing was to find Planchet. D’Artagnan	401.77071865558173
went successively into all the cabarets in which there was a light, but	404.8922989103929
could not find Planchet in any of them.	468.3383712139354
At the sixth he began to reflect that the search was rather dubious.	426.17519843247123
D’Artagnan had appointed six o’clock in the morning for his lackey, and	320.44346456257836
wherever he might be, he was right.	389.84991462775645
Besides, it came into the young man’s mind that by remaining in the	304.40853495169085
environs of the spot on which this sad event had passed, he would,	416.1885071979832
perhaps, have some light thrown upon the mysterious affair. At the	465.6486235202759
sixth cabaret, then, as we said, D’Artagnan stopped, asked for a bottle	419.8595514282389
of wine of the best quality, and placing himself in the darkest corner	438.5203399739837
of the room, determined thus to wait till daylight; but this time again	339.7754050177918
his hopes were disappointed, and although he listened with all his	474.8420516756607
ears, he heard nothing, amid the oaths, coarse jokes, and abuse which	459.19376827302676
passed between the laborers, servants, and carters who comprised the	361.0496549462927
honorable society of which he formed a part, which could put him upon	440.7376860466542
the least track of her who had been stolen from him. He was compelled,	467.1156120705629
then, after having swallowed the contents of his bottle, to pass the	440.65393753374974
time as well as to evade suspicion, to fall into the easiest position	431.6217521754878
in his corner and to sleep, whether well or ill. D’Artagnan, be it	439.58442407671305
remembered, was only twenty years old, and at that age sleep has its	308.3809296596778
imprescriptible rights which it imperiously insists upon, even with the	488.9582371818036
saddest hearts.	488.8700307090563
Toward six o’clock D’Artagnan awoke with that uncomfortable feeling	350.28993241906363
which generally accompanies the break of day after a bad night. He was	434.1095303186437
not long in making his toilet. He examined himself to see if advantage	380.2684456591518
had been taken of his sleep, and having found his diamond ring on his	293.0528466159229
finger, his purse in his pocket, and his pistols in his belt, he rose,	378.96296356218403
paid for his bottle, and went out to try if he could have any better	381.7606688319316
luck in his search after his lackey than he had had the night before.	429.47151834988455
The first thing he perceived through the damp gray mist was honest	430.30449872122824
Planchet, who, with the two horses in hand, awaited him at the door of	308.23986878281045
a little blind cabaret, before which D’Artagnan had passed without even	404.3783885721978
a suspicion of its existence.	447.67145448798556
Chapter XXV.	461.1826997462324
PORTHOS	336.84190151254404
Instead of returning directly home, D’Artagnan alighted at the door of	408.14866905734914
M. de Tréville, and ran quickly up the stairs. This time he had decided	322.26319764788855
to relate all that had passed. M. de Tréville would doubtless give him	475.5500638895247
good advice as to the whole affair. Besides, as M. de Tréville saw the	347.3607076584446
queen almost daily, he might be able to draw from her Majesty some	474.9103830063276
intelligence of the poor young woman, whom they were doubtless making	423.4638053137785
pay very dearly for her devotedness to her mistress.	473.02740446715586
M. de Tréville listened to the young man’s account with a seriousness	427.44329183499633
which proved that he saw something else in this adventure besides a	415.168880720019
love affair. When D’Artagnan had finished, he said, “Hum! All this	395.75495901149696
savors of his Eminence, a league off.”	319.15500870030087
“But what is to be done?” said D’Artagnan.	428.6480866394912
“Nothing, absolutely nothing, at present, but quitting Paris, as I told	380.66954896939677
you, as soon as possible. I will see the queen; I will relate to her	368.38760658933387
the details of the disappearance of this poor woman, of which she is no	393.5326437902989
doubt ignorant. These details will guide her on her part, and on your	325.3230833932889
return, I shall perhaps have some good news to tell you. Rely on me.”	471.6162928037853
D’Artagnan knew that, although a Gascon, M. de Tréville was not in the	310.78130726047664
habit of making promises, and that when by chance he did promise, he	448.99324031626674
more than kept his word. He bowed to him, then, full of gratitude for	419.58927794674213
the past and for the future; and the worthy captain, who on his side	413.93435004781685
felt a lively interest in this young man, so brave and so resolute,	412.4344134808082
pressed his hand kindly, wishing him a pleasant journey.	292.58997606458195
Determined to put the advice of M. de Tréville in practice instantly,	376.6064796783254
D’Artagnan directed his course toward the Rue des Fossoyeurs, in order	365.6082204006942
to superintend the packing of his valise. On approaching the house, he	445.3220192739211
perceived M. Bonacieux in morning costume, standing at his threshold.	307.3897924477637
All that the prudent Planchet had said to him the preceding evening	442.8660888539322
about the sinister character of the old man recurred to the mind of	412.58085677708266
D’Artagnan, who looked at him with more attention than he had done	465.29538960658704
before. In fact, in addition to that yellow, sickly paleness which	487.54643845105664
indicates the insinuation of the bile in the blood, and which might,	476.21074493740576
besides, be accidental, D’Artagnan remarked something perfidiously	489.7827997738765
significant in the play of the wrinkled features of his countenance. A	357.6474346957047
rogue does not laugh in the same way that an honest man does; a	460.50776983241985
hypocrite does not shed the tears of a man of good faith. All falsehood	307.29118220497395
is a mask; and however well made the mask may be, with a little	475.37782825475267
attention we may always succeed in distinguishing it from the true	465.427973383308
face.	464.2288906067972
It appeared, then, to D’Artagnan that M. Bonacieux wore a mask, and	362.4217919593633
likewise that that mask was most disagreeable to look upon. In	443.11545037913066
consequence of this feeling of repugnance, he was about to pass without	295.8432830713886
speaking to him, but, as he had done the day before, M. Bonacieux	391.0294648944485
accosted him.	456.364483675005
“Well, young man,” said he, “we appear to pass rather gay nights! Seven	328.1031981575701
o’clock in the morning! _Peste!_ You seem to reverse ordinary customs,	407.9198377189077
and come home at the hour when other people are going out.”	369.38310232614333
“No one can reproach you for anything of the kind, Monsieur Bonacieux,”	301.3282291938384
said the young man; “you are a model for regular people. It is true	366.68104226806634
that when a man possesses a young and pretty wife, he has no need to	385.5919249653539
seek happiness elsewhere. Happiness comes to meet him, does it not,	292.53658225222085
Monsieur Bonacieux?”	415.5277197210371
Bonacieux became as pale as death, and grinned a ghastly smile.	337.23425083951213
“Ah, ah!” said Bonacieux, “you are a jocular companion! But where the	335.5413613646769
devil were you gadding last night, my young master? It does not appear	462.86169511918484
to be very clean in the crossroads.”	418.1277344173569
D’Artagnan glanced down at his boots, all covered with mud; but that	296.67241279148925
same glance fell upon the shoes and stockings of the mercer, and it	386.2842305841791
might have been said they had been dipped in the same mud heap. Both	317.42291199203993
were stained with splashes of mud of the same appearance.	416.27250129347857
Then a sudden idea crossed the mind of D’Artagnan. That little stout	320.5878216216563
man, short and elderly, that sort of lackey, dressed in dark clothes,	345.2562694674376
treated without ceremony by the men wearing swords who composed the	306.4376450865065
escort, was Bonacieux himself. The husband had presided at the	395.6551339274088
abduction of his wife.	369.3089492702901
A terrible inclination seized D’Artagnan to grasp the mercer by the	336.50632240153027
throat and strangle him; but, as we have said, he was a very prudent	336.2182307915075
youth, and he restrained himself. However, the revolution which	328.28266613385836
appeared upon his countenance was so visible that Bonacieux was	461.71192958197446
terrified at it, and he endeavored to draw back a step or two; but as	365.56201704839805
he was standing before the half of the door which was shut, the	464.94856843941784
obstacle compelled him to keep his place.	387.69489981639083
“Ah, but you are joking, my worthy man!” said D’Artagnan. “It appears	330.74954320041155
to me that if my boots need a sponge, your stockings and shoes stand in	387.04795440851063
equal need of a brush. May you not have been philandering a little	436.15918542485474
also, Monsieur Bonacieux? Oh, the devil! That’s unpardonable in a man	383.1504212718464
of your age, and who besides, has such a pretty wife as yours.”	331.5568423991624
“Oh, Lord! no,” said Bonacieux, “but yesterday I went to St. Mandé to	304.4879358201343
make some inquiries after a servant, as I cannot possibly do without	306.57581986448986
one; and the roads were so bad that I brought back all this mud, which	491.2928116611769
I have not yet had time to remove.”	445.48053686460605
The place named by Bonacieux as that which had been the object of his	341.3268310665861
journey was a fresh proof in support of the suspicions D’Artagnan had	403.2017061794634
conceived. Bonacieux had named Mandé because Mandé was in an exactly	354.69050254085863
opposite direction from St. Cloud. This probability afforded him his	354.7623607373373
first consolation. If Bonacieux knew where his wife was, one might, by	449.20423680093757
extreme means, force the mercer to open his teeth and let his secret	387.03564369265916
escape. The question, then, was how to change this probability into a	312.6725788818193
certainty.	379.2757178174669
“Pardon, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, if I don’t stand upon ceremony,”	317.4589539208555
said D’Artagnan, “but nothing makes one so thirsty as want of sleep. I	446.02954467804625
am parched with thirst. Allow me to take a glass of water in your	447.09571733021534
apartment; you know that is never refused among neighbors.”	444.6700884529068
Without waiting for the permission of his host, D’Artagnan went quickly	402.73561313900274
into the house, and cast a rapid glance at the bed. It had not been	356.40196064015635
used. Bonacieux had not been abed. He had only been back an hour or	349.9864104784876
two; he had accompanied his wife to the place of her confinement, or	462.97074545776064
else at least to the first relay.	371.7860416677827
“Thanks, Monsieur Bonacieux,” said D’Artagnan, emptying his glass,	437.76743078066875
“that is all I wanted of you. I will now go up into my apartment. I	428.20863506885314
will make Planchet brush my boots; and when he has done, I will, if you	306.63219780968643
like, send him to you to brush your shoes.”	369.47905993675687
He left the mercer quite astonished at his singular farewell, and	331.2995892270407
asking himself if he had not been a little inconsiderate.	441.1487739308692
At the top of the stairs he found Planchet in a great fright.	466.91062334688394
“Ah, monsieur!” cried Planchet, as soon as he perceived his master,	305.9658843119912
“here is more trouble. I thought you would never come in.”	316.525577050183
“What’s the matter now, Planchet?” demanded D’Artagnan.	315.6278646450054
“Oh! I give you a hundred, I give you a thousand times to guess,	463.08251916619156
monsieur, the visit I received in your absence.”	385.8277176997634
“When?”	391.6560939134188
“About half an hour ago, while you were at Monsieur de Tréville’s.”	450.6126851166715
“Who has been here? Come, speak.”	439.91374679771104
“Monsieur de Cavois.”	386.2447170844836
“Monsieur de Cavois?”	387.7913784518227
“In person.”	376.3521667728675
“The captain of the cardinal’s Guards?”	404.1173137416377
“Himself.”	396.11239612880723
“Did he come to arrest me?”	452.06080651377886
“I have no doubt that he did, monsieur, for all his wheedling manner.”	471.22106684055336
“Was he so sweet, then?”	354.68805862316134
“Indeed, he was all honey, monsieur.”	476.9649136995322
“Indeed!”	424.6758394042138
“He came, he said, on the part of his Eminence, who wished you well,	475.2230824038868
and to beg you to follow him to the Palais-Royal*.”	338.08948344321004
* It was called the Palais-Cardinal before Richelieu gave it to the	442.93493856289786
King.	473.0929491452804
“What did you answer him?”	383.7628604396755
“That the thing was impossible, seeing that you were not at home, as he	467.46220194109856
could see.”	380.6771502909742
“Well, what did he say then?”	292.5799003370337
“That you must not fail to call upon him in the course of the day; and	344.7524659801781
then he added in a low voice, ‘Tell your master that his Eminence is	317.8652421527609
very well disposed toward him, and that his fortune perhaps depends	305.83045595385084
upon this interview.’”	482.40569173338827
“The snare is rather _maladroit_ for the cardinal,” replied the young	433.5641142994675
man, smiling.	358.6783005768342
“Oh, I saw the snare, and I answered you would be quite in despair on	410.64399641276697
your return.	368.8924121419875
“‘Where has he gone?’ asked Monsieur de Cavois.	446.9586507015873
“‘To Troyes, in Champagne,’ I answered.	296.5972081102718
“‘And when did he set out?’	383.1139377181567
“‘Yesterday evening.’”	445.74367940584045
“Planchet, my friend,” interrupted D’Artagnan, “you are really a	385.779574147042
precious fellow.”	443.06960446898705
“You will understand, monsieur, I thought there would be still time, if	410.446378180559
you wish, to see Monsieur de Cavois to contradict me by saying you were	406.59389427933087
not yet gone. The falsehood would then lie at my door, and as I am not	467.57108550274336
a gentleman, I may be allowed to lie.”	408.3879477035173
“Be of good heart, Planchet, you shall preserve your reputation as a	485.4826075901331
veracious man. In a quarter of an hour we set off.”	482.1224792442449
“That’s the advice I was about to give Monsieur; and where are we	344.70382120853947
going, may I ask, without being too curious?”	308.2806356026338
_“Pardieu!_ In the opposite direction to that which you said I was	412.81202562324336
gone. Besides, are you not as anxious to learn news of Grimaud,	319.558393451247
Mousqueton, and Bazin as I am to know what has become of Athos,	452.4931289642464
Porthos, and Aramis?”	341.2971333725959
“Yes, monsieur,” said Planchet, “and I will go as soon as you please.	411.6469795324556
Indeed, I think provincial air will suit us much better just now than	484.68087945424264
the air of Paris. So then—”	375.7904764324941
“So then, pack up our luggage, Planchet, and let us be off. On my part,	469.6627025695893
I will go out with my hands in my pockets, that nothing may be	491.77980666183083
suspected. You may join me at the Hôtel des Gardes. By the way,	322.93795605310373
Planchet, I think you are right with respect to our host, and that he	431.1812987363452
is decidedly a frightfully low wretch.”	481.6712805209113
“Ah, monsieur, you may take my word when I tell you anything. I am a	392.2590005783463
physiognomist, I assure you.”	454.5061172584857
D’Artagnan went out first, as had been agreed upon. Then, in order that	344.47333467483253
he might have nothing to reproach himself with, he directed his steps,	368.7800167287789
for the last time, toward the residences of his three friends. No news	393.2970770566761
had been received of them; only a letter, all perfumed and of an	474.38983003901075
elegant writing in small characters, had come for Aramis. D’Artagnan	314.97476137605076
took charge of it. Ten minutes afterward Planchet joined him at the	402.1310740886862
stables of the Hôtel des Gardes. D’Artagnan, in order that there might	310.7673399237562
be no time lost, had saddled his horse himself.	472.5593013799333
“That’s well,” said he to Planchet, when the latter added the	354.7235832677921
portmanteau to the equipment. “Now saddle the other three horses.”	351.4906552663925
“Do you think, then, monsieur, that we shall travel faster with two	331.179248969848
horses apiece?” said Planchet, with his shrewd air.	428.8681357760029
“No, Monsieur Jester,” replied D’Artagnan; “but with our four horses we	303.3405658850912
may bring back our three friends, if we should have the good fortune to	338.4654081261239
find them living.”	337.9265302178213
“Which is a great chance,” replied Planchet, “but we must not despair	444.79859936343746
of the mercy of God.”	377.38675683618976
“Amen!” said D’Artagnan, getting into his saddle.	341.09298925021113
As they went from the Hôtel des Gardes, they separated, leaving the	335.05550828309987
street at opposite ends, one having to quit Paris by the Barrière de la	436.03808243077845
Villette and the other by the Barrière Montmartre, to meet again beyond	491.74427196222734
St. Denis—a strategic maneuver which, having been executed with equal	459.3684806077188
punctuality, was crowned with the most fortunate results. D’Artagnan	390.1167737604617
and Planchet entered Pierrefitte together.	469.9160955982185
Planchet was more courageous, it must be admitted, by day than by	301.6251305869311
night. His natural prudence, however, never forsook him for a single	398.2234091045216
instant. He had forgotten not one of the incidents of the first	423.9525957425353
journey, and he looked upon everybody he met on the road as an enemy.	445.0545851165741
It followed that his hat was forever in his hand, which procured him	441.1886864163211
some severe reprimands from D’Artagnan, who feared that his excess of	399.7291099842387
politeness would lead people to think he was the lackey of a man of no	458.2300639767607
consequence.	403.14067463426204
Nevertheless, whether the passengers were really touched by the	357.98719852762537
urbanity of Planchet or whether this time nobody was posted on the	477.24344329486246
young man’s road, our two travelers arrived at Chantilly without any	312.31946593819436
accident, and alighted at the tavern of Great St. Martin, the same at	321.9810047115786
which they had stopped on their first journey.	380.4862024677091
The host, on seeing a young man followed by a lackey with two extra	376.08396541234094
horses, advanced respectfully to the door. Now, as they had already	355.6480682896358
traveled eleven leagues, D’Artagnan thought it time to stop, whether	360.92222687945724
Porthos were or were not in the inn. Perhaps it would not be prudent to	343.7398711214863
ask at once what had become of the Musketeer. The result of these	470.6786075586584
reflections was that D’Artagnan, without asking information of any	391.26322863614286
kind, alighted, commended the horses to the care of his lackey, entered	415.94496462630025
a small room destined to receive those who wished to be alone, and	295.1871327471913
desired the host to bring him a bottle of his best wine and as good a	471.53893431065046
breakfast as possible—a desire which further corroborated the high	332.5295014943376
opinion the innkeeper had formed of the traveler at first sight.	439.742833670361
D’Artagnan was therefore served with miraculous celerity. The regiment	400.8971537317291
of the Guards was recruited among the first gentlemen of the kingdom;	416.3261869640507
and D’Artagnan, followed by a lackey, and traveling with four	335.26515376160205
magnificent horses, despite the simplicity of his uniform, could not	398.5556103546319
fail to make a sensation. The host desired himself to serve him; which	435.317065067041
D’Artagnan perceiving, ordered two glasses to be brought, and commenced	411.9563910557734
the following conversation.	394.7722956498742
“My faith, my good host,” said D’Artagnan, filling the two glasses, “I	396.9528124923072
asked for a bottle of your best wine, and if you have deceived me, you	328.52640239496884
will be punished in what you have sinned; for seeing that I hate	364.7178033055745
drinking by myself, you shall drink with me. Take your glass, then, and	355.3388803714836
let us drink. But what shall we drink to, so as to avoid wounding any	299.92495350419523
susceptibility? Let us drink to the prosperity of your establishment.”	331.85114287347943
“Your Lordship does me much honor,” said the host, “and I thank you	322.041064881302
sincerely for your kind wish.”	316.73856611711494
“But don’t mistake,” said D’Artagnan, “there is more selfishness in my	467.8410092540573
toast than perhaps you may think—for it is only in prosperous	419.67960456080345
establishments that one is well received. In hôtels that do not	372.21057494236095
flourish, everything is in confusion, and the traveler is a victim to	351.21990463740855
the embarrassments of his host. Now, I travel a great deal,	337.4819958484518
particularly on this road, and I wish to see all innkeepers making a	410.71114408757694
fortune.”	411.0092631921486
“It seems to me,” said the host, “that this is not the first time I	313.5077062705173
have had the honor of seeing Monsieur.”	439.3420441023177
“Bah, I have passed perhaps ten times through Chantilly, and out of the	382.7749868333095
ten times I have stopped three or four times at your house at least.	411.14365903838706
Why I was here only ten or twelve days ago. I was conducting some	406.545007658727
friends, Musketeers, one of whom, by the by, had a dispute with a	369.597702192835
stranger—a man who sought a quarrel with him, for I don’t know what.”	431.62290165156566
“Exactly so,” said the host; “I remember it perfectly. It is not	363.75098940929666
Monsieur Porthos that your Lordship means?”	353.28377682229257
“Yes, that is my companion’s name. My God, my dear host, tell me if	432.5095790532489
anything has happened to him?”	394.2716683024523
“Your Lordship must have observed that he could not continue his	384.32536850645886
journey.”	455.1216295611219
“Why, to be sure, he promised to rejoin us, and we have seen nothing of	373.0502078314036
him.”	384.3819801588028
“He has done us the honor to remain here.”	452.8425078767682
“What, he had done you the honor to remain here?”	415.8280783749588
“Yes, monsieur, in this house; and we are even a little uneasy—”	461.0033523219296
“On what account?”	307.4753721205746
“Of certain expenses he has contracted.”	464.68343755600165
“Well, but whatever expenses he may have incurred, I am sure he is in a	381.320805108151
condition to pay them.”	355.2828764050633
“Ah, monsieur, you infuse genuine balm into my blood. We have made	442.00894022930595
considerable advances; and this very morning the surgeon declared that	415.8223174433458
if Monsieur Porthos did not pay him, he should look to me, as it was I	474.138121670886
who had sent for him.”	322.24983078837045
“Porthos is wounded, then?”	420.22172666198446
“I cannot tell you, monsieur.”	448.4195428342067
“What! You cannot tell me? Surely you ought to be able to tell me	471.4171996463159
better than any other person.”	294.78939924164905
“Yes; but in our situation we must not say all we know—particularly as	423.10713992190153
we have been warned that our ears should answer for our tongues.”	482.1321300107066
“Well, can I see Porthos?”	313.0649696303866
“Certainly, monsieur. Take the stairs on your right; go up the first	479.44385121498806
flight and knock at Number One. Only warn him that it is you.”	339.08945825463366
“Why should I do that?”	447.2739743219416
“Because, monsieur, some mischief might happen to you.”	415.0311381535387
“Of what kind, in the name of wonder?”	307.4392303426609
“Monsieur Porthos may imagine you belong to the house, and in a fit of	451.5416600752828
passion might run his sword through you or blow out your brains.”	329.6042384805093
“What have you done to him, then?”	480.9303785855247
“We have asked him for money.”	414.40095373458905
“The devil! Ah, I can understand that. It is a demand that Porthos	488.683126597015
takes very ill when he is not in funds; but I know he must be so at	402.27136215331933
present.”	361.4084321762961
“We thought so, too, monsieur. As our house is carried on very	328.618886858215
regularly, and we make out our bills every week, at the end of eight	338.54413583753836
days we presented our account; but it appeared we had chosen an unlucky	397.09507573533756
moment, for at the first word on the subject, he sent us to all the	470.27376938660075
devils. It is true he had been playing the day before.”	474.35181605461696
“Playing the day before! And with whom?”	368.5748230476097
“Lord, who can say, monsieur? With some gentleman who was traveling	421.2077947283009
this way, to whom he proposed a game of _lansquenet_.”	427.51234663420405
“That’s it, then, and the foolish fellow lost all he had?”	293.4463846002778
“Even to his horse, monsieur; for when the gentleman was about to set	346.8348338287069
out, we perceived that his lackey was saddling Monsieur Porthos’s	468.73771515933765
horse, as well as his master’s. When we observed this to him, he told	371.4453244426872
us all to trouble ourselves about our own business, as this horse	408.3491832021302
belonged to him. We also informed Monsieur Porthos of what was going	303.1383412920932
on; but he told us we were scoundrels to doubt a gentleman’s word, and	312.9993803961992
that as he had said the horse was his, it must be so.”	330.91642273396275
“That’s Porthos all over,” murmured D’Artagnan.	374.49833972524414
“Then,” continued the host, “I replied that as from the moment we	429.7575309652588
seemed not likely to come to a good understanding with respect to	393.4013904864811
payment, I hoped that he would have at least the kindness to grant the	410.689781361272
favor of his custom to my brother host of the Golden Eagle; but	296.0317950573666
Monsieur Porthos replied that, my house being the best, he should	464.81853571029944
remain where he was. This reply was too flattering to allow me to	348.6604784653182
insist on his departure. I confined myself then to begging him to give	444.26187833390253
up his chamber, which is the handsomest in the hôtel, and to be	317.9985604496672
satisfied with a pretty little room on the third floor; but to this	473.9931054632568
Monsieur Porthos replied that as he every moment expected his mistress,	359.5485747105426
who was one of the greatest ladies in the court, I might easily	422.60987527572127
comprehend that the chamber he did me the honor to occupy in my house	332.3978862894098
was itself very mean for the visit of such a personage. Nevertheless,	446.9478426576332
while acknowledging the truth of what he said, I thought proper to	418.39253526121826
insist; but without even giving himself the trouble to enter into any	381.23552064946045
discussion with me, he took one of his pistols, laid it on his table,	380.65423349645005
day and night, and said that at the first word that should be spoken to	348.14151792857274
him about removing, either within the house or out of it, he would blow	470.97316972340195
out the brains of the person who should be so imprudent as to meddle	444.48979219973637
with a matter which only concerned himself. Since that time, monsieur,	316.73388043680086
nobody entered his chamber but his servant.”	408.3144644183551
“What! Mousqueton is here, then?”	490.5505387602079
“Oh, yes, monsieur. Five days after your departure, he came back, and	330.19808192900445
in a very bad condition, too. It appears that he had met with	382.90530813252076
disagreeableness, likewise, on his journey. Unfortunately, he is more	313.78133712525124
nimble than his master; so that for the sake of his master, he puts us	451.7435034606881
all under his feet, and as he thinks we might refuse what he asked for,	375.8392463913855
he takes all he wants without asking at all.”	446.83023783552136
“The fact is,” said D’Artagnan, “I have always observed a great degree	335.65710112730585
of intelligence and devotedness in Mousqueton.”	437.8578192904101
“That is possible, monsieur; but suppose I should happen to be brought	457.8148913372156
in contact, even four times a year, with such intelligence and	479.8799394543872
devotedness—why, I should be a ruined man!”	491.5877960602047
“No, for Porthos will pay you.”	316.57292992953603
“Hum!” said the host, in a doubtful tone.	487.9171407072031
“The favorite of a great lady will not be allowed to be inconvenienced	362.6538601336589
for such a paltry sum as he owes you.”	373.5192835308111
“If I durst say what I believe on that head—”	362.7629193700929
“What you believe?”	404.4763999094099
“I ought rather to say, what I know.”	363.7218793817938
“What you know?”	350.2816362693754
“And even what I am sure of.”	488.12395641080434
“And of what are you so sure?”	462.34163458598607
“I would say that I know this great lady.”	373.78309135107776
“You?”	334.0674445174613
“Yes; I.”	406.46354908549245
“And how do you know her?”	442.36751259296267
“Oh, monsieur, if I could believe I might trust in your discretion.”	320.4561921497919
“Speak! By the word of a gentleman, you shall have no cause to repent	320.3259465883583
of your confidence.”	322.2414301304367
“Well, monsieur, you understand that uneasiness makes us do many	422.8389308282975
things.”	295.9201204346145
“What have you done?”	457.0241176537977
“Oh, nothing which was not right in the character of a creditor.”	411.4916968611412
“Well?”	399.8613572812819
“Monsieur Porthos gave us a note for his duchess, ordering us to put it	366.95800567350017
in the post. This was before his servant came. As he could not leave	380.3712658081961
his chamber, it was necessary to charge us with this commission.”	486.35462897107186
“And then?”	434.98310980413123
“Instead of putting the letter in the post, which is never safe, I took	448.2099853538017
advantage of the journey of one of my lads to Paris, and ordered him to	453.75472216470314
convey the letter to this duchess himself. This was fulfilling the	418.0558561453699
intentions of Monsieur Porthos, who had desired us to be so careful of	434.5490235990175
this letter, was it not?”	422.5128442213597
“Nearly so.”	360.7655788723739
“Well, monsieur, do you know who this great lady is?”	434.57637471164094
“No; I have heard Porthos speak of her, that’s all.”	478.3600129409758
“Do you know who this pretended duchess is?	300.6987197526588
“I repeat to you, I don’t know her.”	427.4212972285037
“Why, she is the old wife of a procurator* of the Châtelet, monsieur,	361.8025454066419
named Madame Coquenard, who, although she is at least fifty, still	462.21286565430955
gives herself jealous airs. It struck me as very odd that a princess	485.69441395925236
should live in the Rue aux Ours.”	489.6253172041871
* Attorney	357.5501418467007
“But how do you know all this?”	404.5547735229968
“Because she flew into a great passion on receiving the letter, saying	472.2979813101427
that Monsieur Porthos was a weathercock, and that she was sure it was	385.4300590639224
for some woman he had received this wound.”	464.5044971665394
“Has he been wounded, then?”	397.61255248987857
“Oh, good Lord! What have I said?”	379.41537858037594
“You said that Porthos had received a sword cut.”	409.93576436420483
“Yes, but he has forbidden me so strictly to say so.”	425.2383579589465
“And why so.”	377.39708317558404
“Zounds, monsieur! Because he had boasted that he would perforate the	331.9397236129254
stranger with whom you left him in dispute; whereas the stranger, on	442.0959847612513
the contrary, in spite of all his rodomontades quickly threw him on his	443.8453373464135
back. As Monsieur Porthos is a very boastful man, he insists that	428.4180010305065
nobody shall know he has received this wound except the duchess, whom	425.9572370084642
he endeavored to interest by an account of his adventure.”	466.4161470866175
“It is a wound that confines him to his bed?”	490.8809017045153
“Ah, and a master stroke, too, I assure you. Your friend’s soul must	362.55300387062744
stick tight to his body.”	342.28858109360135
“Were you there, then?”	459.0865325783905
“Monsieur, I followed them from curiosity, so that I saw the combat	346.51335268106095
without the combatants seeing me.”	304.81212013327564
“And what took place?”	429.47406267011786
“Oh! The affair was not long, I assure you. They placed themselves on	327.7063136823013
guard; the stranger made a feint and a lunge, and that so rapidly that	436.25622887485366
when Monsieur Porthos came to the _parade_, he had already three inches	360.26950735097176
of steel in his breast. He immediately fell backward. The stranger	388.52176314959985
placed the point of his sword at his throat; and Monsieur Porthos,	467.5742473471489
