was Porthos, and not D’Artagnan, he assisted him to rise, brought him	470.159609578379
back to the hôtel, mounted his horse, and disappeared.”	297.9682863325441
“So it was with Monsieur d’Artagnan this stranger meant to quarrel?”	456.22899420827446
“It appears so.”	318.3290434693325
“And do you know what has become of him?”	424.6455773859402
“No, I never saw him until that moment, and have not seen him since.”	491.79052684350404
“Very well; I know all that I wish to know. Porthos’s chamber is, you	462.8575950433599
say, on the first story, Number One?”	378.11440557619187
“Yes, monsieur, the handsomest in the inn—a chamber that I could have	481.3087317335182
let ten times over.”	357.37151530761133
“Bah! Be satisfied,” said D’Artagnan, laughing, “Porthos will pay you	327.6733015099895
with the money of the Duchess Coquenard.”	490.5120808727571
“Oh, monsieur, procurator’s wife or duchess, if she will but loosen her	479.61555798164864
pursestrings, it will be all the same; but she positively answered that	481.80818865181607
she was tired of the exigencies and infidelities of Monsieur Porthos,	359.1277570698367
and that she would not send him a denier.”	308.93777521062054
“And did you convey this answer to your guest?”	358.5842641053697
“We took good care not to do that; he would have found in what fashion	388.6825769454668
we had executed his commission.”	293.9410489022382
“So that he still expects his money?”	431.16477360182535
“Oh, Lord, yes, monsieur! Yesterday he wrote again; but it was his	460.5388555008342
servant who this time put the letter in the post.”	385.3836792435814
“Do you say the procurator’s wife is old and ugly?”	456.38289770088033
“Fifty at least, monsieur, and not at all handsome, according to	308.46911919998746
Pathaud’s account.”	417.6778473333982
“In that case, you may be quite at ease; she will soon be softened.	376.1540440628793
Besides, Porthos cannot owe you much.”	429.26498659798375
“How, not much! Twenty good pistoles, already, without reckoning the	406.03994295770644
doctor. He denies himself nothing; it may easily be seen he has been	345.60287996102676
accustomed to live well.”	474.6352711425832
“Never mind; if his mistress abandons him, he will find friends, I will	404.0710544703466
answer for it. So, my dear host, be not uneasy, and continue to take	425.860536607167
all the care of him that his situation requires.”	439.72371404196724
“Monsieur has promised me not to open his mouth about the procurator’s	431.010588575784
wife, and not to say a word of the wound?”	370.32463063663454
“That’s agreed; you have my word.”	446.5539404011774
“Oh, he would kill me!”	485.6550005319599
“Don’t be afraid; he is not so much of a devil as he appears.”	444.35029821438854
Saying these words, D’Artagnan went upstairs, leaving his host a little	452.7235649989793
better satisfied with respect to two things in which he appeared to be	370.2262362046418
very much interested—his debt and his life.	414.46580235260615
At the top of the stairs, upon the most conspicuous door of the	392.59586885126544
corridor, was traced in black ink a gigantic number “1.” D’Artagnan	485.7278200680304
knocked, and upon the bidding to come in which came from inside, he	478.01079714175546
entered the chamber.	382.4346329792975
Porthos was in bed, and was playing a game at _lansquenet_ with	443.20429908618956
Mousqueton, to keep his hand in; while a spit loaded with partridges	490.6565307902375
was turning before the fire, and on each side of a large chimneypiece,	298.42181456564293
over two chafing dishes, were boiling two stewpans, from which exhaled	411.7261107526578
a double odor of rabbit and fish stews, rejoicing to the smell. In	295.6547153898076
addition to this he perceived that the top of a wardrobe and the marble	362.9071930126525
of a commode were covered with empty bottles.	485.1798007407699
At the sight of his friend, Porthos uttered a loud cry of joy; and	366.0502749561015
Mousqueton, rising respectfully, yielded his place to him, and went to	370.45963705443376
give an eye to the two stewpans, of which he appeared to have the	414.2353592082403
particular inspection.	489.1696479279566
“Ah, _pardieu!_ Is that you?” said Porthos to D’Artagnan. “You are	458.0466593308285
right welcome. Excuse my not coming to meet you; but,” added he,	422.08069583824886
looking at D’Artagnan with a certain degree of uneasiness, “you know	339.7391192456473
what has happened to me?”	437.66151979693984
“No.”	320.6037270718346
“Has the host told you nothing, then?”	439.26713751079996
“I asked after you, and came up as soon as I could.”	317.0651313921638
Porthos seemed to breathe more freely.	305.77420037493516
“And what has happened to you, my dear Porthos?” continued D’Artagnan.	312.40674660195003
“Why, on making a thrust at my adversary, whom I had already hit three	422.4609360405496
times, and whom I meant to finish with the fourth, I put my foot on a	395.88793406677144
stone, slipped, and strained my knee.”	328.1383951806834
“Truly?”	469.08886300809513
“Honor! Luckily for the rascal, for I should have left him dead on the	399.5697057320656
spot, I assure you.”	402.0150673921129
“And what has became of him?”	432.67212717045163
“Oh, I don’t know; he had enough, and set off without waiting for the	413.6700421215244
rest. But you, my dear D’Artagnan, what has happened to you?”	417.56814766754115
“So that this strain of the knee,” continued D’Artagnan, “my dear	480.52003627956185
Porthos, keeps you in bed?”	439.78193651283834
“My God, that’s all. I shall be about again in a few days.”	378.8599441173112
“Why did you not have yourself conveyed to Paris? You must be cruelly	379.8645360839116
bored here.”	400.55433383932376
“That was my intention; but, my dear friend, I have one thing to	421.64608021604647
confess to you.”	470.3036677869208
“What’s that?”	434.4296969283953
“It is that as I was cruelly bored, as you say, and as I had the	456.23624592664873
seventy-five pistoles in my pocket which you had distributed to me, in	309.4948418974547
order to amuse myself I invited a gentleman who was traveling this way	455.2779267520202
to walk up, and proposed a cast of dice. He accepted my challenge, and,	382.87469278749927
my faith, my seventy-five pistoles passed from my pocket to his,	419.7391055759987

“What can you expect, my dear Porthos; a man is not privileged in all	386.84553554494937
ways,” said D’Artagnan. “You know the proverb ‘Unlucky at play, lucky	311.91023209908786
in love.’ You are too fortunate in your love for play not to take its	345.65904484850427
revenge. What consequence can the reverses of fortune be to you? Have	481.5741808000443
you not, happy rogue that you are—have you not your duchess, who cannot	470.6698597044868
fail to come to your aid?”	394.18460780614805
“Well, you see, my dear D’Artagnan, with what ill luck I play,” replied	377.9382452803238
Porthos, with the most careless air in the world. “I wrote to her to	435.8294985352825
send me fifty louis or so, of which I stood absolutely in need on	355.9588720057719
account of my accident.”	401.1301882945336
“Well?”	454.50850654862
“Well, she must be at her country seat, for she has not answered me.”	404.89363021961907
“Truly?”	313.1143912360776
“No; so I yesterday addressed another epistle to her, still more	343.31737092592954
pressing than the first. But you are here, my dear fellow, let us speak	428.4787018095325
of you. I confess I began to be very uneasy on your account.”	304.0933098222123
“But your host behaves very well toward you, as it appears, my dear	373.00573881840904
Porthos,” said D’Artagnan, directing the sick man’s attention to the	385.24049107882735
full stewpans and the empty bottles.	395.4725790479414
“So, so,” replied Porthos. “Only three or four days ago the impertinent	353.71483184582604
jackanapes gave me his bill, and I was forced to turn both him and his	321.5052556245463
bill out of the door; so that I am here something in the fashion of a	380.37676925655217
conqueror, holding my position, as it were, my conquest. So you see,	397.0458463364863
being in constant fear of being forced from that position, I am armed	385.74010070245697
to the teeth.”	354.8626919893556
“And yet,” said D’Artagnan, laughing, “it appears to me that from time	406.2181860701046
to time you must make _sorties_.” And he again pointed to the bottles	330.57886945120276
and the stewpans.	293.0836179585212
“Not I, unfortunately!” said Porthos. “This miserable strain confines	369.0340332104947
me to my bed; but Mousqueton forages, and brings in provisions. Friend	471.6930374877069
Mousqueton, you see that we have a reinforcement, and we must have an	348.30158315940565
increase of supplies.”	422.05601631131475
“Mousqueton,” said D’Artagnan, “you must render me a service.”	398.8107095163228
“What, monsieur?”	374.02179086859053
“You must give your recipe to Planchet. I may be besieged in my turn,	420.6624261932176
and I shall not be sorry for him to be able to let me enjoy the same	346.17978606322754
advantages with which you gratify your master.”	371.8392360003435
“Lord, monsieur! There is nothing more easy,” said Mousqueton, with a	321.10194725630663
modest air. “One only needs to be sharp, that’s all. I was brought up	344.3939658524644
in the country, and my father in his leisure time was something of a	410.4560973274199
poacher.”	340.550940907391
“And what did he do the rest of his time?”	342.4411130193937
“Monsieur, he carried on a trade which I have always thought	342.5475523929599
satisfactory.”	380.72971977040106
“Which?”	478.6291881228842
“As it was a time of war between the Catholics and the Huguenots, and	295.1942285320034
as he saw the Catholics exterminate the Huguenots and the Huguenots	459.80060638243395
exterminate the Catholics—all in the name of religion—he adopted a	453.9538043415022
mixed belief which permitted him to be sometimes Catholic, sometimes a	411.3978293067584
Huguenot. Now, he was accustomed to walk with his fowling piece on his	476.91221649791447
shoulder, behind the hedges which border the roads, and when he saw a	418.16760319294457
Catholic coming alone, the Protestant religion immediately prevailed in	323.5604534646836
his mind. He lowered his gun in the direction of the traveler; then,	414.4911850834227
when he was within ten paces of him, he commenced a conversation which	470.5757243541669
almost always ended by the traveler’s abandoning his purse to save his	484.0673352644758
life. It goes without saying that when he saw a Huguenot coming, he	304.4847919004321
felt himself filled with such ardent Catholic zeal that he could not	424.48454985581236
understand how, a quarter of an hour before, he had been able to have	437.27875304278007
any doubts upon the superiority of our holy religion. For my part,	348.0926648077452
monsieur, I am Catholic—my father, faithful to his principles, having	366.08686925476263
made my elder brother a Huguenot.”	444.95884647860646
“And what was the end of this worthy man?” asked D’Artagnan.	365.2196266231372
“Oh, of the most unfortunate kind, monsieur. One day he was surprised	387.5328548034048
in a lonely road between a Huguenot and a Catholic, with both of whom	292.18141222113536
he had before had business, and who both knew him again; so they united	351.2071801982749
against him and hanged him on a tree. Then they came and boasted of	292.13966910455565
their fine exploit in the cabaret of the next village, where my brother	320.4655922587671
and I were drinking.”	455.7392419320943
“And what did you do?” said D’Artagnan.	392.5902494257904
“We let them tell their story out,” replied Mousqueton. “Then, as in	487.29000111280413
leaving the cabaret they took different directions, my brother went and	361.1324006028661
hid himself on the road of the Catholic, and I on that of the Huguenot.	304.5525039382388
Two hours after, all was over; we had done the business of both,	334.93160074299396
admiring the foresight of our poor father, who had taken the precaution	368.147421103243
to bring each of us up in a different religion.”	348.7346275018401
“Well, I must allow, as you say, your father was a very intelligent	418.75467524953297
fellow. And you say in his leisure moments the worthy man was a	484.25692323964756
poacher?”	380.9133999678777
“Yes, monsieur, and it was he who taught me to lay a snare and ground a	365.63036340403335
line. The consequence is that when I saw our laborers, which did not at	392.76993448402106
all suit two such delicate stomachs as ours, I had recourse to a little	465.8246756153643
of my old trade. While walking near the wood of Monsieur le Prince, I	311.6535703260867
laid a few snares in the runs; and while reclining on the banks of his	418.97500997755725
Highness’s pieces of water, I slipped a few lines into his fish ponds.	406.77293925872857
So that now, thanks be to God, we do not want, as Monsieur can testify,	415.8962002532412
for partridges, rabbits, carp or eels—all light, wholesome food,	471.922453659884
suitable for the sick.”	330.62485251053863
“But the wine,” said D’Artagnan, “who furnishes the wine? Your host?”	407.0400525841701
“That is to say, yes and no.”	357.6806757446618
“How yes and no?”	354.3888334432336
“He furnishes it, it is true, but he does not know that he has that	296.64056083706095
honor.”	327.12839648730153
“Explain yourself, Mousqueton; your conversation is full of instructive	408.63956941282026
things.”	293.1233417320635
“That is it, monsieur. It has so chanced that I met with a Spaniard in	361.53079339957833
my peregrinations who had seen many countries, and among them the New	295.9341088874765
World.”	443.65483127298126
“What connection can the New World have with the bottles which are on	351.8882527636147
the commode and the wardrobe?”	329.2143745443816
“Patience, monsieur, everything will come in its turn.”	306.7764027346638
“This Spaniard had in his service a lackey who had accompanied him in	450.8780234699967
his voyage to Mexico. This lackey was my compatriot; and we became the	392.3109532797898
more intimate from there being many resemblances of character between	393.9273095621681
us. We loved sporting of all kinds better than anything; so that he	411.2108307187685
related to me how in the plains of the Pampas the natives hunt the	441.005168855584
tiger and the wild bull with simple running nooses which they throw to	312.8242355836078
a distance of twenty or thirty paces the end of a cord with such	339.89767201200607
nicety; but in face of the proof I was obliged to acknowledge the truth	452.49076094580226
of the recital. My friend placed a bottle at the distance of thirty	468.8368638537238
paces, and at each cast he caught the neck of the bottle in his running	416.8189357370734
noose. I practiced this exercise, and as nature has endowed me with	454.53604766640984
some faculties, at this day I can throw the lasso with any man in the	298.15967937259626
world. Well, do you understand, monsieur? Our host has a well-furnished	355.0327667638742
cellar the key of which never leaves him; only this cellar has a	460.453759257269
ventilating hole. Now through this ventilating hole I throw my lasso,	409.28572712159456
and as I now know in which part of the cellar is the best wine, that’s	473.17960351082206
my point for sport. You see, monsieur, what the New World has to do	307.3140566677525
with the bottles which are on the commode and the wardrobe. Now, will	442.4031968746734
you taste our wine, and without prejudice say what you think of it?”	455.32711532600837
“Thank you, my friend, thank you; unfortunately, I have just	401.12082732066784
breakfasted.”	459.58392341235174
“Well,” said Porthos, “arrange the table, Mousqueton, and while we	441.91861747557147
breakfast, D’Artagnan will relate to us what has happened to him during	366.4943261291718
the ten days since he left us.”	301.6460556287102
“Willingly,” said D’Artagnan.	308.201239310069
While Porthos and Mousqueton were breakfasting, with the appetites of	325.07630564148604
convalescents and with that brotherly cordiality which unites men in	439.04547474110086
misfortune, D’Artagnan related how Aramis, being wounded, was obliged	407.8024382088926
to stop at Crèvecœur, how he had left Athos fighting at Amiens with	412.76125822012284
four men who accused him of being a coiner, and how he, D’Artagnan, had	355.8725485206682
been forced to run the Comtes de Wardes through the body in order to	377.61801129315415
reach England.	455.7427967096236
But there the confidence of D’Artagnan stopped. He only added that on	390.58228947456627
his return from Great Britain he had brought back four magnificent	458.4711702936561
horses—one for himself, and one for each of his companions; then he	352.51708291314
informed Porthos that the one intended for him was already installed in	403.7196468117204
the stable of the tavern.	321.7024390772495
At this moment Planchet entered, to inform his master that the horses	395.9985061958281
were sufficiently refreshed and that it would be possible to sleep at	461.38099530022856
Clermont.	388.1033516630351
As D’Artagnan was tolerably reassured with regard to Porthos, and as he	431.3385850553604
was anxious to obtain news of his two other friends, he held out his	441.4345936128019
hand to the wounded man, and told him he was about to resume his route	316.08977453526893
in order to continue his researches. For the rest, as he reckoned upon	420.3118020858269
returning by the same route in seven or eight days, if Porthos were	341.8397210637628
still at the Great St. Martin, he would call for him on his way.	348.842817139131
Porthos replied that in all probability his sprain would not permit him	410.9924248500498
to depart yet awhile. Besides, it was necessary he should stay at	485.70381116215776
Chantilly to wait for the answer from his duchess.	487.958541150232
D’Artagnan wished that answer might be prompt and favorable; and having	337.2021084157059
again recommended Porthos to the care of Mousqueton, and paid his bill	300.3961708958522
to the host, he resumed his route with Planchet, already relieved of	386.98968086863954
one of his led horses.	351.44184686631746
Chapter XXVI.	398.0943016639636
ARAMIS AND HIS THESIS	470.69090130406903
D’Artagnan had said nothing to Porthos of his wound or of his	354.809862493509
procurator’s wife. Our Béarnais was a prudent lad, however young he	355.06505508249654
might be. Consequently he had appeared to believe all that the	370.457058338765
vainglorious Musketeer had told him, convinced that no friendship will	410.55069121945377
hold out against a surprised secret. Besides, we feel always a sort of	446.8094126080773
mental superiority over those whose lives we know better than they	309.2223027628303
suppose. In his projects of intrigue for the future, and determined as	338.43271317845176
he was to make his three friends the instruments of his fortune,	383.9067804319278
D’Artagnan was not sorry at getting into his grasp beforehand the	379.226980441118
invisible strings by which he reckoned upon moving them.	296.87911004624436
And yet, as he journeyed along, a profound sadness weighed upon his	302.86716932578344
heart. He thought of that young and pretty Mme. Bonacieux who was to	399.92878004152533
have paid him the price of his devotedness; but let us hasten to say	302.8764542863103
that this sadness possessed the young man less from the regret of the	417.8733623530089
happiness he had missed, than from the fear he entertained that some	349.96050864901423
serious misfortune had befallen the poor woman. For himself, he had no	368.5122266918669
doubt she was a victim of the cardinal’s vengeance; and, as was well	421.2236850257751
known, the vengeance of his Eminence was terrible. How he had found	341.70053316750955
grace in the eyes of the minister, he did not know; but without doubt	474.95417156430864
M. de Cavois would have revealed this to him if the captain of the	292.6820961856961
Guards had found him at home.	419.4447172288994
Nothing makes time pass more quickly or more shortens a journey than a	445.96399663107036
thought which absorbs in itself all the faculties of the organization	371.03551498718116
of him who thinks. External existence then resembles a sleep of which	301.64692266026185
this thought is the dream. By its influence, time has no longer	359.38990124155475
measure, space has no longer distance. We depart from one place, and	407.01077934216613
arrive at another, that is all. Of the interval passed, nothing remains	375.2060574738545
in the memory but a vague mist in which a thousand confused images of	309.03031080535004
trees, mountains, and landscapes are lost. It was as a prey to this	477.02340861754794
hallucination that D’Artagnan traveled, at whatever pace his horse	428.0300125556083
pleased, the six or eight leagues that separated Chantilly from	470.8622323583335
Crèvecœur, without his being able to remember on his arrival in the	465.0106717599803
village any of the things he had passed or met with on the road.	369.40622648672286
There only his memory returned to him. He shook his head, perceived the	380.0724574474454
cabaret at which he had left Aramis, and putting his horse to the trot,	350.50693939648346
he shortly pulled up at the door.	348.83514720126715
This time it was not a host but a hostess who received him. D’Artagnan	390.5880890216805
was a physiognomist. His eye took in at a glance the plump, cheerful	364.1847862730825
countenance of the mistress of the place, and he at once perceived	391.13147068107816
there was no occasion for dissembling with her, or of fearing anything	401.7452571343962
from one blessed with such a joyous physiognomy.	341.0046311441017
“My good dame,” asked D’Artagnan, “can you tell me what has become of	325.1474481950964
one of my friends, whom we were obliged to leave here about a dozen	399.1661229664669
days ago?”	390.4193213560685
“A handsome young man, three- or four-and-twenty years old, mild,	377.4272722838159
amiable, and well made?”	472.6371757086537
“That is he—wounded in the shoulder.”	468.20624986850567
“Just so. Well, monsieur, he is still here.”	459.4040635036146
“Ah, _pardieu!_ My dear dame,” said D’Artagnan, springing from his	418.49435877421126
horse, and throwing the bridle to Planchet, “you restore me to life;	407.62863617501506
where is this dear Aramis? Let me embrace him, I am in a hurry to see	466.79692814763354
him again.”	302.9790122504799
“Pardon, monsieur, but I doubt whether he can see you at this moment.”	423.39168957388483
“Why so? Has he a lady with him?”	326.70365225635675
“Jesus! What do you mean by that? Poor lad! No, monsieur, he has not a	332.354238597523
lady with him.”	297.30775412061695
“With whom is he, then?”	431.27506962931284
“With the curate of Montdidier and the superior of the Jesuits of	336.00536346054776
Amiens.”	455.1031143189133
“Good heavens!” cried D’Artagnan, “is the poor fellow worse, then?”	487.44082065591715
“No, monsieur, quite the contrary; but after his illness grace touched	457.7143732082434
him, and he determined to take orders.”	340.5902691582514
“That’s it!” said D’Artagnan, “I had forgotten that he was only a	383.29558007288614
Musketeer for a time.”	456.6722970502293
“Monsieur still insists upon seeing him?”	490.89431128882575
“More than ever.”	458.8056225994709
“Well, monsieur has only to take the right-hand staircase in the	479.94877726129795
courtyard, and knock at Number Five on the second floor.”	395.10942715755164
D’Artagnan walked quickly in the direction indicated, and found one of	442.2556232929762
those exterior staircases that are still to be seen in the yards of our	299.6755168109023
old-fashioned taverns. But there was no getting at the place of sojourn	301.70388568408913
of the future abbé; the defiles of the chamber of Aramis were as well	366.4045718941194
guarded as the gardens of Armida. Bazin was stationed in the corridor,	295.01843440413205
and barred his passage with the more intrepidity that, after many years	350.968624362201
of trial, Bazin found himself near a result of which he had ever been	296.1640561783215
ambitious.	385.8875579666558
In fact, the dream of poor Bazin had always been to serve a churchman;	299.6814249130946
and he awaited with impatience the moment, always in the future, when	355.30040322011484
Aramis would throw aside the uniform and assume the cassock. The	456.94704186437264
daily-renewed promise of the young man that the moment would not long	463.6925223424404
be delayed, had alone kept him in the service of a Musketeer—a service	315.4088075911042
in which, he said, his soul was in constant jeopardy.	346.36418699075006
Bazin was then at the height of joy. In all probability, this time his	386.98734555565665
master would not retract. The union of physical pain with moral	470.9140669640612
uneasiness had produced the effect so long desired. Aramis, suffering	351.3171650660986
at once in body and mind, had at length fixed his eyes and his thoughts	386.5942285560904
upon religion, and he had considered as a warning from heaven the	422.9275239171641
double accident which had happened to him; that is to say, the sudden	484.7589705254509
disappearance of his mistress and the wound in his shoulder.	339.06459778089913
It may be easily understood that in the present disposition of his	337.27087689242467
master nothing could be more disagreeable to Bazin than the arrival of	452.5388680033189
D’Artagnan, which might cast his master back again into that vortex of	359.0593543357916
mundane affairs which had so long carried him away. He resolved, then,	379.30604308804686
to defend the door bravely; and as, betrayed by the mistress of the	332.59582538711595
inn, he could not say that Aramis was absent, he endeavored to prove to	462.26145013351186
the newcomer that it would be the height of indiscretion to disturb his	295.6717181149169
master in his pious conference, which had commenced with the morning	439.04558510204794
and would not, as Bazin said, terminate before night.	399.25016655257207
But D’Artagnan took very little heed of the eloquent discourse of M.	490.4533500535169
Bazin; and as he had no desire to support a polemic discussion with his	333.78349686413867
friend’s valet, he simply moved him out of the way with one hand, and	354.7964453801655
with the other turned the handle of the door of Number Five. The door	426.2170364927558
opened, and D’Artagnan went into the chamber.	466.20884727840144
Aramis, in a black gown, his head enveloped in a sort of round flat	348.90842442904136
cap, not much unlike a _calotte_, was seated before an oblong table,	349.6482574844193
covered with rolls of paper and enormous volumes in folio. At his right	439.9952766254378
hand was placed the superior of the Jesuits, and on his left the curate	429.0109493526441
of Montdidier. The curtains were half drawn, and only admitted the	483.77934071848335
mysterious light calculated for beatific reveries. All the mundane	487.2558471026953
objects that generally strike the eye on entering the room of a young	471.94978280763246
man, particularly when that young man is a Musketeer, had disappeared	360.5341035075818
as if by enchantment; and for fear, no doubt, that the sight of them	316.38537990274597
might bring his master back to ideas of this world, Bazin had laid his	314.81342856660206
hands upon sword, pistols, plumed hat, and embroideries and laces of	315.77876847568723
all kinds and sorts. In their stead D’Artagnan thought he perceived in	421.5463616028875
an obscure corner a discipline cord suspended from a nail in the wall.	369.4517580421196
At the noise made by D’Artagnan in entering, Aramis lifted up his head,	366.61850383481993
and beheld his friend; but to the great astonishment of the young man,	475.99203115606167
the sight of him did not produce much effect upon the Musketeer, so	295.30369840565925
completely was his mind detached from the things of this world.	483.3807567869378
“Good day, dear D’Artagnan,” said Aramis; “believe me, I am glad to see	491.4512482164754
you.”	462.3912567393544
“So am I delighted to see you,” said D’Artagnan, “although I am not yet	463.7207560526099
sure that it is Aramis I am speaking to.”	386.8355332989468
“To himself, my friend, to himself! But what makes you doubt it?”	374.782330365632
“I was afraid I had made a mistake in the chamber, and that I had found	397.36845442148723
my way into the apartment of some churchman. Then another error seized	325.18990823110386
me on seeing you in company with these gentlemen—I was afraid you were	332.6097919150339
dangerously ill.”	419.4602918614655
The two men in black, who guessed D’Artagnan’s meaning, darted at him a	376.27022275168645
glance which might have been thought threatening; but D’Artagnan took	311.69456680993204
no heed of it.	456.0370709286864
“I disturb you, perhaps, my dear Aramis,” continued D’Artagnan, “for by	314.4447752581752
what I see, I am led to believe that you are confessing to these	481.62884200743594
gentlemen.”	299.5656165711626
Aramis colored imperceptibly. “You disturb me? Oh, quite the contrary,	319.9390457940183
dear friend, I swear; and as a proof of what I say, permit me to	397.37534399739195
declare I am rejoiced to see you safe and sound.”	454.1538069895464
“Ah, he’ll come round,” thought D’Artagnan; “that’s not bad!”	356.2133728948925
“This gentleman, who is my friend, has just escaped from a serious	338.86087292610705
danger,” continued Aramis, with unction, pointing to D’Artagnan with	327.4925221892734
his hand, and addressing the two ecclesiastics.	454.32358863215836
“Praise God, monsieur,” replied they, bowing together.	378.3257896679952
“I have not failed to do so, your Reverences,” replied the young man,	480.14957033205496
returning their salutation.	325.33983622717267
“You arrive in good time, dear D’Artagnan,” said Aramis, “and by taking	333.7446964926442
part in our discussion may assist us with your intelligence. Monsieur	357.92288000255616
the Principal of Amiens, Monsieur the Curate of Montdidier, and I are	300.85572634690965
arguing certain theological questions in which we have been much	421.26556141828
interested; I shall be delighted to have your opinion.”	351.7330338715656
“The opinion of a swordsman can have very little weight,” replied	392.7856056569581
D’Artagnan, who began to be uneasy at the turn things were taking, “and	473.51085645444175
you had better be satisfied, believe me, with the knowledge of these	293.2937055755495
gentlemen.”	406.45181833596405
The two men in black bowed in their turn.	317.2718640650573
“On the contrary,” replied Aramis, “your opinion will be very valuable.	314.17340669711825
The question is this: Monsieur the Principal thinks that my thesis	459.5149791271331
ought to be dogmatic and didactic.”	427.64463015437894
“Your thesis! Are you then making a thesis?”	469.84248903722016
“Without doubt,” replied the Jesuit. “In the examination which precedes	396.0202318631467
ordination, a thesis is always a requisite.”	464.15174258278523
“Ordination!” cried D’Artagnan, who could not believe what the hostess	448.9375820304998
and Bazin had successively told him; and he gazed, half stupefied, upon	450.68508858284986
the three persons before him.	449.05317009888716
“Now,” continued Aramis, taking the same graceful position in his easy	318.35054607331347
chair that he would have assumed in bed, and complacently examining his	377.48759355649423
hand, which was as white and plump as that of a woman, and which he	349.45739648787844
held in the air to cause the blood to descend, “now, as you have heard,	451.0934706345886
D’Artagnan, Monsieur the Principal is desirous that my thesis should be	401.09260033774467
dogmatic, while I, for my part, would rather it should be ideal. This	337.4190668571508
is the reason why Monsieur the Principal has proposed to me the	487.09049046564786
following subject, which has not yet been treated upon, and in which I	477.6122083669694
perceive there is matter for magnificent elaboration—‘_Utraque manus in	390.3757847110327
benedicendo clericis inferioribus necessaria est_.’”	319.477885877446
D’Artagnan, whose erudition we are well acquainted with, evinced no	366.44067633586616
more interest on hearing this quotation than he had at that of M. de	297.95725040888755
Tréville in allusion to the gifts he pretended that D’Artagnan had	430.1125136244359
received from the Duke of Buckingham.	419.8601002683684
“Which means,” resumed Aramis, that he might perfectly understand,	352.0059802458007
“‘The two hands are indispensable for priests of the inferior orders,	344.5829489974426
when they bestow the benediction.’”	292.7042829564014
“An admirable subject!” cried the Jesuit.	484.6088553970201
“Admirable and dogmatic!” repeated the curate, who, about as strong as	336.2280911392321
D’Artagnan with respect to Latin, carefully watched the Jesuit in order	347.50737515763245
to keep step with him, and repeated his words like an echo.	473.0917740434835
As to D’Artagnan, he remained perfectly insensible to the enthusiasm of	454.7356863709886
the two men in black.	433.8727629891431
“Yes, admirable! _prorsus admirabile!_” continued Aramis; “but which	294.93306446805923
requires a profound study of both the Scriptures and the Fathers. Now,	443.5594217134858
I have confessed to these learned ecclesiastics, and that in all	470.3723672907489
humility, that the duties of mounting guard and the service of the king	351.50189454856843
have caused me to neglect study a little. I should find myself,	421.70650046393496
therefore, more at my ease, _facilius natans_, in a subject of my own	341.76044748310846
choice, which would be to these hard theological questions what morals	417.5740065686535
are to metaphysics in philosophy.”	444.73050751379606
D’Artagnan began to be tired, and so did the curate.	336.60310338742016
“See what an exordium!” cried the Jesuit.	464.23334419958826
“Exordium,” repeated the curate, for the sake of saying something.	327.14608561422426
“_Quemadmodum inter cœlorum immensitatem_.”	304.9379030145392
Aramis cast a glance upon D’Artagnan to see what effect all this	306.72076554619025
produced, and found his friend gaping enough to split his jaws.	324.74159990398937
“Let us speak French, my father,” said he to the Jesuit; “Monsieur	463.26582484787195
d’Artagnan will enjoy our conversation better.”	333.92248882379977
“Yes,” replied D’Artagnan; “I am fatigued with reading, and all this	338.0287383860973
Latin confuses me.”	463.64233562715617
“Certainly,” replied the Jesuit, a little put out, while the curate,	350.5505330379412
greatly delighted, turned upon D’Artagnan a look full of gratitude.	456.0901390687824
“Well, let us see what is to be derived from this gloss. Moses, the	377.4461833618029
servant of God—he was but a servant, please to understand—Moses blessed	351.9891125991025
with the hands; he held out both his arms while the Hebrews beat their	297.38731030119095
enemies, and then he blessed them with his two hands. Besides, what	319.4931028409775
does the Gospel say? _Imponite manus_, and not _manum_—place the	305.42100703052364
_hands_, not the _hand_.”	411.25782500022115
“Place the _hands_,” repeated the curate, with a gesture.	380.7661946669996
“St. Peter, on the contrary, of whom the Popes are the successors,”	437.67539023781103
continued the Jesuit; “_porrige digitos_—present the fingers. Are you	476.747201802419
there, now?”	398.3400482160422
“_Certes_,” replied Aramis, in a pleased tone, “but the thing is	314.2936587288058
subtle.”	445.40802243763073
“The _fingers_,” resumed the Jesuit, “St. Peter blessed with the	361.30769057196943
_fingers_. The Pope, therefore blesses with the fingers. And with how	441.6301350573028
many fingers does he bless? With _three_ fingers, to be sure—one for	427.3504689746769
the Father, one for the Son, and one for the Holy Ghost.”	476.75168703709136
All crossed themselves. D’Artagnan thought it was proper to follow this	420.59906610385633
example.	323.7923428965617
“The Pope is the successor of St. Peter, and represents the three	434.8310816177654
divine powers; the rest—_ordines inferiores_—of the ecclesiastical	486.1812551946758
hierarchy bless in the name of the holy archangels and angels. The most	431.45034606355387
humble clerks such as our deacons and sacristans, bless with holy water	336.91672103125916
sprinklers, which resemble an infinite number of blessing fingers.	418.1094186714162
There is the subject simplified. _Argumentum omni denudatum ornamento_.	327.76552881732624
I could make of that subject two volumes the size of this,” continued	398.3999221476014
the Jesuit; and in his enthusiasm he struck a St. Chrysostom in folio,	356.74925698314337
which made the table bend beneath its weight.	446.6867460364766
D’Artagnan trembled.	313.52536827229994
“_Certes_,” said Aramis, “I do justice to the beauties of this thesis;	381.0548410944251
but at the same time I perceive it would be overwhelming for me. I had	295.2751444605904
chosen this text—tell me, dear D’Artagnan, if it is not to your	405.75465387416693
taste—‘_Non inutile est desiderium in oblatione_’; that is, ‘A little	490.8831046639875
regret is not unsuitable in an offering to the Lord.’”	427.91627178808005
“Stop there!” cried the Jesuit, “for that thesis touches closely upon	358.9433072411795
heresy. There is a proposition almost like it in the _Augustinus_ of	478.424170108614
the heresiarch Jansenius, whose book will sooner or later be burned by	417.26621113801474
the hands of the executioner. Take care, my young friend. You are	446.92410266440777
inclining toward false doctrines, my young friend; you will be lost.”	353.43667341761636
“You will be lost,” said the curate, shaking his head sorrowfully.	315.493444134827
“You approach that famous point of free will which is a mortal rock.	372.64253184237793
You face the insinuations of the Pelagians and the semi-Pelagians.”	353.425998712265
“But, my Reverend—” replied Aramis, a little amazed by the shower of	299.8112847385392
arguments that poured upon his head.	416.0889332298302
“How will you prove,” continued the Jesuit, without allowing him time	469.8467395717423
to speak, “that we ought to regret the world when we offer ourselves to	325.68921104325835
God? Listen to this dilemma: God is God, and the world is the devil. To	394.29811962365176
regret the world is to regret the devil; that is my conclusion.”	462.07484028308045
“And that is mine also,” said the curate.	428.23564170078976
“But, for heaven’s sake—” resumed Aramis.	378.227466664928
“_Desideras diabolum_, unhappy man!” cried the Jesuit.	320.5818771308951
“He regrets the devil! Ah, my young friend,” added the curate,	344.9999430906662
groaning, “do not regret the devil, I implore you!”	458.0479494157912
D’Artagnan felt himself bewildered. It seemed to him as though he were	443.5780821639216
in a madhouse, and was becoming as mad as those he saw. He was,	393.384884708774
however, forced to hold his tongue from not comprehending half the	350.628837225545
language they employed.	379.3452679322078
“But listen to me, then,” resumed Aramis with politeness mingled with a	322.85274948093746
little impatience. “I do not say I regret; no, I will never pronounce	354.62547172018094
that sentence, which would not be orthodox.”	407.65222625370694
The Jesuit raised his hands toward heaven, and the curate did the same.	328.35812309337
“No; but pray grant me that it is acting with an ill grace to offer to	456.5679004930304
the Lord only that with which we are perfectly disgusted! Don’t you	330.2371932673505
think so, D’Artagnan?”	362.5805139983375
“I think so, indeed,” cried he.	392.77227937224836
The Jesuit and the curate quite started from their chairs.	424.3028385435337
“This is the point of departure; it is a syllogism. The world is not	397.0570408397247
wanting in attractions. I quit the world; then I make a sacrifice. Now,	350.1046076908634
the Scripture says positively, ‘Make a sacrifice unto the Lord.’”	488.3134047146833
“That is true,” said his antagonists.	334.96833854199014
“And then,” said Aramis, pinching his ear to make it red, as he rubbed	489.38366263665034
his hands to make them white, “and then I made a certain _rondeau_ upon	351.7193970255396
it last year, which I showed to Monsieur Voiture, and that great man	401.1132463434341
paid me a thousand compliments.”	476.7708629990185
“A _rondeau!_” said the Jesuit, disdainfully.	450.1352464971676
“A _rondeau!_” said the curate, mechanically.	301.0786185907044
“Repeat it! Repeat it!” cried D’Artagnan; “it will make a little	394.3730619695822
change.”	422.5227238365834
“Not so, for it is religious,” replied Aramis; “it is theology in	434.4383656385798
verse.”	386.71614633670265
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan.	404.6353926591648
“Here it is,” said Aramis, with a little look of diffidence, which,	409.5061137726579
however, was not exempt from a shade of hypocrisy:	459.3084764578032
“Vous qui pleurez un passé plein de charmes,	415.6207258972649
    Et qui trainez des jours infortunés,	476.1839297659236
    Tous vos malheurs se verront terminés,	331.7373017760609
Quand à Dieu seul vous offrirez vos larmes,	346.305839386004
        Vous qui pleurez!”	377.20832998762955
“You who weep for pleasures fled,	395.12204080334527
    While dragging on a life of care,	442.37840942617777
    All your woes will melt in air,	383.5335104245323
If to God your tears are shed,	458.5456140221542
        You who weep!”	330.7270933891515
D’Artagnan and the curate appeared pleased. The Jesuit persisted in his	349.3797729322265
opinion. “Beware of a profane taste in your theological style. What	379.28439575592836
says Augustine on this subject: ‘_Severus sit clericorum verbo_.’”	489.1808552368261
“Yes, let the sermon be clear,” said the curate.	361.58468791827755
“Now,” hastily interrupted the Jesuit, on seeing that his acolyte was	306.49396708971955
going astray, “now your thesis would please the ladies; it would have	295.01710350033085
the success of one of Monsieur Patru’s pleadings.”	341.146647894172
“Please God!” cried Aramis, transported.	349.15267528995014
“There it is,” cried the Jesuit; “the world still speaks within you in	435.42998748472877
a loud voice, _altisimâ voce_. You follow the world, my young friend,	488.35777261731516
and I tremble lest grace prove not efficacious.”	413.0772964885977
“Be satisfied, my reverend father, I can answer for myself.”	336.8598201572814
“Mundane presumption!”	415.0547248681704
“I know myself, Father; my resolution is irrevocable.”	422.3514908916719
“Then you persist in continuing that thesis?”	386.3818776197141
“I feel myself called upon to treat that, and no other. I will see	302.45514524601856
about the continuation of it, and tomorrow I hope you will be satisfied	445.8387569149246
with the corrections I shall have made in consequence of your advice.”	296.20905830876814
“Work slowly,” said the curate; “we leave you in an excellent tone of	352.76730637091003
mind.”	444.4216723661815
“Yes, the ground is all sown,” said the Jesuit, “and we have not to	415.4043143056492
fear that one portion of the seed may have fallen upon stone, another	476.27269291586254
upon the highway, or that the birds of heaven have eaten the rest,	312.9462205827784
_aves cœli comederunt illam_.”	382.977119890332
“Plague stifle you and your Latin!” said D’Artagnan, who began to feel	344.9181135846133
all his patience exhausted.	446.2465298132139
“Farewell, my son,” said the curate, “till tomorrow.”	410.7989435244143
“Till tomorrow, rash youth,” said the Jesuit. “You promise to become	470.13155576227155
one of the lights of the Church. Heaven grant that this light prove not	299.39010955298306
a devouring fire!”	357.713722603976
D’Artagnan, who for an hour past had been gnawing his nails with	421.7067240648271
impatience, was beginning to attack the quick.	470.423241912217
The two men in black rose, bowed to Aramis and D’Artagnan, and advanced	431.7288147832464
toward the door. Bazin, who had been standing listening to all this	299.8101057114342
controversy with a pious jubilation, sprang toward them, took the	475.43259357895704
breviary of the curate and the missal of the Jesuit, and walked	364.62216550999096
respectfully before them to clear their way.	484.0419631254359
Aramis conducted them to the foot of the stairs, and then immediately	391.03839698710334
came up again to D’Artagnan, whose senses were still in a state of	314.8352321869012
confusion.	382.10471643083645
When left alone, the two friends at first kept an embarrassed silence.	462.9089560049049
It however became necessary for one of them to break it first, and as	470.3803703291055
D’Artagnan appeared determined to leave that honor to his companion,	329.1685992782491
Aramis said, “you see that I am returned to my fundamental ideas.”	319.2290679234033
“Yes, efficacious grace has touched you, as that gentleman said just	381.31389935220113
now.”	352.8192595308619
“Oh, these plans of retreat have been formed for a long time. You have	303.53303764437345
often heard me speak of them, have you not, my friend?”	471.7735960702828
“Yes; but I confess I always thought you jested.”	422.7765807048389
“With such things! Oh, D’Artagnan!”	425.88809715461684
“The devil! Why, people jest with death.”	418.5571124224198
“And people are wrong, D’Artagnan; for death is the door which leads to	361.5361723535526
perdition or to salvation.”	421.87201690708326
“Granted; but if you please, let us not theologize, Aramis. You must	466.08808250094637
have had enough for today. As for me, I have almost forgotten the	383.222313995616
little Latin I have ever known. Then I confess to you that I have eaten	441.7076301962975
nothing since ten o’clock this morning, and I am devilish hungry.”	360.6418155163839
“We will dine directly, my friend; only you must please to remember	415.51263931813554
that this is Friday. Now, on such a day I can neither eat flesh nor see	336.43945531972093
it eaten. If you can be satisfied with my dinner—it consists of cooked	308.63800280708796
tetragones and fruits.”	409.4645566545543
“What do you mean by tetragones?” asked D’Artagnan, uneasily.	397.15237341691363
“I mean spinach,” replied Aramis; “but on your account I will add some	304.9607045301773
eggs, and that is a serious infraction of the rule—for eggs are meat,	334.6651416172301
since they engender chickens.”	334.93067364352436
“This feast is not very succulent; but never mind, I will put up with	383.9502851802979
it for the sake of remaining with you.”	306.66568416584926
“I am grateful to you for the sacrifice,” said Aramis; “but if your	434.0175997239811
body be not greatly benefited by it, be assured your soul will.”	413.5992227321539
“And so, Aramis, you are decidedly going into the Church? What will our	312.6466633436613
two friends say? What will Monsieur de Tréville say? They will treat	334.68283102952125
you as a deserter, I warn you.”	380.04150274738674
“I do not enter the Church; I re-enter it. I deserted the Church for	306.2034901396767
the world, for you know that I forced myself when I became a	326.0099639563913
Musketeer.”	394.80874962107947
“I? I know nothing about it.”	429.823062866775
“You don’t know I quit the seminary?”	486.5303259248755
“Not at all.”	381.9063445321515
“This is my story, then. Besides, the Scriptures say, ‘Confess	295.1360852044962
yourselves to one another,’ and I confess to you, D’Artagnan.”	408.0230454457203
“And I give you absolution beforehand. You see I am a good sort of a	468.63381002802623
man.”	382.9074893776819
“Do not jest about holy things, my friend.”	340.05653212390985
“Go on, then, I listen.”	335.00149801098274
“I had been at the seminary from nine years old; in three days I should	471.9722594865592
have been twenty. I was about to become an abbé, and all was arranged.	487.17601172732657
One evening I went, according to custom, to a house which I frequented	393.8939717411158
with much pleasure: when one is young, what can be expected?—one is	302.06042869750314
weak. An officer who saw me, with a jealous eye, reading the _Lives of	465.1898794987151
the Saints_ to the mistress of the house, entered suddenly and without	407.68108438233975
being announced. That evening I had translated an episode of Judith,	308.0827804159374
and had just communicated my verses to the lady, who gave me all sorts	476.81499630288823
of compliments, and leaning on my shoulder, was reading them a second	380.88389490577316
time with me. Her pose, which I must admit was rather free, wounded	303.102392435666
this officer. He said nothing; but when I went out he followed, and	479.764202588883
quickly came up with me. ‘Monsieur the Abbé,’ said he, ‘do you like	309.4392974564336
blows with a cane?’ ‘I cannot say, monsieur,’ answered I; ‘no one has	412.33758111568
ever dared to give me any.’ ‘Well, listen to me, then, Monsieur the	366.9733756988579
Abbé! If you venture again into the house in which I have met you this	457.26585380841715
evening, I will dare it myself.’ I really think I must have been	477.19367332939123
frightened. I became very pale; I felt my legs fail me; I sought for a	304.30821319784286
reply, but could find none—I was silent. The officer waited for his	479.31613090095397
reply, and seeing it so long coming, he burst into a laugh, turned upon	302.75223063129283
his heel, and re-entered the house. I returned to the seminary.	448.0624457635787
“I am a gentleman born, and my blood is warm, as you may have remarked,	338.4938269532349
my dear D’Artagnan. The insult was terrible, and although unknown to	417.3738968441219
the rest of the world, I felt it live and fester at the bottom of my	321.1029495862181
heart. I informed my superiors that I did not feel myself sufficiently	378.5846939328146
prepared for ordination, and at my request the ceremony was postponed	360.28893592273903
for a year. I sought out the best fencing master in Paris, I made an	335.0176181949911
agreement with him to take a lesson every day, and every day for a year	469.4745839878041
I took that lesson. Then, on the anniversary of the day on which I had	334.6678419654409
been insulted, I hung my cassock on a peg, assumed the costume of a	354.2470359541424
cavalier, and went to a ball given by a lady friend of mine and to	317.4743994046893
which I knew my man was invited. It was in the Rue des	428.9928469404631
France-Bourgeois, close to La Force. As I expected, my officer was	421.88934746569896
there. I went up to him as he was singing a love ditty and looking	371.52641121934323
tenderly at a lady, and interrupted him exactly in the middle of the	298.67468429203035
second couplet. ‘Monsieur,’ said I, ‘does it still displease you that I	355.36440731041733
should frequent a certain house of La Rue Payenne? And would you still	355.9384772165756
cane me if I took it into my head to disobey you? The officer looked at	421.41535047103025
me with astonishment, and then said, ‘What is your business with me,	432.1340126132761
monsieur? I do not know you.’ ‘I am,’ said I, ‘the little abbé who	364.71726902813225
reads _Lives of the Saints_, and translates Judith into verse.’ ‘Ah,	355.470048188624
ah! I recollect now,’ said the officer, in a jeering tone; ‘well, what	382.41653943910256
do you want with me?’ ‘I want you to spare time to take a walk with	443.39503638550804
me.’ ‘Tomorrow morning, if you like, with the greatest pleasure.’ ‘No,	448.9523123676671
not tomorrow morning, if you please, but immediately.’ ‘If you	371.2890965993487
absolutely insist.’ ‘I do insist upon it.’ ‘Come, then. Ladies,’ said	372.5396754340179
the officer, ‘do not disturb yourselves; allow me time just to kill	384.9097687778574
this gentleman, and I will return and finish the last couplet.’	469.1962833608948
“We went out. I took him to the Rue Payenne, to exactly the same spot	327.2218556178963
where, a year before, at the very same hour, he had paid me the	401.6317332153087
compliment I have related to you. It was a superb moonlight night. We	379.05645266217675
immediately drew, and at the first pass I laid him stark dead.”	345.42531426186963
“The devil!” cried D’Artagnan.	448.6468274708264
“Now,” continued Aramis, “as the ladies did not see the singer come	477.16707983726053
back, and as he was found in the Rue Payenne with a great sword wound	325.00827488294965
through his body, it was supposed that I had accommodated him thus; and	297.5090154669014
the matter created some scandal which obliged me to renounce the	366.7170619961141
cassock for a time. Athos, whose acquaintance I made about that period,	455.5201963372796
and Porthos, who had in addition to my lessons taught me some effective	374.7902539437508
tricks of fence, prevailed upon me to solicit the uniform of a	485.2140624973095
Musketeer. The king entertained great regard for my father, who had	308.04282139270157
fallen at the siege of Arras, and the uniform was granted. You may	484.3200946700869
understand that the moment has come for me to re-enter the bosom of the	320.64571497828524
Church.”	396.7404367830776
“And why today, rather than yesterday or tomorrow? What has happened to	407.49114835365833
you today, to raise all these melancholy ideas?”	306.2614044178133
“This wound, my dear D’Artagnan, has been a warning to me from heaven.”	451.2475440574202
“This wound? Bah, it is now nearly healed, and I am sure it is not that	311.50434394174465
which gives you the most pain.”	399.61504173135313
“What, then?” said Aramis, blushing.	434.2202225398462
“You have one at heart, Aramis, one deeper and more painful—a wound	407.8505795622718
made by a woman.”	443.18594985007076
The eye of Aramis kindled in spite of himself.	369.0658055377976
“Ah,” said he, dissembling his emotion under a feigned carelessness,	315.7725417471023
“do not talk of such things, and suffer love pains? _Vanitas	406.0382097288751
vanitatum!_ According to your idea, then, my brain is turned. And for	462.8213971018374
whom—for some _grisette_, some chambermaid with whom I have trifled in	446.57371931667774
some garrison? Fie!”	358.3009596237597
“Pardon, my dear Aramis, but I thought you carried your eyes higher.”	330.48488682774166
“Higher? And who am I, to nourish such ambition? A poor Musketeer, a	372.84195613874897
beggar, an unknown—who hates slavery, and finds himself ill-placed in	407.4098318123397
the world.”	425.62794252655226
“Aramis, Aramis!” cried D’Artagnan, looking at his friend with an air	420.5367504770257
of doubt.	402.0829721781596
“Dust I am, and to dust I return. Life is full of humiliations and	346.1940251438931
sorrows,” continued he, becoming still more melancholy; “all the ties	405.6758812266903
which attach him to life break in the hand of man, particularly the	327.1797526167081
golden ties. Oh, my dear D’Artagnan,” resumed Aramis, giving to his	488.97616257156744
voice a slight tone of bitterness, “trust me! Conceal your wounds when	329.09678445712507
you have any; silence is the last joy of the unhappy. Beware of giving	473.7117837718993
anyone the clue to your griefs; the curious suck our tears as flies	324.8266556262278
suck the blood of a wounded hart.”	486.648715595359
“Alas, my dear Aramis,” said D’Artagnan, in his turn heaving a profound	337.97493611149144
sigh, “that is my story you are relating!”	457.4043235841078
“How?”	320.4508651523813
“Yes; a woman whom I love, whom I adore, has just been torn from me by	429.81022628209394
force. I do not know where she is or whither they have conducted her.	381.68415318181417
She is perhaps a prisoner; she is perhaps dead!”	394.1259768502424
“Yes, but you have at least this consolation, that you can say to	388.2886760079875
yourself she has not quit you voluntarily, that if you learn no news of	480.63457144466537
her, it is because all communication with you is interdicted; while I—”	490.86700165874606
“Well?”	442.953328611313
“Nothing,” replied Aramis, “nothing.”	365.90203585362474
“So you renounce the world, then, forever; that is a settled thing—a	404.95105994946425
resolution registered!”	389.2275688323192
“Forever! You are my friend today; tomorrow you will be no more to me	308.3498161864747
than a shadow, or rather, even, you will no longer exist. As for the	480.87814119934785
world, it is a sepulcher and nothing else.”	414.81310077144735
“The devil! All this is very sad which you tell me.”	309.1494694763636
“What will you? My vocation commands me; it carries me away.”	419.32330803095067
D’Artagnan smiled, but made no answer.	306.1628349378058
Aramis continued, “And yet, while I do belong to the earth, I wish to	485.89631596823875
speak of you—of our friends.”	439.6675293019545
“And on my part,” said D’Artagnan, “I wished to speak of you, but I	337.0677502086447
find you so completely detached from everything! To love you cry, ‘Fie!	294.4229679130058
Friends are shadows! The world is a sepulcher!’”	418.98120003637473
“Alas, you will find it so yourself,” said Aramis, with a sigh.	315.0436115041641
“Well, then, let us say no more about it,” said D’Artagnan; “and let us	444.3786614011993
burn this letter, which, no doubt, announces to you some fresh	409.8008831832119
infidelity of your _grisette_ or your chambermaid.”	322.20690191044844
“What letter?” cried Aramis, eagerly.	405.1888654916148
“A letter which was sent to your abode in your absence, and which was	487.51319131252137
given to me for you.”	301.6968296232012
“But from whom is that letter?”	396.20758640334367
“Oh, from some heartbroken waiting woman, some desponding _grisette;_	298.38993713070806
from Madame de Chevreuse’s chambermaid, perhaps, who was obliged to	448.9401541678257
return to Tours with her mistress, and who, in order to appear smart	339.9904060836683
and attractive, stole some perfumed paper, and sealed her letter with a	442.6261803899249
duchess’s coronet.”	313.6036222786407
“What do you say?”	335.1082729221558
“Hold! I must have lost it,” said the young man maliciously, pretending	338.8817379546369
to search for it. “But fortunately the world is a sepulcher; the men,	489.23047502825455
and consequently the women, are but shadows, and love is a sentiment to	385.82094355369014
which you cry, ‘Fie! Fie!’”	384.21065976993737
“D’Artagnan, D’Artagnan,” cried Aramis, “you are killing me!”	413.35478161416756
“Well, here it is at last!” said D’Artagnan, as he drew the letter from	367.1350581509512
his pocket.	344.8403293350895
Aramis made a bound, seized the letter, read it, or rather devoured it,	468.236429983477
his countenance radiant.	322.9918782628117
“This same waiting maid seems to have an agreeable style,” said the	336.428478505308
messenger, carelessly.	463.57764504937796
“Thanks, D’Artagnan, thanks!” cried Aramis, almost in a state of	455.71795759246766
delirium. “She was forced to return to Tours; she is not faithless; she	391.74972700363827
still loves me! Come, my friend, come, let me embrace you. Happiness	395.8455162190898
almost stifles me!”	467.2282059311998
The two friends began to dance around the venerable St. Chrysostom,	438.7616115756209
kicking about famously the sheets of the thesis, which had fallen on	349.42609284475947
the floor.	481.4951814213912
At that moment Bazin entered with the spinach and the omelet.	465.9733580147743
“Be off, you wretch!” cried Aramis, throwing his skullcap in his face.	360.98705211942683
“Return whence you came; take back those horrible vegetables, and that	372.4232693236531
poor kickshaw! Order a larded hare, a fat capon, mutton leg dressed	439.2763843704332
with garlic, and four bottles of old Burgundy.”	471.21483110395536
Bazin, who looked at his master, without comprehending the cause of	331.3919916233368
this change, in a melancholy manner, allowed the omelet to slip into	371.1324762142274
the spinach, and the spinach onto the floor.	446.60026403763163
“Now this is the moment to consecrate your existence to the King of	413.2068624362586
kings,” said D’Artagnan, “if you persist in offering him a civility.	345.61174162912965
_Non inutile desiderium oblatione_.”	466.85755648640566
“Go to the devil with your Latin. Let us drink, my dear D’Artagnan,	386.8748660326614
_morbleu!_ Let us drink while the wine is fresh! Let us drink heartily,	460.57718127496156
and while we do so, tell me a little of what is going on in the world	413.60237813833345
yonder.”	411.58991265379694
Chapter XXVII.	457.6603463176225
THE WIFE OF ATHOS	447.17934494841006
We have now to search for Athos,” said D’Artagnan to the vivacious	469.36031970754243
Aramis, when he had informed him of all that had passed since their	469.1123772586778
departure from the capital, and an excellent dinner had made one of	391.1238453786658
them forget his thesis and the other his fatigue.	302.9905809057265
“Do you think, then, that any harm can have happened to him?” asked	486.60883890552475
Aramis. “Athos is so cool, so brave, and handles his sword so	461.7983087978738
skillfully.”	398.2806695774809
“No doubt. Nobody has a higher opinion of the courage and skill of	307.6742163833442
Athos than I have; but I like better to hear my sword clang against	491.8288404938403
lances than against staves. I fear lest Athos should have been beaten	341.8007476050805
down by serving men. Those fellows strike hard, and don’t leave off in	349.4040607206817
a hurry. This is why I wish to set out again as soon as possible.”	476.79963380893764
“I will try to accompany you,” said Aramis, “though I scarcely feel in	452.88305557673505
a condition to mount on horseback. Yesterday I undertook to employ that	459.6649284711208
cord which you see hanging against the wall, but pain prevented my	316.8881555740124
continuing the pious exercise.”	382.77720416680575
“That’s the first time I ever heard of anybody trying to cure gunshot	347.07576872558155
wounds with cat-o’-nine-tails; but you were ill, and illness renders	376.4671404580804
the head weak, therefore you may be excused.”	410.5180148391275
“When do you mean to set out?”	315.415417496624
“Tomorrow at daybreak. Sleep as soundly as you can tonight, and	357.0389646383686
tomorrow, if you can, we will take our departure together.”	452.3271702272202
“Till tomorrow, then,” said Aramis; “for iron-nerved as you are, you	299.75688270793376
must need repose.”	471.1975672944732
The next morning, when D’Artagnan entered Aramis’s chamber, he found	382.2596776556149
him at the window.	310.6010477755767
“What are you looking at?” asked D’Artagnan.	387.1618209350577
“My faith! I am admiring three magnificent horses which the stable boys	481.72429900804485
are leading about. It would be a pleasure worthy of a prince to travel	394.22509589501794
upon such horses.”	338.8694248558355
“Well, my dear Aramis, you may enjoy that pleasure, for one of those	465.6351835032936
three horses is yours.”	292.2729013366228
“Ah, bah! Which?”	457.86754656608355
“Whichever of the three you like, I have no preference.”	372.1225107208093
“And the rich caparison, is that mine, too?”	423.85807183323243
“Without doubt.”	384.2699691212911
“You laugh, D’Artagnan.”	443.0350265944154
“No, I have left off laughing, now that you speak French.”	411.4451458463127
“What, those rich holsters, that velvet housing, that saddle studded	465.4025037964382
with silver—are they all for me?”	357.3037026325734
“For you and nobody else, as the horse which paws the ground is mine,	349.26043331822586
and the other horse, which is caracoling, belongs to Athos.”	447.3519415405929
“_Peste!_ They are three superb animals!”	473.5205606173994
“I am glad they please you.”	322.46060173724766
“Why, it must have been the king who made you such a present.”	466.64167220807224
“Certainly it was not the cardinal; but don’t trouble yourself whence	312.8759135727344
they come, think only that one of the three is your property.”	316.6373590724942
“I choose that which the red-headed boy is leading.”	410.56162781536926
“It is yours!”	317.1881919381995
“Good heaven! That is enough to drive away all my pains; I could mount	444.3785048052325
him with thirty balls in my body. On my soul, handsome stirrups!	354.04381655935344
_Holà_, Bazin, come here this minute.”	443.2340363203927
Bazin appeared on the threshold, dull and spiritless.	387.234542131379
“That last order is useless,” interrupted D’Artagnan; “there are loaded	415.4184482850228
pistols in your holsters.”	452.99431419687926
Bazin sighed.	296.9150630229227
“Come, Monsieur Bazin, make yourself easy,” said D’Artagnan; “people of	447.7445850164635
all conditions gain the kingdom of heaven.”	433.40373706325903
“Monsieur was already such a good theologian,” said Bazin, almost	334.3988758137769
weeping; “he might have become a bishop, and perhaps a cardinal.”	421.47210900253333
“Well, but my poor Bazin, reflect a little. Of what use is it to be a	349.0178583885849
churchman, pray? You do not avoid going to war by that means; you see,	308.2276270576171
the cardinal is about to make the next campaign, helm on head and	448.22925893747276
partisan in hand. And Monsieur de Nogaret de la Valette, what do you	413.7941163933346
say of him? He is a cardinal likewise. Ask his lackey how often he has	335.75119618458564
had to prepare lint of him.”	337.3231086098906
“Alas!” sighed Bazin. “I know it, monsieur; everything is turned	327.00376474287816
topsy-turvy in the world nowadays.”	360.7231411928767
While this dialogue was going on, the two young men and the poor lackey	375.5583358462175
descended.	483.53853453146587
“Hold my stirrup, Bazin,” cried Aramis; and Aramis sprang into the	430.8421955560956
saddle with his usual grace and agility, but after a few vaults and	480.50193776950664
curvets of the noble animal his rider felt his pains come on so	346.3918393008236
insupportably that he turned pale and became unsteady in his seat.	389.9669180275513
D’Artagnan, who, foreseeing such an event, had kept his eye on him,	327.1912330887738
sprang toward him, caught him in his arms, and assisted him to his	454.2672511419347
chamber.	469.97650220995683
“That’s all right, my dear Aramis, take care of yourself,” said he; “I	328.3829446152657
will go alone in search of Athos.”	324.6121937605701
“You are a man of brass,” replied Aramis.	340.2469211589198
“No, I have good luck, that is all. But how do you mean to pass your	363.50002958884215
time till I come back? No more theses, no more glosses upon the fingers	313.6003433141288
or upon benedictions, hey?”	326.3900315270582
Aramis smiled. “I will make verses,” said he.	462.5757134929296
“Yes, I dare say; verses perfumed with the odor of the billet from the	298.73022632288485
attendant of Madame de Chevreuse. Teach Bazin prosody; that will	421.119696703719
console him. As to the horse, ride him a little every day, and that	404.1902875059772
will accustom you to his maneuvers.”	397.6796743134595
“Oh, make yourself easy on that head,” replied Aramis. “You will find	448.14880489858984
me ready to follow you.”	340.6798094858698
They took leave of each other, and in ten minutes, after having	401.970468165218
commended his friend to the cares of the hostess and Bazin, D’Artagnan	481.8889026787983
was trotting along in the direction of Amiens.	405.81402684592416
How was he going to find Athos? Should he find him at all? The position	301.61838912222265
in which he had left him was critical. He probably had succumbed. This	358.2096601317208
idea, while darkening his brow, drew several sighs from him, and caused	308.8163070715969
him to formulate to himself a few vows of vengeance. Of all his	299.9595013146094
friends, Athos was the eldest, and the least resembling him in	365.09271587160777
appearance, in his tastes and sympathies.	321.30702797613793
Yet he entertained a marked preference for this gentleman. The noble	483.700018641939
and distinguished air of Athos, those flashes of greatness which from	396.54577396740007
time to time broke out from the shade in which he voluntarily kept	352.2434369187225
himself, that unalterable equality of temper which made him the most	296.597938068953
pleasant companion in the world, that forced and cynical gaiety, that	467.7541569964539
bravery which might have been termed blind if it had not been the	404.42958101622037
result of the rarest coolness—such qualities attracted more than the	326.3308522827043
esteem, more than the friendship of D’Artagnan; they attracted his	392.4186270158909
admiration.	440.7315062378083
Indeed, when placed beside M. de Tréville, the elegant and noble	398.8666822358625
courtier, Athos in his most cheerful days might advantageously sustain	326.7782815047366
a comparison. He was of middle height; but his person was so admirably	319.26699513536266
shaped and so well proportioned that more than once in his struggles	371.60647100167665
with Porthos he had overcome the giant whose physical strength was	458.03043304350524
proverbial among the Musketeers. His head, with piercing eyes, a	307.2603195391197
straight nose, a chin cut like that of Brutus, had altogether an	352.8230089822672
indefinable character of grandeur and grace. His hands, of which he	313.01737149552554
took little care, were the despair of Aramis, who cultivated his with	462.95707972753854
almond paste and perfumed oil. The sound of his voice was at once	384.4683623834012
penetrating and melodious; and then, that which was inconceivable in	316.6278043863422
Athos, who was always retiring, was that delicate knowledge of the	475.0148006498793
world and of the usages of the most brilliant society—those manners of	425.91111568804394
a high degree which appeared, as if unconsciously to himself, in his	346.808819108815
least actions.	443.2606742810445
If a repast were on foot, Athos presided over it better than any other,	454.60305845363115
placing every guest exactly in the rank which his ancestors had earned	311.5779341531432
for him or that he had made for himself. If a question in heraldry were	422.059334324058
started, Athos knew all the noble families of the kingdom, their	442.19429125984345
genealogy, their alliances, their coats of arms, and the origin of	414.8300118966068
them. Etiquette had no minutiæ unknown to him. He knew what were the	368.8082739017131
rights of the great land owners. He was profoundly versed in hunting	430.843246781542
and falconry, and had one day when conversing on this great art	329.0419105239281
astonished even Louis XIII. himself, who took a pride in being	338.5684596572854
considered a past master therein.	401.18914678104034
Like all the great nobles of that period, Athos rode and fenced to	416.3329930719519
perfection. But still further, his education had been so little	456.3993892156115
neglected, even with respect to scholastic studies, so rare at this	406.0706334543551
time among gentlemen, that he smiled at the scraps of Latin which	468.65873340777773
Aramis sported and which Porthos pretended to understand. Two or three	390.9256231582536
times, even, to the great astonishment of his friends, he had, when	294.1574866760325
Aramis allowed some rudimental error to escape him, replaced a verb in	408.58540389975275
its right tense and a noun in its case. Besides, his probity was	483.8646260566278
irreproachable, in an age in which soldiers compromised so easily with	292.18201741108396
their religion and their consciences, lovers with the rigorous delicacy	347.98702014973566
of our era, and the poor with God’s Seventh Commandment. This Athos,	454.03251759202834
then, was a very extraordinary man.	413.6454121093773
And yet this nature so distinguished, this creature so beautiful, this	388.1038635142686
essence so fine, was seen to turn insensibly toward material life, as	373.1072121244239
old men turn toward physical and moral imbecility. Athos, in his hours	479.62489251701436
of gloom—and these hours were frequent—was extinguished as to the whole	427.0036686391678
of the luminous portion of him, and his brilliant side disappeared as	475.3351966619787
into profound darkness.	453.02119731714663
Then the demigod vanished; he remained scarcely a man. His head hanging	345.0933775287073
down, his eye dull, his speech slow and painful, Athos would look for	467.4685297150661
hours together at his bottle, his glass, or at Grimaud, who, accustomed	488.5835195545237
to obey him by signs, read in the faint glance of his master his least	341.88386086887266
desire, and satisfied it immediately. If the four friends were	473.22999014079915
assembled at one of these moments, a word, thrown forth occasionally	323.3986881276832
with a violent effort, was the share Athos furnished to the	358.1142131309148
conversation. In exchange for his silence Athos drank enough for four,	393.13788585591226
and without appearing to be otherwise affected by wine than by a more	294.8455507202061
marked constriction of the brow and by a deeper sadness.	462.28790352473123
D’Artagnan, whose inquiring disposition we are acquainted with, had	384.7883038395148
not—whatever interest he had in satisfying his curiosity on this	300.657210191048
subject—been able to assign any cause for these fits, or for the	373.8347337267557
periods of their recurrence. Athos never received any letters; Athos	483.0967705306191
never had concerns which all his friends did not know.	341.17953927111853
It could not be said that it was wine which produced this sadness; for	378.87825127529123
in truth he only drank to combat this sadness, which wine however, as	477.9981595353232
we have said, rendered still darker. This excess of bilious humor could	398.75362662145255
not be attributed to play; for unlike Porthos, who accompanied the	325.60850811675044
variations of chance with songs or oaths, Athos when he won remained as	371.9714428041749
unmoved as when he lost. He had been known, in the circle of the	437.8108593703224
Musketeers, to win in one night three thousand pistoles; to lose them	312.2449368970163
even to the gold-embroidered belt for gala days, win all this again	393.7488608456116
with the addition of a hundred louis, without his beautiful eyebrow	418.9773451837317
being heightened or lowered half a line, without his hands losing their	394.7740994276996
pearly hue, without his conversation, which was cheerful that evening,	318.6355858693824
ceasing to be calm and agreeable.	460.3437832142539
Neither was it, as with our neighbors, the English, an atmospheric	309.4263481779505
influence which darkened his countenance; for the sadness generally	335.3753014370075
became more intense toward the fine season of the year. June and July	339.6298786416412
were the terrible months with Athos.	399.07958332958884
For the present he had no anxiety. He shrugged his shoulders when	473.9369775249445
people spoke of the future. His secret, then, was in the past, as had	482.35361721505456
often been vaguely said to D’Artagnan.	356.27906630676335
This mysterious shade, spread over his whole person, rendered still	436.6336559373644
more interesting the man whose eyes or mouth, even in the most complete	294.0296890707789
intoxication, had never revealed anything, however skillfully questions	414.98226968130456
had been put to him.	374.6256827146782
“Well,” thought D’Artagnan, “poor Athos is perhaps at this moment dead,	462.8919464430335
and dead by my fault—for it was I who dragged him into this affair, of	327.4046798711285
which he did not know the origin, of which he is ignorant of the	310.99256387227825
result, and from which he can derive no advantage.”	379.11398486592634
“Without reckoning, monsieur,” added Planchet to his master’s audibly	432.7853582428902
expressed reflections, “that we perhaps owe our lives to him. Do you	463.56196769930307
remember how he cried, ‘On, D’Artagnan, on, I am taken’? And when he	362.71662721419733
had discharged his two pistols, what a terrible noise he made with his	491.8306712302747
sword! One might have said that twenty men, or rather twenty mad	296.3186679799687
devils, were fighting.”	429.72456685908134
These words redoubled the eagerness of D’Artagnan, who urged his horse,	474.39063235352796
though he stood in need of no incitement, and they proceeded at a rapid	334.4475245260309
pace. About eleven o’clock in the morning they perceived Amiens, and at	309.97943372438885
half past eleven they were at the door of the cursed inn.	335.22589983607855
D’Artagnan had often meditated against the perfidious host one of those	480.3301717488795
hearty vengeances which offer consolation while they are hoped for. He	391.96560427664343
entered the hostelry with his hat pulled over his eyes, his left hand	430.0751775312515
on the pommel of the sword, and cracking his whip with his right hand.	479.1899929911181
“Do you remember me?” said he to the host, who advanced to greet him.	309.70662119627724
“I have not that honor, monseigneur,” replied the latter, his eyes	461.18155289195954
dazzled by the brilliant style in which D’Artagnan traveled.	470.89157081496637
“What, you don’t know me?”	331.0432595242685
“No, monseigneur.”	482.83586777140545
“Well, two words will refresh your memory. What have you done with that	478.54909896070944
gentleman against whom you had the audacity, about twelve days ago, to	436.8524058623698
make an accusation of passing false money?”	387.8556240361461
The host became as pale as death; for D’Artagnan had assumed a	414.68761092590364
threatening attitude, and Planchet modeled himself after his master.	491.07095161787277
“Ah, monseigneur, do not mention it!” cried the host, in the most	429.3770140576078
pitiable voice imaginable. “Ah, monseigneur, how dearly have I paid for	451.72092093258607
that fault, unhappy wretch as I am!”	454.18385036276845
“That gentleman, I say, what has become of him?”	362.03102166983393
“Deign to listen to me, monseigneur, and be merciful! Sit down, in	328.74432675045546
mercy!”	331.1048049238947
D’Artagnan, mute with anger and anxiety, took a seat in the threatening	350.6010983705029
attitude of a judge. Planchet glared fiercely over the back of his	408.48580224836587
armchair.	469.63830614114136
“Here is the story, monseigneur,” resumed the trembling host; “for I	299.68668444639314
now recollect you. It was you who rode off at the moment I had that	377.84302844924986
unfortunate difference with the gentleman you speak of.”	313.6992572231715
“Yes, it was I; so you may plainly perceive that you have no mercy to	348.35718127516856
expect if you do not tell me the whole truth.”	332.772874933679
“Condescend to listen to me, and you shall know all.”	451.54856499222973
“I listen.”	430.80116540589074
“I had been warned by the authorities that a celebrated coiner of bad	315.42507758540194
money would arrive at my inn, with several of his companions, all	293.2785283062423
disguised as Guards or Musketeers. Monseigneur, I was furnished with a	418.5372033570913
description of your horses, your lackeys, your countenances—nothing was	350.09954784922513
omitted.”	355.3953680003543
“Go on, go on!” said D’Artagnan, who quickly understood whence such an	392.64106231288656
exact description had come.	301.6719872433725
“I took then, in conformity with the orders of the authorities, who	394.94354355049614
sent me a reinforcement of six men, such measures as I thought	397.2728662494646
necessary to get possession of the persons of the pretended coiners.”	468.1576808791739
“Again!” said D’Artagnan, whose ears chafed terribly under the	391.3457064446593
repetition of this word _coiners_.	490.7030249101724
“Pardon me, monseigneur, for saying such things, but they form my	480.67371593907706
excuse. The authorities had terrified me, and you know that an	330.94671157573
innkeeper must keep on good terms with the authorities.”	436.9823252355093
“But once again, that gentleman—where is he? What has become of him? Is	344.69565355263506
he dead? Is he living?”	411.12926319243684
“Patience, monseigneur, we are coming to it. There happened then that	413.5881716264215
which you know, and of which your precipitate departure,” added the	366.29437006885996
host, with an acuteness that did not escape D’Artagnan, “appeared to	311.06008553388443
authorize the issue. That gentleman, your friend, defended himself	413.385316101045
