desperately. His lackey, who, by an unforeseen piece of ill luck, had	490.1604312214696
quarreled with the officers, disguised as stable lads—”	390.2641662060867
“Miserable scoundrel!” cried D’Artagnan, “you were all in the plot,	333.1286374758095
then! And I really don’t know what prevents me from exterminating you	306.684738916881
all.”	489.6299609275686
“Alas, monseigneur, we were not in the plot, as you will soon see.	431.7563434764338
Monsieur your friend (pardon for not calling him by the honorable name	430.55729865002615
which no doubt he bears, but we do not know that name), Monsieur your	343.82787771034344
friend, having disabled two men with his pistols, retreated fighting	354.3679273044094
with his sword, with which he disabled one of my men, and stunned me	318.1469792067778
with a blow of the flat side of it.”	390.8398800752217
“You villain, will you finish?” cried D’Artagnan, “Athos—what has	449.26640244004557
become of Athos?”	299.3519969517207
“While fighting and retreating, as I have told Monseigneur, he found	443.3992004031784
the door of the cellar stairs behind him, and as the door was open, he	367.03734428344615
took out the key, and barricaded himself inside. As we were sure of	486.26173106946396
finding him there, we left him alone.”	294.69527861814123
“Yes,” said D’Artagnan, “you did not really wish to kill; you only	474.78565518774155
wished to imprison him.”	477.92722211527064
“Good God! To imprison him, monseigneur? Why, he imprisoned himself, I	321.59017168029885
swear to you he did. In the first place he had made rough work of it;	293.1724516587001
one man was killed on the spot, and two others were severely wounded.	309.43483259926296
The dead man and the two wounded were carried off by their comrades,	396.6783488513584
and I have heard nothing of either of them since. As for myself, as	370.38694866444496
soon as I recovered my senses I went to Monsieur the Governor, to whom	361.5080871313816
I related all that had passed, and asked, what I should do with my	349.377944556587
prisoner. Monsieur the Governor was all astonishment. He told me he	384.4180232182565
knew nothing about the matter, that the orders I had received did not	452.61471102583994
come from him, and that if I had the audacity to mention his name as	451.4265209731315
being concerned in this disturbance he would have me hanged. It appears	357.5449163768756
that I had made a mistake, monsieur, that I had arrested the wrong	317.34662795535945
person, and that he whom I ought to have arrested had escaped.”	306.57171603971995
“But Athos!” cried D’Artagnan, whose impatience was increased by the	467.5350544727496
disregard of the authorities, “Athos, where is he?”	418.2140132688036
“As I was anxious to repair the wrongs I had done the prisoner,”	374.0835171872874
resumed the innkeeper, “I took my way straight to the cellar in order	411.20276687266863
to set him at liberty. Ah, monsieur, he was no longer a man, he was a	410.3047056033322
devil! To my offer of liberty, he replied that it was nothing but a	437.76073874863744
snare, and that before he came out he intended to impose his own	359.43328829445363
conditions. I told him very humbly—for I could not conceal from myself	485.1424685308467
the scrape I had got into by laying hands on one of his Majesty’s	404.7760987808621
Musketeers—I told him I was quite ready to submit to his conditions.	342.21916522624207
“‘In the first place,’ said he, ‘I wish my lackey placed with me, fully	432.5766755023913
armed.’ We hastened to obey this order; for you will please to	373.094627880237
understand, monsieur, we were disposed to do everything your friend	385.9587541558962
could desire. Monsieur Grimaud (he told us his name, although he does	352.04132666040215
not talk much)—Monsieur Grimaud, then, went down to the cellar, wounded	466.80401953973455
as he was; then his master, having admitted him, barricaded the door	403.19982099428535
afresh, and ordered us to remain quietly in our own bar.”	487.6137898242695
“But where is Athos now?” cried D’Artagnan. “Where is Athos?”	420.40370710447723
“In the cellar, monsieur.”	402.6829690000573
“What, you scoundrel! Have you kept him in the cellar all this time?”	299.91382023112106
“Merciful heaven! No, monsieur! We keep him in the cellar! You do not	401.1477609649771
know what he is about in the cellar. Ah! If you could but persuade him	371.1881871569108
to come out, monsieur, I should owe you the gratitude of my whole life;	459.1393442444504
I should adore you as my patron saint!”	478.2484229403972
“Then he is there? I shall find him there?”	456.1904267733058
“Without doubt you will, monsieur; he persists in remaining there. We	474.5444482928459
every day pass through the air hole some bread at the end of a fork,	373.06870490772747
and some meat when he asks for it; but alas! It is not of bread and	366.28194559074336
meat of which he makes the greatest consumption. I once endeavored to	327.8786376665975
go down with two of my servants; but he flew into terrible rage. I	323.62813781616956
heard the noise he made in loading his pistols, and his servant in	472.0405511481573
loading his musketoon. Then, when we asked them what were their	432.83283258245194
intentions, the master replied that he had forty charges to fire, and	341.2596633270962
that he and his lackey would fire to the last one before he would allow	461.1914846433781
a single soul of us to set foot in the cellar. Upon this I went and	342.348639001748
complained to the governor, who replied that I only had what I	317.7691355734301
deserved, and that it would teach me to insult honorable gentlemen who	295.60247069634073
took up their abode in my house.”	375.860776490062
“So that since that time—” replied D’Artagnan, totally unable to	378.65046848523247
refrain from laughing at the pitiable face of the host.	437.3939156284152
“So from that time, monsieur,” continued the latter, “we have led the	297.5596516184068
most miserable life imaginable; for you must know, monsieur, that all	314.32886587972087
our provisions are in the cellar. There is our wine in bottles, and our	367.5290775144771
wine in casks; the beer, the oil, and the spices, the bacon, and	295.0699806985577
sausages. And as we are prevented from going down there, we are forced	301.7490005423445
to refuse food and drink to the travelers who come to the house; so	361.8183199337973
that our hostelry is daily going to ruin. If your friend remains	384.2629869567871
another week in my cellar I shall be a ruined man.”	310.47476157829965
“And not more than justice, either, you ass! Could you not perceive by	444.3413947141121
our appearance that we were people of quality, and not coiners—say?”	313.623083105602
“Yes, monsieur, you are right,” said the host. “But, hark, hark! There	323.85538909423644
he is!”	476.7204401918881
“Somebody has disturbed him, without doubt,” said D’Artagnan.	363.33382067651183
“But he must be disturbed,” cried the host; “Here are two English	342.856355304046
gentlemen just arrived.”	309.1897939926161
“Well?”	405.023840513813
“Well, the English like good wine, as you may know, monsieur; these	449.2002670304375
have asked for the best. My wife has perhaps requested permission of	294.7791038857569
Monsieur Athos to go into the cellar to satisfy these gentlemen; and	353.86884213818087
he, as usual, has refused. Ah, good heaven! There is the hullabaloo	476.7794831380535
louder than ever!”	467.9475846776716
D’Artagnan, in fact, heard a great noise on the side next the cellar.	418.21542818993777
He rose, and preceded by the host wringing his hands, and followed by	345.4190062375242
Planchet with his musketoon ready for use, he approached the scene of	422.725831748278
action.	473.2156101357331
The two gentlemen were exasperated; they had had a long ride, and were	324.6732924685326
dying with hunger and thirst.	325.86235440567305
“But this is tyranny!” cried one of them, in very good French, though	472.4439453922198
with a foreign accent, “that this madman will not allow these good	482.6699540718819
people access to their own wine! Nonsense, let us break open the door,	294.76764640701055
and if he is too far gone in his madness, well, we will kill him!”	405.14503654748
“Softly, gentlemen!” said D’Artagnan, drawing his pistols from his	312.83991904450426
belt, “you will kill nobody, if you please!”	451.2400547629454
“Good, good!” cried the calm voice of Athos, from the other side of the	378.39695349998374
door, “let them just come in, these devourers of little children, and	312.8939284401358
we shall see!”	391.2316117362736
Brave as they appeared to be, the two English gentlemen looked at each	401.16043909673203
other hesitatingly. One might have thought there was in that cellar one	398.1187910542481
of those famished ogres—the gigantic heroes of popular legends, into	364.23684556329056
whose cavern nobody could force their way with impunity.	488.1680870306478
There was a moment of silence; but at length the two Englishmen felt	339.9988617002818
ashamed to draw back, and the angrier one descended the five or six	454.49582427272907
steps which led to the cellar, and gave a kick against the door enough	469.2261261368091
to split a wall.	419.21159302738045
“Planchet,” said D’Artagnan, cocking his pistols, “I will take charge	490.6648838363302
of the one at the top; you look to the one below. Ah, gentlemen, you	487.5776440317868
want battle; and you shall have it.”	327.1493286454907
“Good God!” cried the hollow voice of Athos, “I can hear D’Artagnan, I	392.63853825614393
think.”	306.0537186725966
“Yes,” cried D’Artagnan, raising his voice in turn, “I am here, my	433.78339946851014
friend.”	440.4026781656628
“Ah, good, then,” replied Athos, “we will teach them, these door	362.437236557285
breakers!”	303.53286752897094
The gentlemen had drawn their swords, but they found themselves taken	440.15620224211324
between two fires. They still hesitated an instant; but, as before,	306.04485379279186
pride prevailed, and a second kick split the door from bottom to top.	309.7459081911452
“Stand on one side, D’Artagnan, stand on one side,” cried Athos. “I am	347.94370415923737
going to fire!”	471.08894390802647
“Gentlemen,” exclaimed D’Artagnan, whom reflection never abandoned,	438.00093947969174
“gentlemen, think of what you are about. Patience, Athos! You are	294.20676567470775
running your heads into a very silly affair; you will be riddled. My	359.15101533070083
lackey and I will have three shots at you, and you will get as many	330.60073757301063
from the cellar. You will then have our swords, with which, I can	450.4290720797136
assure you, my friend and I can play tolerably well. Let me conduct	478.9628320155805
your business and my own. You shall soon have something to drink; I	474.57382492326917
give you my word.”	347.6621037107188
“If there is any left,” grumbled the jeering voice of Athos.	309.4979238161614
The host felt a cold sweat creep down his back.	440.6928209683522
“How! ‘If there is any left!’” murmured he.	302.5398842728266
“What the devil! There must be plenty left,” replied D’Artagnan. “Be	395.7903753479768
satisfied of that; these two cannot have drunk all the cellar.	321.01165478831285
Gentlemen, return your swords to their scabbards.”	392.65108464166565
“Well, provided you replace your pistols in your belt.”	388.0515722707514
“Willingly.”	489.99490286105
And D’Artagnan set the example. Then, turning toward Planchet, he made	431.64217088714975
him a sign to uncock his musketoon.	338.6506965544203
The Englishmen, convinced of these peaceful proceedings, sheathed their	385.5246194662003
swords grumblingly. The history of Athos’s imprisonment was then	483.3069657396503
related to them; and as they were really gentlemen, they pronounced the	339.1736799575986
host in the wrong.	304.75809255461814
“Now, gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, “go up to your room again; and in	473.1399336917181
ten minutes, I will answer for it, you shall have all you desire.”	304.9619011856695
The Englishmen bowed and went upstairs.	345.284195300086
“Now I am alone, my dear Athos,” said D’Artagnan; “open the door, I beg	324.1121120319802
of you.”	357.4382930802547
“Instantly,” said Athos.	308.5915916252416
Then was heard a great noise of fagots being removed and of the	292.41832661436365
groaning of posts; these were the counterscarps and bastions of Athos,	312.1475814857895
which the besieged himself demolished.	294.7787822558311
An instant after, the broken door was removed, and the pale face of	479.5638203502075
Athos appeared, who with a rapid glance took a survey of the	377.4685595761024
surroundings.	460.1238985291408
D’Artagnan threw himself on his neck and embraced him tenderly. He then	338.6367778261711
tried to draw him from his moist abode, but to his surprise he	436.32280889902927
perceived that Athos staggered.	488.97360386154435
“You are wounded,” said he.	484.29015893102064
“I! Not at all. I am dead drunk, that’s all, and never did a man more	339.34320772061204
strongly set about getting so. By the Lord, my good host! I must at	338.7356384225651
least have drunk for my part a hundred and fifty bottles.”	460.443658276613
“Mercy!” cried the host, “if the lackey has drunk only half as much as	418.631336821437
the master, I am a ruined man.”	462.26864500562965
“Grimaud is a well-bred lackey. He would never think of faring in the	488.0800995408963
same manner as his master; he only drank from the cask. Hark! I don’t	355.1274461798825
think he put the faucet in again. Do you hear it? It is running now.”	399.4929659293114
D’Artagnan burst into a laugh which changed the shiver of the host into	298.6305445929824
a burning fever.	305.88280074226014
In the meantime, Grimaud appeared in his turn behind his master, with	476.4887067051385
the musketoon on his shoulder, and his head shaking. Like one of those	328.1798904436952
drunken satyrs in the pictures of Rubens. He was moistened before and	407.2545801760573
behind with a greasy liquid which the host recognized as his best olive	375.6311188926139
oil.	324.8537668353585
The four crossed the public room and proceeded to take possession of	393.02982561960147
the best apartment in the house, which D’Artagnan occupied with	381.70033049689675
authority.	301.7630710466747
In the meantime the host and his wife hurried down with lamps into the	428.7804136531287
cellar, which had so long been interdicted to them and where a	334.99498337150305
frightful spectacle awaited them.	337.3902891867182
Beyond the fortifications through which Athos had made a breach in	430.1565373438784
order to get out, and which were composed of fagots, planks, and empty	425.0006071651651
casks, heaped up according to all the rules of the strategic art, they	410.8927497758993
found, swimming in puddles of oil and wine, the bones and fragments of	449.3689121444945
all the hams they had eaten; while a heap of broken bottles filled the	363.5858719839564
whole left-hand corner of the cellar, and a tun, the cock of which was	359.0940996907548
left running, was yielding, by this means, the last drop of its blood.	366.7575553985535
“The image of devastation and death,” as the ancient poet says,	471.2302561962941
“reigned as over a field of battle.”	367.6945358449542
Of fifty large sausages, suspended from the joists, scarcely ten	451.7799616111767
remained.	455.61037444803753
Then the lamentations of the host and hostess pierced the vault of the	356.35426090145893
cellar. D’Artagnan himself was moved by them. Athos did not even turn	434.0054732317767
his head.	481.7843383334467
To grief succeeded rage. The host armed himself with a spit, and rushed	488.8600133024397
into the chamber occupied by the two friends.	362.0320162898821
“Some wine!” said Athos, on perceiving the host.	308.16484914239265
“Some wine!” cried the stupefied host, “some wine? Why you have drunk	479.5658306792301
more than a hundred pistoles’ worth! I am a ruined man, lost,	481.2041994536147
destroyed!”	444.02650712425566
“Bah,” said Athos, “we were always dry.”	473.7050699133289
“If you had been contented with drinking, well and good; but you have	426.0577129572769
broken all the bottles.”	481.8355442248179
“You pushed me upon a heap which rolled down. That was your fault.”	427.5023037234468
“All my oil is lost!”	320.3896003769127
“Oil is a sovereign balm for wounds; and my poor Grimaud here was	342.150832739435
obliged to dress those you had inflicted on him.”	454.7012380368375
“All my sausages are gnawed!”	360.8870562200897
“There is an enormous quantity of rats in that cellar.”	435.17809643207147
“You shall pay me for all this,” cried the exasperated host.	473.4004000127628
“Triple ass!” said Athos, rising; but he sank down again immediately.	403.17009553835265
He had tried his strength to the utmost. D’Artagnan came to his relief	447.13628857997
with his whip in his hand.	390.05701489320904
The host drew back and burst into tears.	304.94186649557196
“This will teach you,” said D’Artagnan, “to treat the guests God sends	326.3252517264685
you in a more courteous fashion.”	481.77540789544327
“God? Say the devil!”	338.94933645886493
“My dear friend,” said D’Artagnan, “if you annoy us in this manner we	346.3551443709481
will all four go and shut ourselves up in your cellar, and we will see	402.91438965901386
if the mischief is as great as you say.”	357.3334247048979
“Oh, gentlemen,” said the host, “I have been wrong. I confess it, but	434.12444878675456
pardon to every sin! You are gentlemen, and I am a poor innkeeper. You	379.32200413296107
will have pity on me.”	406.41971391782124
“Ah, if you speak in that way,” said Athos, “you will break my heart,	430.5475379951387
and the tears will flow from my eyes as the wine flowed from the cask.	402.0721881964286
We are not such devils as we appear to be. Come hither, and let us	367.41575374508403
talk.”	308.46507791586225
The host approached with hesitation.	390.323082102026
“Come hither, I say, and don’t be afraid,” continued Athos. “At the	390.1166432822504
very moment when I was about to pay you, I had placed my purse on the	430.66747265902063
table.”	423.206446853891
“Yes, monsieur.”	425.65312531361076
“That purse contained sixty pistoles; where is it?”	361.9578906079713
“Deposited with the justice; they said it was bad money.”	443.0024438760198
“Very well; get me my purse back and keep the sixty pistoles.”	292.8682876529986
“But Monseigneur knows very well that justice never lets go that which	452.607181830781
it once lays hold of. If it were bad money, there might be some hopes;	399.9583234827702
but unfortunately, those were all good pieces.”	460.21040590127524
“Manage the matter as well as you can, my good man; it does not concern	425.6853757070289
me, the more so as I have not a livre left.”	299.51436259783696
“Come,” said D’Artagnan, “let us inquire further. Athos’s horse, where	388.377432282371
is that?”	460.55470082773013
“In the stable.”	489.2737015583508
“How much is it worth?”	292.0757879918061
“Fifty pistoles at most.”	300.85791569153685
“It’s worth eighty. Take it, and there ends the matter.”	468.0484958522693
“What,” cried Athos, “are you selling my horse—my Bajazet? And pray	367.1330224429604
upon what shall I make my campaign; upon Grimaud?”	428.80389958233434
“I have brought you another,” said D’Artagnan.	462.3967794394026
“Another?”	355.45755862950045
“And a magnificent one!” cried the host.	362.4971156730808
“Well, since there is another finer and younger, why, you may take the	480.4959589298401
old one; and let us drink.”	334.1148493490624
“What?” asked the host, quite cheerful again.	379.74428641081647
“Some of that at the bottom, near the laths. There are twenty-five	322.7509598072879
bottles of it left; all the rest were broken by my fall. Bring six of	466.7856449902318
them.”	362.9773168844996
“Why, this man is a cask!” said the host, aside. “If he only remains	444.4583097229493
here a fortnight, and pays for what he drinks, I shall soon	361.37182852446597
re-establish my business.”	404.35467151447534
“And don’t forget,” said D’Artagnan, “to bring up four bottles of the	489.08857611800966
same sort for the two English gentlemen.”	370.04210069850734
“And now,” said Athos, “while they bring the wine, tell me, D’Artagnan,	306.52448871527747
what has become of the others, come!”	462.40983147570455
D’Artagnan related how he had found Porthos in bed with a strained	432.1351400755081
knee, and Aramis at a table between two theologians. As he finished,	330.6059352298586
the host entered with the wine ordered and a ham which, fortunately for	386.05818228204276
him, had been left out of the cellar.	474.9876956299822
“That’s well!” said Athos, filling his glass and that of his friend;	445.5810108514281
“here’s to Porthos and Aramis! But you, D’Artagnan, what is the matter	384.1546686847134
with you, and what has happened to you personally? You have a sad air.”	442.31858644987625
“Alas,” said D’Artagnan, “it is because I am the most unfortunate.”	341.55014751329935
“Tell me.”	306.34721721799144
“Presently,” said D’Artagnan.	418.178965970063
“Presently! And why presently? Because you think I am drunk?	355.93393636657805
D’Artagnan, remember this! My ideas are never so clear as when I have	359.9262195480772
had plenty of wine. Speak, then, I am all ears.”	337.31641705984526
D’Artagnan related his adventure with Mme. Bonacieux. Athos listened to	343.9450538091986
him without a frown; and when he had finished, said, “Trifles, only	387.11827658398283
trifles!” That was his favorite word.	487.18010674367326
“You always say _trifles_, my dear Athos!” said D’Artagnan, “and that	348.84979178533393
comes very ill from you, who have never loved.”	361.76397787165996
The drink-deadened eye of Athos flashed out, but only for a moment; it	403.1880120933123
became as dull and vacant as before.	398.7849190628048
“That’s true,” said he, quietly, “for my part I have never loved.”	393.85806806721195
“Acknowledge, then, you stony heart,” said D’Artagnan, “that you are	319.4557891309183
wrong to be so hard upon us tender hearts.”	472.01208635363923
“Tender hearts! Pierced hearts!” said Athos.	394.63398662304985
“What do you say?”	475.2433312676925
“I say that love is a lottery in which he who wins, wins death! You are	443.9137854102541
very fortunate to have lost, believe me, my dear D’Artagnan. And if I	408.3284518517252
have any counsel to give, it is, always lose!”	295.2769796306962
“She seemed to love me so!”	351.73855865736334
“She _seemed_, did she?”	363.12587728905254
“Oh, she _did_ love me!”	337.11997467126787
“You child, why, there is not a man who has not believed, as you do,	350.6996822950109
that his mistress loved him, and there lives not a man who has not been	450.21394019737204
deceived by his mistress.”	425.0938588868415
“Except you, Athos, who never had one.”	294.51311017109555
“That’s true,” said Athos, after a moment’s silence, “that’s true! I	385.65488745322773
never had one! Let us drink!”	301.60145817434017
“But then, philosopher that you are,” said D’Artagnan, “instruct me,	378.8611993110258
support me. I stand in need of being taught and consoled.”	384.7366314581392
“Consoled for what?”	469.8208368845468
“For my misfortune.”	414.5783788745414
“Your misfortune is laughable,” said Athos, shrugging his shoulders; “I	416.8560264949649
should like to know what you would say if I were to relate to you a	392.090170996133
real tale of love!”	449.732844394989
“Which has happened to you?”	335.34893727641776
“Or one of my friends, what matters?”	410.795760379703
“Tell it, Athos, tell it.”	293.46835063245913
“Better if I drink.”	324.3764672895778
“Drink and relate, then.”	304.00945987542525
“Not a bad idea!” said Athos, emptying and refilling his glass. “The	331.3262757276349
two things agree marvelously well.”	403.2059406246696
“I am all attention,” said D’Artagnan.	337.3989788352868
Athos collected himself, and in proportion as he did so, D’Artagnan saw	379.3527291979751
that he became pale. He was at that period of intoxication in which	334.95493510965184
vulgar drinkers fall on the floor and go to sleep. He kept himself	312.5663900238303
upright and dreamed, without sleeping. This somnambulism of drunkenness	297.76635929895286
had something frightful in it.	295.2117969348439
“You particularly wish it?” asked he.	297.98075266783695
“I pray for it,” said D’Artagnan.	320.43070722868316
“Be it then as you desire. One of my friends—one of my friends, please	370.1404958987765
to observe, not myself,” said Athos, interrupting himself with a	318.05414245595506
melancholy smile, “one of the counts of my province—that is to say, of	376.32755345984907
Berry—noble as a Dandolo or a Montmorency, at twenty-five years of age	391.1283084024601
fell in love with a girl of sixteen, beautiful as fancy can paint.	401.0783373007406
Through the ingenuousness of her age beamed an ardent mind, not of the	440.6550001280526
woman, but of the poet. She did not please; she intoxicated. She lived	414.5430276581382
in a small town with her brother, who was a curate. Both had recently	375.15058266624476
come into the country. They came nobody knew whence; but when seeing	323.6215273036588
her so lovely and her brother so pious, nobody thought of asking whence	413.93665985096106
they came. They were said, however, to be of good extraction. My	334.7050426398193
friend, who was seigneur of the country, might have seduced her, or	464.45417452207795
taken her by force, at his will—for he was master. Who would have come	297.21229920356967
to the assistance of two strangers, two unknown persons? Unfortunately	454.0690158976274
he was an honorable man; he married her. The fool! The ass! The idiot!”	341.08419215663343
“How so, if he loved her?” asked D’Artagnan.	360.0483783808592
“Wait,” said Athos. “He took her to his château, and made her the first	395.22339286760786
lady in the province; and in justice it must be allowed that she	329.8786561047345
supported her rank becomingly.”	295.2106987794553
“Well?” asked D’Artagnan.	314.5361099635053
“Well, one day when she was hunting with her husband,” continued Athos,	436.7592465373765
in a low voice, and speaking very quickly, “she fell from her horse and	403.3423042077039
fainted. The count flew to her to help, and as she appeared to be	371.1271951764016
oppressed by her clothes, he ripped them open with his poniard, and in	480.49867615990206
so doing laid bare her shoulder. D’Artagnan,” said Athos, with a	311.59964478648317
maniacal burst of laughter, “guess what she had on her shoulder.”	395.9448827591511
“How can I tell?” said D’Artagnan.	434.9855177136466
“A _fleur-de-lis_,” said Athos. “She was branded.”	348.4593770915434
Athos emptied at a single draught the glass he held in his hand.	357.53721892422413
“Horror!” cried D’Artagnan. “What do you tell me?”	480.83854099084033
“Truth, my friend. The angel was a demon; the poor young girl had	298.6683541512926
stolen the sacred vessels from a church.”	393.5310510943369
“And what did the count do?”	392.2835024051813
“The count was of the highest nobility. He had on his estates the	400.6614025825014
rights of high and low tribunals. He tore the dress of the countess to	349.7014587295207
pieces; he tied her hands behind her, and hanged her on a tree.”	473.90505451659897
“Heavens, Athos, a murder?” cried D’Artagnan.	458.4720172076229
“No less,” said Athos, as pale as a corpse. “But methinks I need wine!”	473.8777561978668
and he seized by the neck the last bottle that was left, put it to his	351.6526423431488
mouth, and emptied it at a single draught, as he would have emptied an	460.9861398259161
ordinary glass.	402.86120276981035
Then he let his head sink upon his two hands, while D’Artagnan stood	347.9852642777315
before him, stupefied.	462.3806669952272
“That has cured me of beautiful, poetical, and loving women,” said	294.6321370951081
Athos, after a considerable pause, raising his head, and forgetting to	400.0085198899909
continue the fiction of the count. “God grant you as much! Let us	382.52849210366696
drink.”	425.6520994417182
“Then she is dead?” stammered D’Artagnan.	364.4624803738477
“_Parbleu!_” said Athos. “But hold out your glass. Some ham, my boy, or	372.9936657936534
we can’t drink.”	432.1918564977402
“And her brother?” added D’Artagnan, timidly.	425.94944256368046
“Her brother?” replied Athos.	379.8166562246656
“Yes, the priest.”	373.93208179386613
“Oh, I inquired after him for the purpose of hanging him likewise; but	347.2873078884564
he was beforehand with me, he had quit the curacy the night before.”	462.98726733144247
“Was it ever known who this miserable fellow was?”	390.52277922737017
“He was doubtless the first lover and accomplice of the fair lady. A	408.1113194034331
worthy man, who had pretended to be a curate for the purpose of getting	491.35316124443904
his mistress married, and securing her a position. He has been hanged	453.4360477165587
and quartered, I hope.”	405.60982597765474
“My God, my God!” cried D’Artagnan, quite stunned by the relation of	380.4426039070714
this horrible adventure.	351.37109642499655
“Taste some of this ham, D’Artagnan; it is exquisite,” said Athos,	467.4050867211216
cutting a slice, which he placed on the young man’s plate.	326.08666084174024
“What a pity it is there were only four like this in the cellar. I	489.88853928429273
could have drunk fifty bottles more.”	401.7763591410041
D’Artagnan could no longer endure this conversation, which had made him	320.6428834129023
bewildered. Allowing his head to sink upon his two hands, he pretended	437.0952023309824
to sleep.	422.5710321968316
“These young fellows can none of them drink,” said Athos, looking at	386.684927176279
him with pity, “and yet this is one of the best!”	394.1475851581851
Chapter XXVIII.	299.07596832598347
THE RETURN	477.1820252804463
D’Artagnan was astounded by the terrible confidence of Athos; yet many	307.21034810622666
things appeared very obscure to him in this half revelation. In the	450.0158521107439
first place it had been made by a man quite drunk to one who was half	470.8463769730703
drunk; and yet, in spite of the incertainty which the vapor of three or	332.286494384611
four bottles of Burgundy carries with it to the brain, D’Artagnan, when	363.5929700242652
awaking on the following morning, had all the words of Athos as present	456.6075625276087
to his memory as if they then fell from his mouth—they had been so	302.80832670603627
impressed upon his mind. All this doubt only gave rise to a more lively	471.750144937075
desire of arriving at a certainty, and he went into his friend’s	309.1087332893178
chamber with a fixed determination of renewing the conversation of the	406.56782536697324
preceding evening; but he found Athos quite himself again—that is to	417.2230149826399
say, the most shrewd and impenetrable of men. Besides which, the	307.8991042154483
Musketeer, after having exchanged a hearty shake of the hand with him,	462.0677537670896
broached the matter first.	425.7923066347631
“I was pretty drunk yesterday, D’Artagnan,” said he, “I can tell that	409.28389392841717
by my tongue, which was swollen and hot this morning, and by my pulse,	322.65884402128654
which was very tremulous. I wager that I uttered a thousand	402.76466875093587
extravagances.”	367.8116587303801
While saying this he looked at his friend with an earnestness that	392.51833736080835
embarrassed him.	425.7824749787253
“No,” replied D’Artagnan, “if I recollect well what you said, it was	485.8682222324811
nothing out of the common way.”	440.17453292865923
“Ah, you surprise me. I thought I had told you a most lamentable	341.4028501587962
story.” And he looked at the young man as if he would read the bottom	473.22794245288003
of his heart.	340.31342689217166
“My faith,” said D’Artagnan, “it appears that I was more drunk than	381.3865970185466
you, since I remember nothing of the kind.”	429.0183976584276
Athos did not trust this reply, and he resumed; “you cannot have failed	454.31040671018286
to remark, my dear friend, that everyone has his particular kind of	318.4944327923383
drunkenness, sad or gay. My drunkenness is always sad, and when I am	302.172537476509
thoroughly drunk my mania is to relate all the lugubrious stories which	381.8649499708021
my foolish nurse inculcated into my brain. That is my failing—a capital	377.64217350155553
failing, I admit; but with that exception, I am a good drinker.”	401.41935132623075
Athos spoke this in so natural a manner that D’Artagnan was shaken in	332.1570266385837
his conviction.	487.41115520985215
“It is that, then,” replied the young man, anxious to find out the	444.7412650058309
truth, “it is that, then, I remember as we remember a dream. We were	449.2688238425666
speaking of hanging.”	425.60857049674144
“Ah, you see how it is,” said Athos, becoming still paler, but yet	378.61690983032605
attempting to laugh; “I was sure it was so—the hanging of people is my	443.9764669548915
nightmare.”	479.05021061401396
“Yes, yes,” replied D’Artagnan. “I remember now; yes, it was about—stop	302.6297206626437
a minute—yes, it was about a woman.”	354.5340725852608
“That’s it,” replied Athos, becoming almost livid; “that is my grand	346.41040623679777
story of the fair lady, and when I relate that, I must be very drunk.”	478.5680800250983
“Yes, that was it,” said D’Artagnan, “the story of a tall, fair lady,	359.14844742883633
with blue eyes.”	407.71417317891644
“Yes, who was hanged.”	308.32942765118025
“By her husband, who was a nobleman of your acquaintance,” continued	428.9573550962272
D’Artagnan, looking intently at Athos.	489.58490167165405
“Well, you see how a man may compromise himself when he does not know	438.0799977520313
what he says,” replied Athos, shrugging his shoulders as if he thought	336.6265317901373
himself an object of pity. “I certainly never will get drunk again,	489.97501054558825
D’Artagnan; it is too bad a habit.”	448.79859737259426
D’Artagnan remained silent; and then changing the conversation all at	308.40600190657847
once, Athos said:	407.73207808359166
“By the by, I thank you for the horse you have brought me.”	431.0996904896797
“Is it to your mind?” asked D’Artagnan.	456.6343113658437
“Yes; but it is not a horse for hard work.”	352.60755500710115
“You are mistaken; I rode him nearly ten leagues in less than an hour	297.285656257698
and a half, and he appeared no more distressed than if he had only made	431.52506110509034
the tour of the Place St. Sulpice.”	438.6070132947816
“Ah, you begin to awaken my regret.”	437.60699437024005
“Regret?”	359.5980226255341
“Yes; I have parted with him.”	401.04008389883097
“How?”	331.6979808875572
“Why, here is the simple fact. This morning I awoke at six o’clock. You	367.331892759153
were still fast asleep, and I did not know what to do with myself; I	369.0728093750814
was still stupid from our yesterday’s debauch. As I came into the	409.41134260102444
public room, I saw one of our Englishman bargaining with a dealer for a	478.16701236366214
horse, his own having died yesterday from bleeding. I drew near, and	383.51700346604116
found he was bidding a hundred pistoles for a chestnut nag.	475.0447662036365
‘_Pardieu_,’ said I, ‘my good gentleman, I have a horse to sell, too.’	486.10739291267873
‘Ay, and a very fine one! I saw him yesterday; your friend’s lackey was	350.7517123041099
leading him.’ ‘Do you think he is worth a hundred pistoles?’ ‘Yes! Will	364.7377616873276
you sell him to me for that sum?’ ‘No; but I will play for him.’	382.40384537182035
‘What?’ ‘At dice.’ No sooner said than done, and I lost the horse. Ah,	368.43064231392987
ah! But please to observe I won back the equipage,” cried Athos.	485.6679574547908
D’Artagnan looked much disconcerted.	380.39908933924926
“This vexes you?” said Athos.	374.90408557726164
“Well, I must confess it does,” replied D’Artagnan. “That horse was to	463.03167590780265
have identified us in the day of battle. It was a pledge, a	305.4466385181325
remembrance. Athos, you have done wrong.”	397.28217100988525
“But, my dear friend, put yourself in my place,” replied the Musketeer.	329.74685021996294
“I was hipped to death; and still further, upon my honor, I don’t like	348.05982723425643
English horses. If it is only to be recognized, why the saddle will	327.00856791022045
suffice for that; it is quite remarkable enough. As to the horse, we	349.80626226411295
can easily find some excuse for its disappearance. Why the devil! A	455.5141496997787
horse is mortal; suppose mine had had the glanders or the farcy?”	342.03425579687723
D’Artagnan did not smile.	428.4960171403584
“It vexes me greatly,” continued Athos, “that you attach so much	435.27351073296745
importance to these animals, for I am not yet at the end of my story.”	411.07142170092044
“What else have you done.”	463.9119594447858
“After having lost my own horse, nine against ten—see how near—I formed	299.9938192833289
an idea of staking yours.”	414.7640869310051
“Yes; but you stopped at the idea, I hope?”	357.9247144690041
“No; for I put it in execution that very minute.”	416.39681348605006
“And the consequence?” said D’Artagnan, in great anxiety.	324.0600401530643
“I threw, and I lost.”	366.7743989133261
“What, my horse?”	322.2367606142503
“Your horse, seven against eight; a point short—you know the proverb.”	368.0032715395648
“Athos, you are not in your right senses, I swear.”	356.71764381969206
“My dear lad, that was yesterday, when I was telling you silly stories,	457.9091723940163
it was proper to tell me that, and not this morning. I lost him then,	386.17247727586096
with all his appointments and furniture.”	305.7213096997999
“Really, this is frightful.”	427.9690129403226
“Stop a minute; you don’t know all yet. I should make an excellent	371.8650612785741
gambler if I were not too hot-headed; but I was hot-headed, just as if	341.43234593591876
I had been drinking. Well, I was not hot-headed then—”	336.4715661364144
“Well, but what else could you play for? You had nothing left?”	433.64264594751364
“Oh, yes, my friend; there was still that diamond left which sparkles	439.9967438507166
on your finger, and which I had observed yesterday.”	377.4300063455406
“This diamond!” said D’Artagnan, placing his hand eagerly on his ring.	385.2925244180463
“And as I am a connoisseur in such things, having had a few of my own	442.58445035215794
once, I estimated it at a thousand pistoles.”	403.5571170673127
“I hope,” said D’Artagnan, half dead with fright, “you made no mention	366.85914061353327
of my diamond?”	409.271071248916
“On the contrary, my dear friend, this diamond became our only	399.2382453207555
resource; with it I might regain our horses and their harnesses, and	411.21071899742043
even money to pay our expenses on the road.”	412.5022467888198
“Athos, you make me tremble!” cried D’Artagnan.	456.45593238127435
“I mentioned your diamond then to my adversary, who had likewise	471.49698734818656
remarked it. What the devil, my dear, do you think you can wear a star	348.35362488163196
from heaven on your finger, and nobody observe it? Impossible!”	330.9149590670851
“Go on, go on, my dear fellow!” said D’Artagnan; “for upon my honor,	425.93425227462717
you will kill me with your indifference.”	363.73480385725065
“We divided, then, this diamond into ten parts of a hundred pistoles	319.7843291431358
each.”	436.0967858024447
“You are laughing at me, and want to try me!” said D’Artagnan, whom	398.4729987952928
anger began to take by the hair, as Minerva takes Achilles, in the	340.4137118027245
_Iliad_.	433.3815352217477
“No, I do not jest, _mordieu!_ I should like to have seen you in my	461.38921723110917
place! I had been fifteen days without seeing a human face, and had	377.3794606785302
been left to brutalize myself in the company of bottles.”	412.9547132678009
“That was no reason for staking my diamond!” replied D’Artagnan,	465.7283139819289
closing his hand with a nervous spasm.	421.21946699622595
“Hear the end. Ten parts of a hundred pistoles each, in ten throws,	303.31762094229543
without revenge; in thirteen throws I had lost all—in thirteen throws.	292.74059900243213
The number thirteen was always fatal to me; it was on the thirteenth of	354.81407376636247
July that—”	353.81872374478985
“_Ventrebleu!_” cried D’Artagnan, rising from the table, the story of	411.1332493903413
the present day making him forget that of the preceding one.	407.14870122549155
“Patience!” said Athos; “I had a plan. The Englishman was an original;	490.208242207584
I had seen him conversing that morning with Grimaud, and Grimaud had	351.08237640019206
told me that he had made him proposals to enter into his service. I	450.5574958950853
staked Grimaud, the silent Grimaud, divided into ten portions.”	361.4862347016887
“Well, what next?” said D’Artagnan, laughing in spite of himself.	312.91477618335
“Grimaud himself, understand; and with the ten parts of Grimaud, which	472.958740526808
are not worth a ducatoon, I regained the diamond. Tell me, now, if	463.7879523185064
persistence is not a virtue?”	412.4213811471801
“My faith! But this is droll,” cried D’Artagnan, consoled, and holding	329.4858697458801
his sides with laughter.	339.58783088278193
“You may guess, finding the luck turned, that I again staked the	462.1592304360213
diamond.”	409.49867075908566
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan, becoming angry again.	452.19586864056294
“I won back your harness, then your horse, then my harness, then my	360.32028538670727
horse, and then I lost again. In brief, I regained your harness and	292.25576922313934
then mine. That’s where we are. That was a superb throw, so I left off	432.0773446822797
there.”	483.5208666988109
D’Artagnan breathed as if the whole hostelry had been removed from his	385.9710954516431
breast.	405.17907130826154
“Then the diamond is safe?” said he, timidly.	409.0560301252615
“Intact, my dear friend; besides the harness of your Bucephalus and	360.88454763124616
mine.”	424.76097184596
“But what is the use of harnesses without horses?”	474.43627256809776
“I have an idea about them.”	328.61608551893374
“Athos, you make me shudder.”	326.4892082029334
“Listen to me. You have not played for a long time, D’Artagnan.”	335.2606077923539
“And I have no inclination to play.”	471.5589745150411
“Swear to nothing. You have not played for a long time, I said; you	489.9489382706066
ought, then, to have a good hand.”	414.85527095566715
“Well, what then?”	360.43597752331254
“Well; the Englishman and his companion are still here. I remarked that	324.0389725932862
he regretted the horse furniture very much. You appear to think much of	336.5523064712312
your horse. In your place I would stake the furniture against the	461.0293925161933
horse.”	397.10230161833056
“But he will not wish for only one harness.”	398.8691007766654
“Stake both, _pardieu!_ I am not selfish, as you are.”	318.25888625875257
“You would do so?” said D’Artagnan, undecided, so strongly did the	345.18380033498204
confidence of Athos begin to prevail, in spite of himself.	388.3579745222435
“On my honor, in one single throw.”	337.6252427097752
“But having lost the horses, I am particularly anxious to preserve the	318.0841285743658
harnesses.”	468.6771591028672
“Stake your diamond, then.”	439.59448055414185
“This? That’s another matter. Never, never!”	423.21655642775045
“The devil!” said Athos. “I would propose to you to stake Planchet, but	304.17520496536315
as that has already been done, the Englishman would not, perhaps, be	411.69705440788914
willing.”	451.2466577852842
“Decidedly, my dear Athos,” said D’Artagnan, “I should like better not	459.04065142599416
to risk anything.”	328.63538073751056
“That’s a pity,” said Athos, coolly. “The Englishman is overflowing	437.5152575546599
with pistoles. Good Lord, try one throw! One throw is soon made!”	378.9936086528002
“And if I lose?”	464.32687360795717
“You will win.”	390.9679675127273
“But if I lose?”	292.5174525106562
“Well, you will surrender the harnesses.”	374.9755913933798
“Have with you for one throw!” said D’Artagnan.	320.78991324751354
Athos went in quest of the Englishman, whom he found in the stable,	394.8019668292287
examining the harnesses with a greedy eye. The opportunity was good. He	486.957228405701
proposed the conditions—the two harnesses, either against one horse or	359.8660397758573
a hundred pistoles. The Englishman calculated fast; the two harnesses	334.09415953912645
were worth three hundred pistoles. He consented.	413.5252295344597
D’Artagnan threw the dice with a trembling hand, and turned up the	461.21502122331
number three; his paleness terrified Athos, who, however, consented	311.37615947184344
himself with saying, “That’s a sad throw, comrade; you will have the	350.6787958212808
horses fully equipped, monsieur.”	430.89803168351017
The Englishman, quite triumphant, did not even give himself the trouble	483.97141618867875
to shake the dice. He threw them on the table without looking at them,	407.20551599756413
so sure was he of victory; D’Artagnan turned aside to conceal his ill	433.3897607237632
humor.	412.2467747446847
“Hold, hold, hold!” said Athos, wit his quiet tone; “that throw of the	432.766224083902
dice is extraordinary. I have not seen such a one four times in my	293.41449120643415
life. Two aces!”	491.80936304609355
The Englishman looked, and was seized with astonishment. D’Artagnan	450.38531847151535
looked, and was seized with pleasure.	366.33887165359977
“Yes,” continued Athos, “four times only; once at the house of Monsieur	398.0887015936096
Créquy; another time at my own house in the country, in my château	414.512259415478
at—when I had a château; a third time at Monsieur de Tréville’s where	345.4766580140382
it surprised us all; and the fourth time at a cabaret, where it fell to	468.20791237458195
my lot, and where I lost a hundred louis and a supper on it.”	419.86595111808924
“Then Monsieur takes his horse back again,” said the Englishman.	484.33789767756724
“Certainly,” said D’Artagnan.	298.33809348842885
“Then there is no revenge?”	320.4108137964126
“Our conditions said, ‘No revenge,’ you will please to recollect.”	294.9908716394049
“That is true; the horse shall be restored to your lackey, monsieur.”	374.78453703585575
“A moment,” said Athos; “with your permission, monsieur, I wish to	320.6652022872759
speak a word with my friend.”	396.547129063503
“Say on.”	464.35487126122166
Athos drew D’Artagnan aside.	409.7019387882041
“Well, Tempter, what more do you want with me?” said D’Artagnan. “You	370.8399205569051
want me to throw again, do you not?”	487.05196265181405
“No, I would wish you to reflect.”	436.26546461408157
“On what?”	393.5956738944339
“You mean to take your horse?”	314.00197380261943
“Without doubt.”	316.83590562142734
“You are wrong, then. I would take the hundred pistoles. You know you	333.20628023636067
have staked the harnesses against the horse or a hundred pistoles, at	305.15619441699295
your choice.”	344.7328008112121
“Yes.”	365.5812581242211
“Well, then, I repeat, you are wrong. What is the use of one horse for	327.37261294330455
us two? I could not ride behind. We should look like the two sons of	418.0460020937227
Aymon, who had lost their brother. You cannot think of humiliating me	411.78606046089135
by prancing along by my side on that magnificent charger. For my part,	296.73975987678295
I should not hesitate a moment; I should take the hundred pistoles. We	448.75101960006555
want money for our return to Paris.”	293.3360242671623
“I am much attached to that horse, Athos.”	349.86408298852973
“And there again you are wrong. A horse slips and injures a joint; a	436.29457546773244
horse stumbles and breaks his knees to the bone; a horse eats out of a	406.3314186940822
manger in which a glandered horse has eaten. There is a horse, while on	491.5830813015581
the contrary, the hundred pistoles feed their master.”	473.5278027681644
“But how shall we get back?”	401.6353884436567
“Upon our lackey’s horses, _pardieu_. Anybody may see by our bearing	314.09974647484773
that we are people of condition.”	304.0535982934014
“Pretty figures we shall cut on ponies while Aramis and Porthos	448.8592116015809
caracole on their steeds.”	394.8000340682855
“Aramis! Porthos!” cried Athos, and laughed aloud.	435.62623090372074
“What is it?” asked D’Artagnan, who did not at all comprehend the	315.674554804361
hilarity of his friend.	401.9066957541141
“Nothing, nothing! Go on!”	407.6723500641824
“Your advice, then?”	349.44271132732723
“To take the hundred pistoles, D’Artagnan. With the hundred pistoles we	348.75243222860934
can live well to the end of the month. We have undergone a great deal	372.9042858024954
of fatigue, remember, and a little rest will do no harm.”	484.8226166676735
“I rest? Oh, no, Athos. Once in Paris, I shall prosecute my search for	448.9596467578034
that unfortunate woman!”	393.53009911729487
“Well, you may be assured that your horse will not be half so	366.9774216407597
serviceable to you for that purpose as good golden louis. Take the	431.2374825485718
hundred pistoles, my friend; take the hundred pistoles!”	437.46388027275265
D’Artagnan only required one reason to be satisfied. This last reason	315.92444210851625
appeared convincing. Besides, he feared that by resisting longer he	305.3940780489579
should appear selfish in the eyes of Athos. He acquiesced, therefore,	378.03217519058336
and chose the hundred pistoles, which the Englishman paid down on the	391.5904804052264
spot.	375.6223861278064
They then determined to depart. Peace with the landlord, in addition to	330.9806129649426
Athos’s old horse, cost six pistoles. D’Artagnan and Athos took the	431.75859360808397
nags of Planchet and Grimaud, and the two lackeys started on foot,	371.5150980014332
carrying the saddles on their heads.	309.40362209354544
However ill our two friends were mounted, they were soon far in advance	427.82572585014066
of their servants, and arrived at Crèvecœur. From a distance they	375.52160109775537
perceived Aramis, seated in a melancholy manner at his window, looking	431.8744211838323
out, like Sister Anne, at the dust in the horizon.	376.60244293020446
“_Holà_, Aramis! What the devil are you doing there?” cried the two	338.178346089035
friends.	469.72545042745935
“Ah, is that you, D’Artagnan, and you, Athos?” said the young man. “I	360.82858242047183
was reflecting upon the rapidity with which the blessings of this world	403.264990619917
leave us. My English horse, which has just disappeared amid a cloud of	293.6134383262638
dust, has furnished me with a living image of the fragility of the	305.1081065827231
things of the earth. Life itself may be resolved into three words:	382.077894788143
_Erat, est, fuit_.”	479.92746907151445
“Which means—” said D’Artagnan, who began to suspect the truth.	309.4962629755617
“Which means that I have just been duped—sixty louis for a horse which	474.61444361177905
by the manner of his gait can do at least five leagues an hour.”	409.1089086163673
D’Artagnan and Athos laughed aloud.	471.2315361422329
“My dear D’Artagnan,” said Aramis, “don’t be too angry with me, I beg.	382.15403635584016
Necessity has no law; besides, I am the person punished, as that	363.28633558130616
rascally horsedealer has robbed me of fifty louis, at least. Ah, you	340.79363472049124
fellows are good managers! You ride on our lackey’s horses, and have	422.8693325937971
your own gallant steeds led along carefully by hand, at short stages.”	363.93577947773446
At the same instant a market cart, which some minutes before had	434.8241029133573
appeared upon the Amiens road, pulled up at the inn, and Planchet and	488.2863338581427
Grimaud came out of it with the saddles on their heads. The cart was	370.4984404220928
returning empty to Paris, and the two lackeys had agreed, for their	365.8532467443279
transport, to slake the wagoner’s thirst along the route.	387.22367289720074
“What is this?” said Aramis, on seeing them arrive. “Nothing but	440.0622591374156
saddles?”	445.239225681935
“Now do you understand?” said Athos.	323.17672716225604
“My friends, that’s exactly like me! I retained my harness by instinct.	441.49179120117975
_Holà_, Bazin! Bring my new saddle and carry it along with those of	473.481481062132
these gentlemen.”	305.345008248065
“And what have you done with your ecclesiastics?” asked D’Artagnan.	412.9446136024542
“My dear fellow, I invited them to a dinner the next day,” replied	325.45054792349663
Aramis. “They have some capital wine here—please to observe that in	297.55693430975595
passing. I did my best to make them drunk. Then the curate forbade me	378.8548188514493
to quit my uniform, and the Jesuit entreated me to get him made a	453.23676849680373
Musketeer.”	403.35711199737574
“Without a thesis?” cried D’Artagnan, “without a thesis? I demand the	325.1441556782203
suppression of the thesis.”	414.1092399852332
“Since then,” continued Aramis, “I have lived very agreeably. I have	348.3945099631255
begun a poem in verses of one syllable. That is rather difficult, but	455.0897009387452
the merit in all things consists in the difficulty. The matter is	393.3630987666926
gallant. I will read you the first canto. It has four hundred lines,	302.5130967030145
and lasts a minute.”	318.6451627247418
“My faith, my dear Aramis,” said D’Artagnan, who detested verses almost	372.66734224854866
as much as he did Latin, “add to the merit of the difficulty that of	297.65185892394334
the brevity, and you are sure that your poem will at least have two	313.9821008825188
merits.”	383.2752453952461
“You will see,” continued Aramis, “that it breathes irreproachable	470.9610999802322
passion. And so, my friends, we return to Paris? Bravo! I am ready. We	476.5280584148847
are going to rejoin that good fellow, Porthos. So much the better. You	307.59988558599656
can’t think how I have missed him, the great simpleton. To see him so	469.57039154604706
self-satisfied reconciles me with myself. He would not sell his horse;	332.13970639595135
not for a kingdom! I think I can see him now, mounted upon his superb	334.28308353763305
animal and seated in his handsome saddle. I am sure he will look like	334.5901653082461
the Great Mogul!”	450.47299222377154
They made a halt for an hour to refresh their horses. Aramis discharged	343.12169310499195
his bill, placed Bazin in the cart with his comrades, and they set	307.35953045834276
forward to join Porthos.	383.39846291811136
They found him up, less pale than when D’Artagnan left him after his	296.9640742708269
first visit, and seated at a table on which, though he was alone, was	365.00313456889586
spread enough for four persons. This dinner consisted of meats nicely	332.3043780536324
dressed, choice wines, and superb fruit.	464.0654638953399
“Ah, _pardieu!_” said he, rising, “you come in the nick of time,	369.12732574823076
gentlemen. I was just beginning the soup, and you will dine with me.”	460.2907018048485
“Oh, oh!” said D’Artagnan, “Mousqueton has not caught these bottles	319.44213995523234
with his lasso. Besides, here is a piquant _fricandeau_ and a fillet of	429.0339480341946
beef.”	400.384970900679
“I am recruiting myself,” said Porthos, “I am recruiting myself.	378.790202143112
Nothing weakens a man more than these devilish strains. Did you ever	312.1193989798997
suffer from a strain, Athos?”	479.97586749654477
“Never! Though I remember, in our affair of the Rue Férou, I received a	332.2013593512838
sword wound which at the end of fifteen or eighteen days produced the	393.47050128417743
same effect.”	332.2580571820187
“But this dinner was not intended for you alone, Porthos?” said Aramis.	368.2109547398352
“No,” said Porthos, “I expected some gentlemen of the neighborhood, who	377.15163134467707
have just sent me word they could not come. You will take their places	312.549721509041
and I shall not lose by the exchange. _Holà_, Mousqueton, seats, and	346.06082612944533
order double the bottles!”	419.7380329704278
“Do you know what we are eating here?” said Athos, at the end of ten	368.2822499725219
minutes.	306.9894648284004
“_Pardieu!_” replied D’Artagnan, “for my part, I am eating veal	366.33437639426086
garnished with shrimps and vegetables.”	404.95399810157636
“And I some lamb chops,” said Porthos.	327.1209789945917
“And I a plain chicken,” said Aramis.	458.4952601145285
“You are all mistaken, gentlemen,” answered Athos, gravely; “you are	361.33719640557064
eating horse.”	447.21672714114766
“Eating what?” said D’Artagnan.	433.78288323247125
“Horse!” said Aramis, with a grimace of disgust.	313.3723911037819
Porthos alone made no reply.	491.75012698607816
“Yes, horse. Are we not eating a horse, Porthos? And perhaps his	317.4530546074938
saddle, therewith.”	364.14015901536186
“No, gentlemen, I have kept the harness,” said Porthos.	324.59252639610173
“My faith,” said Aramis, “we are all alike. One would think we had	360.6794506622551
tipped the wink.”	346.20220899611036
“What could I do?” said Porthos. “This horse made my visitors ashamed	361.68613266273803
of theirs, and I don’t like to humiliate people.”	304.9319822692888
“Then your duchess is still at the waters?” asked D’Artagnan.	387.31462998963167
“Still,” replied Porthos. “And, my faith, the governor of the	373.5791165484004
province—one of the gentlemen I expected today—seemed to have such a	348.16824428552115
wish for him, that I gave him to him.”	491.02510596866114
“Gave him?” cried D’Artagnan.	300.55337704058127
“My God, yes, _gave_, that is the word,” said Porthos; “for the animal	383.7938794173838
was worth at least a hundred and fifty louis, and the stingy fellow	437.6478054926072
would only give me eighty.”	359.234299087966
“Without the saddle?” said Aramis.	320.4506865034159
“Yes, without the saddle.”	309.3551987264521
“You will observe, gentlemen,” said Athos, “that Porthos has made the	361.16659427686074
best bargain of any of us.”	424.87373844198265
And then commenced a roar of laughter in which they all joined, to the	478.2846417921154
astonishment of poor Porthos; but when he was informed of the cause of	393.1339429761132
their hilarity, he shared it vociferously according to his custom.	303.70628702371334
“There is one comfort, we are all in cash,” said D’Artagnan.	315.9672926444307
“Well, for my part,” said Athos, “I found Aramis’s Spanish wine so good	386.3325915984065
that I sent on a hamper of sixty bottles of it in the wagon with the	326.5495733996932
lackeys. That has weakened my purse.”	391.5359100670057
“And I,” said Aramis, “imagined that I had given almost my last sou to	305.66590220585056
the church of Montdidier and the Jesuits of Amiens, with whom I had	296.09734101610627
made engagements which I ought to have kept. I have ordered Masses for	377.6532651182008
myself, and for you, gentlemen, which will be said, gentlemen, for	332.14671142714553
which I have not the least doubt you will be marvelously benefited.”	327.269900360279
“And I,” said Porthos, “do you think my strain cost me nothing?—without	481.78848412485684
reckoning Mousqueton’s wound, for which I had to have the surgeon twice	373.6272670492286
a day, and who charged me double on account of that foolish Mousqueton	452.82940026364986
having allowed himself a ball in a part which people generally only	414.2120032382151
show to an apothecary; so I advised him to try never to get wounded	334.94565487290856
there any more.”	347.7862652295101
“Ay, ay!” said Athos, exchanging a smile with D’Artagnan and Aramis,	301.6562506900624
“it is very clear you acted nobly with regard to the poor lad; that is	428.5562377316713
like a good master.”	309.5137293832498
“In short,” said Porthos, “when all my expenses are paid, I shall have,	298.9803869549946
at most, thirty crowns left.”	444.06059417661004
“And I about ten pistoles,” said Aramis.	364.2154997977497
“Well, then it appears that we are the Crœsuses of the society. How	460.4472931441402
much have you left of your hundred pistoles, D’Artagnan?”	314.22373963211675
“Of my hundred pistoles? Why, in the first place I gave you fifty.”	334.13061288682513
“You think so?”	374.4372727176235
“_Pardieu!_”	336.87295285959755
“Ah, that is true. I recollect.”	417.08000496553063
“Then I paid the host six.”	462.6407977922894
“What a brute of a host! Why did you give him six pistoles?”	395.8094953161534
“You told me to give them to him.”	396.7677740584096
“It is true; I am too good-natured. In brief, how much remains?”	347.08404905402074
“Twenty-five pistoles,” said D’Artagnan.	346.18338378611935
“And I,” said Athos, taking some small change from his pocket, “I—”	490.42939066316734
“You? Nothing!”	305.0485970605039
“My faith! So little that it is not worth reckoning with the general	406.97150441662956
stock.”	437.7619512726115
“Now, then, let us calculate how much we posses in all.”	292.9570213380107
“Porthos?”	314.40270797618456
“Thirty crowns.”	455.6106166006673
“Aramis?”	426.18877385336003
“Ten pistoles.”	437.08082613494463
“And you, D’Artagnan?”	485.1191473392972
“Twenty-five.”	450.9732634693961
“That makes in all?” said Athos.	452.0694256163729
“Four hundred and seventy-five livres,” said D’Artagnan, who reckoned	491.94320200272887
like Archimedes.	349.1824377676982
“On our arrival in Paris, we shall still have four hundred, besides the	321.12373809064076
harnesses,” said Porthos.	441.69206721639296
“But our troop horses?” said Aramis.	333.32478694883093
“Well, of the four horses of our lackeys we will make two for the	401.94424303452683
masters, for which we will draw lots. With the four hundred livres we	432.26499737322604
will make the half of one for one of the unmounted, and then we will	387.2926055170234
give the turnings out of our pockets to D’Artagnan, who has a steady	480.62845096842887
hand, and will go and play in the first gaming house we come to.	489.2031444660812
There!”	329.9483348908097
“Let us dine, then,” said Porthos; “it is getting cold.”	297.2861303111808
The friends, at ease with regard to the future, did honor to the	362.10640359603144
repast, the remains of which were abandoned to Mousqueton, Bazin,	365.72511106051127
Planchet, and Grimaud.	408.6575908025884
On arriving in Paris, D’Artagnan found a letter from M. de Tréville,	449.63245426606096
which informed him that, at his request, the king had promised that he	415.31829890220934
should enter the company of the Musketeers.	296.8973155846589
As this was the height of D’Artagnan’s worldly ambition—apart, be it	350.96691084338386
well understood, from his desire of finding Mme. Bonacieux—he ran, full	338.48587133280364
of joy, to seek his comrades, whom he had left only half an hour	341.9479953519596
before, but whom he found very sad and deeply preoccupied. They were	426.51761507091425
assembled in council at the residence of Athos, which always indicated	337.3434492432243
an event of some gravity. M. de Tréville had intimated to them his	372.9063063868098
Majesty’s fixed intention to open the campaign on the first of May, and	328.0154873018235
they must immediately prepare their outfits.	490.50457477712973
The four philosophers looked at one another in a state of bewilderment.	326.03266861364466
M. de Tréville never jested in matters relating to discipline.	293.9471608837917
“And what do you reckon your outfit will cost?” said D’Artagnan.	314.3841290252607
“Oh, we can scarcely say. We have made our calculations with Spartan	414.56633557440676
economy, and we each require fifteen hundred livres.”	367.7735266139111
“Four times fifteen makes sixty—six thousand livres,” said Athos.	437.4976136776907
“It seems to me,” said D’Artagnan, “with a thousand livres each—I do	415.16164818829867
not speak as a Spartan, but as a procurator—”	415.6927400494817
This word _procurator_ roused Porthos. “Stop,” said he, “I have an	340.33298765901725
idea.”	301.0811574238911
“Well, that’s something, for I have not the shadow of one,” said Athos	344.4024028953824
coolly; “but as to D’Artagnan, gentlemen, the idea of belonging to	477.3929725873281
_ours_ has driven him out of his senses. A thousand livres! For my	398.8722475952335
part, I declare I want two thousand.”	388.88150596005244
“Four times two makes eight,” then said Aramis; “it is eight thousand	320.4616345115575
that we want to complete our outfits, toward which, it is true, we have	358.23742403899087
already the saddles.”	332.3568223376029
“Besides,” said Athos, waiting till D’Artagnan, who went to thank	396.890812720361
Monsieur de Tréville, had shut the door, “besides, there is that	490.04161389035403
beautiful ring which beams from the finger of our friend. What the	424.7875281343071
devil! D’Artagnan is too good a comrade to leave his brothers in	487.8837652806675
embarrassment while he wears the ransom of a king on his finger.”	331.1631864764141
Chapter XXIX.	473.28536077448086
HUNTING FOR THE EQUIPMENTS	294.715343329345
The most preoccupied of the four friends was certainly D’Artagnan,	472.4247912981183
although he, in his quality of Guardsman, would be much more easily	369.5735730954157
equipped than Messieurs the Musketeers, who were all of high rank; but	415.7311773306268
our Gascon cadet was, as may have been observed, of a provident and	392.0990697746929
almost avaricious character, and with that (explain the contradiction)	373.21296089663014
so vain as almost to rival Porthos. To this preoccupation of his	356.8971063497335
vanity, D’Artagnan at this moment joined an uneasiness much less	310.13208473864916
selfish. Notwithstanding all his inquiries respecting Mme. Bonacieux,	481.5848291140214
he could obtain no intelligence of her. M. de Tréville had spoken of	460.43176131874475
her to the queen. The queen was ignorant where the mercer’s young wife	455.4908334771123
was, but had promised to have her sought for; but this promise was very	330.8401422600887
vague and did not at all reassure D’Artagnan.	345.4608542389282
Athos did not leave his chamber; he made up his mind not to take a	341.2405040430384
single step to equip himself.	296.6150761124905
“We have still fifteen days before us,” said he to his friends, “well,	352.389701846289
if at the end of a fortnight I have found nothing, or rather if nothing	480.5454941911779
has come to find me, as I, too good a Catholic to kill myself with a	413.40906176555586
pistol bullet, I will seek a good quarrel with four of his Eminence’s	395.0469128833313
Guards or with eight Englishmen, and I will fight until one of them has	484.67726829483297
killed me, which, considering the number, cannot fail to happen. It	485.76034047778666
will then be said of me that I died for the king; so that I shall have	359.9929059000104
performed my duty without the expense of an outfit.”	397.2863641968853
Porthos continued to walk about with his hands behind him, tossing his	438.91591992221004
head and repeating, “I shall follow up on my idea.”	376.57694976260996
Aramis, anxious and negligently dressed, said nothing.	327.5253340711551
It may be seen by these disastrous details that desolation reigned in	385.73513293088234
the community.	378.48891737671204
The lackeys on their part, like the coursers of Hippolytus, shared the	467.96814506737303
sadness of their masters. Mousqueton collected a store of crusts;	470.1431494781351
Bazin, who had always been inclined to devotion, never quit the	469.33441735339244
churches; Planchet watched the flight of flies; and Grimaud, whom the	411.30788886645485
general distress could not induce to break the silence imposed by his	415.84049562320666
master, heaved sighs enough to soften the stones.	437.30124390302944
The three friends—for, as we have said, Athos had sworn not to stir a	456.9717433481467
foot to equip himself—went out early in the morning, and returned late	362.56931349170475
at night. They wandered about the streets, looking at the pavement as	304.6022203513796
if to see whether the passengers had not left a purse behind them. They	334.9125554856023
might have been supposed to be following tracks, so observant were they	437.32800983931986
wherever they went. When they met they looked desolately at one	476.2487496889998
another, as much as to say, “Have you found anything?”	351.45448916098127
However, as Porthos had first found an idea, and had thought of it	426.0058230696128
earnestly afterward, he was the first to act. He was a man of	428.6694317150994
execution, this worthy Porthos. D’Artagnan perceived him one day	340.17608786522914
walking toward the church of St. Leu, and followed him instinctively.	402.77800629026626
He entered, after having twisted his mustache and elongated his	458.0612978425048
imperial, which always announced on his part the most triumphant	292.48996305785226
resolutions. As D’Artagnan took some precautions to conceal himself,	302.69384805940126
Porthos believed he had not been seen. D’Artagnan entered behind him.	331.28763218023875
Porthos went and leaned against the side of a pillar. D’Artagnan, still	295.9345646747134
unperceived, supported himself against the other side.	324.710051646703
There happened to be a sermon, which made the church very full of	373.38430868181933
people. Porthos took advantage of this circumstance to ogle the women.	317.8285601331655
Thanks to the cares of Mousqueton, the exterior was far from announcing	463.03207290173384
the distress of the interior. His hat was a little napless, his feather	401.542081501982
was a little faded, his gold lace was a little tarnished, his laces	330.3022347924375
were a trifle frayed; but in the obscurity of the church these things	323.5681778239717
were not seen, and Porthos was still the handsome Porthos.	308.13664487158843
D’Artagnan observed, on the bench nearest to the pillar against which	483.76666259832956
Porthos leaned, a sort of ripe beauty, rather yellow and rather dry,	379.82797688712617
but erect and haughty under her black hood. The eyes of Porthos were	382.0643709062815
furtively cast upon this lady, and then roved about at large over the	382.33596023988673
nave.	326.65358506413975
On her side the lady, who from time to time blushed, darted with the	308.48005281266245
rapidity of lightning a glance toward the inconstant Porthos; and then	333.50975021310626
immediately the eyes of Porthos wandered anxiously. It was plain that	414.7699760046249
this mode of proceeding piqued the lady in the black hood, for she bit	417.5592218216649
her lips till they bled, scratched the end of her nose, and could not	481.85669472689807
sit still in her seat.	439.3278522838292
Porthos, seeing this, retwisted his mustache, elongated his imperial a	321.0108611240552
second time, and began to make signals to a beautiful lady who was near	350.37939340764797
the choir, and who not only was a beautiful lady, but still further, no	465.9810514560928
doubt, a great lady—for she had behind her a Negro boy who had brought	387.0748396158194
the cushion on which she knelt, and a female servant who held the	392.22879732251556
emblazoned bag in which was placed the book from which she read the	336.46352562537885
Mass.	345.5361080207845
The lady with the black hood followed through all their wanderings the	468.7733713128251
looks of Porthos, and perceived that they rested upon the lady with the	457.03771053026526
velvet cushion, the little Negro, and the maid-servant.	406.47925807802744
During this time Porthos played close. It was almost imperceptible	292.21121673103715
motions of his eyes, fingers placed upon the lips, little assassinating	466.42380211948387
smiles, which really did assassinate the disdained beauty.	490.99946939614927
Then she cried, “Ahem!” under cover of the _mea culpa_, striking her	300.94313845260683
breast so vigorously that everybody, even the lady with the red	337.733513731626
cushion, turned round toward her. Porthos paid no attention.	347.4613227892791
Nevertheless, he understood it all, but was deaf.	296.88138129750183
The lady with the red cushion produced a great effect—for she was very	409.3206267874219
handsome—upon the lady with the black hood, who saw in her a rival	482.19053929568474
really to be dreaded; a great effect upon Porthos, who thought her much	295.3905373646437
prettier than the lady with the black hood; a great effect upon	479.2323161835618
D’Artagnan, who recognized in her the lady of Meung, of Calais, and of	305.0843193306415
Dover, whom his persecutor, the man with the scar, had saluted by the	326.61673098435773
name of Milady.	446.7746657019961
D’Artagnan, without losing sight of the lady of the red cushion,	378.98033675002114
continued to watch the proceedings of Porthos, which amused him	406.36356173453635
greatly. He guessed that the lady of the black hood was the	326.5535395131849
procurator’s wife of the Rue aux Ours, which was the more probable from	335.24011047052807
the church of St. Leu being not far from that locality.	367.1317975389372
He guessed, likewise, by induction, that Porthos was taking his revenge	457.1264444127603
for the defeat of Chantilly, when the procurator’s wife had proved so	311.2567626607174
refractory with respect to her purse.	438.8275993593485
Amid all this, D’Artagnan remarked also that not one countenance	384.194695757875
responded to the gallantries of Porthos. There were only chimeras and	341.52797450025554
illusions; but for real love, for true jealousy, is there any reality	438.01556277875886
except illusions and chimeras?	464.72076262100154
The sermon over, the procurator’s wife advanced toward the holy font.	480.3869727579885
Porthos went before her, and instead of a finger, dipped his whole hand	464.4897851882745
in. The procurator’s wife smiled, thinking that it was for her Porthos	342.1703250137407
had put himself to this trouble; but she was cruelly and promptly	396.0447703416882
undeceived. When she was only about three steps from him, he turned his	298.7531490026788
head round, fixing his eyes steadfastly upon the lady with the red	370.74705659153676
cushion, who had risen and was approaching, followed by her black boy	335.2227973985557
and her woman.	398.92168673938124
When the lady of the red cushion came close to Porthos, Porthos drew	329.1169723132145
his dripping hand from the font. The fair worshipper touched the great	352.1435919946075
hand of Porthos with her delicate fingers, smiled, made the sign of the	473.9443288649695
cross, and left the church.	490.85741990474787
This was too much for the procurator’s wife; she doubted not there was	347.33895719461935
an intrigue between this lady and Porthos. If she had been a great lady	420.19469782291503
she would have fainted; but as she was only a procurator’s wife, she	418.0030408006395
contented herself saying to the Musketeer with concentrated fury, “Eh,	358.85621297252965
Monsieur Porthos, you don’t offer me any holy water?”	440.59575235409204
Porthos, at the sound of that voice, started like a man awakened from a	326.4529561319314
sleep of a hundred years.	295.0526754304965
“Ma-madame!” cried he; “is that you? How is your husband, our dear	363.959107125129
Monsieur Coquenard? Is he still as stingy as ever? Where can my eyes	383.0710894015358
have been not to have seen you during the two hours of the sermon?”	414.62518025659017
“I was within two paces of you, monsieur,” replied the procurator’s	462.6281426791175
wife; “but you did not perceive me because you had no eyes but for the	480.8387613985308
pretty lady to whom you just now gave the holy water.”	425.45808839752704
Porthos pretended to be confused. “Ah,” said he, “you have remarked—”	352.0687357786244
“I must have been blind not to have seen.”	378.755814144417
“Yes,” said Porthos, “that is a duchess of my acquaintance whom I have	310.23077632768957
great trouble to meet on account of the jealousy of her husband, and	414.28602351652984
who sent me word that she should come today to this poor church, buried	480.5873765120267
in this vile quarter, solely for the sake of seeing me.”	422.644792651805
“Monsieur Porthos,” said the procurator’s wife, “will you have the	342.4600427096681
kindness to offer me your arm for five minutes? I have something to say	386.2597449930159
to you.”	485.2482986592935
“Certainly, madame,” said Porthos, winking to himself, as a gambler	433.72110595772335
does who laughs at the dupe he is about to pluck.	333.5553080511138
At that moment D’Artagnan passed in pursuit of Milady; he cast a	380.6952811704471
passing glance at Porthos, and beheld this triumphant look.	352.54583148814777
“Eh, eh!” said he, reasoning to himself according to the strangely easy	321.6732316262976
morality of that gallant period, “there is one who will be equipped in	425.29409483543697
good time!”	343.99690775405764
Porthos, yielding to the pressure of the arm of the procurator’s wife,	465.4695550940473
as a bark yields to the rudder, arrived at the cloister St. Magloire—a	479.0998765941713
little-frequented passage, enclosed with a turnstile at each end. In	294.47599450728524
the daytime nobody was seen there but mendicants devouring their	412.00727634192486
crusts, and children at play.	435.36383202112336
“Ah, Monsieur Porthos,” cried the procurator’s wife, when she was	292.62739282988167
assured that no one who was a stranger to the population of the	379.86765379100984
locality could either see or hear her, “ah, Monsieur Porthos, you are a	349.5485435728952
great conqueror, as it appears!”	407.2093548207673
“I, madame?” said Porthos, drawing himself up proudly; “how so?”	366.988300827249
“The signs just now, and the holy water! But that must be a princess,	430.02458680773236
at least—that lady with her Negro boy and her maid!”	358.56227920076765
“My God! Madame, you are deceived,” said Porthos; “she is simply a	447.14776230162954
duchess.”	311.5291165483169
“And that running footman who waited at the door, and that carriage	392.20544608108656
with a coachman in grand livery who sat waiting on his seat?”	452.83805074786585
Porthos had seen neither the footman nor the carriage, but with the eye	437.7149208281055
of a jealous woman, Mme. Coquenard had seen everything.	432.6643474548167
Porthos regretted that he had not at once made the lady of the red	463.7033593107956
cushion a princess.	398.53283462494784
“Ah, you are quite the pet of the ladies, Monsieur Porthos!” resumed	418.6426866427864
the procurator’s wife, with a sigh.	354.84330807941876
“Well,” responded Porthos, “you may imagine, with the physique with	298.3682895188043
which nature has endowed me, I am not in want of good luck.”	452.4280353626637
“Good Lord, how quickly men forget!” cried the procurator’s wife,	363.63583722967405
raising her eyes toward heaven.	491.10599999498925
“Less quickly than the women, it seems to me,” replied Porthos; “for I,	449.21299943905706
madame, I may say I was your victim, when wounded, dying, I was	375.97866285280855
abandoned by the surgeons. I, the offspring of a noble family, who	299.5277113923177
placed reliance upon your friendship—I was near dying of my wounds at	485.9776565557537
first, and of hunger afterward, in a beggarly inn at Chantilly, without	382.7540914662384
you ever deigning once to reply to the burning letters I addressed to	453.6071870340587
you.”	369.6769767690295
“But, Monsieur Porthos,” murmured the procurator’s wife, who began to	304.8150264243205
feel that, to judge by the conduct of the great ladies of the time, she	302.8709531092361
was wrong.	394.5645858856941
“I, who had sacrificed for you the Baronne de—”	443.5026970688522
“I know it well.”	417.7004505671405
“The Comtesse de—”	450.0204516118842
“Monsieur Porthos, be generous!”	344.7389501282421
“You are right, madame, and I will not finish.”	369.53110820938934
“But it was my husband who would not hear of lending.”	414.4965138253997
“Madame Coquenard,” said Porthos, “remember the first letter you wrote	477.88890978996915
me, and which I preserve engraved in my memory.”	309.5339943810308
The procurator’s wife uttered a groan.	292.85502489259017
“Besides,” said she, “the sum you required me to borrow was rather	415.7778079149382
large.”	334.12701713893796
