“Madame Coquenard, I gave you the preference. I had but to write to the	491.51443694589676
Duchesse—but I won’t repeat her name, for I am incapable of	324.47891043514346
compromising a woman; but this I know, that I had but to write to her	327.41358541567024
and she would have sent me fifteen hundred.”	484.56117740683
The procurator’s wife shed a tear.	416.0486225140283
“Monsieur Porthos,” said she, “I can assure you that you have severely	470.3186393459162
punished me; and if in the time to come you should find yourself in a	316.3171998269012
similar situation, you have but to apply to me.”	362.3087887527247
“Fie, madame, fie!” said Porthos, as if disgusted. “Let us not talk	448.4553413698495
about money, if you please; it is humiliating.”	489.78649477286694
“Then you no longer love me!” said the procurator’s wife, slowly and	464.1430858993041
sadly.	422.4464624530723
Porthos maintained a majestic silence.	472.02226429636767
“And that is the only reply you make? Alas, I understand.”	381.59489613657826
“Think of the offense you have committed toward me, madame! It remains	342.5292571023235
_here!_” said Porthos, placing his hand on his heart, and pressing it	445.18236536209804
strongly.	393.7217984753542
“I will repair it, indeed I will, my dear Porthos.”	293.87804041746983
“Besides, what did I ask of you?” resumed Porthos, with a movement of	461.6456162896668
the shoulders full of good fellowship. “A loan, nothing more! After	399.556599306093
all, I am not an unreasonable man. I know you are not rich, Madame	400.84393880735826
Coquenard, and that your husband is obliged to bleed his poor clients	483.5632570001005
to squeeze a few paltry crowns from them. Oh! If you were a duchess, a	342.14364014932846
marchioness, or a countess, it would be quite a different thing; it	359.1935823987129
would be unpardonable.”	385.9054752967083
The procurator’s wife was piqued.	411.6330331873032
“Please to know, Monsieur Porthos,” said she, “that my strongbox, the	456.919618783179
strongbox of a procurator’s wife though it may be, is better filled	423.63333877279973
than those of your affected minxes.”	297.08574157355525
“That doubles the offense,” said Porthos, disengaging his arm from that	293.2993435868805
of the procurator’s wife; “for if you are rich, Madame Coquenard, then	329.88759740733985
there is no excuse for your refusal.”	351.1490254772215
“When I said rich,” replied the procurator’s wife, who saw that she had	393.6585529656936
gone too far, “you must not take the word literally. I am not precisely	361.1688866686265
rich, though I am pretty well off.”	450.5371291452612
“Hold, madame,” said Porthos, “let us say no more upon the subject, I	378.3591411961539
beg of you. You have misunderstood me, all sympathy is extinct between	391.43314580868787
us.”	469.34710076225736
“Ingrate that you are!”	414.15033647908785
“Ah! I advise you to complain!” said Porthos.	442.17746882273383
“Begone, then, to your beautiful duchess; I will detain you no longer.”	341.9411917320143
“And she is not to be despised, in my opinion.”	370.20774108571106
“Now, Monsieur Porthos, once more, and this is the last! Do you love me	472.79419715439514
still?”	340.4813443273083
“Ah, madame,” said Porthos, in the most melancholy tone he could	303.2437307143543
assume, “when we are about to enter upon a campaign—a campaign, in	419.8177441059107
which my presentiments tell me I shall be killed—”	314.9666107156477
“Oh, don’t talk of such things!” cried the procurator’s wife, bursting	457.47599919178754
into tears.	297.8049480904902
“Something whispers me so,” continued Porthos, becoming more and more	314.27006758318157
melancholy.	362.2924317342511
“Rather say that you have a new love.”	312.34275318070235
“Not so; I speak frankly to you. No object affects me; and I even feel	440.76685849809945
here, at the bottom of my heart, something which speaks for you. But in	386.26584500057294
fifteen days, as you know, or as you do not know, this fatal campaign	404.92126686101693
is to open. I shall be fearfully preoccupied with my outfit. Then I	429.94726611379633
must make a journey to see my family, in the lower part of Brittany, to	376.3804296115672
obtain the sum necessary for my departure.”	324.18134667789144
Porthos observed a last struggle between love and avarice.	473.1719106326342
“And as,” continued he, “the duchess whom you saw at the church has	412.83148979358646
estates near to those of my family, we mean to make the journey	304.56588555665394
together. Journeys, you know, appear much shorter when we travel two in	414.45108055384827
company.”	372.81888007761546
“Have you no friends in Paris, then, Monsieur Porthos?” said the	415.617267342211
procurator’s wife.	461.7303930468608
“I thought I had,” said Porthos, resuming his melancholy air; “but I	362.46621642441255
have been taught my mistake.”	370.02022398053236
“You have some!” cried the procurator’s wife, in a transport that	421.90017366731985
surprised even herself. “Come to our house tomorrow. You are the son of	316.3604996216597
my aunt, consequently my cousin; you come from Noyon, in Picardy; you	475.7711878679703
have several lawsuits and no attorney. Can you recollect all that?”	315.834264211687
“Perfectly, madame.”	296.949879276675
“Come at dinnertime.”	454.7612664465096
“Very well.”	319.7307827160629
“And be upon your guard before my husband, who is rather shrewd,	479.3231110100851
notwithstanding his seventy-six years.”	487.3150023469835
“Seventy-six years! _Peste!_ That’s a fine age!” replied Porthos.	364.2464063297788
“A great age, you mean, Monsieur Porthos. Yes, the poor man may be	465.2073117509934
expected to leave me a widow, any hour,” continued she, throwing a	304.86783419294534
significant glance at Porthos. “Fortunately, by our marriage contract,	459.3473701318585
the survivor takes everything.”	385.8370532539727
“All?”	444.36456447219643
“Yes, all.”	340.6801077897616
“You are a woman of precaution, I see, my dear Madame Coquenard,” said	399.7083183092608
Porthos, squeezing the hand of the procurator’s wife tenderly.	342.6097000039849
“We are then reconciled, dear Monsieur Porthos?” said she, simpering.	446.2933043527985
“For life,” replied Porthos, in the same manner.	341.30469621516045
“Till we meet again, then, dear traitor!”	377.55455883117867
“Till we meet again, my forgetful charmer!”	401.53460428555553
“Tomorrow, my angel!”	443.9474857854327
“Tomorrow, flame of my life!”	330.76287002076964
Chapter XXX.	344.6549175331681
D’ARTAGNAN AND THE ENGLISHMAN	387.3411850900376
D’Artagnan followed Milady without being perceived by her. He saw her	433.03187465074
get into her carriage, and heard her order the coachman to drive to St.	444.7154162182296
Germain.	432.5751086757123
It was useless to try to keep pace on foot with a carriage drawn by two	308.91411098628936
powerful horses. D’Artagnan therefore returned to the Rue Férou.	355.62047690705765
In the Rue de Seine he met Planchet, who had stopped before the house	308.78022740359927
of a pastry cook, and was contemplating with ecstasy a cake of the most	354.230844297222
appetizing appearance.	310.4132964158474
He ordered him to go and saddle two horses in M. de Tréville’s	329.9933352309156
stables—one for himself, D’Artagnan, and one for Planchet—and bring	298.7362685649107
them to Athos’s place. Once for all, Tréville had placed his stable at	454.6033738843264
D’Artagnan’s service.	389.6888672109423
Planchet proceeded toward the Rue du Colombier, and D’Artagnan toward	358.6522831508744
the Rue Férou. Athos was at home, emptying sadly a bottle of the famous	395.08220397468386
Spanish wine he had brought back with him from his journey into	315.21969252321026
Picardy. He made a sign for Grimaud to bring a glass for D’Artagnan,	391.4458869174656
and Grimaud obeyed as usual.	393.47639479476004
D’Artagnan related to Athos all that had passed at the church between	377.673382616043
Porthos and the procurator’s wife, and how their comrade was probably	453.11370186111003
by that time in a fair way to be equipped.	314.5858789141448
“As for me,” replied Athos to this recital, “I am quite at my ease; it	366.754724364524
will not be women that will defray the expense of my outfit.”	314.51484565260705
“Handsome, well-bred, noble lord as you are, my dear Athos, neither	303.05157232940604
princesses nor queens would be secure from your amorous solicitations.”	366.1359388221291
“How young this D’Artagnan is!” said Athos, shrugging his shoulders;	326.0148073736889
and he made a sign to Grimaud to bring another bottle.	367.1734790024539
At that moment Planchet put his head modestly in at the half-open door,	393.18721099144796
and told his master that the horses were ready.	385.12681382911245
“What horses?” asked Athos.	405.7499827126377
“Two horses that Monsieur de Tréville lends me at my pleasure, and with	347.5494051805334
which I am now going to take a ride to St. Germain.”	444.7952230698362
“Well, and what are you going to do at St. Germain?” then demanded	378.2010698153971
Athos.	297.06422236834766
Then D’Artagnan described the meeting which he had at the church, and	389.45729282364846
how he had found that lady who, with the seigneur in the black cloak	434.2601145981612
and with the scar near his temple, filled his mind constantly.	344.51118293745037
“That is to say, you are in love with this lady as you were with Madame	435.6114668218082
Bonacieux,” said Athos, shrugging his shoulders contemptuously, as if	340.722455656881
he pitied human weakness.	389.90026037352214
“I? not at all!” said D’Artagnan. “I am only curious to unravel the	474.8447452817337
mystery to which she is attached. I do not know why, but I imagine that	458.282559412793
this woman, wholly unknown to me as she is, and wholly unknown to her	459.3249239900042
as I am, has an influence over my life.”	428.60997758401214
“Well, perhaps you are right,” said Athos. “I do not know a woman that	467.0300146488492
is worth the trouble of being sought for when she is once lost. Madame	339.23309324875646
Bonacieux is lost; so much the worse for her if she is found.”	336.7670304777273
“No, Athos, no, you are mistaken,” said D’Artagnan; “I love my poor	364.54037012092795
Constance more than ever, and if I knew the place in which she is, were	351.82792453409616
it at the end of the world, I would go to free her from the hands of	374.9236399410171
her enemies; but I am ignorant. All my researches have been useless.	417.15396280067404
What is to be said? I must divert my attention!”	456.8882219463009
“Amuse yourself with Milady, my dear D’Artagnan; I wish you may with	338.16270484116325
all my heart, if that will amuse you.”	457.9383676238921
“Hear me, Athos,” said D’Artagnan. “Instead of shutting yourself up	337.7752941129838
here as if you were under arrest, get on horseback and come and take a	457.63442650824186
ride with me to St. Germain.”	339.06452837212913
“My dear fellow,” said Athos, “I ride horses when I have any; when I	345.86242610980645
have none, I go afoot.”	470.29758057384475
“Well,” said D’Artagnan, smiling at the misanthropy of Athos, which	453.34397758172213
from any other person would have offended him, “I ride what I can get;	338.65434654804835
I am not so proud as you. So _au revoir_, dear Athos.”	360.7714111086292
“_Au revoir_,” said the Musketeer, making a sign to Grimaud to uncork	348.27768697117034
the bottle he had just brought.	491.43823344281486
D’Artagnan and Planchet mounted, and took the road to St. Germain.	293.4109933310132
All along the road, what Athos had said respecting Mme. Bonacieux	398.48080906979203
recurred to the mind of the young man. Although D’Artagnan was not of a	301.2756031142058
very sentimental character, the mercer’s pretty wife had made a real	366.56068548853267
impression upon his heart. As he said, he was ready to go to the end of	330.29680215739154
the world to seek her; but the world, being round, has many ends, so	487.2269077720348
that he did not know which way to turn. Meantime, he was going to try	463.7137615482844
to find out Milady. Milady had spoken to the man in the black cloak;	412.2010045601622
therefore she knew him. Now, in the opinion of D’Artagnan, it was	384.6478013011547
certainly the man in the black cloak who had carried off Mme. Bonacieux	446.7994688590892
the second time, as he had carried her off the first. D’Artagnan then	385.46248078424327
only half-lied, which is lying but little, when he said that by going	462.46728254717107
in search of Milady he at the same time went in search of Constance.	335.8073215728632
Thinking of all this, and from time to time giving a touch of the spur	422.2995830290048
to his horse, D’Artagnan completed his short journey, and arrived at	335.7305798514723
St. Germain. He had just passed by the pavilion in which ten years	334.8214586327902
later Louis XIV. was born. He rode up a very quiet street, looking to	331.36810832897993
the right and the left to see if he could catch any vestige of his	327.12677374806026
beautiful Englishwoman, when from the ground floor of a pretty house,	306.9178778823887
which, according to the fashion of the time, had no window toward the	406.76653777744195
street, he saw a face peep out with which he thought he was acquainted.	345.86929865903767
This person walked along the terrace, which was ornamented with	427.1077246979431
flowers. Planchet recognized him first.	366.4409261139283
“Eh, monsieur!” said he, addressing D’Artagnan, “don’t you remember	449.69752169043466
that face which is blinking yonder?”	452.0833944737156
“No,” said D’Artagnan, “and yet I am certain it is not the first time I	416.8657210337028
have seen that visage.”	464.7856188859163
“_Parbleu_, I believe it is not,” said Planchet. “Why, it is poor	396.4133281454599
Lubin, the lackey of the Comte de Wardes—he whom you took such good	439.4326041099474
care of a month ago at Calais, on the road to the governor’s country	368.37942330093097
house!”	304.526953546067
“So it is!” said D’Artagnan; “I know him now. Do you think he would	459.01365385306354
recollect you?”	325.8147724602955
“My faith, monsieur, he was in such trouble that I doubt if he can have	347.29477854181823
retained a very clear recollection of me.”	415.8226099304986
“Well, go and talk with the boy,” said D’Artagnan, “and make out if you	400.4179666579028
can from his conversation whether his master is dead.”	391.4456456450631
Planchet dismounted and went straight up to Lubin, who did not at all	342.67763543746827
remember him, and the two lackeys began to chat with the best	430.9972621957844
understanding possible; while D’Artagnan turned the two horses into a	468.2282227189315
lane, went round the house, and came back to watch the conference from	402.7370437811518
behind a hedge of filberts.	465.61199690621197
At the end of an instant’s observation he heard the noise of a vehicle,	471.39297316150504
and saw Milady’s carriage stop opposite to him. He could not be	487.7848085205302
mistaken; Milady was in it. D’Artagnan leaned upon the neck of his	464.37059267589416
horse, in order that he might see without being seen.	489.41192649799075
Milady put her charming blond head out at the window, and gave her	423.69158041822595
orders to her maid.	331.75556381423957
The latter—a pretty girl of about twenty or twenty-two years, active	395.637042058907
and lively, the true _soubrette_ of a great lady—jumped from the step	363.5356453224666
upon which, according to the custom of the time, she was seated, and	462.1704835421556
took her way toward the terrace upon which D’Artagnan had perceived	460.1936032479315
Lubin.	294.0745729501396
D’Artagnan followed the _soubrette_ with his eyes, and saw her go	307.36383481243035
toward the terrace; but it happened that someone in the house called	417.611442626344
Lubin, so that Planchet remained alone, looking in all directions for	380.6225341562621
the road where D’Artagnan had disappeared.	437.40831800210765
The maid approached Planchet, whom she took for Lubin, and holding out	295.687813923566
a little billet to him said, “For your master.”	333.71766348170064
“For my master?” replied Planchet, astonished.	319.0715537692107
“Yes, and important. Take it quickly.”	364.6401942932758
Thereupon she ran toward the carriage, which had turned round toward	389.1006933602544
the way it came, jumped upon the step, and the carriage drove off.	489.0261906824153
Planchet turned and returned the billet. Then, accustomed to passive	378.65769051389873
obedience, he jumped down from the terrace, ran toward the lane, and at	292.14156743482147
the end of twenty paces met D’Artagnan, who, having seen all, was	406.56818233886656
coming to him.	378.76027961081564
“For you, monsieur,” said Planchet, presenting the billet to the young	450.6945708224624
man.	364.3568904809571
“For me?” said D’Artagnan; “are you sure of that?”	299.5170198963572
“_Pardieu_, monsieur, I can’t be more sure. The _soubrette_ said, ‘For	422.9198183475055
your master.’ I have no other master but you; so—a pretty little lass,	364.91241128508796
my faith, is that _soubrette!_”	446.93289888587594
D’Artagnan opened the letter, and read these words:	373.02440127980685
“A person who takes more interest in you than she is willing to confess	383.2741194312376
wishes to know on what day it will suit you to walk in the forest?	308.4852213277118
Tomorrow, at the Hôtel Field of the Cloth of Gold, a lackey in black	378.540952690222
and red will wait for your reply.”	466.2588453548967
“Oh!” said D’Artagnan, “this is rather warm; it appears that Milady and	463.0970539720302
I are anxious about the health of the same person. Well, Planchet, how	402.5318265081551
is the good Monsieur de Wardes? He is not dead, then?”	395.38556132680844
“No, monsieur, he is as well as a man can be with four sword wounds in	301.49292671601654
his body; for you, without question, inflicted four upon the dear	345.9775048717324
gentleman, and he is still very weak, having lost almost all his blood.	365.67694089609404
As I said, monsieur, Lubin did not know me, and told me our adventure	448.48768311071143
from one end to the other.”	449.12842346886043
“Well done, Planchet! you are the king of lackeys. Now jump onto your	390.4962877942158
horse, and let us overtake the carriage.”	406.4835435215748
This did not take long. At the end of five minutes they perceived the	417.725244628488
carriage drawn up by the roadside; a cavalier, richly dressed, was	397.51253657472137
close to the door.	377.834669613896
The conversation between Milady and the cavalier was so animated that	424.7480447390898
D’Artagnan stopped on the other side of the carriage without anyone but	440.64399811364126
the pretty _soubrette_ perceiving his presence.	445.95537543076716
The conversation took place in English—a language which D’Artagnan	483.67106636752794
could not understand; but by the accent the young man plainly saw that	393.51066362125516
the beautiful Englishwoman was in a great rage. She terminated it by an	383.92083090198696
action which left no doubt as to the nature of this conversation; this	400.95849961900075
was a blow with her fan, applied with such force that the little	478.3600296615574
feminine weapon flew into a thousand pieces.	478.03031068373934
The cavalier laughed aloud, which appeared to exasperate Milady still	428.01890509860505
more.	411.1260172517029
D’Artagnan thought this was the moment to interfere. He approached the	325.0638770752964
other door, and taking off his hat respectfully, said, “Madame, will	301.3618019350524
you permit me to offer you my services? It appears to me that this	316.4255312332731
cavalier has made you very angry. Speak one word, madame, and I take	439.16867042056066
upon myself to punish him for his want of courtesy.”	362.3971933147421
At the first word Milady turned, looking at the young man with	340.4656987898095
astonishment; and when he had finished, she said in very good French,	482.83735044514
“Monsieur, I should with great confidence place myself under your	310.40313984036584
protection if the person with whom I quarrel were not my brother.”	326.66999609318304
“Ah, excuse me, then,” said D’Artagnan. “You must be aware that I was	352.2632967508112
ignorant of that, madame.”	370.0291621225781
“What is that stupid fellow troubling himself about?” cried the	295.3891139331497
cavalier whom Milady had designated as her brother, stooping down to	316.44717154866885
the height of the coach window. “Why does not he go about his	364.17112880762573
business?”	414.8465912795956
“Stupid fellow yourself!” said D’Artagnan, stooping in his turn on the	299.39603500841514
neck of his horse, and answering on his side through the carriage	378.36022210403723
window. “I do not go on because it pleases me to stop here.”	408.7378232334125
The cavalier addressed some words in English to his sister.	420.557641998512
“I speak to you in French,” said D’Artagnan; “be kind enough, then, to	473.3636692283774
reply to me in the same language. You are Madame’s brother, I learn—be	456.5966005440682
it so; but fortunately you are not mine.”	383.9095516960034
It might be thought that Milady, timid as women are in general, would	311.4690704259074
have interposed in this commencement of mutual provocations in order to	385.8043478810007
prevent the quarrel from going too far; but on the contrary, she threw	412.3508379491546
herself back in her carriage, and called out coolly to the coachman,	360.09638128250924
“Go on—home!”	472.27864169720806
The pretty _soubrette_ cast an anxious glance at D’Artagnan, whose good	385.0973186328117
looks seemed to have made an impression on her.	361.7166921655513
The carriage went on, and left the two men facing each other; no	315.4415592855795
material obstacle separated them.	380.0438061218931
The cavalier made a movement as if to follow the carriage; but	456.24822867880505
D’Artagnan, whose anger, already excited, was much increased by	489.8672646545408
recognizing in him the Englishman of Amiens who had won his horse and	430.4141586223871
had been very near winning his diamond of Athos, caught at his bridle	301.7395346482699
and stopped him.	371.4162816539655
“Well, monsieur,” said he, “you appear to be more stupid than I am, for	455.4234621304445
you forget there is a little quarrel to arrange between us two.”	402.8023902569328
“Ah,” said the Englishman, “is it you, my master? It seems you must	337.43560692539063
always be playing some game or other.”	446.2801385500966
“Yes; and that reminds me that I have a revenge to take. We will see,	429.53798733969126
my dear monsieur, if you can handle a sword as skillfully as you can a	348.30062609774103
dice box.”	321.2453362603443
“You see plainly that I have no sword,” said the Englishman. “Do you	362.42852471855616
wish to play the braggart with an unarmed man?”	341.61397367511
“I hope you have a sword at home; but at all events, I have two, and if	442.25952646360247
you like, I will throw with you for one of them.”	444.2188118375167
“Needless,” said the Englishman; “I am well furnished with such	422.0472029063935
playthings.”	322.53654286056803
“Very well, my worthy gentleman,” replied D’Artagnan, “pick out the	292.98857118916777
longest, and come and show it to me this evening.”	309.95493359316754
“Where, if you please?”	405.45532640621843
“Behind the Luxembourg; that’s a charming spot for such amusements as	443.19177249042303
the one I propose to you.”	403.22250050372446
“That will do; I will be there.”	401.5406001281703
“Your hour?”	295.9443216765706
“Six o’clock.”	404.7425964655589
“_A propos_, you have probably one or two friends?”	417.0749227224554
“I have three, who would be honored by joining in the sport with me.”	301.1267663743878
“Three? Marvelous! That falls out oddly! Three is just my number!”	334.90236153852925
“Now, then, who are you?” asked the Englishman.	421.4234945262498
“I am Monsieur d’Artagnan, a Gascon gentleman, serving in the king’s	428.81919365425426
Musketeers. And you?”	333.5248409777229
“I am Lord de Winter, Baron Sheffield.”	306.3298828179313
“Well, then, I am your servant, Monsieur Baron,” said D’Artagnan,	311.85062686493364
“though you have names rather difficult to recollect.” And touching his	373.2921869785212
horse with the spur, he cantered back to Paris. As he was accustomed to	389.7270192436716
do in all cases of any consequence, D’Artagnan went straight to the	372.2128254393824
residence of Athos.	416.53928385413406
He found Athos reclining upon a large sofa, where he was waiting, as he	294.5466855656951
said, for his outfit to come and find him. He related to Athos all that	295.3954041587769
had passed, except the letter to M. de Wardes.	369.0921109622745
Athos was delighted to find he was going to fight an Englishman. We	489.3105905436479
might say that was his dream.	429.4241217055172
They immediately sent their lackeys for Porthos and Aramis, and on	489.3801489984904
their arrival made them acquainted with the situation.	457.08675523638715
Porthos drew his sword from the scabbard, and made passes at the wall,	363.33712907318005
springing back from time to time, and making contortions like a dancer.	441.23930905190656
Aramis, who was constantly at work at his poem, shut himself up in	436.9867212329675
Athos’s closet, and begged not to be disturbed before the moment of	426.7746648349462
drawing swords.	390.0907550153046
Athos, by signs, desired Grimaud to bring another bottle of wine.	488.5806418233468
D’Artagnan employed himself in arranging a little plan, of which we	482.83545823443626
shall hereafter see the execution, and which promised him some	417.5097772366531
agreeable adventure, as might be seen by the smiles which from time to	399.9565216136727
time passed over his countenance, whose thoughtfulness they animated.	297.6875992995046
Chapter XXXI.	461.0986744545693
ENGLISH AND FRENCH	415.225856084099
The hour having come, they went with their four lackeys to a spot	420.60834758621144
behind the Luxembourg given up to the feeding of goats. Athos threw a	487.20422330096125
piece of money to the goatkeeper to withdraw. The lackeys were ordered	462.6343606904726
to act as sentinels.	390.7311905196739
A silent party soon drew near to the same enclosure, entered, and	316.78047839237615
joined the Musketeers. Then, according to foreign custom, the	491.6925252016232
presentations took place.	425.82961476675723
The Englishmen were all men of rank; consequently the odd names of	323.7846415345201
their adversaries were for them not only a matter of surprise, but of	473.6815801692648
annoyance.	351.59255021782064
“But after all,” said Lord de Winter, when the three friends had been	400.6129882141169
named, “we do not know who you are. We cannot fight with such names;	355.3808758023606
they are names of shepherds.”	314.0912869693132
“Therefore your lordship may suppose they are only assumed names,” said	381.744524695721
Athos.	306.2678658891991
“Which only gives us a greater desire to know the real ones,” replied	440.5476038900472
the Englishman.	472.7387694567884
“You played very willingly with us without knowing our names,” said	368.33405991365606
Athos, “by the same token that you won our horses.”	311.6234897154992
“That is true, but we then only risked our pistoles; this time we risk	449.2586044899556
our blood. One plays with anybody; but one fights only with equals.”	466.29118856433763
“And that is but just,” said Athos, and he took aside the one of the	302.720861676565
four Englishmen with whom he was to fight, and communicated his name in	457.50596334153937
a low voice.	452.80754927246915
Porthos and Aramis did the same.	459.32850477714817
“Does that satisfy you?” said Athos to his adversary. “Do you find me	325.5750583668045
of sufficient rank to do me the honor of crossing swords with me?”	448.68692457761256
“Yes, monsieur,” said the Englishman, bowing.	292.61822635124236
“Well! now shall I tell you something?” added Athos, coolly.	349.0132912442799
“What?” replied the Englishman.	443.18571764009675
“Why, that is that you would have acted much more wisely if you had not	351.26541352453216
required me to make myself known.”	393.4022869792466
“Why so?”	449.4727570019873
“Because I am believed to be dead, and have reasons for wishing nobody	359.61608325284215
to know I am living; so that I shall be obliged to kill you to prevent	466.735394041091
my secret from roaming over the fields.”	347.38060586482607
The Englishman looked at Athos, believing that he jested, but Athos did	407.2887150386192
not jest the least in the world.	425.3219375790078
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, addressing at the same time his companions and	467.22102296315205
their adversaries, “are we ready?”	308.2993343848093
“Yes!” answered the Englishmen and the Frenchmen, as with one voice.	399.09306526743256
“On guard, then!” cried Athos.	385.7120966897589
Immediately eight swords glittered in the rays of the setting sun, and	352.1169095585324
the combat began with an animosity very natural between men twice	335.3799188952527
enemies.	344.02235615239454
Athos fenced with as much calmness and method as if he had been	427.1196631656279
practicing in a fencing school.	454.6446752660821
Porthos, abated, no doubt, of his too-great confidence by his adventure	397.60050355498
of Chantilly, played with skill and prudence. Aramis, who had the third	473.4252884312455
canto of his poem to finish, behaved like a man in haste.	340.9999354922704
Athos killed his adversary first. He hit him but once, but as he had	370.9205366525489
foretold, that hit was a mortal one; the sword pierced his heart.	339.1148662707793
Second, Porthos stretched his upon the grass with a wound through his	466.0034722240778
thigh, As the Englishman, without making any further resistance, then	373.89224929832454
surrendered his sword, Porthos took him up in his arms and bore him to	339.6882985320909
his carriage.	408.9207499774461
Aramis pushed his so vigorously that after going back fifty paces, the	409.262570488085
man ended by fairly taking to his heels, and disappeared amid the	422.1852159080562
hooting of the lackeys.	383.20917125933613
As to D’Artagnan, he fought purely and simply on the defensive; and	343.3149741351782
when he saw his adversary pretty well fatigued, with a vigorous side	476.10765776615955
thrust sent his sword flying. The baron, finding himself disarmed, took	346.0061464617543
two or three steps back, but in this movement his foot slipped and he	363.378346568528
fell backward.	472.7549203132623
D’Artagnan was over him at a bound, and said to the Englishman,	479.53904586372784
pointing his sword to his throat, “I could kill you, my Lord, you are	368.5252841466554
completely in my hands; but I spare your life for the sake of your	305.92973531097056
sister.”	342.1247613253146
D’Artagnan was at the height of joy; he had realized the plan he had	445.64662164639856
imagined beforehand, whose picturing had produced the smiles we noted	473.8351125066388
upon his face.	418.76746928316584
The Englishman, delighted at having to do with a gentleman of such a	316.2045258824387
kind disposition, pressed D’Artagnan in his arms, and paid a thousand	295.2392027622133
compliments to the three Musketeers, and as Porthos’s adversary was	309.7403179475289
already installed in the carriage, and as Aramis’s had taken to his	302.8391346085476
heels, they had nothing to think about but the dead.	385.3172429906195
As Porthos and Aramis were undressing him, in the hope of finding his	330.53442834430496
wound not mortal, a large purse dropped from his clothes. D’Artagnan	317.6512381002417
picked it up and offered it to Lord de Winter.	430.09307151468477
“What the devil would you have me do with that?” said the Englishman.	409.21939369738067
“You can restore it to his family,” said D’Artagnan.	304.753450043445
“His family will care much about such a trifle as that! His family will	360.20395086065344
inherit fifteen thousand louis a year from him. Keep the purse for your	484.22720963838344
lackeys.”	389.50330241542997
D’Artagnan put the purse into his pocket.	298.1895437825674
“And now, my young friend, for you will permit me, I hope, to give you	425.24177021787943
that name,” said Lord de Winter, “on this very evening, if agreeable to	425.60057495788504
you, I will present you to my sister, Milady Clarik, for I am desirous	320.24100471703184
that she should take you into her good graces; and as she is not in bad	316.3875541479076
odor at court, she may perhaps on some future day speak a word that	396.0626833537231
will not prove useless to you.”	353.32718610300526
D’Artagnan blushed with pleasure, and bowed a sign of assent.	309.5973505040914
At this time Athos came up to D’Artagnan.	383.3751904094224
“What do you mean to do with that purse?” whispered he.	382.76144933490104
“Why, I meant to pass it over to you, my dear Athos.”	397.94630858464103
“Me! why to me?”	438.6846718029228
“Why, you killed him! They are the spoils of victory.”	412.78547869584025
“I, the heir of an enemy!” said Athos; “for whom, then, do you take	364.6699252508523
me?”	419.7954975207375
“It is the custom in war,” said D’Artagnan, “why should it not be the	448.00087916068446
custom in a duel?”	452.2497731284891
“Even on the field of battle, I have never done that.”	390.2962560623807
Porthos shrugged his shoulders; Aramis by a movement of his lips	367.4906678450635
endorsed Athos.	359.51743633955084
“Then,” said D’Artagnan, “let us give the money to the lackeys, as Lord	488.44172547834853
de Winter desired us to do.”	362.78417338077605
“Yes,” said Athos; “let us give the money to the lackeys—not to our	384.2176556893136
lackeys, but to the lackeys of the Englishmen.”	453.8691822257347
Athos took the purse, and threw it into the hand of the coachman. “For	327.3681351132701
you and your comrades.”	424.77054393641777
This greatness of spirit in a man who was quite destitute struck even	450.2950848784997
Porthos; and this French generosity, repeated by Lord de Winter and his	350.15542659554137
friend, was highly applauded, except by MM. Grimaud, Bazin, Mousqueton	409.3904787886032
and Planchet.	309.18848347745916
Lord de Winter, on quitting D’Artagnan, gave him his sister’s address.	334.1072280019257
She lived in the Place Royale—then the fashionable quarter—at Number 6,	329.11647372462835
and he undertook to call and take D’Artagnan with him in order to	365.6174472791986
introduce him. D’Artagnan appointed eight o’clock at Athos’s residence.	398.8900482246357
This introduction to Milady Clarik occupied the head of our Gascon	399.66284551422484
greatly. He remembered in what a strange manner this woman had hitherto	466.2675679191534
been mixed up in his destiny. According to his conviction, she was some	485.33270996082854
creature of the cardinal, and yet he felt himself invincibly drawn	474.9799092713175
toward her by one of those sentiments for which we cannot account. His	396.39183814430316
only fear was that Milady would recognize in him the man of Meung and	402.5813873740855
of Dover. Then she knew that he was one of the friends of M. de	457.1645804265072
Tréville, and consequently, that he belonged body and soul to the king;	486.2816263365712
which would make him lose a part of his advantage, since when known to	483.20629579332694
Milady as he knew her, he played only an equal game with her. As to the	310.1397255846157
commencement of an intrigue between her and M. de Wardes, our	293.231319275644
presumptuous hero gave but little heed to that, although the marquis	407.77918552194075
was young, handsome, rich, and high in the cardinal’s favor. It is not	454.12440044333016
for nothing we are but twenty years old, above all if we were born at	336.7555245020387
Tarbes.	384.7470612674632
D’Artagnan began by making his most splendid toilet, then returned to	428.38512175336393
Athos’s, and according to custom, related everything to him. Athos	491.13744800761924
listened to his projects, then shook his head, and recommended prudence	322.0263977843149
to him with a shade of bitterness.	346.1715498092079
“What!” said he, “you have just lost one woman, whom you call good,	389.23586544837065
charming, perfect; and here you are, running headlong after another.”	338.4711800908428
D’Artagnan felt the truth of this reproach.	299.4584431694107
“I loved Madame Bonacieux with my heart, while I only love Milady with	442.85168678790524
my head,” said he. “In getting introduced to her, my principal object	384.37719804462904
is to ascertain what part she plays at court.”	322.1210358397464
“The part she plays, _pardieu!_ It is not difficult to divine that,	444.12095423852395
after all you have told me. She is some emissary of the cardinal; a	335.4804078556553
woman who will draw you into a snare in which you will leave your	374.0762394590515
head.”	424.7583102629501
“The devil! my dear Athos, you view things on the dark side, methinks.”	483.30430267933025
“My dear fellow, I mistrust women. Can it be otherwise? I bought my	396.3411557345627
experience dearly—particularly fair women. Milady is fair, you say?”	304.28424353440835
“She has the most beautiful light hair imaginable!”	481.6635324638694
“Ah, my poor D’Artagnan!” said Athos.	477.3338351252527
“Listen to me! I want to be enlightened on a subject; then, when I	403.98085193225086
shall have learned what I desire to know, I will withdraw.”	482.69155246825835
“Be enlightened!” said Athos, phlegmatically.	454.5253790392985
Lord de Winter arrived at the appointed time; but Athos, being warned	377.668971850555
of his coming, went into the other chamber. He therefore found	370.98716793166074
D’Artagnan alone, and as it was nearly eight o’clock he took the young	358.2546007754727
man with him.	461.13861315326994
An elegant carriage waited below, and as it was drawn by two excellent	301.7382865098209
horses, they were soon at the Place Royale.	394.2425561622238
Milady Clarik received D’Artagnan ceremoniously. Her hôtel was	421.1619357599101
remarkably sumptuous, and while the most part of the English had quit,	379.457105313633
or were about to quit, France on account of the war, Milady had just	334.2666478763381
been laying out much money upon her residence; which proved that the	417.41940503447324
general measure which drove the English from France did not affect her.	361.74582981780515
“You see,” said Lord de Winter, presenting D’Artagnan to his sister, “a	445.5320031806783
young gentleman who has held my life in his hands, and who has not	304.2122588071074
abused his advantage, although we have been twice enemies, although it	459.1837579760049
was I who insulted him, and although I am an Englishman. Thank him,	343.73653542532435
then, madame, if you have any affection for me.”	429.14501612852075
Milady frowned slightly; a scarcely visible cloud passed over her brow,	345.7548457124083
and so peculiar a smile appeared upon her lips that the young man, who	315.02532864595184
saw and observed this triple shade, almost shuddered at it.	424.84308213089446
The brother did not perceive this; he had turned round to play with	398.3248913123022
Milady’s favorite monkey, which had pulled him by the doublet.	387.90833117733456
“You are welcome, monsieur,” said Milady, in a voice whose singular	401.23718354296966
sweetness contrasted with the symptoms of ill-humor which D’Artagnan	331.0685668755123
had just remarked; “you have today acquired eternal rights to my	435.8582527125252
gratitude.”	382.7080965319808
The Englishman then turned round and described the combat without	382.5844725624878
omitting a single detail. Milady listened with the greatest attention,	395.9974276892152
and yet it was easily to be perceived, whatever effort she made to	339.36853552337277
conceal her impressions, that this recital was not agreeable to her.	298.68208574562146
The blood rose to her head, and her little foot worked with impatience	316.9584739438762
beneath her robe.	418.3819153278337
Lord de Winter perceived nothing of this. When he had finished, he went	445.52654117483587
to a table upon which was a salver with Spanish wine and glasses. He	326.7343105995352
filled two glasses, and by a sign invited D’Artagnan to drink.	322.5120023597242
D’Artagnan knew it was considered disobliging by an Englishman to	334.81786739327333
refuse to pledge him. He therefore drew near to the table and took the	481.2189440174121
second glass. He did not, however, lose sight of Milady, and in a	368.28278092215885
mirror he perceived the change that came over her face. Now that she	337.2859370899441
believed herself to be no longer observed, a sentiment resembling	396.0180311358845
ferocity animated her countenance. She bit her handkerchief with her	389.11786501805176
beautiful teeth.	396.6848767074142
That pretty little _soubrette_ whom D’Artagnan had already observed	307.21188494413417
then came in. She spoke some words to Lord de Winter in English, who	435.90258818527485
thereupon requested D’Artagnan’s permission to retire, excusing himself	292.50447778883296
on account of the urgency of the business that had called him away, and	312.4322681376692
charging his sister to obtain his pardon.	419.9374716930668
D’Artagnan exchanged a shake of the hand with Lord de Winter, and then	361.50932208335706
returned to Milady. Her countenance, with surprising mobility, had	478.51898075916915
recovered its gracious expression; but some little red spots on her	344.558957402361
handkerchief indicated that she had bitten her lips till the blood	337.0395952758387
came. Those lips were magnificent; they might be said to be of coral.	360.0375287250674
The conversation took a cheerful turn. Milady appeared to have entirely	387.53078830933396
recovered. She told D’Artagnan that Lord de Winter was her	361.16195110077075
brother-in-law, and not her brother. She had married a younger brother	439.639892999385
of the family, who had left her a widow with one child. This child was	460.504277825818
the only heir to Lord de Winter, if Lord de Winter did not marry. All	364.2402529641247
this showed D’Artagnan that there was a veil which concealed something;	330.183051003468
but he could not yet see under this veil.	393.1972934437754
In addition to this, after a half hour’s conversation D’Artagnan was	359.87958812008685
convinced that Milady was his compatriot; she spoke French with an	363.7654714222592
elegance and a purity that left no doubt on that head.	298.3006698601804
D’Artagnan was profuse in gallant speeches and protestations of	396.7479848504681
devotion. To all the simple things which escaped our Gascon, Milady	463.6652752265387
replied with a smile of kindness. The hour came for him to retire.	488.7687725321664
D’Artagnan took leave of Milady, and left the saloon the happiest of	437.2687163905756
men.	390.2295137953899
On the staircase he met the pretty _soubrette_, who brushed gently	402.86468685631957
against him as she passed, and then, blushing to the eyes, asked his	342.9561418001566
pardon for having touched him in a voice so sweet that the pardon was	345.5501030423031
granted instantly.	475.81020511377983
D’Artagnan came again on the morrow, and was still better received than	479.55234760697107
on the evening before. Lord de Winter was not at home; and it was	417.2983891961548
Milady who this time did all the honors of the evening. She appeared to	384.20813542250824
take a great interest in him, asked him whence he came, who were his	457.41408990094527
friends, and whether he had not sometimes thought of attaching himself	466.32477584368576
to the cardinal.	323.9591418237842
D’Artagnan, who, as we have said, was exceedingly prudent for a young	351.8912088159554
man of twenty, then remembered his suspicions regarding Milady. He	440.2374964366369
launched into a eulogy of his Eminence, and said that he should not	309.66065453541285
have failed to enter into the Guards of the cardinal instead of the	451.2645947500698
king’s Guards if he had happened to know M. de Cavois instead of M. de	469.79087707985076
Tréville.	300.55789935128695
Milady changed the conversation without any appearance of affectation,	440.4807464314209
and asked D’Artagnan in the most careless manner possible if he had	302.040373983588
ever been in England.	395.7069065365961
D’Artagnan replied that he had been sent thither by M. de Tréville to	297.19584539265304
treat for a supply of horses, and that he had brought back four as	410.83972321872767
specimens.	485.0196188878044
Milady in the course of the conversation twice or thrice bit her lips;	332.88310419534156
she had to deal with a Gascon who played close.	423.66897176377825
At the same hour as on the preceding evening, D’Artagnan retired. In	394.54096884168143
the corridor he again met the pretty Kitty; that was the name of the	452.7180399362029
_soubrette_. She looked at him with an expression of kindness which it	362.7243842374281
was impossible to mistake; but D’Artagnan was so preoccupied by the	311.6058218374967
mistress that he noticed absolutely nothing but her.	374.624038700698
D’Artagnan came again on the morrow and the day after that, and each	321.9569328508393
day Milady gave him a more gracious reception.	316.1090822052487
Every evening, either in the antechamber, the corridor, or on the	405.18586612976924
stairs, he met the pretty _soubrette_. But, as we have said, D’Artagnan	479.6515608920379
paid no attention to this persistence of poor Kitty.	341.58077618886654
Chapter XXXII.	307.0095411062402
A PROCURATOR’S DINNER	487.4917870869528
However brilliant had been the part played by Porthos in the duel, it	396.19385814372947
had not made him forget the dinner of the procurator’s wife.	439.4432275798953
On the morrow he received the last touches of Mousqueton’s brush for an	420.57686848951613
hour, and took his way toward the Rue aux Ours with the steps of a man	456.12772568482416
who was doubly in favor with fortune.	371.45216073463473
His heart beat, but not like D’Artagnan’s with a young and impatient	426.2253470661776
love. No; a more material interest stirred his blood. He was about at	292.8305778037112
last to pass that mysterious threshold, to climb those unknown stairs	411.6516771987782
by which, one by one, the old crowns of M. Coquenard had ascended. He	408.24134858468346
was about to see in reality a certain coffer of which he had twenty	352.06829054842956
times beheld the image in his dreams—a coffer long and deep, locked,	401.49764743535525
bolted, fastened in the wall; a coffer of which he had so often heard,	413.30250330308775
and which the hands—a little wrinkled, it is true, but still not	489.9337504517912
without elegance—of the procurator’s wife were about to open to his	409.7546906849968
admiring looks.	437.06819899336153
And then he—a wanderer on the earth, a man without fortune, a man	437.4239355219735
without family, a soldier accustomed to inns, cabarets, taverns, and	376.8599833652508
restaurants, a lover of wine forced to depend upon chance treats—was	326.9298305996533
about to partake of family meals, to enjoy the pleasures of a	362.85015837562804
comfortable establishment, and to give himself up to those little	320.89963061137786
attentions which “the harder one is, the more they please,” as old	370.6059061669985
soldiers say.	475.08047969714437
To come in the capacity of a cousin, and seat himself every day at a	322.95585257080677
good table; to smooth the yellow, wrinkled brow of the old procurator;	447.4513037824333
to pluck the clerks a little by teaching them _bassette_, _passe-dix_,	448.2963665731919
and _lansquenet_, in their utmost nicety, and winning from them, by way	398.0138049468252
of fee for the lesson he would give them in an hour, their savings of a	440.53998862340717
month—all this was enormously delightful to Porthos.	485.17693152359027
The Musketeer could not forget the evil reports which then prevailed,	416.7255071885768
and which indeed have survived them, of the procurators of the	485.76109228627223
period—meanness, stinginess, fasts; but as, after all, excepting some	395.3014398072364
few acts of economy which Porthos had always found very unseasonable,	463.78717365750674
the procurator’s wife had been tolerably liberal—that is, be it	423.14431318624963
understood, for a procurator’s wife—he hoped to see a household of a	328.38675373169605
highly comfortable kind.	321.6062765526065
And yet, at the very door the Musketeer began to entertain some doubts.	324.3461272360975
The approach was not such as to prepossess people—an ill-smelling, dark	407.21381267373613
passage, a staircase half-lighted by bars through which stole a glimmer	300.2684505886843
from a neighboring yard; on the first floor a low door studded with	375.0613652036792
enormous nails, like the principal gate of the Grand Châtelet.	451.3351581496687
Porthos knocked with his hand. A tall, pale clerk, his face shaded by a	397.79776530776473
forest of virgin hair, opened the door, and bowed with the air of a man	410.7728678389937
forced at once to respect in another lofty stature, which indicated	420.24788510424094
strength, the military dress, which indicated rank, and a ruddy	426.2152697577966
countenance, which indicated familiarity with good living.	320.4788012730354
A shorter clerk came behind the first, a taller clerk behind the	303.15539799449493
second, a stripling of a dozen years rising behind the third. In all,	413.5995723694058
three clerks and a half, which, for the time, argued a very extensive	411.2047084137805
clientage.	450.860817478998
Although the Musketeer was not expected before one o’clock, the	365.98577408440633
procurator’s wife had been on the watch ever since midday, reckoning	377.220714675631
that the heart, or perhaps the stomach, of her lover would bring him	298.52221491923973
before his time.	368.3792342138395
Mme. Coquenard therefore entered the office from the house at the same	431.53637199017993
moment her guest entered from the stairs, and the appearance of the	437.36438303575756
worthy lady relieved him from an awkward embarrassment. The clerks	341.66140490362034
surveyed him with great curiosity, and he, not knowing well what to say	335.58067450488613
to this ascending and descending scale, remained tongue-tied.	417.35223271896376
“It is my cousin!” cried the procurator’s wife. “Come in, come in,	358.5185280307126
Monsieur Porthos!”	344.3970460658145
The name of Porthos produced its effect upon the clerks, who began to	489.3837252518613
laugh; but Porthos turned sharply round, and every countenance quickly	430.6535243289973
recovered its gravity.	352.2378337203904
They reached the office of the procurator after having passed through	391.53119115960925
the antechamber in which the clerks were, and the study in which they	326.19589768876017
ought to have been. This last apartment was a sort of dark room,	484.0020004404784
littered with papers. On quitting the study they left the kitchen on	344.4808382478083
the right, and entered the reception room.	458.87201279601936
All these rooms, which communicated with one another, did not inspire	331.99304366628576
Porthos favorably. Words might be heard at a distance through all these	377.3491135712939
open doors. Then, while passing, he had cast a rapid, investigating	457.3532136767663
glance into the kitchen; and he was obliged to confess to himself, to	465.6836264221587
the shame of the procurator’s wife and his own regret, that he did not	364.6691499563773
see that fire, that animation, that bustle, which when a good repast is	339.883147437393
on foot prevails generally in that sanctuary of good living.	325.75740277366316
The procurator had without doubt been warned of his visit, as he	395.184708661407
expressed no surprise at the sight of Porthos, who advanced toward him	389.31386786903266
with a sufficiently easy air, and saluted him courteously.	331.6331550668739
“We are cousins, it appears, Monsieur Porthos?” said the procurator,	466.1823521764497
rising, yet supporting his weight upon the arms of his cane chair.	399.00010328950134
The old man, wrapped in a large black doublet, in which the whole of	379.1692706507426
his slender body was concealed, was brisk and dry. His little gray eyes	475.8716275503747
shone like carbuncles, and appeared, with his grinning mouth, to be the	311.16668509935676
only part of his face in which life survived. Unfortunately the legs	371.80771482373683
began to refuse their service to this bony machine. During the last	440.8825646878602
five or six months that this weakness had been felt, the worthy	437.3587315609549
procurator had nearly become the slave of his wife.	432.0053945098538
The cousin was received with resignation, that was all. M. Coquenard,	295.3123672640444
firm upon his legs, would have declined all relationship with M.	370.6751432957798
Porthos.	368.5902140637601
“Yes, monsieur, we are cousins,” said Porthos, without being	407.912657898274
disconcerted, as he had never reckoned upon being received	305.4270107633203
enthusiastically by the husband.	446.9590853244468
“By the female side, I believe?” said the procurator, maliciously.	468.0984327062125
Porthos did not feel the ridicule of this, and took it for a piece of	418.6537257095403
simplicity, at which he laughed in his large mustache. Mme. Coquenard,	364.1662824988674
who knew that a simple-minded procurator was a very rare variety in the	324.8306601673591
species, smiled a little, and colored a great deal.	409.9200930075951
M. Coquenard had, since the arrival of Porthos, frequently cast his	470.4887120152992
eyes with great uneasiness upon a large chest placed in front of his	381.33154679566906
oak desk. Porthos comprehended that this chest, although it did not	379.92786387559204
correspond in shape with that which he had seen in his dreams, must be	380.4309739451438
the blessed coffer, and he congratulated himself that the reality was	414.91485876739114
several feet higher than the dream.	379.6462173197135
M. Coquenard did not carry his genealogical investigations any further;	481.9373744015845
but withdrawing his anxious look from the chest and fixing it upon	336.59975350247134
Porthos, he contented himself with saying, “Monsieur our cousin will do	431.9477530879709
us the favor of dining with us once before his departure for the	465.4540367035007
campaign, will he not, Madame Coquenard?”	347.4723246522268
This time Porthos received the blow right in his stomach, and felt it.	298.2748917162732
It appeared likewise that Mme. Coquenard was not less affected by it on	415.9890003323824
her part, for she added, “My cousin will not return if he finds that we	315.6634691584392
do not treat him kindly; but otherwise he has so little time to pass in	433.09551829794293
Paris, and consequently to spare to us, that we must entreat him to	313.44496857644634
give us every instant he can call his own previous to his departure.”	402.6060144371101
“Oh, my legs, my poor legs! where are you?” murmured Coquenard, and he	299.31132498371426
tried to smile.	424.5200057265725
This succor, which came to Porthos at the moment in which he was	426.9734402139112
attacked in his gastronomic hopes, inspired much gratitude in the	312.9702351900697
Musketeer toward the procurator’s wife.	364.8269114800413
The hour of dinner soon arrived. They passed into the eating room—a	486.7006567467189
large dark room situated opposite the kitchen.	447.5473902875239
The clerks, who, as it appeared, had smelled unusual perfumes in the	380.48349902819285
house, were of military punctuality, and held their stools in hand	384.23633947103997
quite ready to sit down. Their jaws moved preliminarily with fearful	483.1017969924817
threatenings.	340.63420746653384
“Indeed!” thought Porthos, casting a glance at the three hungry	390.270882159159
clerks—for the errand boy, as might be expected, was not admitted to	406.165023007075
the honors of the magisterial table, “in my cousin’s place, I would not	428.4359404966996
keep such gourmands! They look like shipwrecked sailors who have not	324.2028622128754
eaten for six weeks.”	339.707318456008
M. Coquenard entered, pushed along upon his armchair with casters by	301.01744853579646
Mme. Coquenard, whom Porthos assisted in rolling her husband up to the	471.9819402675017
table. He had scarcely entered when he began to agitate his nose and	304.05246023686647
his jaws after the example of his clerks.	312.10549542227955
“Oh, oh!” said he; “here is a soup which is rather inviting.”	435.0569829843405
“What the devil can they smell so extraordinary in this soup?” said	460.6612451669797
Porthos, at the sight of a pale liquid, abundant but entirely free from	388.65682633912877
meat, on the surface of which a few crusts swam about as rare as the	387.38964264563793
islands of an archipelago.	299.6586101206821
Mme. Coquenard smiled, and upon a sign from her everyone eagerly took	373.79979980934706
his seat.	347.1240549082427
M. Coquenard was served first, then Porthos. Afterward Mme. Coquenard	453.3823245273957
filled her own plate, and distributed the crusts without soup to the	458.75854191769076
impatient clerks. At this moment the door of the dining room unclosed	296.95814263126687
with a creak, and Porthos perceived through the half-open flap the	479.02946851160414
little clerk who, not being allowed to take part in the feast, ate his	386.46737787208366
dry bread in the passage with the double odor of the dining room and	470.2101885139955
kitchen.	394.6123798344456
After the soup the maid brought a boiled fowl—a piece of magnificence	411.0215482918908
which caused the eyes of the diners to dilate in such a manner that	377.54501900573194
they seemed ready to burst.	490.1164301578083
“One may see that you love your family, Madame Coquenard,” said the	452.71006560099187
procurator, with a smile that was almost tragic. “You are certainly	376.67570390679117
treating your cousin very handsomely!”	300.26621427206766
The poor fowl was thin, and covered with one of those thick, bristly	403.64571993594325
skins through which the teeth cannot penetrate with all their efforts.	474.85892299248076
The fowl must have been sought for a long time on the perch, to which	459.57614843317594
it had retired to die of old age.	301.7715314190582
“The devil!” thought Porthos, “this is poor work. I respect old age,	315.89634808830033
but I don’t much like it boiled or roasted.”	422.0462019015141
And he looked round to see if anybody partook of his opinion; but on	436.17317162661
the contrary, he saw nothing but eager eyes which were devouring, in	386.5414571576588
anticipation, that sublime fowl which was the object of his contempt.	395.72870967981066
Mme. Coquenard drew the dish toward her, skillfully detached the two	335.3851942243343
great black feet, which she placed upon her husband’s plate, cut off	299.3246642446538
the neck, which with the head she put on one side for herself, raised	378.96848893994513
the wing for Porthos, and then returned the bird otherwise intact to	405.7794937693708
the servant who had brought it in, who disappeared with it before the	479.55861353427827
Musketeer had time to examine the variations which disappointment	385.71371734399554
produces upon faces, according to the characters and temperaments of	485.1395802266206
those who experience it.	363.8591900406097
In the place of the fowl a dish of haricot beans made its appearance—an	483.7860716090669
enormous dish in which some bones of mutton that at first sight one	300.15740212659864
might have believed to have some meat on them pretended to show	397.4516678395971
themselves.	408.24094861666765
But the clerks were not the dupes of this deceit, and their lugubrious	353.652730930372
looks settled down into resigned countenances.	466.4430411476689
Mme. Coquenard distributed this dish to the young men with the	305.0296225895067
moderation of a good housewife.	353.1163400415311
The time for wine came. M. Coquenard poured from a very small stone	372.82480363791353
bottle the third of a glass for each of the young men, served himself	486.2086056500935
in about the same proportion, and passed the bottle to Porthos and Mme.	412.0930805095451
Coquenard.	445.8290725020746
The young men filled up their third of a glass with water; then, when	457.9005833607051
they had drunk half the glass, they filled it up again, and continued	439.62369400136936
to do so. This brought them, by the end of the repast, to swallowing a	359.501188349871
drink which from the color of the ruby had passed to that of a pale	410.28221777661304
topaz.	485.78078951340694
Porthos ate his wing of the fowl timidly, and shuddered when he felt	358.5715432357452
the knee of the procurator’s wife under the table, as it came in search	429.13079179306226
of his. He also drank half a glass of this sparingly served wine, and	429.89903920974734
found it to be nothing but that horrible Montreuil—the terror of all	299.2900555422475
expert palates.	475.0154191139377
M. Coquenard saw him swallowing this wine undiluted, and sighed deeply.	463.395857845784
“Will you eat any of these beans, Cousin Porthos?” said Mme. Coquenard,	465.1812942510851
in that tone which says, “Take my advice, don’t touch them.”	353.90597755729834
“Devil take me if I taste one of them!” murmured Porthos to himself,	296.75702839283787
and then said aloud, “Thank you, my cousin, I am no longer hungry.”	354.93999073217634
There was silence. Porthos could hardly keep his countenance.	421.6492110833227
The procurator repeated several times, “Ah, Madame Coquenard! Accept my	377.37452509957745
compliments; your dinner has been a real feast. Lord, how I have	415.6714782552425
eaten!”	367.04654650124826
M. Coquenard had eaten his soup, the black feet of the fowl, and the	442.7383758399129
only mutton bone on which there was the least appearance of meat.	323.0159404576864
Porthos fancied they were mystifying him, and began to curl his	411.31397577101217
mustache and knit his eyebrows; but the knee of Mme. Coquenard gently	404.5222094977382
advised him to be patient.	303.93944363193094
This silence and this interruption in serving, which were	325.61918673401027
unintelligible to Porthos, had, on the contrary, a terrible meaning for	443.0684806012145
the clerks. Upon a look from the procurator, accompanied by a smile	423.17217901106557
from Mme. Coquenard, they arose slowly from the table, folded their	325.2771632901453
napkins more slowly still, bowed, and retired.	431.11054810972126
“Go, young men! go and promote digestion by working,” said the	471.0922918550168
procurator, gravely.	314.749465618762
The clerks gone, Mme. Coquenard rose and took from a buffet a piece of	340.7417859541613
cheese, some preserved quinces, and a cake which she had herself made	488.48075624806995
of almonds and honey.	453.86471679255476
M. Coquenard knit his eyebrows because there were too many good things.	382.0268531987365
Porthos bit his lips because he saw not the wherewithal to dine. He	421.90031820827346
looked to see if the dish of beans was still there; the dish of beans	467.0700883124812
had disappeared.	461.25220622634924
“A positive feast!” cried M. Coquenard, turning about in his chair, “a	410.95327083818995
real feast, _epulœ epulorum_. Lucullus dines with Lucullus.”	332.377936793142
Porthos looked at the bottle, which was near him, and hoped that with	488.5612550043905
wine, bread, and cheese, he might make a dinner; but wine was wanting,	387.135257157223
the bottle was empty. M. and Mme. Coquenard did not seem to observe it.	491.98757748703645
“This is fine!” said Porthos to himself; “I am prettily caught!”	475.89374638282186
He passed his tongue over a spoonful of preserves, and stuck his teeth	474.11164391639807
into the sticky pastry of Mme. Coquenard.	317.8359184727159
“Now,” said he, “the sacrifice is consummated! Ah! if I had not the	340.80258722803256
hope of peeping with Madame Coquenard into her husband’s chest!”	402.1095414439565
M. Coquenard, after the luxuries of such a repast, which he called an	448.62903382240916
excess, felt the want of a siesta. Porthos began to hope that the thing	436.0775077360354
would take place at the present sitting, and in that same locality; but	347.0935379359678
the procurator would listen to nothing, he would be taken to his room,	369.21394917066584
and was not satisfied till he was close to his chest, upon the edge of	303.43904796634615
which, for still greater precaution, he placed his feet.	399.31590247375175
The procurator’s wife took Porthos into an adjoining room, and they	380.79239647322015
began to lay the basis of a reconciliation.	481.03841299979103
“You can come and dine three times a week,” said Mme. Coquenard.	355.5616899475872
“Thanks, madame!” said Porthos, “but I don’t like to abuse your	424.25120812943646
kindness; besides, I must think of my outfit!”	403.10420788243846
“That’s true,” said the procurator’s wife, groaning, “that unfortunate	335.8412284808635
outfit!”	428.0263428474125
“Alas, yes,” said Porthos, “it is so.”	392.6058590703118
“But of what, then, does the equipment of your company consist,	399.5684870549511
Monsieur Porthos?”	397.22951720417853
“Oh, of many things!” said Porthos. “The Musketeers are, as you know,	358.5326932543494
picked soldiers, and they require many things useless to the Guardsmen	367.32823631287624
or the Swiss.”	317.59204750042886
“But yet, detail them to me.”	447.62079897100705
“Why, they may amount to—“, said Porthos, who preferred discussing the	489.4507927268827
total to taking them one by one.	367.4521129593361
The procurator’s wife waited tremblingly.	365.2003712027631
“To how much?” said she. “I hope it does not exceed—” She stopped;	416.6292524804272
speech failed her.	456.5130416402864
“Oh, no,” said Porthos, “it does not exceed two thousand five hundred	389.6564776763793
livres! I even think that with economy I could manage it with two	381.9256689314127
thousand livres.”	297.721194110069
“Good God!” cried she, “two thousand livres! Why, that is a fortune!”	413.83371926044964
Porthos made a most significant grimace; Mme. Coquenard understood it.	318.98618760078597
“I wished to know the detail,” said she, “because, having many	361.04039054015215
relatives in business, I was almost sure of obtaining things at a	314.08408492894785
hundred per cent less than you would pay yourself.”	435.3255286852534
“Ah, ah!” said Porthos, “that is what you meant to say!”	396.9016295215205
“Yes, dear Monsieur Porthos. Thus, for instance, don’t you in the first	447.3685088245692
place want a horse?”	458.65783338160793
“Yes, a horse.”	377.04472087895135
“Well, then! I can just suit you.”	428.8891386458302
“Ah!” said Porthos, brightening, “that’s well as regards my horse; but	422.4000977646771
I must have the appointments complete, as they include objects which a	468.45060456377337
Musketeer alone can purchase, and which will not amount, besides, to	322.7787638721743
more than three hundred livres.”	392.19157228029997
“Three hundred livres? Then put down three hundred livres,” said the	430.86235452835103
procurator’s wife, with a sigh.	432.393284299703
Porthos smiled. It may be remembered that he had the saddle which came	427.87332983296324
from Buckingham. These three hundred livres he reckoned upon putting	309.3273450173763
snugly into his pocket.	300.7979340308974
“Then,” continued he, “there is a horse for my lackey, and my valise.	309.39066422467505
As to my arms, it is useless to trouble you about them; I have them.”	350.05547587527917
“A horse for your lackey?” resumed the procurator’s wife, hesitatingly;	362.73578318566877
“but that is doing things in lordly style, my friend.”	345.1430294334048
“Ah, madame!” said Porthos, haughtily; “do you take me for a beggar?”	429.413003818033
“No; I only thought that a pretty mule makes sometimes as good an	362.3892913838965
appearance as a horse, and it seemed to me that by getting a pretty	434.7892998940115
mule for Mousqueton—”	317.39098952048295
“Well, agreed for a pretty mule,” said Porthos; “you are right, I have	394.2176669518998
seen very great Spanish nobles whose whole suite were mounted on mules.	363.09272414243003
But then you understand, Madame Coquenard, a mule with feathers and	448.6374526930621
bells.”	402.19955520597665
“Be satisfied,” said the procurator’s wife.	475.05040188073247
“There remains the valise,” added Porthos.	382.5559375017317
“Oh, don’t let that disturb you,” cried Mme. Coquenard. “My husband has	416.9015741471816
five or six valises; you shall choose the best. There is one in	370.62577597122214
particular which he prefers in his journeys, large enough to hold all	365.5627395480757
the world.”	319.9916411348447
“Your valise is then empty?” asked Porthos, with simplicity.	436.8682074616549
“Certainly it is empty,” replied the procurator’s wife, in real	383.7178012986765
innocence.	426.2679561533769
“Ah, but the valise I want,” cried Porthos, “is a well-filled one, my	300.897236884421
dear.”	427.1851514647046
Madame uttered fresh sighs. Molière had not written his scene in	442.93806978305247
“L’Avare” then. Mme. Coquenard was in the dilemma of Harpagan.	468.1459542311569
Finally, the rest of the equipment was successively debated in the same	309.405205813244
manner; and the result of the sitting was that the procurator’s wife	305.46352349682087
should give eight hundred livres in money, and should furnish the horse	427.24146094405177
and the mule which should have the honor of carrying Porthos and	344.3846848343423
Mousqueton to glory.	394.82986236091403
These conditions being agreed to, Porthos took leave of Mme. Coquenard.	298.3849638926995
The latter wished to detain him by darting certain tender glances; but	429.9412224757555
Porthos urged the commands of duty, and the procurator’s wife was	348.5744379491349
obliged to give place to the king.	384.8392874759048
The Musketeer returned home hungry and in bad humor.	361.5169404255752
Chapter XXXIII.	489.3713886825276
SOUBRETTE AND MISTRESS	322.27110201793215
Meantime, as we have said, despite the cries of his conscience and the	384.3753187904533
wise counsels of Athos, D’Artagnan became hourly more in love with	378.859342632243
Milady. Thus he never failed to pay his diurnal court to her; and the	402.9473790405107
self-satisfied Gascon was convinced that sooner or later she could not	453.9594505000052
fail to respond.	336.38253606322405
One day, when he arrived with his head in the air, and as light at	303.86301488244635
heart as a man who awaits a shower of gold, he found the _soubrette_	307.51669575174884
under the gateway of the hôtel; but this time the pretty Kitty was not	489.08654544043577
contented with touching him as he passed, she took him gently by the	392.2510575477861
hand.	309.13556925443555
“Good!” thought D’Artagnan, “She is charged with some message for me	482.08572604987074
from her mistress; she is about to appoint some rendezvous of which she	361.30498857635087
had not courage to speak.” And he looked down at the pretty girl with	441.72678340807283
the most triumphant air imaginable.	360.21018895468745
“I wish to say three words to you, Monsieur Chevalier,” stammered the	333.9230305618978
_soubrette_.	467.8437142548728
“Speak, my child, speak,” said D’Artagnan; “I listen.”	374.90380231062807
“Here? Impossible! That which I have to say is too long, and above all,	367.2157569955647
too secret.”	324.75784302420027
“Well, what is to be done?”	353.92346359127185
“If Monsieur Chevalier would follow me?” said Kitty, timidly.	408.7967156771772
“Where you please, my dear child.”	317.36776223189617
“Come, then.”	430.87748737274967
And Kitty, who had not let go the hand of D’Artagnan, led him up a	377.98835241282256
little dark, winding staircase, and after ascending about fifteen	384.46436711311145
steps, opened a door.	414.6258813553622
“Come in here, Monsieur Chevalier,” said she; “here we shall be alone,	372.1229373853742
and can talk.”	375.56627162393914
“And whose room is this, my dear child?”	423.92920855979946
“It is mine, Monsieur Chevalier; it communicates with my mistress’s by	312.4133308877751
that door. But you need not fear. She will not hear what we say; she	400.1598651094447
never goes to bed before midnight.”	327.22769213202946
D’Artagnan cast a glance around him. The little apartment was charming	461.04979099498655
for its taste and neatness; but in spite of himself, his eyes were	473.9614034805319
directed to that door which Kitty said led to Milady’s chamber.	488.2695001787922
Kitty guessed what was passing in the mind of the young man, and heaved	477.057717520446
a deep sigh.	422.6661682070463
“You love my mistress, then, very dearly, Monsieur Chevalier?” said	425.9062192333447
she.	407.92317434317033
“Oh, more than I can say, Kitty! I am mad for her!”	393.3716960973751
Kitty breathed a second sigh.	309.4427765157307
“Alas, monsieur,” said she, “that is too bad.”	414.68432108311094
“What the devil do you see so bad in it?” said D’Artagnan.	368.955504206183
“Because, monsieur,” replied Kitty, “my mistress loves you not at all.”	397.72068049244376
“_Hein!_” said D’Artagnan, “can she have charged you to tell me so?”	381.1050842028386
“Oh, no, monsieur; but out of the regard I have for you, I have taken	428.46776303651666
the resolution to tell you so.”	381.8934492688178
“Much obliged, my dear Kitty; but for the intention only—for the	423.53635523747715
information, you must agree, is not likely to be at all agreeable.”	404.82256095942256
“That is to say, you don’t believe what I have told you; is it not so?”	474.90941089101045
“We have always some difficulty in believing such things, my pretty	447.3830406385497
dear, were it only from self-love.”	406.15162595628647
“Then you don’t believe me?”	460.6713015805112
“I confess that unless you deign to give me some proof of what you	301.6164825127164
advance—”	435.1599128822711
“What do you think of this?”	344.9617103957198
Kitty drew a little note from her bosom.	321.69804774121553
“For me?” said D’Artagnan, seizing the letter.	430.18887458701363
“No; for another.”	473.62433206028095
“For another?”	369.1224728607625
“Yes.”	383.23104031263733
“His name; his name!” cried D’Artagnan.	415.3114854450414
“Read the address.”	487.0147149529279
“Monsieur El Comte de Wardes.”	486.8378586367181
The remembrance of the scene at St. Germain presented itself to the	336.1630360917448
mind of the presumptuous Gascon. As quick as thought, he tore open the	465.0516402819097
letter, in spite of the cry which Kitty uttered on seeing what he was	298.9019756479927
going to do, or rather, what he was doing.	453.59969433054357
“Oh, good Lord, Monsieur Chevalier,” said she, “what are you doing?”	400.7008627282443
“I?” said D’Artagnan; “nothing,” and he read,	454.8520758934535
“You have not answered my first note. Are you indisposed, or have you	404.3032163973384
forgotten the glances you favored me with at the ball of Mme. de Guise?	409.6715480287831
You have an opportunity now, Count; do not allow it to escape.”	400.9914171038223
D’Artagnan became very pale; he was wounded in his _self_-love: he	431.1584530882782
thought that it was in his _love_.	460.69300644565396
“Poor dear Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said Kitty, in a voice full of	465.8600503410119
compassion, and pressing anew the young man’s hand.	327.6671159728846
“You pity me, little one?” said D’Artagnan.	354.47169454113106
“Oh, yes, and with all my heart; for I know what it is to be in love.”	367.32271175288247
“You know what it is to be in love?” said D’Artagnan, looking at her	454.6756122213127
for the first time with much attention.	464.3964763884117
“Alas, yes.”	337.7046013742892
“Well, then, instead of pitying me, you would do much better to assist	303.3819259970034
me in avenging myself on your mistress.”	352.8802891343637
“And what sort of revenge would you take?”	418.19677184575323
“I would triumph over her, and supplant my rival.”	352.95521367435424
“I will never help you in that, Monsieur Chevalier,” said Kitty,	471.6012635537701
warmly.	441.3134351343822
“And why not?” demanded D’Artagnan.	464.616263191361
“For two reasons.”	338.1913672102645
“What ones?”	466.77565154161675
“The first is that my mistress will never love you.”	457.34780312726025
“How do you know that?”	362.102562292558
“You have cut her to the heart.”	294.98087014201155
“I? In what can I have offended her—I who ever since I have known her	336.61339697277424
have lived at her feet like a slave? Speak, I beg you!”	361.0986521867832
“I will never confess that but to the man—who should read to the bottom	426.8252075166104
of my soul!”	403.21336995424485
D’Artagnan looked at Kitty for the second time. The young girl had	330.36547027633594
freshness and beauty which many duchesses would have purchased with	358.9134697214689
their coronets.	306.87812830279324
“Kitty,” said he, “I will read to the bottom of your soul whenever you	393.59911002950275
like; don’t let that disturb you.” And he gave her a kiss at which the	312.18196618926635
poor girl became as red as a cherry.	425.59881230738705
“Oh, no,” said Kitty, “it is not me you love! It is my mistress you	315.81428076403955
love; you told me so just now.”	367.9344486275059
“And does that hinder you from letting me know the second reason?”	361.75491633079383
“The second reason, Monsieur the Chevalier,” replied Kitty, emboldened	341.7437515060141
by the kiss in the first place, and still further by the expression of	387.87407557801833
the eyes of the young man, “is that in love, everyone for herself!”	415.438062754001
Then only D’Artagnan remembered the languishing glances of Kitty, her	488.1499879555347
constantly meeting him in the antechamber, the corridor, or on the	313.40119729160847
stairs, those touches of the hand every time she met him, and her deep	474.7390198707974
sighs; but absorbed by his desire to please the great lady, he had	419.982601302976
disdained the _soubrette_. He whose game is the eagle takes no heed of	318.69060930710816
the sparrow.	308.34892052834687
But this time our Gascon saw at a glance all the advantage to be	430.97122121412406
derived from the love which Kitty had just confessed so innocently, or	348.41266524960264
so boldly: the interception of letters addressed to the Comte de	311.5532525059869
Wardes, news on the spot, entrance at all hours into Kitty’s chamber,	313.6434618761052
which was contiguous to her mistress’s. The perfidious deceiver was, as	482.5289523090528
may plainly be perceived, already sacrificing, in intention, the poor	478.2796802155374
girl in order to obtain Milady, willy-nilly.	313.7554793455763
“Well,” said he to the young girl, “are you willing, my dear Kitty,	471.439482006714
that I should give you a proof of that love which you doubt?”	303.33623167287385
“What love?” asked the young girl.	333.30590299393776
“Of that which I am ready to feel toward you.”	434.71694113187266
“And what is that proof?”	474.9368708535516
“Are you willing that I should this evening pass with you the time I	387.674092079346
generally spend with your mistress?”	466.34924055776946
“Oh, yes,” said Kitty, clapping her hands, “very willing.”	317.2037780690629
“Well, then, come here, my dear,” said D’Artagnan, establishing himself	293.45815511020317
in an easy chair; “come, and let me tell you that you are the prettiest	334.58255307659704
_soubrette_ I ever saw!”	436.42590952139506
And he did tell her so much, and so well, that the poor girl, who asked	366.68117944377815
nothing better than to believe him, did believe him. Nevertheless, to	320.181125080836
D’Artagnan’s great astonishment, the pretty Kitty defended herself	407.0606749684233
resolutely.	373.75009253998394
Time passes quickly when it is passed in attacks and defenses. Midnight	360.4430687473006
sounded, and almost at the same time the bell was rung in Milady’s	456.5861751335579
chamber.	396.1005533826275
“Good God,” cried Kitty, “there is my mistress calling me! Go; go	295.12714390549934
directly!”	386.9361214665814
D’Artagnan rose, took his hat, as if it had been his intention to obey,	404.0323781326269
