then, opening quickly the door of a large closet instead of that	370.59495389574414
leading to the staircase, he buried himself amid the robes and dressing	327.1049140273734
gowns of Milady.	455.3365900107036
“What are you doing?” cried Kitty.	343.81844785783954
D’Artagnan, who had secured the key, shut himself up in the closet	382.986590036199
without reply.	452.434162937372
“Well,” cried Milady, in a sharp voice. “Are you asleep, that you don’t	307.78376927510703
answer when I ring?”	332.05281633041676
And D’Artagnan heard the door of communication opened violently.	405.88990369163184
“Here am I, Milady, here am I!” cried Kitty, springing forward to meet	466.3826765755429
her mistress.	293.0426471577688
Both went into the bedroom, and as the door of communication remained	395.4588487404883
open, D’Artagnan could hear Milady for some time scolding her maid. She	424.2316603603874
was at length appeased, and the conversation turned upon him while	305.30471809848535
Kitty was assisting her mistress.	325.5761969647699
“Well,” said Milady, “I have not seen our Gascon this evening.”	446.38711004459094
“What, Milady! has he not come?” said Kitty. “Can he be inconstant	356.2610988476779
before being happy?”	369.4636851054443
“Oh, no; he must have been prevented by Monsieur de Tréville or	385.5175568067075
Monsieur Dessessart. I understand my game, Kitty; I have this one	349.6036056916669
safe.”	333.9930295064538
“What will you do with him, madame?”	379.66895450633643
“What will I do with him? Be easy, Kitty, there is something between	448.3793551589267
that man and me that he is quite ignorant of: he nearly made me lose my	455.35842745157765
credit with his Eminence. Oh, I will be revenged!”	423.84468494616243
“I believed that Madame loved him.”	386.14824029273956
“I love him? I detest him! An idiot, who held the life of Lord de	372.3861046108883
Winter in his hands and did not kill him, by which I missed three	304.58304117414843
hundred thousand livres’ income.”	346.04437136188864
“That’s true,” said Kitty; “your son was the only heir of his uncle,	480.51321411352336
and until his majority you would have had the enjoyment of his	490.06208977002683
fortune.”	486.3218621357772
D’Artagnan shuddered to the marrow at hearing this suave creature	375.6153584943453
reproach him, with that sharp voice which she took such pains to	419.33890593896916
conceal in conversation, for not having killed a man whom he had seen	407.7949593609381
load her with kindnesses.	354.51865845996485
“For all this,” continued Milady, “I should long ago have revenged	396.20736424242546
myself on him if, and I don’t know why, the cardinal had not requested	297.53048898323186
me to conciliate him.”	444.4798333525464
“Oh, yes; but Madame has not conciliated that little woman he was so	436.15140098594
fond of.”	445.0496584161583
“What, the mercer’s wife of the Rue des Fossoyeurs? Has he not already	345.1648550361158
forgotten she ever existed? Fine vengeance that, on my faith!”	467.757987486404
A cold sweat broke from D’Artagnan’s brow. Why, this woman was a	404.4860750348744
monster! He resumed his listening, but unfortunately the toilet was	442.3489870843089
finished.	453.1622874443134
“That will do,” said Milady; “go into your own room, and tomorrow	384.20903102167557
endeavor again to get me an answer to the letter I gave you.”	486.7997874535485
“For Monsieur de Wardes?” said Kitty.	440.13241102645543
“To be sure; for Monsieur de Wardes.”	477.21269652966345
“Now, there is one,” said Kitty, “who appears to me quite a different	348.7191593737938
sort of a man from that poor Monsieur d’Artagnan.”	426.51230491957665
“Go to bed, mademoiselle,” said Milady; “I don’t like comments.”	367.4397849167346
D’Artagnan heard the door close; then the noise of two bolts by which	397.73920059927354
Milady fastened herself in. On her side, but as softly as possible,	391.43382555549067
Kitty turned the key of the lock, and then D’Artagnan opened the closet	469.3645150162846
door.	479.4023447209738
“Oh, good Lord!” said Kitty, in a low voice, “what is the matter with	474.7039914928072
you? How pale you are!”	364.49373363484017
“The abominable creature,” murmured D’Artagnan.	316.54736455968265
“Silence, silence, begone!” said Kitty. “There is nothing but a	364.8053361724938
wainscot between my chamber and Milady’s; every word that is uttered in	438.7808905351337
one can be heard in the other.”	386.69879539590045
“That’s exactly the reason I won’t go,” said D’Artagnan.	424.13262543831814
“What!” said Kitty, blushing.	429.1100814941013
“Or, at least, I will go—later.”	488.2650450056527
He drew Kitty to him. She had the less motive to resist, resistance	465.2187769339903
would make so much noise. Therefore Kitty surrendered.	481.47440111490016
It was a movement of vengeance upon Milady. D’Artagnan believed it	443.69398445885565
right to say that vengeance is the pleasure of the gods. With a little	398.53187619112117
more heart, he might have been contented with this new conquest; but	412.0815104221814
the principal features of his character were ambition and pride. It	402.53765812530366
must, however, be confessed in his justification that the first use he	469.1363333522429
made of his influence over Kitty was to try and find out what had	420.23665514651435
become of Mme. Bonacieux; but the poor girl swore upon the crucifix to	484.18878969042464
D’Artagnan that she was entirely ignorant on that head, her mistress	460.52672418002214
never admitting her into half her secrets—only she believed she could	372.7655662385827
say she was not dead.	447.06136567377837
As to the cause which was near making Milady lose her credit with the	407.1247102301505
cardinal, Kitty knew nothing about it; but this time D’Artagnan was	393.2799123110169
better informed than she was. As he had seen Milady on board a vessel	424.6721438743298
at the moment he was leaving England, he suspected that it was, almost	383.0433725612387
without a doubt, on account of the diamond studs.	398.8386846585752
But what was clearest in all this was that the true hatred, the	475.16737100937263
profound hatred, the inveterate hatred of Milady, was increased by his	384.3899212358503
not having killed her brother-in-law.	398.91137123473976
D’Artagnan came the next day to Milady’s, and finding her in a very	475.17156259582964
ill-humor, had no doubt that it was lack of an answer from M. de Wardes	459.7439319280529
that provoked her thus. Kitty came in, but Milady was very cross with	336.51595706695394
her. The poor girl ventured a glance at D’Artagnan which said, “See how	298.58763557080374
I suffer on your account!”	430.7309340007883
Toward the end of the evening, however, the beautiful lioness became	351.1477228813252
milder; she smilingly listened to the soft speeches of D’Artagnan, and	456.4559786481708
even gave him her hand to kiss.	464.99416171792063
D’Artagnan departed, scarcely knowing what to think, but as he was a	410.0441514651909
youth who did not easily lose his head, while continuing to pay his	349.69789860738825
court to Milady, he had framed a little plan in his mind.	453.2668333035796
He found Kitty at the gate, and, as on the preceding evening, went up	327.4614549438242
to her chamber. Kitty had been accused of negligence and severely	452.9265879858878
scolded. Milady could not at all comprehend the silence of the Comte de	435.83146367151636
Wardes, and she ordered Kitty to come at nine o’clock in the morning to	338.3341607601485
take a third letter.	413.49392349688935
D’Artagnan made Kitty promise to bring him that letter on the following	352.6788313219564
morning. The poor girl promised all her lover desired; she was mad.	489.71264511376876
Things passed as on the night before. D’Artagnan concealed himself in	389.49105554179204
his closet; Milady called, undressed, sent away Kitty, and shut the	306.2856251193665
door. As the night before, D’Artagnan did not return home till five	383.1707177445501
o’clock in the morning.	294.405719929478
At eleven o’clock Kitty came to him. She held in her hand a fresh	294.2179739258584
billet from Milady. This time the poor girl did not even argue with	303.51820192379523
D’Artagnan; she gave it to him at once. She belonged body and soul to	304.03488923528425
her handsome soldier.	479.9187385668298
D’Artagnan opened the letter and read as follows:	391.19778636035903
This is the third time I have written to you to tell you that I love	453.57891503994404
you. Beware that I do not write to you a fourth time to tell you that I	396.66274213537656
detest you.	475.54021336147343
    If you repent of the manner in which you have acted toward me, the	331.9233038180622
    young girl who brings you this will tell you how a man of spirit	461.3556220322715
    may obtain his pardon.	365.30051624154135
D’Artagnan colored and grew pale several times in reading this billet.	455.3928894661981
“Oh, you love her still,” said Kitty, who had not taken her eyes off	351.1255268216706
the young man’s countenance for an instant.	487.67371937126734
“No, Kitty, you are mistaken. I do not love her, but I will avenge	348.98434284226073
myself for her contempt.”	329.78990957538116
“Oh, yes, I know what sort of vengeance! You told me that!”	397.99816419148823
“What matters it to you, Kitty? You know it is you alone whom I love.”	376.98282279121025
“How can I know that?”	315.0310012972853
“By the scorn I will throw upon her.”	441.96359564789765
D’Artagnan took a pen and wrote:	428.9476459125656
MADAME, Until the present moment I could not believe that it was to me	348.23341052991293
your first two letters were addressed, so unworthy did I feel myself of	416.91511345711695
such an honor; besides, I was so seriously indisposed that I could not	416.55660647730787
in any case have replied to them.	352.29059172054735
    But now I am forced to believe in the excess of your kindness,	415.35851243929426
    since not only your letter but your servant assures me that I have	475.11943056839306
    the good fortune to be beloved by you.	399.01555205291
    She has no occasion to teach me the way in which a man of spirit	379.7980109652399
    may obtain his pardon. I will come and ask mine at eleven o’clock	298.3677867008679
    this evening.	432.908819903652
    To delay it a single day would be in my eyes now to commit a fresh	469.9665272594075
    offense.	460.20627085183
    From him whom you have rendered the happiest of men,	468.9173175259758
COMTE DE WARDES	313.8190408883685
This note was in the first place a forgery; it was likewise an	415.76621025595136
indelicacy. It was even, according to our present manners, something	373.9292131032764
like an infamous action; but at that period people did not manage	449.50288071494026
affairs as they do today. Besides, D’Artagnan from her own admission	308.7548824156696
knew Milady culpable of treachery in matters more important, and could	308.16226431647056
entertain no respect for her. And yet, notwithstanding this want of	313.15203810972025
respect, he felt an uncontrollable passion for this woman boiling in	387.54705150792347
his veins—passion drunk with contempt; but passion or thirst, as the	427.46752647131154
reader pleases.	386.841844809705
D’Artagnan’s plan was very simple. By Kitty’s chamber he could gain	416.9155239672816
that of her mistress. He would take advantage of the first moment of	415.5845433447176
surprise, shame, and terror, to triumph over her. He might fail, but	358.9483190968888
something must be left to chance. In eight days the campaign would	365.6302094023483
open, and he would be compelled to leave Paris; D’Artagnan had no time	333.2277538277366
for a prolonged love siege.	360.46911897473325
“There,” said the young man, handing Kitty the letter sealed; “give	438.69668738678575
that to Milady. It is the count’s reply.”	320.35787714826876
Poor Kitty became as pale as death; she suspected what the letter	329.3513377911044
contained.	481.3045345227751
“Listen, my dear girl,” said D’Artagnan; “you cannot but perceive that	310.287903011447
all this must end, some way or other. Milady may discover that you gave	311.852765028726
the first billet to my lackey instead of to the count’s; that it is I	410.48542982284073
who have opened the others which ought to have been opened by de	383.4883751153197
Wardes. Milady will then turn you out of doors, and you know she is not	408.56332364322077
the woman to limit her vengeance.”	457.70471092338073
“Alas!” said Kitty, “for whom have I exposed myself to all that?”	367.92299160196904
“For me, I well know, my sweet girl,” said D’Artagnan. “But I am	442.0409322962956
grateful, I swear to you.”	472.29644688315653
“But what does this note contain?”	382.76910260681024
“Milady will tell you.”	375.75292712541443
“Ah, you do not love me!” cried Kitty, “and I am very wretched.”	434.78019146830763
To this reproach there is always one response which deludes women.	418.0197611902926
D’Artagnan replied in such a manner that Kitty remained in her great	407.12647427791956
delusion. Although she cried freely before deciding to transmit the	410.1566304877704
letter to her mistress, she did at last so decide, which was all	366.3297283523948
D’Artagnan wished. Finally he promised that he would leave her	432.0259554338329
mistress’s presence at an early hour that evening, and that when he	380.1419055992608
left the mistress he would ascend with the maid. This promise completed	471.3892218106874
poor Kitty’s consolation.	314.48542824429234
Chapter XXXIV.	432.98271153777176
IN WHICH THE EQUIPMENT OF ARAMIS AND PORTHOS IS TREATED OF	301.5822237565095
Since the four friends had been each in search of his equipments, there	426.7842883708147
had been no fixed meeting between them. They dined apart from one	388.4068944581352
another, wherever they might happen to be, or rather where they could.	429.12808560270196
Duty likewise on its part took a portion of that precious time which	303.19003254537114
was gliding away so rapidly—only they had agreed to meet once a week,	426.86703570189445
about one o’clock, at the residence of Athos, seeing that he, in	432.83808704517685
agreement with the vow he had formed, did not pass over the threshold	404.17036289645216
of his door.	409.3916289068645
This day of reunion was the same day as that on which Kitty came to	329.9886947417184
find D’Artagnan. Soon as Kitty left him, D’Artagnan directed his steps	453.4793803680245
toward the Rue Férou.	328.04172582459967
He found Athos and Aramis philosophizing. Aramis had some slight	461.4089047960174
inclination to resume the cassock. Athos, according to his system,	365.228276559441
neither encouraged nor dissuaded him. Athos believed that everyone	319.420426113286
should be left to his own free will. He never gave advice but when it	333.7644503833299
was asked, and even then he required to be asked twice.	465.14329795505233
“People, in general,” he said, “only ask advice not to follow it; or if	331.8494431311769
they do follow it, it is for the sake of having someone to blame for	450.47601215127503
having given it.”	427.2430581778433
Porthos arrived a minute after D’Artagnan. The four friends were	432.82633055865534
reunited.	431.97324477879636
The four countenances expressed four different feelings: that of	460.94668337582186
Porthos, tranquillity; that of D’Artagnan, hope; that of Aramis,	393.90660926054994
uneasiness; that of Athos, carelessness.	296.93046089647595
At the end of a moment’s conversation, in which Porthos hinted that a	431.03096811676005
lady of elevated rank had condescended to relieve him from his	377.9267086605737
embarrassment, Mousqueton entered. He came to request his master to	299.56560803150757
return to his lodgings, where his presence was urgent, as he piteously	328.2025886598017
said.	391.62624938430685
“Is it my equipment?”	305.72322526998244
“Yes and no,” replied Mousqueton.	411.54466938251244
“Well, but can’t you speak?”	433.1633128061104
“Come, monsieur.”	467.15301602725526
Porthos rose, saluted his friends, and followed Mousqueton. An instant	438.5329774939555
after, Bazin made his appearance at the door.	426.47222713954375
“What do you want with me, my friend?” said Aramis, with that mildness	349.0367753314848
of language which was observable in him every time that his ideas were	393.4820357867409
directed toward the Church.	403.56450234239753
“A man wishes to see Monsieur at home,” replied Bazin.	338.0699810799561
“A man! What man?”	362.3091661074826
“A mendicant.”	490.6530384088366
“Give him alms, Bazin, and bid him pray for a poor sinner.”	353.17584142186985
“This mendicant insists upon speaking to you, and pretends that you	405.8802401117365
will be very glad to see him.”	319.63896058741454
“Has he sent no particular message for me?”	356.2799150064118
“Yes. If Monsieur Aramis hesitates to come,” he said, “tell him I am	312.9316466986727
from Tours.”	407.7130549456596
“From Tours!” cried Aramis. “A thousand pardons, gentlemen; but no	491.80007084514205
doubt this man brings me the news I expected.” And rising also, he went	426.80227079973247
off at a quick pace. There remained Athos and D’Artagnan.	395.6675749190892
“I believe these fellows have managed their business. What do you	333.346550823858
think, D’Artagnan?” said Athos.	359.6058170230256
“I know that Porthos was in a fair way,” replied D’Artagnan; “and as to	480.2344300012745
Aramis to tell you the truth, I have never been seriously uneasy on his	326.3554003564333
account. But you, my dear Athos—you, who so generously distributed the	330.5007117203267
Englishman’s pistoles, which were our legitimate property—what do you	424.9967401208283
mean to do?”	457.61732966995066
“I am satisfied with having killed that fellow, my boy, seeing that it	374.12103297038783
is blessed bread to kill an Englishman; but if I had pocketed his	443.63693807587134
pistoles, they would have weighed me down like a remorse.”	324.43692133457546
“Go to, my dear Athos; you have truly inconceivable ideas.”	437.63042361541824
“Let it pass. What do you think of Monsieur de Tréville telling me,	355.72985804574876
when he did me the honor to call upon me yesterday, that you associated	452.16818533124183
with the suspected English, whom the cardinal protects?”	351.386436867692
“That is to say, I visit an Englishwoman—the one I named.”	474.6764931808947
“Oh, ay! the fair woman on whose account I gave you advice, which	418.90228992242726
naturally you took care not to adopt.”	413.60952892146
“I gave you my reasons.”	461.20959221513095
“Yes; you look there for your outfit, I think you said.”	440.59571516378924
“Not at all. I have acquired certain knowledge that that woman was	368.95891392150384
concerned in the abduction of Madame Bonacieux.”	425.22601159841867
“Yes, I understand now: to find one woman, you court another. It is the	356.26378957744265
longest road, but certainly the most amusing.”	416.71580828340757
D’Artagnan was on the point of telling Athos all; but one consideration	444.56987825508094
restrained him. Athos was a gentleman, punctilious in points of honor;	443.6651602735172
and there were in the plan which our lover had devised for Milady, he	402.0145487457031
was sure, certain things that would not obtain the assent of this	387.8374291553167
Puritan. He was therefore silent; and as Athos was the least	331.6523431409693
inquisitive of any man on earth, D’Artagnan’s confidence stopped there.	341.7315614073997
We will therefore leave the two friends, who had nothing important to	409.05241637156803
say to each other, and follow Aramis.	342.43312573257197
Upon being informed that the person who wanted to speak to him came	451.6389739492105
from Tours, we have seen with what rapidity the young man followed, or	376.9207691863378
rather went before, Bazin; he ran without stopping from the Rue Férou	394.89830203488486
to the Rue de Vaugirard. On entering he found a man of short stature	449.04251711689943
and intelligent eyes, but covered with rags.	487.5077678992663
“You have asked for me?” said the Musketeer.	404.7296349994328
“I wish to speak with Monsieur Aramis. Is that your name, monsieur?”	405.7489548054761
“My very own. You have brought me something?”	410.64971003683365
“Yes, if you show me a certain embroidered handkerchief.”	438.8653835222094
“Here it is,” said Aramis, taking a small key from his breast and	356.58147372441465
opening a little ebony box inlaid with mother of pearl, “here it is.	401.02119940764635
Look.”	334.8123749535327
“That is right,” replied the mendicant; “dismiss your lackey.”	292.8068277223825
In fact, Bazin, curious to know what the mendicant could want with his	304.4066666761174
master, kept pace with him as well as he could, and arrived almost at	314.2428688075154
the same time he did; but his quickness was not of much use to him. At	451.6367019994317
the hint from the mendicant his master made him a sign to retire, and	456.4230893523752
he was obliged to obey.	398.7008578262499
Bazin gone, the mendicant cast a rapid glance around him in order to be	379.8395832412184
sure that nobody could either see or hear him, and opening his ragged	491.70410326914237
vest, badly held together by a leather strap, he began to rip the upper	353.6138516565397
part of his doublet, from which he drew a letter.	379.64393635495634
Aramis uttered a cry of joy at the sight of the seal, kissed the	308.85264859471147
superscription with an almost religious respect, and opened the	325.58619361390674
epistle, which contained what follows:	345.1981762743833
“My Friend, it is the will of fate that we should be still for some	400.6105947396911
time separated; but the delightful days of youth are not lost beyond	377.6080875726924
return. Perform your duty in camp; I will do mine elsewhere. Accept	406.0311618343885
that which the bearer brings you; make the campaign like a handsome	307.5052800360979
true gentleman, and think of me, who kisses tenderly your black eyes.	436.5923440098194
    “Adieu; or rather, _au revoir_.”	363.19257820899963
The mendicant continued to rip his garments; and drew from amid his	311.23485203151415
rags a hundred and fifty Spanish double pistoles, which he laid down on	436.42167096339324
the table; then he opened the door, bowed, and went out before the	351.8913179017829
young man, stupefied by his letter, had ventured to address a word to	384.0672201502006
him.	333.0746253937184
Aramis then reperused the letter, and perceived a postscript:	301.88017832381087
PS. You may behave politely to the bearer, who is a count and a grandee	325.10654591638513
of Spain!	361.43835295342893
“Golden dreams!” cried Aramis. “Oh, beautiful life! Yes, we are young;	327.16133736131457
yes, we shall yet have happy days! My love, my blood, my life! all,	431.21401177285895
all, all, are thine, my adored mistress!”	404.93714582268973
And he kissed the letter with passion, without even vouchsafing a look	363.3663952949622
at the gold which sparkled on the table.	340.34198625075317
Bazin scratched at the door, and as Aramis had no longer any reason to	324.8736882400277
exclude him, he bade him come in.	424.85641589399046
Bazin was stupefied at the sight of the gold, and forgot that he came	358.6498920730369
to announce D’Artagnan, who, curious to know who the mendicant could	441.09363467659716
be, came to Aramis on leaving Athos.	483.57452636865855
Now, as D’Artagnan used no ceremony with Aramis, seeing that Bazin	377.83844780911664
forgot to announce him, he announced himself.	347.08574962370545
“The devil! my dear Aramis,” said D’Artagnan, “if these are the prunes	376.6322208727646
that are sent to you from Tours, I beg you will make my compliments to	389.5792147995918
the gardener who gathers them.”	479.2754781888143
“You are mistaken, friend D’Artagnan,” said Aramis, always on his	491.809761035111
guard; “this is from my publisher, who has just sent me the price of	318.14452312455677
that poem in one-syllable verse which I began yonder.”	476.1820524148518
“Ah, indeed,” said D’Artagnan. “Well, your publisher is very generous,	459.3914706730986
my dear Aramis, that’s all I can say.”	418.27593795240824
“How, monsieur?” cried Bazin, “a poem sell so dear as that! It is	390.3082056852229
incredible! Oh, monsieur, you can write as much as you like; you may	460.3216496234793
become equal to Monsieur de Voiture and Monsieur de Benserade. I like	384.8914267800994
that. A poet is as good as an abbé. Ah! Monsieur Aramis, become a poet,	446.80012152378674
I beg of you.”	441.0476590680116
“Bazin, my friend,” said Aramis, “I believe you meddle with my	301.9472804165795
conversation.”	359.1357181200628
Bazin perceived he was wrong; he bowed and went out.	404.6096986978529
“Ah!” said D’Artagnan with a smile, “you sell your productions at their	334.6658869146555
weight in gold. You are very fortunate, my friend; but take care or you	388.96023922954134
will lose that letter which is peeping from your doublet, and which	482.6778935956305
also comes, no doubt, from your publisher.”	439.8383550861256
Aramis blushed to the eyes, crammed in the letter, and re-buttoned his	455.2954696369778
doublet.	394.14205967483935
“My dear D’Artagnan,” said he, “if you please, we will join our	403.5107829853487
friends; as I am rich, we will today begin to dine together again,	330.61838352471307
expecting that you will be rich in your turn.”	363.18395142277365
“My faith!” said D’Artagnan, with great pleasure. “It is long since we	415.16092380179276
have had a good dinner; and I, for my part, have a somewhat hazardous	434.9454172181732
expedition for this evening, and shall not be sorry, I confess, to	380.2177938870801
fortify myself with a few glasses of good old Burgundy.”	447.0976685570944
“Agreed, as to the old Burgundy; I have no objection to that,” said	408.35430512958345
Aramis, from whom the letter and the gold had removed, as by magic, his	445.43448340676537
ideas of conversion.	461.28475481515807
And having put three or four double pistoles into his pocket to answer	425.7359376379263
the needs of the moment, he placed the others in the ebony box, inlaid	413.9616147305605
with mother of pearl, in which was the famous handkerchief which served	452.8565974801827
him as a talisman.	403.8222132493865
The two friends repaired to Athos’s, and he, faithful to his vow of not	477.66829118728515
going out, took upon him to order dinner to be brought to them. As he	326.7039134079891
was perfectly acquainted with the details of gastronomy, D’Artagnan and	453.03732783788496
Aramis made no objection to abandoning this important care to him.	410.045760766726
They went to find Porthos, and at the corner of the Rue Bac met	469.00088842410537
Mousqueton, who, with a most pitiable air, was driving before him a	480.2584319334502
mule and a horse.	325.41525127316146
D’Artagnan uttered a cry of surprise, which was not quite free from	314.77098952381584
joy.	434.9359251274332
“Ah, my yellow horse,” cried he. “Aramis, look at that horse!”	461.847340467319
“Oh, the frightful brute!” said Aramis.	304.98594734044286
“Ah, my dear,” replied D’Artagnan, “upon that very horse I came to	361.66361599353166
Paris.”	324.25097008367413
“What, does Monsieur know this horse?” said Mousqueton.	491.7560866765926
“It is of an original color,” said Aramis; “I never saw one with such a	460.4638486604224
hide in my life.”	456.3152441993796
“I can well believe it,” replied D’Artagnan, “and that was why I got	368.03628506975394
three crowns for him. It must have been for his hide, for, _certes_,	433.9885491350998
the carcass is not worth eighteen livres. But how did this horse come	365.2888660362899
into your hands, Mousqueton?”	452.098209069508
“Pray,” said the lackey, “say nothing about it, monsieur; it is a	345.81522204380144
frightful trick of the husband of our duchess!”	320.2485525659356
“How is that, Mousqueton?”	456.4622092274112
“Why, we are looked upon with a rather favorable eye by a lady of	360.85903593953947
quality, the Duchesse de—but, your pardon; my master has commanded me	338.0805786336494
to be discreet. She had forced us to accept a little souvenir, a	312.0277661497589
magnificent Spanish _genet_ and an Andalusian mule, which were	344.2796536424744
beautiful to look upon. The husband heard of the affair; on their way	410.39963137694565
he confiscated the two magnificent beasts which were being sent to us,	348.7198911945717
and substituted these horrible animals.”	405.50522630718785
“Which you are taking back to him?” said D’Artagnan.	460.06405008291824
“Exactly!” replied Mousqueton. “You may well believe that we will not	455.5315739833195
accept such steeds as these in exchange for those which had been	365.8900242269332
promised to us.”	365.2867848922599
“No, _pardieu;_ though I should like to have seen Porthos on my yellow	294.43168065490374
horse. That would give me an idea of how I looked when I arrived in	293.19568967658734
Paris. But don’t let us hinder you, Mousqueton; go and perform your	364.86532146770026
master’s orders. Is he at home?”	339.19237411916055
“Yes, monsieur,” said Mousqueton, “but in a very ill humor. Get up!”	390.79384376194747
He continued his way toward the Quai des Grands Augustins, while the	448.73919996803
two friends went to ring at the bell of the unfortunate Porthos. He,	360.4723026528943
having seen them crossing the yard, took care not to answer, and they	338.8672745227309
rang in vain.	329.57353749997543
Meanwhile Mousqueton continued on his way, and crossing the Pont Neuf,	471.1368876412431
still driving the two sorry animals before him, he reached the Rue aux	310.5404939481344
Ours. Arrived there, he fastened, according to the orders of his	332.17935024278154
master, both horse and mule to the knocker of the procurator’s door;	312.1330048211249
then, without taking any thought for their future, he returned to	406.74709962492784
Porthos, and told him that his commission was completed.	467.3309163030924
In a short time the two unfortunate beasts, who had not eaten anything	402.4795159665361
since the morning, made such a noise in raising and letting fall the	441.18108793001784
knocker that the procurator ordered his errand boy to go and inquire in	306.54089912297746
the neighborhood to whom this horse and mule belonged.	431.09758069230264
Mme. Coquenard recognized her present, and could not at first	437.3173634100718
comprehend this restitution; but the visit of Porthos soon enlightened	343.3862108978359
her. The anger which fired the eyes of the Musketeer, in spite of his	472.31724528263203
efforts to suppress it, terrified his sensitive inamorata. In fact,	415.87422732920385
Mousqueton had not concealed from his master that he had met D’Artagnan	473.58173522015795
and Aramis, and that D’Artagnan in the yellow horse had recognized the	453.93228075294707
Béarnese pony upon which he had come to Paris, and which he had sold	320.8985579264862
for three crowns.	421.1445970788793
Porthos went away after having appointed a meeting with the	306.78136494299395
procurator’s wife in the cloister of St. Magloire. The procurator,	372.50928288762606
seeing he was going, invited him to dinner—an invitation which the	306.17740321123335
Musketeer refused with a majestic air.	394.5934665617439
Mme. Coquenard repaired trembling to the cloister of St. Magloire, for	466.1841243477294
she guessed the reproaches that awaited her there; but she was	412.2981171027948
fascinated by the lofty airs of Porthos.	454.50289102434186
All that which a man wounded in his self-love could let fall in the	380.14362640412116
shape of imprecations and reproaches upon the head of a woman Porthos	378.29924635992063
let fall upon the bowed head of the procurator’s wife.	334.8817538589433
“Alas,” said she, “I did all for the best! One of our clients is a	363.96347105705246
horsedealer; he owes money to the office, and is backward in his pay. I	307.3564752439508
took the mule and the horse for what he owed us; he assured me that	428.57155104303683
they were two noble steeds.”	347.0019218991862
“Well, madame,” said Porthos, “if he owed you more than five crowns,	453.04668343834373
your horsedealer is a thief.”	387.68261582253547
“There is no harm in trying to buy things cheap, Monsieur Porthos,”	333.40859899995473
said the procurator’s wife, seeking to excuse herself.	395.82293244023526
“No, madame; but they who so assiduously try to buy things cheap ought	343.73130655454236
to permit others to seek more generous friends.” And Porthos, turning	423.80565134146474
on his heel, made a step to retire.	404.002378358579
“Monsieur Porthos! Monsieur Porthos!” cried the procurator’s wife. “I	419.0054326511852
have been wrong; I see it. I ought not to have driven a bargain when it	312.37719867944327
was to equip a cavalier like you.”	491.78537326668356
Porthos, without reply, retreated a second step. The procurator’s wife	370.946003929684
fancied she saw him in a brilliant cloud, all surrounded by duchesses	487.0215033236136
and marchionesses, who cast bags of money at his feet.	464.24915974183784
“Stop, in the name of heaven, Monsieur Porthos!” cried she. “Stop, and	484.84233154205555
let us talk.”	380.2443766829733
“Talking with you brings me misfortune,” said Porthos.	339.1027515673551
“But, tell me, what do you ask?”	347.0588804615488
“Nothing; for that amounts to the same thing as if I asked you for	488.9781688014006
something.”	464.02727435164906
The procurator’s wife hung upon the arm of Porthos, and in the violence	472.56700924112397
of her grief she cried out, “Monsieur Porthos, I am ignorant of all	387.5032996363177
such matters! How should I know what a horse is? How should I know what	378.98447618074067
horse furniture is?”	378.63405607675327
“You should have left it to me, then, madame, who know what they are;	480.58706878932065
but you wished to be frugal, and consequently to lend at usury.”	434.3678926831509
“It was wrong, Monsieur Porthos; but I will repair that wrong, upon my	466.5271467613629
word of honor.”	305.7204852962617
“How so?” asked the Musketeer.	468.3188228931354
“Listen. This evening M. Coquenard is going to the house of the Duc de	402.46857799701814
Chaulnes, who has sent for him. It is for a consultation, which will	320.96762449291174
last three hours at least. Come! We shall be alone, and can make up our	356.5642037341212
accounts.”	431.68654999067456
“In good time. Now you talk, my dear.”	443.7792804048758
“You pardon me?”	397.871585045953
“We shall see,” said Porthos, majestically; and the two separated	411.5353591193374
saying, “Till this evening.”	398.5750211243657
“The devil!” thought Porthos, as he walked away, “it appears I am	427.0767106229399
getting nearer to Monsieur Coquenard’s strongbox at last.”	403.25711435989643
Chapter XXXV.	455.881801591778
A GASCON A MATCH FOR CUPID	376.19131704992395
The evening so impatiently waited for by Porthos and by D’Artagnan at	372.4474375344422
last arrived.	487.5581089129522
As was his custom, D’Artagnan presented himself at Milady’s at about	457.65559354001834
nine o’clock. He found her in a charming humor. Never had he been so	310.7353523891655
well received. Our Gascon knew, by the first glance of his eye, that	318.5215287612405
his billet had been delivered, and that this billet had had its effect.	379.78066584585645
Kitty entered to bring some sherbet. Her mistress put on a charming	389.736818885369
face, and smiled on her graciously; but alas! the poor girl was so sad	379.8691125044478
that she did not even notice Milady’s condescension.	338.8143836006232
D’Artagnan looked at the two women, one after the other, and was forced	434.4019451493002
to acknowledge that in his opinion Dame Nature had made a mistake in	457.93310337993626
their formation. To the great lady she had given a heart vile and	341.44214844889206
venal; to the _soubrette_ she had given the heart of a duchess.	488.88699254324865
At ten o’clock Milady began to appear restless. D’Artagnan knew what	461.0843864284245
she wanted. She looked at the clock, rose, reseated herself, smiled at	339.19398435663504
D’Artagnan with an air which said, “You are very amiable, no doubt, but	375.4521056903849
you would be _charming_ if you would only depart.”	343.0902932514059
D’Artagnan rose and took his hat; Milady gave him her hand to kiss. The	391.8692540191154
young man felt her press his hand, and comprehended that this was a	474.11378672648124
sentiment, not of coquetry, but of gratitude because of his departure.	382.5149067808027
“She loves him devilishly,” he murmured. Then he went out.	308.6926648378747
This time Kitty was nowhere waiting for him; neither in the	324.5917557897874
antechamber, nor in the corridor, nor beneath the great door. It was	411.22124133537665
necessary that D’Artagnan should find alone the staircase and the	486.2843258291242
little chamber. She heard him enter, but she did not raise her head.	305.2427508842157
The young man went to her and took her hands; then she sobbed aloud.	411.0183928032304
As D’Artagnan had presumed, on receiving his letter, Milady in a	306.89498839292264
delirium of joy had told her servant everything; and by way of	318.0820949584349
recompense for the manner in which she had this time executed the	468.39273240053706
commission, she had given Kitty a purse.	454.1363750320655
Returning to her own room, Kitty had thrown the purse into a corner,	448.58917390702163
where it lay open, disgorging three or four gold pieces on the carpet.	468.23304457816187
The poor girl, under the caresses of D’Artagnan, lifted her head.	429.02724380084726
D’Artagnan himself was frightened by the change in her countenance. She	376.7123759511487
joined her hands with a suppliant air, but without venturing to speak a	386.5689414497086
word. As little sensitive as was the heart of D’Artagnan, he was	469.4421264252245
touched by this mute sorrow; but he held too tenaciously to his	361.8453109484667
projects, above all to this one, to change the program which he had	302.4329389621369
laid out in advance. He did not therefore allow her any hope that he	345.3279610827984
would flinch; only he represented his action as one of simple	334.2452676490706
vengeance.	349.34802455455235
For the rest this vengeance was very easy; for Milady, doubtless to	389.1987725846696
conceal her blushes from her lover, had ordered Kitty to extinguish all	307.17841468502365
the lights in the apartment, and even in the little chamber itself.	368.94804455358184
Before daybreak M. de Wardes must take his departure, still in	337.6029750639403
obscurity.	313.61239430412496
Presently they heard Milady retire to her room. D’Artagnan slipped into	394.5366090995364
the wardrobe. Hardly was he concealed when the little bell sounded.	455.7147807723186
Kitty went to her mistress, and did not leave the door open; but the	450.9233628937051
partition was so thin that one could hear nearly all that passed	474.61591293596524
between the two women.	480.74560096793414
Milady seemed overcome with joy, and made Kitty repeat the smallest	325.0776073410479
details of the pretended interview of the _soubrette_ with De Wardes	399.27341638643804
when he received the letter; how he had responded; what was the	376.7077294080726
expression of his face; if he seemed very amorous. And to all these	455.93329171271546
questions poor Kitty, forced to put on a pleasant face, responded in a	349.4511316606741
stifled voice whose dolorous accent her mistress did not however	344.312012370139
remark, solely because happiness is egotistical.	310.2190730756601
Finally, as the hour for her interview with the count approached,	478.10701338439935
Milady had everything about her darkened, and ordered Kitty to return	453.9073366707935
to her own chamber, and introduce De Wardes whenever he presented	377.66099019743046
himself.	419.7780862595612
Kitty’s detention was not long. Hardly had D’Artagnan seen, through a	384.1683186049589
crevice in his closet, that the whole apartment was in obscurity, than	435.41187447614914
he slipped out of his concealment, at the very moment when Kitty	436.36816276567254
reclosed the door of communication.	360.885950360942
“What is that noise?” demanded Milady.	333.40236805701886
“It is I,” said D’Artagnan in a subdued voice, “I, the Comte de	468.1214182491108
Wardes.”	416.7759233704154
“Oh, my God, my God!” murmured Kitty, “he has not even waited for the	386.9582432657517
hour he himself named!”	470.6361928892303
“Well,” said Milady, in a trembling voice, “why do you not enter?	329.59642432370117
Count, Count,” added she, “you know that I wait for you.”	341.74856130666876
At this appeal D’Artagnan drew Kitty quietly away, and slipped into the	361.733162395279
chamber.	364.1718908781499
If rage or sorrow ever torture the heart, it is when a lover receives	354.149740830075
under a name which is not his own protestations of love addressed to	325.5962910638741
his happy rival. D’Artagnan was in a dolorous situation which he had	336.93164091131825
not foreseen. Jealousy gnawed his heart; and he suffered almost as much	417.3367511575908
as poor Kitty, who at that very moment was crying in the next chamber.	352.09972138747514
“Yes, Count,” said Milady, in her softest voice, and pressing his hand	295.1791768814314
in her own, “I am happy in the love which your looks and your words	425.9958365979237
have expressed to me every time we have met. I also—I love you. Oh,	461.29753290367034
tomorrow, tomorrow, I must have some pledge from you which will prove	335.68154539062385
that you think of me; and that you may not forget me, take this!” and	475.27491523989477
she slipped a ring from her finger onto D’Artagnan’s. D’Artagnan	416.1743092165352
remembered having seen this ring on the finger of Milady; it was a	327.51543631844277
magnificent sapphire, encircled with brilliants.	422.58922467900175
The first movement of D’Artagnan was to return it, but Milady added,	347.2035924760937
“No, no! Keep that ring for love of me. Besides, in accepting it,” she	354.91037646998336
added, in a voice full of emotion, “you render me a much greater	421.67869973392396
service than you imagine.”	397.2772607584778
“This woman is full of mysteries,” murmured D’Artagnan to himself. At	419.420139275712
that instant he felt himself ready to reveal all. He even opened his	382.5804998783541
mouth to tell Milady who he was, and with what a revengeful purpose he	372.32626383663967
had come; but she added, “Poor angel, whom that monster of a Gascon	375.8701175384799
barely failed to kill.”	459.6510777160371
The monster was himself.	295.8647182741321
“Oh,” continued Milady, “do your wounds still make you suffer?”	477.28126357547904
“Yes, much,” said D’Artagnan, who did not well know how to answer.	456.715669395247
“Be tranquil,” murmured Milady; “I will avenge you—and cruelly!”	400.3818361961952
“_Peste!_” said D’Artagnan to himself, “the moment for confidences has	487.67477694326885
not yet come.”	455.1687081311062
It took some time for D’Artagnan to resume this little dialogue; but	349.01491540959387
then all the ideas of vengeance which he had brought with him had	456.86721094646356
completely vanished. This woman exercised over him an unaccountable	400.5481338420788
power; he hated and adored her at the same time. He would not have	475.90214208393127
believed that two sentiments so opposite could dwell in the same heart,	426.2238752027065
and by their union constitute a passion so strange, and as it were,	360.28947338087886
diabolical.	483.7295804216785
Presently it sounded one o’clock. It was necessary to separate.	437.65695934915635
D’Artagnan at the moment of quitting Milady felt only the liveliest	334.9489136823935
regret at the parting; and as they addressed each other in a	436.9343351436379
reciprocally passionate adieu, another interview was arranged for the	341.12224252305236
following week.	381.1489025116324
Poor Kitty hoped to speak a few words to D’Artagnan when he passed	399.09996193875276
through her chamber; but Milady herself reconducted him through the	295.61344539813814
darkness, and only quit him at the staircase.	415.78554936611323
The next morning D’Artagnan ran to find Athos. He was engaged in an	483.27954413029886
adventure so singular that he wished for counsel. He therefore told him	316.77448537517586
all.	473.70616651064347
“Your Milady,” said he, “appears to be an infamous creature, but not	427.57361382473357
the less you have done wrong to deceive her. In one fashion or another	372.8608488580046
you have a terrible enemy on your hands.”	347.16335397816175
While thus speaking Athos regarded with attention the sapphire set with	415.78002172056364
diamonds which had taken, on D’Artagnan’s finger, the place of the	351.4169100316052
queen’s ring, carefully kept in a casket.	482.8999659977419
“You notice my ring?” said the Gascon, proud to display so rich a gift	427.78584388333525
in the eyes of his friends.	312.3041111305019
“Yes,” said Athos, “it reminds me of a family jewel.”	425.4001715809144
“It is beautiful, is it not?” said D’Artagnan.	314.1903986867878
“Yes,” said Athos, “magnificent. I did not think two sapphires of such	341.5532076087696
a fine water existed. Have you traded it for your diamond?”	329.9405802007989
“No. It is a gift from my beautiful Englishwoman, or rather	452.06960268402077
Frenchwoman—for I am convinced she was born in France, though I have	455.38731774121845
not questioned her.”	369.2499530052253
“That ring comes from Milady?” cried Athos, with a voice in which it	463.86099187964925
was easy to detect strong emotion.	362.40071209409
“Her very self; she gave it me last night. Here it is,” replied	330.5296317233057
D’Artagnan, taking it from his finger.	339.89625362450005
Athos examined it and became very pale. He tried it on his left hand;	485.84942129022244
it fit his finger as if made for it.	433.6148985157402
A shade of anger and vengeance passed across the usually calm brow of	439.6115904436113
this gentleman.	485.34914021112934
“It is impossible it can be she,” said he. “How could this ring come	479.22576223298535
into the hands of Milady Clarik? And yet it is difficult to suppose	311.72074825473
such a resemblance should exist between two jewels.”	416.9314406636664
“Do you know this ring?” said D’Artagnan.	345.4960148992456
“I thought I did,” replied Athos; “but no doubt I was mistaken.” And he	450.50140631745046
returned D’Artagnan the ring without, however, ceasing to look at it.	480.5176008250643
“Pray, D’Artagnan,” said Athos, after a minute, “either take off that	323.4409908768343
ring or turn the mounting inside; it recalls such cruel recollections	388.4984641571229
that I shall have no head to converse with you. Don’t ask me for	346.13937617057155
counsel; don’t tell me you are perplexed what to do. But stop! let me	440.0069822610661
look at that sapphire again; the one I mentioned to you had one of its	413.46993401635046
faces scratched by accident.”	456.4734269801545
D’Artagnan took off the ring, giving it again to Athos.	433.99688510779424
Athos started. “Look,” said he, “is it not strange?” and he pointed out	377.66099679201443
to D’Artagnan the scratch he had remembered.	484.06853056295085
“But from whom did this ring come to you, Athos?”	455.6869925885554
“From my mother, who inherited it from her mother. As I told you, it is	414.1852260330974
an old family jewel.”	380.1663711060967
“And you—sold it?” asked D’Artagnan, hesitatingly.	346.11328751910537
“No,” replied Athos, with a singular smile. “I gave it away in a night	357.53939705629136
of love, as it has been given to you.”	476.8180833030454
D’Artagnan became pensive in his turn; it appeared as if there were	432.00001796351137
abysses in Milady’s soul whose depths were dark and unknown. He took	411.97662141096055
back the ring, but put it in his pocket and not on his finger.	303.4988795336297
“D’Artagnan,” said Athos, taking his hand, “you know I love you; if I	333.2515834323133
had a son I could not love him better. Take my advice, renounce this	354.0421492630775
woman. I do not know her, but a sort of intuition tells me she is a	301.17699043854003
lost creature, and that there is something fatal about her.”	459.62835870751644
“You are right,” said D’Artagnan; “I will have done with her. I own	456.8653408087558
that this woman terrifies me.”	300.2263573589257
“Shall you have the courage?” said Athos.	354.21389440000615
“I shall,” replied D’Artagnan, “and instantly.”	303.87138769929163
“In truth, my young friend, you will act rightly,” said the gentleman,	429.1689950105071
pressing the Gascon’s hand with an affection almost paternal; “and God	301.67668360824774
grant that this woman, who has scarcely entered into your life, may not	468.21182726956874
leave a terrible trace in it!” And Athos bowed to D’Artagnan like a man	339.5291553914352
who wishes it understood that he would not be sorry to be left alone	457.95915653444933
with his thoughts.	448.28729979672596
On reaching home D’Artagnan found Kitty waiting for him. A month of	428.0557490864578
fever could not have changed her more than this one night of	315.31531070516763
sleeplessness and sorrow.	402.60636368566986
She was sent by her mistress to the false De Wardes. Her mistress was	384.9050957870693
mad with love, intoxicated with joy. She wished to know when her lover	352.8694634004332
would meet her a second night; and poor Kitty, pale and trembling,	402.72177835155685
awaited D’Artagnan’s reply. The counsels of his friend, joined to the	412.6068119338637
cries of his own heart, made him determine, now his pride was saved and	456.9992481961359
his vengeance satisfied, not to see Milady again. As a reply, he wrote	460.57150877264394
the following letter:	490.0740822410593
Do not depend upon me, madame, for the next meeting. Since my	449.9780340314687
convalescence I have so many affairs of this kind on my hands that I am	337.7650180842657
forced to regulate them a little. When your turn comes, I shall have	412.81762746318816
the honor to inform you of it. I kiss your hands.	477.59415462340377
COMTE DE WARDES	461.91405648039876
Not a word about the sapphire. Was the Gascon determined to keep it as	479.2709811584109
a weapon against Milady, or else, let us be frank, did he not reserve	332.57340890661675
the sapphire as a last resource for his outfit? It would be wrong to	370.14632706900665
judge the actions of one period from the point of view of another. That	347.27250607323055
which would now be considered as disgraceful to a gentleman was at that	330.0853091938451
time quite a simple and natural affair, and the younger sons of the	347.4182623261041
best families were frequently supported by their mistresses. D’Artagnan	404.8020478345669
gave the open letter to Kitty, who at first was unable to comprehend	395.2325926632344
it, but who became almost wild with joy on reading it a second time.	292.28029034425924
She could scarcely believe in her happiness; and D’Artagnan was forced	433.02358067859683
to renew with the living voice the assurances which he had written. And	423.56440799308825
whatever might be—considering the violent character of Milady—the	361.9481825145733
danger which the poor girl incurred in giving this billet to her	444.42908262123865
mistress, she ran back to the Place Royale as fast as her legs could	469.89052623244606
carry her.	425.2008237596931
The heart of the best woman is pitiless toward the sorrows of a rival.	313.74146474976015
Milady opened the letter with eagerness equal to Kitty’s in bringing	298.96986878306956
it; but at the first words she read she became livid. She crushed the	318.15416468559056
paper in her hand, and turning with flashing eyes upon Kitty, she	376.0859182665921
cried, “What is this letter?”	429.7848097299822
“The answer to Madame’s,” replied Kitty, all in a tremble.	475.63757399784333
“Impossible!” cried Milady. “It is impossible a gentleman could have	474.3527733284049
written such a letter to a woman.” Then all at once, starting, she	425.0208049790548
cried, “My God! can he have—” and she stopped. She ground her teeth;	380.5692855510571
she was of the color of ashes. She tried to go toward the window for	361.8888573664281
air, but she could only stretch forth her arms; her legs failed her,	394.5209299085623
and she sank into an armchair. Kitty, fearing she was ill, hastened	384.0216991172524
toward her and was beginning to open her dress; but Milady started up,	428.3651705939046
pushing her away. “What do you want with me?” said she, “and why do you	482.33368757605774
place your hand on me?”	408.8861171688278
“I thought that Madame was ill, and I wished to bring her help,”	472.5300121793242
responded the maid, frightened at the terrible expression which had	407.70115580225115
come over her mistress’s face.	447.3257410264158
“I faint? I? I? Do you take me for half a woman? When I am insulted I	309.5869745472809
do not faint; I avenge myself!”	482.70762562093563
And she made a sign for Kitty to leave the room.	428.78898408200484
Chapter XXXVI.	450.65246349884933
DREAM OF VENGEANCE	341.7251468691696
That evening Milady gave orders that when M. d’Artagnan came as usual,	461.46520990384784
he should be immediately admitted; but he did not come.	369.70988537757904
The next day Kitty went to see the young man again, and related to him	375.52680006541465
all that had passed on the preceding evening. D’Artagnan smiled; this	300.7253142740484
jealous anger of Milady was his revenge.	326.8221605692538
That evening Milady was still more impatient than on the preceding	325.4843987204796
evening. She renewed the order relative to the Gascon; but as before	309.9244617684247
she expected him in vain.	389.7863437263577
The next morning, when Kitty presented herself at D’Artagnan’s, she was	482.1709038965755
no longer joyous and alert as on the two preceding days; but on the	330.1647260937542
contrary sad as death.	470.66189938325374
D’Artagnan asked the poor girl what was the matter with her; but she,	484.91343556644665
as her only reply, drew a letter from her pocket and gave it to him.	295.96034942809916
This letter was in Milady’s handwriting; only this time it was	487.3625584457266
addressed to M. d’Artagnan, and not to M. de Wardes.	394.38523430045547
He opened it and read as follows:	322.26970575200374
DEAR M. D’ARTAGNAN, It is wrong thus to neglect your friends,	375.2090447073606
particularly at the moment you are about to leave them for so long a	354.50573896370344
time. My brother-in-law and myself expected you yesterday and the day	387.86724432061555
before, but in vain. Will it be the same this evening?	458.8018882930985
Your very grateful,	417.34306372627526
MILADY CLARIK	421.21962799594223
“That’s all very simple,” said D’Artagnan; “I expected this letter. My	392.4699439200115
credit rises by the fall of that of the Comte de Wardes.”	444.4003419693846
“And will you go?” asked Kitty.	329.10933675082504
“Listen to me, my dear girl,” said the Gascon, who sought for an excuse	307.8453589537231
in his own eyes for breaking the promise he had made Athos; “you must	406.1386279254252
understand it would be impolitic not to accept such a positive	482.134478863423
invitation. Milady, not seeing me come again, would not be able to	410.04754402334737
understand what could cause the interruption of my visits, and might	442.6171850856758
suspect something; who could say how far the vengeance of such a woman	362.8949491012902
would go?”	385.42524090259667
“Oh, my God!” said Kitty, “you know how to represent things in such a	462.7752732697162
way that you are always in the right. You are going now to pay your	353.2261484179803
court to her again, and if this time you succeed in pleasing her in	438.07197733405945
your own name and with your own face, it will be much worse than	376.7103708965495
before.”	366.435270012928
Instinct made poor Kitty guess a part of what was to happen. D’Artagnan	385.37685339221605
reassured her as well as he could, and promised to remain insensible to	314.39770531623344
the seductions of Milady.	345.84341158754194
He desired Kitty to tell her mistress that he could not be more	347.4589460633291
grateful for her kindnesses than he was, and that he would be obedient	450.5504954748915
to her orders. He did not dare to write for fear of not being able—to	296.7043098194255
such experienced eyes as those of Milady—to disguise his writing	390.21139916543825
sufficiently.	403.10426545315056
As nine o’clock sounded, D’Artagnan was at the Place Royale. It was	441.5557059404253
evident that the servants who waited in the antechamber were warned,	440.987281415299
for as soon as D’Artagnan appeared, before even he had asked if Milady	393.4489797048316
were visible, one of them ran to announce him.	405.59165159401164
“Show him in,” said Milady, in a quick tone, but so piercing that	444.97611640099126
D’Artagnan heard her in the antechamber.	306.77969658299077
He was introduced.	388.9486727775583
“I am at home to nobody,” said Milady; “observe, to _nobody_.”	437.358040123751
The servant went out.	407.6520325548705
D’Artagnan cast an inquiring glance at Milady. She was pale, and looked	368.53174288181447
fatigued, either from tears or want of sleep. The number of lights had	423.33933073042033
been intentionally diminished, but the young woman could not conceal	490.9553099180737
the traces of the fever which had devoured her for two days.	459.1328950206658
D’Artagnan approached her with his usual gallantry. She then made an	333.6963828299606
extraordinary effort to receive him, but never did a more distressed	418.22187798460055
countenance give the lie to a more amiable smile.	374.15534273823937
To the questions which D’Artagnan put concerning her health, she	396.6568802123341
replied, “Bad, very bad.”	413.4332947541142
“Then,” replied he, “my visit is ill-timed; you, no doubt, stand in	475.9877879800722
need of repose, and I will withdraw.”	419.81398546779735
“No, no!” said Milady. “On the contrary, stay, Monsieur d’Artagnan;	462.70004602105666
your agreeable company will divert me.”	436.83904988397273
“Oh, oh!” thought D’Artagnan. “She has never been so kind before. On	438.0167516487308
guard!”	388.6195816182351
Milady assumed the most agreeable air possible, and conversed with more	356.80065103495974
than her usual brilliancy. At the same time the fever, which for an	385.06219856845513
instant abandoned her, returned to give luster to her eyes, color to	348.6139292829564
her cheeks, and vermillion to her lips. D’Artagnan was again in the	478.67770708894625
presence of the Circe who had before surrounded him with her	308.5601902900297
enchantments. His love, which he believed to be extinct but which was	426.75016236369623
only asleep, awoke again in his heart. Milady smiled, and D’Artagnan	451.1470285536247
felt that he could damn himself for that smile. There was a moment at	393.3782138469869
which he felt something like remorse.	472.3689939001159
By degrees, Milady became more communicative. She asked D’Artagnan if	486.1952467619542
he had a mistress.	474.36703491973935
“Alas!” said D’Artagnan, with the most sentimental air he could assume,	294.8941634095981
“can you be cruel enough to put such a question to me—to me, who, from	480.18005569689086
the moment I saw you, have only breathed and sighed through you and for	357.0846609629538
you?”	443.8851278196451
Milady smiled with a strange smile.	487.9099772712086
“Then you love me?” said she.	445.8850871122677
“Have I any need to tell you so? Have you not perceived it?”	477.2235974801889
“It may be; but you know the more hearts are worth the capture, the	364.03917613851775
more difficult they are to be won.”	323.240145740128
“Oh, difficulties do not affright me,” said D’Artagnan. “I shrink	361.0305872629832
before nothing but impossibilities.”	317.4449028873023
“Nothing is impossible,” replied Milady, “to true love.”	412.97821233183066
“Nothing, madame?”	318.6142703812104
“Nothing,” replied Milady.	469.69847134740456
“The devil!” thought D’Artagnan. “The note is changed. Is she going to	404.2719142073196
fall in love with me, by chance, this fair inconstant; and will she be	483.6604331331713
disposed to give me myself another sapphire like that which she gave me	352.8115150955682
for De Wardes?”	306.5555666378571
D’Artagnan rapidly drew his seat nearer to Milady’s.	361.74765358591657
“Well, now,” she said, “let us see what you would do to prove this love	314.8193429966803
of which you speak.”	472.1672167453096
“All that could be required of me. Order; I am ready.”	472.32970657663367
“For everything?”	300.27557454789786
“For everything,” cried D’Artagnan, who knew beforehand that he had not	455.6947552244193
much to risk in engaging himself thus.	473.1054259749643
“Well, now let us talk a little seriously,” said Milady, in her turn	449.1923371227759
drawing her armchair nearer to D’Artagnan’s chair.	489.1261723090016
“I am all attention, madame,” said he.	477.45321323803375
Milady remained thoughtful and undecided for a moment; then, as if	311.19630902182297
appearing to have formed a resolution, she said, “I have an enemy.”	347.9308414381427
“You, madame!” said D’Artagnan, affecting surprise; “is that possible,	467.0483908410072
my God?—good and beautiful as you are!”	345.05214325151576
“A mortal enemy.”	405.0189832047552
“Indeed!”	444.05465757270787
“An enemy who has insulted me so cruelly that between him and me it is	359.1181760772623
war to the death. May I reckon on you as an auxiliary?”	338.8687711596034
D’Artagnan at once perceived the ground which the vindictive creature	355.7182972993038
wished to reach.	307.48500746567294
“You may, madame,” said he, with emphasis. “My arm and my life belong	426.4689539271315
to you, like my love.”	295.95479322815436
“Then,” said Milady, “since you are as generous as you are loving—”	325.3608030434369
She stopped.	414.4407693685014
“Well?” demanded D’Artagnan.	374.6418006161841
“Well,” replied Milady, after a moment of silence, “from the present	487.38467390512534
time, cease to talk of impossibilities.”	411.12111094892333
“Do not overwhelm me with happiness,” cried D’Artagnan, throwing	321.0152014651559
himself on his knees, and covering with kisses the hands abandoned to	389.0586502953568
him.	401.56985596285017
“Avenge me of that infamous De Wardes,” said Milady, between her teeth,	309.13546453569654
“and I shall soon know how to get rid of you—you double idiot, you	479.58903596291145
animated sword blade!”	331.2926700676368
“Fall voluntarily into my arms, hypocritical and dangerous woman,” said	415.43922940238326
D’Artagnan, likewise to himself, “after having abused me with such	367.02094996082184
effrontery, and afterward I will laugh at you with him whom you wish me	382.69783190943576
to kill.”	318.57574500093364
D’Artagnan lifted up his head.	434.2705132422619
“I am ready,” said he.	449.1056640439706
“You have understood me, then, dear Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said Milady.	370.18555513916044
“I could interpret one of your looks.”	473.9310042569749
“Then you would employ for me your arm which has already acquired so	407.24532256604084
much renown?”	347.81663715161824
“Instantly!”	389.1640043584411
“But on my part,” said Milady, “how should I repay such a service? I	310.7999227347969
know these lovers. They are men who do nothing for nothing.”	361.9831950889773
“You know the only reply that I desire,” said D’Artagnan, “the only one	470.0438351011925
worthy of you and of me!”	349.82230508651946
And he drew nearer to her.	367.4207757305645
She scarcely resisted.	489.725615743409
“Interested man!” cried she, smiling.	410.74050167446046
“Ah,” cried D’Artagnan, really carried away by the passion this woman	468.92036378443197
had the power to kindle in his heart, “ah, that is because my happiness	328.47024612108106
appears so impossible to me; and I have such fear that it should fly	438.05809554690234
away from me like a dream that I pant to make a reality of it.”	463.35594112427145
“Well, merit this pretended happiness, then!”	442.9069662739637
“I am at your orders,” said D’Artagnan.	324.4820618708414
“Quite certain?” said Milady, with a last doubt.	476.8130951963558
“Only name to me the base man that has brought tears into your	373.1524244048917
beautiful eyes!”	488.66308320572347
“Who told you that I had been weeping?” said she.	331.41167026337394
“It appeared to me—”	386.84558327921496
“Such women as I never weep,” said Milady.	395.6009809542305
“So much the better! Come, tell me his name!”	346.27371424135896
“Remember that his name is all my secret.”	357.7814164470523
“Yet I must know his name.”	451.3762202990957
“Yes, you must; see what confidence I have in you!”	462.06809144128863
“You overwhelm me with joy. What is his name?”	428.8809117478355
“You know him.”	415.46953963871385
“Indeed.”	352.6963268910206
“Yes.”	349.3832614873334
“It is surely not one of my friends?” replied D’Artagnan, affecting	345.714809109723
hesitation in order to make her believe him ignorant.	453.846334486556
“If it were one of your friends you would hesitate, then?” cried	480.30860538387293
Milady; and a threatening glance darted from her eyes.	429.15825731721213
“Not if it were my own brother!” cried D’Artagnan, as if carried away	474.5747087270005
by his enthusiasm.	310.9220554016451
Our Gascon promised this without risk, for he knew all that was meant.	384.74056665214755
“I love your devotedness,” said Milady.	461.9953341901586
“Alas, do you love nothing else in me?” asked D’Artagnan.	477.9159743765815
“I love you also, _you!_” said she, taking his hand.	423.5806902847706
The warm pressure made D’Artagnan tremble, as if by the touch that	336.908214030197
fever which consumed Milady attacked himself.	374.7200616950649
“You love me, you!” cried he. “Oh, if that were so, I should lose my	428.98112205287
reason!”	299.4704499746765
And he folded her in his arms. She made no effort to remove her lips	489.7261124788272
from his kisses; only she did not respond to them. Her lips were cold;	304.82183052900893
it appeared to D’Artagnan that he had embraced a statue.	337.68473941829313
He was not the less intoxicated with joy, electrified by love. He	383.1719791681357
almost believed in the tenderness of Milady; he almost believed in the	295.7199876185612
crime of De Wardes. If De Wardes had at that moment been under his	473.1973995960226
hand, he would have killed him.	422.5108426825865
Milady seized the occasion.	335.31112335946204
“His name is—” said she, in her turn.	461.70156764919534
“De Wardes; I know it,” cried D’Artagnan.	474.5297419479939
“And how do you know it?” asked Milady, seizing both his hands, and	369.59637656074153
endeavoring to read with her eyes to the bottom of his heart.	441.82811964712096
D’Artagnan felt he had allowed himself to be carried away, and that he	458.1604860137538
had committed an error.	329.7431491591554
“Tell me, tell me, tell me, I say,” repeated Milady, “how do you know	322.380792155589
it?”	324.7717577741146
“How do I know it?” said D’Artagnan.	460.7853744908142
“Yes.”	413.2097638375172
“I know it because yesterday Monsieur de Wardes, in a saloon where I	400.5953159338709
was, showed a ring which he said he had received from you.”	434.17140062701196
“Wretch!” cried Milady.	469.07989749614296
The epithet, as may be easily understood, resounded to the very bottom	329.0525942191433
of D’Artagnan’s heart.	389.023502500085
“Well?” continued she.	463.4315257660179
“Well, I will avenge you of this wretch,” replied D’Artagnan, giving	459.89168125606557
himself the airs of Don Japhet of Armenia.	416.7438487823635
“Thanks, my brave friend!” cried Milady; “and when shall I be avenged?”	315.195065230894
“Tomorrow—immediately—when you please!”	442.4773052330333
Milady was about to cry out, “Immediately,” but she reflected that such	491.4397428594345
precipitation would not be very gracious toward D’Artagnan.	418.1223868092467
Besides, she had a thousand precautions to take, a thousand counsels to	419.75333078684105
give to her defender, in order that he might avoid explanations with	301.11265571783997
the count before witnesses. All this was answered by an expression of	450.91268368714924
D’Artagnan’s. “Tomorrow,” said he, “you will be avenged, or I shall be	478.36851070841965
dead.”	431.26506161267116
“No,” said she, “you will avenge me; but you will not be dead. He is a	344.4796646853318
coward.”	410.4466276048806
“With women, perhaps; but not with men. I know something of him.”	307.4623790982123
“But it seems you had not much reason to complain of your fortune in	447.4905011163296
your contest with him.”	405.48614811318237
“Fortune is a courtesan; favorable yesterday, she may turn her back	317.4997221093983
tomorrow.”	441.9983371276975
“Which means that you now hesitate?”	301.4848331642733
“No, I do not hesitate; God forbid! But would it be just to allow me to	455.51985517570256
go to a possible death without having given me at least something more	382.4240376345272
than hope?”	468.9296004907019
Milady answered by a glance which said, “Is that all?—speak, then.” And	471.2254916245296
then accompanying the glance with explanatory words, “That is but too	318.59012658478804
just,” said she, tenderly.	409.3430723100669
“Oh, you are an angel!” exclaimed the young man.	357.3476425467849
“Then all is agreed?” said she.	360.38043038820064
“Except that which I ask of you, dear love.”	359.6184331073857
“But when I assure you that you may rely on my tenderness?”	313.8069927721097
“I cannot wait till tomorrow.”	357.79611147311203
“Silence! I hear my brother. It will be useless for him to find you	475.135010606909
here.”	382.2291009101489
She rang the bell and Kitty appeared.	327.5397073904328
“Go out this way,” said she, opening a small private door, “and come	432.11084483354364
back at eleven o’clock; we will then terminate this conversation. Kitty	437.23241445066685
will conduct you to my chamber.”	489.1246631082763
The poor girl almost fainted at hearing these words.	367.5740842252764
“Well, mademoiselle, what are you thinking about, standing there like a	369.828103438153
statue? Do as I bid you: show the chevalier out; and this evening at	293.25621058105605
eleven o’clock—you have heard what I said.”	406.09693967623605
“It appears that these appointments are all made for eleven o’clock,”	305.22460821432963
thought D’Artagnan; “that’s a settled custom.”	323.4152692545166
Milady held out her hand to him, which he kissed tenderly.	313.9428609848017
“But,” said he, as he retired as quickly as possible from the	335.020020411453
reproaches of Kitty, “I must not play the fool. This woman is certainly	474.02065142342377
a great liar. I must take care.”	415.9973960359375
Chapter XXXVII.	466.0738454827231
MILADY’S SECRET	300.27797897805897
D’Artagnan left the hôtel instead of going up at once to Kitty’s	384.39194772737363
chamber, as she endeavored to persuade him to do—and that for two	424.45935075363974
reasons: the first, because by this means he should escape reproaches,	409.2282160874692
recriminations, and prayers; the second, because he was not sorry to	458.97568146670903
have an opportunity of reading his own thoughts and endeavoring, if	336.7035665639449
possible, to fathom those of this woman.	347.91060883367993
What was most clear in the matter was that D’Artagnan loved Milady like	465.81052122896256
a madman, and that she did not love him at all. In an instant	471.48701253375964
D’Artagnan perceived that the best way in which he could act would be	448.061918492745
to go home and write Milady a long letter, in which he would confess to	316.44890855292084
her that he and De Wardes were, up to the present moment absolutely the	328.3450284936462
same, and that consequently he could not undertake, without committing	401.17807792496063
suicide, to kill the Comte de Wardes. But he also was spurred on by a	396.372347729433
ferocious desire of vengeance. He wished to subdue this woman in his	432.4762433619585
own name; and as this vengeance appeared to him to have a certain	399.6647434219852
sweetness in it, he could not make up his mind to renounce it.	408.82387694681864
He walked six or seven times round the Place Royale, turning at every	341.9551769385645
ten steps to look at the light in Milady’s apartment, which was to be	420.5648117271045
seen through the blinds. It was evident that this time the young woman	370.8740049577682
was not in such haste to retire to her apartment as she had been the	376.626124681223
first.	358.6456382300806
At length the light disappeared. With this light was extinguished the	315.3383688012185
last irresolution in the heart of D’Artagnan. He recalled to his mind	378.54216227588125
the details of the first night, and with a beating heart and a brain on	452.57416697758833
fire he re-entered the hôtel and flew toward Kitty’s chamber.	308.9934245038458
The poor girl, pale as death and trembling in all her limbs, wished to	368.5635770068327
delay her lover; but Milady, with her ear on the watch, had heard the	400.06529373443783
noise D’Artagnan had made, and opening the door, said, “Come in.”	387.3753525239609
All this was of such incredible immodesty, of such monstrous	327.09931124611836
effrontery, that D’Artagnan could scarcely believe what he saw or what	491.21190509979414
he heard. He imagined himself to be drawn into one of those fantastic	451.55389369930697
intrigues one meets in dreams. He, however, darted not the less quickly	318.40404090728754
toward Milady, yielding to that magnetic attraction which the loadstone	385.3475854463764
exercises over iron.	320.41625391284265
As the door closed after them Kitty rushed toward it. Jealousy, fury,	362.66735467456454
offended pride, all the passions in short that dispute the heart of an	423.1789756467352
outraged woman in love, urged her to make a revelation; but she	317.8358304728962
reflected that she would be totally lost if she confessed having	363.46723768924807
assisted in such a machination, and above all, that D’Artagnan would	320.4964108858813
also be lost to her forever. This last thought of love counseled her to	390.19533780494487
make this last sacrifice.	319.00323014723216
D’Artagnan, on his part, had gained the summit of all his wishes. It	361.3627503071135
was no longer a rival who was beloved; it was himself who was	358.8218882803076
apparently beloved. A secret voice whispered to him, at the bottom of	473.1542120627578
his heart, that he was but an instrument of vengeance, that he was only	454.2756663231539
caressed till he had given death; but pride, but self-love, but madness	330.2549834762112
silenced this voice and stifled its murmurs. And then our Gascon, with	435.01686892357884
that large quantity of conceit which we know he possessed, compared	447.38107152869577
himself with De Wardes, and asked himself why, after all, he should not	454.8970871463654
be beloved for himself?	352.93974161513313
He was absorbed entirely by the sensations of the moment. Milady was no	442.6118403432031
longer for him that woman of fatal intentions who had for a moment	324.55495547643415
terrified him; she was an ardent, passionate mistress, abandoning	469.9183060414935
herself to love which she also seemed to feel. Two hours thus glided	473.3961439125435
away. When the transports of the two lovers were calmer, Milady, who	402.92568435816344
had not the same motives for forgetfulness that D’Artagnan had, was the	433.3012198115406
first to return to reality, and asked the young man if the means which	394.25415036882737
were on the morrow to bring on the encounter between him and De Wardes	385.15071956859674
were already arranged in his mind.	368.11138012449516
But D’Artagnan, whose ideas had taken quite another course, forgot	339.6998454230383
himself like a fool, and answered gallantly that it was too late to	440.61432808194616
think about duels and sword thrusts.	445.0149655318696
This coldness toward the only interests that occupied her mind	463.8008995363231
terrified Milady, whose questions became more pressing.	460.9911354628702
Then D’Artagnan, who had never seriously thought of this impossible	379.5683826980194
duel, endeavored to turn the conversation; but he could not succeed.	399.0348719191562
Milady kept him within the limits she had traced beforehand with her	453.1687214539086
irresistible spirit and her iron will.	461.7639165294403
D’Artagnan fancied himself very cunning when advising Milady to	372.9557257520921
renounce, by pardoning De Wardes, the furious projects she had formed.	449.11228266957056
But at the first word the young woman started, and exclaimed in a	454.10114317390617
sharp, bantering tone, which sounded strangely in the darkness, “Are	406.4409124707432
you afraid, dear Monsieur d’Artagnan?”	452.6796027918592
“You cannot think so, dear love!” replied D’Artagnan; “but now, suppose	434.4117910493561
this poor Comte de Wardes were less guilty than you think him?”	478.08708457518946
“At all events,” said Milady, seriously, “he has deceived me, and from	355.73882979396643
the moment he deceived me, he merited death.”	301.0977559132473
“He shall die, then, since you condemn him!” said D’Artagnan, in so	439.1787076358965
firm a tone that it appeared to Milady an undoubted proof of devotion.	385.60408037028094
This reassured her.	396.5545390144927
We cannot say how long the night seemed to Milady, but D’Artagnan	297.225018508356
believed it to be hardly two hours before the daylight peeped through	359.75289596035475
the window blinds, and invaded the chamber with its paleness. Seeing	355.32660535631874
D’Artagnan about to leave her, Milady recalled his promise to avenge	426.5625175192122
her on the Comte de Wardes.	396.70662555581407
“I am quite ready,” said D’Artagnan; “but in the first place I should	401.1770766060733
like to be certain of one thing.”	382.3953550537229
“And what is that?” asked Milady.	399.7550184371239
“That is, whether you really love me?”	412.23501119856996
“I have given you proof of that, it seems to me.”	377.75005398841563
“And I am yours, body and soul!”	490.33001217166577
“Thanks, my brave lover; but as you are satisfied of my love, you must,	366.72390482099723
in your turn, satisfy me of yours. Is it not so?”	482.07598322435996
“Certainly; but if you love me as much as you say,” replied D’Artagnan,	476.24334983808865
“do you not entertain a little fear on my account?”	356.8540021782685
“What have I to fear?”	411.3583931173468
“Why, that I may be dangerously wounded—killed even.”	435.0873917922727
“Impossible!” cried Milady, “you are such a valiant man, and such an	402.6090294571058
expert swordsman.”	428.44259239290693
“You would not, then, prefer a method,” resumed D’Artagnan, “which	385.4657828490144
would equally avenge you while rendering the combat useless?”	416.0625591981071
Milady looked at her lover in silence. The pale light of the first rays	323.49288479785366
of day gave to her clear eyes a strangely frightful expression.	449.954189678671
“Really,” said she, “I believe you now begin to hesitate.”	318.2816140591367
“No, I do not hesitate; but I really pity this poor Comte de Wardes,	328.36599995239584
since you have ceased to love him. I think that a man must be so	413.5179638068824
severely punished by the loss of your love that he stands in need of no	335.8521512032198
other chastisement.”	373.7214100769785
“Who told you that I loved him?” asked Milady, sharply.	396.4825126549153
“At least, I am now at liberty to believe, without too much fatuity,	431.0308228625414
that you love another,” said the young man, in a caressing tone, “and I	435.3413228646293
repeat that I am really interested for the count.”	413.3507915086958
“You?” asked Milady.	453.40325610050263
“Yes, I.”	426.60074962476835
“And why _you?_”	414.2922644718522
“Because I alone know—”	476.3803190606941
“What?”	404.4508852890468
“That he is far from being, or rather having been, so guilty toward you	387.09715957491784
as he appears.”	364.0396026940564
“Indeed!” said Milady, in an anxious tone; “explain yourself, for I	437.65514520721626
