really cannot tell what you mean.”	379.4934090506122
And she looked at D’Artagnan, who embraced her tenderly, with eyes	318.2251715221647
which seemed to burn themselves away.	405.30101823768564
“Yes; I am a man of honor,” said D’Artagnan, determined to come to an	325.5766836478309
end, “and since your love is mine, and I am satisfied I possess it—for	477.09059176112913
I do possess it, do I not?”	487.1780545046238
“Entirely; go on.”	293.21910115274125
“Well, I feel as if transformed—a confession weighs on my mind.”	389.97175673486475
“A confession!”	430.31027883208446
“If I had the least doubt of your love I would not make it, but you	425.9141546337779
love me, my beautiful mistress, do you not?”	368.2504775842952
“Without doubt.”	322.5287049108733
“Then if through excess of love I have rendered myself culpable toward	414.2324279761391
you, you will pardon me?”	441.66987096060893
“Perhaps.”	347.77423692153667
D’Artagnan tried with his sweetest smile to touch his lips to Milady’s,	476.87360139020734
but she evaded him.	355.2639311193826
“This confession,” said she, growing paler, “what is this confession?”	414.9737434293988
“You gave De Wardes a meeting on Thursday last in this very room, did	343.2707747309462
you not?”	407.48241684857436
“No, no! It is not true,” said Milady, in a tone of voice so firm, and	363.332259282403
with a countenance so unchanged, that if D’Artagnan had not been in	476.29258518988956
such perfect possession of the fact, he would have doubted.	396.1093947497337
“Do not lie, my angel,” said D’Artagnan, smiling; “that would be	326.04587979634636
useless.”	478.3588253335672
“What do you mean? Speak! you kill me.”	459.73737706220606
“Be satisfied; you are not guilty toward me, and I have already	309.51578339134966
pardoned you.”	329.29404260672663
“What next? what next?”	391.45465051459485
“De Wardes cannot boast of anything.”	429.532652730354
“How is that? You told me yourself that that ring—”	478.79377079357334
“That ring I have! The Comte de Wardes of Thursday and the D’Artagnan	390.36533656556054
of today are the same person.”	420.5162484245976
The imprudent young man expected a surprise, mixed with shame—a slight	463.87077077546286
storm which would resolve itself into tears; but he was strangely	424.5017305852046
deceived, and his error was not of long duration.	341.7690518038233
Pale and trembling, Milady repulsed D’Artagnan’s attempted embrace by a	367.07685073778293
violent blow on the chest, as she sprang out of bed.	393.3758207942366
It was almost broad daylight.	309.35108961468427
D’Artagnan detained her by her night dress of fine India linen, to	462.6700674215024
implore her pardon; but she, with a strong movement, tried to escape.	416.1377930028345
Then the cambric was torn from her beautiful shoulders; and on one of	353.5324497186126
those lovely shoulders, round and white, D’Artagnan recognized, with	455.62514779197284
inexpressible astonishment, the _fleur-de-lis_—that indelible mark	463.1687383051643
which the hand of the infamous executioner had imprinted.	432.0859140642018
“Great God!” cried D’Artagnan, loosing his hold of her dress, and	386.01034528168105
remaining mute, motionless, and frozen.	486.0112226765376
But Milady felt herself denounced even by his terror. He had doubtless	407.4134282824974
seen all. The young man now knew her secret, her terrible secret—the	292.0629516775039
secret she concealed even from her maid with such care, the secret of	340.1417483767828
which all the world was ignorant, except himself.	366.9927295528664
She turned upon him, no longer like a furious woman, but like a wounded	393.8248036215996
panther.	366.38237243637155
“Ah, wretch!” cried she, “you have basely betrayed me, and still more,	381.9989908866912
you have my secret! You shall die.”	484.91059453465886
And she flew to a little inlaid casket which stood upon the dressing	333.6179103035077
table, opened it with a feverish and trembling hand, drew from it a	351.82033394245354
small poniard, with a golden haft and a sharp thin blade, and then	365.0519655558151
threw herself with a bound upon D’Artagnan.	371.6765043490069
Although the young man was brave, as we know, he was terrified at that	464.8382437464966
wild countenance, those terribly dilated pupils, those pale cheeks, and	452.98499473952427
those bleeding lips. He recoiled to the other side of the room as he	398.98976797194405
would have done from a serpent which was crawling toward him, and his	374.60160658324895
sword coming in contact with his nervous hand, he drew it almost	437.20233014847537
unconsciously from the scabbard. But without taking any heed of the	378.27120315818183
sword, Milady endeavored to get near enough to him to stab him, and did	423.7220830782169
not stop till she felt the sharp point at her throat.	414.1547498819059
She then tried to seize the sword with her hands; but D’Artagnan kept	417.051850126933
it free from her grasp, and presenting the point, sometimes at her	410.96446330295225
eyes, sometimes at her breast, compelled her to glide behind the	490.01352761267003
bedstead, while he aimed at making his retreat by the door which led to	439.44929700682627
Kitty’s apartment.	467.71015158345585
Milady during this time continued to strike at him with horrible fury,	409.68770470544746
screaming in a formidable way.	433.26123594002706
As all this, however, bore some resemblance to a duel, D’Artagnan began	427.55121856757
to recover himself little by little.	301.30412375051117
“Well, beautiful lady, very well,” said he; “but, _pardieu_, if you	413.20566689234045
don’t calm yourself, I will design a second _fleur-de-lis_ upon one of	393.47286889427943
those pretty cheeks!”	385.2685053651147
“Scoundrel, infamous scoundrel!” howled Milady.	312.58826711206444
But D’Artagnan, still keeping on the defensive, drew near to Kitty’s	411.4314411892732
door. At the noise they made, she in overturning the furniture in her	323.32558735016823
efforts to get at him, he in screening himself behind the furniture to	353.6597147753989
keep out of her reach, Kitty opened the door. D’Artagnan, who had	339.14567059781484
unceasingly maneuvered to gain this point, was not at more than three	388.01589768201916
paces from it. With one spring he flew from the chamber of Milady into	389.3634881529292
that of the maid, and quick as lightning, he slammed to the door, and	379.99117947031925
placed all his weight against it, while Kitty pushed the bolts.	415.66128594911083
Then Milady attempted to tear down the doorcase, with a strength	350.13301662393525
apparently above that of a woman; but finding she could not accomplish	401.8289544204392
this, she in her fury stabbed at the door with her poniard, the point	468.66589172935505
of which repeatedly glittered through the wood. Every blow was	471.5885131491969
accompanied with terrible imprecations.	384.64109425770863
“Quick, Kitty, quick!” said D’Artagnan, in a low voice, as soon as the	406.70912386637815
bolts were fast, “let me get out of the hôtel; for if we leave her time	354.5948209562338
to turn round, she will have me killed by the servants.”	292.86755929129953
“But you can’t go out so,” said Kitty; “you are naked.”	321.70277005825477
“That’s true,” said D’Artagnan, then first thinking of the costume he	353.1863150429041
found himself in, “that’s true. But dress me as well as you are able,	360.5789620302191
only make haste; think, my dear girl, it’s life and death!”	390.24710211360116
Kitty was but too well aware of that. In a turn of the hand she muffled	373.2429984393266
him up in a flowered robe, a large hood, and a cloak. She gave him some	427.3281340669733
slippers, in which he placed his naked feet, and then conducted him	466.8144746990256
down the stairs. It was time. Milady had already rung her bell, and	477.18150001845834
roused the whole hôtel. The porter was drawing the cord at the moment	335.29715655955
Milady cried from her window, “Don’t open!”	387.8318104143568
The young man fled while she was still threatening him with an impotent	380.44688128121385
gesture. The moment she lost sight of him, Milady tumbled fainting into	344.00482035897517
her chamber.	408.9065093494961
Chapter XXXVIII.	365.90984807602626
HOW, WITHOUT INCOMMDING HIMSELF, ATHOS PROCURES HIS EQUIPMENT	441.65380922058284
D’Artagnan was so completely bewildered that without taking any heed of	483.7662740343791
what might become of Kitty he ran at full speed across half Paris, and	387.2402402805201
did not stop till he came to Athos’s door. The confusion of his mind,	439.1397892105661
the terror which spurred him on, the cries of some of the patrol who	407.6568683213306
started in pursuit of him, and the hooting of the people who,	297.506622668196
notwithstanding the early hour, were going to their work, only made him	338.78982529471637
precipitate his course.	348.15206296523314
He crossed the court, ran up the two flights to Athos’s apartment, and	430.5869990139155
knocked at the door enough to break it down.	436.80416186805724
Grimaud came, rubbing his half-open eyes, to answer this noisy summons,	446.4648384885769
and D’Artagnan sprang with such violence into the room as nearly to	476.9702637838402
overturn the astonished lackey.	456.15689548656576
In spite of his habitual silence, the poor lad this time found his	302.0675797573921
speech.	441.8562255238519
“Holloa, there!” cried he; “what do you want, you strumpet? What’s your	408.7420729326914
business here, you hussy?”	319.2064641890357
D’Artagnan threw off his hood, and disengaged his hands from the folds	312.75097177781777
of the cloak. At sight of the mustaches and the naked sword, the poor	432.8305728999304
devil perceived he had to deal with a man. He then concluded it must be	299.6651312521176
an assassin.	294.8023557851187
“Help! murder! help!” cried he.	352.85727453767254
“Hold your tongue, you stupid fellow!” said the young man; “I am	349.9637284851141
D’Artagnan; don’t you know me? Where is your master?”	312.1552188496951
“You, Monsieur d’Artagnan!” cried Grimaud, “impossible.”	329.251692835517
“Grimaud,” said Athos, coming out of his apartment in a dressing gown,	338.65077285255603
“Grimaud, I thought I heard you permitting yourself to speak?”	406.0706344917304
“Ah, monsieur, it is—”	375.7844519515311
“Silence!”	478.0285089871574
Grimaud contented himself with pointing D’Artagnan out to his master	351.74851741895554
with his finger.	347.86300725174897
Athos recognized his comrade, and phlegmatic as he was, he burst into a	319.8512429255844
laugh which was quite excused by the strange masquerade before his	461.27499841877136
eyes—petticoats falling over his shoes, sleeves tucked up, and	369.1198865369533
mustaches stiff with agitation.	475.7956079055225
“Don’t laugh, my friend!” cried D’Artagnan; “for heaven’s sake, don’t	377.52700819492907
laugh, for upon my soul, it’s no laughing matter!”	364.1520796312478
And he pronounced these words with such a solemn air and with such a	488.60913971646005
real appearance of terror, that Athos eagerly seized his hand, crying,	457.17080439240453
“Are you wounded, my friend? How pale you are!”	462.2640305222334
“No, but I have just met with a terrible adventure! Are you alone,	307.1787292157464
Athos?”	450.98793741857514
“_Parbleu!_ whom do you expect to find with me at this hour?”	295.8179023056786
“Well, well!” and D’Artagnan rushed into Athos’s chamber.	393.8149043418279
“Come, speak!” said the latter, closing the door and bolting it, that	491.62795134069563
they might not be disturbed. “Is the king dead? Have you killed the	310.06609776215555
cardinal? You are quite upset! Come, come, tell me; I am dying with	463.05160526512407
curiosity and uneasiness!”	336.37649693010326
“Athos,” said D’Artagnan, getting rid of his female garments, and	382.10017040377863
appearing in his shirt, “prepare yourself to hear an incredible, an	437.0405453652178
unheard-of story.”	367.09591633026105
“Well, but put on this dressing gown first,” said the Musketeer to his	297.27995666008513
friend.	449.69351054533706
D’Artagnan donned the robe as quickly as he could, mistaking one sleeve	458.30332390679337
for the other, so greatly was he still agitated.	347.49775286012425
“Well?” said Athos.	431.4983472207741
“Well,” replied D’Artagnan, bending his mouth to Athos’s ear, and	318.48053561319495
lowering his voice, “Milady is marked with a _fleur-de-lis_ upon her	310.657975544857
shoulder!”	433.1728647495559
“Ah!” cried the Musketeer, as if he had received a ball in his heart.	428.50461913376176
“Let us see,” said D’Artagnan. “Are you _sure_ that the _other_ is	473.8848510818689
dead?”	364.824776870203
“_The other?_” said Athos, in so stifled a voice that D’Artagnan	297.0565042751336
scarcely heard him.	470.12340702593013
“Yes, she of whom you told me one day at Amiens.”	430.6191735457469
Athos uttered a groan, and let his head sink on his hands.	411.4611592320311
“This is a woman of twenty-six or twenty-eight years.”	424.1935345743292
“Fair,” said Athos, “is she not?”	441.25710567506405
“Very.”	395.04778004980255
“Blue and clear eyes, of a strange brilliancy, with black eyelids and	482.0963863644196
eyebrows?”	474.1205197828579
“Yes.”	448.3890074220519
“Tall, well-made? She has lost a tooth, next to the eyetooth on the	400.01082424050094
left?”	325.82388191902606
“Yes.”	442.0934198295712
“The _fleur-de-lis_ is small, rosy in color, and looks as if efforts	443.51376259935967
had been made to efface it by the application of poultices?”	470.1045021818168
“Yes.”	387.8014602159623
“But you say she is English?”	455.04371364693634
“She is called Milady, but she may be French. Lord de Winter is only	474.84778152712363
her brother-in-law.”	481.08777602872783
“I will see her, D’Artagnan!”	313.0004046255135
“Beware, Athos, beware. You tried to kill her; she is a woman to return	422.9452219617501
you the like, and not to fail.”	350.12754451619423
“She will not dare to say anything; that would be to denounce herself.”	435.1172146863753
“She is capable of anything or everything. Did you ever see her	333.0540708869014
furious?”	475.80967014661223
“No,” said Athos.	311.9941983122786
“A tigress, a panther! Ah, my dear Athos, I am greatly afraid I have	293.570491152279
drawn a terrible vengeance on both of us!”	383.1348361034137
D’Artagnan then related all—the mad passion of Milady and her menaces	431.4762162548152
of death.	419.48023448230543
“You are right; and upon my soul, I would give my life for a hair,”	385.2611746889878
said Athos. “Fortunately, the day after tomorrow we leave Paris. We are	440.33756671622655
going according to all probability to La Rochelle, and once gone—”	464.4629491291481
“She will follow you to the end of the world, Athos, if she recognizes	459.95690105389224
you. Let her, then, exhaust her vengeance on me alone!”	292.670231193104
“My dear friend, of what consequence is it if she kills me?” said	417.46518178524997
Athos. “Do you, perchance, think I set any great store by life?”	331.8890607226075
“There is something horribly mysterious under all this, Athos; this	307.22543375024856
woman is one of the cardinal’s spies, I am sure of that.”	299.6624715413875
“In that case, take care! If the cardinal does not hold you in high	449.20551602211816
admiration for the affair of London, he entertains a great hatred for	474.51555413487915
you; but as, considering everything, he cannot accuse you openly, and	308.17599117066203
as hatred must be satisfied, particularly when it’s a cardinal’s	409.93202147407175
hatred, take care of yourself. If you go out, do not go out alone; when	345.1027085192578
you eat, use every precaution. Mistrust everything, in short, even your	355.13728962689925
own shadow.”	342.8610540180302
“Fortunately,” said D’Artagnan, “all this will be only necessary till	345.4461250655685
after tomorrow evening, for when once with the army, we shall have, I	418.7323955222037
hope, only men to dread.”	457.9338965828565
“In the meantime,” said Athos, “I renounce my plan of seclusion, and	469.82931968908724
wherever you go, I will go with you. You must return to the Rue des	464.5924462411151
Fossoyeurs; I will accompany you.”	371.1046150267575
“But however near it may be,” replied D’Artagnan, “I cannot go thither	322.6181068724961
in this guise.”	402.6173479418602
“That’s true,” said Athos, and he rang the bell.	314.9371670312532
Grimaud entered.	485.23638939241914
Athos made him a sign to go to D’Artagnan’s residence, and bring back	469.76432565660065
some clothes. Grimaud replied by another sign that he understood	476.2032699641152
perfectly, and set off.	435.969114682827
“All this will not advance your outfit,” said Athos; “for if I am not	376.149259377418
mistaken, you have left the best of your apparel with Milady, and she	425.92867552489105
will certainly not have the politeness to return it to you.	381.54993262872335
Fortunately, you have the sapphire.”	465.84285021142114
“The jewel is yours, my dear Athos! Did you not tell me it was a family	298.4145145037404
jewel?”	457.06448990772475
“Yes, my grandfather gave two thousand crowns for it, as he once told	316.38924485601814
me. It formed part of the nuptial present he made his wife, and it is	466.7839787253444
magnificent. My mother gave it to me, and I, fool as I was, instead of	313.6320149455861
keeping the ring as a holy relic, gave it to this wretch.”	431.43203128500056
“Then, my friend, take back this ring, to which I see you attach much	317.89316485747196
value.”	319.5370469148986
“I take back the ring, after it has passed through the hands of that	449.755431002665
infamous creature? Never; that ring is defiled, D’Artagnan.”	486.41698525242356
“Sell it, then.”	326.7891834825577
“Sell a jewel which came from my mother! I vow I should consider it a	442.6806274150372
profanation.”	379.36349259228246
“Pledge it, then; you can borrow at least a thousand crowns on it. With	392.1842995703282
that sum you can extricate yourself from your present difficulties; and	434.9298205426503
when you are full of money again, you can redeem it, and take it back	418.6314284057362
cleansed from its ancient stains, as it will have passed through the	415.8589331537877
hands of usurers.”	437.08519026248644
Athos smiled.	472.8349227445231
“You are a capital companion, D’Artagnan,” said he; “your never-failing	337.9558167667283
cheerfulness raises poor souls in affliction. Well, let us pledge the	329.3821265077379
ring, but upon one condition.”	450.41438944789
“What?”	294.7032516527366
“That there shall be five hundred crowns for you, and five hundred	354.39611423127866
crowns for me.”	433.9748363958727
“Don’t dream it, Athos. I don’t need the quarter of such a sum—I who am	394.48549868701457
still only in the Guards—and by selling my saddles, I shall procure it.	382.32142934535466
What do I want? A horse for Planchet, that’s all. Besides, you forget	318.01915940605073
that I have a ring likewise.”	391.49602513044925
“To which you attach more value, it seems, than I do to mine; at least,	466.70819725944784
I have thought so.”	369.42806888452606
“Yes, for in any extreme circumstance it might not only extricate us	467.1773657832123
from some great embarrassment, but even a great danger. It is not only	323.78022607458496
a valuable diamond, but it is an enchanted talisman.”	410.0781806755541
“I don’t at all understand you, but I believe all you say to be true.	433.02723623032546
Let us return to my ring, or rather to yours. You shall take half the	367.1275283936839
sum that will be advanced upon it, or I will throw it into the Seine;	409.99298971851863
and I doubt, as was the case with Polycrates, whether any fish will be	389.407249993808
sufficiently complaisant to bring it back to us.”	300.78874805996196
“Well, I will take it, then,” said D’Artagnan.	307.6064612460153
At this moment Grimaud returned, accompanied by Planchet; the latter,	365.80876937039574
anxious about his master and curious to know what had happened to him,	455.13128855255934
had taken advantage of the opportunity and brought the garments	311.0407054978208
himself.	308.27026934562235
D’Artagnan dressed himself, and Athos did the same. When the two were	406.25430254087377
ready to go out, the latter made Grimaud the sign of a man taking aim,	433.69548875816804
and the lackey immediately took down his musketoon, and prepared to	415.9023316587951
follow his master.	490.8495239139886
They arrived without accident at the Rue des Fossoyeurs. Bonacieux was	473.7610274143245
standing at the door, and looked at D’Artagnan hatefully.	317.3486736841357
“Make haste, dear lodger,” said he; “there is a very pretty girl	338.1839402025512
waiting for you upstairs; and you know women don’t like to be kept	387.09368849912187
waiting.”	468.3467878596113
“That’s Kitty!” said D’Artagnan to himself, and darted into the	456.58685855625833
passage.	443.0145984893959
Sure enough! Upon the landing leading to the chamber, and crouching	474.86369133306164
against the door, he found the poor girl, all in a tremble. As soon as	406.58540736000845
she perceived him, she cried, “You have promised your protection; you	350.4800647862318
have promised to save me from her anger. Remember, it is you who have	292.85841074772014
ruined me!”	425.1045586906349
“Yes, yes, to be sure, Kitty,” said D’Artagnan; “be at ease, my girl.	368.65104557939105
But what happened after my departure?”	490.82346916143666
“How can I tell!” said Kitty. “The lackeys were brought by the cries	480.4800745528863
she made. She was mad with passion. There exist no imprecations she did	315.1181141253446
not pour out against you. Then I thought she would remember it was	446.2785482573367
through my chamber you had penetrated hers, and that then she would	414.41837214687536
suppose I was your accomplice; so I took what little money I had and	382.9904157554604
the best of my things, and I got away.	317.7123424425026
“Poor dear girl! But what can I do with you? I am going away the day	305.19429934590727
after tomorrow.”	402.4501821139955
“Do what you please, Monsieur Chevalier. Help me out of Paris; help me	342.6322203015557
out of France!”	374.13615138975837
“I cannot take you, however, to the siege of La Rochelle,” said	458.595053002689
D’Artagnan.	343.4258926860848
“No; but you can place me in one of the provinces with some lady of	316.53788819446333
your acquaintance—in your own country, for instance.”	405.49663806961007
“My dear little love! In my country the ladies do without chambermaids.	414.90828685583085
But stop! I can manage your business for you. Planchet, go and find	455.89430659797875
Aramis. Request him to come here directly. We have something very	457.1753266634236
important to say to him.”	457.3372501794019
“I understand,” said Athos; “but why not Porthos? I should have thought	427.0373001676526
that his duchess—”	374.0487453874411
“Oh, Porthos’s duchess is dressed by her husband’s clerks,” said	420.04444132999333
D’Artagnan, laughing. “Besides, Kitty would not like to live in the Rue	364.26203775060446
aux Ours. Isn’t it so, Kitty?”	489.7722543940266
“I do not care where I live,” said Kitty, “provided I am well	308.7151775352172
concealed, and nobody knows where I am.”	357.48555852360414
“Meanwhile, Kitty, when we are about to separate, and you are no longer	352.73962912869143
jealous of me—”	426.2628268609031
“Monsieur Chevalier, far off or near,” said Kitty, “I shall always love	308.11706215517995
you.”	334.0889189455063
“Where the devil will constancy niche itself next?” murmured Athos.	413.2757022906987
“And I, also,” said D’Artagnan, “I also. I shall always love you; be	373.6954867523143
sure of that. But now answer me. I attach great importance to the	406.19621119302303
question I am about to put to you. Did you never hear talk of a young	311.89868481469364
woman who was carried off one night?”	465.3740267173779
“There, now! Oh, Monsieur Chevalier, do you love that woman still?”	457.7671311424429
“No, no; it is one of my friends who loves her—Monsieur Athos, this	392.7313830861464
gentleman here.”	347.65900918721394
“I?” cried Athos, with an accent like that of a man who perceives he is	326.9385998440254
about to tread upon an adder.	416.5013013193579
“You, to be sure!” said D’Artagnan, pressing Athos’s hand. “You know	480.064920749092
the interest we both take in this poor little Madame Bonacieux.	464.08854148385296
Besides, Kitty will tell nothing; will you, Kitty? You understand, my	301.2673286974624
dear girl,” continued D’Artagnan, “she is the wife of that frightful	305.9261457789243
baboon you saw at the door as you came in.”	414.658212173896
“Oh, my God! You remind me of my fright! If he should have known me	383.58943482540474
again!”	472.3201801273615
“How? know you again? Did you ever see that man before?”	372.583317559521
“He came twice to Milady’s.”	477.87872439106775
“That’s it. About what time?”	360.36081306997613
“Why, about fifteen or eighteen days ago.”	415.3340256908117
“Exactly so.”	442.46030290765236
“And yesterday evening he came again.”	414.83055305710127
“Yesterday evening?”	377.9101540649542
“Yes, just before you came.”	311.4450848898806
“My dear Athos, we are enveloped in a network of spies. And do you	307.9410010590783
believe he knew you again, Kitty?”	366.0708313838067
“I pulled down my hood as soon as I saw him, but perhaps it was too	433.8687652591557
late.”	323.0592456686024
“Go down, Athos—he mistrusts you less than me—and see if he be still at	486.7490607487275
his door.”	449.07715282632273
Athos went down and returned immediately.	407.2928754245196
“He has gone,” said he, “and the house door is shut.”	380.8873118835538
“He has gone to make his report, and to say that all the pigeons are at	428.50857481182504
this moment in the dovecot.”	386.65022490550035
“Well, then, let us all fly,” said Athos, “and leave nobody here but	481.4236035471795
Planchet to bring us news.”	429.3839161195848
“A minute. Aramis, whom we have sent for!”	326.2067856673188
“That’s true,” said Athos; “we must wait for Aramis.”	354.7127274937432
At that moment Aramis entered.	308.16027315756344
The matter was all explained to him, and the friends gave him to	480.2581744347514
understand that among all his high connections he must find a place for	368.8626618501906
Kitty.	330.64883704755783
Aramis reflected for a minute, and then said, coloring, “Will it be	419.10735526209487
really rendering you a service, D’Artagnan?”	374.28425469227375
“I shall be grateful to you all my life.”	455.39446293908827
“Very well. Madame de Bois-Tracy asked me, for one of her friends who	438.06304831734747
resides in the provinces, I believe, for a trustworthy maid. If you	423.9407888219726
can, my dear D’Artagnan, answer for Mademoiselle—”	450.64553960715125
“Oh, monsieur, be assured that I shall be entirely devoted to the	408.0593189303509
person who will give me the means of quitting Paris.”	410.4994478456469
“Then,” said Aramis, “this falls out very well.”	321.2933031736847
He placed himself at the table and wrote a little note which he sealed	372.02275960046404
with a ring, and gave the billet to Kitty.	345.940542314948
“And now, my dear girl,” said D’Artagnan, “you know that it is not good	391.1108369997095
for any of us to be here. Therefore let us separate. We shall meet	319.6795169007732
again in better days.”	294.94548412770735
“And whenever we find each other, in whatever place it may be,” said	328.3658583923491
Kitty, “you will find me loving you as I love you today.”	424.0632119031833
“Dicers’ oaths!” said Athos, while D’Artagnan went to conduct Kitty	350.19606349222397
downstairs.	357.7588684905597
An instant afterward the three young men separated, agreeing to meet	426.57699461979746
again at four o’clock with Athos, and leaving Planchet to guard the	414.5188797702138
house.	331.22761693413935
Aramis returned home, and Athos and D’Artagnan busied themselves about	427.4684827574582
pledging the sapphire.	395.3459447494639
As the Gascon had foreseen, they easily obtained three hundred pistoles	480.36852536309357
on the ring. Still further, the Jew told them that if they would sell	448.98425285719895
it to him, as it would make a magnificent pendant for earrings, he	346.56055202580353
would give five hundred pistoles for it.	468.17857749047056
Athos and D’Artagnan, with the activity of two soldiers and the	306.38603871146256
knowledge of two connoisseurs, hardly required three hours to purchase	474.9299987907604
the entire equipment of the Musketeer. Besides, Athos was very easy,	402.3583919291543
and a noble to his fingers’ ends. When a thing suited him he paid the	350.97109325055294
price demanded, without thinking to ask for any abatement. D’Artagnan	297.84618683077247
would have remonstrated at this; but Athos put his hand upon his	447.17942794807516
shoulder, with a smile, and D’Artagnan understood that it was all very	294.6743587588699
well for such a little Gascon gentleman as himself to drive a bargain,	297.61657485536836
but not for a man who had the bearing of a prince. The Musketeer met	358.0521617443992
with a superb Andalusian horse, black as jet, nostrils of fire, legs	315.2718116084754
clean and elegant, rising six years. He examined him, and found him	409.0976815999577
sound and without blemish. They asked a thousand livres for him.	318.13489227522814
He might perhaps have been bought for less; but while D’Artagnan was	365.640027040921
discussing the price with the dealer, Athos was counting out the money	405.63370095830584
on the table.	297.349662556988
Grimaud had a stout, short Picard cob, which cost three hundred livres.	472.8235174206227
But when the saddle and arms for Grimaud were purchased, Athos had not	428.6605806559736
a sou left of his hundred and fifty pistoles. D’Artagnan offered his	397.6008376102576
friend a part of his share which he should return when convenient.	371.78485082990306
But Athos only replied to this proposal by shrugging his shoulders.	369.81126056745137
“How much did the Jew say he would give for the sapphire if he	316.93251911185837
purchased it?” said Athos.	422.9724015356245
“Five hundred pistoles.”	331.7257145201234
“That is to say, two hundred more—a hundred pistoles for you and a	360.8125051919524
hundred pistoles for me. Well, now, that would be a real fortune to us,	340.432844924887
my friend; let us go back to the Jew’s again.”	460.57515016346065
“What! will you—”	318.1139707071769
“This ring would certainly only recall very bitter remembrances; then	334.10201228080666
we shall never be masters of three hundred pistoles to redeem it, so	346.99414605161826
that we really should lose two hundred pistoles by the bargain. Go and	364.5897457573833
tell him the ring is his, D’Artagnan, and bring back the two hundred	307.21481773484504
pistoles with you.”	421.96195424616076
“Reflect, Athos!”	423.2967560525417
“Ready money is needful for the present time, and we must learn how to	379.73092901373
make sacrifices. Go, D’Artagnan, go; Grimaud will accompany you with	484.98831747958684
his musketoon.”	395.6576544726033
A half hour afterward, D’Artagnan returned with the two thousand	300.8232010681206
livres, and without having met with any accident.	292.60009812820255
It was thus Athos found at home resources which he did not expect.	397.79136501260206
Chapter XXXIX.	413.04814315262917
A VISION	297.46924391095826
At four o’clock the four friends were all assembled with Athos. Their	466.87426632153915
anxiety about their outfits had all disappeared, and each countenance	299.07762698380157
only preserved the expression of its own secret disquiet—for behind all	423.1586625582652
present happiness is concealed a fear for the future.	298.49832897860045
Suddenly Planchet entered, bringing two letters for D’Artagnan.	393.4130581647991
The one was a little billet, genteelly folded, with a pretty seal in	338.1708427331303
green wax on which was impressed a dove bearing a green branch.	414.791010416729
The other was a large square epistle, resplendent with the terrible	397.10465154808173
arms of his Eminence the cardinal duke.	350.44646568693184
At the sight of the little letter the heart of D’Artagnan bounded, for	363.9449414913672
he believed he recognized the handwriting, and although he had seen	411.0172061276806
that writing but once, the memory of it remained at the bottom of his	477.93780017684355
heart.	452.4963829359646
He therefore seized the little epistle, and opened it eagerly.	468.73727205757746
“Be,” said the letter, “on Thursday next, at from six to seven o’clock	457.08018606310367
in the evening, on the road to Chaillot, and look carefully into the	462.34866289513934
carriages that pass; but if you have any consideration for your own	429.43823433068104
life or that of those who love you, do not speak a single word, do not	397.2529197336587
make a movement which may lead anyone to believe you have recognized	457.552496200232
her who exposes herself to everything for the sake of seeing you but	491.4473053000831
for an instant.”	297.93049487190916
No signature.	294.1881999424473
“That’s a snare,” said Athos; “don’t go, D’Artagnan.”	438.7642848584986
“And yet,” replied D’Artagnan, “I think I recognize the writing.”	479.45314704679515
“It may be counterfeit,” said Athos. “Between six and seven o’clock the	380.00633257942326
road of Chaillot is quite deserted; you might as well go and ride in	340.59466076244473
the forest of Bondy.”	358.42257748444746
“But suppose we all go,” said D’Artagnan; “what the devil! They won’t	400.02602685216044
devour us all four, four lackeys, horses, arms, and all!”	435.03023983484456
“And besides, it will be a chance for displaying our new equipments,”	361.99286801174384
said Porthos.	339.57311918893686
“But if it is a woman who writes,” said Aramis, “and that woman desires	338.4753469998386
not to be seen, remember, you compromise her, D’Artagnan; which is not	339.78216369339054
the part of a gentleman.”	341.5307653458565
“We will remain in the background,” said Porthos, “and he will advance	307.58856497495196
alone.”	298.92974494339484
“Yes; but a pistol shot is easily fired from a carriage which goes at a	352.7691559771558
gallop.”	330.9010452254358
“Bah!” said D’Artagnan, “they will miss me; if they fire we will ride	369.36074152459446
after the carriage, and exterminate those who may be in it. They must	313.834170143981
be enemies.”	455.2184585759851
“He is right,” said Porthos; “battle. Besides, we must try our own	384.09954129766953
arms.”	423.61923848162587
“Bah, let us enjoy that pleasure,” said Aramis, with his mild and	374.1474277063174
careless manner.	449.02671487708676
“As you please,” said Athos.	389.8041081890707
“Gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, “it is half past four, and we have	348.14084698577295
scarcely time to be on the road of Chaillot by six.”	411.92321358241645
“Besides, if we go out too late, nobody will see us,” said Porthos,	393.1707776747876
“and that will be a pity. Let us get ready, gentlemen.”	434.7173166586217
“But this second letter,” said Athos, “you forget that; it appears to	351.2207081588209
me, however, that the seal denotes that it deserves to be opened. For	333.99748517107514
my part, I declare, D’Artagnan, I think it of much more consequence	321.6473859343774
than the little piece of waste paper you have so cunningly slipped into	345.474393334121
your bosom.”	476.84258161121363
D’Artagnan blushed.	472.2952348256439
“Well,” said he, “let us see, gentlemen, what are his Eminence’s	454.6722134841894
commands,” and D’Artagnan unsealed the letter and read,	475.7977718519757
“M. d’Artagnan, of the king’s Guards, company Dessessart, is expected	348.181188315503
at the Palais-Cardinal this evening, at eight o’clock.	316.05360328875895
“LA HOUDINIERE, _Captain of the Guards_”	369.74680388677336
“The devil!” said Athos; “here’s a rendezvous much more serious than	373.11403765591837
the other.”	438.0700430058579
“I will go to the second after attending the first,” said D’Artagnan.	377.5407639810144
“One is for seven o’clock, and the other for eight; there will be time	292.73949971211283
for both.”	397.99819893154904
“Hum! I would not go at all,” said Aramis. “A gallant knight cannot	481.80478559866077
decline a rendezvous with a lady; but a prudent gentleman may excuse	441.65347823577963
himself from not waiting on his Eminence, particularly when he has	300.6929111585361
reason to believe he is not invited to make his compliments.”	388.21742727076736
“I am of Aramis’s opinion,” said Porthos.	401.2369533423848
“Gentlemen,” replied D’Artagnan, “I have already received by Monsieur	435.660662250677
de Cavois a similar invitation from his Eminence. I neglected it, and	450.6312935509452
on the morrow a serious misfortune happened to me—Constance	382.8320595344035
disappeared. Whatever may ensue, I will go.”	460.87939078493514
“If you are determined,” said Athos, “do so.”	460.94358938810785
“But the Bastille?” said Aramis.	360.23725929748804
“Bah! you will get me out if they put me there,” said D’Artagnan.	483.0968059353338
“To be sure we will,” replied Aramis and Porthos, with admirable	332.84337286354844
promptness and decision, as if that were the simplest thing in the	427.55354025408826
world, “to be sure we will get you out; but meantime, as we are to set	428.91307101547136
off the day after tomorrow, you would do much better not to risk this	449.4780118934936
Bastille.”	321.68053875445645
“Let us do better than that,” said Athos; “do not let us leave him	308.1210605938968
during the whole evening. Let each of us wait at a gate of the palace	402.4705583721653
with three Musketeers behind him; if we see a close carriage, at all	446.6156220571718
suspicious in appearance, come out, let us fall upon it. It is a long	437.10160655707625
time since we have had a skirmish with the Guards of Monsieur the	452.321943798765
Cardinal; Monsieur de Tréville must think us dead.”	477.96541057192286
“To a certainty, Athos,” said Aramis, “you were meant to be a general	307.38354585083556
of the army! What do you think of the plan, gentlemen?”	451.9330205568572
“Admirable!” replied the young men in chorus.	367.5345459449901
“Well,” said Porthos, “I will run to the hôtel, and engage our comrades	331.88424279517704
to hold themselves in readiness by eight o’clock; the rendezvous, the	434.0640947522152
Place du Palais-Cardinal. Meantime, you see that the lackeys saddle the	310.68632410431394
horses.”	477.94102960241344
“I have no horse,” said D’Artagnan; “but that is of no consequence, I	400.62992284074016
can take one of Monsieur de Tréville’s.”	478.58479806990016
“That is not worth while,” said Aramis, “you can have one of mine.”	395.5540464398057
“One of yours! how many have you, then?” asked D’Artagnan.	352.79639700775266
“Three,” replied Aramis, smiling.	333.6410649955567
“_Certes_,” cried Athos, “you are the best-mounted poet of France or	421.47587307601634
Navarre.”	448.048177070613
“Well, my dear Aramis, you don’t want three horses? I cannot comprehend	489.1427774282772
what induced you to buy three!”	330.3353343793884
“Therefore I only purchased two,” said Aramis.	415.05372851426785
“The third, then, fell from the clouds, I suppose?”	400.2942215290327
“No, the third was brought to me this very morning by a groom out of	406.5537368489727
livery, who would not tell me in whose service he was, and who said he	377.643940321944
had received orders from his master.”	486.9009926464991
“Or his mistress,” interrupted D’Artagnan.	455.7733934381889
“That makes no difference,” said Aramis, coloring; “and who affirmed,	357.43732322110634
as I said, that he had received orders from his master or mistress to	313.71793087678043
place the horse in my stable, without informing me whence it came.”	474.3910441719589
“It is only to poets that such things happen,” said Athos, gravely.	450.3512966141085
“Well, in that case, we can manage famously,” said D’Artagnan; “which	330.92619639119533
of the two horses will you ride—that which you bought or the one that	367.9846516419426
was given to you?”	443.4266447020756
“That which was given to me, assuredly. You cannot for a moment	412.72601620823576
imagine, D’Artagnan, that I would commit such an offense toward—”	394.21306067266335
“The unknown giver,” interrupted D’Artagnan.	461.36925709425196
“Or the mysterious benefactress,” said Athos.	485.16086827001664
“The one you bought will then become useless to you?”	360.80235402248144
“Nearly so.”	464.90662776118666
“And you selected it yourself?”	356.25457464264696
“With the greatest care. The safety of the horseman, you know, depends	355.6632893895419
almost always upon the goodness of his horse.”	487.67382853272477
“Well, transfer it to me at the price it cost you?”	302.8884260193643
“I was going to make you the offer, my dear D’Artagnan, giving you all	321.8166345728274
the time necessary for repaying me such a trifle.”	298.96055263097634
“How much did it cost you?”	460.82093605668155
“Eight hundred livres.”	355.36366360070423
“Here are forty double pistoles, my dear friend,” said D’Artagnan,	325.64577144054186
taking the sum from his pocket; “I know that is the coin in which you	302.83016306811396
were paid for your poems.”	325.645401716285
“You are rich, then?” said Aramis.	458.5233928238442
“Rich? Richest, my dear fellow!”	456.7798406640244
And D’Artagnan chinked the remainder of his pistoles in his pocket.	399.92208573635656
“Send your saddle, then, to the hôtel of the Musketeers, and your horse	453.4792201506515
can be brought back with ours.”	314.19546483881845
“Very well; but it is already five o’clock, so make haste.”	414.5577326402164
A quarter of an hour afterward Porthos appeared at the end of the Rue	303.09909455117804
Férou on a very handsome _genet_. Mousqueton followed him upon an	479.95697352111995
Auvergne horse, small but very handsome. Porthos was resplendent with	313.74088679518115
joy and pride.	410.15729790658577
At the same time, Aramis made his appearance at the other end of the	334.6582147189327
street upon a superb English charger. Bazin followed him upon a roan,	364.00598127191455
holding by the halter a vigorous Mecklenburg horse; this was	391.1403712298863
D’Artagnan’s mount.	486.507832144618
The two Musketeers met at the gate. Athos and D’Artagnan watched their	398.85788839758783
approach from the window.	417.85621013924293
“The devil!” cried Aramis, “you have a magnificent horse there,	439.4116078556584
Porthos.”	292.3728723303971
“Yes,” replied Porthos, “it is the one that ought to have been sent to	357.70968386000385
me at first. A bad joke of the husband’s substituted the other; but the	468.605118917033
husband has been punished since, and I have obtained full	405.8562583796692
satisfaction.”	445.4236156314277
Planchet and Grimaud appeared in their turn, leading their masters’	314.25003180014795
steeds. D’Artagnan and Athos put themselves into saddle with their	311.6180476862399
companions, and all four set forward; Athos upon a horse he owed to a	292.8050776289492
woman, Aramis on a horse he owed to his mistress, Porthos on a horse he	326.03750195949
owed to his procurator’s wife, and D’Artagnan on a horse he owed to his	356.453558231098
good fortune—the best mistress possible.	338.31161115636746
The lackeys followed.	354.98284747350357
As Porthos had foreseen, the cavalcade produced a good effect; and if	398.20297722350125
Mme. Coquenard had met Porthos and seen what a superb appearance he	476.01311756832774
made upon his handsome Spanish _genet_, she would not have regretted	420.0756953761416
the bleeding she had inflicted upon the strongbox of her husband.	488.7461345482962
Near the Louvre the four friends met with M. de Tréville, who was	346.11004645724154
returning from St. Germain; he stopped them to offer his compliments	404.3100042046517
upon their appointments, which in an instant drew round them a hundred	299.46610307465323
gapers.	343.00582158274597
D’Artagnan profited by the circumstance to speak to M. de Tréville of	461.95780901189653
the letter with the great red seal and the cardinal’s arms. It is well	479.1587548457985
understood that he did not breathe a word about the other.	462.6512628710808
M. de Tréville approved of the resolution he had adopted, and assured	390.73230818614314
him that if on the morrow he did not appear, he himself would undertake	452.4839403541782
to find him, let him be where he might.	459.2545949272808
At this moment the clock of La Samaritaine struck six; the four friends	333.82201288343015
pleaded an engagement, and took leave of M. de Tréville.	421.1344937349942
A short gallop brought them to the road of Chaillot; the day began to	448.77610239028706
decline, carriages were passing and repassing. D’Artagnan, keeping at	465.56121788028634
some distance from his friends, darted a scrutinizing glance into every	316.9444066002264
carriage that appeared, but saw no face with which he was acquainted.	486.9548188288063
At length, after waiting a quarter of an hour and just as twilight was	435.506457380024
beginning to thicken, a carriage appeared, coming at a quick pace on	489.5675121277105
the road of Sèvres. A presentiment instantly told D’Artagnan that this	300.2158398562507
carriage contained the person who had appointed the rendezvous; the	396.7173698849012
young man was himself astonished to find his heart beat so violently.	477.27959111240483
Almost instantly a female head was put out at the window, with two	331.8375611686729
fingers placed upon her mouth, either to enjoin silence or to send him	304.52785109579617
a kiss. D’Artagnan uttered a slight cry of joy; this woman, or rather	400.20485559307747
this apparition—for the carriage passed with the rapidity of a	307.64512996045636
vision—was Mme. Bonacieux.	476.4567799081806
By an involuntary movement and in spite of the injunction given,	461.1534047527158
D’Artagnan put his horse into a gallop, and in a few strides overtook	357.37726513364225
the carriage; but the window was hermetically closed, the vision had	301.40578167151745
disappeared.	356.48009484851383
D’Artagnan then remembered the injunction: “If you value your own life	326.39407501073214
or that of those who love you, remain motionless, and as if you had	348.99135603907655
seen nothing.”	461.9432812977439
He stopped, therefore, trembling not for himself but for the poor woman	317.6057690915862
who had evidently exposed herself to great danger by appointing this	353.62125882158716
rendezvous.	360.49709353063963
The carriage pursued its way, still going at a great pace, till it	321.964274334147
dashed into Paris, and disappeared.	341.0682671462167
D’Artagnan remained fixed to the spot, astounded and not knowing what	455.3441515058279
to think. If it was Mme. Bonacieux and if she was returning to Paris,	329.4071942704304
why this fugitive rendezvous, why this simple exchange of a glance, why	379.97598565106745
this lost kiss? If, on the other side, it was not she—which was still	296.86806794213294
quite possible—for the little light that remained rendered a mistake	418.4336202621437
easy—might it not be the commencement of some plot against him through	439.91473546550714
the allurement of this woman, for whom his love was known?	341.2117044486843
His three companions joined him. All had plainly seen a woman’s head	302.94060286443835
appear at the window, but none of them, except Athos, knew Mme.	446.1773754055016
Bonacieux. The opinion of Athos was that it was indeed she; but less	329.9388075007973
preoccupied by that pretty face than D’Artagnan, he had fancied he saw	406.75864252868547
a second head, a man’s head, inside the carriage.	383.8420129754388
“If that be the case,” said D’Artagnan, “they are doubtless	367.3326004786796
transporting her from one prison to another. But what can they intend	479.0755215429804
to do with the poor creature, and how shall I ever meet her again?”	315.08768342336265
“Friend,” said Athos, gravely, “remember that it is the dead alone with	301.5168716298069
whom we are not likely to meet again on this earth. You know something	461.7915916816861
of that, as well as I do, I think. Now, if your mistress is not dead,	435.48799347090824
if it is she we have just seen, you will meet with her again some day	395.6417244362893
or other. And perhaps, my God!” added he, with that misanthropic tone	472.20266242859077
which was peculiar to him, “perhaps sooner than you wish.”	484.3335036751688
Half past seven had sounded. The carriage had been twenty minutes	418.27382330515115
behind the time appointed. D’Artagnan’s friends reminded him that he	373.0075787921112
had a visit to pay, but at the same time bade him observe that there	358.2453810926596
was yet time to retract.	312.741413480843
But D’Artagnan was at the same time impetuous and curious. He had made	441.0372901677498
up his mind that he would go to the Palais-Cardinal, and that he would	381.3337624484831
learn what his Eminence had to say to him. Nothing could turn him from	409.66217144553076
his purpose.	418.5816363364884
They reached the Rue St. Honoré, and in the Place du Palais-Cardinal	455.12813244267943
they found the twelve invited Musketeers, walking about in expectation	344.15455769743
of their comrades. There only they explained to them the matter in	459.9105791701155
hand.	454.8536623425151
D’Artagnan was well known among the honorable corps of the king’s	439.3383798314161
Musketeers, in which it was known he would one day take his place; he	331.19097410578183
was considered beforehand as a comrade. It resulted from these	299.0643073759835
antecedents that everyone entered heartily into the purpose for which	451.3001678296473
they met; besides, it would not be unlikely that they would have an	393.83690068013345
opportunity of playing either the cardinal or his people an ill turn,	476.656530340113
and for such expeditions these worthy gentlemen were always ready.	425.3802094769075
Athos divided them into three groups, assumed the command of one, gave	363.4055516850993
the second to Aramis, and the third to Porthos; and then each group	412.6107500650043
went and took their watch near an entrance.	398.4677003242671
D’Artagnan, on his part, entered boldly at the principal gate.	416.6414609804616
Although he felt himself ably supported, the young man was not without	378.13664087409813
a little uneasiness as he ascended the great staircase, step by step.	309.74293671022633
His conduct toward Milady bore a strong resemblance to treachery, and	422.4195451331635
he was very suspicious of the political relations which existed between	460.03919942850143
that woman and the cardinal. Still further, De Wardes, whom he had	367.4496156031927
treated so ill, was one of the tools of his Eminence; and D’Artagnan	415.8044616884365
knew that while his Eminence was terrible to his enemies, he was	302.86602583147555
strongly attached to his friends.	450.96084448643455
“If De Wardes has related all our affair to the cardinal, which is not	339.2647259188675
to be doubted, and if he has recognized me, as is probable, I may	424.90159849388203
consider myself almost as a condemned man,” said D’Artagnan, shaking	358.62279342548834
his head. “But why has he waited till now? That’s all plain enough.	380.17717404013104
Milady has laid her complaints against me with that hypocritical grief	331.682198756599
which renders her so interesting, and this last offense has made the	330.7471339733817
cup overflow.”	482.2318741353333
“Fortunately,” added he, “my good friends are down yonder, and they	423.31480007925154
will not allow me to be carried away without a struggle. Nevertheless,	432.1549254352334
Monsieur de Tréville’s company of Musketeers alone cannot maintain a	338.21337290129816
war against the cardinal, who disposes of the forces of all France, and	303.5879000046813
before whom the queen is without power and the king without will.	297.1604192600272
D’Artagnan, my friend, you are brave, you are prudent, you have	459.50151535491403
excellent qualities; but the women will ruin you!”	489.59906180961787
He came to this melancholy conclusion as he entered the antechamber. He	433.6859032600887
placed his letter in the hands of the usher on duty, who led him into	362.04311278204216
the waiting room and passed on into the interior of the palace.	461.45555729389673
In this waiting room were five or six of the cardinal’s Guards, who	309.16915379554365
recognized D’Artagnan, and knowing that it was he who had wounded	369.92925961438584
Jussac, they looked upon him with a smile of singular meaning.	459.6808391963764
This smile appeared to D’Artagnan to be of bad augury. Only, as our	435.3156131260815
Gascon was not easily intimidated—or rather, thanks to a great pride	327.974721967025
natural to the men of his country, he did not allow one easily to see	431.12278685070925
what was passing in his mind when that which was passing at all	454.6293902863517
resembled fear—he placed himself haughtily in front of Messieurs the	412.942617259161
Guards, and waited with his hand on his hip, in an attitude by no means	487.7147325901508
deficient in majesty.	379.3393066634302
The usher returned and made a sign to D’Artagnan to follow him. It	420.29040795207806
appeared to the young man that the Guards, on seeing him depart,	446.7094412319223
chuckled among themselves.	402.2725994343506
He traversed a corridor, crossed a grand saloon, entered a library, and	388.1239271879963
found himself in the presence of a man seated at a desk and writing.	454.41899596483796
The usher introduced him, and retired without speaking a word.	407.23117941212536
D’Artagnan remained standing and examined this man.	383.7436398853277
D’Artagnan at first believed that he had to do with some judge	446.94676993593396
examining his papers; but he perceived that the man at the desk wrote,	390.6814978323064
or rather corrected, lines of unequal length, scanning the words on his	398.0411187759261
fingers. He saw then that he was with a poet. At the end of an instant	310.1254382608397
the poet closed his manuscript, upon the cover of which was written	389.70560652027007
“Mirame, a Tragedy in Five Acts,” and raised his head.	377.37618639404
D’Artagnan recognized the cardinal.	353.35638760827453
Chapter XL.	380.3989263365717
A TERRIBLE VISION	330.6790757193844
The cardinal leaned his elbow on his manuscript, his cheek upon his	384.54104444794575
hand, and looked intently at the young man for a moment. No one had a	332.6046130153915
more searching eye than the Cardinal de Richelieu, and D’Artagnan felt	376.11592284529723
this glance run through his veins like a fever.	303.3011937120683
He however kept a good countenance, holding his hat in his hand and	385.40926638763864
awaiting the good pleasure of his Eminence, without too much assurance,	395.11414552686483
but also without too much humility.	294.4994514634099
“Monsieur,” said the cardinal, “are you a D’Artagnan from Béarn?”	361.4861581630556
“Yes, monseigneur,” replied the young man.	364.0895708210611
“There are several branches of the D’Artagnans at Tarbes and in its	385.77258713193896
environs,” said the cardinal; “to which do you belong?”	440.18004538154656
“I am the son of him who served in the Religious Wars under the great	347.4513301932587
King Henry, the father of his gracious Majesty.”	350.49439861825476
“That is well. It is you who set out seven or eight months ago from	434.1433708716762
your country to seek your fortune in the capital?”	298.24892248276444
“Yes, monseigneur.”	442.07026476830265
“You came through Meung, where something befell you. I don’t very well	472.8699795318473
know what, but still something.”	459.0218536004571
“Monseigneur,” said D’Artagnan, “this was what happened to me—”	299.3183024017162
“Never mind, never mind!” resumed the cardinal, with a smile which	347.4924587239636
indicated that he knew the story as well as he who wished to relate it.	451.4969894896369
“You were recommended to Monsieur de Tréville, were you not?”	385.2493084158952
“Yes, monseigneur; but in that unfortunate affair at Meung—”	329.89866956869764
“The letter was lost,” replied his Eminence; “yes, I know that. But	341.1670595745268
Monsieur de Tréville is a skilled physiognomist, who knows men at first	387.68979812914563
sight; and he placed you in the company of his brother-in-law, Monsieur	322.970083742556
Dessessart, leaving you to hope that one day or other you should enter	340.15591095024274
the Musketeers.”	448.20243064624765
“Monseigneur is correctly informed,” said D’Artagnan.	319.9682007171529
“Since that time many things have happened to you. You were walking one	460.04171855972186
day behind the Chartreux, when it would have been better if you had	341.1774548422318
been elsewhere. Then you took with your friends a journey to the waters	480.6376382683748
of Forges; they stopped on the road, but you continued yours. That is	344.5949882087314
all very simple: you had business in England.”	324.59441420229547
“Monseigneur,” said D’Artagnan, quite confused, “I went—”	438.73610246662804
“Hunting at Windsor, or elsewhere—that concerns nobody. I know, because	407.2361705094233
it is my office to know everything. On your return you were received by	457.148991184852
an august personage, and I perceive with pleasure that you preserve the	406.1859372141759
souvenir she gave you.”	473.23482640988664
D’Artagnan placed his hand upon the queen’s diamond, which he wore, and	413.30176534407224
quickly turned the stone inward; but it was too late.	312.49511941696767
“The day after that, you received a visit from Cavois,” resumed the	437.0399954813735
cardinal. “He went to desire you to come to the palace. You have not	399.2299235257693
returned that visit, and you were wrong.”	366.65853327378966
“Monseigneur, I feared I had incurred disgrace with your Eminence.”	346.70744149453196
“How could that be, monsieur? Could you incur my displeasure by having	469.6542468757398
followed the orders of your superiors with more intelligence and	358.3078772226625
courage than another would have done? It is the people who do not obey	316.8164516988347
that I punish, and not those who, like you, obey—but too well. As a	321.0243264146837
proof, remember the date of the day on which I had you bidden to come	335.30171937729693
to me, and seek in your memory for what happened to you that very	300.58260603100416
night.”	368.0252127798961
That was the very evening when the abduction of Mme. Bonacieux took	428.60819626431646
place. D’Artagnan trembled; and he likewise recollected that during the	310.18089704548254
past half hour the poor woman had passed close to him, without doubt	444.990145253838
carried away by the same power that had caused her disappearance.	368.7831334263989
“In short,” continued the cardinal, “as I have heard nothing of you for	398.34149293585443
some time past, I wished to know what you were doing. Besides, you owe	307.31430365507754
me some thanks. You must yourself have remarked how much you have been	417.7755559144091
considered in all the circumstances.”	326.71142502935305
D’Artagnan bowed with respect.	329.0115531173847
“That,” continued the cardinal, “arose not only from a feeling of	323.940830116652
natural equity, but likewise from a plan I have marked out with respect	384.85286511264115
to you.”	480.4509593473874
D’Artagnan became more and more astonished.	473.29100205618187
“I wished to explain this plan to you on the day you received my first	320.42879230065273
invitation; but you did not come. Fortunately, nothing is lost by this	352.12411280392627
delay, and you are now about to hear it. Sit down there, before me,	453.227328066769
D’Artagnan; you are gentleman enough not to listen standing.” And the	485.65510666605394
cardinal pointed with his finger to a chair for the young man, who was	383.11603356339026
so astonished at what was passing that he awaited a second sign from	438.43357094840405
his interlocutor before he obeyed.	380.0063421915998
“You are brave, Monsieur d’Artagnan,” continued his Eminence; “you are	476.45238267312857
prudent, which is still better. I like men of head and heart. Don’t be	414.174725392284
afraid,” said he, smiling. “By men of heart I mean men of courage. But	364.1817455813318
young as you are, and scarcely entering into the world, you have	394.6844159637868
powerful enemies; if you do not take great heed, they will destroy	301.00870243461077
you.”	380.9044030110469
“Alas, monseigneur!” replied the young man, “very easily, no doubt, for	308.686049404207
they are strong and well supported, while I am alone.”	476.82280449555765
“Yes, that’s true; but alone as you are, you have done much already,	358.46864880376705
and will do still more, I don’t doubt. Yet you have need, I believe, to	331.9558671609092
be guided in the adventurous career you have undertaken; for, if I	406.16079309586695
mistake not, you came to Paris with the ambitious idea of making your	387.6849164790426
fortune.”	320.1864759212924
“I am at the age of extravagant hopes, monseigneur,” said D’Artagnan.	382.7989501485806
“There are no extravagant hopes but for fools, monsieur, and you are a	353.23151336113716
man of understanding. Now, what would you say to an ensign’s commission	427.1643621760903
in my Guards, and a company after the campaign?”	401.6415527027509
“Ah, monseigneur.”	384.67373537107915
“You accept it, do you not?”	407.8950879982922
“Monseigneur,” replied D’Artagnan, with an embarrassed air.	454.67396463136697
“How? You refuse?” cried the cardinal, with astonishment.	448.1440092777386
“I am in his Majesty’s Guards, monseigneur, and I have no reason to be	345.12202176664005
dissatisfied.”	345.85071290955443
“But it appears to me that my Guards—mine—are also his Majesty’s	327.65941195084497
Guards; and whoever serves in a French corps serves the king.”	314.4652607525035
“Monseigneur, your Eminence has ill understood my words.”	346.96742747441095
“You want a pretext, do you not? I comprehend. Well, you have this	350.14924365676
excuse: advancement, the opening campaign, the opportunity which I	308.02550321629707
offer you—so much for the world. As regards yourself, the need of	427.84575560348503
protection; for it is fit you should know, Monsieur d’Artagnan, that I	336.5507257208182
have received heavy and serious complaints against you. You do not	442.4543402798721
consecrate your days and nights wholly to the king’s service.”	461.9439185128977
D’Artagnan colored.	396.0893299918039
“In fact,” said the cardinal, placing his hand upon a bundle of papers,	352.1437986285605
“I have here a whole pile which concerns you. I know you to be a man of	314.0437616965113
resolution; and your services, well directed, instead of leading you to	447.9418792045409
ill, might be very advantageous to you. Come; reflect, and decide.”	391.8903022016196
“Your goodness confounds me, monseigneur,” replied D’Artagnan, “and I	327.2403559535077
am conscious of a greatness of soul in your Eminence that makes me mean	304.2370142617945
as an earthworm; but since Monseigneur permits me to speak freely—”	305.1532481000687
D’Artagnan paused.	345.52096996469476
“Yes; speak.”	351.99857731231594
“Then, I will presume to say that all my friends are in the king’s	399.30856908752804
Musketeers and Guards, and that by an inconceivable fatality my enemies	410.00458827271314
are in the service of your Eminence; I should, therefore, be ill	423.9490522777472
received here and ill regarded there if I accepted what Monseigneur	452.79986807136
offers me.”	357.90791750498164
“Do you happen to entertain the haughty idea that I have not yet made	406.56881192195
you an offer equal to your value?” asked the cardinal, with a smile of	359.34004378436646
disdain.	323.7070438080705
“Monseigneur, your Eminence is a hundred times too kind to me; and on	312.9318604329587
the contrary, I think I have not proved myself worthy of your goodness.	489.1563580463047
The siege of La Rochelle is about to be resumed, monseigneur. I shall	469.7221340065485
serve under the eye of your Eminence, and if I have the good fortune to	324.84677619016674
conduct myself at the siege in such a manner as merits your attention,	293.3858396782774
then I shall at least leave behind me some brilliant action to justify	380.635754746368
the protection with which you honor me. Everything is best in its time,	456.5224666213134
monseigneur. Hereafter, perhaps, I shall have the right of _giving_	425.2197412536495
myself; at present I shall appear to sell myself.”	411.9156111430347
“That is to say, you refuse to serve me, monsieur,” said the cardinal,	337.5213638068444
with a tone of vexation, through which, however, might be seen a sort	387.5945624136082
of esteem; “remain free, then, and guard your hatreds and your	477.5840519990862
sympathies.”	321.6165039346656
“Monseigneur—”	409.00968376739274
“Well, well,” said the cardinal, “I don’t wish you any ill; but you	379.6791337908327
must be aware that it is quite trouble enough to defend and recompense	326.41972292325164
our friends. We owe nothing to our enemies; and let me give you a piece	384.56751501957774
of advice; take care of yourself, Monsieur d’Artagnan, for from the	310.2035670787328
moment I withdraw my hand from behind you, I would not give an _obolus_	423.6286951086289
for your life.”	406.8853446228815
“I will try to do so, monseigneur,” replied the Gascon, with a noble	424.87635243946596
confidence.	440.8137801461297
“Remember at a later period and at a certain moment, if any mischance	300.5158627655406
should happen to you,” said Richelieu, significantly, “that it was I	383.41949004251296
who came to seek you, and that I did all in my power to prevent this	419.56747615674254
misfortune befalling you.”	377.01971560568734
“I shall entertain, whatever may happen,” said D’Artagnan, placing his	297.8419124688089
hand upon his breast and bowing, “an eternal gratitude toward your	378.2939267953586
Eminence for that which you now do for me.”	327.28523135647464
“Well, let it be, then, as you have said, Monsieur d’Artagnan; we shall	304.1290526984318
see each other again after the campaign. I will have my eye upon you,	427.95620629063615
for I shall be there,” replied the cardinal, pointing with his finger	350.74140954019117
to a magnificent suit of armor he was to wear, “and on our return,	293.2893557307697
well—we will settle our account!”	417.3855822996296
“Ah, monseigneur,” cried D’Artagnan, “spare me the weight of your	387.15431668438464
displeasure. Remain neutral monseigneur, if you find that I act as	491.3676560786007
becomes a gallant man.”	448.4594411854198
“Young man,” said Richelieu, “if I shall be able to say to you at	315.24773693338045
another time what I have said to you today, I promise you to do so.”	349.7670811891604
This last expression of Richelieu’s conveyed a terrible doubt; it	476.4245731422986
alarmed D’Artagnan more than a menace would have done, for it was a	433.14143319288894
warning. The cardinal, then, was seeking to preserve him from some	373.6966191509957
misfortune which threatened him. He opened his mouth to reply, but with	406.14277175389304
a haughty gesture the cardinal dismissed him.	350.5435369882042
D’Artagnan went out, but at the door his heart almost failed him, and	460.46463111086143
he felt inclined to return. Then the noble and severe countenance of	407.85054679254597
Athos crossed his mind; if he made the compact with the cardinal which	437.7686779837342
he required, Athos would no more give him his hand—Athos would renounce	381.5006307360796
him.	317.66398990610645
It was this fear that restrained him, so powerful is the influence of a	428.14905197803057
truly great character on all that surrounds it.	311.68805092234953
D’Artagnan descended by the staircase at which he had entered, and	314.3073803808782
found Athos and the four Musketeers waiting his appearance, and	423.12520073198147
beginning to grow uneasy. With a word, D’Artagnan reassured them; and	442.9818955116956
Planchet ran to inform the other sentinels that it was useless to keep	368.35520020434086
guard longer, as his master had come out safe from the Palais-Cardinal.	476.39894984808114
Returned home with Athos, Aramis and Porthos inquired eagerly the cause	410.4759323966947
of the strange interview; but D’Artagnan confined himself to telling	432.3608689127507
them that M. de Richelieu had sent for him to propose to him to enter	405.2267249839292
into his guards with the rank of ensign, and that he had refused.	347.7380899481357
“And you were right,” cried Aramis and Porthos, with one voice.	430.7199141411015
Athos fell into a profound reverie and answered nothing. But when they	402.80933999621317
were alone he said, “You have done that which you ought to have done,	379.375013899216
D’Artagnan; but perhaps you have been wrong.”	416.6062029382916
D’Artagnan sighed deeply, for this voice responded to a secret voice of	381.1336053970865
his soul, which told him that great misfortunes awaited him.	320.04335410576385
The whole of the next day was spent in preparations for departure.	396.6320433600132
D’Artagnan went to take leave of M. de Tréville. At that time it was	439.2076880951116
believed that the separation of the Musketeers and the Guards would be	438.7970313979547
but momentary, the king holding his Parliament that very day and	305.1432552128343
proposing to set out the day after. M. de Tréville contented himself	414.135241950896
with asking D’Artagnan if he could do anything for him, but D’Artagnan	361.38318717153834
answered that he was supplied with all he wanted.	443.85935510978186
That night brought together all those comrades of the Guards of M.	437.42289519583454
Dessessart and the company of Musketeers of M. de Tréville who had been	441.96046133241737
accustomed to associate together. They were parting to meet again when	349.06207082667214
it pleased God, and if it pleased God. That night, then, was somewhat	372.6381186970729
riotous, as may be imagined. In such cases extreme preoccupation is	344.0287982054566
only to be combated by extreme carelessness.	445.33676359901006
At the first sound of the morning trumpet the friends separated; the	465.1267307627945
Musketeers hastening to the hôtel of M. de Tréville, the Guards to that	450.39569489190905
of M. Dessessart. Each of the captains then led his company to the	491.4851569085607
Louvre, where the king held his review.	423.60743826849733
The king was dull and appeared ill, which detracted a little from his	467.7370068625995
usual lofty bearing. In fact, the evening before, a fever had seized	415.2560111092786
him in the midst of the Parliament, while he was holding his Bed of	458.7058227798767
Justice. He had, not the less, decided upon setting out that same	486.09229836977653
evening; and in spite of the remonstrances that had been offered to	405.92380053899467
him, he persisted in having the review, hoping by setting it at	362.28189061526416
defiance to conquer the disease which began to lay hold upon him.	351.4200114072057
The review over, the Guards set forward alone on their march, the	467.8654480055109
Musketeers waiting for the king, which allowed Porthos time to go and	395.00305947296215
take a turn in his superb equipment in the Rue aux Ours.	412.7214384734484
The procurator’s wife saw him pass in his new uniform and on his fine	470.8810616161556
horse. She loved Porthos too dearly to allow him to part thus; she made	483.278345361099
him a sign to dismount and come to her. Porthos was magnificent; his	428.8913473599686
spurs jingled, his cuirass glittered, his sword knocked proudly against	481.3551442867848
his ample limbs. This time the clerks evinced no inclination to laugh,	464.317155422072
such a real ear clipper did Porthos appear.	339.5738995267168
The Musketeer was introduced to M. Coquenard, whose little gray eyes	400.98185642196546
sparkled with anger at seeing his cousin all blazing new. Nevertheless,	484.5140027076647
one thing afforded him inward consolation; it was expected by everybody	304.874525737521
that the campaign would be a severe one. He whispered a hope to himself	476.4871291904935
that this beloved relative might be killed in the field.	396.0362977166691
Porthos paid his compliments to M. Coquenard and bade him farewell. M.	481.7108545392548
Coquenard wished him all sorts of prosperities. As to Mme. Coquenard,	421.19963490796306
she could not restrain her tears; but no evil impressions were taken	429.5392012020217
from her grief as she was known to be very much attached to her	303.5744555374937
relatives, about whom she was constantly having serious disputes with	466.97181644474165
her husband.	414.0038731320909
But the real adieux were made in Mme. Coquenard’s chamber; they were	337.4534662558461
heartrending.	351.11106372584123
As long as the procurator’s wife could follow him with her eyes, she	352.06665052970277
waved her handkerchief to him, leaning so far out of the window as to	475.54285118494306
lead people to believe she wished to precipitate herself. Porthos	450.44267737373025
received all these attentions like a man accustomed to such	394.419512602282
demonstrations, only on turning the corner of the street he lifted his	332.96264936845637
hat gracefully, and waved it to her as a sign of adieu.	361.36691015256883
On his part Aramis wrote a long letter. To whom? Nobody knew. Kitty,	307.56544106287726
who was to set out that evening for Tours, was waiting in the next	394.0244197535083
chamber.	380.73336475345724
Athos sipped the last bottle of his Spanish wine.	356.80779630881574
In the meantime D’Artagnan was defiling with his company. Arriving at	295.58600011177117
the Faubourg St. Antoine, he turned round to look gaily at the	339.5782969325388
Bastille; but as it was the Bastille alone he looked at, he did not	395.8976417990032
observe Milady, who, mounted upon a light chestnut horse, designated	308.01708238777854
him with her finger to two ill-looking men who came close up to the	484.7997839875435
ranks to take notice of him. To a look of interrogation which they	355.10209291885576
made, Milady replied by a sign that it was he. Then, certain that there	297.03877105645495
could be no mistake in the execution of her orders, she started her	336.86382124624873
horse and disappeared.	359.04520953456586
The two men followed the company, and on leaving the Faubourg St.	429.3802394286988
Antoine, mounted two horses properly equipped, which a servant without	469.2579177804611
livery had waiting for them.	415.9556874824938
Chapter XLI.	433.4671796084395
THE SIEGE OF LA ROCHELLE	395.29735892796685
The Siege of La Rochelle was one of the great political events of the	366.8837362665425
reign of Louis XIII., and one of the great military enterprises of the	350.59416562846246
cardinal. It is, then, interesting and even necessary that we should	415.3069866330695
say a few words about it, particularly as many details of this siege	386.70723037990695
are connected in too important a manner with the story we have	453.56762952214956
undertaken to relate to allow us to pass it over in silence.	423.2507424250549
The political plans of the cardinal when he undertook this siege were	393.30129403134544
extensive. Let us unfold them first, and then pass on to the private	302.2081874181178
plans which perhaps had not less influence upon his Eminence than the	359.6826793347879
others.	488.3459867179462
Of the important cities given up by Henry IV. to the Huguenots as places	458.90812991755894
of safety, there only remained La Rochelle. It became necessary,	381.2750762386074
therefore, to destroy this last bulwark of Calvinism—a dangerous leaven	371.98315515479084
with which the ferments of civil revolt and foreign war were constantly	454.0829666607027
mingling.	397.7204224404463
Spaniards, Englishmen, and Italian malcontents, adventurers of all	416.93985288513625
nations, and soldiers of fortune of every sect, flocked at the first	381.07637540727154
summons under the standard of the Protestants, and organized themselves	408.5949287126793
like a vast association, whose branches diverged freely over all parts	433.71721376751475
of Europe.	332.8836224006093
La Rochelle, which had derived a new importance from the ruin of the	318.5070335869293
other Calvinist cities, was, then, the focus of dissensions and	388.94190424017864
ambition. Moreover, its port was the last in the kingdom of France open	295.29690013803787
to the English, and by closing it against England, our eternal enemy,	485.8958984295466
the cardinal completed the work of Joan of Arc and the Duc de Guise.	306.69930143531036
Thus Bassompierre, who was at once Protestant and Catholic—Protestant	387.4895462331398
by conviction and Catholic as commander of the order of the Holy Ghost;	428.6368366589998
Bassompierre, who was a German by birth and a Frenchman at heart—in	463.625701590946
short, Bassompierre, who had a distinguished command at the siege of La	331.2194466333791
Rochelle, said, in charging at the head of several other Protestant	470.361834869896
nobles like himself, “You will see, gentlemen, that we shall be fools	427.2567629135326
enough to take La Rochelle.”	441.34328575355477
And Bassompierre was right. The cannonade of the Isle of Ré presaged to	293.3568343787146
him the dragonnades of the Cévennes; the taking of La Rochelle was the	313.51015783831383
preface to the revocation of the Edict of Nantes.	383.8858918024959
We have hinted that by the side of these views of the leveling and	390.51376849013513
simplifying minister, which belong to history, the chronicler is forced	411.00400249650056
to recognize the lesser motives of the amorous man and jealous rival.	462.990357278794
Richelieu, as everyone knows, had loved the queen. Was this love a	488.41879343896943
simple political affair, or was it naturally one of those profound	341.37165641177774
passions which Anne of Austria inspired in those who approached her?	356.0951913661517
That we are not able to say; but at all events, we have seen, by the	490.7326979106153
anterior developments of this story, that Buckingham had the advantage	419.35119344701616
over him, and in two or three circumstances, particularly that of the	487.9176174389586
diamond studs, had, thanks to the devotedness of the three Musketeers	473.2606745170176
and the courage and conduct of D’Artagnan, cruelly mystified him.	405.21205053145854
It was, then, Richelieu’s object, not only to get rid of an enemy of	476.24837231271033
France, but to avenge himself on a rival; but this vengeance must be	473.3257750187621
grand and striking and worthy in every way of a man who held in his	343.0915550840264
hand, as his weapon for combat, the forces of a kingdom.	386.9764497151243
Richelieu knew that in combating England he combated Buckingham; that	378.54049731835244
in triumphing over England he triumphed over Buckingham—in short, that	372.6939413655245
in humiliating England in the eyes of Europe he humiliated Buckingham	328.2811409524309
in the eyes of the queen.	420.10204253643394
On his side Buckingham, in pretending to maintain the honor of England,	298.32743309975325
was moved by interests exactly like those of the cardinal. Buckingham	393.27526195403175
also was pursuing a private vengeance. Buckingham could not under any	300.84695362695265
pretense be admitted into France as an ambassador; he wished to enter	447.14767057780034
it as a conqueror.	436.8608622450872
It resulted from this that the real stake in this game, which two most	353.44986962186135
powerful kingdoms played for the good pleasure of two amorous men, was	441.90660435004065
simply a kind look from Anne of Austria.	379.12244203846967
The first advantage had been gained by Buckingham. Arriving	451.8738750487329
unexpectedly in sight of the Isle of Ré with ninety vessels and nearly	349.1124759844032
twenty thousand men, he had surprised the Comte de Toiras, who	390.9559055725465
commanded for the king in the Isle, and he had, after a bloody	363.0043811841165
conflict, effected his landing.	433.7979763602941
