Allow us to observe in passing that in this fight perished the Baron de	424.0479395934919
Chantal; that the Baron de Chantal left a little orphan girl eighteen	425.97691110504377
months old, and that this little girl was afterward Mme. de Sévigné.	361.1048136947422
The Comte de Toiras retired into the citadel St. Martin with his	397.84125242524084
garrison, and threw a hundred men into a little fort called the fort of	449.4268142130145
La Prée.	312.04068081766985
This event had hastened the resolutions of the cardinal; and till the	420.59137358568853
king and he could take the command of the siege of La Rochelle, which	469.8797849204136
was determined, he had sent Monsieur to direct the first operations,	457.67603120471387
and had ordered all the troops he could dispose of to march toward the	456.59982105074505
theater of war. It was of this detachment, sent as a vanguard, that our	392.0548235669147
friend D’Artagnan formed a part.	337.5751252326359
The king, as we have said, was to follow as soon as his Bed of Justice	439.6894095843821
had been held; but on rising from his Bed of Justice on the	336.81034104990795
twenty-eighth of June, he felt himself attacked by fever. He was,	348.05546941547163
notwithstanding, anxious to set out; but his illness becoming more	378.5243312037112
serious, he was forced to stop at Villeroy.	292.67603727756943
Now, whenever the king halted, the Musketeers halted. It followed that	463.87254140037646
D’Artagnan, who was as yet purely and simply in the Guards, found	442.45712186107903
himself, for the time at least, separated from his good friends—Athos,	402.58829045912455
Porthos, and Aramis. This separation, which was no more than an	318.21946192015804
unpleasant circumstance, would have certainly become a cause of serious	478.0406294656245
uneasiness if he had been able to guess by what unknown dangers he was	443.01567292233324
surrounded.	430.816724772385
He, however, arrived without accident in the camp established before La	379.9832901372099
Rochelle, on the tenth of the month of September of the year 1627.	354.9480871777936
Everything was in the same state. The Duke of Buckingham and his	481.70087821305935
English, masters of the Isle of Ré, continued to besiege, but without	440.102341765805
success, the citadel St. Martin and the fort of La Prée; and	442.9381965016554
hostilities with La Rochelle had commenced, two or three days before,	326.0521460573732
about a fort which the Duc d’Angoulême had caused to be constructed	429.62577845148144
near the city.	463.33780999047246
The Guards, under the command of M. Dessessart, took up their quarters	392.4946733895392
at the Minimes; but, as we know, D’Artagnan, possessed with ambition to	330.73675177294126
enter the Musketeers, had formed but few friendships among his	307.8764826815103
comrades, and he felt himself isolated and given up to his own	371.98315923641667
reflections.	426.7576596165217
His reflections were not very cheerful. From the time of his arrival in	355.3220382431512
Paris, he had been mixed up with public affairs; but his own private	375.0939284497101
affairs had made no great progress, either in love or fortune. As to	487.3686984174807
love, the only woman he could have loved was Mme. Bonacieux; and Mme.	305.41787676383774
Bonacieux had disappeared, without his being able to discover what had	406.650726260656
become of her. As to fortune, he had made—he, humble as he was—an enemy	376.21764831948076
of the cardinal; that is to say, of a man before whom trembled the	364.05840892354854
greatest men of the kingdom, beginning with the king.	369.25637776117907
That man had the power to crush him, and yet he had not done so. For a	311.0265189892508
mind so perspicuous as that of D’Artagnan, this indulgence was a light	470.8410555333363
by which he caught a glimpse of a better future.	389.8098996171557
Then he had made himself another enemy, less to be feared, he thought;	426.6960602368314
but nevertheless, he instinctively felt, not to be despised. This enemy	427.4676560384038
was Milady.	368.65797339124407
In exchange for all this, he had acquired the protection and good will	425.14126874112924
of the queen; but the favor of the queen was at the present time an	450.29669615210616
additional cause of persecution, and her protection, as it was known,	364.2814898431347
protected badly—as witness Chalais and Mme. Bonacieux.	477.1503419598256
What he had clearly gained in all this was the diamond, worth five or	443.6711411692613
six thousand livres, which he wore on his finger; and even this	356.3571218836124
diamond—supposing that D’Artagnan, in his projects of ambition, wished	423.8245132143805
to keep it, to make it someday a pledge for the gratitude of the	383.9086936786392
queen—had not in the meanwhile, since he could not part with it, more	332.6196282375482
value than the gravel he trod under his feet.	427.1440685637555
We say the gravel he trod under his feet, for D’Artagnan made these	463.789332164922
reflections while walking solitarily along a pretty little road which	328.0347586184012
led from the camp to the village of Angoutin. Now, these reflections	435.42711755866134
had led him further than he intended, and the day was beginning to	404.7493126385875
decline when, by the last ray of the setting sun, he thought he saw the	486.22749586572746
barrel of a musket glitter from behind a hedge.	422.30303673866763
D’Artagnan had a quick eye and a prompt understanding. He comprehended	309.9569916088211
that the musket had not come there of itself, and that he who bore it	306.1446332680097
had not concealed himself behind a hedge with any friendly intentions.	315.687906298799
He determined, therefore, to direct his course as clear from it as he	415.8314761877739
could when, on the opposite side of the road, from behind a rock, he	313.5424664446645
perceived the extremity of another musket.	312.81841148517225
This was evidently an ambuscade.	485.7759234424972
The young man cast a glance at the first musket and saw, with a certain	429.98512571692174
degree of inquietude, that it was leveled in his direction; but as soon	318.6702581743535
as he perceived that the orifice of the barrel was motionless, he threw	297.59279205540537
himself upon the ground. At the same instant the gun was fired, and he	327.65900920196
heard the whistling of a ball pass over his head.	403.27294421966087
No time was to be lost. D’Artagnan sprang up with a bound, and at the	367.3059402982271
same instant the ball from the other musket tore up the gravel on the	303.98405164384604
very spot on the road where he had thrown himself with his face to the	397.4752136138433
ground.	481.67330368045526
D’Artagnan was not one of those foolhardy men who seek a ridiculous	444.3530452438414
death in order that it may be said of them that they did not retreat a	471.4110916038435
single step. Besides, courage was out of the question here; D’Artagnan	388.32989099349766
had fallen into an ambush.	407.8563473434299
“If there is a third shot,” said he to himself, “I am a lost man.”	392.33068764485233
He immediately, therefore, took to his heels and ran toward the camp,	476.4381694235664
with the swiftness of the young men of his country, so renowned for	383.67915398186904
their agility; but whatever might be his speed, the first who fired,	298.58745009169945
having had time to reload, fired a second shot, and this time so well	440.056917390486
aimed that it struck his hat, and carried it ten paces from him.	413.96320886506896
As he, however, had no other hat, he picked up this as he ran, and	329.2161248774147
arrived at his quarters very pale and quite out of breath. He sat down	405.64532498449216
without saying a word to anybody, and began to reflect.	297.52765625322655
This event might have three causes:	471.21504619161254
The first and the most natural was that it might be an ambuscade of the	344.4625516709843
Rochellais, who might not be sorry to kill one of his Majesty’s Guards,	304.7617121588363
because it would be an enemy the less, and this enemy might have a	421.08658801369364
well-furnished purse in his pocket.	413.8433844756518
D’Artagnan took his hat, examined the hole made by the ball, and shook	455.6093258988151
his head. The ball was not a musket ball—it was an arquebus ball. The	325.5617432401167
accuracy of the aim had first given him the idea that a special weapon	485.5831332390035
had been employed. This could not, then, be a military ambuscade, as	391.38738675161886
the ball was not of the regular caliber.	348.8515767685124
This might be a kind remembrance of Monsieur the Cardinal. It may be	436.73843491277466
observed that at the very moment when, thanks to the ray of the sun, he	489.1863115383487
perceived the gun barrel, he was thinking with astonishment on the	296.666205769979
forbearance of his Eminence with respect to him.	360.68575960234034
But D’Artagnan again shook his head. For people toward whom he had but	442.57700790687886
to put forth his hand, his Eminence had rarely recourse to such means.	454.846866612731
It might be a vengeance of Milady; that was most probable.	330.0382877267876
He tried in vain to remember the faces or dress of the assassins; he	415.71655107498304
had escaped so rapidly that he had not had leisure to notice anything.	382.61241716130826
“Ah, my poor friends!” murmured D’Artagnan; “where are you? And that	327.56683034381115
you should fail me!”	292.0683492575741
D’Artagnan passed a very bad night. Three or four times he started up,	433.65442784279946
imagining that a man was approaching his bed for the purpose of	419.9721489477049
stabbing him. Nevertheless, day dawned without darkness having brought	336.8018406630639
any accident.	429.2311168141669
But D’Artagnan well suspected that that which was deferred was not	299.10898141977697
relinquished.	438.69102694437044
D’Artagnan remained all day in his quarters, assigning as a reason to	449.24151961332063
himself that the weather was bad.	339.74375095013505
At nine o’clock the next morning, the drums beat to arms. The Duc	452.0520398325116
d’Orléans visited the posts. The guards were under arms, and D’Artagnan	402.4515782142872
took his place in the midst of his comrades.	489.31905952503837
Monsieur passed along the front of the line; then all the superior	405.76471971354545
officers approached him to pay their compliments, M. Dessessart,	447.4578308812488
captain of the Guards, as well as the others.	405.5062913873524
At the expiration of a minute or two, it appeared to D’Artagnan that M.	385.1474162888528
Dessessart made him a sign to approach. He waited for a fresh gesture	459.8933810553579
on the part of his superior, for fear he might be mistaken; but this	300.11849739174176
gesture being repeated, he left the ranks, and advanced to receive	431.63599344856084
orders.	301.01789871547226
“Monsieur is about to ask for some men of good will for a dangerous	390.9446182855917
mission, but one which will do honor to those who shall accomplish it;	325.41710120906015
and I made you a sign in order that you might hold yourself in	371.18620940860785
readiness.”	487.8876852010046
“Thanks, my captain!” replied D’Artagnan, who wished for nothing better	419.44470058482574
than an opportunity to distinguish himself under the eye of the	342.56712438325826
lieutenant general.	328.4728572635591
In fact the Rochellais had made a _sortie_ during the night, and had	424.0653014404655
retaken a bastion of which the royal army had gained possession two	318.3182514132901
days before. The matter was to ascertain, by reconnoitering, how the	354.1816655055908
enemy guarded this bastion.	354.6512043675883
At the end of a few minutes Monsieur raised his voice, and said, “I	461.019118382657
want for this mission three or four volunteers, led by a man who can be	346.7931778149504
depended upon.”	457.47091031471007
“As to the man to be depended upon, I have him under my hand,	447.2834885341804
monsieur,” said M. Dessessart, pointing to D’Artagnan; “and as to the	468.0355786204693
four or five volunteers, Monsieur has but to make his intentions known,	488.77850052258617
and the men will not be wanting.”	385.9806025706431
“Four men of good will who will risk being killed with me!” said	296.08525478913236
D’Artagnan, raising his sword.	462.46664298893734
Two of his comrades of the Guards immediately sprang forward, and two	371.50320143482793
other soldiers having joined them, the number was deemed sufficient.	444.08132417152876
D’Artagnan declined all others, being unwilling to take the first	339.66390235816965
chance from those who had the priority.	426.7282232000722
It was not known whether, after the taking of the bastion, the	389.63687823383714
Rochellais had evacuated it or left a garrison in it; the object then	348.7460965243916
was to examine the place near enough to verify the reports.	333.5941419436873
D’Artagnan set out with his four companions, and followed the trench;	326.2905822453614
the two Guards marched abreast with him, and the two soldiers followed	379.2907472116658
behind.	326.42050185782443
They arrived thus, screened by the lining of the trench, till they came	407.65865349059266
within a hundred paces of the bastion. There, on turning round,	316.3035155382326
D’Artagnan perceived that the two soldiers had disappeared.	420.2625584711485
He thought that, beginning to be afraid, they had stayed behind, and he	398.89474162262604
continued to advance.	488.4880583512227
At the turning of the counterscarp they found themselves within about	407.83210532237564
sixty paces of the bastion. They saw no one, and the bastion seemed	473.0384486998737
abandoned.	427.5341771338068
The three composing our forlorn hope were deliberating whether they	338.9235703760211
should proceed any further, when all at once a circle of smoke	316.0124523073833
enveloped the giant of stone, and a dozen balls came whistling around	484.53711777824503
D’Artagnan and his companions.	346.2816108283005
They knew all they wished to know; the bastion was guarded. A longer	350.08091356801754
stay in this dangerous spot would have been useless imprudence.	469.22210241536925
D’Artagnan and his two companions turned their backs, and commenced a	465.0868925642055
retreat which resembled a flight.	316.8251355401182
On arriving at the angle of the trench which was to serve them as a	364.70807218807596
rampart, one of the Guardsmen fell. A ball had passed through his	307.9750392678859
breast. The other, who was safe and sound, continued his way toward the	443.85469498302473
camp.	439.0951616606974
D’Artagnan was not willing to abandon his companion thus, and stooped	426.6498109175305
to raise him and assist him in regaining the lines; but at this moment	420.21596724321097
two shots were fired. One ball struck the head of the already-wounded	373.2753586312197
guard, and the other flattened itself against a rock, after having	407.2486461348008
passed within two inches of D’Artagnan.	355.96932031403236
The young man turned quickly round, for this attack could not have come	345.0913942075538
from the bastion, which was hidden by the angle of the trench. The idea	461.37445786965986
of the two soldiers who had abandoned him occurred to his mind, and	424.0717090653993
with them he remembered the assassins of two evenings before. He	382.3947713574352
resolved this time to know with whom he had to deal, and fell upon the	343.53543679648266
body of his comrade as if he were dead.	324.8925648544116
He quickly saw two heads appear above an abandoned work within thirty	346.1219561125896
paces of him; they were the heads of the two soldiers. D’Artagnan had	376.73945830458194
not been deceived; these two men had only followed for the purpose of	349.985841763233
assassinating him, hoping that the young man’s death would be placed to	410.8309559118877
the account of the enemy.	474.3877350416841
As he might be only wounded and might denounce their crime, they came	355.23540860966637
up to him with the purpose of making sure. Fortunately, deceived by	376.028825565848
D’Artagnan’s trick, they neglected to reload their guns.	313.27044097932327
When they were within ten paces of him, D’Artagnan, who in falling had	385.768650938046
taken care not to let go his sword, sprang up close to them.	320.1719356599375
The assassins comprehended that if they fled toward the camp without	369.0242308107048
having killed their man, they should be accused by him; therefore their	477.9777341301914
first idea was to join the enemy. One of them took his gun by the	326.4782905840909
barrel, and used it as he would a club. He aimed a terrible blow at	308.0714537857979
D’Artagnan, who avoided it by springing to one side; but by this	442.8166352912098
movement he left a passage free to the bandit, who darted off toward	393.16290607722357
the bastion. As the Rochellais who guarded the bastion were ignorant of	415.4763299561604
the intentions of the man they saw coming toward them, they fired upon	468.43224166281084
him, and he fell, struck by a ball which broke his shoulder.	373.35338954839756
Meantime D’Artagnan had thrown himself upon the other soldier,	357.60469333973793
attacking him with his sword. The conflict was not long; the wretch had	300.2419701245526
nothing to defend himself with but his discharged arquebus. The sword	312.83120020640104
of the Guardsman slipped along the barrel of the now-useless weapon,	411.8374786592599
and passed through the thigh of the assassin, who fell.	475.4776288321724
D’Artagnan immediately placed the point of his sword at his throat.	385.3335402849365
“Oh, do not kill me!” cried the bandit. “Pardon, pardon, my officer,	342.02896193324284
and I will tell you all.”	318.4294502538823
“Is your secret of enough importance to me to spare your life for it?”	386.6978774703733
asked the young man, withholding his arm.	314.41372837321984
“Yes; if you think existence worth anything to a man of twenty, as you	469.1767973768675
are, and who may hope for everything, being handsome and brave, as you	491.5142719619136
are.”	333.8460005144775
“Wretch,” cried D’Artagnan, “speak quickly! Who employed you to	448.0348523385118
assassinate me?”	439.1021175007297
“A woman whom I don’t know, but who is called Milady.”	397.3118760860227
“But if you don’t know this woman, how do you know her name?”	371.8531376323553
“My comrade knows her, and called her so. It was with him she agreed,	403.33205765744253
and not with me; he even has in his pocket a letter from that person,	464.73584109326873
who attaches great importance to you, as I have heard him say.”	330.534190435699
“But how did you become concerned in this villainous affair?”	393.5081345205365
“He proposed to me to undertake it with him, and I agreed.”	380.0113555265515
“And how much did she give you for this fine enterprise?”	294.47463426365977
“A hundred louis.”	407.31987217886984
“Well, come!” said the young man, laughing, “she thinks I am worth	383.2563050938183
something. A hundred louis? Well, that was a temptation for two	386.77422739979016
wretches like you. I understand why you accepted it, and I grant you my	357.5641269207699
pardon; but upon one condition.”	481.0590950220014
“What is that?” said the soldier, uneasy at perceiving that all was not	318.7727789226772
over.	382.8117230830227
“That you will go and fetch me the letter your comrade has in his	433.37611621365477
pocket.”	470.1989753247017
“But,” cried the bandit, “that is only another way of killing me. How	379.6830040964462
can I go and fetch that letter under the fire of the bastion?”	339.5917576268802
“You must nevertheless make up your mind to go and get it, or I swear	422.9810836049783
you shall die by my hand.”	420.9510293773146
“Pardon, monsieur; pity! In the name of that young lady you love, and	373.5524837029716
whom you perhaps believe dead but who is not!” cried the bandit,	398.8774036496325
throwing himself upon his knees and leaning upon his hand—for he began	434.22152641078617
to lose his strength with his blood.	310.4042973680868
“And how do you know there is a young woman whom I love, and that I	350.5011531550998
believed that woman dead?” asked D’Artagnan.	392.7235718791393
“By that letter which my comrade has in his pocket.”	398.0916519967862
“You see, then,” said D’Artagnan, “that I must have that letter. So no	319.7012059914516
more delay, no more hesitation; or else whatever may be my repugnance	405.1334912699057
to soiling my sword a second time with the blood of a wretch like you,	450.8823114326552
I swear by my faith as an honest man—” and at these words D’Artagnan	427.5799859965978
made so fierce a gesture that the wounded man sprang up.	463.812041841265
“Stop, stop!” cried he, regaining strength by force of terror. “I will	341.53699318048723
go—I will go!”	456.2925023137379
D’Artagnan took the soldier’s arquebus, made him go on before him, and	357.646822088815
urged him toward his companion by pricking him behind with his sword.	297.61032255030614
It was a frightful thing to see this wretch, leaving a long track of	448.6724534725414
blood on the ground he passed over, pale with approaching death, trying	387.28147463583804
to drag himself along without being seen to the body of his accomplice,	478.98202764230575
which lay twenty paces from him.	301.472237872065
Terror was so strongly painted on his face, covered with a cold sweat,	334.5276085236107
that D’Artagnan took pity on him, and casting upon him a look of	377.1905817989201
contempt, “Stop,” said he, “I will show you the difference between a	425.4506964829654
man of courage and such a coward as you. Stay where you are; I will go	428.6021929970744
myself.”	371.5070723930718
And with a light step, an eye on the watch, observing the movements of	445.82313693336323
the enemy and taking advantage of the accidents of the ground,	396.1966887309071
D’Artagnan succeeded in reaching the second soldier.	461.87982541735846
There were two means of gaining his object—to search him on the spot,	327.04675154371984
or to carry him away, making a buckler of his body, and search him in	482.5879920264201
the trench.	298.86101562344
D’Artagnan preferred the second means, and lifted the assassin onto his	351.8198278928877
shoulders at the moment the enemy fired.	363.15703289045206
A slight shock, the dull noise of three balls which penetrated the	390.36440287466075
flesh, a last cry, a convulsion of agony, proved to D’Artagnan that the	327.39401480718675
would-be assassin had saved his life.	419.44579313080396
D’Artagnan regained the trench, and threw the corpse beside the wounded	481.0092412804337
man, who was as pale as death.	474.47335491503975
Then he began to search. A leather pocketbook, a purse, in which was	327.3216781787559
evidently a part of the sum which the bandit had received, with a dice	423.4865557008357
box and dice, completed the possessions of the dead man.	442.49203166295104
He left the box and dice where they fell, threw the purse to the	475.2205646664131
wounded man, and eagerly opened the pocketbook.	384.8937123164483
Among some unimportant papers he found the following letter, that which	468.15127918105645
he had sought at the risk of his life:	485.949476326667
“Since you have lost sight of that woman and she is now in safety in	369.4496245605728
the convent, which you should never have allowed her to reach, try, at	431.02227526798686
least, not to miss the man. If you do, you know that my hand stretches	421.8962926935881
far, and that you shall pay very dearly for the hundred louis you have	479.3007911747565
from me.”	360.7432507412898
No signature. Nevertheless it was plain the letter came from Milady. He	312.33165899976683
consequently kept it as a piece of evidence, and being in safety behind	463.0611368908759
the angle of the trench, he began to interrogate the wounded man. He	377.5648479465717
confessed that he had undertaken with his comrade—the same who was	409.44659842340366
killed—to carry off a young woman who was to leave Paris by the	335.46850825941954
Barrière de La Villette; but having stopped to drink at a cabaret, they	365.1541226495781
had missed the carriage by ten minutes.	434.3690419513139
“But what were you to do with that woman?” asked D’Artagnan, with	457.4752520275169
anguish.	490.60037661637614
“We were to have conveyed her to a hôtel in the Place Royale,” said the	374.55968410028856
wounded man.	454.7857448430534
“Yes, yes!” murmured D’Artagnan; “that’s the place—Milady’s own	394.97198809890017
residence!”	431.60751229761104
Then the young man tremblingly comprehended what a terrible thirst for	348.61615507853526
vengeance urged this woman on to destroy him, as well as all who loved	440.6368513884105
him, and how well she must be acquainted with the affairs of the court,	314.1874244952281
since she had discovered all. There could be no doubt she owed this	292.7660363852726
information to the cardinal.	478.4627473848381
But amid all this he perceived, with a feeling of real joy, that the	378.9751018487672
queen must have discovered the prison in which poor Mme. Bonacieux was	415.00291897741334
explaining her devotion, and that she had freed her from that prison;	482.8296612678257
and the letter he had received from the young woman, and her passage	348.45999752464115
along the road of Chaillot like an apparition, were now explained.	428.9451267273363
Then also, as Athos had predicted, it became possible to find Mme.	315.6550967068995
Bonacieux, and a convent was not impregnable.	367.5989201724765
This idea completely restored clemency to his heart. He turned toward	454.93495975115354
the wounded man, who had watched with intense anxiety all the various	370.98923238255435
expressions of his countenance, and holding out his arm to him, said,	402.35476984601576
“Come, I will not abandon you thus. Lean upon me, and let us return to	300.781930180928
the camp.”	479.6864318226296
“Yes,” said the man, who could scarcely believe in such magnanimity,	433.60671141672935
“but is it not to have me hanged?”	423.2060895372361
“You have my word,” said he; “for the second time I give you your	372.93259879565755
life.”	463.1217169000297
The wounded man sank upon his knees, to again kiss the feet of his	438.9112358035769
preserver; but D’Artagnan, who had no longer a motive for staying so	315.4791590202434
near the enemy, abridged the testimonials of his gratitude.	444.5346591462487
The Guardsman who had returned at the first discharge announced the	374.71031891317176
death of his four companions. They were therefore much astonished and	359.70554720489315
delighted in the regiment when they saw the young man come back safe	382.48195288699253
and sound.	447.07432421755107
D’Artagnan explained the sword wound of his companion by a _sortie_	434.7047467938198
which he improvised. He described the death of the other soldier, and	365.25985944950963
the perils they had encountered. This recital was for him the occasion	361.6987405184565
of veritable triumph. The whole army talked of this expedition for a	489.56227502082334
day, and Monsieur paid him his compliments upon it. Besides this, as	322.48708354366397
every great action bears its recompense with it, the brave exploit of	356.2950034813597
D’Artagnan resulted in the restoration of the tranquility he had lost.	330.49709706733836
In fact, D’Artagnan believed that he might be tranquil, as one of his	379.4912507690457
two enemies was killed and the other devoted to his interests.	469.75856934201795
This tranquillity proved one thing—that D’Artagnan did not yet know	294.9756183071887
Milady.	451.23553613741
Chapter XLII.	421.5088981759971
THE ANJOU WINE	372.3261569123722
After the most disheartening news of the king’s health, a report of his	428.79623170754405
convalescence began to prevail in the camp; and as he was very anxious	459.64946655383835
to be in person at the siege, it was said that as soon as he could	488.46479812633925
mount a horse he would set forward.	304.76380509248133
Meantime, Monsieur, who knew that from one day to the other he might	472.5060138059041
expect to be removed from his command by the Duc d’Angoulême, by	337.1809504749118
Bassompierre, or by Schomberg, who were all eager for his post, did but	360.0066474554757
little, lost his days in wavering, and did not dare to attempt any	336.2277349980068
great enterprise to drive the English from the Isle of Ré, where they	473.59142176697696
still besieged the citadel St. Martin and the fort of La Prée, as on	294.61260743635165
their side the French were besieging La Rochelle.	479.9397543543263
D’Artagnan, as we have said, had become more tranquil, as always	488.9144935826893
happens after a past danger, particularly when the danger seems to have	483.1183527536866
vanished. He only felt one uneasiness, and that was at not hearing any	364.24427436177996
tidings from his friends.	354.8908976265504
But one morning at the commencement of the month of November everything	306.7740306914193
was explained to him by this letter, dated from Villeroy:	381.46626243120016
M. D’ARTAGNAN, MM. Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, after having had an	455.161688992049
entertainment at my house and enjoying themselves very much, created	463.74247615348634
such a disturbance that the provost of the castle, a rigid man, has	446.2918830541002
ordered them to be confined for some days; but I accomplish the order	409.7129453405737
they have given me by forwarding to you a dozen bottles of my Anjou	469.92351781051775
wine, with which they are much pleased. They are desirous that you	297.6585900494721
should drink to their health in their favorite wine. I have done this,	446.14226864170746
and am, monsieur, with great respect,	366.16164782661235
Your very humble and obedient servant,	378.494077519202
GODEAU, _Purveyor of the Musketeers_	359.27443108715863
“That’s all well!” cried D’Artagnan. “They think of me in their	339.67725576797676
pleasures, as I thought of them in my troubles. Well, I will certainly	312.1835282957327
drink to their health with all my heart, but I will not drink alone.”	382.16934213153894
And D’Artagnan went among those Guardsmen with whom he had formed	405.97989068598054
greater intimacy than with the others, to invite them to enjoy with him	351.3227568390918
this present of delicious Anjou wine which had been sent him from	479.6740251865139
Villeroy.	352.86682909751266
One of the two Guardsmen was engaged that evening, and another the	453.9602746653479
next, so the meeting was fixed for the day after that.	377.8137539348837
D’Artagnan, on his return, sent the twelve bottles of wine to the	303.8411383420031
refreshment room of the Guards, with strict orders that great care	428.459082466757
should be taken of it; and then, on the day appointed, as the dinner	344.87892304128985
was fixed for midday D’Artagnan sent Planchet at nine in the morning to	474.6664818698807
assist in preparing everything for the entertainment.	466.5822012141695
Planchet, very proud of being raised to the dignity of landlord,	399.7581437633402
thought he would make all ready, like an intelligent man; and with this	442.47128228937083
view called in the assistance of the lackey of one of his master’s	404.27686088955795
guests, named Fourreau, and the false soldier who had tried to kill	451.8264450667943
D’Artagnan and who, belonging to no corps, had entered into the service	333.0916231086817
of D’Artagnan, or rather of Planchet, after D’Artagnan had saved his	345.1448957133108
life.	294.8199642446791
The hour of the banquet being come, the two guards arrived, took their	369.6311326896924
places, and the dishes were arranged on the table. Planchet waited,	444.2546547415517
towel on arm; Fourreau uncorked the bottles; and Brisemont, which was	312.0159734866728
the name of the convalescent, poured the wine, which was a little	487.7930769125393
shaken by its journey, carefully into decanters. Of this wine, the	380.06004935067085
first bottle being a little thick at the bottom, Brisemont poured the	340.2153505816615
lees into a glass, and D’Artagnan desired him to drink it, for the poor	428.2622046349037
devil had not yet recovered his strength.	377.25397135950953
The guests having eaten the soup, were about to lift the first glass of	480.2645730192519
wine to their lips, when all at once the cannon sounded from Fort Louis	466.3926333687557
and Fort Neuf. The Guardsmen, imagining this to be caused by some	388.4459950506555
unexpected attack, either of the besieged or the English, sprang to	385.4544671206927
their swords. D’Artagnan, not less forward than they, did likewise, and	316.1873067962961
all ran out, in order to repair to their posts.	305.5836191532565
But scarcely were they out of the room before they were made aware of	443.92702710054095
the cause of this noise. Cries of “Live the king! Live the cardinal!”	485.3919120849305
resounded on every side, and the drums were beaten in all directions.	431.54840247666493
In short, the king, impatient, as has been said, had come by forced	385.0842362768535
marches, and had that moment arrived with all his household and a	341.38677591035946
reinforcement of ten thousand troops. His Musketeers proceeded and	464.1185272299761
followed him. D’Artagnan, placed in line with his company, saluted with	304.0077923001642
an expressive gesture his three friends, whose eyes soon discovered	317.95487006179695
him, and M. de Tréville, who detected him at once.	418.60294216936245
The ceremony of reception over, the four friends were soon in one	484.2602014281622
another’s arms.	419.0758794573105
“_Pardieu!_” cried D’Artagnan, “you could not have arrived in better	424.6035980633591
time; the dinner cannot have had time to get cold! Can it, gentlemen?”	436.7928071695761
added the young man, turning to the two Guards, whom he introduced to	477.76516837137063
his friends.	456.8683483553787
“Ah, ah!” said Porthos, “it appears we are feasting!”	343.29631883734623
“I hope,” said Aramis, “there are no women at your dinner.”	491.20060611948804
“Is there any drinkable wine in your tavern?” asked Athos.	294.16188734566884
“Well, _pardieu!_ there is yours, my dear friend,” replied D’Artagnan.	329.50752436092847
“Our wine!” said Athos, astonished.	449.26701089275286
“Yes, that you sent me.”	454.77781130167784
“We sent you wine?”	448.25961385684604
“You know very well—the wine from the hills of Anjou.”	380.79848379438147
“Yes, I know what brand you are talking about.”	483.90242336321035
“The wine you prefer.”	367.3873870050143
“Well, in the absence of champagne and chambertin, you must content	452.70445040438517
yourselves with that.”	368.51127796885214
“And so, connoisseurs in wine as we are, we have sent you some Anjou	435.91870287396955
wine?” said Porthos.	370.694568027182
“Not exactly, it is the wine that was sent by your order.”	369.9842907486319
“On our account?” said the three Musketeers.	308.2577957334295
“Did you send this wine, Aramis?” said Athos.	314.72076371298806
“No; and you, Porthos?”	489.120755732947
“No; and you, Athos?”	424.7657882973901
“No!”	487.46486530082274
“If it was not you, it was your purveyor,” said D’Artagnan.	359.5589495064351
“Our purveyor!”	376.34050887503105
“Yes, your purveyor, Godeau—the purveyor of the Musketeers.”	450.8647367719392
“My faith! never mind where it comes from,” said Porthos, “let us taste	471.7522993811946
it, and if it is good, let us drink it.”	446.38715735382425
“No,” said Athos; “don’t let us drink wine which comes from an unknown	381.089946359204
source.”	408.2518992907327
“You are right, Athos,” said D’Artagnan. “Did none of you charge your	463.76467967785754
purveyor, Godeau, to send me some wine?”	321.58978963940064
“No! And yet you say he has sent you some as from us?”	396.85942985160113
“Here is his letter,” said D’Artagnan, and he presented the note to his	475.7418829495998
comrades.	478.58806605699107
“This is not his writing!” said Athos. “I am acquainted with it; before	428.0348058581378
we left Villeroy I settled the accounts of the regiment.”	425.8489431322886
“A false letter altogether,” said Porthos, “we have not been	325.2203597818237
disciplined.”	344.9600003290715
“D’Artagnan,” said Aramis, in a reproachful tone, “how could you	449.14329949294483
believe that we had made a disturbance?”	366.13489950410576
D’Artagnan grew pale, and a convulsive trembling shook all his limbs.	339.4404534384631
“Thou alarmest me!” said Athos, who never used _thee_ and _thou_ but	475.87790654732413
upon very particular occasions, “what has happened?”	359.5542595302658
“Look you, my friends!” cried D’Artagnan, “a horrible suspicion crosses	427.99534503002434
my mind! Can this be another vengeance of that woman?”	471.41024366606257
It was now Athos who turned pale.	424.5283701794765
D’Artagnan rushed toward the refreshment room, the three Musketeers and	293.9486063359546
the two Guards following him.	415.33444400381444
The first object that met the eyes of D’Artagnan on entering the room	373.2820984973015
was Brisemont, stretched upon the ground and rolling in horrible	486.2952887403113
convulsions.	403.08668975780523
Planchet and Fourreau, as pale as death, were trying to give him	491.2653408243964
succor; but it was plain that all assistance was useless—all the	356.7125253744301
features of the dying man were distorted with agony.	293.26717832471627
“Ah!” cried he, on perceiving D’Artagnan, “ah! this is frightful! You	478.4686070357536
pretend to pardon me, and you poison me!”	448.2497030768931
“I!” cried D’Artagnan. “I, wretch? What do you say?”	491.163145638217
“I say that it was you who gave me the wine; I say that it was you who	376.7685211039758
desired me to drink it. I say you wished to avenge yourself on me, and	411.1624673973788
I say that it is horrible!”	458.5804173825643
“Do not think so, Brisemont,” said D’Artagnan; “do not think so. I	359.63112855148296
swear to you, I protest—”	389.5582886921534
“Oh, but God is above! God will punish you! My God, grant that he may	445.88202317006346
one day suffer what I suffer!”	463.4336257936533
“Upon the Gospel,” said D’Artagnan, throwing himself down by the dying	454.12755503042945
man, “I swear to you that the wine was poisoned and that I was going to	396.97573746187015
drink of it as you did.”	477.11172073371887
“I do not believe you,” cried the soldier, and he expired amid horrible	343.1767853178997
tortures.	330.28956423088886
“Frightful! frightful!” murmured Athos, while Porthos broke the bottles	421.83570804469593
and Aramis gave orders, a little too late, that a confessor should be	413.5913740169348
sent for.	433.7728105625794
“Oh, my friends,” said D’Artagnan, “you come once more to save my life,	442.34228960152564
not only mine but that of these gentlemen. Gentlemen,” continued he,	387.268357451763
addressing the Guardsmen, “I request you will be silent with regard to	483.9713280582503
this adventure. Great personages may have had a hand in what you have	452.8679966952825
seen, and if talked about, the evil would only recoil upon us.”	306.3642861020848
“Ah, monsieur!” stammered Planchet, more dead than alive, “ah,	430.92737728731834
monsieur, what an escape I have had!”	293.7143839543858
“How, sirrah! you were going to drink my wine?”	457.59092096041445
“To the health of the king, monsieur; I was going to drink a small	342.0378853146536
glass of it if Fourreau had not told me I was called.”	319.21578370968234
“Alas!” said Fourreau, whose teeth chattered with terror, “I wanted to	463.3644873654265
get him out of the way that I might drink myself.”	436.15963929299255
“Gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, addressing the Guardsmen, “you may easily	418.7280160851006
comprehend that such a feast can only be very dull after what has taken	304.64648760238754
place; so accept my excuses, and put off the party till another day, I	393.18238491769205
beg of you.”	427.44642489859416
The two Guardsmen courteously accepted D’Artagnan’s excuses, and	384.2218430816142
perceiving that the four friends desired to be alone, retired.	337.0077924009317
When the young Guardsman and the three Musketeers were without	346.99122798920786
witnesses, they looked at one another with an air which plainly	490.5249375139086
expressed that each of them perceived the gravity of their situation.	451.49827106068574
“In the first place,” said Athos, “let us leave this chamber; the dead	450.4183610521104
are not agreeable company, particularly when they have died a violent	449.0101378487928
death.”	368.424234103659
“Planchet,” said D’Artagnan, “I commit the corpse of this poor devil to	436.8877116364623
your care. Let him be interred in holy ground. He committed a crime, it	434.1684619237003
is true; but he repented of it.”	340.553073903143
And the four friends quit the room, leaving to Planchet and Fourreau	459.76752894400306
the duty of paying mortuary honors to Brisemont.	343.6329750348206
The host gave them another chamber, and served them with fresh eggs and	441.6575843513725
some water, which Athos went himself to draw at the fountain. In a few	319.78417203048315
words, Porthos and Aramis were posted as to the situation.	330.8205717898436
“Well,” said D’Artagnan to Athos, “you see, my dear friend, that this	438.986703185694
is war to the death.”	334.84940816629916
Athos shook his head.	300.3576503704357
“Yes, yes,” replied he, “I perceive that plainly; but do you really	368.13360495788254
believe it is she?”	311.770338707326
“I am sure of it.”	335.34920255067726
“Nevertheless, I confess I still doubt.”	306.22465389717115
“But the _fleur-de-lis_ on her shoulder?”	417.5205824103629
“She is some Englishwoman who has committed a crime in France, and has	479.81438208418024
been branded in consequence.”	403.95180493693726
“Athos, she is your wife, I tell you,” repeated D’Artagnan; “only	366.44390423296653
reflect how much the two descriptions resemble each other.”	373.07530676042336
“Yes; but I should think the other must be dead, I hanged her so	381.36790011219557
effectually.”	310.92674534101064
It was D’Artagnan who now shook his head in his turn.	436.9582236049013
“But in either case, what is to be done?” said the young man.	405.72144731098126
“The fact is, one cannot remain thus, with a sword hanging eternally	399.89192689527204
over his head,” said Athos. “We must extricate ourselves from this	346.2387625221839
position.”	301.65556300564225
“But how?”	384.1540822027297
“Listen! You must try to see her, and have an explanation with her. Say	392.947675078465
to her: ‘Peace or war! My word as a gentleman never to say anything of	469.0194833131191
you, never to do anything against you; on your side, a solemn oath to	319.4680490871491
remain neutral with respect to me. If not, I will apply to the	413.81586862639693
chancellor, I will apply to the king, I will apply to the hangman, I	344.1245034894546
will move the courts against you, I will denounce you as branded, I	420.3868609411137
will bring you to trial; and if you are acquitted, well, by the faith	306.0752954173817
of a gentleman, I will kill you at the corner of some wall, as I would	403.563772209005
a mad dog.’”	343.14661400129546
“I like the means well enough,” said D’Artagnan, “but where and how to	308.27092059296285
meet with her?”	366.49587415924077
“Time, dear friend, time brings round opportunity; opportunity is the	450.9445357788342
martingale of man. The more we have ventured the more we gain, when we	468.16214388859265
know how to wait.”	471.5163703940244
“Yes; but to wait surrounded by assassins and poisoners.”	474.8240653627913
“Bah!” said Athos. “God has preserved us hitherto, God will preserve us	386.38477997546863
still.”	321.56190631883703
“Yes, we. Besides, we are men; and everything considered, it is our lot	412.71344256194556
to risk our lives; but _she_,” asked he, in an undertone.	462.16015431008015
“What she?” asked Athos.	367.06160370361295
“Constance.”	419.4945633392206
“Madame Bonacieux! Ah, that’s true!” said Athos. “My poor friend, I had	467.2689814297413
forgotten you were in love.”	377.4729790414282
“Well, but,” said Aramis, “have you not learned by the letter you found	355.03658565653075
on the wretched corpse that she is in a convent? One may be very	442.5394248740419
comfortable in a convent; and as soon as the siege of La Rochelle is	441.86180022251926
terminated, I promise you on my part—”	377.45547267187834
“Good,” cried Athos, “good! Yes, my dear Aramis, we all know that your	442.89930763743087
views have a religious tendency.”	401.03664484588575
“I am only temporarily a Musketeer,” said Aramis, humbly.	356.40148925516735
“It is some time since we heard from his mistress,” said Athos, in a	320.6858324568321
low voice. “But take no notice; we know all about that.”	315.02873501513756
“Well,” said Porthos, “it appears to me that the means are very	332.0992176068013
simple.”	294.77877735265054
“What?” asked D’Artagnan.	467.40512297217253
“You say she is in a convent?” replied Porthos.	301.50552691441715
“Yes.”	388.3567777523452
“Very well. As soon as the siege is over, we’ll carry her off from that	316.945853575313
convent.”	344.516674378053
“But we must first learn what convent she is in.”	317.21512173189547
“That’s true,” said Porthos.	402.0789184579473
“But I think I have it,” said Athos. “Don’t you say, dear D’Artagnan,	484.1295172241915
that it is the queen who has made choice of the convent for her?”	321.97038188806926
“I believe so, at least.”	477.588847904978
“In that case Porthos will assist us.”	353.9356548151306
“And how so, if you please?”	442.3091288050366
“Why, by your marchioness, your duchess, your princess. She must have a	352.35077610465885
long arm.”	342.03367046104665
“Hush!” said Porthos, placing a finger on his lips. “I believe her to	337.33736538053984
be a cardinalist; she must know nothing of the matter.”	476.030436991738
“Then,” said Aramis, “I take upon myself to obtain intelligence of	365.5283645789321
her.”	318.56101059018545
“You, Aramis?” cried the three friends. “You! And how?”	344.56313833530555
“By the queen’s almoner, to whom I am very intimately allied,” said	376.30133909896495
Aramis, coloring.	384.8182280183229
And on this assurance, the four friends, who had finished their modest	445.8698413806321
repast, separated, with the promise of meeting again that evening.	328.6022886072684
D’Artagnan returned to less important affairs, and the three Musketeers	472.2113687607346
repaired to the king’s quarters, where they had to prepare their	297.77676751870155
lodging.	408.8414815021947
Chapter XLIII.	381.8216359767696
THE SIGN OF THE RED DOVECOT	459.4117332322779
Meanwhile the king, who, with more reason than the cardinal, showed his	472.486072495406
hatred for Buckingham, although scarcely arrived was in such a haste to	456.46103504300027
meet the enemy that he commanded every disposition to be made to drive	301.57622329690014
the English from the Isle of Ré, and afterward to press the siege of La	464.4411727937784
Rochelle; but notwithstanding his earnest wish, he was delayed by the	342.8039057356002
dissensions which broke out between MM. Bassompierre and Schomberg,	312.53550370705375
against the Duc d’Angoulême.	425.69937440822775
MM. Bassompierre and Schomberg were marshals of France, and claimed	335.0106582119272
their right of commanding the army under the orders of the king; but	417.86738843216705
the cardinal, who feared that Bassompierre, a Huguenot at heart, might	413.3420936463996
press but feebly the English and Rochellais, his brothers in religion,	295.81538011692817
supported the Duc d’Angoulême, whom the king, at his instigation, had	409.92208588455514
named lieutenant general. The result was that to prevent MM.	366.55259564135423
Bassompierre and Schomberg from deserting the army, a separate command	405.1333178396511
had to be given to each. Bassompierre took up his quarters on the north	337.13020964853945
of the city, between Leu and Dompierre; the Duc d’Angoulême on the	329.5377899107252
east, from Dompierre to Perigny; and M. de Schomberg on the south, from	421.8990875435902
Perigny to Angoutin.	346.0545688670742
The quarters of Monsieur were at Dompierre; the quarters of the king	312.01932900701274
were sometimes at Estrée, sometimes at Jarrie; the cardinal’s quarters	466.2473563264425
were upon the downs, at the bridge of La Pierre, in a simple house	389.46800644325276
without any entrenchment. So that Monsieur watched Bassompierre; the	462.7030984678752
king, the Duc d’Angoulême; and the cardinal, M. de Schomberg.	465.45652419771284
As soon as this organization was established, they set about driving	394.4542363932235
the English from the Isle.	485.6970318541761
The juncture was favorable. The English, who require, above everything,	292.48447539529906
good living in order to be good soldiers, only eating salt meat and bad	382.99888286034303
biscuit, had many invalids in their camp. Still further, the sea, very	402.76538545236446
rough at this period of the year all along the sea coast, destroyed	486.7389097932579
every day some little vessel; and the shore, from the point of	364.27405655682907
l’Aiguillon to the trenches, was at every tide literally covered with	381.4792130153895
the wrecks of pinnacles, _roberges_, and feluccas. The result was that	416.38068552897084
even if the king’s troops remained quietly in their camp, it was	338.5144933241511
evident that some day or other, Buckingham, who only continued in the	371.9192973615443
Isle from obstinacy, would be obliged to raise the siege.	363.14678071714485
But as M. de Toiras gave information that everything was preparing in	442.69219815800716
the enemy’s camp for a fresh assault, the king judged that it would be	292.75419254017015
best to put an end to the affair, and gave the necessary orders for a	345.59895067502623
decisive action.	406.29055319866075
As it is not our intention to give a journal of the siege, but on the	482.49626483059126
contrary only to describe such of the events of it as are connected	315.9082971622448
with the story we are relating, we will content ourselves with saying	402.0208342966879
in two words that the expedition succeeded, to the great astonishment	391.4535170360805
of the king and the great glory of the cardinal. The English, repulsed	406.40266174655096
foot by foot, beaten in all encounters, and defeated in the passage of	441.8202075185019
the Isle of Loie, were obliged to re-embark, leaving on the field of	382.61732063847614
battle two thousand men, among whom were five colonels, three	378.00804207495315
lieutenant colonels, two hundred and fifty captains, twenty gentlemen	408.4915299182446
of rank, four pieces of cannon, and sixty flags, which were taken to	367.2386405737904
Paris by Claude de St. Simon, and suspended with great pomp in the	468.8538609063137
arches of Notre Dame.	451.11511033472595
Te Deums were chanted in camp, and afterward throughout France.	477.0377688425076
The cardinal was left free to carry on the siege, without having, at	478.37964782572135
least at the present, anything to fear on the part of the English.	378.3581495890929
But it must be acknowledged, this response was but momentary. An envoy	451.4819876028304
of the Duke of Buckingham, named Montague, was taken, and proof was	319.3953605635215
obtained of a league between the German Empire, Spain, England, and	490.9153071667521
Lorraine. This league was directed against France.	302.4182677715279
Still further, in Buckingham’s lodging, which he had been forced to	336.689709571887
abandon more precipitately than he expected, papers were found which	322.0880043065679
confirmed this alliance and which, as the cardinal asserts in his	334.4634146915214
memoirs, strongly compromised Mme. de Chevreuse and consequently the	328.9666074015148
queen.	407.2429040350214
It was upon the cardinal that all the responsibility fell, for one is	427.10749807001116
not a despotic minister without responsibility. All, therefore, of the	489.2035934429834
vast resources of his genius were at work night and day, engaged in	318.4327386853624
listening to the least report heard in any of the great kingdoms of	436.3914588214486
Europe.	300.6977016697038
The cardinal was acquainted with the activity, and more particularly	387.3515301398442
the hatred, of Buckingham. If the league which threatened France	412.8380069839628
triumphed, all his influence would be lost. Spanish policy and Austrian	422.5875704951158
policy would have their representatives in the cabinet of the Louvre,	462.1150866891421
where they had as yet but partisans; and he, Richelieu—the French	334.61281982788586
minister, the national minister—would be ruined. The king, even while	400.8578838789565
obeying him like a child, hated him as a child hates his master, and	399.8042599753518
would abandon him to the personal vengeance of Monsieur and the queen.	422.7845424703782
He would then be lost, and France, perhaps, with him. All this must be	458.6306986747235
prepared against.	322.34589214107604
Courtiers, becoming every instant more numerous, succeeded one another,	442.8071717174256
day and night, in the little house of the bridge of La Pierre, in which	340.69386496879093
the cardinal had established his residence.	442.9942749988265
There were monks who wore the frock with such an ill grace that it was	484.5575087192075
easy to perceive they belonged to the church militant; women a little	426.65024552562403
inconvenienced by their costume as pages and whose large trousers could	474.1996279623774
not entirely conceal their rounded forms; and peasants with blackened	468.6025064933212
hands but with fine limbs, savoring of the man of quality a league off.	329.4117711687764
There were also less agreeable visits—for two or three times reports	372.15710391433544
were spread that the cardinal had nearly been assassinated.	491.0645185474408
It is true that the enemies of the cardinal said that it was he himself	357.3816494709733
who set these bungling assassins to work, in order to have, if wanted,	327.68497664584834
the right of using reprisals; but we must not believe everything	376.2866378203015
ministers say, nor everything their enemies say.	464.2844342064142
These attempts did not prevent the cardinal, to whom his most	417.85753537949097
inveterate detractors have never denied personal bravery, from making	420.5742618098953
nocturnal excursions, sometimes to communicate to the Duc d’Angoulême	349.8050780781694
important orders, sometimes to confer with the king, and sometimes to	412.70196165680676
have an interview with a messenger whom he did not wish to see at home.	301.86378733010287
On their part the Musketeers, who had not much to do with the siege,	403.184188510404
were not under very strict orders and led a joyous life. This was the	336.3575615505254
more easy for our three companions in particular; for being friends of	398.0983989791169
M. de Tréville, they obtained from him special permission to be absent	448.7512735147791
after the closing of the camp.	360.87374866217067
Now, one evening when D’Artagnan, who was in the trenches, was not able	413.1100422972407
to accompany them, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, mounted on their battle	351.13044825242525
steeds, enveloped in their war cloaks, with their hands upon their	346.2787700420008
pistol butts, were returning from a drinking place called the Red	374.7111359979574
Dovecot, which Athos had discovered two days before upon the route to	317.4812993529686
Jarrie, following the road which led to the camp and quite on their	330.28783387173655
guard, as we have stated, for fear of an ambuscade, when, about a	338.8925125445347
quarter of a league from the village of Boisnau, they fancied they	348.6441192273028
heard the sound of horses approaching them. They immediately all three	393.7878081572282
halted, closed in, and waited, occupying the middle of the road. In an	327.7898883998976
instant, and as the moon broke from behind a cloud, they saw at a	392.5095023123387
turning of the road two horsemen who, on perceiving them, stopped in	358.14091055560095
their turn, appearing to deliberate whether they should continue their	405.49712149756124
route or go back. The hesitation created some suspicion in the three	468.2537660993132
friends, and Athos, advancing a few paces in front of the others, cried	314.19183538866196
in a firm voice, “Who goes there?”	482.17766627060075
“Who goes there, yourselves?” replied one of the horsemen.	446.89394206129043
“That is not an answer,” replied Athos. “Who goes there? Answer, or we	387.4423437102787
charge.”	484.5108566662201
“Beware of what you are about, gentlemen!” said a clear voice which	394.14454104974516
seemed accustomed to command.	361.0867378632936
“It is some superior officer making his night rounds,” said Athos.	365.7785828755196
“What do you wish, gentlemen?”	398.59569905956556
“Who are you?” said the same voice, in the same commanding tone.	367.1287648471942
“Answer in your turn, or you may repent of your disobedience.”	348.06811380710434
“King’s Musketeers,” said Athos, more and more convinced that he who	402.1209441455541
interrogated them had the right to do so.	460.1310234336806
“What company?”	432.76801010135796
“Company of Tréville.”	328.06070519574723
“Advance, and give an account of what you are doing here at this hour.”	482.63041226175153
The three companions advanced rather humbly—for all were now convinced	456.28835689909613
that they had to do with someone more powerful than themselves—leaving	416.4782840325524
Athos the post of speaker.	314.8743834136745
One of the two riders, he who had spoken second, was ten paces in front	343.01828949073024
of his companion. Athos made a sign to Porthos and Aramis also to	317.46927302716415
remain in the rear, and advanced alone.	324.64312884316854
“Your pardon, my officer,” said Athos; “but we were ignorant with whom	336.1662717648586
we had to do, and you may see that we were keeping good guard.”	400.1473216984329
“Your name?” said the officer, who covered a part of his face with his	378.57611354884807
cloak.	485.35883174910873
“But yourself, monsieur,” said Athos, who began to be annoyed by this	434.7224875536431
inquisition, “give me, I beg you, the proof that you have the right to	315.78869452036685
question me.”	408.34042119231935
“Your name?” repeated the cavalier a second time, letting his cloak	486.8069703153793
fall, and leaving his face uncovered.	427.5212620752873
“Monsieur the Cardinal!” cried the stupefied Musketeer.	313.638012213147
“Your name?” cried his Eminence, for the third time.	481.9590937782614
“Athos,” said the Musketeer.	423.79897806422645
The cardinal made a sign to his attendant, who drew near. “These three	306.4760928806323
Musketeers shall follow us,” said he, in an undertone. “I am not	363.7173677195099
willing it should be known I have left the camp; and if they follow us	338.3624750118838
we shall be certain they will tell nobody.”	421.822850276204
“We are gentlemen, monseigneur,” said Athos; “require our parole, and	415.56556761833417
give yourself no uneasiness. Thank God, we can keep a secret.”	330.75776658392
The cardinal fixed his piercing eyes on this courageous speaker.	386.02862218790125
“You have a quick ear, Monsieur Athos,” said the cardinal; “but now	381.8071994327771
listen to this. It is not from mistrust that I request you to follow	322.32507664986923
me, but for my security. Your companions are no doubt Messieurs Porthos	442.81510663566644
and Aramis.”	351.3755708869254
“Yes, your Eminence,” said Athos, while the two Musketeers who had	469.1566628300501
remained behind advanced hat in hand.	340.3742800352393
“I know you, gentlemen,” said the cardinal, “I know you. I know you are	366.97293234096304
not quite my friends, and I am sorry you are not so; but I know you are	369.83251424387413
brave and loyal gentlemen, and that confidence may be placed in you.	334.9186522129672
Monsieur Athos, do me, then, the honor to accompany me; you and your	384.1352535630712
two friends, and then I shall have an escort to excite envy in his	356.29918118641103
Majesty, if we should meet him.”	310.008577265236
The three Musketeers bowed to the necks of their horses.	454.6956453245551
“Well, upon my honor,” said Athos, “your Eminence is right in taking us	363.9382283721899
with you; we have seen several ill-looking faces on the road, and we	400.39959585699705
have even had a quarrel at the Red Dovecot with four of those faces.”	307.8778094420527
“A quarrel, and what for, gentlemen?” said the cardinal; “you know I	368.0501192158031
don’t like quarrelers.”	394.2624348343329
“And that is the reason why I have the honor to inform your Eminence of	454.80588182928733
what has happened; for you might learn it from others, and upon a false	368.16609596341743
account believe us to be in fault.”	311.9586452185983
“What have been the results of your quarrel?” said the cardinal,	467.3772333738909
knitting his brow.	364.12541884610675
“My friend, Aramis, here, has received a slight sword wound in the arm,	457.18643242803023
but not enough to prevent him, as your Eminence may see, from mounting	306.5350544875992
to the assault tomorrow, if your Eminence orders an escalade.”	491.02272788272364
“But you are not the men to allow sword wounds to be inflicted upon you	421.6676551704109
thus,” said the cardinal. “Come, be frank, gentlemen, you have settled	396.2501007389467
accounts with somebody! Confess; you know I have the right of giving	486.39278612645853
absolution.”	415.9294720045608
“I, monseigneur?” said Athos. “I did not even draw my sword, but I took	375.442377861827
him who offended me round the body, and threw him out of the window. It	351.3452181801428
appears that in falling,” continued Athos, with some hesitation, “he	368.2398995334106
broke his thigh.”	457.1436279883815
“Ah, ah!” said the cardinal; “and you, Monsieur Porthos?”	366.0199372191806
“I, monseigneur, knowing that dueling is prohibited—I seized a bench,	394.4059339296306
and gave one of those brigands such a blow that I believe his shoulder	385.25314904073906
is broken.”	347.93284376298516
“Very well,” said the cardinal; “and you, Monsieur Aramis?”	464.9792605772477
“Monseigneur, being of a very mild disposition, and being, likewise, of	357.35503333348527
which Monseigneur perhaps is not aware, about to enter into orders, I	460.7061343674173
endeavored to appease my comrades, when one of these wretches gave me a	459.70663536084203
wound with a sword, treacherously, across my left arm. Then I admit my	377.8778727170805
patience failed me; I drew my sword in my turn, and as he came back to	328.01744151137405
the charge, I fancied I felt that in throwing himself upon me, he let	327.82364649283267
it pass through his body. I only know for a certainty that he fell; and	390.6940371991751
it seemed to me that he was borne away with his two companions.”	409.6557821061615
“The devil, gentlemen!” said the cardinal, “three men placed _hors de	377.20492350796485
combat_ in a cabaret squabble! You don’t do your work by halves. And	482.60087039592895
pray what was this quarrel about?”	433.45118535567224
“These fellows were drunk,” said Athos, “and knowing there was a lady	344.64980575906446
who had arrived at the cabaret this evening, they wanted to force her	487.535711790962
door.”	475.56646111264797
“Force her door!” said the cardinal, “and for what purpose?”	416.79766502076393
“To do her violence, without doubt,” said Athos. “I have had the honor	368.33477388296285
of informing your Eminence that these men were drunk.”	431.5343830316705
“And was this lady young and handsome?” asked the cardinal, with a	375.1738504807928
certain degree of anxiety.	322.8957992818671
“We did not see her, monseigneur,” said Athos.	486.8646853855968
“You did not see her? Ah, very well,” replied the cardinal, quickly.	424.0606922531373
“You did well to defend the honor of a woman; and as I am going to the	394.4810027585391
Red Dovecot myself, I shall know if you have told me the truth.”	462.2369173096959
“Monseigneur,” said Athos, haughtily, “we are gentlemen, and to save	434.80755180151976
our heads we would not be guilty of a falsehood.”	309.616261135961
“Therefore I do not doubt what you say, Monsieur Athos, I do not doubt	373.6417740938952
it for a single instant; but,” added he, “to change the conversation,	409.4810675012228
was this lady alone?”	292.6976412394379
“The lady had a cavalier shut up with her,” said Athos, “but as	436.01442304804334
notwithstanding the noise, this cavalier did not show himself, it is to	444.524999962229
be presumed that he is a coward.”	442.4829456167572
“‘Judge not rashly’, says the Gospel,” replied the cardinal.	380.16735164960323
Athos bowed.	317.40021160093625
“And now, gentlemen, that’s well,” continued the cardinal. “I know what	324.59404248724337
I wish to know; follow me.”	348.4560409153428
The three Musketeers passed behind his Eminence, who again enveloped	402.14631955620143
his face in his cloak, and put his horse in motion, keeping from eight	417.81853679394806
to ten paces in advance of his four companions.	403.424960114909
They soon arrived at the silent, solitary inn. No doubt the host knew	475.3153395517122
what illustrious visitor was expected, and had consequently sent	408.39571938641876
intruders out of the way.	405.7662895862195
Ten paces from the door the cardinal made a sign to his esquire and the	428.3996865332614
three Musketeers to halt. A saddled horse was fastened to the window	294.78189678761777
shutter. The cardinal knocked three times, and in a peculiar manner.	460.44503920673014
A man, enveloped in a cloak, came out immediately, and exchanged some	440.3066172175031
rapid words with the cardinal; after which he mounted his horse, and	350.0707564035313
set off in the direction of Surgères, which was likewise the way to	297.4885184861666
Paris.	314.0033074893364
“Advance, gentlemen,” said the cardinal.	307.0084518032833
“You have told me the truth, my gentlemen,” said he, addressing the	336.4072938119886
Musketeers, “and it will not be my fault if our encounter this evening	389.24143743518624
be not advantageous to you. In the meantime, follow me.”	390.8241372650764
The cardinal alighted; the three Musketeers did likewise. The cardinal	372.5750819622915
threw the bridle of his horse to his esquire; the three Musketeers	384.62517587820327
fastened the horses to the shutters.	383.7762587104702
The host stood at the door. For him, the cardinal was only an officer	327.6537515599503
coming to visit a lady.	485.918459069042
“Have you any chamber on the ground floor where these gentlemen can	339.0230916717271
wait near a good fire?” said the cardinal.	449.7030934275981
The host opened the door of a large room, in which an old stove had	310.11150305474916
just been replaced by a large and excellent chimney.	358.6471842082338
“I have this,” said he.	292.1553393890286
“That will do,” replied the cardinal. “Enter, gentlemen, and be kind	376.697604577683
enough to wait for me; I shall not be more than half an hour.”	353.9376631883274
And while the three Musketeers entered the ground floor room, the	406.25497216846946
cardinal, without asking further information, ascended the staircase	369.6500127503806
like a man who has no need of having his road pointed out to him.	477.8890922468089
Chapter XLIV.	341.1452937164601
THE UTILITY OF STOVEPIPES	477.2720400908295
It was evident that without suspecting it, and actuated solely by their	445.39093981813096
chivalrous and adventurous character, our three friends had just	401.08854606426576
rendered a service to someone the cardinal honored with his special	413.37462060536825
protection.	478.46095395228133
Now, who was that someone? That was the question the three Musketeers	378.7558355993752
put to one another. Then, seeing that none of their replies could throw	298.9751062750033
any light on the subject, Porthos called the host and asked for dice.	327.0036161210666
Porthos and Aramis placed themselves at the table and began to play.	370.21500819775
Athos walked about in a contemplative mood.	430.3956749611265
While thinking and walking, Athos passed and repassed before the pipe	483.6653924551076
of the stove, broken in halves, the other extremity passing into the	415.7554015978774
chamber above; and every time he passed and repassed he heard a murmur	416.5017142900472
of words, which at length fixed his attention. Athos went close to it,	414.7947695770264
and distinguished some words that appeared to merit so great an	303.36585575113696
interest that he made a sign to his friends to be silent, remaining	444.7319570265579
himself bent with his ear directed to the opening of the lower orifice.	430.19190325729716
“Listen, Milady,” said the cardinal, “the affair is important. Sit	429.1695876827924
down, and let us talk it over.”	425.6676498596105
“Milady!” murmured Athos.	449.8635460722783
“I listen to your Eminence with greatest attention,” replied a female	300.5887170375563
voice which made the Musketeer start.	452.3273643375354
“A small vessel with an English crew, whose captain is on my side,	405.14699748279855
awaits you at the mouth of Charente, at Fort La Pointe*. He will set	480.0130790931258
sail tomorrow morning.”	356.8779142350199
* Fort La Pointe, or Fort Vasou, was not built until 1672, nearly 50	445.2272285783847
years later.	331.2762063929243
“I must go thither tonight?”	332.6473768566726
“Instantly! That is to say, when you have received my instructions. Two	359.8852043715873
men, whom you will find at the door on going out, will serve you as	471.36769678599296
escort. You will allow me to leave first; then, after half an hour, you	420.6379973585547
can go away in your turn.”	344.4482645069671
“Yes, monseigneur. Now let us return to the mission with which you wish	351.8580241982494
to charge me; and as I desire to continue to merit the confidence of	432.3108186563928
your Eminence, deign to unfold it to me in terms clear and precise,	403.79147199469105
that I may not commit an error.”	360.6102187446812
There was an instant of profound silence between the two interlocutors.	295.12473703278926
It was evident that the cardinal was weighing beforehand the terms in	346.19679538723506
which he was about to speak, and that Milady was collecting all her	445.276737641283
intellectual faculties to comprehend the things he was about to say,	296.4763835777328
and to engrave them in her memory when they should be spoken.	338.95364310584813
Athos took advantage of this moment to tell his two companions to	300.1238866362825
fasten the door inside, and to make them a sign to come and listen with	459.045098748395
him.	293.2065499816579
The two Musketeers, who loved their ease, brought a chair for each of	335.2481027309783
themselves and one for Athos. All three then sat down with their heads	426.6379513090322
together and their ears on the alert.	338.4336889978895
“You will go to London,” continued the cardinal. “Arrived in London,	452.62079924824616
you will seek Buckingham.”	357.1699277107009
“I must beg your Eminence to observe,” said Milady, “that since the	361.5685714594942
affair of the diamond studs, about which the duke always suspected me,	391.2777624308015
his Grace distrusts me.”	314.3066365200233
“Well, this time,” said the cardinal, “it is not necessary to steal his	397.9017785295908
confidence, but to present yourself frankly and loyally as a	366.66592399495426
negotiator.”	448.28821652714566
“Frankly and loyally,” repeated Milady, with an unspeakable expression	342.6430885486953
of duplicity.	328.0119231089342
“Yes, frankly and loyally,” replied the cardinal, in the same tone.	458.3194471416729
“All this negotiation must be carried on openly.”	335.15184585403864
“I will follow your Eminence’s instructions to the letter. I only wait	309.75949984386887
till you give them.”	302.0522653985869
“You will go to Buckingham in my behalf, and you will tell him I am	390.21474467998314
acquainted with all the preparations he has made; but that they give me	475.20722010220004
no uneasiness, since at the first step he takes I will ruin the queen.”	452.1592020210237
“Will he believe that your Eminence is in a position to accomplish the	414.4142755463117
threat thus made?”	348.9475890205474
“Yes; for I have the proofs.”	376.4399932475055
“I must be able to present these proofs for his appreciation.”	397.8263054524916
“Without doubt. And you will tell him I will publish the report of	344.70186173317165
Bois-Robert and the Marquis de Beautru, upon the interview which the	468.16329484784376
duke had at the residence of Madame the Constable with the queen on the	304.57142615469473
evening Madame the Constable gave a masquerade. You will tell him, in	359.967786740273
order that he may not doubt, that he came there in the costume of the	334.74402708686006
Great Mogul, which the Chevalier de Guise was to have worn, and that he	456.9409863713628
purchased this exchange for the sum of three thousand pistoles.”	330.01735187792633
“Well, monseigneur?”	331.9122913615453
“All the details of his coming into and going out of the palace—on the	432.3245527162021
night when he introduced himself in the character of an Italian fortune	375.7730906730168
teller—you will tell him, that he may not doubt the correctness of my	435.3674788905659
information; that he had under his cloak a large white robe dotted with	321.29498360139684
black tears, death’s heads, and crossbones—for in case of a surprise,	429.62920524990966
he was to pass for the phantom of the White Lady who, as all the world	476.790088446318
knows, appears at the Louvre every time any great event is impending.”	346.0938621179186
“Is that all, monseigneur?”	465.0924036748677
“Tell him also that I am acquainted with all the details of the	346.251728991694
adventure at Amiens; that I will have a little romance made of it,	470.3308786410247
wittily turned, with a plan of the garden and portraits of the	305.9415944214639
principal actors in that nocturnal romance.”	406.1629289602279
“I will tell him that.”	465.94492780957694
“Tell him further that I hold Montague in my power; that Montague is in	407.8936113475526
the Bastille; that no letters were found upon him, it is true, but that	391.30432074857066
torture may make him tell much of what he knows, and even what he does	425.1912584334767
not know.”	473.272206546099
“Exactly.”	336.6059334896614
“Then add that his Grace has, in the precipitation with which he quit	407.5497011336879
the Isle of Ré, forgotten and left behind him in his lodging a certain	363.8505598399804
letter from Madame de Chevreuse which singularly compromises the queen,	464.19851311366074
inasmuch as it proves not only that her Majesty can love the enemies of	419.39211038148596
the king but that she can conspire with the enemies of France. You	381.2186152353172
recollect perfectly all I have told you, do you not?”	356.1314423072401
“Your Eminence will judge: the ball of Madame the Constable; the night	372.08554328142526
at the Louvre; the evening at Amiens; the arrest of Montague; the	407.8946721690164
letter of Madame de Chevreuse.”	481.79313333498874
“That’s it,” said the cardinal, “that’s it. You have an excellent	447.62764608193015
memory, Milady.”	304.57391578169955
“But,” resumed she to whom the cardinal addressed this flattering	333.39513492717026
compliment, “if, in spite of all these reasons, the duke does not give	358.0970862777293
way and continues to menace France?”	486.22194934673814
“The duke is in love to madness, or rather to folly,” replied	294.5298010726153
Richelieu, with great bitterness. “Like the ancient paladins, he has	440.48380456378993
only undertaken this war to obtain a look from his lady love. If he	295.0974518249621
becomes certain that this war will cost the honor, and perhaps the	385.4964702636387
liberty, of the lady of his thoughts, as he says, I will answer for it	317.626385285512
he will look twice.”	441.0791030842665
“And yet,” said Milady, with a persistence that proved she wished to	417.2372411787802
see clearly to the end of the mission with which she was about to be	317.72462678205454
charged, “if he persists?”	322.6885945235502
“If he persists?” said the cardinal. “That is not probable.”	442.05836862935723
“It is possible,” said Milady.	418.4636265663486
“If he persists—” His Eminence made a pause, and resumed: “If he	450.70068148705525
persists—well, then I shall hope for one of those events which change	467.2492666878875
the destinies of states.”	298.14388475292435
“If your Eminence would quote to me some one of these events in	483.05785743787095
history,” said Milady, “perhaps I should partake of your confidence as	431.37103162810854
to the future.”	323.4036755266029
“Well, here, for example,” said Richelieu: “when, in 1610, for a cause	399.4045228573283
similar to that which moves the duke, King Henry IV., of glorious	372.57357490409703
memory, was about, at the same time, to invade Flanders and Italy, in	440.275668818546
order to attack Austria on both sides. Well, did there not happen an	363.43676608023065
event which saved Austria? Why should not the king of France have the	441.0201525597138
same chance as the emperor?”	427.100535307178
“Your Eminence means, I presume, the knife stab in the Rue de la	488.84698213743593
Feronnerie?”	417.7112233676356
“Precisely,” said the cardinal.	322.81739837627407
“Does not your Eminence fear that the punishment inflicted upon	389.27783239746356
Ravaillac may deter anyone who might entertain the idea of imitating	417.4227284573943
him?”	374.8537628046915
“There will be, in all times and in all countries, particularly if	381.3126664357608
religious divisions exist in those countries, fanatics who ask nothing	475.7453304898248
better than to become martyrs. Ay, and observe—it just occurs to me	487.8202800448314
that the Puritans are furious against Buckingham, and their preachers	412.84114531720877
designate him as the Antichrist.”	466.04391542320445
“Well?” said Milady.	370.4276579837106
“Well,” continued the cardinal, in an indifferent tone, “the only thing	443.7879601458968
to be sought for at this moment is some woman, handsome, young, and	455.6248632372757
clever, who has cause of quarrel with the duke. The duke has had many	372.29227328994637
affairs of gallantry; and if he has fostered his amours by promises of	453.87192030470817
eternal constancy, he must likewise have sown the seeds of hatred by	383.2648881886368
his eternal infidelities.”	371.0127953899233
“No doubt,” said Milady, coolly, “such a woman may be found.”	419.3564478056044
“Well, such a woman, who would place the knife of Jacques Clément or of	433.7990451789894
Ravaillac in the hands of a fanatic, would save France.”	355.04006611646236
“Yes; but she would then be the accomplice of an assassination.”	446.14886045224216
“Were the accomplices of Ravaillac or of Jacques Clément ever known?”	409.75131311533124
“No; for perhaps they were too high-placed for anyone to dare look for	386.08416356543637
them where they were. The Palace of Justice would not be burned down	440.65728242712817
for everybody, monseigneur.”	457.6640522984997
“You think, then, that the fire at the Palace of Justice was not caused	440.1406451318806
by chance?” asked Richelieu, in the tone with which he would have put a	431.7048325776525
question of no importance.	449.6168862537941
“I, monseigneur?” replied Milady. “I think nothing; I quote a fact,	423.4603456191539
that is all. Only I say that if I were named Madame de Montpensier, or	444.3350593882153
the Queen Marie de Médicis, I should use less precautions than I take,	420.35024551898175
being simply called Milady Clarik.”	422.25783774797264
“That is just,” said Richelieu. “What do you require, then?”	302.3794423612317
“I require an order which would ratify beforehand all that I should	324.39819026385277
think proper to do for the greatest good of France.”	387.43731259048457
“But in the first place, this woman I have described must be found who	359.6239708082338
is desirous of avenging herself upon the duke.”	318.39670553225096
