“She is found,” said Milady.	430.55539368103155
“Then the miserable fanatic must be found who will serve as an	347.2324164169433
instrument of God’s justice.”	477.23443105807155
“He will be found.”	330.43013845673903
“Well,” said the cardinal, “then it will be time to claim the order	292.3684411383889
which you just now required.”	401.6933214755534
“Your Eminence is right,” replied Milady; “and I have been wrong in	324.6420455422678
seeing in the mission with which you honor me anything but that which	380.54283544944917
it really is—that is, to announce to his Grace, on the part of your	324.18730137208775
Eminence, that you are acquainted with the different disguises by means	312.86536912840745
of which he succeeded in approaching the queen during the fête given by	339.08340398374895
Madame the Constable; that you have proofs of the interview granted at	355.90384660739363
the Louvre by the queen to a certain Italian astrologer who was no	299.81490004323143
other than the Duke of Buckingham; that you have ordered a little	382.4147999795707
romance of a satirical nature to be written upon the adventures of	343.42083694215995
Amiens, with a plan of the gardens in which those adventures took	426.1383146469321
place, and portraits of the actors who figured in them; that Montague	381.4689125692173
is in the Bastille, and that the torture may make him say things he	478.9384415977315
remembers, and even things he has forgotten; that you possess a certain	306.30742581495156
letter from Madame de Chevreuse, found in his Grace’s lodging, which	341.21684905394
singularly compromises not only her who wrote it, but her in whose name	395.620563479202
it was written. Then, if he persists, notwithstanding all this—as that	303.7421294704622
is, as I have said, the limit of my mission—I shall have nothing to do	352.1332207955093
but to pray God to work a miracle for the salvation of France. That is	348.4842801443551
it, is it not, monseigneur, and I shall have nothing else to do?”	430.9071505075806
“That is it,” replied the cardinal, dryly.	469.12866017814144
“And now,” said Milady, without appearing to remark the change of the	439.22611262177645
duke’s tone toward her—“now that I have received the instructions of	342.9634579302768
your Eminence as concerns your enemies, Monseigneur will permit me to	479.6698526909448
say a few words to him of mine?”	430.3165490796123
“Have you enemies, then?” asked Richelieu.	489.7563466327091
“Yes, monseigneur, enemies against whom you owe me all your support,	379.5607537574694
for I made them by serving your Eminence.”	449.8816716889048
“Who are they?” replied the duke.	312.51088111492516
“In the first place, there is a little _intrigante_ named Bonacieux.”	416.14838549635533
“She is in the prison of Nantes.”	461.2935398608016
“That is to say, she was there,” replied Milady; “but the queen has	311.7495051051395
obtained an order from the king by means of which she has been conveyed	433.83804003869756
to a convent.”	292.90972876979487
“To a convent?” said the duke.	382.99052313799945
“Yes, to a convent.”	464.80080615427926
“And to which?”	397.19314742720564
“I don’t know; the secret has been well kept.”	425.5824422825481
“But _I_ will know!”	454.9070769597206
“And your Eminence will tell me in what convent that woman is?”	418.28432762751015
“I can see nothing inconvenient in that,” said the cardinal.	394.19097443601504
“Well, now I have an enemy much more to be dreaded by me than this	388.57704137770605
little Madame Bonacieux.”	412.2545352890248
“Who is that?”	404.1116601953334
“Her lover.”	409.853879590715
“What is his name?”	401.36274918557865
“Oh, your Eminence knows him well,” cried Milady, carried away by her	486.8509974442568
anger. “He is the evil genius of both of us. It is he who in an	303.10927129257976
encounter with your Eminence’s Guards decided the victory in favor of	427.54443209842714
the king’s Musketeers; it is he who gave three desperate wounds to De	474.761985499032
Wardes, your emissary, and who caused the affair of the diamond studs	418.0488460210102
to fail; it is he who, knowing it was I who had Madame Bonacieux	425.3578662840566
carried off, has sworn my death.”	371.3821059726388
“Ah, ah!” said the cardinal, “I know of whom you speak.”	295.268658845891
“I mean that miserable D’Artagnan.”	331.6185804262549
“He is a bold fellow,” said the cardinal.	363.93661481340973
“And it is exactly because he is a bold fellow that he is the more to	343.84270542886907
be feared.”	461.1698250419114
“I must have,” said the duke, “a proof of his connection with	398.4822066927163
Buckingham.”	432.2935921172724
“A proof?” cried Milady; “I will have ten.”	426.750000894755
“Well, then, it becomes the simplest thing in the world; get me that	393.9250208247172
proof, and I will send him to the Bastille.”	403.3820233818658
“So far good, monseigneur; but afterwards?”	407.908324568662
“When once in the Bastille, there is no afterward!” said the cardinal,	461.45548658803546
in a low voice. “Ah, _pardieu!_” continued he, “if it were as easy for	419.9277803717701
me to get rid of my enemy as it is easy to get rid of yours, and if it	300.2319691343542
were against such people you require impunity—”	348.00242671692826
“Monseigneur,” replied Milady, “a fair exchange. Life for life, man for	377.42236989593613
man; give me one, I will give you the other.”	402.5467261065959
“I don’t know what you mean, nor do I even desire to know what you	298.6631183544301
mean,” replied the cardinal; “but I wish to please you, and see nothing	388.3662263503596
out of the way in giving you what you demand with respect to so	353.5658529864172
infamous a creature—the more so as you tell me this D’Artagnan is a	332.7868555650372
libertine, a duelist, and a traitor.”	358.3357219355453
“An infamous scoundrel, monseigneur, a scoundrel!”	394.300765065564
“Give me paper, a quill, and some ink, then,” said the cardinal.	369.51383158102163
“Here they are, monseigneur.”	471.5347753305276
There was a moment of silence, which proved that the cardinal was	311.41830220064134
employed in seeking the terms in which he should write the note, or	322.3803175224991
else in writing it. Athos, who had not lost a word of the conversation,	392.25075734538433
took his two companions by the hand, and led them to the other end of	368.9766309715473
the room.	353.610716427988
“Well,” said Porthos, “what do you want, and why do you not let us	419.2240292297484
listen to the end of the conversation?”	418.2787809986609
“Hush!” said Athos, speaking in a low voice. “We have heard all it was	395.63961874173265
necessary we should hear; besides, I don’t prevent you from listening,	467.31894099532576
but I must be gone.”	361.8660876441675
“You must be gone!” said Porthos; “and if the cardinal asks for you,	442.5921802790516
what answer can we make?”	470.7787592887262
“You will not wait till he asks; you will speak first, and tell him	389.4238960597356
that I am gone on the lookout, because certain expressions of our host	458.45886228140444
have given me reason to think the road is not safe. I will say two	311.9225036020258
words about it to the cardinal’s esquire likewise. The rest concerns	365.2194676663609
myself; don’t be uneasy about that.”	352.51541063529885
“Be prudent, Athos,” said Aramis.	292.01631751952766
“Be easy on that head,” replied Athos; “you know I am cool enough.”	337.9112225379376
Porthos and Aramis resumed their places by the stovepipe.	313.4756195629742
As to Athos, he went out without any mystery, took his horse, which was	381.3556343890499
tied with those of his friends to the fastenings of the shutters, in	411.4581879612123
four words convinced the attendant of the necessity of a vanguard for	296.35864193741855
their return, carefully examined the priming of his pistols, drew his	308.86935275116446
sword, and took, like a forlorn hope, the road to the camp.	451.3427178783769
Chapter XLV.	353.44907700337876
A CONJUGAL SCENE	383.69957603590115
As Athos had foreseen, it was not long before the cardinal came down.	397.40864896216493
He opened the door of the room in which the Musketeers were, and found	475.40272789855726
Porthos playing an earnest game of dice with Aramis. He cast a rapid	315.0581339526564
glance around the room, and perceived that one of his men was missing.	397.9658416903813
“What has become of Monseigneur Athos?” asked he.	415.61016114032594
“Monseigneur,” replied Porthos, “he has gone as a scout, on account of	343.4484349461138
some words of our host, which made him believe the road was not safe.”	364.1496304639701
“And you, what have you done, Monsieur Porthos?”	337.51902916482754
“I have won five pistoles of Aramis.”	454.70105500413365
“Well; now will you return with me?”	484.57765527432616
“We are at your Eminence’s orders.”	418.19878703528417
“To horse, then, gentlemen; for it is getting late.”	447.6376738806928
The attendant was at the door, holding the cardinal’s horse by the	337.24653730875497
bridle. At a short distance a group of two men and three horses	317.15952671293564
appeared in the shade. These were the two men who were to conduct	376.76140349498945
Milady to Fort La Pointe, and superintend her embarkation.	429.56886168972414
The attendant confirmed to the cardinal what the two Musketeers had	317.3569467591328
already said with respect to Athos. The cardinal made an approving	412.88377988988043
gesture, and retraced his route with the same precautions he had used	433.3655307651535
in coming.	302.2356379621696
Let us leave him to follow the road to the camp protected by his	400.9786172280072
esquire and the two Musketeers, and return to Athos.	431.9322490212253
For a hundred paces he maintained the speed at which he started; but	321.4403485242274
when out of sight he turned his horse to the right, made a circuit, and	329.2948396704577
came back within twenty paces of a high hedge to watch the passage of	430.330230649673
the little troop. Having recognized the laced hats of his companions	350.65487574601957
and the golden fringe of the cardinal’s cloak, he waited till the	476.1508689967153
horsemen had turned the angle of the road, and having lost sight of	390.0539481287959
them, he returned at a gallop to the inn, which was opened to him	349.67553637375613
without hesitation.	306.7205208046129
The host recognized him.	487.9630371728812
“My officer,” said Athos, “has forgotten to give a piece of very	453.5885627791664
important information to the lady, and has sent me back to repair his	411.70962824823977
forgetfulness.”	430.8419888852254
“Go up,” said the host; “she is still in her chamber.”	412.09191849956665
Athos availed himself of the permission, ascended the stairs with his	394.93173102299545
lightest step, gained the landing, and through the open door perceived	380.0858994972499
Milady putting on her hat.	409.59282873964594
He entered the chamber and closed the door behind him. At the noise he	406.8031003506978
made in pushing the bolt, Milady turned round.	441.3562760240836
Athos was standing before the door, enveloped in his cloak, with his	454.71576738257147
hat pulled down over his eyes. On seeing this figure, mute and	306.66166201584196
immovable as a statue, Milady was frightened.	468.0877086646793
“Who are you, and what do you want?” cried she.	328.2313143929285
“Humph,” murmured Athos, “it is certainly she!”	448.49438533092894
And letting fall his cloak and raising his hat, he advanced toward	302.30808666166683
Milady.	344.304594085845
“Do you know me, madame?” said he.	364.674872986184
Milady made one step forward, and then drew back as if she had seen a	461.44256102884117
serpent.	407.0323204222227
“So far, well,” said Athos, “I perceive you know me.”	352.7602556109831
“The Comte de la Fère!” murmured Milady, becoming exceedingly pale, and	339.6847872055208
drawing back till the wall prevented her from going any farther.	349.1779597606318
“Yes, Milady,” replied Athos; “the Comte de la Fère in person, who	339.11273493386176
comes expressly from the other world to have the pleasure of paying you	449.0812167007761
a visit. Sit down, madame, and let us talk, as the cardinal said.”	421.8015826379177
Milady, under the influence of inexpressible terror, sat down without	383.4612526786165
uttering a word.	311.697746560769
“You certainly are a demon sent upon the earth!” said Athos. “Your	478.94894819608464
power is great, I know; but you also know that with the help of God men	448.20371046645164
have often conquered the most terrible demons. You have once before	477.6630420126439
thrown yourself in my path. I thought I had crushed you, madame; but	419.8214659738244
either I was deceived or hell has resuscitated you!”	427.1460503378075
Milady at these words, which recalled frightful remembrances, hung down	413.1488325072575
her head with a suppressed groan.	423.32578177642256
“Yes, hell has resuscitated you,” continued Athos. “Hell has made you	459.1749115165123
rich, hell has given you another name, hell has almost made you another	438.08105178088914
face; but it has neither effaced the stains from your soul nor the	430.9072402485689
brand from your body.”	372.0703681713587
Milady arose as if moved by a powerful spring, and her eyes flashed	325.9424949221481
lightning. Athos remained sitting.	402.9006734862499
“You believed me to be dead, did you not, as I believed you to be? And	317.4763281174247
the name of Athos as well concealed the Comte de la Fère, as the name	330.34286121295867
Milady Clarik concealed Anne de Breuil. Was it not so you were called	379.71880084764774
when your honored brother married us? Our position is truly a strange	427.4746113213512
one,” continued Athos, laughing. “We have only lived up to the present	384.7234991687931
time because we believed each other dead, and because a remembrance is	321.1109712550047
less oppressive than a living creature, though a remembrance is	431.94476783807704
sometimes devouring.”	340.90571650775587
“But,” said Milady, in a hollow, faint voice, “what brings you back to	467.01078944207484
me, and what do you want with me?”	337.3204192852537
“I wish to tell you that though remaining invisible to your eyes, I	364.0127097870966
have not lost sight of you.”	353.9535344829684
“You know what I have done?”	395.7551343580582
“I can relate to you, day by day, your actions from your entrance to	301.48972339616716
the service of the cardinal to this evening.”	395.0863578907496
A smile of incredulity passed over the pale lips of Milady.	394.323279443024
“Listen! It was you who cut off the two diamond studs from the shoulder	315.2929556087257
of the Duke of Buckingham; it was you who had Madame Bonacieux carried	302.701033264676
off; it was you who, in love with De Wardes and thinking to pass the	432.1992450939371
night with him, opened the door to Monsieur d’Artagnan; it was you who,	297.40758361663916
believing that De Wardes had deceived you, wished to have him killed by	349.511900933168
his rival; it was you who, when this rival had discovered your infamous	336.0641658904456
secret, wished to have him killed in his turn by two assassins, whom	447.3808859420362
you sent in pursuit of him; it was you who, finding the balls had	294.43002187147727
missed their mark, sent poisoned wine with a forged letter, to make	368.9711472630439
your victim believe that the wine came from his friends. In short, it	326.9090220267375
was you who have but now in this chamber, seated in this chair I now	398.6386223819885
fill, made an engagement with Cardinal Richelieu to cause the Duke of	318.307408512431
Buckingham to be assassinated, in exchange for the promise he has made	344.20534428043345
you to allow you to assassinate D’Artagnan.”	463.0302744695441
Milady was livid.	309.1616234687427
“You must be Satan!” cried she.	351.0879486307513
“Perhaps,” said Athos; “But at all events listen well to this.	301.5112053834268
Assassinate the Duke of Buckingham, or cause him to be assassinated—I	378.7419029050465
care very little about that! I don’t know him. Besides, he is an	409.7116724550839
Englishman. But do not touch with the tip of your finger a single hair	486.09204911599124
of D’Artagnan, who is a faithful friend whom I love and defend, or I	383.22060395390287
swear to you by the head of my father the crime which you shall have	464.82461470422606
endeavored to commit, or shall have committed, shall be the last.”	380.04899057293
“Monsieur d’Artagnan has cruelly insulted me,” said Milady, in a hollow	332.67485494022554
tone; “Monsieur d’Artagnan shall die!”	395.4039686319572
“Indeed! Is it possible to insult you, madame?” said Athos, laughing;	472.19170294905666
“he has insulted you, and he shall die!”	435.75833257331226
“He shall die!” replied Milady; “she first, and he afterward.”	378.8328578820024
Athos was seized with a kind of vertigo. The sight of this creature,	298.53838316147295
who had nothing of the woman about her, recalled awful remembrances. He	442.3153131135661
thought how one day, in a less dangerous situation than the one in	371.6858828296902
which he was now placed, he had already endeavored to sacrifice her to	482.00098812455013
his honor. His desire for blood returned, burning his brain and	438.3887229309968
pervading his frame like a raging fever; he arose in his turn, reached	310.1438229665393
his hand to his belt, drew forth a pistol, and cocked it.	455.06597102133327
Milady, pale as a corpse, endeavored to cry out; but her swollen tongue	355.03657882293794
could utter no more than a hoarse sound which had nothing human in it	396.26438735828407
and resembled the rattle of a wild beast. Motionless against the dark	389.2197313462177
tapestry, with her hair in disorder, she appeared like a horrid image	387.3427871215747
of terror.	399.8134260121373
Athos slowly raised his pistol, stretched out his arm so that the	418.62968029903834
weapon almost touched Milady’s forehead, and then, in a voice the more	384.9277406565285
terrible from having the supreme calmness of a fixed resolution,	417.00899644390097
“Madame,” said he, “you will this instant deliver to me the paper the	318.0725330254487
cardinal signed; or upon my soul, I will blow your brains out.”	466.38651226535626
With another man, Milady might have preserved some doubt; but she knew	403.65331958992647
Athos. Nevertheless, she remained motionless.	461.1442416831032
“You have one second to decide,” said he.	312.72708956197675
Milady saw by the contraction of his countenance that the trigger was	475.2665710394349
about to be pulled; she reached her hand quickly to her bosom, drew out	458.9448554080825
a paper, and held it toward Athos.	307.8361885728655
“Take it,” said she, “and be accursed!”	393.308909963575
Athos took the paper, returned the pistol to his belt, approached the	338.10730161019563
lamp to be assured that it was the paper, unfolded it, and read:	447.19454010812615
“Dec. 3, 1627	478.2314810494862
“It is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of	337.8291059402344
this has done what he has done.	472.3699268572493
“RICHELIEU”	310.1865465210491
“And now,” said Athos, resuming his cloak and putting on his hat, “now	300.86480709765186
that I have drawn your teeth, viper, bite if you can.”	330.5390135353144
And he left the chamber without once looking behind him.	409.3738706470616
At the door he found the two men and the spare horse which they held.	306.982979360465
“Gentlemen,” said he, “Monseigneur’s order is, you know, to conduct	344.9655745106405
that woman, without losing time, to Fort La Pointe, and never to leave	378.88799725492686
her till she is on board.”	444.0354273240665
As these words agreed wholly with the order they had received, they	411.27801837853525
bowed their heads in sign of assent.	461.6674145453077
With regard to Athos, he leaped lightly into the saddle and set out at	462.4962234480063
full gallop; only instead of following the road, he went across the	450.2494981764861
fields, urging his horse to the utmost and stopping occasionally to	327.751804020516
listen.	462.38929496001856
In one of those halts he heard the steps of several horses on the road.	482.57307432444816
He had no doubt it was the cardinal and his escort. He immediately made	423.24707616720843
a new point in advance, rubbed his horse down with some heath and	466.9865415440381
leaves of trees, and placed himself across the road, about two hundred	469.40653392345746
paces from the camp.	390.3833849471389
“Who goes there?” cried he, as soon as he perceived the horsemen.	483.57159377677533
“That is our brave Musketeer, I think,” said the cardinal.	405.6766858197531
“Yes, monseigneur,” said Porthos, “it is he.”	409.89069162399215
“Monsieur Athos,” said Richelieu, “receive my thanks for the good guard	412.9562482623485
you have kept. Gentlemen, we are arrived; take the gate on the left.	304.02698529774284
The watchword is, ‘King and Ré.’”	427.09761256841625
Saying these words, the cardinal saluted the three friends with an	374.36117134926036
inclination of his head, and took the right hand, followed by his	467.0639377082333
attendant—for that night he himself slept in the camp.	440.05744163209215
“Well!” said Porthos and Aramis together, as soon as the cardinal was	380.8935441543299
out of hearing, “well, he signed the paper she required!”	351.80769151620433
“I know it,” said Athos, coolly, “since here it is.”	382.38959214877514
And the three friends did not exchange another word till they reached	403.8913736149705
their quarters, except to give the watchword to the sentinels. Only	480.73086060229247
they sent Mousqueton to tell Planchet that his master was requested,	491.9577571246259
the instant that he left the trenches, to come to the quarters of the	299.3960227186632
Musketeers.	307.71193555885026
Milady, as Athos had foreseen, on finding the two men that awaited her,	335.3326500934222
made no difficulty in following them. She had had for an instant an	415.089722113782
inclination to be reconducted to the cardinal, and relate everything to	425.0642434072275
him; but a revelation on her part would bring about a revelation on the	490.575330921593
part of Athos. She might say that Athos had hanged her; but then Athos	383.0616630937169
would tell that she was branded. She thought it was best to preserve	381.8844255927493
silence, to discreetly set off to accomplish her difficult mission with	351.6516913754707
her usual skill; and then, all things being accomplished to the	350.78546466144627
satisfaction of the cardinal, to come to him and claim her vengeance.	409.013180827236
In consequence, after having traveled all night, at seven o’clock she	380.7050663436663
was at the fort of the Point; at eight o’clock she had embarked; and at	297.68495892391076
nine, the vessel, which with letters of marque from the cardinal was	475.43534642536736
supposed to be sailing for Bayonne, raised anchor, and steered its	452.17837848510874
course toward England.	306.7866774605113
Chapter XLVI.	370.8013320360204
THE BASTION SAINT-GERVAIS	398.9208351361025
On arriving at the lodgings of his three friends, D’Artagnan found them	292.8195785431881
assembled in the same chamber. Athos was meditating; Porthos was	352.12421275102014
twisting his mustache; Aramis was saying his prayers in a charming	400.7963976686976
little Book of Hours, bound in blue velvet.	390.15285816423597
“_Pardieu_, gentlemen,” said he. “I hope what you have to tell me is	358.47040827407545
worth the trouble, or else, I warn you, I will not pardon you for	411.6824818122811
making me come here instead of getting a little rest after a night	446.87569497828986
spent in taking and dismantling a bastion. Ah, why were you not there,	358.5483845500073
gentlemen? It was warm work.”	406.1645420434246
“We were in a place where it was not very cold,” replied Porthos,	362.2862736156435
giving his mustache a twist which was peculiar to him.	354.192333874799
“Hush!” said Athos.	335.3840190727524
“Oh, oh!” said D’Artagnan, comprehending the slight frown of the	332.9481836282485
Musketeer. “It appears there is something fresh aboard.”	293.69257213423015
“Aramis,” said Athos, “you went to breakfast the day before yesterday	394.4316588132907
at the inn of the Parpaillot, I believe?”	390.01169654387735
“Yes.”	309.91647497677735
“How did you fare?”	325.90081680363176
“For my part, I ate but little. The day before yesterday was a fish	347.7533177315391
day, and they had nothing but meat.”	379.8408510528719
“What,” said Athos, “no fish at a seaport?”	477.48706063213655
“They say,” said Aramis, resuming his pious reading, “that the dyke	448.1502624109145
which the cardinal is making drives them all out into the open sea.”	303.7864627509065
“But that is not quite what I mean to ask you, Aramis,” replied Athos.	371.52379011329685
“I want to know if you were left alone, and nobody interrupted you.”	339.8595402390735
“Why, I think there were not many intruders. Yes, Athos, I know what	418.581212565854
you mean: we shall do very well at the Parpaillot.”	440.9825980791037
“Let us go to the Parpaillot, then, for here the walls are like sheets	417.5632240041681
of paper.”	388.24499124320124
D’Artagnan, who was accustomed to his friend’s manner of acting, and	483.2574896594966
who perceived immediately, by a word, a gesture, or a sign from him,	388.0995209004132
that the circumstances were serious, took Athos’s arm, and went out	445.1482340872084
without saying anything. Porthos followed, chatting with Aramis.	406.7883999979907
On their way they met Grimaud. Athos made him a sign to come with them.	448.79537399754184
Grimaud, according to custom, obeyed in silence; the poor lad had	343.7735620526048
nearly come to the pass of forgetting how to speak.	330.912698365797
They arrived at the drinking room of the Parpaillot. It was seven	299.57395576292157
o’clock in the morning, and daylight began to appear. The three friends	374.72910197292487
ordered breakfast, and went into a room in which the host said they	316.51177789875084
would not be disturbed.	466.14685147878754
Unfortunately, the hour was badly chosen for a private conference. The	333.34578713554004
morning drum had just been beaten; everyone shook off the drowsiness of	374.4377123660494
night, and to dispel the humid morning air, came to take a drop at the	317.30674892837845
inn. Dragoons, Swiss, Guardsmen, Musketeers, light-horsemen, succeeded	427.6722392777727
one another with a rapidity which might answer the purpose of the host	371.682315465987
very well, but agreed badly with the views of the four friends. Thus	374.4383395296157
they applied very curtly to the salutations, healths, and jokes of	465.6147989312568
their companions.	443.4499049985044
“I see how it will be,” said Athos: “we shall get into some pretty	402.40017433648876
quarrel or other, and we have no need of one just now. D’Artagnan, tell	390.3151047041416
us what sort of a night you have had, and we will describe ours	314.46437332460323
afterward.”	429.0953838892861
“Ah, yes,” said a light-horseman, with a glass of brandy in his hand,	322.76052290746156
which he sipped slowly. “I hear you gentlemen of the Guards have been	390.6855639465147
in the trenches tonight, and that you did not get much the best of the	346.92686350021114
Rochellais.”	299.0668148634894
D’Artagnan looked at Athos to know if he ought to reply to this	407.8226597125798
intruder who thus mixed unasked in their conversation.	361.75014653944123
“Well,” said Athos, “don’t you hear Monsieur de Busigny, who does you	463.095873587888
the honor to ask you a question? Relate what has passed during the	341.67972608812465
night, since these gentlemen desire to know it.”	483.12138391310964
“Have you not taken a bastion?” said a Swiss, who was drinking rum out	442.31936239338063
of a beer glass.	446.4547900895801
“Yes, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan, bowing, “we have had that honor. We	296.8023157747491
even have, as you may have heard, introduced a barrel of powder under	311.0433218773339
one of the angles, which in blowing up made a very pretty breach.	416.38534606929164
Without reckoning that as the bastion was not built yesterday all the	460.75780798808233
rest of the building was badly shaken.”	389.3316906084582
“And what bastion is it?” asked a dragoon, with his saber run through a	410.9031913659879
goose which he was taking to be cooked.	480.1991936159209
“The bastion St. Gervais,” replied D’Artagnan, “from behind which the	327.10113845076796
Rochellais annoyed our workmen.”	386.1423690943002
“Was that affair hot?”	408.51898609921346
“Yes, moderately so. We lost five men, and the Rochellais eight or	328.75933618876303
ten.”	411.3737386931763
“_Balzempleu!_” said the Swiss, who, notwithstanding the admirable	441.2841647260473
collection of oaths possessed by the German language, had acquired a	335.9019554974706
habit of swearing in French.	340.2182422476544
“But it is probable,” said the light-horseman, “that they will send	426.9012686338698
pioneers this morning to repair the bastion.”	461.1567002306722
“Yes, that’s probable,” said D’Artagnan.	360.5097451835566
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, “a wager!”	300.4351510953355
“Ah, _wooi_, a vager!” cried the Swiss.	338.00944364215286
“What is it?” said the light-horseman.	466.06450034198986
“Stop a bit,” said the dragoon, placing his saber like a spit upon the	428.0347251950194
two large iron dogs which held the firebrands in the chimney, “stop a	482.0006507016061
bit, I am in it. You cursed host! a dripping pan immediately, that I	327.4715617751837
may not lose a drop of the fat of this estimable bird.”	391.9475540093613
“You was right,” said the Swiss; “goose grease is kood with basdry.”	399.1315659723882
“There!” said the dragoon. “Now for the wager! We listen, Monsieur	437.1123335382799
Athos.”	393.00992623868973
“Yes, the wager!” said the light-horseman.	465.744271873275
“Well, Monsieur de Busigny, I will bet you,” said Athos, “that my three	339.4446767756309
companions, Messieurs Porthos, Aramis, and D’Artagnan, and myself, will	332.2140254352057
go and breakfast in the bastion St. Gervais, and we will remain there	333.61010856246565
an hour, by the watch, whatever the enemy may do to dislodge us.”	408.7787063666117
Porthos and Aramis looked at each other; they began to comprehend.	481.6836516790682
“But,” said D’Artagnan, in the ear of Athos, “you are going to get us	444.62012301190657
all killed without mercy.”	383.2920723408813
“We are much more likely to be killed,” said Athos, “if we do not go.”	472.5954646268832
“My faith, gentlemen,” said Porthos, turning round upon his chair and	377.57181713914946
twisting his mustache, “that’s a fair bet, I hope.”	349.09201826162854
“I take it,” said M. de Busigny; “so let us fix the stake.”	406.63921689967935
“You are four gentlemen,” said Athos, “and we are four; an unlimited	346.4950402647004
dinner for eight. Will that do?”	301.7501862289072
“Capitally,” replied M. de Busigny.	489.5549651566458
“Perfectly,” said the dragoon.	421.82646050088977
“That shoots me,” said the Swiss.	427.13892552530433
The fourth auditor, who during all this conversation had played a mute	384.8246660792277
part, made a sign of the head in proof that he acquiesced in the	491.00623073610865
proposition.	418.98857173672303
“The breakfast for these gentlemen is ready,” said the host.	355.8890966235592
“Well, bring it,” said Athos.	418.5011862704136
The host obeyed. Athos called Grimaud, pointed to a large basket which	349.49962387530974
lay in a corner, and made a sign to him to wrap the viands up in the	324.1148376227163
napkins.	339.00850174879133
Grimaud understood that it was to be a breakfast on the grass, took the	431.17321204861616
basket, packed up the viands, added the bottles, and then took the	374.85461673354996
basket on his arm.	395.69784245399
“But where are you going to eat my breakfast?” asked the host.	316.41308937129895
“What matter, if you are paid for it?” said Athos, and he threw two	328.45822909191895
pistoles majestically on the table.	427.07727442990205
“Shall I give you the change, my officer?” said the host.	292.4388121314986
“No, only add two bottles of champagne, and the difference will be for	311.1871206115452
the napkins.”	378.72813047347756
The host had not quite so good a bargain as he at first hoped for, but	297.16713629569995
he made amends by slipping in two bottles of Anjou wine instead of two	463.2862885765761
bottles of champagne.	458.17229462627176
“Monsieur de Busigny,” said Athos, “will you be so kind as to set your	459.32912656953795
watch with mine, or permit me to regulate mine by yours?”	459.27247262755634
“Which you please, monsieur!” said the light-horseman, drawing from his	359.8211410602457
fob a very handsome watch, studded with diamonds; “half past seven.”	435.2109169239693
“Thirty-five minutes after seven,” said Athos, “by which you perceive I	436.77546270567996
am five minutes faster than you.”	374.2148628761482
And bowing to all the astonished persons present, the young men took	296.88567405815047
the road to the bastion St. Gervais, followed by Grimaud, who carried	328.49150606539587
the basket, ignorant of where he was going but in the passive obedience	312.7267216563994
which Athos had taught him not even thinking of asking.	461.924905781387
As long as they were within the circle of the camp, the four friends	298.09279403262354
did not exchange one word; besides, they were followed by the curious,	422.3125508075879
who, hearing of the wager, were anxious to know how they would come out	294.4278336653916
of it. But when once they passed the line of circumvallation and found	358.48141933273484
themselves in the open plain, D’Artagnan, who was completely ignorant	456.18014261162887
of what was going forward, thought it was time to demand an	406.9881052640143
explanation.	307.90130266718825
“And now, my dear Athos,” said he, “do me the kindness to tell me where	464.22774891386445
we are going?”	477.190126608201
“Why, you see plainly enough we are going to the bastion.”	318.2398499721785
“But what are we going to do there?”	329.5077577045612
“You know well that we go to breakfast there.”	454.66646052165515
“But why did we not breakfast at the Parpaillot?”	410.35231228623434
“Because we have very important matters to communicate to one another,	294.4072872322017
and it was impossible to talk five minutes in that inn without being	318.2875875950558
annoyed by all those importunate fellows, who keep coming in, saluting	413.2949629469757
you, and addressing you. Here at least,” said Athos, pointing to the	478.76681434451854
bastion, “they will not come and disturb us.”	305.36599386164863
“It appears to me,” said D’Artagnan, with that prudence which allied	325.7842541130519
itself in him so naturally with excessive bravery, “that we could have	378.9007399836863
found some retired place on the downs or the seashore.”	407.92246418545545
“Where we should have been seen all four conferring together, so that	369.70802721890914
at the end of a quarter of an hour the cardinal would have been	324.224919857155
informed by his spies that we were holding a council.”	404.75103496797834
“Yes,” said Aramis, “Athos is right: _Animadvertuntur in desertis_.”	312.8559482871289
“A desert would not have been amiss,” said Porthos; “but it behooved us	426.87100200051174
to find it.”	373.5948364684427
“There is no desert where a bird cannot pass over one’s head, where a	420.1487433904819
fish cannot leap out of the water, where a rabbit cannot come out of	438.49738987720724
its burrow, and I believe that bird, fish, and rabbit each becomes a	362.2415142935157
spy of the cardinal. Better, then, pursue our enterprise; from which,	386.5050233143953
besides, we cannot retreat without shame. We have made a wager—a wager	365.62542625852166
which could not have been foreseen, and of which I defy anyone to	317.06528434658054
divine the true cause. We are going, in order to win it, to remain an	480.05430822082144
hour in the bastion. Either we shall be attacked, or not. If we are	329.65792237587146
not, we shall have all the time to talk, and nobody will hear us—for I	314.9587420233291
guarantee the walls of the bastion have no ears; if we are, we will	387.1795107871342
talk of our affairs just the same. Moreover, in defending ourselves, we	337.9109735433179
shall cover ourselves with glory. You see that everything is to our	477.34428746964636
advantage.”	419.0669973594112
“Yes,” said D’Artagnan; “but we shall indubitably attract a ball.”	453.8997866921578
“Well, my dear,” replied Athos, “you know well that the balls most to	440.8033895141201
be dreaded are not from the enemy.”	393.990496776487
“But for such an expedition we surely ought to have brought our	478.26339959277664
muskets.”	403.4686503944794
“You are stupid, friend Porthos. Why should we load ourselves with a	404.853538903677
useless burden?”	395.1217037696384
“I don’t find a good musket, twelve cartridges, and a powder flask very	486.69588272792106
useless in the face of an enemy.”	400.5206979031019
“Well,” replied Athos, “have you not heard what D’Artagnan said?”	293.45586886402435
“What did he say?” demanded Porthos.	447.65834034983476
“D’Artagnan said that in the attack of last night eight or ten	471.3311416235242
Frenchmen were killed, and as many Rochellais.”	453.6432855098909
“What then?”	371.7300885304136
“The bodies were not plundered, were they? It appears the conquerors	354.0089304857942
had something else to do.”	304.69540265437655
“Well?”	470.3436725840888
“Well, we shall find their muskets, their cartridges, and their flasks;	380.2856827574822
and instead of four musketoons and twelve balls, we shall have fifteen	378.62082580806197
guns and a hundred charges to fire.”	443.4723738359522
“Oh, Athos!” said Aramis, “truly you are a great man.”	307.8305233500506
Porthos nodded in sign of agreement. D’Artagnan alone did not seem	304.43789086562356
convinced.	312.9205115123388
Grimaud no doubt shared the misgivings of the young man, for seeing	429.13618585344966
that they continued to advance toward the bastion—something he had till	444.6111220317593
then doubted—he pulled his master by the skirt of his coat.	329.19794989653394
“Where are we going?” asked he, by a gesture.	432.43570046748926
Athos pointed to the bastion.	491.4333563205854
“But,” said Grimaud, in the same silent dialect, “we shall leave our	422.4456218995644
skins there.”	356.1555762373097
Athos raised his eyes and his finger toward heaven.	327.1164270451926
Grimaud put his basket on the ground and sat down with a shake of the	373.75308128543816
head.	303.1899565919441
Athos took a pistol from his belt, looked to see if it was properly	368.62229393452105
primed, cocked it, and placed the muzzle close to Grimaud’s ear.	379.8466212191555
Grimaud was on his legs again as if by a spring. Athos then made him a	425.9524623430285
sign to take up his basket and to walk on first. Grimaud obeyed. All	427.79530370771187
that Grimaud gained by this momentary pantomime was to pass from the	392.20109762675037
rear guard to the vanguard.	323.3187843117252
Arrived at the bastion, the four friends turned round.	420.4076576830988
More than three hundred soldiers of all kinds were assembled at the	303.81362252269605
gate of the camp; and in a separate group might be distinguished M. de	414.1202096564416
Busigny, the dragoon, the Swiss, and the fourth bettor.	417.1558052890954
Athos took off his hat, placed it on the end of his sword, and waved it	437.67216406518503
in the air.	329.80060686197635
All the spectators returned him his salute, accompanying this courtesy	452.4265537725529
with a loud hurrah which was audible to the four; after which all four	411.1875240028363
disappeared in the bastion, whither Grimaud had preceded them.	445.2313409458418
Chapter XLVII.	420.31719092658216
THE COUNCIL OF THE MUSKETEERS	410.76524633735517
As Athos had foreseen, the bastion was only occupied by a dozen	456.92299140764067
corpses, French and Rochellais.	483.13368481699695
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, who had assumed the command of the expedition,	341.43821437765894
“while Grimaud spreads the table, let us begin by collecting the guns	369.7084025046879
and cartridges together. We can talk while performing that necessary	468.1201739719913
task. These gentlemen,” added he, pointing to the bodies, “cannot hear	415.3143247614788
us.”	331.7691789565052
“But we could throw them into the ditch,” said Porthos, “after having	473.08780920128504
assured ourselves they have nothing in their pockets.”	311.2970122866435
“Yes,” said Athos, “that’s Grimaud’s business.”	435.8968122321579
“Well, then,” cried D’Artagnan, “pray let Grimaud search them and throw	398.5488540428785
them over the walls.”	353.2407796867326
“Heaven forfend!” said Athos; “they may serve us.”	404.22283697746605
“These bodies serve us?” said Porthos. “You are mad, dear friend.”	314.842332995084
“Judge not rashly, say the gospel and the cardinal,” replied Athos.	472.58031713980233
“How many guns, gentlemen?”	315.48830856372456
“Twelve,” replied Aramis.	337.6187496065723
“How many shots?”	393.4836158153381
“A hundred.”	465.4719879302279
“That’s quite as many as we shall want. Let us load the guns.”	427.494544697426
The four Musketeers went to work; and as they were loading the last	335.27749410091053
musket Grimaud announced that the breakfast was ready.	424.6988758068958
Athos replied, always by gestures, that that was well, and indicated to	404.5668624248052
Grimaud, by pointing to a turret that resembled a pepper caster, that	448.0178793522574
he was to stand as sentinel. Only, to alleviate the tediousness of the	385.38012588904064
duty, Athos allowed him to take a loaf, two cutlets, and a bottle of	366.7543130897217
wine.	332.03786508733924
“And now to table,” said Athos.	462.9323319837881
The four friends seated themselves on the ground with their legs	393.51127389117084
crossed like Turks, or even tailors.	482.53584789049063
“And now,” said D’Artagnan, “as there is no longer any fear of being	431.88110530798974
overheard, I hope you are going to let me into your secret.”	382.57953343481296
“I hope at the same time to procure you amusement and glory,	482.0250375027214
gentlemen,” said Athos. “I have induced you to take a charming	299.3453194745215
promenade; here is a delicious breakfast; and yonder are five hundred	430.66257908748867
persons, as you may see through the loopholes, taking us for heroes or	464.09592187848887
madmen—two classes of imbeciles greatly resembling each other.”	426.4627921466777
“But the secret!” said D’Artagnan.	373.86376222621016
“The secret is,” said Athos, “that I saw Milady last night.”	388.53820840045967
D’Artagnan was lifting a glass to his lips; but at the name of Milady,	301.0338103160021
his hand trembled so, that he was obliged to put the glass on the	403.40584021023795
ground again for fear of spilling the contents.”	397.4859874227976
“You saw your wi—”	307.57405756075735
“Hush!” interrupted Athos. “You forget, my dear, you forget that these	479.49684967843586
gentlemen are not initiated into my family affairs like yourself. I	429.8258230370892
have seen Milady.”	306.8519136494779
“Where?” demanded D’Artagnan.	430.97948270310854
“Within two leagues of this place, at the inn of the Red Dovecot.”	460.0895504270718
“In that case I am lost,” said D’Artagnan.	427.4280082398865
“Not so bad yet,” replied Athos; “for by this time she must have quit	448.43537095717056
the shores of France.”	440.3499687840649
D’Artagnan breathed again.	469.7696769816855
“But after all,” asked Porthos, “who is Milady?”	485.0228458500237
“A charming woman!” said Athos, sipping a glass of sparkling wine.	400.52746767178917
“Villainous host!” cried he, “he has given us Anjou wine instead of	324.31199696512107
champagne, and fancies we know no better! Yes,” continued he, “a	384.8413682138151
charming woman, who entertained kind views toward our friend	299.9714263291826
D’Artagnan, who, on his part, has given her some offense for which she	295.55528217232154
tried to revenge herself a month ago by having him killed by two musket	433.2799440960501
shots, a week ago by trying to poison him, and yesterday by demanding	483.000040693008
his head of the cardinal.”	489.15418373995044
“What! by demanding my head of the cardinal?” cried D’Artagnan, pale	415.8694370335418
with terror.	353.83929856834504
“Yes, that is true as the Gospel,” said Porthos; “I heard her with my	332.82024603378505
own ears.”	429.50357681393047
“I also,” said Aramis.	362.6746771222129
“Then,” said D’Artagnan, letting his arm fall with discouragement, “it	422.58938430057685
is useless to struggle longer. I may as well blow my brains out, and	444.59039022868865
all will be over.”	380.1587420293131
“That’s the last folly to be committed,” said Athos, “seeing it is the	490.41726008088744
only one for which there is no remedy.”	491.9980091309051
“But I can never escape,” said D’Artagnan, “with such enemies. First,	389.2404242584937
my stranger of Meung; then De Wardes, to whom I have given three sword	296.1552785040173
wounds; next Milady, whose secret I have discovered; finally, the	486.26590471766804
cardinal, whose vengeance I have balked.”	480.73641163527924
“Well,” said Athos, “that only makes four; and we are four—one for one.	408.2620227225248
_Pardieu!_ if we may believe the signs Grimaud is making, we are about	453.5727622245387
to have to do with a very different number of people. What is it,	376.13451042302233
Grimaud? Considering the gravity of the occasion, I permit you to	303.5874828178166
speak, my friend; but be laconic, I beg. What do you see?”	349.82448459852503
“A troop.”	384.42827427374107
“Of how many persons?”	483.77069133657665
“Twenty men.”	410.1651834663454
“What sort of men?”	327.259350060017
“Sixteen pioneers, four soldiers.”	346.1544902549502
“How far distant?”	298.085208920028
“Five hundred paces.”	360.8399860348737
“Good! We have just time to finish this fowl and to drink one glass of	357.2935295872583
wine to your health, D’Artagnan.”	461.7303896898118
“To your health!” repeated Porthos and Aramis.	415.6360169708291
“Well, then, to my health! although I am very much afraid that your	364.89688602596067
good wishes will not be of great service to me.”	292.67928422016246
“Bah!” said Athos, “God is great, as say the followers of Mohammed, and	478.32542456065283
the future is in his hands.”	363.28746077961216
Then, swallowing the contents of his glass, which he put down close to	322.6447019440386
him, Athos arose carelessly, took the musket next to him, and drew near	429.0166273188032
to one of the loopholes.	479.1059843548331
Porthos, Aramis and D’Artagnan followed his example. As to Grimaud, he	405.5876458557987
received orders to place himself behind the four friends in order to	491.7796119584481
reload their weapons.	413.7578348592794
“_Pardieu!_” said Athos, “it was hardly worth while to distribute	483.60923218302526
ourselves for twenty fellows armed with pickaxes, mattocks, and	372.2558172397067
shovels. Grimaud had only to make them a sign to go away, and I am	398.4661437117431
convinced they would have left us in peace.”	332.0513394237743
“I doubt that,” replied D’Artagnan, “for they are advancing very	339.9719499248804
resolutely. Besides, in addition to the pioneers, there are four	411.75562115882633
soldiers and a brigadier, armed with muskets.”	411.07770265292555
“That’s because they don’t see us,” said Athos.	360.01948330815287
“My faith,” said Aramis, “I must confess I feel a great repugnance to	367.64458326103477
fire on these poor devils of civilians.”	405.4156920109647
“He is a bad priest,” said Porthos, “who has pity for heretics.”	303.6838663277454
“In truth,” said Athos, “Aramis is right. I will warn them.”	447.9989759925744
“What the devil are you going to do?” cried D’Artagnan, “you will be	433.1521843633736
shot.”	486.9519610822582
But Athos heeded not his advice. Mounting on the breach, with his	389.42457516007846
musket in one hand and his hat in the other, he said, bowing	406.14801485245744
courteously and addressing the soldiers and the pioneers, who,	367.9617420426015
astonished at this apparition, stopped fifty paces from the bastion:	324.9647534694276
“Gentlemen, a few friends and myself are about to breakfast in this	424.54921182222904
bastion. Now, you know nothing is more disagreeable than being	361.133309999733
disturbed when one is at breakfast. We request you, then, if you really	472.97127754739694
have business here, to wait till we have finished our repast, or to	470.6279419369182
come again a short time hence; unless, which would be far better, you	450.60303967659775
form the salutary resolution to quit the side of the rebels, and come	399.6470046266116
and drink with us to the health of the King of France.”	402.19768816547503
“Take care, Athos!” cried D’Artagnan; “don’t you see they are aiming?”	484.8831345785521
“Yes, yes,” said Athos; “but they are only civilians—very bad marksmen,	432.3688421370571
who will be sure not to hit me.”	425.1891161992548
In fact, at the same instant four shots were fired, and the balls were	341.2897128431079
flattened against the wall around Athos, but not one touched him.	425.65576258299893
Four shots replied to them almost instantaneously, but much better	445.0521518299229
aimed than those of the aggressors; three soldiers fell dead, and one	308.68153300532924
of the pioneers was wounded.	476.469652754234
“Grimaud,” said Athos, still on the breach, “another musket!”	490.83713054054977
Grimaud immediately obeyed. On their part, the three friends had	357.84680570263663
reloaded their arms; a second discharge followed the first. The	480.2053097245072
brigadier and two pioneers fell dead; the rest of the troop took to	441.428447821664
flight.	395.55877573950215
“Now, gentlemen, a _sortie!_” cried Athos.	343.7867113901019
And the four friends rushed out of the fort, gained the field of	414.3772353701281
battle, picked up the four muskets of the privates and the half-pike of	406.7917342546918
the brigadier, and convinced that the fugitives would not stop till	366.08874934700935
they reached the city, turned again toward the bastion, bearing with	348.7754867996082
them the trophies of their victory.	491.4762806353881
“Reload the muskets, Grimaud,” said Athos, “and we, gentlemen, will go	373.5576326332432
on with our breakfast, and resume our conversation. Where were we?”	445.91059763189406
“I recollect you were saying,” said D’Artagnan, “that after having	331.20868735235143
demanded my head of the cardinal, Milady had quit the shores of France.	481.26364017489425
Whither goes she?” added he, strongly interested in the route Milady	477.9271574888693
followed.	488.0194340792757
“She goes into England,” said Athos.	429.941925573229
“With what view?”	336.6168912640486
“With the view of assassinating, or causing to be assassinated, the	489.7611970031751
Duke of Buckingham.”	306.9468335028578
D’Artagnan uttered an exclamation of surprise and indignation.	363.37740357136045
“But this is infamous!” cried he.	486.60824022486463
“As to that,” said Athos, “I beg you to believe that I care very little	361.4175801917439
about it. Now you have done, Grimaud, take our brigadier’s half-pike,	298.40389192062804
tie a napkin to it, and plant it on top of our bastion, that these	318.5199064463286
rebels of Rochellais may see that they have to deal with brave and	337.50850488970343
loyal soldiers of the king.”	485.1389421394806
Grimaud obeyed without replying. An instant afterward, the white flag	451.52544343271416
was floating over the heads of the four friends. A thunder of applause	458.3476049209319
saluted its appearance; half the camp was at the barrier.	437.1911889317435
“How?” replied D’Artagnan, “you care little if she kills Buckingham or	313.77196018306336
causes him to be killed? But the duke is our friend.”	405.6873301143824
“The duke is English; the duke fights against us. Let her do what she	392.37073868746916
likes with the duke; I care no more about him than an empty bottle.”	335.06015979634384
And Athos threw fifteen paces from him an empty bottle from which he	358.828137610436
had poured the last drop into his glass.	411.634892439856
“A moment,” said D’Artagnan. “I will not abandon Buckingham thus. He	322.2101003547761
gave us some very fine horses.”	311.8841053930267
“And moreover, very handsome saddles,” said Porthos, who at the moment	415.6589348415899
wore on his cloak the lace of his own.	298.77771095467745
“Besides,” said Aramis, “God desires the conversion and not the death	346.58790488201043
of a sinner.”	413.0194248982308
“Amen!” said Athos, “and we will return to that subject later, if such	481.74833612500265
be your pleasure; but what for the moment engaged my attention most	379.588836765829
earnestly, and I am sure you will understand me, D’Artagnan, was the	312.83700989984374
getting from this woman a kind of _carte blanche_ which she had	488.92859489439854
extorted from the cardinal, and by means of which she could with	394.74092385286167
impunity get rid of you and perhaps of us.”	441.46285152459586
“But this creature must be a demon!” said Porthos, holding out his	441.05797383147
plate to Aramis, who was cutting up a fowl.	366.2159077603194
“And this _carte blanche_,” said D’Artagnan, “this _carte blanche_,	361.73696612392155
does it remain in her hands?”	447.4292829251123
“No, it passed into mine; I will not say without trouble, for if I did	366.3357306926024
I should tell a lie.”	485.993328476332
“My dear Athos, I shall no longer count the number of times I am	304.07168990629134
indebted to you for my life.”	420.11073360889225
“Then it was to go to her that you left us?” said Aramis.	298.12770314884534
“Exactly.”	474.29717288776123
“And you have that letter of the cardinal?” said D’Artagnan.	353.44409297711934
“Here it is,” said Athos; and he took the invaluable paper from the	330.11432880189494
pocket of his uniform. D’Artagnan unfolded it with one hand, whose	294.17963276057293
trembling he did not even attempt to conceal, to read:	296.53908309849936
“Dec. 3, 1627	460.8420006824893
“It is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of	442.39079709230316
this has done what he has done.	356.7505116696551
“RICHELIEU”	443.5406871879603
“In fact,” said Aramis, “it is an absolution according to rule.”	346.89477809765214
“That paper must be torn to pieces,” said D’Artagnan, who fancied he	425.83069677987885
read in it his sentence of death.	461.4850703105544
“On the contrary,” said Athos, “it must be preserved carefully. I would	311.10231232706343
not give up this paper if covered with as many gold pieces.”	315.348448853007
“And what will she do now?” asked the young man.	447.5436149548784
“Why,” replied Athos, carelessly, “she is probably going to write to	395.61369650008965
the cardinal that a damned Musketeer, named Athos, has taken her	464.9427422521311
safe-conduct from her by force; she will advise him in the same letter	367.5072317490818
to get rid of his two friends, Aramis and Porthos, at the same time.	293.3428996974911
The cardinal will remember that these are the same men who have often	473.3612624153942
crossed his path; and then some fine morning he will arrest D’Artagnan,	303.4853955341171
and for fear he should feel lonely, he will send us to keep him company	292.3904526839101
in the Bastille.”	445.22148200572303
“Go to! It appears to me you make dull jokes, my dear,” said Porthos.	401.4780560798827
“I do not jest,” said Athos.	452.0692775328015
“Do you know,” said Porthos, “that to twist that damned Milady’s neck	364.9980302216792
would be a smaller sin than to twist those of these poor devils of	297.32341188810784
Huguenots, who have committed no other crime than singing in French the	405.5218972912452
psalms we sing in Latin?”	351.2161001533923
“What says the abbé?” asked Athos, quietly.	331.04446535004445
“I say I am entirely of Porthos’s opinion,” replied Aramis.	327.8429480367556
“And I, too,” said D’Artagnan.	293.2467609375647
“Fortunately, she is far off,” said Porthos, “for I confess she would	362.4060498444554
worry me if she were here.”	390.82354476665483
“She worries me in England as well as in France,” said Athos.	365.3205238970005
“She worries me everywhere,” said D’Artagnan.	476.57000348535314
“But when you held her in your power, why did you not drown her,	298.75521192084534
strangle her, hang her?” said Porthos. “It is only the dead who do not	292.332265588492
return.”	436.513998239439
“You think so, Porthos?” replied the Musketeer, with a sad smile which	422.2393564779589
D’Artagnan alone understood.	375.0610135042222
“I have an idea,” said D’Artagnan.	460.51974209397656
“What is it?” said the Musketeers.	327.3093098002644
“To arms!” cried Grimaud.	434.4115994310327
The young men sprang up, and seized their muskets.	479.12273445576574
This time a small troop advanced, consisting of from twenty to	407.956774725645
twenty-five men; but they were not pioneers, they were soldiers of the	450.79474763865915
garrison.	400.68171230245014
“Shall we return to the camp?” said Porthos. “I don’t think the sides	470.5850589013975
are equal.”	419.7566859643427
“Impossible, for three reasons,” replied Athos. “The first, that we	482.8906056907167
have not finished breakfast; the second, that we still have some very	407.2237355428616
important things to say; and the third, that it yet wants ten minutes	434.0707553783489
before the lapse of the hour.”	484.7211748870334
“Well, then,” said Aramis, “we must form a plan of battle.”	407.5101678801798
“That’s very simple,” replied Athos. “As soon as the enemy are within	400.2445346329088
musket shot, we must fire upon them. If they continue to advance, we	309.3137325224613
must fire again. We must fire as long as we have loaded guns. If those	299.1055715185394
who remain of the troop persist in coming to the assault, we will allow	448.0245035523179
the besiegers to get as far as the ditch, and then we will push down	413.1880412962312
upon their heads that strip of wall which keeps its perpendicular by a	325.9401646808775
miracle.”	304.3760178057158
“Bravo!” cried Porthos. “Decidedly, Athos, you were born to be a	441.9511124081066
general, and the cardinal, who fancies himself a great soldier, is	349.4088315629004
nothing beside you.”	435.144206391921
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, “no divided attention, I beg; let each one	380.60968004738214
pick out his man.”	464.46764983583387
“I cover mine,” said D’Artagnan.	421.9418506384881
“And I mine,” said Porthos.	466.97770698652846
“And I _idem_,” said Aramis.	448.31251987773106
“Fire, then,” said Athos.	366.5711455578535
The four muskets made but one report, but four men fell.	444.7165376263078
The drum immediately beat, and the little troop advanced at charging	346.3666344197416
pace.	336.16409621007864
Then the shots were repeated without regularity, but always aimed with	391.82716811359256
the same accuracy. Nevertheless, as if they had been aware of the	373.1507803301331
numerical weakness of the friends, the Rochellais continued to advance	409.0736574841177
in quick time.	436.18009865125555
With every three shots at least two men fell; but the march of those	311.99713470517383
who remained was not slackened.	471.6781812757524
Arrived at the foot of the bastion, there were still more than a dozen	345.6960989744836
of the enemy. A last discharge welcomed them, but did not stop them;	327.75902458562683
they jumped into the ditch, and prepared to scale the breach.	365.3570908750263
“Now, my friends,” said Athos, “finish them at a blow. To the wall; to	488.3079750950993
the wall!”	476.701107609613
And the four friends, seconded by Grimaud, pushed with the barrels of	429.3058938858848
their muskets an enormous sheet of the wall, which bent as if pushed by	433.32713217665685
the wind, and detaching itself from its base, fell with a horrible	395.46959231929253
crash into the ditch. Then a fearful crash was heard; a cloud of dust	471.2419456192046
mounted toward the sky—and all was over!	478.35876950603756
“Can we have destroyed them all, from the first to the last?” said	405.1225106458718
Athos.	344.53172558241687
“My faith, it appears so!” said D’Artagnan.	476.34450950883445
“No,” cried Porthos; “there go three or four, limping away.”	310.48522507288726
In fact, three or four of these unfortunate men, covered with dirt and	325.54179245080246
blood, fled along the hollow way, and at length regained the city.	292.14937837459206
These were all who were left of the little troop.	305.4128677946478
Athos looked at his watch.	318.4822153385737
“Gentlemen,” said he, “we have been here an hour, and our wager is won;	485.6075339958215
but we will be fair players. Besides, D’Artagnan has not told us his	399.6615976960122
idea yet.”	297.72429604612125
And the Musketeer, with his usual coolness, reseated himself before the	445.56069254822773
remains of the breakfast.	447.2024980963394
“My idea?” said D’Artagnan.	325.59019957421293
“Yes; you said you had an idea,” said Athos.	387.37199405016344
“Oh, I remember,” said D’Artagnan. “Well, I will go to England a second	308.3555289542985
time; I will go and find Buckingham.”	307.19082252102976
“You shall not do that, D’Artagnan,” said Athos, coolly.	323.3310015012513
“And why not? Have I not been there once?”	381.633996492221
“Yes; but at that period we were not at war. At that period Buckingham	423.5549661223281
was an ally, and not an enemy. What you would now do amounts to	403.84572317787365
treason.”	325.92528188641523
D’Artagnan perceived the force of this reasoning, and was silent.	440.253907069054
“But,” said Porthos, “I think I have an idea, in my turn.”	371.6143355971451
“Silence for Monsieur Porthos’s idea!” said Aramis.	476.2820768484054
“I will ask leave of absence of Monsieur de Tréville, on some pretext	398.91183217412845
or other which you must invent; I am not very clever at pretexts.	347.0176220802394
Milady does not know me; I will get access to her without her	390.0061043770858
suspecting me, and when I catch my beauty, I will strangle her.”	348.2550414336607
“Well,” replied Athos, “I am not far from approving the idea of	328.0550370331192
Monsieur Porthos.”	481.59107676760004
“For shame!” said Aramis. “Kill a woman? No, listen to me; I have the	375.3074762451944
true idea.”	346.28744120689623
“Let us see your idea, Aramis,” said Athos, who felt much deference for	308.010235070175
the young Musketeer.	467.9486167058137
“We must inform the queen.”	376.9217772914154
“Ah, my faith, yes!” said Porthos and D’Artagnan, at the same time; “we	416.0817976327691
are coming nearer to it now.”	412.9932357782391
“Inform the queen!” said Athos; “and how? Have we relations with the	429.16610060974836
court? Could we send anyone to Paris without its being known in the	373.63374551594217
camp? From here to Paris it is a hundred and forty leagues; before our	462.24427750316954
letter was at Angers we should be in a dungeon.”	439.0858585278842
“As to remitting a letter with safety to her Majesty,” said Aramis,	418.0287764230699
coloring, “I will take that upon myself. I know a clever person at	413.40808821668287
Tours—”	398.90705344045176
Aramis stopped on seeing Athos smile.	349.73510962071066
“Well, do you not adopt this means, Athos?” said D’Artagnan.	419.8142173043986
“I do not reject it altogether,” said Athos; “but I wish to remind	485.1035071329072
Aramis that he cannot quit the camp, and that nobody but one of	385.89769618138587
ourselves is trustworthy; that two hours after the messenger has set	414.42671963926233
out, all the Capuchins, all the police, all the black caps of the	341.3332326793576
cardinal, will know your letter by heart, and you and your clever	479.24097353971325
person will be arrested.”	349.750567355717
“Without reckoning,” objected Porthos, “that the queen would save	446.9197825421441
Monsieur de Buckingham, but would take no heed of us.”	448.03652556393206
“Gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, “what Porthos says is full of sense.”	354.73174564808807
“Ah, ah! but what’s going on in the city yonder?” said Athos.	445.721993847507
“They are beating the general alarm.”	324.62484545024415
The four friends listened, and the sound of the drum plainly reached	425.062501132196
them.	470.94907787452917
“You see, they are going to send a whole regiment against us,” said	450.3409394293668
Athos.	439.36094482108
“You don’t think of holding out against a whole regiment, do you?” said	375.6189038675491
Porthos.	311.11648650621305
“Why not?” said the Musketeer. “I feel myself quite in a humor for it;	472.38929183651146
and I would hold out before an army if we had taken the precaution to	342.24116062601206
bring a dozen more bottles of wine.”	351.3617436144178
“Upon my word, the drum draws near,” said D’Artagnan.	350.26375976296043
“Let it come,” said Athos. “It is a quarter of an hour’s journey from	321.3990738854064
here to the city, consequently a quarter of an hour’s journey from the	302.6796663199515
city to hither. That is more than time enough for us to devise a plan.	353.5393512543161
If we go from this place we shall never find another so suitable. Ah,	379.7086801335953
stop! I have it, gentlemen; the right idea has just occurred to me.”	484.49730240053543
“Tell us.”	440.6250937456647
“Allow me to give Grimaud some indispensable orders.”	407.7195161589709
Athos made a sign for his lackey to approach.	474.4937336751689
“Grimaud,” said Athos, pointing to the bodies which lay under the wall	445.22120870110876
of the bastion, “take those gentlemen, set them up against the wall,	306.07515501217733
put their hats upon their heads, and their guns in their hands.”	347.40629661603197
“Oh, the great man!” cried D’Artagnan. “I comprehend now.”	478.006280091895
“You comprehend?” said Porthos.	403.07432787958294
“And do you comprehend, Grimaud?” said Aramis.	370.6764611136392
Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative.	295.1050359551485
“That’s all that is necessary,” said Athos; “now for my idea.”	435.8972123595904
“I should like, however, to comprehend,” said Porthos.	467.9160463216765
“That is useless.”	371.7644510644106
“Yes, yes! Athos’s idea!” cried Aramis and D’Artagnan, at the same	457.78988148044357
time.	383.20612421230584
“This Milady, this woman, this creature, this demon, has a	426.4655942279256
brother-in-law, as I think you told me, D’Artagnan?”	400.8353137292637
“Yes, I know him very well; and I also believe that he has not a very	450.2835727362831

“There is no harm in that. If he detested her, it would be all the	327.37163494329815

“In that case we are as well off as we wish.”	362.24458707295474
“And yet,” said Porthos, “I would like to know what Grimaud is about.”	414.91246008680986
“Silence, Porthos!” said Aramis.	361.16833045617295
“What is her brother-in-law’s name?”	344.29436787790905
“Lord de Winter.”	336.1308427040205
“Where is he now?”	325.0903999983652
“He returned to London at the first sound of war.”	479.22546537751833
“Well, there’s just the man we want,” said Athos. “It is he whom we	345.20898461564184
must warn. We will have him informed that his sister-in-law is on the	461.25803772317647
point of having someone assassinated, and beg him not to lose sight of	347.1703532438292

Magdalens, or of the Repentant Daughters. He must place his sister in	348.4644317149995
one of these, and we shall be in peace.”	312.41043573511024
“Yes,” said D’Artagnan, “till she comes out.”	355.35704850210936
“Ah, my faith!” said Athos, “you require too much, D’Artagnan. I have	397.6724372921851

“But I think it would be still better,” said Aramis, “to inform the	487.39659952248144
queen and Lord de Winter at the same time.”	304.16345851038164
“Yes; but who is to carry the letter to Tours, and who to London?”	344.6155022119758
“I answer for Bazin,” said Aramis.	349.895147126597
“And I for Planchet,” said D’Artagnan.	348.0346118592115
“Ay,” said Porthos, “if we cannot leave the camp, our lackeys may.”	401.16149960419926
“To be sure they may; and this very day we will write the letters,”	367.26747249429286
said Aramis. “Give the lackeys money, and they will start.”	391.7380077088328
“We will give them money?” replied Athos. “Have you any money?”	347.7198180412768
The four friends looked at one another, and a cloud came over the brows	423.4684452776538
which but lately had been so cheerful.	341.7335192954057
“Look out!” cried D’Artagnan, “I see black points and red points moving	385.8286043255429

“My faith, yes,” said Athos; “there they are. See the sneaks come,	448.97388633086075
without drum or trumpet. Ah, ah! have you finished, Grimaud?”	402.7866033020345
Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative, and pointed to a dozen bodies	458.9846242785136
which he had set up in the most picturesque attitudes. Some carried	351.89057937935024
arms, others seemed to be taking aim, and the remainder appeared merely	320.85919715512995
to be sword in hand.	325.3384423840947
“Bravo!” said Athos; “that does honor to your imagination.”	396.3813142144056
“All very well,” said Porthos, “but I should like to understand.”	303.2795125264145
“Let us decamp first, and you will understand afterward.”	427.8832583467292
“A moment, gentlemen, a moment; give Grimaud time to clear away the	401.1754363734036
breakfast.”	409.3556585339895
“Ah, ah!” said Aramis, “the black points and the red points are visibly	466.9061978069384
enlarging. I am of D’Artagnan’s opinion; we have no time to lose in	315.66485016240915
regaining our camp.”	474.5201116494378
“My faith,” said Athos, “I have nothing to say against a retreat. We	294.3726862860502
bet upon one hour, and we have stayed an hour and a half. Nothing can	349.0603667789659
be said; let us be off, gentlemen, let us be off!”	374.1716771677334
Grimaud was already ahead, with the basket and the dessert. The four	440.0692855981009
friends followed, ten paces behind him.	456.13371640289836
“What the devil shall we do now, gentlemen?” cried Athos.	340.8494007178032
“Have you forgotten anything?” said Aramis.	350.2324910445309
“The white flag, _morbleu!_ We must not leave a flag in the hands of	363.2329057900304
the enemy, even if that flag be but a napkin.”	475.37144105082064
And Athos ran back to the bastion, mounted the platform, and bore off	476.0036921335299
the flag; but as the Rochellais had arrived within musket range, they	415.10519176490806
opened a terrible fire upon this man, who appeared to expose himself	345.21127946108106
for pleasure’s sake.	349.1339838878586
But Athos might be said to bear a charmed life. The balls passed and	430.77021242556464
whistled all around him; not one struck him.	490.7919724621463
Athos waved his flag, turning his back on the guards of the city, and	347.4941747126828
saluting those of the camp. On both sides loud cries arose—on the one	412.9963103330592
side cries of anger, on the other cries of enthusiasm.	372.2028165576398
A second discharge followed the first, and three balls, by passing	346.5104974195656
through it, made the napkin really a flag. Cries were heard from the	467.1927173559366
camp, “Come down! come down!”	340.30244199912414
Athos came down; his friends, who anxiously awaited him, saw him	391.76329199174904
returned with joy.	432.1240061673276
“Come along, Athos, come along!” cried D’Artagnan; “now we have found	300.89044175152975
everything except money, it would be stupid to be killed.”	453.75436413557054
But Athos continued to march majestically, whatever remarks his	453.6727701702351
companions made; and they, finding their remarks useless, regulated	491.1936907779477
their pace by his.	409.60493085251557
Grimaud and his basket were far in advance, out of the range of the	446.7036936886831
balls.	425.583790186668
At the end of an instant they heard a furious fusillade.	483.3977140072242
“What’s that?” asked Porthos, “what are they firing at now? I hear no	311.01433849167074
balls whistle, and I see nobody!”	318.1073818626258
“They are firing at the corpses,” replied Athos.	457.44563859335625
“But the dead cannot return their fire.”	294.78138206395676
“Certainly not! They will then fancy it is an ambuscade, they will	440.4066127461363
deliberate; and by the time they have found out the pleasantry, we	350.9030455042693
shall be out of the range of their balls. That renders it useless to	378.29719669190945
get a pleurisy by too much haste.”	424.0448407171697
“Oh, I comprehend now,” said the astonished Porthos.	399.0869115350694
“That’s lucky,” said Athos, shrugging his shoulders.	388.58638024004654
On their part, the French, on seeing the four friends return at such a	455.97541382395434
step, uttered cries of enthusiasm.	319.8607735374006
At length a fresh discharge was heard, and this time the balls came	338.66787192385044
rattling among the stones around the four friends, and whistling	394.2739727479002
sharply in their ears. The Rochellais had at last taken possession of	319.76927932877106
the bastion.	326.2951236264306
“These Rochellais are bungling fellows,” said Athos; “how many have we	313.06051661057506
killed of them—a dozen?”	426.03590991119813
“Or fifteen.”	309.1338634652925
“How many did we crush under the wall?”	396.2840730200565
“Eight or ten.”	458.0390647928682
“And in exchange for all that not even a scratch! Ah, but what is the	294.19826562383156
matter with your hand, D’Artagnan? It bleeds, seemingly.”	304.48073635185125
“Oh, it’s nothing,” said D’Artagnan.	324.58045740425035
“A spent ball?”	350.77228563762213
“Not even that.”	424.9098621789991
“What is it, then?”	435.6410199716463
We have said that Athos loved D’Artagnan like a child, and this somber	435.98262575107344
and inflexible personage felt the anxiety of a parent for the young	353.42156776273737
man.	409.67536534058286
“Only grazed a little,” replied D’Artagnan; “my fingers were caught	403.6728465777695
between two stones—that of the wall and that of my ring—and the skin	320.58343685601443
was broken.”	330.4955263983327
“That comes of wearing diamonds, my master,” said Athos, disdainfully.	299.5781282105812
“Ah, to be sure,” cried Porthos, “there is a diamond. Why the devil,	448.4396700227787
then, do we plague ourselves about money, when there is a diamond?”	459.9258228055145
“Stop a bit!” said Aramis.	303.42165180017486
“Well thought of, Porthos; this time you have an idea.”	352.064598056557
“Undoubtedly,” said Porthos, drawing himself up at Athos’s compliment;	296.87584900652325
“as there is a diamond, let us sell it.”	428.20773024625333
“But,” said D’Artagnan, “it is the queen’s diamond.”	364.9685895961236
“The stronger reason why it should be sold,” replied Athos. “The queen	389.8319048039047
saving Monsieur de Buckingham, her lover; nothing more just. The queen	467.5411966978635
saving us, her friends; nothing more moral. Let us sell the diamond.	445.63444174459767
What says Monsieur the Abbé? I don’t ask Porthos; his opinion has been	472.8664203694575
given.”	394.850981050984
“Why, I think,” said Aramis, blushing as usual, “that his ring not	312.4913337229303
coming from a mistress, and consequently not being a love token,	339.47129589061404
D’Artagnan may sell it.”	386.0705440482183
“My dear Aramis, you speak like theology personified. Your advice,	306.70101778250097
then, is—”	491.8966712674954
“To sell the diamond,” replied Aramis.	357.24566409228305
“Well, then,” said D’Artagnan, gaily, “let us sell the diamond, and say	471.3277625703777
no more about it.”	332.6522655914738
The fusillade continued; but the four friends were out of reach, and	356.44974218819846
the Rochellais only fired to appease their consciences.	426.25324661622216
“My faith, it was time that idea came into Porthos’s head. Here we are	358.53589774084423
at the camp; therefore, gentlemen, not a word more of this affair. We	422.49292509205173
are observed; they are coming to meet us. We shall be carried in	430.10550953967265
triumph.”	384.9002357414482
In fact, as we have said, the whole camp was in motion. More than two	452.56742979553155
thousand persons had assisted, as at a spectacle, in this fortunate but	486.9235108362127
wild undertaking of the four friends—an undertaking of which they were	297.1041982566623
far from suspecting the real motive. Nothing was heard but cries of	478.44389379815436
“Live the Musketeers! Live the Guards!” M. de Busigny was the first to	364.9317105010348
come and shake Athos by the hand, and acknowledge that the wager was	475.4218067877863
lost. The dragoon and the Swiss followed him, and all their comrades	468.4956909147022
followed the dragoon and the Swiss. There was nothing but	382.01328853920336
felicitations, pressures of the hand, and embraces; there was no end to	458.1815205692686
the inextinguishable laughter at the Rochellais. The tumult at length	379.34413536819477
became so great that the cardinal fancied there must be some riot, and	440.6094769692438
sent La Houdinière, his captain of the Guards, to inquire what was	440.39149677856096
going on.	348.72740978232457
The affair was described to the messenger with all the effervescence of	368.9904685402239
enthusiasm.	310.5137571469926
“Well?” asked the cardinal, on seeing La Houdinière return.	305.81817447510235
“Well, monseigneur,” replied the latter, “three Musketeers and a	430.397953223822
Guardsman laid a wager with Monsieur de Busigny that they would go and	399.19278109083416
breakfast in the bastion St. Gervais; and while breakfasting they held	421.40531644818935
it for two hours against the enemy, and have killed I don’t know how	453.85681030226203
many Rochellais.”	394.4741131468678
“Did you inquire the names of those three Musketeers?”	341.39773822026433
“Yes, monseigneur.”	465.061211938247
“What are their names?”	341.2682505156994
“Messieurs Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.”	403.5238499962004
“Still my three brave fellows!” murmured the cardinal. “And the	306.5922835624932
Guardsman?”	444.2978251355957
“D’Artagnan.”	378.5490492226477
“Still my young scapegrace. Positively, these four men must be on my	454.30127817189964
side.”	372.6534367131745
The same evening the cardinal spoke to M. de Tréville of the exploit of	383.6643979285047
the morning, which was the talk of the whole camp. M. de Tréville, who	444.19581057947187
had received the account of the adventure from the mouths of the heroes	488.04978808619296
of it, related it in all its details to his Eminence, not forgetting	312.12190902579107
the episode of the napkin.	415.7942346155189
“That’s well, Monsieur de Tréville,” said the cardinal; “pray let that	312.65740378313313
napkin be sent to me. I will have three _fleur-de-lis_ embroidered on	306.94628629119427
it in gold, and will give it to your company as a standard.”	310.63354582323984
“Monseigneur,” said M. de Tréville, “that will be unjust to the	448.0532604050689
Guardsmen. Monsieur d’Artagnan is not with me; he serves under Monsieur	485.6673633904415
Dessessart.”	295.9841713821945
“Well, then, take him,” said the cardinal; “when four men are so much	377.02935619428536
attached to one another, it is only fair that they should serve in the	320.02539180717605
same company.”	465.6389601638527
That same evening M. de Tréville announced this good news to the three	413.75564251191366
Musketeers and D’Artagnan, inviting all four to breakfast with him next	442.28968588320345
morning.	324.3002797252733
D’Artagnan was beside himself with joy. We know that the dream of his	469.9414834124668
life had been to become a Musketeer. The three friends were likewise	461.1292843927256
greatly delighted.	373.1943578062036
“My faith,” said D’Artagnan to Athos, “you had a triumphant idea! As	372.77480991232005
you said, we have acquired glory, and were enabled to carry on a	306.2509425351237
conversation of the highest importance.”	332.18724967919104
“Which we can resume now without anybody suspecting us, for, with the	351.4160160976745
help of God, we shall henceforth pass for cardinalists.”	294.0622329662488
That evening D’Artagnan went to present his respects to M. Dessessart,	468.90401839178344
and inform him of his promotion.	439.8814590337266
