M. Dessessart, who esteemed D’Artagnan, made him offers of help, as	350.5261020016061
this change would entail expenses for equipment.	310.9857545590805
D’Artagnan refused; but thinking the opportunity a good one, he begged	373.0249357571546
him to have the diamond he put into his hand valued, as he wished to	359.28738164110445
turn it into money.	347.8575252680206
The next day, M. Dessessart’s valet came to D’Artagnan’s lodging, and	402.8776703515975
gave him a bag containing seven thousand livres.	327.4088314783229
This was the price of the queen’s diamond.	357.03077222404886
Chapter XLVIII.	315.9222059982449
A FAMILY AFFAIR	363.4279781998503
Athos had invented the phrase, family affair. A family affair was not	314.8630427455606
subject to the investigation of the cardinal; a family affair concerned	364.5831678017348
nobody. People might employ themselves in a family affair before all	339.45117645668915
the world. Therefore Athos had invented the phrase, _family affair_.	343.2269676046102
Aramis had discovered the idea, _the lackeys_.	428.2957299057201
Porthos had discovered the means, _the diamond_.	345.58738809960533
D’Artagnan alone had discovered nothing—he, ordinarily the most	491.5041842572893
inventive of the four; but it must be also said that the very name of	418.8952559664564
Milady paralyzed him.	337.17119949656205
Ah! no, we were mistaken; he had discovered a purchaser for his	370.6893573430123
diamond.	351.07404120178893
The breakfast at M. de Tréville’s was as gay and cheerful as possible.	491.22651488829797
D’Artagnan already wore his uniform—for being nearly of the same size	331.08413141949654
as Aramis, and as Aramis was so liberally paid by the publisher who	369.96916289629075
purchased his poem as to allow him to buy everything double, he sold	452.37221128265594
his friend a complete outfit.	425.7714752175914
D’Artagnan would have been at the height of his wishes if he had not	326.5176382110622
constantly seen Milady like a dark cloud hovering in the horizon.	312.4456149034948
After breakfast, it was agreed that they should meet again in the	317.1922101781797
evening at Athos’s lodging, and there finish their plans.	330.24813934952516
D’Artagnan passed the day in exhibiting his Musketeer’s uniform in	440.5560278755802
every street of the camp.	350.9118894410703
In the evening, at the appointed hour, the four friends met. There only	297.066283179823
remained three things to decide—what they should write to Milady’s	469.76681090294187
brother; what they should write to the clever person at Tours; and	466.65220127016175
which should be the lackeys to carry the letters.	417.44723625673583
Everyone offered his own. Athos talked of the discretion of Grimaud,	337.2503242703724
who never spoke a word but when his master unlocked his mouth. Porthos	413.4532726761214
boasted of the strength of Mousqueton, who was big enough to thrash	338.4504408073493
four men of ordinary size. Aramis, confiding in the address of Bazin,	414.3077314002335
made a pompous eulogium on his candidate. Finally, D’Artagnan had	341.93209600936524
entire faith in the bravery of Planchet, and reminded them of the	467.2988582211807
manner in which he had conducted himself in the ticklish affair of	485.89766316723484
Boulogne.	403.42818916030467
These four virtues disputed the prize for a length of time, and gave	468.4019863400388
birth to magnificent speeches which we do not repeat here for fear they	372.79605556164944
should be deemed too long.	307.8143437659045
“Unfortunately,” said Athos, “he whom we send must possess in himself	470.97942855264165
alone the four qualities united.”	446.79928481871934
“But where is such a lackey to be found?”	324.16244446918375
“Not to be found!” cried Athos. “I know it well, so take Grimaud.”	425.4573034737692
“Take Mousqueton.”	424.3127351112247
“Take Bazin.”	435.49991142719614
“Take Planchet. Planchet is brave and shrewd; they are two qualities	377.3303593818552
out of the four.”	385.478806129904
“Gentlemen,” said Aramis, “the principal question is not to know which	457.65863245951135
of our four lackeys is the most discreet, the most strong, the most	439.95958446486316
clever, or the most brave; the principal thing is to know which loves	315.4559374521634
money the best.”	355.03138612200826
“What Aramis says is very sensible,” replied Athos; “we must speculate	479.79638929258385
upon the faults of people, and not upon their virtues. Monsieur Abbé,	320.07170282033013
you are a great moralist.”	466.06539098553446
“Doubtless,” said Aramis, “for we not only require to be well served in	462.6739605694438
order to succeed, but moreover, not to fail; for in case of failure,	425.03865137505755
heads are in question, not for our lackeys—”	489.6675854900904
“Speak lower, Aramis,” said Athos.	415.0238080070812
“That’s wise—not for the lackeys,” resumed Aramis, “but for the	350.5443987031175
master—for the _masters_, we may say. Are our lackeys sufficiently	440.9647232377075
devoted to us to risk their lives for us? No.”	388.2287864558717
“My faith,” said D’Artagnan. “I would almost answer for Planchet.”	386.2596232247017
“Well, my dear friend, add to his natural devotedness a good sum of	409.77981422635713
money, and then, instead of answering for him once, answer for him	327.6770760125697
twice.”	395.28031412260736
“Why, good God! you will be deceived just the same,” said Athos, who	464.1824514141507
was an optimist when things were concerned, and a pessimist when men	375.0746875679559
were in question. “They will promise everything for the sake of the	332.74350692269826
money, and on the road fear will prevent them from acting. Once taken,	426.6382421477025
they will be pressed; when pressed, they will confess everything. What	449.77100006877095
the devil! we are not children. To reach England”—Athos lowered his	299.4422810346596
voice—“all France, covered with spies and creatures of the cardinal,	348.81030615789365
must be crossed. A passport for embarkation must be obtained; and the	413.8575126258832
party must be acquainted with English in order to ask the way to	357.47876873468334
London. Really, I think the thing very difficult.”	474.4743557676236
“Not at all,” cried D’Artagnan, who was anxious the matter should be	487.73014957155044
accomplished; “on the contrary, I think it very easy. It would be, no	429.59322063182276
doubt, _parbleu_, if we write to Lord de Winter about affairs of vast	486.82146094935933
importance, of the horrors of the cardinal—”	336.0225946953596
“Speak lower!” said Athos.	322.23712239592703
“—of intrigues and secrets of state,” continued D’Artagnan, complying	385.17610154296
with the recommendation. “There can be no doubt we would all be broken	344.781944789149
on the wheel; but for God’s sake, do not forget, as you yourself said,	449.71340792713204
Athos, that we only write to him concerning a family affair; that we	319.8164468353526
only write to him to entreat that as soon as Milady arrives in London	425.024041715163
he will put it out of her power to injure us. I will write to him,	337.2494213873175
then, nearly in these terms.”	429.88091094771653
“Let us see,” said Athos, assuming in advance a critical look.	431.02390540062925
“_Monsieur and dear friend_—”	292.528719080488
“Ah, yes! _Dear friend_ to an Englishman,” interrupted Athos; “well	378.41692025521354
commenced! Bravo, D’Artagnan! Only with that word you would be	297.5420349766428
quartered instead of being broken on the wheel.”	484.54125510517014
“Well, perhaps. I will say, then, _Monsieur_, quite short.”	430.76852343302085
“You may even say, _My Lord_,” replied Athos, who stickled for	361.05455458960955
propriety.	405.7746137515544
“_My Lord, do you remember the little goat pasture of the Luxembourg?_”	443.7494414260275
“Good, _the Luxembourg!_ One might believe this is an allusion to the	401.48830707968364
queen-mother! That’s ingenious,” said Athos.	491.11407239445197
“Well, then, we will put simply, _My Lord, do you remember a certain	388.7869039562157
little enclosure where your life was spared?_”	314.9538628099981
“My dear D’Artagnan, you will never make anything but a very bad	418.14220012987755
secretary. _Where your life was spared!_ For shame! that’s unworthy. A	437.42762300818316
man of spirit is not to be reminded of such services. A benefit	370.4743840563433
reproached is an offense committed.”	321.25143719899387
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan, “you are insupportable. If the letter	489.34338594595397
must be written under your censure, my faith, I renounce the task.”	393.00764302576863
“And you will do right. Handle the musket and the sword, my dear	471.85643621358724
fellow. You will come off splendidly at those two exercises; but pass	425.5742376559822
the pen over to Monsieur Abbé. That’s his province.”	398.28017716387467
“Ay, ay!” said Porthos; “pass the pen to Aramis, who writes theses in	305.37174165876064
Latin.”	424.38791730911635
“Well, so be it,” said D’Artagnan. “Draw up this note for us, Aramis;	428.50188474867514
but by our Holy Father the Pope, cut it short, for I shall prune you in	398.04685131952095
my turn, I warn you.”	312.4622321491464
“I ask no better,” said Aramis, with that ingenious air of confidence	364.77866996705063
which every poet has in himself; “but let me be properly acquainted	472.2737059715769
with the subject. I have heard here and there that this sister-in-law	370.9025993005018
was a hussy. I have obtained proof of it by listening to her	490.50692109618484
conversation with the cardinal.”	477.9511731627865
“Lower! _sacré bleu!_” said Athos.	417.4611726989156
“But,” continued Aramis, “the details escape me.”	417.3248490861499
“And me also,” said Porthos.	341.0873234449246
D’Artagnan and Athos looked at each other for some time in silence. At	319.5088164701276
length Athos, after serious reflection and becoming more pale than	298.2955561118103
usual, made a sign of assent to D’Artagnan, who by it understood he was	371.73076085349214
at liberty to speak.	377.6732963619454
“Well, this is what you have to say,” said D’Artagnan: “_My Lord, your	457.0551287902511
sister-in-law is an infamous woman, who wished to have you killed that	403.09348720243474
she might inherit your wealth; but she could not marry your brother,	324.5104327530704
being already married in France, and having been_—” D’Artagnan stopped,	296.69088424561744
as if seeking for the word, and looked at Athos.	420.6283209640326
“Repudiated by her husband,” said Athos.	307.93808683060513
“Because she had been branded,” continued D’Artagnan.	414.4265544133509
“Bah!” cried Porthos. “Impossible! What do you say—that she wanted to	442.37873942849023
have her brother-in-law killed?”	423.90709164604345
“Yes.”	297.9835005436198
“She was married?” asked Aramis.	486.4083680045609
“Yes.”	484.9602922863015
“And her husband found out that she had a _fleur-de-lis_ on her	429.28917582603043
shoulder?” cried Porthos.	314.007878439089
“Yes.”	367.62543836342957
These three _yeses_ had been pronounced by Athos, each with a sadder	378.58494123904524
intonation.	322.5670627412968
“And who has seen this _fleur-de-lis?_” inquired Aramis.	354.23590043162227
“D’Artagnan and I. Or rather, to observe the chronological order, I and	445.9236116849794
D’Artagnan,” replied Athos.	309.91190463894634
“And does the husband of this frightful creature still live?” said	330.259343672492
Aramis.	373.7213926131386
“He still lives.”	343.2357273321718
“Are you quite sure of it?”	398.88647585660317
“I am he.”	449.06881637685103
There was a moment of cold silence, during which everyone was affected	297.09154000082646
according to his nature.	388.6798322932997
“This time,” said Athos, first breaking the silence, “D’Artagnan has	329.6040476858253
given us an excellent program, and the letter must be written at once.”	385.2118810381817
“The devil! You are right, Athos,” said Aramis; “and it is a rather	477.1355094706755
difficult matter. The chancellor himself would be puzzled how to write	434.97333924147927
such a letter, and yet the chancellor draws up an official report very	410.6855307985607
readily. Never mind! Be silent, I will write.”	445.0439995568112
Aramis accordingly took the quill, reflected for a few moments, wrote	343.7781438995019
eight or ten lines in a charming little female hand, and then with a	347.53126515424134
voice soft and slow, as if each word had been scrupulously weighed, he	428.91660070876696
read the following:	481.46681795797053
“My Lord, The person who writes these few lines had the honor of	355.74559308921874
crossing swords with you in the little enclosure of the Rue d’Enfer. As	425.1496522354477
you have several times since declared yourself the friend of that	364.2554917772889
person, he thinks it his duty to respond to that friendship by sending	309.0874744594262
you important information. Twice you have nearly been the victim of a	311.86123252247216
near relative, whom you believe to be your heir because you are	430.64117620588615
ignorant that before she contracted a marriage in England she was	411.32686087881507
already married in France. But the third time, which is the present,	466.7515187520821
you may succumb. Your relative left La Rochelle for England during the	450.319613412641
night. Watch her arrival, for she has great and terrible projects. If	447.01022215626983
you require to know positively what she is capable of, read her past	329.2526794559716
history on her left shoulder.”	490.93905895957
“Well, now that will do wonderfully well,” said Athos. “My dear Aramis,	344.79920967551186
you have the pen of a secretary of state. Lord de Winter will now be	305.5201854269935
upon his guard if the letter should reach him; and even if it should	306.6328076611399
fall into the hands of the cardinal, we shall not be compromised. But	320.6220414081783
as the lackey who goes may make us believe he has been to London and	399.4041106006727
may stop at Châtellerault, let us give him only half the sum promised	424.42682855302587
him, with the letter, with an agreement that he shall have the other	414.03677172245443
half in exchange for the reply. Have you the diamond?” continued Athos.	395.4533161659347
“I have what is still better. I have the price;” and D’Artagnan threw	361.14787598603715
the bag upon the table. At the sound of the gold Aramis raised his eyes	363.837501314847
and Porthos started. As to Athos, he remained unmoved.	320.0547710638298
“How much in that little bag?”	293.4429789098682
“Seven thousand livres, in louis of twelve francs.”	335.57586957560324
“Seven thousand livres!” cried Porthos. “That poor little diamond was	474.8225800916392
worth seven thousand livres?”	457.284914252091
“It appears so,” said Athos, “since here they are. I don’t suppose that	387.07912720122204
our friend D’Artagnan has added any of his own to the amount.”	488.48351302301944
“But, gentlemen, in all this,” said D’Artagnan, “we do not think of the	457.33836509151934
queen. Let us take some heed of the welfare of her dear Buckingham.	326.3702442640031
That is the least we owe her.”	387.9307917645477
“That’s true,” said Athos; “but that concerns Aramis.”	422.0140452780572
“Well,” replied the latter, blushing, “what must I say?”	317.1570361259953
“Oh, that’s simple enough!” replied Athos. “Write a second letter for	294.1275741959617
that clever personage who lives at Tours.”	457.52311456709157
Aramis resumed his pen, reflected a little, and wrote the following	437.7999465920603
lines, which he immediately submitted to the approbation of his	300.6719846116143
friends.	316.77379128281046
“_My dear cousin_.”	360.4225232939409
“Ah, ah!” said Athos. “This clever person is your relative, then?”	449.8416738243293
“Cousin-german.”	327.7602107787059
“Go on, to your cousin, then!”	304.02142364245606
Aramis continued:	371.08284160990456
“MY DEAR COUSIN, His Eminence, the cardinal, whom God preserve for the	330.78348319278587
happiness of France and the confusion of the enemies of the kingdom, is	448.8609906088134
on the point of putting an end to the hectic rebellion of La Rochelle.	360.9319615627885
It is probable that the succor of the English fleet will never even	354.1799299981383
arrive in sight of the place. I will even venture to say that I am	482.9941163287524
certain M. de Buckingham will be prevented from setting out by some	306.09715346599387
great event. His Eminence is the most illustrious politician of times	436.35220445019627
past, of times present, and probably of times to come. He would	387.3179102527312
extinguish the sun if the sun incommoded him. Give these happy tidings	400.16161058609674
to your sister, my dear cousin. I have dreamed that the unlucky	382.3322949848299
Englishman was dead. I cannot recollect whether it was by steel or by	478.11166633259154
poison; only of this I am sure, I have dreamed he was dead, and you	455.39833932595434
know my dreams never deceive me. Be assured, then, of seeing me soon	454.7551215739976
return.”	479.5588389218431
“Capital!” cried Athos; “you are the king of poets, my dear Aramis. You	419.31434522940856
speak like the Apocalypse, and you are as true as the Gospel. There is	344.44971086615357
nothing now to do but to put the address to this letter.”	350.8312433453242
“That is easily done,” said Aramis.	333.4388076593669
He folded the letter fancifully, and took up his pen and wrote:	374.54547593461353
“_To Mlle. Michon, seamstress, Tours_.”	485.43418551703905
The three friends looked at one another and laughed; they were caught.	465.66660732497166
“Now,” said Aramis, “you will please to understand, gentlemen, that	324.32666934462765
Bazin alone can carry this letter to Tours. My cousin knows nobody but	445.6195283233502
Bazin, and places confidence in nobody but him; any other person would	461.2207031558272
fail. Besides, Bazin is ambitious and learned; Bazin has read history,	333.7276252358311
gentlemen, he knows that Sixtus the Fifth became Pope after having kept	356.79898509854013
pigs. Well, as he means to enter the Church at the same time as myself,	351.6314542562276
he does not despair of becoming Pope in his turn, or at least a	292.8440769451478
cardinal. You can understand that a man who has such views will never	465.5683593990527
allow himself to be taken, or if taken, will undergo martyrdom rather	408.0633424008343
than speak.”	485.6440389803428
“Very well,” said D’Artagnan, “I consent to Bazin with all my heart,	438.5122251025539
but grant me Planchet. Milady had him one day turned out of doors, with	324.85747292359764
sundry blows of a good stick to accelerate his motions. Now, Planchet	491.71618874436535
has an excellent memory; and I will be bound that sooner than	466.5231595874414
relinquish any possible means of vengeance, he will allow himself to be	420.2334184826609
beaten to death. If your arrangements at Tours are your arrangements,	322.4493577821829
Aramis, those of London are mine. I request, then, that Planchet may be	372.02186983435547
chosen, more particularly as he has already been to London with me, and	307.3822376186318
knows how to speak correctly: _London, sir, if you please, and my	309.4563888824211
master, Lord D’Artagnan_. With that you may be satisfied he can make	338.6251067132227
his way, both going and returning.”	345.00161217444327
“In that case,” said Athos, “Planchet must receive seven hundred livres	435.5917075759178
for going, and seven hundred livres for coming back; and Bazin, three	448.8754529455215
hundred livres for going, and three hundred livres for returning—that	304.3077740020592
will reduce the sum to five thousand livres. We will each take a	337.9600276482208
thousand livres to be employed as seems good, and we will leave a fund	338.5943418266638
of a thousand livres under the guardianship of Monsieur Abbé here, for	427.0657094767164
extraordinary occasions or common wants. Will that do?”	351.6101772202758
“My dear Athos,” said Aramis, “you speak like Nestor, who was, as	476.2791646226992
everyone knows, the wisest among the Greeks.”	292.04786314513285
“Well, then,” said Athos, “it is agreed. Planchet and Bazin shall go.	449.1788537022124
Everything considered, I am not sorry to retain Grimaud; he is	404.94521882652634
accustomed to my ways, and I am particular. Yesterday’s affair must	439.4359526437341
have shaken him a little; his voyage would upset him quite.”	371.44300388039466
Planchet was sent for, and instructions were given him. The matter had	446.4643746976342
been named to him by D’Artagnan, who in the first place pointed out the	379.6166699948027
money to him, then the glory, and then the danger.	457.62823298343613
“I will carry the letter in the lining of my coat,” said Planchet; “and	326.6048799308284
if I am taken I will swallow it.”	449.92695787861055
“Well, but then you will not be able to fulfill your commission,” said	397.7810918333546
D’Artagnan.	354.70573693614574
“You will give me a copy this evening, which I shall know by heart	301.9639369883155
tomorrow.”	460.36548427857747
D’Artagnan looked at his friends, as if to say, “Well, what did I tell	296.8251024907791
you?”	487.1566163194296
“Now,” continued he, addressing Planchet, “you have eight days to get	326.2712562591987
an interview with Lord de Winter; you have eight days to return—in all	360.4472029897774
sixteen days. If, on the sixteenth day after your departure, at eight	317.1814740368329
o’clock in the evening you are not here, no money—even if it be but	418.7433685009484
five minutes past eight.”	356.1474686707208
“Then, monsieur,” said Planchet, “you must buy me a watch.”	324.35658469548844
“Take this,” said Athos, with his usual careless generosity, giving him	348.8637088355417
his own, “and be a good lad. Remember, if you talk, if you babble, if	436.5725541246412
you get drunk, you risk your master’s head, who has so much confidence	470.67091025876744
in your fidelity, and who answers for you. But remember, also, that if	416.1028452726744
by your fault any evil happens to D’Artagnan, I will find you, wherever	361.98862482320067
you may be, for the purpose of ripping up your belly.”	487.3956837482444
“Oh, monsieur!” said Planchet, humiliated by the suspicion, and	321.6735585168837
moreover, terrified at the calm air of the Musketeer.	400.42489590276045
“And I,” said Porthos, rolling his large eyes, “remember, I will skin	293.60772867706123
you alive.”	332.6294431819927
“Ah, monsieur!”	319.1163108219857
“And I,” said Aramis, with his soft, melodius voice, “remember that I	330.0570676974735
will roast you at a slow fire, like a savage.”	438.35257260443825
“Ah, monsieur!”	318.3907562343194
Planchet began to weep. We will not venture to say whether it was from	298.99603928833636
terror created by the threats or from tenderness at seeing four friends	464.4160968220567
so closely united.	313.45668195315073
D’Artagnan took his hand. “See, Planchet,” said he, “these gentlemen	413.7564768135117
only say this out of affection for me, but at bottom they all like	433.27510377477256
you.”	474.21467148931373
“Ah, monsieur,” said Planchet, “I will succeed or I will consent to be	373.87967567011646
cut in quarters; and if they do cut me in quarters, be assured that not	379.69082259628084
a morsel of me will speak.”	336.0696561351744
It was decided that Planchet should set out the next day, at eight	454.56313073955516
o’clock in the morning, in order, as he had said, that he might during	365.1344232789111
the night learn the letter by heart. He gained just twelve hours by	407.88736303371667
this engagement; he was to be back on the sixteenth day, by eight	323.4422796485278
o’clock in the evening.	311.98694885020603
In the morning, as he was mounting his horse, D’Artagnan, who felt at	301.26233163026035
the bottom of his heart a partiality for the duke, took Planchet aside.	470.74749031955605
“Listen,” said he to him. “When you have given the letter to Lord de	439.44797072286735
Winter and he has read it, you will further say to him: _Watch over his	299.72069498863414
Grace Lord Buckingham, for they wish to assassinate him_. But this,	324.8607115603638
Planchet, is so serious and important that I have not informed my	491.56068467693484
friends that I would entrust this secret to you; and for a captain’s	460.30550798228217
commission I would not write it.”	461.6863965133401
“Be satisfied, monsieur,” said Planchet, “you shall see if confidence	466.79727289310676
can be placed in me.”	375.6120468925172
Mounted on an excellent horse, which he was to leave at the end of	335.6352407743216
twenty leagues in order to take the post, Planchet set off at a gallop,	325.3815757734345
his spirits a little depressed by the triple promise made him by the	452.7724990663836
Musketeers, but otherwise as light-hearted as possible.	458.2318745687275
Bazin set out the next day for Tours, and was allowed eight days for	402.7316816276814
performing his commission.	350.28682761775644
The four friends, during the period of these two absences, had, as may	368.8909609151263
well be supposed, the eye on the watch, the nose to the wind, and the	416.8159916165961
ear on the hark. Their days were passed in endeavoring to catch all	424.8944572121104
that was said, in observing the proceeding of the cardinal, and in	302.3703141846515
looking out for all the couriers who arrived. More than once an	390.6882622894874
involuntary trembling seized them when called upon for some unexpected	393.0143696195114
service. They had, besides, to look constantly to their own proper	455.2522383404779
safety; Milady was a phantom which, when it had once appeared to	364.4837109806949
people, did not allow them to sleep very quietly.	333.68506471845313
On the morning of the eighth day, Bazin, fresh as ever, and smiling,	339.2437681407014
according to custom, entered the cabaret of the Parpaillot as the four	322.1173472465583
friends were sitting down to breakfast, saying, as had been agreed	404.0067639940332
upon: “Monsieur Aramis, the answer from your cousin.”	440.559423960095
The four friends exchanged a joyful glance; half of the work was done.	395.7253272122463
It is true, however, that it was the shorter and easier part.	363.8878474369604
Aramis, blushing in spite of himself, took the letter, which was in a	475.3522631751498
large, coarse hand and not particular for its orthography.	381.5055796472502
“Good God!” cried he, laughing, “I quite despair of my poor Michon; she	373.8104600608692
will never write like Monsieur de Voiture.”	321.00157278502303
“What does you mean by boor Michon?” said the Swiss, who was chatting	380.4531277322741
with the four friends when the letter came.	390.33927876370126
“Oh, _pardieu_, less than nothing,” said Aramis; “a charming little	447.885805959353
seamstress, whom I love dearly and from whose hand I requested a few	355.8358185288665
lines as a sort of keepsake.”	404.9133449469774
“The duvil!” said the Swiss, “if she is as great a lady as her writing	454.75316342006215
is large, you are a lucky fellow, gomrade!”	384.24091455062074
Aramis read the letter, and passed it to Athos.	472.9184978352372
“See what she writes to me, Athos,” said he.	420.74823747127016
Athos cast a glance over the epistle, and to disperse all the	345.79668915603645
suspicions that might have been created, read aloud:	308.035993770574
“MY COUSIN, My sister and I are skillful in interpreting dreams, and	436.1503460718777
even entertain great fear of them; but of yours it may be said, I hope,	375.0714601702142
every dream is an illusion. Adieu! Take care of yourself, and act so	413.44529139235914
that we may from time to time hear you spoken of.	383.856352849207
“MARIE MICHON”	375.86059401774037
“And what dream does she mean?” asked the dragoon, who had approached	377.9724256935111
during the reading.	443.9072824339571
“Yez; what’s the dream?” said the Swiss.	371.6384712066908
“Well, _pardieu!_” said Aramis, “it was only this: I had a dream, and I	345.81245376759404
related it to her.”	417.22300212329685
“Yez, yez,” said the Swiss; “it’s simple enough to dell a dream, but I	478.46704698730343
neffer dream.”	445.9137714844181
“You are very fortunate,” said Athos, rising; “I wish I could say as	477.02417309872027
much!”	485.21807994904793
“Neffer,” replied the Swiss, enchanted that a man like Athos could envy	328.91894133648606
him anything. “Neffer, neffer!”	386.72891100295146
D’Artagnan, seeing Athos rise, did likewise, took his arm, and went	477.51779628665616
out.	339.1679257096481
Porthos and Aramis remained behind to encounter the jokes of the	465.06127487470417
dragoon and the Swiss.	315.21566081488135
As to Bazin, he went and lay down on a truss of straw; and as he had	357.7144747791494
more imagination than the Swiss, he dreamed that Aramis, having become	349.09872346551884
pope, adorned his head with a cardinal’s hat.	405.31954466868547
But, as we have said, Bazin had not, by his fortunate return, removed	401.80474869197997
more than a part of the uneasiness which weighed upon the four friends.	484.39904769373584
The days of expectation are long, and D’Artagnan, in particular, would	328.8020566631252
have wagered that the days were forty-four hours. He forgot the	393.181165130925
necessary slowness of navigation; he exaggerated to himself the power	335.2595275194782
of Milady. He credited this woman, who appeared to him the equal of a	295.560985516185
demon, with agents as supernatural as herself; at the least noise, he	371.72204810515643
imagined himself about to be arrested, and that Planchet was being	352.1094326622479
brought back to be confronted with himself and his friends. Still	462.96242419501596
further, his confidence in the worthy Picard, at one time so great,	438.3847439246969
diminished day by day. This anxiety became so great that it even	417.6421554741922
extended to Aramis and Porthos. Athos alone remained unmoved, as if no	436.68916987161356
danger hovered over him, and as if he breathed his customary	455.20974884807174
atmosphere.	484.0035460610518
On the sixteenth day, in particular, these signs were so strong in	393.9831955404474
D’Artagnan and his two friends that they could not remain quiet in one	311.38712723334334
place, and wandered about like ghosts on the road by which Planchet was	417.4069291348086
expected.	425.7438952030012
“Really,” said Athos to them, “you are not men but children, to let a	471.16672579202657
woman terrify you so! And what does it amount to, after all? To be	444.1280150601321
imprisoned. Well, but we should be taken out of prison; Madame	313.64843322139757
Bonacieux was released. To be decapitated? Why, every day in the	439.1354793107044
trenches we go cheerfully to expose ourselves to worse than that—for a	359.7558253723832
bullet may break a leg, and I am convinced a surgeon would give us more	486.5148823638674
pain in cutting off a thigh than an executioner in cutting off a head.	305.9127929886178
Wait quietly, then; in two hours, in four, in six hours at latest,	386.9096936808595
Planchet will be here. He promised to be here, and I have very great	463.8493428782609
faith in Planchet, who appears to me to be a very good lad.”	367.2340075318037
“But if he does not come?” said D’Artagnan.	349.8043681989032
“Well, if he does not come, it will be because he has been delayed,	365.9195617679869
that’s all. He may have fallen from his horse, he may have cut a caper	389.5131386903801
from the deck; he may have traveled so fast against the wind as to have	365.0637496223667
brought on a violent catarrh. Eh, gentlemen, let us reckon upon	329.57132573562353
accidents! Life is a chaplet of little miseries which the philosopher	476.62367299889473
counts with a smile. Be philosophers, as I am, gentlemen; sit down at	454.7301010607157
the table and let us drink. Nothing makes the future look so bright as	443.88449571408336
surveying it through a glass of chambertin.”	446.38410940598266
“That’s all very well,” replied D’Artagnan; “but I am tired of fearing	362.5834561857049
when I open a fresh bottle that the wine may come from the cellar of	362.4466393453855
Milady.”	347.0663661550052
“You are very fastidious,” said Athos; “such a beautiful woman!”	477.80053204334774
“A woman of mark!” said Porthos, with his loud laugh.	356.93296305099426
Athos started, passed his hand over his brow to remove the drops of	387.4628204175295
perspiration that burst forth, and rose in his turn with a nervous	313.2688809312102
movement he could not repress.	367.9540586026111
The day, however, passed away; and the evening came on slowly, but	365.8212073009201
finally it came. The bars were filled with drinkers. Athos, who had	469.48743734059997
pocketed his share of the diamond, seldom quit the Parpaillot. He had	304.74651521805276
found in M. de Busigny, who, by the by, had given them a magnificent	375.1123832583979
dinner, a partner worthy of his company. They were playing together, as	328.8345032110663
usual, when seven o’clock sounded; the patrol was heard passing to	384.23293640106976
double the posts. At half past seven the retreat was sounded.	457.9933350429279
“We are lost,” said D’Artagnan, in the ear of Athos.	349.8481670031315
“You mean to say we _have lost_,” said Athos, quietly, drawing four	316.4910413199548
pistoles from his pocket and throwing them upon the table. “Come,	309.7682178735122
gentlemen,” said he, “they are beating the tattoo. Let us to bed!”	342.5603886621503
And Athos went out of the Parpaillot, followed by D’Artagnan. Aramis	419.3303427307534
came behind, giving his arm to Porthos. Aramis mumbled verses to	411.7522762816611
himself, and Porthos from time to time pulled a hair or two from his	401.64047923913057
mustache, in sign of despair.	381.5310351395919
But all at once a shadow appeared in the darkness the outline of which	421.4035989718914
was familiar to D’Artagnan, and a well-known voice said, “Monsieur, I	422.98068622287974
have brought your cloak; it is chilly this evening.”	432.77739983018785
“Planchet!” cried D’Artagnan, beside himself with joy.	416.70974669403415
“Planchet!” repeated Aramis and Porthos.	407.7522645462059
“Well, yes, Planchet, to be sure,” said Athos, “what is there so	405.2447215525831
astonishing in that? He promised to be back by eight o’clock, and eight	347.9741785900715
is striking. Bravo, Planchet, you are a lad of your word, and if ever	321.7309983057161
you leave your master, I will promise you a place in my service.”	409.48587849873945
“Oh, no, never,” said Planchet, “I will never leave Monsieur	423.88791799119997
d’Artagnan.”	419.1932097431112
At the same time D’Artagnan felt that Planchet slipped a note into his	297.27408253360073
hand.	404.56827181951314
D’Artagnan felt a strong inclination to embrace Planchet as he had	296.97074411054035
embraced him on his departure; but he feared lest this mark of	315.89261744555154
affection, bestowed upon his lackey in the open street, might appear	366.3440130683225
extraordinary to passers-by, and he restrained himself.	312.2908110258277
“I have the note,” said he to Athos and to his friends.	490.97184311326475
“That’s well,” said Athos, “let us go home and read it.”	447.8507370591867
The note burned the hand of D’Artagnan. He wished to hasten their	401.69730062115883
steps; but Athos took his arm and passed it under his own, and the	370.34868328856317
young man was forced to regulate his pace by that of his friend.	385.87431768264065
At length they reached the tent, lit a lamp, and while Planchet stood	382.11250462317776
at the entrance that the four friends might not be surprised,	358.7906596000247
D’Artagnan, with a trembling hand, broke the seal and opened the so	297.8603754287303
anxiously expected letter.	438.08379649185133
It contained half a line, in a hand perfectly British, and with a	294.1193513248277
conciseness as perfectly Spartan:	305.8697763327454
_Thank you; be easy_.	379.8834051678547
D’Artagnan translated this for the others.	353.0803456699306
Athos took the letter from the hands of D’Artagnan, approached the	477.82941440974923
lamp, set fire to the paper, and did not let go till it was reduced to	314.5828325357362
a cinder.	346.76123823142757
Then, calling Planchet, he said, “Now, my lad, you may claim your seven	336.9613635575434
hundred livres, but you did not run much risk with such a note as	479.3589116358402
that.”	339.06199342579487
“I am not to blame for having tried every means to compress it,” said	348.9903559746285
Planchet.	411.92730303025024
“Well!” cried D’Artagnan, “tell us all about it.”	442.26964832683814
“_Dame_, that’s a long job, monsieur.”	434.4855405980001
“You are right, Planchet,” said Athos; “besides, the tattoo has been	404.43631321044336
sounded, and we should be observed if we kept a light burning much	332.68834501174047
longer than the others.”	382.69757586452107
“So be it,” said D’Artagnan. “Go to bed, Planchet, and sleep soundly.”	321.33051283872305
“My faith, monsieur! that will be the first time I have done so for	326.6421074528914
sixteen days.”	308.51836092056834
“And me, too!” said D’Artagnan.	373.9512663698119
“And me, too!” said Porthos.	322.7386745001446
“And me, too!” said Aramis.	336.15142988359065
“Well, if you will have the truth, and me, too!” said Athos.	294.9353418355346
Chapter XLIX.	358.1598355393626
FATALITY	421.25609183235633
Meantime Milady, drunk with passion, roaring on the deck like a lioness	470.7738730005417
that has been embarked, had been tempted to throw herself into the sea	468.7001074317484
that she might regain the coast, for she could not get rid of the	381.0776381834071
thought that she had been insulted by D’Artagnan, threatened by Athos,	323.98471547285044
and that she had quit France without being revenged on them. This idea	343.55074994301697
soon became so insupportable to her that at the risk of whatever	490.6859691740722
terrible consequences might result to herself from it, she implored the	324.1788613151762
captain to put her on shore; but the captain, eager to escape from his	436.01946774408725
false position—placed between French and English cruisers, like the bat	434.8723095912378
between the mice and the birds—was in great haste to regain England,	344.78607259074136
and positively refused to obey what he took for a woman’s caprice,	315.80283988187864
promising his passenger, who had been particularly recommended to him	479.60261003798496
by the cardinal, to land her, if the sea and the French permitted him,	374.9659640006083
at one of the ports of Brittany, either at Lorient or Brest. But the	465.9272962689223
wind was contrary, the sea bad; they tacked and kept offshore. Nine	340.0197236645363
days after leaving the Charente, pale with fatigue and vexation, Milady	398.4514727780221
saw only the blue coasts of Finisterre appear.	460.307570391754
She calculated that to cross this corner of France and return to the	361.1063722330916
cardinal it would take her at least three days. Add another day for	297.9463750530101
landing, and that would make four. Add these four to the nine others,	434.70949838858735
that would be thirteen days lost—thirteen days, during which so many	463.68639472201
important events might pass in London. She reflected likewise that the	295.87323064998685
cardinal would be furious at her return, and consequently would be more	470.1833701344067
disposed to listen to the complaints brought against her than to the	436.1348707687456
accusations she brought against others.	457.04858350208076
She allowed the vessel to pass Lorient and Brest without repeating her	399.99571631970855
request to the captain, who, on his part, took care not to remind her	452.52753727089146
of it. Milady therefore continued her voyage, and on the very day that	490.85368508438023
Planchet embarked at Portsmouth for France, the messenger of his	339.6819056760302
Eminence entered the port in triumph.	437.4164545135791
All the city was agitated by an extraordinary movement. Four large	337.877933509303
vessels, recently built, had just been launched. At the end of the	350.2708854141036
jetty, his clothes richly laced with gold, glittering, as was customary	372.7618711113776
with him, with diamonds and precious stones, his hat ornamented with a	470.07818465235925
white feather which drooped upon his shoulder, Buckingham was seen	321.13679446324096
surrounded by a staff almost as brilliant as himself.	320.5953808519077
It was one of those rare and beautiful days in winter when England	437.6871885673306
remembers that there is a sun. The star of day, pale but nevertheless	404.3432021806146
still splendid, was setting in the horizon, glorifying at once the	326.6694543604292
heavens and the sea with bands of fire, and casting upon the towers and	466.9155346219785
the old houses of the city a last ray of gold which made the windows	360.75934666952946
sparkle like the reflection of a conflagration. Breathing that sea	441.8725103695696
breeze, so much more invigorating and balsamic as the land is	308.09018855868953
approached, contemplating all the power of those preparations she was	350.02477427706236
commissioned to destroy, all the power of that army which she was to	324.9064551824049
combat alone—she, a woman with a few bags of gold—Milady compared	378.71228068612754
herself mentally to Judith, the terrible Jewess, when she penetrated	303.21336841511993
the camp of the Assyrians and beheld the enormous mass of chariots,	302.79537233459376
horses, men, and arms, which a gesture of her hand was to dissipate	355.2311864099299
like a cloud of smoke.	298.3454074251479
They entered the roadstead; but as they drew near in order to cast	323.6719766159656
anchor, a little cutter, looking like a coastguard formidably armed,	455.4359603758867
approached the merchant vessel and dropped into the sea a boat which	353.839111702168
directed its course to the ladder. This boat contained an officer, a	406.27278041285246
mate, and eight rowers. The officer alone went on board, where he was	296.1791842205157
received with all the deference inspired by the uniform.	458.0904190707653
The officer conversed a few instants with the captain, gave him several	406.4147139682636
papers, of which he was the bearer, to read, and upon the order of the	470.56772969140013
merchant captain the whole crew of the vessel, both passengers and	404.5455312229217
sailors, were called upon deck.	483.7459990690402
When this species of summons was made the officer inquired aloud the	457.98088828643637
point of the brig’s departure, its route, its landings; and to all	392.4032512886512
these questions the captain replied without difficulty and without	379.2526571419776
hesitation. Then the officer began to pass in review all the people,	460.99424191422105
one after the other, and stopping when he came to Milady, surveyed her	376.4500510950442
very closely, but without addressing a single word to her.	335.82170022961924
He then returned to the captain, said a few words to him, and as if	469.5507867542711
from that moment the vessel was under his command, he ordered a	319.794513564641
maneuver which the crew executed immediately. Then the vessel resumed	412.20080891827
its course, still escorted by the little cutter, which sailed side by	419.753845214821
side with it, menacing it with the mouths of its six cannon. The boat	435.05226543182187
followed in the wake of the ship, a speck near the enormous mass.	349.5544523467253
During the examination of Milady by the officer, as may well be	307.73298483733333
imagined, Milady on her part was not less scrutinizing in her glances.	361.36379287783944
But however great was the power of this woman with eyes of flame in	389.95305809900367
reading the hearts of those whose secrets she wished to divine, she met	341.43846888452686
this time with a countenance of such impassivity that no discovery	415.8174469207263
followed her investigation. The officer who had stopped in front of her	450.3462662846517
and studied her with so much care might have been twenty-five or	295.27202281392096
twenty-six years of age. He was of pale complexion, with clear blue	409.6304804071958
eyes, rather deeply set; his mouth, fine and well cut, remained	325.56693595899435
motionless in its correct lines; his chin, strongly marked, denoted	357.3358130349989
that strength of will which in the ordinary Britannic type denotes	470.028820348545
mostly nothing but obstinacy; a brow a little receding, as is proper	307.79974431902696
for poets, enthusiasts, and soldiers, was scarcely shaded by short thin	336.3665814661556
hair which, like the beard which covered the lower part of his face,	376.1499049611779
was of a beautiful deep chestnut color.	343.48420157092175
When they entered the port, it was already night. The fog increased the	440.15311336510985
darkness, and formed round the sternlights and lanterns of the jetty a	352.64170423386
circle like that which surrounds the moon when the weather threatens to	438.87497148347506
become rainy. The air they breathed was heavy, damp, and cold.	413.1136451044938
Milady, that woman so courageous and firm, shivered in spite of	294.53857969013944
herself.	398.65917917120686
The officer desired to have Milady’s packages pointed out to him, and	388.1114217945684
ordered them to be placed in the boat. When this operation was	354.50184873565433
complete, he invited her to descend by offering her his hand.	299.7599069814815
Milady looked at this man, and hesitated. “Who are you, sir,” asked	345.24270195976453
she, “who has the kindness to trouble yourself so particularly on my	484.01289301449725
account?”	402.95209001276197
“You may perceive, madame, by my uniform, that I am an officer in the	442.268428882891
English navy,” replied the young man.	447.73913355537576
“But is it the custom for the officers in the English navy to place	334.79355466065124
themselves at the service of their female compatriots when they land in	377.7188667364231
a port of Great Britain, and carry their gallantry so far as to conduct	429.39108858334816
them ashore?”	461.9023789622745
“Yes, madame, it is the custom, not from gallantry but prudence, that	467.34906169176713
in time of war foreigners should be conducted to particular hôtels, in	411.92196766820496
order that they may remain under the eye of the government until full	445.98876644132616
information can be obtained about them.”	446.98586597399697
These words were pronounced with the most exact politeness and the most	449.6177285322175
perfect calmness. Nevertheless, they had not the power of convincing	426.89232438941127
Milady.	361.04787180104927
“But I am not a foreigner, sir,” said she, with an accent as pure as	379.9161117326767
ever was heard between Portsmouth and Manchester; “my name is Lady	301.4408660963348
Clarik, and this measure—”	484.6785880899152
“This measure is general, madame; and you will seek in vain to evade	380.08007750668946
it.”	401.29420897903674
“I will follow you, then, sir.”	433.2026120286961
Accepting the hand of the officer, she began the descent of the ladder,	480.9084916508184
at the foot of which the boat waited. The officer followed her. A large	440.59042374947387
cloak was spread at the stern; the officer requested her to sit down	299.07725626483864
upon this cloak, and placed himself beside her.	316.9791742615184
“Row!” said he to the sailors.	470.80762320060785
The eight oars fell at once into the sea, making but a single sound,	453.7108087134586
giving but a single stroke, and the boat seemed to fly over the surface	491.1011766691162
of the water.	487.4814582911084
In five minutes they gained the land.	419.9808501465962
The officer leaped to the pier, and offered his hand to Milady. A	399.1186519956503
carriage was in waiting.	299.1284626982822
“Is this carriage for us?” asked Milady.	303.0591975903993
“Yes, madame,” replied the officer.	485.59162747586254
“The hôtel, then, is far away?”	330.8157131593948
“At the other end of the town.”	378.20767274470836
“Very well,” said Milady; and she resolutely entered the carriage.	343.02190116553913
The officer saw that the baggage was fastened carefully behind the	403.3590201633358
carriage; and this operation ended, he took his place beside Milady,	468.70527166030456
and shut the door.	378.3778446478836
Immediately, without any order being given or his place of destination	477.6650915449228
indicated, the coachman set off at a rapid pace, and plunged into the	407.18142544885796
streets of the city.	469.99437248760466
So strange a reception naturally gave Milady ample matter for	365.0326663518849
reflection; so seeing that the young officer did not seem at all	383.09080606894867
disposed for conversation, she reclined in her corner of the carriage,	462.68400589979797
and one after the other passed in review all the surmises which	427.27022888984726
presented themselves to her mind.	404.2491925799802
At the end of a quarter of an hour, however, surprised at the length of	403.27631494457773
the journey, she leaned forward toward the door to see whither she was	333.5297501709076
being conducted. Houses were no longer to be seen; trees appeared in	412.71577092554014
the darkness like great black phantoms chasing one another. Milady	480.9190914374448
shuddered.	464.5986937543411
“But we are no longer in the city, sir,” said she.	380.9545011527296
The young officer preserved silence.	488.0377688942094
“I beg you to understand, sir, I will go no farther unless you tell me	334.3692606346154
whither you are taking me.”	312.368271963572
This threat brought no reply.	470.1117117095429
“Oh, this is too much,” cried Milady. “Help! help!”	383.2050559809239
No voice replied to hers; the carriage continued to roll on with	366.87229476725287
rapidity; the officer seemed a statue.	304.77129852154707
Milady looked at the officer with one of those terrible expressions	439.9042151958329
peculiar to her countenance, and which so rarely failed of their	446.6585233649469
effect; anger made her eyes flash in the darkness.	365.1455203130819
The young man remained immovable.	300.27461852177123
Milady tried to open the door in order to throw herself out.	449.7676656215315
“Take care, madame,” said the young man, coolly, “you will kill	477.11599480710447
yourself in jumping.”	435.3438638936753
Milady reseated herself, foaming. The officer leaned forward, looked at	466.5229951029705
her in his turn, and appeared surprised to see that face, just before	314.65833406248396
so beautiful, distorted with passion and almost hideous. The artful	424.08077098541156
creature at once comprehended that she was injuring herself by allowing	341.12118488783426
him thus to read her soul; she collected her features, and in a	319.073097897066
complaining voice said: “In the name of heaven, sir, tell me if it is	460.99082684518703
to you, if it is to your government, if it is to an enemy I am to	373.5122063385091
attribute the violence that is done me?”	375.96617485092895
“No violence will be offered to you, madame, and what happens to you is	375.7657655539026
the result of a very simple measure which we are obliged to adopt with	488.83943466040535
all who land in England.”	477.4288740489453
“Then you don’t know me, sir?”	456.90161406020053
“It is the first time I have had the honor of seeing you.”	449.3736711314893
“And on your honor, you have no cause of hatred against me?”	473.90675015427394
“None, I swear to you.”	296.16830665118766
There was so much serenity, coolness, mildness even, in the voice of	332.34012564102363
the young man, that Milady felt reassured.	387.3159198492178
At length after a journey of nearly an hour, the carriage stopped	357.3543537184339
before an iron gate, which closed an avenue leading to a castle severe	397.3635138698894
in form, massive, and isolated. Then, as the wheels rolled over a fine	295.4659195224776
gravel, Milady could hear a vast roaring, which she at once recognized	387.68414463226463
as the noise of the sea dashing against some steep cliff.	417.4649477540124
The carriage passed under two arched gateways, and at length stopped in	335.40516177528644
a court large, dark, and square. Almost immediately the door of the	425.89613506437445
carriage was opened, the young man sprang lightly out and presented his	335.6766946592047
hand to Milady, who leaned upon it, and in her turn alighted with	336.13029162598895
tolerable calmness.	482.9817794813945
“Still, then, I am a prisoner,” said Milady, looking around her, and	406.22303187169626
bringing back her eyes with a most gracious smile to the young officer;	384.1400834818467
“but I feel assured it will not be for long,” added she. “My own	410.17314523881436
conscience and your politeness, sir, are the guarantees of that.”	476.32200372819176
However flattering this compliment, the officer made no reply; but	364.1247888768391
drawing from his belt a little silver whistle, such as boatswains use	413.123948590616
in ships of war, he whistled three times, with three different	458.6196976834893
modulations. Immediately several men appeared, who unharnessed the	401.45845358631016
smoking horses, and put the carriage into a coach house.	426.6362348315911
Then the officer, with the same calm politeness, invited his prisoner	448.40146768373427
to enter the house. She, with a still-smiling countenance, took his	374.2317389284107
arm, and passed with him under a low arched door, which by a vaulted	313.4704434970446
passage, lighted only at the farther end, led to a stone staircase	383.29409850639826
around an angle of stone. They then came to a massive door, which after	356.0924753659883
the introduction into the lock of a key which the young man carried	479.1207374582757
with him, turned heavily upon its hinges, and disclosed the chamber	294.2220643340342
destined for Milady.	409.1488694156026
With a single glance the prisoner took in the apartment in its minutest	447.2332763628375
details. It was a chamber whose furniture was at once appropriate for a	415.15627083270135
prisoner or a free man; and yet bars at the windows and outside bolts	429.96875623105797
at the door decided the question in favor of the prison.	442.0091833712387
In an instant all the strength of mind of this creature, though drawn	426.85888649496997
from the most vigorous sources, abandoned her; she sank into a large	327.8850758655783
easy chair, with her arms crossed, her head lowered, and expecting	425.07137425210266
every instant to see a judge enter to interrogate her.	377.66033731036754
But no one entered except two or three marines, who brought her trunks	483.98920760001107
and packages, deposited them in a corner, and retired without speaking.	328.3400282855566
The officer superintended all these details with the same calmness	434.66203589804843
Milady had constantly seen in him, never pronouncing a word himself,	480.4453697253065
and making himself obeyed by a gesture of his hand or a sound of his	304.9933196711235
whistle.	433.4247013175183
It might have been said that between this man and his inferiors spoken	431.1210266652365
language did not exist, or had become useless.	387.81000547101434
At length Milady could hold out no longer; she broke the silence. “In	435.38571850121616
the name of heaven, sir,” cried she, “what means all that is passing?	474.89496583532775
Put an end to my doubts; I have courage enough for any danger I can	416.01085100557333
foresee, for every misfortune which I understand. Where am I, and why	375.4695652370858
am I here? If I am free, why these bars and these doors? If I am a	382.2346281479051
prisoner, what crime have I committed?”	328.6112396499084
“You are here in the apartment destined for you, madame. I received	370.96233961424383
orders to go and take charge of you on the sea, and to conduct you to	419.8011252438796
this castle. This order I believe I have accomplished with all the	491.03915720282
exactness of a soldier, but also with the courtesy of a gentleman.	304.7939277703968
There terminates, at least to the present moment, the duty I had to	386.07821727550106
fulfill toward you; the rest concerns another person.”	338.5762881200895
“And who is that other person?” asked Milady, warmly. “Can you not tell	411.4780932234987
me his name?”	310.7551434652853
At the moment a great jingling of spurs was heard on the stairs. Some	339.5075169052885
voices passed and faded away, and the sound of a single footstep	461.24801767312226
approached the door.	428.42883084394566
“That person is here, madame,” said the officer, leaving the entrance	458.9334149076144
open, and drawing himself up in an attitude of respect.	454.07776512529904
At the same time the door opened; a man appeared on the threshold. He	418.85939633517523
was without a hat, carried a sword, and flourished a handkerchief in	440.216315136018
his hand.	447.71593222573
Milady thought she recognized this shadow in the gloom; she supported	311.7709341695361
herself with one hand upon the arm of the chair, and advanced her head	459.86740299102473
as if to meet a certainty.	335.71660809474804
The stranger advanced slowly, and as he advanced, after entering into	302.4873041676802
the circle of light projected by the lamp, Milady involuntarily drew	374.3555833607268
back.	425.10740351504415
Then when she had no longer any doubt, she cried, in a state of stupor,	411.85819443675894
“What, my brother, is it you?”	394.95178482370864
“Yes, fair lady!” replied Lord de Winter, making a bow, half courteous,	469.7423425319304
half ironical; “it is I, myself.”	402.0317430323955
“But this castle, then?”	403.32867624685105
“Is mine.”	338.535063439465
“This chamber?”	330.3736058235526
“Is yours.”	355.8865897596977
“I am, then, your prisoner?”	334.1974791238531
“Nearly so.”	451.40261150274887
“But this is a frightful abuse of power!”	350.13665995546467
“No high-sounding words! Let us sit down and chat quietly, as brother	476.2006174261717
and sister ought to do.”	410.27982382087254
Then, turning toward the door, and seeing that the young officer was	425.2334834201689
waiting for his last orders, he said. “All is well, I thank you; now	428.9362761276017
leave us alone, Mr. Felton.”	423.63200384475886
Chapter L.	409.9149314004509
CHAT BETWEEN BROTHER AND SISTER	323.76940157428714
During the time which Lord de Winter took to shut the door, close a	436.0730118052006
shutter, and draw a chair near to his sister-in-law’s _fauteuil_,	372.5266204745913
Milady, anxiously thoughtful, plunged her glance into the depths of	299.24183630828554
possibility, and discovered all the plan, of which she could not even	314.7336579559526
obtain a glance as long as she was ignorant into whose hands she had	489.49699559485646
fallen. She knew her brother-in-law to be a worthy gentleman, a bold	417.3559741001633
hunter, an intrepid player, enterprising with women, but by no means	484.7015702132302
remarkable for his skill in intrigues. How had he discovered her	298.47908778667136
arrival, and caused her to be seized? Why did he detain her?	370.8073369172688
Athos had dropped some words which proved that the conversation she had	293.68246968108457
with the cardinal had fallen into outside ears; but she could not	446.9086091168473
suppose that he had dug a countermine so promptly and so boldly. She	459.90643075135506
rather feared that her preceding operations in England might have been	438.6989022495859
discovered. Buckingham might have guessed that it was she who had cut	444.0351925193595
off the two studs, and avenge himself for that little treachery; but	485.4004692028055
Buckingham was incapable of going to any excess against a woman,	402.5073210719253
particularly if that woman was supposed to have acted from a feeling of	462.3730607954517
jealousy.	474.42948623045993
This supposition appeared to her most reasonable. It seemed to her that	372.0163912751151
they wanted to revenge the past, and not to anticipate the future. At	324.5651981323038
all events, she congratulated herself upon having fallen into the hands	366.8203810699126
of her brother-in-law, with whom she reckoned she could deal very	403.4078765915665
easily, rather than into the hands of an acknowledged and intelligent	334.5808941594118
enemy.	317.34728284283403
“Yes, let us chat, brother,” said she, with a kind of cheerfulness,	449.5950444856354
decided as she was to draw from the conversation, in spite of all the	313.2010257522664
dissimulation Lord de Winter could bring, the revelations of which she	470.94847189277414
stood in need to regulate her future conduct.	477.18171398215975
“You have, then, decided to come to England again,” said Lord de	313.79860693133446
Winter, “in spite of the resolutions you so often expressed in Paris	321.93935066789754
never to set your feet on British ground?”	310.87054572067285
Milady replied to this question by another question. “To begin with,	347.44402639567676
tell me,” said she, “how have you watched me so closely as to be aware	367.65624631879416
beforehand not only of my arrival, but even of the day, the hour, and	459.4749427458862
the port at which I should arrive?”	435.65054135786227
Lord de Winter adopted the same tactics as Milady, thinking that as his	437.93047900590955
sister-in-law employed them they must be the best.	471.8954498133578
“But tell me, my dear sister,” replied he, “what makes you come to	355.35373077651064
England?”	307.0003670341739
“I come to see you,” replied Milady, without knowing how much she	324.22895797801107
aggravated by this reply the suspicions to which D’Artagnan’s letter	463.23402328353217
had given birth in the mind of her brother-in-law, and only desiring to	432.44618524904865
gain the good will of her auditor by a falsehood.	425.9907539817997
“Ah, to see me?” said de Winter, cunningly.	402.3904852016911
“To be sure, to see you. What is there astonishing in that?”	490.4399037923229
“And you had no other object in coming to England but to see me?”	450.7506764158253
“No.”	344.01958915387223
“So it was for me alone you have taken the trouble to cross the	395.8587792704243
Channel?”	312.2553123243723
“For you alone.”	421.30161312770935
“The deuce! What tenderness, my sister!”	337.00621953186476
“But am I not your nearest relative?” demanded Milady, with a tone of	344.9354978579113
the most touching ingenuousness.	353.25812345432513
“And my only heir, are you not?” said Lord de Winter in his turn,	426.65469050515196
fixing his eyes on those of Milady.	394.5870454900106
Whatever command she had over herself, Milady could not help starting;	404.60561878182955
and as in pronouncing the last words Lord de Winter placed his hand	387.9243508980118
upon the arm of his sister, this start did not escape him.	393.33411984807935
In fact, the blow was direct and severe. The first idea that occurred	359.45288881867896
to Milady’s mind was that she had been betrayed by Kitty, and that she	395.2867780394802
had recounted to the baron the selfish aversion toward himself of which	348.10957763968037
she had imprudently allowed some marks to escape before her servant.	436.3783930585007
She also recollected the furious and imprudent attack she had made upon	415.4762006580662
D’Artagnan when he spared the life of her brother.	422.59580246953897
“I do not understand, my Lord,” said she, in order to gain time and	452.5190339607889
make her adversary speak out. “What do you mean to say? Is there any	325.4056966136417
secret meaning concealed beneath your words?”	457.5020190453371
“Oh, my God, no!” said Lord de Winter, with apparent good nature. “You	344.9119594831848
wish to see me, and you come to England. I learn this desire, or rather	418.06129382642575
I suspect that you feel it; and in order to spare you all the	318.0958873802744
annoyances of a nocturnal arrival in a port and all the fatigues of	459.08548933520945
landing, I send one of my officers to meet you, I place a carriage at	361.60976875939446
his orders, and he brings you hither to this castle, of which I am	296.84908883365154
governor, whither I come every day, and where, in order to satisfy our	484.0531548957624
mutual desire of seeing each other, I have prepared you a chamber. What	491.1112345540341
is there more astonishing in all that I have said to you than in what	332.9837628821525
you have told me?”	399.6324112105671
“No; what I think astonishing is that you should expect my coming.”	470.59981730074276
“And yet that is the most simple thing in the world, my dear sister.	337.3992827402663
Have you not observed that the captain of your little vessel, on	349.4714983730281
entering the roadstead, sent forward, in order to obtain permission to	418.547945202224
enter the port, a little boat bearing his logbook and the register of	363.6877805511426
his voyagers? I am commandant of the port. They brought me that book. I	434.93298691799345
recognized your name in it. My heart told me what your mouth has just	299.0846182755356
confirmed—that is to say, with what view you have exposed yourself to	408.00624242052373
the dangers of a sea so perilous, or at least so troublesome at this	438.5518861037773
moment—and I sent my cutter to meet you. You know the rest.”	481.4667004470324
Milady knew that Lord de Winter lied, and she was the more alarmed.	348.6996954951444
“My brother,” continued she, “was not that my Lord Buckingham whom I	302.7654991881667
saw on the jetty this evening as we arrived?”	438.7964442771617
“Himself. Ah, I can understand how the sight of him struck you,”	405.3963582513254
replied Lord de Winter. “You came from a country where he must be very	324.0196307163936
much talked of, and I know that his armaments against France greatly	421.0026078153528
engage the attention of your friend the cardinal.”	369.1149196029112
“My friend the cardinal!” cried Milady, seeing that on this point as on	318.68241207500427
the other Lord de Winter seemed well instructed.	313.64086230509747
“Is he not your friend?” replied the baron, negligently. “Ah, pardon! I	376.5339207120064
thought so; but we will return to my Lord Duke presently. Let us not	381.0141157780011
depart from the sentimental turn our conversation had taken. You came,	323.93204178385446
you say, to see me?”	323.224203953315
“Yes.”	302.38063293106643
“Well, I reply that you shall be served to the height of your wishes,	442.87902071020903
and that we shall see each other every day.”	297.53855997045946
“Am I, then, to remain here eternally?” demanded Milady, with a certain	371.2104418557659
terror.	485.8983411986019
“Do you find yourself badly lodged, sister? Demand anything you want,	485.2458309650275
and I will hasten to have you furnished with it.”	300.8508419451806
“But I have neither my women nor my servants.”	455.80929022032103
“You shall have all, madame. Tell me on what footing your household was	347.37475790946394
established by your first husband, and although I am only your	418.8729357391956
brother-in-law, I will arrange one similar.”	483.3075427415739
“My first husband!” cried Milady, looking at Lord de Winter with eyes	309.9017991682385
almost starting from their sockets.	489.82466339774555
“Yes, your French husband. I don’t speak of my brother. If you have	456.4847160158263
forgotten, as he is still living, I can write to him and he will send	378.86681285307634
me information on the subject.”	383.5966332856183
A cold sweat burst from the brow of Milady.	377.2152700853897
“You jest!” said she, in a hollow voice.	328.6392203762893
“Do I look so?” asked the baron, rising and going a step backward.	296.8816939174761
“Or rather you insult me,” continued she, pressing with her stiffened	422.4695832771549
hands the two arms of her easy chair, and raising herself upon her	413.6553308299507
wrists.	296.64546535937694
“I insult you!” said Lord de Winter, with contempt. “In truth, madame,	353.6644686793034
do you think that can be possible?”	409.9820730183933
“Indeed, sir,” said Milady, “you must be either drunk or mad. Leave the	422.801474221366
room, and send me a woman.”	353.3707540054494
“Women are very indiscreet, my sister. Cannot I serve you as a waiting	449.46478947872765
maid? By that means all our secrets will remain in the family.”	346.77596730216084
“Insolent!” cried Milady; and as if acted upon by a spring, she bounded	295.8347305823235
toward the baron, who awaited her attack with his arms crossed, but	293.0668186939318
nevertheless with one hand on the hilt of his sword.	446.52922683264654
“Come!” said he. “I know you are accustomed to assassinate people; but	477.1488470605249
I warn you I shall defend myself, even against you.”	359.05559813658454
“You are right,” said Milady. “You have all the appearance of being	458.3406568002721
cowardly enough to lift your hand against a woman.”	455.2857214219255
“Perhaps so; and I have an excuse, for mine would not be the first hand	378.8394747455858
of a man that has been placed upon you, I imagine.”	387.2560534215892
And the baron pointed, with a slow and accusing gesture, to the left	352.31607905216543
shoulder of Milady, which he almost touched with his finger.	420.1398045937681
Milady uttered a deep, inward shriek, and retreated to a corner of the	373.06143224316787
room like a panther which crouches for a spring.	394.21115312992606
“Oh, growl as much as you please,” cried Lord de Winter, “but don’t try	399.28398586873686
to bite, for I warn you that it would be to your disadvantage. There	398.00267708933495
are here no procurators who regulate successions beforehand. There is	418.479811249299
no knight-errant to come and seek a quarrel with me on account of the	471.79927832059775
fair lady I detain a prisoner; but I have judges quite ready who will	322.0449058645328
quickly dispose of a woman so shameless as to glide, a bigamist, into	326.92445292205366
the bed of Lord de Winter, my brother. And these judges, I warn you,	403.4350390498152
will soon send you to an executioner who will make both your shoulders	343.4030333426249
alike.”	470.7540380387483
The eyes of Milady darted such flashes that although he was a man and	412.37601043258434
armed before an unarmed woman, he felt the chill of fear glide through	448.95277858119647
his whole frame. However, he continued all the same, but with	398.47793638459905
increasing warmth: “Yes, I can very well understand that after having	418.8604324666517
inherited the fortune of my brother it would be very agreeable to you	393.3422094387597
to be my heir likewise; but know beforehand, if you kill me or cause me	484.25219397662556
to be killed, my precautions are taken. Not a penny of what I possess	472.9239617141876
will pass into your hands. Were you not already rich enough—you who	450.59359602582725
possess nearly a million? And could you not stop your fatal career, if	311.65392044968456
you did not do evil for the infinite and supreme joy of doing it? Oh,	344.26900147332447
be assured, if the memory of my brother were not sacred to me, you	444.0199163115341
should rot in a state dungeon or satisfy the curiosity of sailors at	389.1773366427685
Tyburn. I will be silent, but you must endure your captivity quietly.	413.5711145675921
In fifteen or twenty days I shall set out for La Rochelle with the	431.00838521303183
army; but on the eve of my departure a vessel which I shall see depart	454.604313959316
will take you hence and convey you to our colonies in the south. And be	471.71038318503906
assured that you shall be accompanied by one who will blow your brains	487.1651030266604
out at the first attempt you make to return to England or the	354.6932288957889
Continent.”	297.7674063889117
Milady listened with an attention that dilated her inflamed eyes.	389.1843871793027
“Yes, at present,” continued Lord de Winter, “you will remain in this	409.1612891822535
castle. The walls are thick, the doors strong, and the bars solid;	427.89124972842234
besides, your window opens immediately over the sea. The men of my	460.4997083441107
crew, who are devoted to me for life and death, mount guard around this	426.6303298854316
apartment, and watch all the passages that lead to the courtyard. Even	482.2976700095944
if you gained the yard, there would still be three iron gates for you	343.1822757103167
to pass. The order is positive. A step, a gesture, a word, on your	390.52491864277965
part, denoting an effort to escape, and you are to be fired upon. If	367.5253155041107
they kill you, English justice will be under an obligation to me for	461.4921786367594
having saved it trouble. Ah! I see your features regain their calmness,	316.2308531935566
your countenance recovers its assurance. You are saying to yourself:	328.5025196317621
‘Fifteen days, twenty days? Bah! I have an inventive mind; before that	298.3509491767511
is expired some idea will occur to me. I have an infernal spirit. I	439.97442227177123
shall meet with a victim. Before fifteen days are gone by I shall be	386.3990343618711
away from here.’ Ah, try it!”	393.96472381489383
Milady, finding her thoughts betrayed, dug her nails into her flesh to	378.9910529411924
subdue every emotion that might give to her face any expression except	474.4734432647782
agony.	320.0306261444173
Lord de Winter continued: “The officer who commands here in my absence	350.89081900445143
you have already seen, and therefore know him. He knows how, as you	292.42164298523994
must have observed, to obey an order—for you did not, I am sure, come	438.85271053053816
from Portsmouth hither without endeavoring to make him speak. What do	317.1223195680518
you say of him? Could a statue of marble have been more impassive and	414.3607126858394
more mute? You have already tried the power of your seductions upon	299.04866964228734
many men, and unfortunately you have always succeeded; but I give you	487.1652997041739
leave to try them upon this one. _Pardieu!_ if you succeed with him, I	339.6473886290488
pronounce you the demon himself.”	408.6498770153491
He went toward the door and opened it hastily.	346.6345305714713
“Call Mr. Felton,” said he. “Wait a minute longer, and I will introduce	340.4909476322344
him to you.”	382.6875208937714
There followed between these two personages a strange silence, during	455.32440751264255
which the sound of a slow and regular step was heard approaching.	419.68260883680244
Shortly a human form appeared in the shade of the corridor, and the	316.17281011472403
young lieutenant, with whom we are already acquainted, stopped at the	417.9772577465378
threshold to receive the orders of the baron.	390.2009896231169
“Come in, my dear John,” said Lord de Winter, “come in, and shut the	349.77242464595497
door.”	474.8064563316234
The young officer entered.	341.46965020575925
“Now,” said the baron, “look at this woman. She is young; she is	406.13127692809815
beautiful; she possesses all earthly seductions. Well, she is a	372.2687384002087
monster, who, at twenty-five years of age, has been guilty of as many	303.30076145424346
crimes as you could read of in a year in the archives of our tribunals.	341.1961084122046
Her voice prejudices her hearers in her favor; her beauty serves as a	477.07006758572584
bait to her victims; her body even pays what she promises—I must do her	395.15159668857916
that justice. She will try to seduce you, perhaps she will try to kill	476.3947507024305
you. I have extricated you from misery, Felton; I have caused you to be	391.23106577271994
named lieutenant; I once saved your life, you know on what occasion. I	431.97583166831845
am for you not only a protector, but a friend; not only a benefactor,	371.838622311
but a father. This woman has come back again into England for the	325.0011432100577
purpose of conspiring against my life. I hold this serpent in my hands.	388.02872541683394
Well, I call you, and say to you: Friend Felton, John, my child, guard	293.0967716265015
me, and more particularly guard yourself, against this woman. Swear, by	328.9578760605571
your hopes of salvation, to keep her safely for the chastisement she	333.8330078197467
has merited. John Felton, I trust your word! John Felton, I put faith	473.45493475855733
in your loyalty!”	386.17495228800607
“My Lord,” said the young officer, summoning to his mild countenance	427.53946366144567
all the hatred he could find in his heart, “my Lord, I swear all shall	420.25403181473985
be done as you desire.”	322.38885804659503
Milady received this look like a resigned victim; it was impossible to	358.01028233593655
imagine a more submissive or a more mild expression than that which	417.21452780645717
prevailed on her beautiful countenance. Lord de Winter himself could	452.7811607139681
scarcely recognize the tigress who, a minute before, prepared	436.6271013759894
apparently for a fight.	452.9329994873135
“She is not to leave this chamber, understand, John,” continued the	362.7322436476185
baron. “She is to correspond with nobody; she is to speak to no one but	377.03255330537
you—if you will do her the honor to address a word to her.”	295.59536450317853
“That is sufficient, my Lord! I have sworn.”	428.21660078489197
“And now, madame, try to make your peace with God, for you are judged	312.09530216133373
by men!”	365.1177652256305
Milady let her head sink, as if crushed by this sentence. Lord de	404.68279050929743
Winter went out, making a sign to Felton, who followed him, shutting	381.44897325798644
the door after him.	311.5788389235589
One instant after, the heavy step of a marine who served as sentinel	338.9740556210504
was heard in the corridor—his ax in his girdle and his musket on his	293.08778783051275
shoulder.	360.56770022428435
Milady remained for some minutes in the same position, for she thought	386.31452056257575
they might perhaps be examining her through the keyhole; she then	476.8169055209301
slowly raised her head, which had resumed its formidable expression of	320.785708286713
menace and defiance, ran to the door to listen, looked out of her	444.6843408711592
window, and returning to bury herself again in her large armchair, she	342.64206632621426
reflected.	325.073515549223
Chapter LI.	395.27542679972476
OFFICER	423.11154365495895
Meanwhile, the cardinal looked anxiously for news from England; but no	460.15164659773984
news arrived that was not annoying and threatening.	393.5560664141003
Although La Rochelle was invested, however certain success might	306.25589514238004
appear—thanks to the precautions taken, and above all to the dyke,	465.4052720630796
which prevented the entrance of any vessel into the besieged city—the	323.6338948462863
blockade might last a long time yet. This was a great affront to the	412.6040299909864
king’s army, and a great inconvenience to the cardinal, who had no	486.667049414035
longer, it is true, to embroil Louis XIII. with Anne of Austria—for that	467.9605672971593
affair was over—but he had to adjust matters for M. de Bassompierre,	354.20333155400834
who was embroiled with the Duc d’Angoulême.	473.7412672238777
As to Monsieur, who had begun the siege, he left to the cardinal the	462.6460477454782
task of finishing it.	346.3807195230455
The city, notwithstanding the incredible perseverance of its mayor, had	371.7235543504519
attempted a sort of mutiny for a surrender; the mayor had hanged the	392.4747532683193
mutineers. This execution quieted the ill-disposed, who resolved to	472.5986079065034
allow themselves to die of hunger—this death always appearing to them	488.9541002339288
more slow and less sure than strangulation.	414.86125923222994
On their side, from time to time, the besiegers took the messengers	308.41308927099794
which the Rochellais sent to Buckingham, or the spies which Buckingham	438.1293298294147
sent to the Rochellais. In one case or the other, the trial was soon	428.65524837385715
over. The cardinal pronounced the single word, “Hanged!” The king was	339.4343124033086
invited to come and see the hanging. He came languidly, placing himself	293.9394907828903
in a good situation to see all the details. This amused him sometimes a	403.2663750869461
little, and made him endure the siege with patience; but it did not	320.1487538627808
prevent his getting very tired, or from talking at every moment of	481.97252454891077
