returning to Paris—so that if the messengers and the spies had failed,	457.5469737419937
his Eminence, notwithstanding all his inventiveness, would have found	480.54205520763514
himself much embarrassed.	314.57767298890735
Nevertheless, time passed on, and the Rochellais did not surrender. The	441.4893155207882
last spy that was taken was the bearer of a letter. This letter told	373.20622190574727
Buckingham that the city was at an extremity; but instead of adding,	386.18317404120245
“If your succor does not arrive within fifteen days, we will	333.9941502646626
surrender,” it added, quite simply, “If your succor comes not within	462.4147027783662
fifteen days, we shall all be dead with hunger when it comes.”	466.1136866530269
The Rochellais, then, had no hope but in Buckingham. Buckingham was	335.32357704753986
their Messiah. It was evident that if they one day learned positively	314.8228582184012
that they must not count on Buckingham, their courage would fail with	422.9679606156915
their hope.	339.3798388289965
The cardinal looked, then, with great impatience for the news from	352.23777876147267
England which would announce to him that Buckingham would not come.	472.6555203743826
The question of carrying the city by assault, though often debated in	423.5756638016518
the council of the king, had been always rejected. In the first place,	402.4578322981482
La Rochelle appeared impregnable. Then the cardinal, whatever he said,	420.7940261197043
very well knew that the horror of bloodshed in this encounter, in which	465.8755315079097
Frenchman would combat against Frenchman, was a retrograde movement of	403.0560129497037
sixty years impressed upon his policy; and the cardinal was at that	300.5595642586345
period what we now call a man of progress. In fact, the sack of La	331.9729519753086
Rochelle, and the assassination of three of four thousand Huguenots who	488.09299011778126
allowed themselves to be killed, would resemble too closely, in 1628,	305.66216154583907
the massacre of St. Bartholomew in 1572; and then, above all this, this	315.89955775620433
extreme measure, which was not at all repugnant to the king, good	350.3129622334958
Catholic as he was, always fell before this argument of the besieging	372.7216581766822
generals—La Rochelle is impregnable except to famine.	310.80855121310935
The cardinal could not drive from his mind the fear he entertained of	316.50250876232553
his terrible emissary—for he comprehended the strange qualities of this	396.7285653046485
woman, sometimes a serpent, sometimes a lion. Had she betrayed him? Was	344.232364364051
she dead? He knew her well enough in all cases to know that, whether	336.12757946719825
acting for or against him, as a friend or an enemy, she would not	319.4277195875703
remain motionless without great impediments; but whence did these	359.1526121515019
impediments arise? That was what he could not know.	306.19063726913186
And yet he reckoned, and with reason, on Milady. He had divined in the	475.3941450456656
past of this woman terrible things which his red mantle alone could	420.9320089237536
cover; and he felt, from one cause or another, that this woman was his	440.65209582645593
own, as she could look to no other but himself for a support superior	421.676639613896
to the danger which threatened her.	312.7390655399783
He resolved, then, to carry on the war alone, and to look for no	388.8497729921673
success foreign to himself, but as we look for a fortunate chance. He	411.95664535833293
continued to press the raising of the famous dyke which was to starve	491.5931535991739
La Rochelle. Meanwhile, he cast his eyes over that unfortunate city,	440.7642429434045
which contained so much deep misery and so many heroic virtues, and	432.01000473560725
recalling the saying of Louis XI., his political predecessor, as he	438.34790124609117
himself was the predecessor of Robespierre, he repeated this maxim of	312.53374136680316
Tristan’s gossip: “Divide in order to reign.”	451.1978872532469
Henry IV., when besieging Paris, had loaves and provisions thrown over	419.7023137452272
the walls. The cardinal had little notes thrown over in which he	378.36320225937925
represented to the Rochellais how unjust, selfish, and barbarous was	419.34265609512863
the conduct of their leaders. These leaders had corn in abundance, and	402.9412392618297
would not let them partake of it; they adopted as a maxim—for they,	433.88520721749853
too, had maxims—that it was of very little consequence that women,	352.9218395133721
children, and old men should die, so long as the men who were to defend	437.3148259813171
the walls remained strong and healthy. Up to that time, whether from	427.79083342598057
devotedness or from want of power to act against it, this maxim,	306.02990968548323
without being generally adopted, nevertheless passed from theory into	365.93690562908625
practice; but the notes did it injury. The notes reminded the men that	395.06873930879743
the children, women, and old men whom they allowed to die were their	463.8821670861821
sons, their wives, and their fathers, and that it would be more just	328.5145505646563
for everyone to be reduced to the common misery, in order that equal	470.8751732016801
conditions should give birth to unanimous resolutions.	357.0663211468787
These notes had all the effect that he who wrote them could expect, in	465.2757715524287
that they induced a great number of the inhabitants to open private	453.9747460031931
negotiations with the royal army.	361.6739556766702
But at the moment when the cardinal saw his means already bearing	489.7498494440607
fruit, and applauded himself for having put it in action, an inhabitant	407.91032287443056
of La Rochelle who had contrived to pass the royal lines—God knows how,	429.7501251955614
such was the watchfulness of Bassompierre, Schomberg, and the Duc	448.55240009140846
d’Angoulême, themselves watched over by the cardinal—an inhabitant of	375.3519120244816
La Rochelle, we say, entered the city, coming from Portsmouth, and	299.8347316512992
saying that he had seen a magnificent fleet ready to sail within eight	398.70349841000814
days. Still further, Buckingham announced to the mayor that at length	410.53531096128535
the great league was about to declare itself against France, and that	411.80346949738407
the kingdom would be at once invaded by the English, Imperial, and	327.8937005426699
Spanish armies. This letter was read publicly in all parts of the city.	363.7418188302423
Copies were put up at the corners of the streets; and even they who had	342.67733543173836
begun to open negotiations interrupted them, being resolved to await	304.76423060892967
the succor so pompously announced.	336.951867878925
This unexpected circumstance brought back Richelieu’s former anxiety,	381.7153613690356
and forced him in spite of himself once more to turn his eyes to the	360.92402574474846
other side of the sea.	463.81431017489683
During this time, exempt from the anxiety of its only and true chief,	489.63663044338404
the royal army led a joyous life, neither provisions nor money being	422.8512007380839
wanting in the camp. All the corps rivaled one another in audacity and	424.19105069833824
gaiety. To take spies and hang them, to make hazardous expeditions upon	434.44807045443247
the dyke or the sea, to imagine wild plans, and to execute them	478.49248452837026
coolly—such were the pastimes which made the army find these days short	451.7056249837087
which were not only so long to the Rochellais, a prey to famine and	412.8093496103961
anxiety, but even to the cardinal, who blockaded them so closely.	427.03213618651546
Sometimes when the cardinal, always on horseback, like the lowest	293.97062123976184
_gendarme_ of the army, cast a pensive glance over those works, so	387.9477582612219
slowly keeping pace with his wishes, which the engineers, brought from	394.11460609595963
all the corners of France, were executing under his orders, if he met a	431.24243256135605
Musketeer of the company of Tréville, he drew near and looked at him in	464.83840528195526
a peculiar manner, and not recognizing in him one of our four	341.6969128243772
companions, he turned his penetrating look and profound thoughts in	333.7959000442112
another direction.	294.3861338085976
One day when oppressed with a mortal weariness of mind, without hope in	490.4086384403273
the negotiations with the city, without news from England, the cardinal	485.34770001630284
went out, without any other aim than to be out of doors, and	421.1022459955725
accompanied only by Cahusac and La Houdinière, strolled along the	447.2259216545874
beach. Mingling the immensity of his dreams with the immensity of the	293.6937003160138
ocean, he came, his horse going at a foot’s pace, to a hill from the	412.2681435060671
top of which he perceived behind a hedge, reclining on the sand and	403.4722399246273
catching in its passage one of those rays of the sun so rare at this	408.46487544514434
period of the year, seven men surrounded by empty bottles. Four of	457.8262550015489
these men were our Musketeers, preparing to listen to a letter one of	309.3604834355879
them had just received. This letter was so important that it made them	323.43778269544543
forsake their cards and their dice on the drumhead.	328.3904409514473
The other three were occupied in opening an enormous flagon of	341.56938952005567
Collicure wine; these were the lackeys of these gentlemen.	375.92168375326196
The cardinal was, as we have said, in very low spirits; and nothing	403.18920223262865
when he was in that state of mind increased his depression so much as	300.5817389119228
gaiety in others. Besides, he had another strange fancy, which was	418.292845956268
always to believe that the causes of his sadness created the gaiety of	387.74389130270566
others. Making a sign to La Houdinière and Cahusac to stop, he alighted	373.92639323307765
from his horse, and went toward these suspected merry companions,	453.9984875325256
hoping, by means of the sand which deadened the sound of his steps and	401.9138328212027
of the hedge which concealed his approach, to catch some words of this	420.9439252934331
conversation which appeared so interesting. At ten paces from the hedge	354.165382667042
he recognized the talkative Gascon; and as he had already perceived	330.5060884871483
that these men were Musketeers, he did not doubt that the three others	343.6128855112604
were those called the Inseparables; that is to say, Athos, Porthos, and	472.4528418467277
Aramis.	394.08729518407097
It may be supposed that his desire to hear the conversation was	471.89807143442
augmented by this discovery. His eyes took a strange expression, and	304.7393810645694
with the step of a tiger-cat he advanced toward the hedge; but he had	407.80216964947056
not been able to catch more than a few vague syllables without any	352.52419470461325
positive sense, when a sonorous and short cry made him start, and	326.87198490287
attracted the attention of the Musketeers.	483.6368071369924
“Officer!” cried Grimaud.	319.6408995749169
“You are speaking, you scoundrel!” said Athos, rising upon his elbow,	364.88880441365825
and transfixing Grimaud with his flaming look.	355.3171668554538
Grimaud therefore added nothing to his speech, but contented himself	432.0837766264692
with pointing his index finger in the direction of the hedge,	402.94234288147675
announcing by this gesture the cardinal and his escort.	382.10104695631577
With a single bound the Musketeers were on their feet, and saluted with	466.73660165727114
respect.	296.4915700847923
The cardinal seemed furious.	424.94173343169587
“It appears that Messieurs the Musketeers keep guard,” said he. “Are	377.0034583073773
the English expected by land, or do the Musketeers consider themselves	422.7414371020052
superior officers?”	320.048463087145
“Monseigneur,” replied Athos, for amid the general fright he alone had	332.4808805341043
preserved the noble calmness and coolness that never forsook him,	368.87821385850077
“Monseigneur, the Musketeers, when they are not on duty, or when their	375.3706238284617
duty is over, drink and play at dice, and they are certainly superior	487.01567791976123
officers to their lackeys.”	406.589030720552
“Lackeys?” grumbled the cardinal. “Lackeys who have the order to warn	430.4402171586861
their masters when anyone passes are not lackeys, they are sentinels.”	322.1040772714912
“Your Eminence may perceive that if we had not taken this precaution,	368.7855366366994
we should have been exposed to allowing you to pass without presenting	443.86596427554815
you our respects or offering you our thanks for the favor you have done	355.81641328872064
us in uniting us. D’Artagnan,” continued Athos, “you, who but lately	469.9172777161776
were so anxious for such an opportunity for expressing your gratitude	300.5761213507393
to Monseigneur, here it is; avail yourself of it.”	330.66931065071526
These words were pronounced with that imperturbable phlegm which	351.9957944944766
distinguished Athos in the hour of danger, and with that excessive	362.0939283247987
politeness which made of him at certain moments a king more majestic	384.2463372173935
than kings by birth.	475.68200009894537
D’Artagnan came forward and stammered out a few words of gratitude	308.23404175253313
which soon expired under the gloomy looks of the cardinal.	463.95809568549885
“It does not signify, gentlemen,” continued the cardinal, without	371.81638890668006
appearing to be in the least swerved from his first intention by the	473.2767902286788
diversion which Athos had started, “it does not signify, gentlemen. I	469.7661764591072
do not like to have simple soldiers, because they have the advantage of	358.6756431460866
serving in a privileged corps, thus to play the great lords; discipline	434.8416126588396
is the same for them as for everybody else.”	455.4726382753547
Athos allowed the cardinal to finish his sentence completely, and bowed	476.3564988451005
in sign of assent. Then he resumed in his turn: “Discipline,	414.4998826946734
Monseigneur, has, I hope, in no way been forgotten by us. We are not on	423.2011895059162
duty, and we believed that not being on duty we were at liberty to	292.73446638360855
dispose of our time as we pleased. If we are so fortunate as to have	339.3955448584194
some particular duty to perform for your Eminence, we are ready to obey	428.1850772165999
you. Your Eminence may perceive,” continued Athos, knitting his brow,	395.8725202848268
for this sort of investigation began to annoy him, “that we have not	486.66697344985454
come out without our arms.”	370.7289714658323
And he showed the cardinal, with his finger, the four muskets piled	317.13810844639926
near the drum, on which were the cards and dice.	353.20273040586346
“Your Eminence may believe,” added D’Artagnan, “that we would have come	360.2648007138886
to meet you, if we could have supposed it was Monseigneur coming toward	309.98932494389607
us with so few attendants.”	394.0286902011352
The cardinal bit his mustache, and even his lips a little.	459.6766289535873
“Do you know what you look like, all together, as you are armed and	340.8060870129186
guarded by your lackeys?” said the cardinal. “You look like four	454.0803852108522
conspirators.”	381.1580722529783
“Oh, as to that, Monseigneur, it is true,” said Athos; “we do conspire,	351.9307472154835
as your Eminence might have seen the other morning. Only we conspire	462.7682251692953
against the Rochellais.”	469.0737783451566
“Ah, you gentlemen of policy!” replied the cardinal, knitting his brow	323.74041347178047
in his turn, “the secret of many unknown things might perhaps be found	450.3711856074543
in your brains, if we could read them as you read that letter which you	469.32602110937853
concealed as soon as you saw me coming.”	339.2872865206959
The color mounted to the face of Athos, and he made a step toward his	476.3623393413809
Eminence.	372.7721169885272
“One might think you really suspected us, monseigneur, and we were	358.5189382414443
undergoing a real interrogatory. If it be so, we trust your Eminence	376.2498611947003
will deign to explain yourself, and we should then at least be	448.7247957904292
acquainted with our real position.”	429.84624673924463
“And if it were an interrogatory!” replied the cardinal. “Others	310.4962104146992
besides you have undergone such, Monsieur Athos, and have replied	328.05537774441143
thereto.”	383.75259262005005
“Thus I have told your Eminence that you had but to question us, and we	394.8107499264754
are ready to reply.”	439.35244431689506
“What was that letter you were about to read, Monsieur Aramis, and	346.3861970394426
which you so promptly concealed?”	449.06573694357473
“A woman’s letter, monseigneur.”	421.8862858185655
“Ah, yes, I see,” said the cardinal; “we must be discreet with this	353.4662723629429
sort of letters; but nevertheless, we may show them to a confessor, and	334.82155423872985
you know I have taken orders.”	434.4625815554375
“Monseigneur,” said Athos, with a calmness the more terrible because he	307.94300089281177
risked his head in making this reply, “the letter is a woman’s letter,	401.1079100540685
but it is neither signed Marion de Lorme, nor Madame d’Aiguillon.”	404.84104654986663
The cardinal became as pale as death; lightning darted from his eyes.	382.6389413539201
He turned round as if to give an order to Cahusac and Houdinière. Athos	468.8966283496212
saw the movement; he made a step toward the muskets, upon which the	369.36377422603215
other three friends had fixed their eyes, like men ill-disposed to	482.18845824975017
allow themselves to be taken. The cardinalists were three; the	405.74088664270306
Musketeers, lackeys included, were seven. He judged that the match	345.94571460401323
would be so much the less equal, if Athos and his companions were	465.70890771021936
really plotting; and by one of those rapid turns which he always had at	344.8961690973715
command, all his anger faded away into a smile.	468.03741829680627
“Well, well!” said he, “you are brave young men, proud in daylight,	338.50744941998266
faithful in darkness. We can find no fault with you for watching over	471.7307302103774
yourselves, when you watch so carefully over others. Gentlemen, I have	322.7135206797214
not forgotten the night in which you served me as an escort to the Red	488.31127884924365
Dovecot. If there were any danger to be apprehended on the road I am	391.4760076632348
going, I would request you to accompany me; but as there is none,	366.9716883447369
remain where you are, finish your bottles, your game, and your letter.	430.591738705264
Adieu, gentlemen!”	370.34051562377715
And remounting his horse, which Cahusac led to him, he saluted them	348.2347808281031
with his hand, and rode away.	296.1075346907512
The four young men, standing and motionless, followed him with their	433.7266833990084
eyes without speaking a single word until he had disappeared. Then they	413.03475769237303
looked at one another.	449.297553955516
The countenances of all gave evidence of terror, for notwithstanding	300.7319918248251
the friendly adieu of his Eminence, they plainly perceived that the	482.58094066608976
cardinal went away with rage in his heart.	343.2645685296425
Athos alone smiled, with a self-possessed, disdainful smile.	459.921222169995
When the cardinal was out of hearing and sight, “That Grimaud kept bad	372.31863463851136
watch!” cried Porthos, who had a great inclination to vent his	300.07294797646523
ill-humor on somebody.	390.97798012476585
Grimaud was about to reply to excuse himself. Athos lifted his finger,	319.87164880930607
and Grimaud was silent.	458.79339502939865
“Would you have given up the letter, Aramis?” said D’Artagnan.	354.89066105327834
“I,” said Aramis, in his most flutelike tone, “I had made up my mind.	369.5571008745256
If he had insisted upon the letter being given up to him, I would have	339.2133361732747
presented the letter to him with one hand, and with the other I would	481.1326525709861
have run my sword through his body.”	377.9863029201183
“I expected as much,” said Athos; “and that was why I threw myself	338.99445539482133
between you and him. Indeed, this man is very much to blame for talking	323.193496074877
thus to other men; one would say he had never had to do with any but	433.90473315846214
women and children.”	292.08222337190426
“My dear Athos, I admire you, but nevertheless we were in the wrong,	373.29225085294945
after all.”	393.44888296171314
“How, in the wrong?” said Athos. “Whose, then, is the air we breathe?	369.3609103563972
Whose is the ocean upon which we look? Whose is the sand upon which we	479.55605547467223
were reclining? Whose is that letter of your mistress? Do these belong	433.714371420557
to the cardinal? Upon my honor, this man fancies the world belongs to	302.71915032114276
him. There you stood, stammering, stupefied, annihilated. One might	369.1690623412306
have supposed the Bastille appeared before you, and that the gigantic	440.762683544023
Medusa had converted you into stone. Is being in love conspiring? You	438.98197306410316
are in love with a woman whom the cardinal has caused to be shut up,	475.0217651428302
and you wish to get her out of the hands of the cardinal. That’s a	392.98177485186915
match you are playing with his Eminence; this letter is your game. Why	313.73280809599044
should you expose your game to your adversary? That is never done. Let	392.93331822643586
him find it out if he can! We can find out his!”	423.86736176088556
“Well, that’s all very sensible, Athos,” said D’Artagnan.	438.53030034810195
“In that case, let there be no more question of what’s past, and let	362.62280887341706
Aramis resume the letter from his cousin where the cardinal interrupted	393.5186523808351
him.”	319.39603776167985
Aramis drew the letter from his pocket; the three friends surrounded	309.6974846244824
him, and the three lackeys grouped themselves again near the wine jar.	362.1504265033495
“You had only read a line or two,” said D’Artagnan; “read the letter	309.3009452685474
again from the commencement.”	437.1317957282956
“Willingly,” said Aramis.	456.65672207171076
“MY DEAR COUSIN, I think I shall make up my mind to set out for	384.2754599852882
Béthune, where my sister has placed our little servant in the convent	486.8820493005409
of the Carmelites; this poor child is quite resigned, as she knows she	405.75600819326166
cannot live elsewhere without the salvation of her soul being in	342.6773128076635
danger. Nevertheless, if the affairs of our family are arranged, as we	299.35822830134305
hope they will be, I believe she will run the risk of being damned, and	452.0086222670624
will return to those she regrets, particularly as she knows they are	404.4270319867798
always thinking of her. Meanwhile, she is not very wretched; what she	312.6520731968375
most desires is a letter from her intended. I know that such viands	382.385691346278
pass with difficulty through convent gratings; but after all, as I have	351.7074706717648
given you proofs, my dear cousin, I am not unskilled in such affairs,	444.6291600342995
and I will take charge of the commission. My sister thanks you for your	327.1181401639488
good and eternal remembrance. She has experienced much anxiety; but she	451.9623760964853
is now at length a little reassured, having sent her secretary away in	296.39669057130766
order that nothing may happen unexpectedly.	333.794787775666
    “Adieu, my dear cousin. Tell us news of yourself as often as you	294.0560184694513
    can; that is to say, as often as you can with safety. I embrace	352.7867809949169
    you.	303.3965016898902
“MARIE MICHON”	336.4721749747609
“Oh, what do I not owe you, Aramis?” said D’Artagnan. “Dear Constance!	360.5591438955703
I have at length, then, intelligence of you. She lives; she is in	478.3751992726603
safety in a convent; she is at Béthune! Where is Béthune, Athos?”	351.1759699017264
“Why, upon the frontiers of Artois and of Flanders. The siege once	341.46014270081173
over, we shall be able to make a tour in that direction.”	465.89414251177914
“And that will not be long, it is to be hoped,” said Porthos; “for they	471.3994855055813
have this morning hanged a spy who confessed that the Rochellais were	460.5473818305627
reduced to the leather of their shoes. Supposing that after having	329.664185758753
eaten the leather they eat the soles, I cannot see much that is left	426.7342690209855
unless they eat one another.”	474.90395730368124
“Poor fools!” said Athos, emptying a glass of excellent Bordeaux wine	324.86267557532057
which, without having at that period the reputation it now enjoys,	438.3411843274984
merited it no less, “poor fools! As if the Catholic religion was not	456.010454521277
the most advantageous and the most agreeable of all religions! All the	307.7343087936029
same,” resumed he, after having clicked his tongue against his palate,	452.7516467248165
“they are brave fellows! But what the devil are you about, Aramis?”	470.6741833126755
continued Athos. “Why, you are squeezing that letter into your pocket!”	303.210697542434
“Yes,” said D’Artagnan, “Athos is right, it must be burned. And yet if	337.9854754800184
we burn it, who knows whether Monsieur Cardinal has not a secret to	316.7044701987427
interrogate ashes?”	418.88945059159363
“He must have one,” said Athos.	422.3493735379699
“What will you do with the letter, then?” asked Porthos.	490.4191644511528
“Come here, Grimaud,” said Athos. Grimaud rose and obeyed. “As a	467.9745210070213
punishment for having spoken without permission, my friend, you will	391.0432852988096
please to eat this piece of paper; then to recompense you for the	342.4522783581475
service you will have rendered us, you shall afterward drink this glass	381.44228340002496
of wine. First, here is the letter. Eat heartily.”	441.89334313796206
Grimaud smiled; and with his eyes fixed upon the glass which Athos held	448.20201373208454
in his hand, he ground the paper well between his teeth and then	461.36223870291985
swallowed it.	337.6311720090749
“Bravo, Monsieur Grimaud!” said Athos; “and now take this. That’s well.	369.0022139278275
We dispense with your saying grace.”	472.43030986138024
Grimaud silently swallowed the glass of Bordeaux wine; but his eyes,	456.55981361330424
raised toward heaven during this delicious occupation, spoke a language	357.051656057635
which, though mute, was not the less expressive.	326.765291320793
“And now,” said Athos, “unless Monsieur Cardinal should form the	376.7247756287554
ingenious idea of ripping up Grimaud, I think we may be pretty much at	432.7626928033081
our ease respecting the letter.”	308.81607372146993
Meantime, his Eminence continued his melancholy ride, murmuring between	370.84012777435737
his mustaches, “These four men must positively be mine.”	427.92490774719727
Chapter LII.	349.8758823537332
CAPTIVITY: THE FIRST DAY	375.4606856028719
Let us return to Milady, whom a glance thrown upon the coast of France	294.42955898384446
has made us lose sight of for an instant.	390.08289918551236
We shall find her still in the despairing attitude in which we left	490.85563960291313
her, plunged in an abyss of dismal reflection—a dark hell at the gate	346.5771804568311
of which she has almost left hope behind, because for the first time	434.9593108697196
she doubts, for the first time she fears.	355.070206445836
On two occasions her fortune has failed her, on two occasions she has	391.51757374493576
found herself discovered and betrayed; and on these two occasions it	369.50140411494556
was to one fatal genius, sent doubtlessly by the Lord to combat her,	324.27336834711866
that she has succumbed. D’Artagnan has conquered her—her, that	438.53508934279716
invincible power of evil.	408.6166876960766
He has deceived her in her love, humbled her in her pride, thwarted her	366.9261824916198
in her ambition; and now he ruins her fortune, deprives her of liberty,	318.4133902066457
and even threatens her life. Still more, he has lifted the corner of	296.9243938270992
her mask—that shield with which she covered herself and which rendered	371.8107100157915
her so strong.	482.0007581479558
D’Artagnan has turned aside from Buckingham, whom she hates as she	446.5168416868647
hates everyone she has loved, the tempest with which Richelieu	381.64444794005567
threatened him in the person of the queen. D’Artagnan had passed	352.41176381035996
himself upon her as De Wardes, for whom she had conceived one of those	303.97452934946483
tigerlike fancies common to women of her character. D’Artagnan knows	329.2835055432958
that terrible secret which she has sworn no one shall know without	489.4890529875283
dying. In short, at the moment in which she has just obtained from	490.3660417191057
Richelieu a _carte blanche_ by the means of which she is about to take	322.50287122118516
vengeance on her enemy, this precious paper is torn from her hands, and	372.16142983318497
it is D’Artagnan who holds her prisoner and is about to send her to	419.16123705575353
some filthy Botany Bay, some infamous Tyburn of the Indian Ocean.	353.0928723627568
All this she owes to D’Artagnan, without doubt. From whom can come so	457.31877703052004
many disgraces heaped upon her head, if not from him? He alone could	473.262001647844
have transmitted to Lord de Winter all these frightful secrets which he	463.0899299868802
has discovered, one after another, by a train of fatalities. He knows	367.80206682930566
her brother-in-law. He must have written to him.	346.5869547279476
What hatred she distills! Motionless, with her burning and fixed	417.91737435198786
glances, in her solitary apartment, how well the outbursts of passion	434.6959529455181
which at times escape from the depths of her chest with her	410.7449793446292
respiration, accompany the sound of the surf which rises, growls,	299.88511181368625
roars, and breaks itself like an eternal and powerless despair against	391.42976829392484
the rocks on which is built this dark and lofty castle! How many	440.62802781229414
magnificent projects of vengeance she conceives by the light of the	359.5561401899043
flashes which her tempestuous passion casts over her mind against Mme.	411.7393452327816
Bonacieux, against Buckingham, but above all against	438.3742984287426
D’Artagnan—projects lost in the distance of the future.	465.8729523706042
Yes; but in order to avenge herself she must be free. And to be free, a	482.2034760099109
prisoner has to pierce a wall, detach bars, cut through a floor—all	328.10080617272763
undertakings which a patient and strong man may accomplish, but before	306.38072362580425
which the feverish irritations of a woman must give way. Besides, to do	489.1138055802641
all this, time is necessary—months, years; and she has ten or twelve	310.2939589353896
days, as Lord de Winter, her fraternal and terrible jailer, has told	392.3102430352821
her.	301.73089415611025
And yet, if she were a man she would attempt all this, and perhaps	482.4172682893752
might succeed; why, then, did heaven make the mistake of placing that	451.3269892927461
manlike soul in that frail and delicate body?	384.6557509045434
The first moments of her captivity were terrible; a few convulsions of	322.10144762143653
rage which she could not suppress paid her debt of feminine weakness to	411.340935133994
nature. But by degrees she overcame the outbursts of her mad passion;	425.88408690402525
and nervous tremblings which agitated her frame disappeared, and she	446.96809064309195
remained folded within herself like a fatigued serpent in repose.	438.1524673298657
“Go to, go to! I must have been mad to allow myself to be carried away	306.5596006682521
so,” says she, gazing into the glass, which reflects back to her eyes	453.4159551500417
the burning glance by which she appears to interrogate herself. “No	469.2300795226637
violence; violence is the proof of weakness. In the first place, I have	336.19947157699596
never succeeded by that means. Perhaps if I employed my strength	367.7364852513188
against women I might perchance find them weaker than myself, and	353.5652719652677
consequently conquer them; but it is with men that I struggle, and I am	461.4739912005029
but a woman to them. Let me fight like a woman, then; my strength is in	459.86648608102064
my weakness.”	405.5324118977934
Then, as if to render an account to herself of the changes she could	390.50203686608353
place upon her countenance, so mobile and so expressive, she made it	353.5012438973884
take all expressions from that of passionate anger, which convulsed her	436.15433070509687
features, to that of the most sweet, most affectionate, and most	460.994167092389
seducing smile. Then her hair assumed successively, under her skillful	375.80310558961776
hands, all the undulations she thought might assist the charms of her	398.5739128293631
face. At length she murmured, satisfied with herself, “Come, nothing is	442.0529318924314
lost; I am still beautiful.”	453.7990222646904
It was then nearly eight o’clock in the evening. Milady perceived a	306.269735274029
bed; she calculated that the repose of a few hours would not only	294.1969152247016
refresh her head and her ideas, but still further, her complexion. A	325.04608103979945
better idea, however, came into her mind before going to bed. She had	386.49479923820513
heard something said about supper. She had already been an hour in this	378.13083344456106
apartment; they could not long delay bringing her a repast. The	381.50350364829745
prisoner did not wish to lose time; and she resolved to make that very	449.5499663965385
evening some attempts to ascertain the nature of the ground she had to	447.5741242932918
work upon, by studying the characters of the men to whose guardianship	453.4807980378574
she was committed.	333.0331979485109
A light appeared under the door; this light announced the reappearance	346.37555458591794
of her jailers. Milady, who had arisen, threw herself quickly into the	357.59363124856594
armchair, her head thrown back, her beautiful hair unbound and	444.834326608885
disheveled, her bosom half bare beneath her crumpled lace, one hand on	329.34038060975473
her heart, and the other hanging down.	399.91720316374597
The bolts were drawn; the door groaned upon its hinges. Steps sounded	346.25419124237885
in the chamber, and drew near.	396.8738025743052
“Place that table there,” said a voice which the prisoner recognized as	323.2722689297131
that of Felton.	436.8754507593129
The order was executed.	450.89333346649676
“You will bring lights, and relieve the sentinel,” continued Felton.	355.9306340508301
And this double order which the young lieutenant gave to the same	454.9744526955138
individuals proved to Milady that her servants were the same men as her	436.360043369575
guards; that is to say, soldiers.	469.30802889288327
Felton’s orders were, for the rest, executed with a silent rapidity	334.7523055796434
that gave a good idea of the way in which he maintained discipline.	377.61748337412195
At length Felton, who had not yet looked at Milady, turned toward her.	334.44733665781087
“Ah, ah!” said he, “she is asleep; that’s well. When she wakes she can	315.29133186050313
sup.” And he made some steps toward the door.	372.3099708062795
“But, my lieutenant,” said a soldier, less stoical than his chief, and	423.3629101265815
who had approached Milady, “this woman is not asleep.”	375.72353195414644
“What, not asleep!” said Felton; “what is she doing, then?”	324.8601322588701
“She has fainted. Her face is very pale, and I have listened in vain; I	481.84987878079335
do not hear her breathe.”	460.6368936452242
“You are right,” said Felton, after having looked at Milady from the	357.5523302384153
spot on which he stood without moving a step toward her. “Go and tell	355.3084782729357
Lord de Winter that his prisoner has fainted—for this event not having	398.00437817239754
been foreseen, I don’t know what to do.”	325.370924650322
The soldier went out to obey the orders of his officer. Felton sat down	430.98556805144983
upon an armchair which happened to be near the door, and waited without	372.8739546733974
speaking a word, without making a gesture. Milady possessed that great	309.7557874114501
art, so much studied by women, of looking through her long eyelashes	340.47640239554937
without appearing to open the lids. She perceived Felton, who sat with	332.1007913710389
his back toward her. She continued to look at him for nearly ten	470.68711166378023
minutes, and in these ten minutes the immovable guardian never turned	399.1874133883692
round once.	379.3499473984873
She then thought that Lord de Winter would come, and by his presence	332.7906950071718
give fresh strength to her jailer. Her first trial was lost; she acted	433.9761325065799
like a woman who reckons up her resources. As a result she raised her	323.9444167942307
head, opened her eyes, and sighed deeply.	491.6703231131414
At this sigh Felton turned round.	471.6497406456164
“Ah, you are awake, madame,” he said; “then I have nothing more to do	467.1743266073295
here. If you want anything you can ring.”	413.18161740197434
“Oh, my God, my God! how I have suffered!” said Milady, in that	483.10604079907404
harmonious voice which, like that of the ancient enchantresses, charmed	387.43007223646777
all whom she wished to destroy.	440.42195632844937
And she assumed, upon sitting up in the armchair, a still more graceful	329.64278669556325
and abandoned position than when she reclined.	357.71450505992607
Felton arose.	425.97128752322544
“You will be served, thus, madame, three times a day,” said he. “In the	379.5555719394864
morning at nine o’clock, in the day at one o’clock, and in the evening	490.8863073469139
at eight. If that does not suit you, you can point out what other hours	377.24122851569535
you prefer, and in this respect your wishes will be complied with.”	324.3544775592893
“But am I to remain always alone in this vast and dismal chamber?”	487.90721749110173
asked Milady.	362.1120271164966
“A woman of the neighbourhood has been sent for, who will be tomorrow	394.21401047807944
at the castle, and will return as often as you desire her presence.”	334.38305417320544
“I thank you, sir,” replied the prisoner, humbly.	459.03804558541447
Felton made a slight bow, and directed his steps toward the door. At	315.11285145457333
the moment he was about to go out, Lord de Winter appeared in the	334.6771251886298
corridor, followed by the soldier who had been sent to inform him of	430.3418208440816
the swoon of Milady. He held a vial of salts in his hand.	359.2506191438186
“Well, what is it—what is going on here?” said he, in a jeering voice,	374.8628227101778
on seeing the prisoner sitting up and Felton about to go out. “Is this	315.9203081841505
corpse come to life already? Felton, my lad, did you not perceive that	320.12964986892064
you were taken for a novice, and that the first act was being performed	380.7890656318798
of a comedy of which we shall doubtless have the pleasure of following	386.30877564657277
out all the developments?”	315.6039876712589
“I thought so, my lord,” said Felton; “but as the prisoner is a woman,	488.84762302476213
after all, I wish to pay her the attention that every man of gentle	315.06834249452396
birth owes to a woman, if not on her account, at least on my own.”	397.2781251940304
Milady shuddered through her whole system. These words of Felton’s	483.1663236172381
passed like ice through her veins.	346.04891789697916
“So,” replied de Winter, laughing, “that beautiful hair so skillfully	490.46034822725863
disheveled, that white skin, and that languishing look, have not yet	315.94623941609814
seduced you, you heart of stone?”	356.61624698600383
“No, my Lord,” replied the impassive young man; “your Lordship may be	413.57659258165756
assured that it requires more than the tricks and coquetry of a woman	294.9317174843043
to corrupt me.”	382.2440808562762
“In that case, my brave lieutenant, let us leave Milady to find out	465.055306909059
something else, and go to supper; but be easy! She has a fruitful	372.7594682324544
imagination, and the second act of the comedy will not delay its steps	454.9233773096399
after the first.”	415.65212592592366
And at these words Lord de Winter passed his arm through that of	350.55075447479027
Felton, and led him out, laughing.	474.896663680982
“Oh, I will be a match for you!” murmured Milady, between her teeth;	472.9265725010416
“be assured of that, you poor spoiled monk, you poor converted soldier,	383.92572965934187
who has cut his uniform out of a monk’s frock!”	440.28101357627656
“By the way,” resumed de Winter, stopping at the threshold of the door,	484.2289969878874
“you must not, Milady, let this check take away your appetite. Taste	414.4368971436265
that fowl and those fish. On my honor, they are not poisoned. I have a	455.23984641051766
very good cook, and he is not to be my heir; I have full and perfect	439.1805617430564
confidence in him. Do as I do. Adieu, dear sister, till your next	358.4341465635648
swoon!”	384.9836054943042
This was all that Milady could endure. Her hands clutched her armchair;	360.8267047484111
she ground her teeth inwardly; her eyes followed the motion of the door	448.82808002432887
as it closed behind Lord de Winter and Felton, and the moment she was	344.9751268680696
alone a fresh fit of despair seized her. She cast her eyes upon the	399.54841405738557
table, saw the glittering of a knife, rushed toward it and clutched it;	306.3081947865929
but her disappointment was cruel. The blade was round, and of flexible	308.0945018603433
silver.	322.6922242302377
A burst of laughter resounded from the other side of the ill-closed	415.79794554455293
door, and the door reopened.	433.5817989895419
“Ha, ha!” cried Lord de Winter; “ha, ha! Don’t you see, my brave	463.41463438595827
Felton; don’t you see what I told you? That knife was for you, my lad;	411.2778355717893
she would have killed you. Observe, this is one of her peculiarities,	482.0257650423214
to get rid thus, after one fashion or another, of all the people who	472.2566109449945
bother her. If I had listened to you, the knife would have been pointed	309.7355214707099
and of steel. Then no more of Felton; she would have cut your throat,	389.7174640451128
and after that everybody else’s. See, John, see how well she knows how	382.2998831141405
to handle a knife.”	346.86177471518533
In fact, Milady still held the harmless weapon in her clenched hand;	471.5907062889022
but these last words, this supreme insult, relaxed her hands, her	452.7332121357456
strength, and even her will. The knife fell to the ground.	469.6056040803861
“You were right, my Lord,” said Felton, with a tone of profound disgust	404.7576649586675
which sounded to the very bottom of the heart of Milady, “you were	488.82466218703564
right, my Lord, and I was wrong.”	386.85217575724755
And both again left the room.	367.45463198816276
But this time Milady lent a more attentive ear than the first, and she	382.6053897523493
heard their steps die away in the distance of the corridor.	443.4913233245784
“I am lost,” murmured she; “I am lost! I am in the power of men upon	436.3879104323069
whom I can have no more influence than upon statues of bronze or	317.3096244828754
granite; they know me by heart, and are steeled against all my weapons.	413.2951551660925
It is, however, impossible that this should end as they have decreed!”	302.95701386318694
In fact, as this last reflection indicated—this instinctive return to	333.44683083105946
hope—sentiments of weakness or fear did not dwell long in her ardent	384.05859846605216
spirit. Milady sat down to table, ate from several dishes, drank a	323.9983216032885
little Spanish wine, and felt all her resolution return.	398.38325698725254
Before she went to bed she had pondered, analyzed, turned on all sides,	421.64897815906994
examined on all points, the words, the steps, the gestures, the signs,	348.6259076830103
and even the silence of her interlocutors; and of this profound,	374.76713594068235
skillful, and anxious study the result was that Felton, everything	349.130318199436
considered, appeared the more vulnerable of her two persecutors.	374.7950396627732
One expression above all recurred to the mind of the prisoner: “If I	308.0492943855093
had listened to you,” Lord de Winter had said to Felton.	369.51102950575864
Felton, then, had spoken in her favor, since Lord de Winter had not	400.42267191557426
been willing to listen to him.	439.0338685780539
“Weak or strong,” repeated Milady, “that man has, then, a spark of pity	332.49661910889085
in his soul; of that spark I will make a flame that shall devour him.	364.4694266214825
As to the other, he knows me, he fears me, and knows what he has to	347.1713427721161
expect of me if ever I escape from his hands. It is useless, then, to	381.0289430356492
attempt anything with him. But Felton—that’s another thing. He is a	477.1037947074176
young, ingenuous, pure man who seems virtuous; him there are means of	441.9296865291871
destroying.”	385.520393252017
And Milady went to bed and fell asleep with a smile upon her lips.	310.103321097516
Anyone who had seen her sleeping might have said she was a young girl	356.2863572877179
dreaming of the crown of flowers she was to wear on her brow at the	397.61359554230467
next festival.	388.36540768107346
Chapter LIII.	380.81376297883753
CAPTIVITY: THE SECOND DAY	346.3386538720199
Milady dreamed that she at length had D’Artagnan in her power, that she	440.8820237011971
was present at his execution; and it was the sight of his odious blood,	470.38053416112183
flowing beneath the ax of the headsman, which spread that charming	318.8317508714392
smile upon her lips.	476.22865928091085
She slept as a prisoner sleeps, rocked by his first hope.	467.0286888194668
In the morning, when they entered her chamber she was still in bed.	431.3589832060853
Felton remained in the corridor. He brought with him the woman of whom	425.9397783301288
he had spoken the evening before, and who had just arrived; this woman	380.7262098595521
entered, and approaching Milady’s bed, offered her services.	388.39691555143656
Milady was habitually pale; her complexion might therefore deceive a	308.8722735063607
person who saw her for the first time.	460.6246705280578
“I am in a fever,” said she; “I have not slept a single instant during	458.7993251450623
all this long night. I suffer horribly. Are you likely to be more	341.00096531247334
humane to me than others were yesterday? All I ask is permission to	420.07711883927306
remain abed.”	350.3419365887288
“Would you like to have a physician called?” said the woman.	401.468411817163
Felton listened to this dialogue without speaking a word.	379.5257664326464
Milady reflected that the more people she had around her the more she	404.32751899193966
would have to work upon, and Lord de Winter would redouble his watch.	425.0537304199628
Besides, the physician might declare the ailment feigned; and Milady,	396.4652272178696
after having lost the first trick, was not willing to lose the second.	420.61574198922426
“Go and fetch a physician?” said she. “What could be the good of that?	366.5254381706431
These gentlemen declared yesterday that my illness was a comedy; it	449.99458032152006
would be just the same today, no doubt—for since yesterday evening they	487.7344267620383
have had plenty of time to send for a doctor.”	341.1464654338595
“Then,” said Felton, who became impatient, “say yourself, madame, what	330.2547507624144
treatment you wish followed.”	456.08000361121674
“Eh, how can I tell? My God! I know that I suffer, that’s all. Give me	439.76039437341956
anything you like, it is of little consequence.”	405.48409861502716
“Go and fetch Lord de Winter,” said Felton, tired of these eternal	380.0550648613141
complaints.	320.313970990474
“Oh, no, no!” cried Milady; “no, sir, do not call him, I conjure you. I	302.656393996793
am well, I want nothing; do not call him.”	318.0231440909802
She gave so much vehemence, such magnetic eloquence to this	475.9937419637524
exclamation, that Felton in spite of himself advanced some steps into	359.0445512625793
the room.	460.01697368504915
“He has come!” thought Milady.	310.9951066399397
“Meanwhile, madame, if you really suffer,” said Felton, “a physician	433.9386421125873
shall be sent for; and if you deceive us—well, it will be the worse for	360.65793921714976
you. But at least we shall not have to reproach ourselves with	388.25523534916636
anything.”	318.4204697254075
Milady made no reply, but turning her beautiful head round upon her	295.98609385037525
pillow, she burst into tears, and uttered heartbreaking sobs.	296.7592706222504
Felton surveyed her for an instant with his usual impassiveness; then,	468.67238444104674
seeing that the crisis threatened to be prolonged, he went out. The	351.53903846473224
woman followed him, and Lord de Winter did not appear.	318.833982207723
“I fancy I begin to see my way,” murmured Milady, with a savage joy,	361.4992458487959
burying herself under the clothes to conceal from anybody who might be	319.9744929969437
watching her this burst of inward satisfaction.	313.13850461283073
Two hours passed away.	442.2686411652738
“Now it is time that the malady should be over,” said she; “let me	318.63409240698934
rise, and obtain some success this very day. I have but ten days, and	489.03609761199016
this evening two of them will be gone.”	432.35655492971136
In the morning, when they entered Milady’s chamber they had brought her	323.9283933292349
breakfast. Now, she thought, they could not long delay coming to clear	317.4215981381919
the table, and that Felton would then reappear.	419.1963902579819
Milady was not deceived. Felton reappeared, and without observing	398.3172141232793
whether Milady had or had not touched her repast, made a sign that the	375.5506915080604
table should be carried out of the room, it having been brought in	396.25672002008156
ready spread.	477.6228547762445
Felton remained behind; he held a book in his hand.	437.745417849742
Milady, reclining in an armchair near the chimney, beautiful, pale, and	311.94299708832636
resigned, looked like a holy virgin awaiting martyrdom.	320.8934758729611
Felton approached her, and said, “Lord de Winter, who is a Catholic,	427.012577625809
like yourself, madame, thinking that the deprivation of the rites and	459.9421687596459
ceremonies of your church might be painful to you, has consented that	481.7928742221918
you should read every day the ordinary of your Mass; and here is a book	400.21815273901814
which contains the ritual.”	403.4758040729423
At the manner in which Felton laid the book upon the little table near	420.0922352187053
which Milady was sitting, at the tone in which he pronounced the two	324.7419901060198
words, _your Mass_, at the disdainful smile with which he accompanied	428.8030536599448
them, Milady raised her head, and looked more attentively at the	432.9616527796059
officer.	348.7155768263579
By that plain arrangement of the hair, by that costume of extreme	305.0986466689833
simplicity, by the brow polished like marble and as hard and	385.3915553940443
impenetrable, she recognized one of those gloomy Puritans she had so	422.77048553388204
often met, not only in the court of King James, but in that of the King	298.8035554090245
of France, where, in spite of the remembrance of the St. Bartholomew,	300.165592781287
they sometimes came to seek refuge.	450.4131170236619
She then had one of those sudden inspirations which only people of	484.7221756275668
genius receive in great crises, in supreme moments which are to decide	445.6668924246246
their fortunes or their lives.	294.82219632063635
Those two words, _your Mass_, and a simple glance cast upon Felton,	309.6801349099125
revealed to her all the importance of the reply she was about to make;	351.5630320642628
but with that rapidity of intelligence which was peculiar to her, this	332.0105944345853
reply, ready arranged, presented itself to her lips:	352.91255513729845
“I?” said she, with an accent of disdain in unison with that which she	394.92981156679224
had remarked in the voice of the young officer, “I, sir? _My Mass?_	462.79910626736176
Lord de Winter, the corrupted Catholic, knows very well that I am not	399.68560755013647
of his religion, and this is a snare he wishes to lay for me!”	382.06962193957145
“And of what religion are you, then, madame?” asked Felton, with an	470.76932830024873
astonishment which in spite of the empire he held over himself he could	331.88334314770566
not entirely conceal.	402.0269025492168
“I will tell it,” cried Milady, with a feigned exultation, “on the day	488.0934687116678
when I shall have suffered sufficiently for my faith.”	310.24050544199787
The look of Felton revealed to Milady the full extent of the space she	312.9286630152269
had opened for herself by this single word.	368.5948748253006
The young officer, however, remained mute and motionless; his look	489.9679814292979
alone had spoken.	325.9092769349268
“I am in the hands of my enemies,” continued she, with that tone of	299.91090357675495
enthusiasm which she knew was familiar to the Puritans. “Well, let my	415.81039356230104
God save me, or let me perish for my God! That is the reply I beg you	319.4177871118999
to make to Lord de Winter. And as to this book,” added she, pointing to	448.7965576831507
the manual with her finger but without touching it, as if she must be	438.29036045540204
contaminated by it, “you may carry it back and make use of it yourself,	390.03562145795615
for doubtless you are doubly the accomplice of Lord de Winter—the	373.78264834842116
accomplice in his persecutions, the accomplice in his heresies.”	347.46395529334427
Felton made no reply, took the book with the same appearance of	381.64595309374585
repugnance which he had before manifested, and retired pensively.	371.5593876350007
Lord de Winter came toward five o’clock in the evening. Milady had had	446.15190226183125
time, during the whole day, to trace her plan of conduct. She received	302.4614952755092
him like a woman who had already recovered all her advantages.	417.9711777079705
“It appears,” said the baron, seating himself in the armchair opposite	464.3396597445824
that occupied by Milady, and stretching out his legs carelessly upon	369.2145896385804
the hearth, “it appears we have made a little apostasy!”	491.24765684768107
“What do you mean, sir!”	358.4977218872444
“I mean to say that since we last met you have changed your religion.	427.5090177817606
You have not by chance married a Protestant for a third husband, have	362.7837080837992
you?”	357.4929814695119
“Explain yourself, my Lord,” replied the prisoner, with majesty; “for	352.3982926336514
though I hear your words, I declare I do not understand them.”	467.97086696832696
“Then you have no religion at all; I like that best,” replied Lord de	418.47038594342723
Winter, laughing.	365.92350998809195
“Certainly that is most in accord with your own principles,” replied	379.5997333066803
Milady, frigidly.	294.50435156404484
“Oh, I confess it is all the same to me.”	334.22278356472304
“Oh, you need not avow this religious indifference, my Lord; your	394.1879882882927
debaucheries and crimes would vouch for it.”	293.586875966074
“What, you talk of debaucheries, Madame Messalina, Lady Macbeth! Either	339.3616902936759
I misunderstand you or you are very shameless!”	440.34336663684985
“You only speak thus because you are overheard,” coolly replied Milady;	331.1737044519012
“and you wish to interest your jailers and your hangmen against me.”	446.68245645924776
“My jailers and my hangmen! Heyday, madame! you are taking a poetical	301.5782233107461
tone, and the comedy of yesterday turns to a tragedy this evening. As	312.2654739065149
to the rest, in eight days you will be where you ought to be, and my	378.2780352720308
task will be completed.”	322.62464287517895
“Infamous task! impious task!” cried Milady, with the exultation of a	380.04151343831904
victim who provokes his judge.	304.2672874041632
“My word,” said de Winter, rising, “I think the hussy is going mad!	365.3268791691842
Come, come, calm yourself, Madame Puritan, or I’ll remove you to a	359.59917256826225
dungeon. It’s my Spanish wine that has got into your head, is it not?	489.9123817479278
But never mind; that sort of intoxication is not dangerous, and will	473.9524040292107
have no bad effects.”	463.0607064664147
And Lord de Winter retired swearing, which at that period was a very	437.92333482651736
knightly habit.	408.44247230365477
Felton was indeed behind the door, and had not lost one word of this	432.70016016330254
scene. Milady had guessed aright.	407.2000924659196
“Yes, go, go!” said she to her brother; “the effects _are_ drawing	423.0170221051126
near, on the contrary; but you, weak fool, will not see them until it	351.62421743760643
is too late to shun them.”	376.53462510708727
Silence was re-established. Two hours passed away. Milady’s supper was	448.72925893703996
brought in, and she was found deeply engaged in saying her prayers	419.54911706493016
aloud—prayers which she had learned of an old servant of her second	327.1188451835208
husband, a most austere Puritan. She appeared to be in ecstasy, and did	365.4909668036192
not pay the least attention to what was going on around her. Felton	386.5132816223393
made a sign that she should not be disturbed; and when all was	467.80588360476327
arranged, he went out quietly with the soldiers.	372.9498845872575
Milady knew she might be watched, so she continued her prayers to the	348.27771850446237
end; and it appeared to her that the soldier who was on duty at her	357.0749104493644
door did not march with the same step, and seemed to listen. For the	394.41838747641424
moment she wished nothing better. She arose, came to the table, ate but	476.40538824902126
little, and drank only water.	370.2820816626529
An hour after, her table was cleared; but Milady remarked that this	360.2900615112471
time Felton did not accompany the soldiers. He feared, then, to see her	440.77722474332046
too often.	335.6104138284102
She turned toward the wall to smile—for there was in this smile such an	461.79247315795647
expression of triumph that this smile alone would have betrayed her.	335.26019382846744
She allowed, therefore, half an hour to pass away; and as at that	305.9663854492925
moment all was silence in the old castle, as nothing was heard but the	430.1991120073778
eternal murmur of the waves—that immense breaking of the ocean—with her	392.586593309273
pure, harmonious, and powerful voice, she began the first couplet of	330.9829380801805
the psalm then in great favor with the Puritans:	487.4528921291346
“Thou leavest thy servants, Lord,	425.64386383707176
    To see if they be strong;	345.5083433631383
But soon thou dost afford	355.1360360919763
    Thy hand to lead them on.”	417.0039124633695
These verses were not excellent—very far from it; but as it is well	357.3021113744536
known, the Puritans did not pique themselves upon their poetry.	305.644304547606
While singing, Milady listened. The soldier on guard at her door	490.6010716435258
stopped, as if he had been changed into stone. Milady was then able to	340.17848530252894
judge of the effect she had produced.	385.34616731908795
Then she continued her singing with inexpressible fervor and feeling.	489.812824220931
It appeared to her that the sounds spread to a distance beneath the	307.860708234127
vaulted roofs, and carried with them a magic charm to soften the hearts	472.6653458634297
of her jailers. It however likewise appeared that the soldier on duty—a	364.65940103209726
zealous Catholic, no doubt—shook off the charm, for through the door he	407.95462914621487
called: “Hold your tongue, madame! Your song is as dismal as a ‘De	344.0836261137823
profundis’; and if besides the pleasure of being in garrison here, we	432.1988801399641
must hear such things as these, no mortal can hold out.”	489.4733073623472
“Silence!” then exclaimed another stern voice which Milady recognized	375.1706875855858
as that of Felton. “What are you meddling with, stupid? Did anybody	328.0629274856104
order you to prevent that woman from singing? No. You were told to	470.129510304683
guard her—to fire at her if she attempted to fly. Guard her! If she	404.179463315291
flies, kill her; but don’t exceed your orders.”	329.3954264179631
An expression of unspeakable joy lightened the countenance of Milady;	378.2955037522648
but this expression was fleeting as the reflection of lightning.	461.50474289341435
Without appearing to have heard the dialogue, of which she had not lost	320.5685064963962
a word, she began again, giving to her voice all the charm, all the	465.84697114215686
power, all the seduction the demon had bestowed upon it:	355.7673707927523
“For all my tears, my cares,	441.3167419198353
    My exile, and my chains,	326.0802894594834
I have my youth, my prayers,	304.859037776869
    And God, who counts my pains.”	478.69788726231627
Her voice, of immense power and sublime expression, gave to the rude,	311.42797778288576
unpolished poetry of these psalms a magic and an effect which the most	366.2668390540455
exalted Puritans rarely found in the songs of their brethren, and which	467.1337311432908
they were forced to ornament with all the resources of their	299.70387733170804
imagination. Felton believed he heard the singing of the angel who	372.7309275935529
consoled the three Hebrews in the furnace.	484.73184018589234
Milady continued:	488.2820406622423
“One day our doors will ope,	475.54380504530843
    With God come our desire;	407.82135150964575
And if betrays that hope,	476.51418829916605
    To death we can aspire.”	483.4406557082617
This verse, into which the terrible enchantress threw her whole soul,	326.03972664262045
completed the trouble which had seized the heart of the young officer.	336.3297644708406
He opened the door quickly; and Milady saw him appear, pale as usual,	463.53772298028997
but with his eye inflamed and almost wild.	418.2381520950437
“Why do you sing thus, and with such a voice?” said he.	454.481221061837
“Your pardon, sir,” said Milady, with mildness. “I forgot that my songs	483.979309605837
are out of place in this castle. I have perhaps offended you in your	357.82478033891425
creed; but it was without wishing to do so, I swear. Pardon me, then, a	488.1779267346104
fault which is perhaps great, but which certainly was involuntary.”	457.4853519933869
Milady was so beautiful at this moment, the religious ecstasy in which	454.2676273346872
she appeared to be plunged gave such an expression to her countenance,	343.3548766087364
that Felton was so dazzled that he fancied he beheld the angel whom he	402.1595918408742
had only just before heard.	359.5804203634315
“Yes, yes,” said he; “you disturb, you agitate the people who live in	479.97133909605367
the castle.”	335.6558491097112
The poor, senseless young man was not aware of the incoherence of his	321.3136436093708
words, while Milady was reading with her lynx’s eyes the very depths of	333.1477299461597
his heart.	385.30074994499194
“I will be silent, then,” said Milady, casting down her eyes with all	469.2571429100474
the sweetness she could give to her voice, with all the resignation she	409.81543810485755
could impress upon her manner.	340.1643849152709
“No, no, madame,” said Felton, “only do not sing so loud, particularly	297.1052564262046
at night.”	370.50804873413443
And at these words Felton, feeling that he could not long maintain his	409.0285755229131
severity toward his prisoner, rushed out of the room.	307.9469459578357
“You have done right, Lieutenant,” said the soldier. “Such songs	366.09737879434806
disturb the mind; and yet we become accustomed to them, her voice is so	387.2041734751317
beautiful.”	376.81554921326915
Chapter LIV.	447.5849872142777
CAPTIVITY: THE THIRD DAY	473.28235223789096
Felton had fallen; but there was still another step to be taken. He	405.8801006067748
must be retained, or rather he must be left quite alone; and Milady but	474.98456872786426
obscurely perceived the means which could lead to this result.	377.1197875697384
Still more must be done. He must be made to speak, in order that he	335.8204315795634
might be spoken to—for Milady very well knew that her greatest	425.859204320808
seduction was in her voice, which so skillfully ran over the whole	427.50963451252
gamut of tones from human speech to language celestial.	374.0119235445278
Yet in spite of all this seduction Milady might fail—for Felton was	305.0827943405344
forewarned, and that against the least chance. From that moment she	473.92933467326867
watched all his actions, all his words, from the simplest glance of his	320.3920551686434
eyes to his gestures—even to a breath that could be interpreted as a	404.24028391998695
sigh. In short, she studied everything, as a skillful comedian does to	475.9080602424341
whom a new part has been assigned in a line to which he is not	430.4759367614735
accustomed.	391.90844214509787
Face to face with Lord de Winter her plan of conduct was more easy. She	416.310534365582
had laid that down the preceding evening. To remain silent and	332.54051514711836
dignified in his presence; from time to time to irritate him by	334.87974564649517
affected disdain, by a contemptuous word; to provoke him to threats and	374.40561118162987
violence which would produce a contrast with her own resignation—such	399.4775702869365
was her plan. Felton would see all; perhaps he would say nothing, but	308.6444174217423
he would see.	489.6184543712479
In the morning, Felton came as usual; but Milady allowed him to preside	296.1699939121378
over all the preparations for breakfast without addressing a word to	450.2384717824805
him. At the moment when he was about to retire, she was cheered with a	394.09865510472923
ray of hope, for she thought he was about to speak; but his lips moved	454.4799813598846
without any sound leaving his mouth, and making a powerful effort to	378.4524395209551
control himself, he sent back to his heart the words that were about to	316.7615044406489
escape from his lips, and went out. Toward midday, Lord de Winter	359.40034241329477
entered.	360.11565585031076
It was a tolerably fine winter’s day, and a ray of that pale English	335.1577737634755
sun which lights but does not warm came through the bars of her prison.	321.73938214968575
Milady was looking out at the window, and pretended not to hear the	340.7927292267484
door as it opened.	352.21928576431594
“Ah, ah!” said Lord de Winter, “after having played comedy, after	463.5797886584678
having played tragedy, we are now playing melancholy?”	355.13996411575675
The prisoner made no reply.	462.1033430102436
“Yes, yes,” continued Lord de Winter, “I understand. You would like	337.60670365873113
very well to be at liberty on that beach! You would like very well to	447.5441225946464
be in a good ship dancing upon the waves of that emerald-green sea; you	368.4781255705661
would like very well, either on land or on the ocean, to lay for me one	309.5135031406705
of those nice little ambuscades you are so skillful in planning.	331.51981706162
Patience, patience! In four days’ time the shore will be beneath your	410.0279798124805
feet, the sea will be open to you—more open than will perhaps be	466.3129746042575
agreeable to you, for in four days England will be relieved of you.”	373.2077580356459
Milady folded her hands, and raising her fine eyes toward heaven,	439.8512341909599
“Lord, Lord,” said she, with an angelic meekness of gesture and tone,	490.67074416904507
“pardon this man, as I myself pardon him.”	433.8417837196766
“Yes, pray, accursed woman!” cried the baron; “your prayer is so much	458.72652877397945
the more generous from your being, I swear to you, in the power of a	430.003594024506
man who will never pardon you!” and he went out.	307.45127981703916
At the moment he went out a piercing glance darted through the opening	463.23355292377437
of the nearly closed door, and she perceived Felton, who drew quickly	489.65679329638374
to one side to prevent being seen by her.	311.24570378347437
Then she threw herself upon her knees, and began to pray.	431.3490762388336
“My God, my God!” said she, “thou knowest in what holy cause I suffer;	458.2626557744204
give me, then, strength to suffer.”	361.47851138389007
The door opened gently; the beautiful supplicant pretended not to hear	391.33329123623605
the noise, and in a voice broken by tears, she continued:	315.6688464616662
“God of vengeance! God of goodness! wilt thou allow the frightful	453.72670274549614
projects of this man to be accomplished?”	346.9610149532251
Then only she pretended to hear the sound of Felton’s steps, and rising	374.02075535288947
quick as thought, she blushed, as if ashamed of being surprised on her	490.8822871097105
knees.	459.60577182526447
“I do not like to disturb those who pray, madame,” said Felton,	347.70106034398583
seriously; “do not disturb yourself on my account, I beseech you.”	369.24773568008504
“How do you know I was praying, sir?” said Milady, in a voice broken by	469.04388425232264
sobs. “You were deceived, sir; I was not praying.”	475.47930506737464
“Do you think, then, madame,” replied Felton, in the same serious	408.624852366445
voice, but with a milder tone, “do you think I assume the right of	322.56454211804885
preventing a creature from prostrating herself before her Creator? God	445.3845405604418
forbid! Besides, repentance becomes the guilty; whatever crimes they	354.209924101794
may have committed, for me the guilty are sacred at the feet of God!”	292.1021227063907
“Guilty? I?” said Milady, with a smile which might have disarmed the	414.35705535946295
angel of the last judgment. “Guilty? Oh, my God, thou knowest whether I	423.9499064930012
am guilty! Say I am condemned, sir, if you please; but you know that	370.51017970077476
God, who loves martyrs, sometimes permits the innocent to be	487.4424068600829
condemned.”	354.2708038824819
“Were you condemned, were you innocent, were you a martyr,” replied	387.82100107447087
Felton, “the greater would be the necessity for prayer; and I myself	297.96692312962773
would aid you with my prayers.”	418.68970476532604
“Oh, you are a just man!” cried Milady, throwing herself at his feet.	490.1920946760459
“I can hold out no longer, for I fear I shall be wanting in strength at	451.99634594688416
the moment when I shall be forced to undergo the struggle, and confess	347.294334002838
my faith. Listen, then, to the supplication of a despairing woman. You	294.5671528599462
are abused, sir; but that is not the question. I only ask you one	385.8217079712634
favor; and if you grant it me, I will bless you in this world and in	489.98350782897035
the next.”	342.35626143709334
“Speak to the master, madame,” said Felton; “happily I am neither	374.7720421125781
charged with the power of pardoning nor punishing. It is upon one	405.53503883338544
higher placed than I am that God has laid this responsibility.”	348.35547951243296
“To you—no, to you alone! Listen to me, rather than add to my	489.95838602199456
destruction, rather than add to my ignominy!”	327.7805550745878
“If you have merited this shame, madame, if you have incurred this	361.2129642459347
ignominy, you must submit to it as an offering to God.”	428.3305720770341
“What do you say? Oh, you do not understand me! When I speak of	416.84444795865375
ignominy, you think I speak of some chastisement, of imprisonment or	335.872112540611
death. Would to heaven! Of what consequence to me is imprisonment or	328.92390670563555
death?”	420.4716545039672
“It is I who no longer understand you, madame,” said Felton.	405.42641035393007
“Or, rather, who pretend not to understand me, sir!” replied the	357.9326674487897
prisoner, with a smile of incredulity.	311.32620121501384
“No, madame, on the honor of a soldier, on the faith of a Christian.”	397.63072291782726
“What, you are ignorant of Lord de Winter’s designs upon me?”	382.96034252467985
“I am.”	352.1800425810338
“Impossible; you are his confidant!”	420.27999394979855
“I never lie, madame.”	340.13882802881204
“Oh, he conceals them too little for you not to divine them.”	470.80583911329916
“I seek to divine nothing, madame; I wait till I am confided in, and	326.4981576372388
apart from that which Lord de Winter has said to me before you, he has	414.3778061343399
confided nothing to me.”	489.34424255116346
“Why, then,” cried Milady, with an incredible tone of truthfulness,	329.7444449934911
“you are not his accomplice; you do not know that he destines me to a	362.82083115341493
disgrace which all the punishments of the world cannot equal in	346.00899400887175
horror?”	310.94590449380127
“You are deceived, madame,” said Felton, blushing; “Lord de Winter is	382.17093490633164
not capable of such a crime.”	425.6151179285396
“Good,” said Milady to herself; “without thinking what it is, he calls	374.39713635072076
it a crime!” Then aloud, “The friend of that wretch is capable of	387.82232085142016
everything.”	438.07941668631497
“Whom do you call _that wretch?_” asked Felton.	387.8278275998763
“Are there, then, in England two men to whom such an epithet can be	327.7562117453071
applied?”	441.4801181485082
“You mean George Villiers?” asked Felton, whose looks became excited.	349.7536528485708
“Whom Pagans and unbelieving Gentiles call Duke of Buckingham,” replied	466.1358651832126
Milady. “I could not have thought that there was an Englishman in all	455.88109768843924
England who would have required so long an explanation to make him	424.0378395162067
understand of whom I was speaking.”	364.04796334657146
“The hand of the Lord is stretched over him,” said Felton; “he will not	300.3981923012643
escape the chastisement he deserves.”	294.677302670228
Felton only expressed, with regard to the duke, the feeling of	476.5226240136376
execration which all the English had declared toward him whom the	437.1558207895689
Catholics themselves called the extortioner, the pillager, the	306.3938576458723
debauchee, and whom the Puritans styled simply Satan.	315.2430104882351
“Oh, my God, my God!” cried Milady; “when I supplicate thee to pour	449.13052312103423
upon this man the chastisement which is his due, thou knowest it is not	307.093704531026
my own vengeance I pursue, but the deliverance of a whole nation that I	474.4963281179974
implore!”	300.98370377786887
“Do you know him, then?” asked Felton.	439.38336181539233
“At length he interrogates me!” said Milady to herself, at the height	438.7077521100909
of joy at having obtained so quickly such a great result. “Oh, know	434.39904683811875
him? Yes, yes! to my misfortune, to my eternal misfortune!” and Milady	420.204343864616
twisted her arms as if in a paroxysm of grief.	449.3550809289057
Felton no doubt felt within himself that his strength was abandoning	353.7880959385572
him, and he made several steps toward the door; but the prisoner, whose	410.32829671757645
eye never left him, sprang in pursuit of him and stopped him.	304.27392700079923
“Sir,” cried she, “be kind, be clement, listen to my prayer! That	389.4396562168421
knife, which the fatal prudence of the baron deprived me of, because he	381.37687811306023
knows the use I would make of it! Oh, hear me to the end! that knife,	463.05296101590955
give it to me for a minute only, for mercy’s, for pity’s sake! I will	453.21348297465664
embrace your knees! You shall shut the door that you may be certain I	335.0847153217891
contemplate no injury to you! My God! to you—the only just, good, and	411.2253874074255
compassionate being I have met with! To you—my preserver, perhaps! One	316.529586233746
minute that knife, one minute, a single minute, and I will restore it	326.1908824397209
to you through the grating of the door. Only one minute, Mr. Felton,	409.8560387232192
and you will have saved my honor!”	293.17192617546334
“To kill yourself?” cried Felton, with terror, forgetting to withdraw	304.5159856318635
his hands from the hands of the prisoner, “to kill yourself?”	342.0919898686001
“I have told, sir,” murmured Milady, lowering her voice, and allowing	419.8466559805588
herself to sink overpowered to the ground; “I have told my secret! He	340.922177112206
knows all! My God, I am lost!”	328.7751907246062
Felton remained standing, motionless and undecided.	380.7005924295893
“He still doubts,” thought Milady; “I have not been earnest enough.”	471.8136246865133
Someone was heard in the corridor; Milady recognized the step of Lord	491.4747431374982
de Winter.	458.0056449198013
Felton recognized it also, and made a step toward the door.	385.93571352484116
Milady sprang toward him. “Oh, not a word,” said she in a concentrated	388.48954969236496
voice, “not a word of all that I have said to you to this man, or I am	333.40048105521544
lost, and it would be you—you—”	464.62449201494917
Then as the steps drew near, she became silent for fear of being heard,	416.82917224222825
applying, with a gesture of infinite terror, her beautiful hand to	379.6785401097966
Felton’s mouth.	424.0145677739926
Felton gently repulsed Milady, and she sank into a chair.	488.8809263872037
Lord de Winter passed before the door without stopping, and they heard	378.42260351346744
the noise of his footsteps soon die away.	356.49249879289357
Felton, as pale as death, remained some instants with his ear bent and	459.5242425220323
listening; then, when the sound was quite extinct, he breathed like a	371.7584131369107
man awaking from a dream, and rushed out of the apartment.	385.55999144648933
“Ah!” said Milady, listening in her turn to the noise of Felton’s	470.8003587973525
steps, which withdrew in a direction opposite to those of Lord de	434.4641613631459
Winter; “at length you are mine!”	375.39952559649953
Then her brow darkened. “If he tells the baron,” said she, “I am	384.2430596355034
lost—for the baron, who knows very well that I shall not kill myself,	378.7853189807348
will place me before him with a knife in my hand, and he will discover	363.9684835448983
that all this despair is but acted.”	466.60452117178284
She placed herself before the glass, and regarded herself attentively;	296.0960422205671
never had she appeared more beautiful.	327.1928649758987
“Oh, yes,” said she, smiling, “but we won’t tell him!”	349.02080376667163
In the evening Lord de Winter accompanied the supper.	353.479654372528
“Sir,” said Milady, “is your presence an indispensable accessory of my	350.7160869648055
captivity? Could you not spare me the increase of torture which your	446.0239604716197
visits cause me?”	490.81902643016724
“How, dear sister!” said Lord de Winter. “Did not you sentimentally	320.40224514039716
inform me with that pretty mouth of yours, so cruel to me today, that	301.5374483121613
you came to England solely for the pleasure of seeing me at your ease,	425.69156969227754
an enjoyment of which you told me you so sensibly felt the deprivation	294.4262120492144
that you had risked everything for it—seasickness, tempest, captivity?	395.8020667326003
Well, here I am; be satisfied. Besides, this time, my visit has a	292.57957531001364
motive.”	295.2121438418344
Milady trembled; she thought Felton had told all. Perhaps never in her	421.8122910530243
life had this woman, who had experienced so many opposite and powerful	444.99222992345864
emotions, felt her heart beat so violently.	379.7929495820443
She was seated. Lord de Winter took a chair, drew it toward her, and	435.52573641159756
sat down close beside her. Then taking a paper out of his pocket, he	365.46605207312666
unfolded it slowly.	488.47127808853486
“Here,” said he, “I want to show you the kind of passport which I have	448.9462497480828
drawn up, and which will serve you henceforward as the rule of order in	428.3912788618817
