the life I consent to leave you.”	437.45061722149904
Then turning his eyes from Milady to the paper, he read: “‘Order to	484.6747792352038
conduct—’ The name is blank,” interrupted Lord de Winter. “If you have	480.1471978059501
any preference you can point it out to me; and if it be not within a	376.06087567330843
thousand leagues of London, attention will be paid to your wishes. I	385.5167641702351
will begin again, then:	401.01723726083526
“‘Order to conduct to—the person named Charlotte Backson, branded by	427.5069775890368
the justice of the kingdom of France, but liberated after chastisement.	360.41542830107693
She is to dwell in this place without ever going more than three	478.6202792131688
leagues from it. In case of any attempt to escape, the penalty of death	424.73142812545467
is to be applied. She will receive five shillings per day for lodging	367.7194355248579
and food’”.	379.88002329924836
“That order does not concern me,” replied Milady, coldly, “since it	381.20129188973436
bears another name than mine.”	408.1079805363151
“A name? Have you a name, then?”	368.669009650856
“I bear that of your brother.”	409.1528915199111
“Ay, but you are mistaken. My brother is only your second husband; and	437.8184193689959
your first is still living. Tell me his name, and I will put it in the	370.20223275388093
place of the name of Charlotte Backson. No? You will not? You are	367.85965080307955
silent? Well, then you must be registered as Charlotte Backson.”	462.3955334163543
Milady remained silent; only this time it was no longer from	465.76469864508795
affectation, but from terror. She believed the order ready for	486.0008820037491
execution. She thought that Lord de Winter had hastened her departure;	335.7316704666076
she thought she was condemned to set off that very evening. Everything	403.2940945638999
in her mind was lost for an instant; when all at once she perceived	447.76813460881505
that no signature was attached to the order. The joy she felt at this	491.89713549460134
discovery was so great she could not conceal it.	476.39072799817114
“Yes, yes,” said Lord de Winter, who perceived what was passing in her	484.4882861212376
mind; “yes, you look for the signature, and you say to yourself: ‘All	408.0845097481016
is not lost, for that order is not signed. It is only shown to me to	326.86317997573167
terrify me, that’s all.’ You are mistaken. Tomorrow this order will be	329.4567306240491
sent to the Duke of Buckingham. The day after tomorrow it will return	461.8944765330267
signed by his hand and marked with his seal; and four-and-twenty hours	429.1494879060994
afterward I will answer for its being carried into execution. Adieu,	325.70060173267296
madame. That is all I had to say to you.”	368.1442210884953
“And I reply to you, sir, that this abuse of power, this exile under a	397.3686180149648
fictitious name, are infamous!”	402.09560583137886
“Would you like better to be hanged in your true name, Milady? You know	421.3470200001219
that the English laws are inexorable on the abuse of marriage. Speak	463.812802135258
freely. Although my name, or rather that of my brother, would be mixed	443.55437931008277
up with the affair, I will risk the scandal of a public trial to make	400.6547423615381
myself certain of getting rid of you.”	422.0330660422027
Milady made no reply, but became as pale as a corpse.	322.8023655034612
“Oh, I see you prefer peregrination. That’s well madame; and there is	491.7610321863941
an old proverb that says, ‘Traveling trains youth.’ My faith! you are	434.5615652961228
not wrong after all, and life is sweet. That’s the reason why I take	368.1604418021549
such care you shall not deprive me of mine. There only remains, then,	305.7583269529928
the question of the five shillings to be settled. You think me rather	368.0104580073122
parsimonious, don’t you? That’s because I don’t care to leave you the	473.9942903689716
means of corrupting your jailers. Besides, you will always have your	310.21290256790206
charms left to seduce them with. Employ them, if your check with regard	435.69034869039865
to Felton has not disgusted you with attempts of that kind.”	370.0370229660838
“Felton has not told him,” said Milady to herself. “Nothing is lost,	301.2067244674102
then.”	402.11523575113404
“And now, madame, till I see you again! Tomorrow I will come and	401.3825584723747
announce to you the departure of my messenger.”	395.9065666710036
Lord de Winter rose, saluted her ironically, and went out.	348.77754005365694
Milady breathed again. She had still four days before her. Four days	311.24047582631124
would quite suffice to complete the seduction of Felton.	313.85737848317984
A terrible idea, however, rushed into her mind. She thought that Lord	323.05344962055403
de Winter would perhaps send Felton himself to get the order signed by	463.99972125766897
the Duke of Buckingham. In that case Felton would escape her—for in	334.80918178467687
order to secure success, the magic of a continuous seduction was	368.31591251438476
necessary. Nevertheless, as we have said, one circumstance reassured	455.7462506565189
her. Felton had not spoken.	418.2101401684504
As she would not appear to be agitated by the threats of Lord de	406.5805716383928
Winter, she placed herself at the table and ate.	319.75708955101163
Then, as she had done the evening before, she fell on her knees and	390.47681378432
repeated her prayers aloud. As on the evening before, the soldier	391.5147679046498
stopped his march to listen to her.	358.6917760278299
Soon after she heard lighter steps than those of the sentinel, which	330.6979288063567
came from the end of the corridor and stopped before her door.	311.9975542494936
“It is he,” said she. And she began the same religious chant which had	491.665065072634
so strongly excited Felton the evening before.	471.05049273047155
But although her voice—sweet, full, and sonorous—vibrated as	397.78312341514345
harmoniously and as affectingly as ever, the door remained shut. It	390.4335690806961
appeared however to Milady that in one of the furtive glances she	433.02990821610365
darted from time to time at the grating of the door she thought she saw	357.8073724647583
the ardent eyes of the young man through the narrow opening. But	470.2116680077417
whether this was reality or vision, he had this time sufficient	474.60882743844365
self-command not to enter.	356.8106905201122
However, a few instants after she had finished her religious song,	375.57132479360314
Milady thought she heard a profound sigh. Then the same steps she had	298.6750859841826
heard approach slowly withdrew, as if with regret.	486.5342362103493
Chapter LV.	429.2630718702861
CAPTIVITY: THE FOURTH DAY	371.9341360875375
The next day, when Felton entered Milady’s apartment he found her	485.7511604634789
standing, mounted upon a chair, holding in her hands a cord made by	294.8309588780056
means of torn cambric handkerchiefs, twisted into a kind of rope one	308.8725000955456
with another, and tied at the ends. At the noise Felton made in	390.91794719606736
entering, Milady leaped lightly to the ground, and tried to conceal	483.57330888716194
behind her the improvised cord she held in her hand.	298.53757239121353
The young man was more pale than usual, and his eyes, reddened by want	383.0468955666836
of sleep, denoted that he had passed a feverish night. Nevertheless,	339.99859624147916
his brow was armed with a severity more austere than ever.	309.1110669986008
He advanced slowly toward Milady, who had seated herself, and taking an	402.19438629910667
end of the murderous rope which by neglect, or perhaps by design, she	455.4775603994307
allowed to be seen, “What is this, madame?” he asked coldly.	353.38999081526197
“That? Nothing,” said Milady, smiling with that painful expression	299.6428197805702
which she knew so well how to give to her smile. “Ennui is the mortal	318.76443053053845
enemy of prisoners; I had ennui, and I amused myself with twisting that	337.11315001298993
rope.”	336.8788683844986
Felton turned his eyes toward the part of the wall of the apartment	296.55809383815784
before which he had found Milady standing in the armchair in which she	364.3863110058943
was now seated, and over her head he perceived a gilt-headed screw,	461.0276034284045
fixed in the wall for the purpose of hanging up clothes or weapons.	400.84942684510037
He started, and the prisoner saw that start—for though her eyes were	394.03260303491214
cast down, nothing escaped her.	471.2194998297014
“What were you doing on that armchair?” asked he.	332.331233526425
“Of what consequence?” replied Milady.	436.3311116210299
“But,” replied Felton, “I wish to know.”	402.6217417031521
“Do not question me,” said the prisoner; “you know that we who are true	446.9307294119424
Christians are forbidden to lie.”	344.98777439404034
“Well, then,” said Felton, “I will tell you what you were doing, or	462.6764626919926
rather what you meant to do; you were going to complete the fatal	318.95963483315086
project you cherish in your mind. Remember, madame, if our God forbids	387.332186988262
falsehood, he much more severely condemns suicide.”	482.4589400257306
“When God sees one of his creatures persecuted unjustly, placed between	468.04917092376
suicide and dishonor, believe me, sir,” replied Milady, in a tone of	402.4783124368217
deep conviction, “God pardons suicide, for then suicide becomes	294.85831613632115
martyrdom.”	405.41060480033946
“You say either too much or too little; speak, madame. In the name of	383.6167504742119
heaven, explain yourself.”	464.39124919591103
“That I may relate my misfortunes for you to treat them as fables; that	427.16389123394026
I may tell you my projects for you to go and betray them to my	385.946272655507
persecutor? No, sir. Besides, of what importance to you is the life or	478.11816929118316
death of a condemned wretch? You are only responsible for my body, is	310.4988875373389
it not so? And provided you produce a carcass that may be recognized as	346.7656610412416
mine, they will require no more of you; nay, perhaps you will even have	336.51892038532753
a double reward.”	458.60400412426765
“I, madame, I?” cried Felton. “You suppose that I would ever accept the	327.22728993856805
price of your life? Oh, you cannot believe what you say!”	381.4618329151108
“Let me act as I please, Felton, let me act as I please,” said Milady,	352.6240962595508
elated. “Every soldier must be ambitious, must he not? You are a	387.5731233076448
lieutenant? Well, you will follow me to the grave with the rank of	327.63577784817096
captain.”	482.0871596140164
“What have I, then, done to you,” said Felton, much agitated, “that you	394.4573747758602
should load me with such a responsibility before God and before men? In	300.57140682586237
a few days you will be away from this place; your life, madame, will	480.2083331366497
then no longer be under my care, and,” added he, with a sigh, “then you	297.3318356940727
can do what you will with it.”	425.6864291619531
“So,” cried Milady, as if she could not resist giving utterance to a	312.7785276927551
holy indignation, “you, a pious man, you who are called a just man, you	449.60826229522934
ask but one thing—and that is that you may not be inculpated, annoyed,	295.43232737368515
by my death!”	376.2620715385631
“It is my duty to watch over your life, madame, and I will watch.”	448.90586022810885
“But do you understand the mission you are fulfilling? Cruel enough, if	471.2853041082269
I am guilty; but what name can you give it, what name will the Lord	446.34651207140394
give it, if I am innocent?”	370.20439394766976
“I am a soldier, madame, and fulfill the orders I have received.”	408.68608650269306
“Do you believe, then, that at the day of the Last Judgment God will	312.7527284683755
separate blind executioners from iniquitous judges? You are not willing	373.52087211092703
that I should kill my body, and you make yourself the agent of him who	462.60451857981843
would kill my soul.”	381.0061587982562
“But I repeat it again to you,” replied Felton, in great emotion, “no	388.1003766187547
danger threatens you; I will answer for Lord de Winter as for myself.”	396.9806405212213
“Dunce,” cried Milady, “dunce! who dares to answer for another man,	306.8768281845715
when the wisest, when those most after God’s own heart, hesitate to	306.5423467359367
answer for themselves, and who ranges himself on the side of the	409.3398313179147
strongest and the most fortunate, to crush the weakest and the most	483.2312058199964
unfortunate.”	430.56100614459945
“Impossible, madame, impossible,” murmured Felton, who felt to the	353.0554845996984
bottom of his heart the justness of this argument. “A prisoner, you	441.8173467830492
will not recover your liberty through me; living, you will not lose	446.86691554092215
your life through me.”	377.91243898448033
“Yes,” cried Milady, “but I shall lose that which is much dearer to me	452.47046757691476
than life, I shall lose my honor, Felton; and it is you, you whom I	483.55615060139235
make responsible, before God and before men, for my shame and my	419.84854358899156
infamy.”	489.6507764128658
This time Felton, immovable as he was, or appeared to be, could not	396.5325789087453
resist the secret influence which had already taken possession of him.	308.85454333589973
To see this woman, so beautiful, fair as the brightest vision, to see	404.22168771272004
her by turns overcome with grief and threatening; to resist at once the	381.70767243593724
ascendancy of grief and beauty—it was too much for a visionary; it was	483.0603529304023
too much for a brain weakened by the ardent dreams of an ecstatic	436.6860705648563
faith; it was too much for a heart furrowed by the love of heaven that	308.8871965989139
burns, by the hatred of men that devours.	361.3641023911855
Milady saw the trouble. She felt by intuition the flame of the opposing	433.03497201769176
passions which burned with the blood in the veins of the young fanatic.	323.0323901144447
As a skillful general, seeing the enemy ready to surrender, marches	413.2262253610272
toward him with a cry of victory, she rose, beautiful as an antique	451.71126636152417
priestess, inspired like a Christian virgin, her arms extended, her	441.61405089737264
throat uncovered, her hair disheveled, holding with one hand her robe	411.48972931461105
modestly drawn over her breast, her look illumined by that fire which	451.1654561649622
had already created such disorder in the veins of the young Puritan,	309.44883328604374
and went toward him, crying out with a vehement air, and in her	442.0504182655513
melodious voice, to which on this occasion she communicated a terrible	307.76971816034194
energy:	320.5806555998307
“Let this victim to Baal be sent,	490.6050386501345
    To the lions the martyr be thrown!	299.11202288422675
Thy God shall teach thee to repent!	389.01389424788346
    From th’ abyss he’ll give ear to my moan.”	343.4410517238568
Felton stood before this strange apparition like one petrified.	315.9693696855915
“Who art thou? Who art thou?” cried he, clasping his hands. “Art thou a	348.2845508441532
messenger from God; art thou a minister from hell; art thou an angel or	388.9556428419768
a demon; callest thou thyself Eloa or Astarte?”	388.2793314668276
“Do you not know me, Felton? I am neither an angel nor a demon; I am a	444.2530552445663
daughter of earth, I am a sister of thy faith, that is all.”	318.72333494466824
“Yes, yes!” said Felton, “I doubted, but now I believe.”	361.43350986142707
“You believe, and still you are an accomplice of that child of Belial	387.84418571809937
who is called Lord de Winter! You believe, and yet you leave me in the	451.26281684480256
hands of mine enemies, of the enemy of England, of the enemy of God!	437.7109643273432
You believe, and yet you deliver me up to him who fills and defiles the	324.8587603233575
world with his heresies and debaucheries—to that infamous Sardanapalus	382.3825232899517
whom the blind call the Duke of Buckingham, and whom believers name	362.09108641520334
Antichrist!”	314.1626247830018
“I deliver you up to Buckingham? I? what mean you by that?”	301.4541946385202
“They have eyes,” cried Milady, “but they see not; ears have they, but	342.0123205190378
they hear not.”	339.0635673904681
“Yes, yes!” said Felton, passing his hands over his brow, covered with	407.00907395695833
sweat, as if to remove his last doubt. “Yes, I recognize the voice	399.56554748738176
which speaks to me in my dreams; yes, I recognize the features of the	351.0484654260443
angel who appears to me every night, crying to my soul, which cannot	318.413434208625
sleep: ‘Strike, save England, save thyself—for thou wilt die without	294.98276577431113
having appeased God!’ Speak, speak!” cried Felton, “I can understand	396.16593387615916
you now.”	366.6426258311223
A flash of terrible joy, but rapid as thought, gleamed from the eyes of	356.4917859104288
Milady.	314.983085692127
However fugitive this homicide flash, Felton saw it, and started as if	415.03619918994343
its light had revealed the abysses of this woman’s heart. He recalled,	383.41049227631606
all at once, the warnings of Lord de Winter, the seductions of Milady,	339.93441195835743
her first attempts after her arrival. He drew back a step, and hung	325.5238719561306
down his head, without, however, ceasing to look at her, as if,	344.63031675656373
fascinated by this strange creature, he could not detach his eyes from	488.24905211604477
her eyes.	321.260743597998
Milady was not a woman to misunderstand the meaning of this hesitation.	381.076421180103
Under her apparent emotions her icy coolness never abandoned her.	373.2111894721161
Before Felton replied, and before she should be forced to resume this	338.9382820732843
conversation, so difficult to be sustained in the same exalted tone,	324.5941699715209
she let her hands fall; and as if the weakness of the woman overpowered	408.5614170162776
the enthusiasm of the inspired fanatic, she said: “But no, it is not	480.62416654135166
for me to be the Judith to deliver Bethulia from this Holofernes. The	421.2681789492865
sword of the eternal is too heavy for my arm. Allow me, then, to avoid	370.73846643333263
dishonor by death; let me take refuge in martyrdom. I do not ask you	298.2520787450901
for liberty, as a guilty one would, nor for vengeance, as would a	457.0002569740951
pagan. Let me die; that is all. I supplicate you, I implore you on my	414.76401553311945
knees—let me die, and my last sigh shall be a blessing for my	371.63628522070843
preserver.”	484.22115051607716
Hearing that voice, so sweet and suppliant, seeing that look, so timid	372.86803856090216
and downcast, Felton reproached himself. By degrees the enchantress had	359.0947454529625
clothed herself with that magic adornment which she assumed and threw	318.81323792609834
aside at will; that is to say, beauty, meekness, and tears—and above	349.0471485197562
all, the irresistible attraction of mystical voluptuousness, the most	486.77697248298693
devouring of all voluptuousness.	444.57555169868743
“Alas!” said Felton, “I can do but one thing, which is to pity you if	305.81242251649553
you prove to me you are a victim! But Lord de Winter makes cruel	316.3469932337918
accusations against you. You are a Christian; you are my sister in	468.70117365374756
religion. I feel myself drawn toward you—I, who have never loved anyone	480.3928975019519
but my benefactor—I who have met with nothing but traitors and impious	438.23284850582706
men. But you, madame, so beautiful in reality, you, so pure in	320.68325012136165
appearance, must have committed great iniquities for Lord de Winter to	489.94739976555996
pursue you thus.”	441.9723325897513
“They have eyes,” repeated Milady, with an accent of indescribable	356.8177532345601
grief, “but they see not; ears have they, but they hear not.”	412.94290163403787
“But,” cried the young officer, “speak, then, speak!”	354.73220574777537
“Confide my shame to you,” cried Milady, with the blush of modesty upon	423.9469154813477
her countenance, “for often the crime of one becomes the shame of	356.86291089470774
another—confide my shame to you, a man, and I a woman? Oh,” continued	466.9070538145701
she, placing her hand modestly over her beautiful eyes, “never!	413.34526416201606
never!—I could not!”	413.4245231602708
“To me, to a brother?” said Felton.	306.73043433168596
Milady looked at him for some time with an expression which the young	449.0398533860233
man took for doubt, but which, however, was nothing but observation, or	347.10062328953575
rather the wish to fascinate.	313.1502426608871
Felton, in his turn a suppliant, clasped his hands.	392.53283466851656
“Well, then,” said Milady, “I confide in my brother; I will dare to—”	362.41722003303084
At this moment the steps of Lord de Winter were heard; but this time	319.65750374011463
the terrible brother-in-law of Milady did not content himself, as on	312.0083806379929
the preceding day, with passing before the door and going away again.	379.2534948902003
He paused, exchanged two words with the sentinel; then the door opened,	342.38726575586566
and he appeared.	313.1082555019811
During the exchange of these two words Felton drew back quickly, and	461.10183507783347
when Lord de Winter entered, he was several paces from the prisoner.	312.12897116025465
The baron entered slowly, sending a scrutinizing glance from Milady to	326.7809611043554
the young officer.	305.2388361774408
“You have been here a very long time, John,” said he. “Has this woman	490.70338569550563
been relating her crimes to you? In that case I can comprehend the	382.7503566478265
length of the conversation.”	475.8888657829247
Felton started; and Milady felt she was lost if she did not come to the	316.8492914607743
assistance of the disconcerted Puritan.	463.3939839711094
“Ah, you fear your prisoner should escape!” said she. “Well, ask your	448.577670908395
worthy jailer what favor I this instant solicited of him.”	450.49445348946324
“You demanded a favor?” said the baron, suspiciously.	436.9708100273409
“Yes, my Lord,” replied the young man, confused.	380.9621631585263
“And what favor, pray?” asked Lord de Winter.	299.276820386559
“A knife, which she would return to me through the grating of the door	458.3475407521492
a minute after she had received it,” replied Felton.	373.63601707217674
“There is someone, then, concealed here whose throat this amiable lady	376.9394544565961
is desirous of cutting,” said de Winter, in an ironical, contemptuous	330.97414932573054
tone.	467.173177405381
“There is myself,” replied Milady.	418.561064287611
“I have given you the choice between America and Tyburn,” replied Lord	415.24180770120665
de Winter. “Choose Tyburn, madame. Believe me, the cord is more certain	372.4152639609719
than the knife.”	444.5085855630523
Felton grew pale, and made a step forward, remembering that at the	449.3223640047293
moment he entered Milady had a rope in her hand.	426.67497576381464
“You are right,” said she, “I have often thought of it.” Then she added	411.43000979061037
in a low voice, “And I will think of it again.”	454.17764713571364
Felton felt a shudder run to the marrow of his bones; probably Lord de	342.1670188432829
Winter perceived this emotion.	294.8699537608477
“Mistrust yourself, John,” said he. “I have placed reliance upon you,	382.8404778966966
my friend. Beware! I have warned you! But be of good courage, my lad;	368.930216838099
in three days we shall be delivered from this creature, and where I	386.9508046188781
shall send her she can harm nobody.”	468.6370882059964
“You hear him!” cried Milady, with vehemence, so that the baron might	414.0860165399189
believe she was addressing heaven, and that Felton might understand she	431.111573837857
was addressing him.	479.00232387959227
Felton lowered his head and reflected.	323.4325953717158
The baron took the young officer by the arm, and turned his head over	323.94021749399445
his shoulder, so as not to lose sight of Milady till he was gone out.	402.41105204297264
“Well,” said the prisoner, when the door was shut, “I am not so far	424.72022910976204
advanced as I believed. De Winter has changed his usual stupidity into	411.02447124408286
a strange prudence. It is the desire of vengeance, and how desire molds	310.4117428421377
a man! As to Felton, he hesitates. Ah, he is not a man like that cursed	483.23320645228574
D’Artagnan. A Puritan only adores virgins, and he adores them by	311.3084716402475
clasping his hands. A Musketeer loves women, and he loves them by	483.57906219869386
clasping his arms round them.”	359.466458902549
Milady waited, then, with much impatience, for she feared the day would	297.65159133497895
pass away without her seeing Felton again. At last, in an hour after	304.97093051965476
the scene we have just described, she heard someone speaking in a low	464.6398659288364
voice at the door. Presently the door opened, and she perceived Felton.	476.0892817966974
The young man advanced rapidly into the chamber, leaving the door open	480.2877457936987
behind him, and making a sign to Milady to be silent; his face was much	293.10334465738833
agitated.	488.54345390082494
“What do you want with me?” said she.	327.8628635355257
“Listen,” replied Felton, in a low voice. “I have just sent away the	372.60693437425226
sentinel that I might remain here without anybody knowing it, in order	300.28435820388347
to speak to you without being overheard. The baron has just related a	302.9663883656255
frightful story to me.”	316.261938386143
Milady assumed her smile of a resigned victim, and shook her head.	469.164718564669
“Either you are a demon,” continued Felton, “or the baron—my	390.85210352524774
benefactor, my father—is a monster. I have known you four days; I have	481.4691847262949
loved him four years. I therefore may hesitate between you. Be not	382.6516068908088
alarmed at what I say; I want to be convinced. Tonight, after twelve, I	374.81176558885613
will come and see you, and you shall convince me.”	336.1643592262999
“No, Felton, no, my brother,” said she; “the sacrifice is too great,	424.94082243085944
and I feel what it must cost you. No, I am lost; do not be lost with	339.1809758626947
me. My death will be much more eloquent than my life, and the silence	378.13781241391393
of the corpse will convince you much better than the words of the	418.5803432092772
prisoner.”	460.1076209329946
“Be silent, madame,” cried Felton, “and do not speak to me thus; I came	486.51446474610555
to entreat you to promise me upon your honor, to swear to me by what	429.95401259476455
you hold most sacred, that you will make no attempt upon your life.”	374.0766931850799
“I will not promise,” said Milady, “for no one has more respect for a	459.1415362893089
promise or an oath than I have; and if I make a promise I must keep	292.0027951208125
it.”	408.06326874642843
“Well,” said Felton, “only promise till you have seen me again. If,	477.3504015459837
when you have seen me again, you still persist—well, then you shall be	299.58235749784143
free, and I myself will give you the weapon you desire.”	419.5162201315249
“Well,” said Milady, “for you I will wait.”	323.58744763843333
“Swear.”	447.250238198627
“I swear it, by our God. Are you satisfied?”	344.55426523945215
“Well,” said Felton, “till tonight.”	371.25418932530596
And he darted out of the room, shut the door, and waited in the	306.52282110825405
corridor, the soldier’s half-pike in his hand, and as if he had mounted	354.4537765334701
guard in his place.	352.51225188281285
The soldier returned, and Felton gave him back his weapon.	463.40452247440055
Then, through the grating to which she had drawn near, Milady saw the	378.3038264648162
young man make a sign with delirious fervor, and depart in an apparent	312.6002591082282
transport of joy.	487.94807086266326
As for her, she returned to her place with a smile of savage contempt	300.8049060824579
upon her lips, and repeated, blaspheming, that terrible name of God, by	313.8808880505811
whom she had just sworn without ever having learned to know Him.	422.4642309498829
“My God,” said she, “what a senseless fanatic! My God, it is I—I—and	406.1324767734652
this fellow who will help me to avenge myself.”	437.22178085973337
Chapter LVI.	394.2651227552426
CAPTIVITY: THE FIFTH DAY	436.3235392579696
Milady had however achieved a half-triumph, and success doubled her	417.08093147161793
forces.	348.6244677656176
It was not difficult to conquer, as she had hitherto done, men prompt	390.36471841406285
to let themselves be seduced, and whom the gallant education of a court	427.59824793757986
led quickly into her net. Milady was handsome enough not to find much	368.3684734842461
resistance on the part of the flesh, and she was sufficiently skillful	341.2271600687663
to prevail over all the obstacles of the mind.	431.768110641958
But this time she had to contend with an unpolished nature,	396.15715996515746
concentrated and insensible by force of austerity. Religion and its	317.02768808193036
observances had made Felton a man inaccessible to ordinary seductions.	368.4186386278757
There fermented in that sublimated brain plans so vast, projects so	366.3025004735357
tumultuous, that there remained no room for any capricious or material	392.6739876656436
love—that sentiment which is fed by leisure and grows with corruption.	346.73504115333355
Milady had, then, made a breach by her false virtue in the opinion of a	438.09610219339106
man horribly prejudiced against her, and by her beauty in the heart of	467.13824857392694
a man hitherto chaste and pure. In short, she had taken the measure of	454.754601400791
motives hitherto unknown to herself, through this experiment, made upon	434.5341493103989
the most rebellious subject that nature and religion could submit to	416.8093078264849
her study.	432.9242768706556
Many a time, nevertheless, during the evening she despaired of fate and	361.86171577661514
of herself. She did not invoke God, we very well know, but she had	475.3815650321169
faith in the genius of evil—that immense sovereignty which reigns in	461.0360582525423
all the details of human life, and by which, as in the Arabian fable, a	344.21809156880073
single pomegranate seed is sufficient to reconstruct a ruined world.	355.00450503240717
Milady, being well prepared for the reception of Felton, was able to	320.92727049460996
erect her batteries for the next day. She knew she had only two days	345.22722014795613
left; that when once the order was signed by Buckingham—and Buckingham	430.76435195593456
would sign it the more readily from its bearing a false name, and he	427.64783338674215
could not, therefore, recognize the woman in question—once this order	429.7110497528506
was signed, we say, the baron would make her embark immediately, and	472.9740113393342
she knew very well that women condemned to exile employ arms much less	348.75846719718805
powerful in their seductions than the pretendedly virtuous woman whose	422.2425097391483
beauty is lighted by the sun of the world, whose style the voice of	398.55494387112634
fashion lauds, and whom a halo of aristocracy gilds with enchanting	399.6291492246831
splendors. To be a woman condemned to a painful and disgraceful	454.33361233743585
punishment is no impediment to beauty, but it is an obstacle to the	453.6096286749329
recovery of power. Like all persons of real genius, Milady knew what	459.8035552380011
suited her nature and her means. Poverty was repugnant to her;	459.848838177848
degradation took away two-thirds of her greatness. Milady was only a	448.6374488465344
queen while among queens. The pleasure of satisfied pride was necessary	443.43442468247906
to her domination. To command inferior beings was rather a humiliation	485.83174118043416
than a pleasure for her.	462.51830383389694
She should certainly return from her exile—she did not doubt that a	354.4029932107025
single instant; but how long might this exile last? For an active,	473.7214130615679
ambitious nature, like that of Milady, days not spent in climbing are	397.0621405931058
inauspicious days. What word, then, can be found to describe the days	318.85129593006405
which they occupy in descending? To lose a year, two years, three	306.7120552394184
years, is to talk of an eternity; to return after the death or disgrace	341.3974281954784
of the cardinal, perhaps; to return when D’Artagnan and his friends,	343.3887922295976
happy and triumphant, should have received from the queen the reward	293.1483337429604
they had well acquired by the services they had rendered her—these were	405.8434992896131
devouring ideas that a woman like Milady could not endure. For the	353.49424621845503
rest, the storm which raged within her doubled her strength, and she	418.0755382060039
would have burst the walls of her prison if her body had been able to	293.28180456946063
take for a single instant the proportions of her mind.	440.1870036504861
Then that which spurred her on additionally in the midst of all this	417.25039951031795
was the remembrance of the cardinal. What must the mistrustful,	340.9527328479365
restless, suspicious cardinal think of her silence—the cardinal, not	412.7068395033077
merely her only support, her only prop, her only protector at present,	296.38876584480255
but still further, the principal instrument of her future fortune and	360.8447194882017
vengeance? She knew him; she knew that at her return from a fruitless	321.4256741572714
journey it would be in vain to tell him of her imprisonment, in vain to	330.5185272903817
enlarge upon the sufferings she had undergone. The cardinal would	398.9980762253609
reply, with the sarcastic calmness of the skeptic, strong at once by	396.5953418731722
power and genius, “You should not have allowed yourself to be taken.”	300.39613656491747
Then Milady collected all her energies, murmuring in the depths of her	448.5486513511521
soul the name of Felton—the only beam of light that penetrated to her	359.33785403715774
in the hell into which she had fallen; and like a serpent which folds	312.21923758945803
and unfolds its rings to ascertain its strength, she enveloped Felton	435.0172710474742
beforehand in the thousand meshes of her inventive imagination.	372.9259603838219
Time, however, passed away; the hours, one after another, seemed to	294.8794344003789
awaken the clock as they passed, and every blow of the brass hammer	405.89530056515287
resounded upon the heart of the prisoner. At nine o’clock, Lord de	453.50119776257645
Winter made his customary visit, examined the window and the bars,	477.1041303886475
sounded the floor and the walls, looked to the chimney and the doors,	472.3385058522621
without, during this long and minute examination, he or Milady	322.97872798441495
pronouncing a single word.	409.2949591309906
Doubtless both of them understood that the situation had become too	368.5172846728303
serious to lose time in useless words and aimless wrath.	346.89315920994727
“Well,” said the baron, on leaving her “you will not escape tonight!”	477.06383103178655
At ten o’clock Felton came and placed the sentinel. Milady recognized	305.8553994562425
his step. She was as well acquainted with it now as a mistress is with	413.0646466613345
that of the lover of her heart; and yet Milady at the same time	479.7836632892737
detested and despised this weak fanatic.	458.50612264181143
That was not the appointed hour. Felton did not enter.	312.8421450325893
Two hours after, as midnight sounded, the sentinel was relieved. This	418.1173797578166
time it _was_ the hour, and from this moment Milady waited with	479.90803990652034
impatience. The new sentinel commenced his walk in the corridor. At the	382.7649271341123
expiration of ten minutes Felton came.	481.6403888808321
Milady was all attention.	292.8653901707651
“Listen,” said the young man to the sentinel. “On no pretense leave the	320.5433115841869
door, for you know that last night my Lord punished a soldier for	374.6659086697535
having quit his post for an instant, although I, during his absence,	311.4143924871055
watched in his place.”	426.7389881288979
“Yes, I know it,” said the soldier.	441.297272714059
“I recommend you therefore to keep the strictest watch. For my part I	383.9095134944203
am going to pay a second visit to this woman, who I fear entertains	324.7441410948566
sinister intentions upon her own life, and I have received orders to	340.0150418788459
watch her.”	426.5877803014977
“Good!” murmured Milady; “the austere Puritan lies.”	300.48958908644295
As to the soldier, he only smiled.	332.9905715453178
“Zounds, Lieutenant!” said he; “you are not unlucky in being charged	468.2758919039751
with such commissions, particularly if my Lord has authorized you to	386.4829184907711
look into her bed.”	317.2654781474796
Felton blushed. Under any other circumstances he would have reprimanded	315.63127459763746
the soldier for indulging in such pleasantry, but his conscience	415.14543829324487
murmured too loud for his mouth to dare speak.	408.8481961336555
“If I call, come,” said he. “If anyone comes, call me.”	417.01906433971834
“I will, Lieutenant,” said the soldier.	483.5022742790884
Felton entered Milady’s apartment. Milady arose.	451.3817322370128
“You are here!” said she.	425.40912716872776
“I promised to come,” said Felton, “and I have come.”	403.3620236226285
“You promised me something else.”	343.5553011511576
“What, my God!” said the young man, who in spite of his self-command	465.0807176570238
felt his knees tremble and the sweat start from his brow.	478.42674125955796
“You promised to bring a knife, and to leave it with me after our	333.8153376242711
interview.”	319.60557172269563
“Say no more of that, madame,” said Felton. “There is no situation,	480.37727154855895
however terrible it may be, which can authorize a creature of God to	428.3546464737695
inflict death upon himself. I have reflected, and I cannot, must not be	348.45247774224356
guilty of such a sin.”	308.1674199428321
“Ah, you have reflected!” said the prisoner, sitting down in her	292.44446644123457
armchair, with a smile of disdain; “and I also have reflected.”	308.13446280949915
“Upon what?”	459.92263685952474
“That I can have nothing to say to a man who does not keep his word.”	310.04179985593504
“Oh, my God!” murmured Felton.	432.1552158146622
“You may retire,” said Milady. “I will not talk.”	452.9062926165062
“Here is the knife,” said Felton, drawing from his pocket the weapon	375.1074926742567
which he had brought, according to his promise, but which he hesitated	337.7267179295253
to give to his prisoner.	393.6048724883281
“Let me see it,” said Milady.	382.34422387615456
“For what purpose?”	360.17097147430286
“Upon my honor, I will instantly return it to you. You shall place it	378.9244307554565
on that table, and you may remain between it and me.”	460.23723568963874
Felton offered the weapon to Milady, who examined the temper of it	473.06594209509024
attentively, and who tried the point on the tip of her finger.	386.5778035494235
“Well,” said she, returning the knife to the young officer, “this is	476.04574476068666
fine and good steel. You are a faithful friend, Felton.”	321.6009311647483
Felton took back the weapon, and laid it upon the table, as he had	437.3197578164433
agreed with the prisoner.	422.73982492184575
Milady followed him with her eyes, and made a gesture of satisfaction.	316.7848239994643
“Now,” said she, “listen to me.”	474.81420877690266
The request was needless. The young officer stood upright before her,	460.3767283385029
awaiting her words as if to devour them.	410.50161733814673
“Felton,” said Milady, with a solemnity full of melancholy, “imagine	337.76782267965973
that your sister, the daughter of your father, speaks to you. While yet	410.78898251802264
young, unfortunately handsome, I was dragged into a snare. I resisted.	399.9325142171831
Ambushes and violences multiplied around me, but I resisted. The	420.6663992778717
religion I serve, the God I adore, were blasphemed because I called	435.210094429774
upon that religion and that God, but still I resisted. Then outrages	485.05122244561335
were heaped upon me, and as my soul was not subdued they wished to	383.86736530636085
defile my body forever. Finally—”	432.53876342374076
Milady stopped, and a bitter smile passed over her lips.	487.3429633255672
“Finally,” said Felton, “finally, what did they do?”	460.42392849921845
“At length, one evening my enemy resolved to paralyze the resistance he	442.4517948362075
could not conquer. One evening he mixed a powerful narcotic with my	297.9872399739684
water. Scarcely had I finished my repast, when I felt myself sink by	386.46169661659286
degrees into a strange torpor. Although I was without mistrust, a vague	363.31797629446544
fear seized me, and I tried to struggle against sleepiness. I arose. I	485.61027466830274
wished to run to the window and call for help, but my legs refused	363.90800801643735
their office. It appeared as if the ceiling sank upon my head and	405.3694675964184
crushed me with its weight. I stretched out my arms. I tried to speak.	340.4802736643812
I could only utter inarticulate sounds, and irresistible faintness came	412.62340161329814
over me. I supported myself by a chair, feeling that I was about to	384.051722638198
fall, but this support was soon insufficient on account of my weak	392.30414782372907
arms. I fell upon one knee, then upon both. I tried to pray, but my	451.23709603014015
tongue was frozen. God doubtless neither heard nor saw me, and I sank	460.78078193655665
upon the floor a prey to a slumber which resembled death.	419.22905018063557
“Of all that passed in that sleep, or the time which glided away while	452.4195622826461
it lasted, I have no remembrance. The only thing I recollect is that I	401.90935442714084
awoke in bed in a round chamber, the furniture of which was sumptuous,	466.2977185411768
and into which light only penetrated by an opening in the ceiling. No	413.3153674773174
door gave entrance to the room. It might be called a magnificent	353.1747824064769
prison.	422.88979932580975
“It was a long time before I was able to make out what place I was in,	323.5051595903406
or to take account of the details I describe. My mind appeared to	327.71628784040485
strive in vain to shake off the heavy darkness of the sleep from which	402.59310274300185
I could not rouse myself. I had vague perceptions of space traversed,	440.76221707126246
of the rolling of a carriage, of a horrible dream in which my strength	449.93496933587653
had become exhausted; but all this was so dark and so indistinct in my	351.9010294782748
mind that these events seemed to belong to another life than mine, and	471.218613199031
yet mixed with mine in fantastic duality.	337.8853927503443
“At times the state into which I had fallen appeared so strange that I	341.30980780181943
believed myself dreaming. I arose trembling. My clothes were near me on	491.0843827922948
a chair; I neither remembered having undressed myself nor going to bed.	447.03934679039475
Then by degrees the reality broke upon me, full of chaste terrors. I	348.7720042081938
was no longer in the house where I had dwelt. As well as I could judge	393.7686488894341
by the light of the sun, the day was already two-thirds gone. It was	380.8004127720331
the evening before when I had fallen asleep; my sleep, then, must have	313.7459263690569
lasted twenty-four hours! What had taken place during this long sleep?	336.57227871000345
“I dressed myself as quickly as possible; my slow and stiff motions all	477.7171314910004
attested that the effects of the narcotic were not yet entirely	488.55872165471123
dissipated. The chamber was evidently furnished for the reception of a	436.22736625819084
woman; and the most finished coquette could not have formed a wish, but	394.1701467650574
on casting her eyes about the apartment, she would have found that wish	369.2353777504611
accomplished.	467.00475352818273
“Certainly I was not the first captive that had been shut up in this	465.3955223514711
splendid prison; but you may easily comprehend, Felton, that the more	466.2384052106837
superb the prison, the greater was my terror.	326.74086372732387
“Yes, it was a prison, for I tried in vain to get out of it. I sounded	358.7757483392314
all the walls, in the hopes of discovering a door, but everywhere the	411.7253767188761
walls returned a full and flat sound.	370.9568329377625
“I made the tour of the room at least twenty times, in search of an	459.9042998448352
outlet of some kind; but there was none. I sank exhausted with fatigue	485.85035393401483
and terror into an armchair.	301.2633128340456
“Meantime, night came on rapidly, and with night my terrors increased.	311.4073719876696
I did not know but I had better remain where I was seated. It appeared	434.9828267709074
that I was surrounded with unknown dangers into which I was about to	442.6496417755634
fall at every instant. Although I had eaten nothing since the evening	382.83124373596377
before, my fears prevented my feeling hunger.	474.9014983981442
“No noise from without by which I could measure the time reached me; I	395.03396769558304
only supposed it must be seven or eight o’clock in the evening, for it	439.76250359369294
was in the month of October and it was quite dark.	446.9988929241573
“All at once the noise of a door, turning on its hinges, made me start.	415.8406392244185
A globe of fire appeared above the glazed opening of the ceiling,	432.99734763648667
casting a strong light into my chamber; and I perceived with terror	490.9437373811925
that a man was standing within a few paces of me.	389.1645475409539
“A table, with two covers, bearing a supper ready prepared, stood, as	345.3505035324493
if by magic, in the middle of the apartment.	415.80738261314093
“That man was he who had pursued me during a whole year, who had vowed	466.92060654237656
my dishonor, and who, by the first words that issued from his mouth,	462.1984598574072
gave me to understand he had accomplished it the preceding night.”	298.42715813521966
“Scoundrel!” murmured Felton.	410.37599409949627
“Oh, yes, scoundrel!” cried Milady, seeing the interest which the young	394.4920198284894
officer, whose soul seemed to hang on her lips, took in this strange	395.08111604495025
recital. “Oh, yes, scoundrel! He believed, having triumphed over me in	431.600161131097
my sleep, that all was completed. He came, hoping that I would accept	472.35363383482996
my shame, as my shame was consummated; he came to offer his fortune in	294.14905263920565
exchange for my love.	411.87129518269614
“All that the heart of a woman could contain of haughty contempt and	389.5333217444229
disdainful words, I poured out upon this man. Doubtless he was	340.1763397934602
accustomed to such reproaches, for he listened to me calm and smiling,	305.1454983790958
with his arms crossed over his breast. Then, when he thought I had said	298.9539734761709
all, he advanced toward me; I sprang toward the table, I seized a	391.1113800163998
knife, I placed it to my breast.	391.3264090874601
“Take one step more,” said I, “and in addition to my dishonor, you	437.7048869080921
shall have my death to reproach yourself with.”	367.7740966243268
“There was, no doubt, in my look, my voice, my whole person, that	319.9533549554674
sincerity of gesture, of attitude, of accent, which carries conviction	387.62526149564974
to the most perverse minds, for he paused.	306.86263641804976
“‘Your death?’ said he; ‘oh, no, you are too charming a mistress to	437.7910049381393
allow me to consent to lose you thus, after I have had the happiness to	457.40590431504086
possess you only a single time. Adieu, my charmer; I will wait to pay	479.5539831613577
you my next visit till you are in a better humor.’	309.8158129191728
“At these words he blew a whistle; the globe of fire which lighted the	343.34560489662465
room reascended and disappeared. I found myself again in complete	383.2339340348045
darkness. The same noise of a door opening and shutting was repeated	318.4400651789267
the instant afterward; the flaming globe descended afresh, and I was	385.2905274736964
completely alone.	361.4539674614645
“This moment was frightful; if I had any doubts as to my misfortune,	445.4003373165249
these doubts had vanished in an overwhelming reality. I was in the	377.35519121001204
power of a man whom I not only detested, but despised—of a man capable	387.14866225647137
of anything, and who had already given me a fatal proof of what he was	313.8342276093048
able to do.”	323.44401199412204
“But who, then, was this man?” asked Felton.	293.1518310866955
“I passed the night on a chair, starting at the least noise, for toward	297.13664101626244
midnight the lamp went out, and I was again in darkness. But the night	415.6442982480286
passed away without any fresh attempt on the part of my persecutor. Day	323.32151836452744
came; the table had disappeared, only I had still the knife in my hand.	402.22529558742383
“This knife was my only hope.	386.77864719464503
“I was worn out with fatigue. Sleeplessness inflamed my eyes; I had not	315.099172236296
dared to sleep a single instant. The light of day reassured me; I went	373.3885691310566
and threw myself on the bed, without parting with the emancipating	437.83827667040276
knife, which I concealed under my pillow.	459.4159405867995
“When I awoke, a fresh meal was served.	336.1257604256108
“This time, in spite of my terrors, in spite of my agony, I began to	480.8493062009703
feel a devouring hunger. It was forty-eight hours since I had taken any	421.69187852164754
nourishment. I ate some bread and some fruit; then, remembering the	434.5297282522282
narcotic mixed with the water I had drunk, I would not touch that which	347.18358505730953
was placed on the table, but filled my glass at a marble fountain fixed	344.0239944321108
in the wall over my dressing table.	468.16537664205487
“And yet, notwithstanding these precautions, I remained for some time	378.8348888465275
in a terrible agitation of mind. But my fears were this time	460.91217376852734
ill-founded; I passed the day without experiencing anything of the kind	350.77560976744314
I dreaded.	464.57238062506997
“I took the precaution to half empty the _carafe_, in order that my	399.40126847819914
suspicions might not be noticed.	473.8440335282286
“The evening came on, and with it darkness; but however profound was	412.2809083707149
this darkness, my eyes began to accustom themselves to it. I saw, amid	407.79893659404934
the shadows, the table sink through the floor; a quarter of an hour	351.26100069771644
later it reappeared, bearing my supper. In an instant, thanks to the	316.5713163049554
lamp, my chamber was once more lighted.	308.7259938912281
“I was determined to eat only such things as could not possibly have	395.5188387284065
anything soporific introduced into them. Two eggs and some fruit	365.6831129544264
composed my repast; then I drew another glass of water from my	423.3638238211036
protecting fountain, and drank it.	418.30102207862876
“At the first swallow, it appeared to me not to have the same taste as	487.94374597440054
in the morning. Suspicion instantly seized me. I paused, but I had	470.52119267078024
already drunk half a glass.	441.9180093325091
“I threw the rest away with horror, and waited, with the dew of fear	341.9139487907153
upon my brow.	394.0444530613703
“No doubt some invisible witness had seen me draw the water from that	431.8521512357894
fountain, and had taken advantage of my confidence in it, the better to	328.6444460482715
assure my ruin, so coolly resolved upon, so cruelly pursued.	362.10755166989514
“Half an hour had not passed when the same symptoms began to appear;	351.31261850904286
but as I had only drunk half a glass of the water, I contended longer,	401.36732537160776
and instead of falling entirely asleep, I sank into a state of	346.29223606438364
drowsiness which left me a perception of what was passing around me,	294.91169045531086
while depriving me of the strength either to defend myself or to fly.	308.68046400618437
“I dragged myself toward the bed, to seek the only defense I had	376.47774814811066
left—my saving knife; but I could not reach the bolster. I sank on my	378.1996477474696
knees, my hands clasped round one of the bedposts; then I felt that I	393.9944324681469
was lost.”	329.1646676416195
Felton became frightfully pale, and a convulsive tremor crept through	407.4135324236296
his whole body.	477.211126665275
“And what was most frightful,” continued Milady, her voice altered, as	471.53961088263463
if she still experienced the same agony as at that awful minute, “was	488.5458912590742
that at this time I retained a consciousness of the danger that	490.6270395388346
threatened me; was that my soul, if I may say so, waked in my sleeping	364.06241268467926
body; was that I saw, that I heard. It is true that all was like a	336.0907524400045
dream, but it was not the less frightful.	488.9640919242041
“I saw the lamp ascend, and leave me in darkness; then I heard the	362.1416938159824
well-known creaking of the door although I had heard that door open but	339.7058160748235
twice.	326.47075787637334
“I felt instinctively that someone approached me; it is said that the	412.2048129109196
doomed wretch in the deserts of America thus feels the approach of the	412.49614357619157
serpent.	482.1865819769848
“I wished to make an effort; I attempted to cry out. By an incredible	389.59418079281653
effort of will I even raised myself up, but only to sink down again	352.71144880714627
immediately, and to fall into the arms of my persecutor.”	358.83400491308583
“Tell me who this man was!” cried the young officer.	364.40391821747505
Milady saw at a single glance all the painful feelings she inspired in	442.7943348113986
Felton by dwelling on every detail of her recital; but she would not	425.23924779996867
spare him a single pang. The more profoundly she wounded his heart, the	389.63228917535037
more certainly he would avenge her. She continued, then, as if she had	391.5558983903271
not heard his exclamation, or as if she thought the moment was not yet	354.7927702468236
come to reply to it.	466.4569003166388
“Only this time it was no longer an inert body, without feeling, that	353.33865212918573
the villain had to deal with. I have told you that without being able	334.67412518650235
to regain the complete exercise of my faculties, I retained the sense	331.1592368610667
of my danger. I struggled, then, with all my strength, and doubtless	424.3435557056116
opposed, weak as I was, a long resistance, for I heard him cry out,	345.20832284759854
‘These miserable Puritans! I knew very well that they tired out their	313.180771535184
executioners, but I did not believe them so strong against their	329.9588362655722
lovers!’	480.9501598769692
“Alas! this desperate resistance could not last long. I felt my	455.0863586625281
strength fail, and this time it was not my sleep that enabled the	486.8592297925493
coward to prevail, but my swoon.”	488.7525616654747
Felton listened without uttering any word or sound, except an inward	353.2349158152091
expression of agony. The sweat streamed down his marble forehead, and	365.1174419496254
his hand, under his coat, tore his breast.	376.4718792012065
“My first impulse, on coming to myself, was to feel under my pillow for	467.631663441926
the knife I had not been able to reach; if it had not been useful for	313.20458492699186
defense, it might at least serve for expiation.	381.2127084488844
“But on taking this knife, Felton, a terrible idea occurred to me. I	313.6870094870512
have sworn to tell you all, and I will tell you all. I have promised	477.9036566295185
you the truth; I will tell it, were it to destroy me.”	305.8142094312227
“The idea came into your mind to avenge yourself on this man, did it	307.02833757311157
not?” cried Felton.	331.49946227062884
“Yes,” said Milady. “The idea was not that of a Christian, I knew; but	488.03973322099404
without doubt, that eternal enemy of our souls, that lion roaring	456.04888987556683
constantly around us, breathed it into my mind. In short, what shall I	380.55556732419234
say to you, Felton?” continued Milady, in the tone of a woman accusing	357.04113981500893
herself of a crime. “This idea occurred to me, and did not leave me; it	359.4083837183905
is of this homicidal thought that I now bear the punishment.”	433.6512156503841
“Continue, continue!” said Felton; “I am eager to see you attain your	490.02728081926995
vengeance!”	491.94982547379925
“Oh, I resolved that it should take place as soon as possible. I had no	298.21189653853514
doubt he would return the following night. During the day I had nothing	471.30092366874544
to fear.	475.9047963508077
“When the hour of breakfast came, therefore, I did not hesitate to eat	425.3201187096599
and drink. I had determined to make believe sup, but to eat nothing. I	374.9710222637566
was forced, then, to combat the fast of the evening with the	299.55875649130905
nourishment of the morning.	433.6862001806331
“Only I concealed a glass of water, which remained after my breakfast,	357.01705867549344
thirst having been the chief of my sufferings when I remained	407.1477819132176
forty-eight hours without eating or drinking.	448.9425455775676
“The day passed away without having any other influence on me than to	348.81615305537156
strengthen the resolution I had formed; only I took care that my face	392.9278460265664
should not betray the thoughts of my heart, for I had no doubt I was	423.73058438903035
watched. Several times, even, I felt a smile on my lips. Felton, I dare	464.38782452704254
not tell you at what idea I smiled; you would hold me in horror—”	369.72036088204334
“Go on! go on!” said Felton; “you see plainly that I listen, and that I	411.0275742137104
am anxious to know the end.”	338.5487005814747
“Evening came; the ordinary events took place. During the darkness, as	436.4537670649969
before, my supper was brought. Then the lamp was lighted, and I sat	324.2795067080546
down to table. I only ate some fruit. I pretended to pour out water	339.87493434068335
from the jug, but I only drank that which I had saved in my glass. The	487.47527410306895
substitution was made so carefully that my spies, if I had any, could	445.55271450181317
have no suspicion of it.	410.9958901395101
“After supper I exhibited the same marks of languor as on the preceding	402.6334952511566
evening; but this time, as I yielded to fatigue, or as if I had become	294.5618082516663
familiarized with danger, I dragged myself toward my bed, let my robe	375.1934207667173
fall, and lay down.	308.67710469717184
“I found my knife where I had placed it, under my pillow, and while	398.1926078098961
feigning to sleep, my hand grasped the handle of it convulsively.	464.3994033144206
“Two hours passed away without anything fresh happening. Oh, my God!	430.87825514265637
who could have said so the evening before? I began to fear that he	471.52992047267793
would not come.	482.4789183919527
“At length I saw the lamp rise softly, and disappear in the depths of	480.32001495106294
the ceiling; my chamber was filled with darkness and obscurity, but I	391.57509831514767
made a strong effort to penetrate this darkness and obscurity.	342.35551230176884
“Nearly ten minutes passed; I heard no other noise but the beating of	470.45627480075007
my own heart. I implored heaven that he might come.	342.66408843204636
“At length I heard the well-known noise of the door, which opened and	302.21460322462275
shut; I heard, notwithstanding the thickness of the carpet, a step	319.35483066897814
which made the floor creak; I saw, notwithstanding the darkness, a	332.4354647050577
shadow which approached my bed.”	486.524514380866
“Haste! haste!” said Felton; “do you not see that each of your words	332.79946712689207
burns me like molten lead?”	364.7752367923035
“Then,” continued Milady, “then I collected all my strength; I recalled	327.5924493568665
to my mind that the moment of vengeance, or rather, of justice, had	332.46167340193324
struck. I looked upon myself as another Judith; I gathered myself up,	371.054320726976
my knife in my hand, and when I saw him near me, stretching out his	397.61743971514574
arms to find his victim, then, with the last cry of agony and despair,	328.2901195870876
I struck him in the middle of his breast.	341.61306329227756
“The miserable villain! He had foreseen all. His breast was covered	316.65692764526324
with a coat-of-mail; the knife was bent against it.	390.67484263391134
“‘Ah, ah!’ cried he, seizing my arm, and wresting from me the weapon	392.7193813044221
that had so badly served me, ‘you want to take my life, do you, my	381.1242455032467
pretty Puritan? But that’s more than dislike, that’s ingratitude! Come,	478.06383033201973
come, calm yourself, my sweet girl! I thought you had softened. I am	485.507640612567
not one of those tyrants who detain women by force. You don’t love me.	311.7310427962279
With my usual fatuity I doubted it; now I am convinced. Tomorrow you	389.55855274453586
shall be free.’	296.1305521569149
“I had but one wish; that was that he should kill me.	442.7489388110969
“‘Beware!’ said I, ‘for my liberty is your dishonor.’	310.2040670053095
“‘Explain yourself, my pretty sibyl!’	319.5857555835872
“‘Yes; for as soon as I leave this place I will tell everything. I will	457.02688240884606
proclaim the violence you have used toward me. I will describe my	340.219759577985
captivity. I will denounce this place of infamy. You are placed on	390.8474444722811
high, my Lord, but tremble! Above you there is the king; above the king	472.3448074788221
there is God!’	344.62964694957464
“However perfect master he was over himself, my persecutor allowed a	415.27499384028044
movement of anger to escape him. I could not see the expression of his	322.0882036864803
countenance, but I felt the arm tremble upon which my hand was placed.	343.30889645981193
“‘Then you shall not leave this place,’ said he.	392.47774241811635
“‘Very well,’ cried I, ‘then the place of my punishment will be that of	309.4884346078623
my tomb. I will die here, and you will see if a phantom that accuses is	293.5917396543404
not more terrible than a living being that threatens!’	396.29159991648635
“‘You shall have no weapon left in your power.’	328.7756434008249
“‘There is a weapon which despair has placed within the reach of every	301.36000498247915
creature who has the courage to use it. I will allow myself to die with	316.4010030585326
hunger.’	473.7416348243048
“‘Come,’ said the wretch, ‘is not peace much better than such a war as	458.51955756872565
that? I will restore you to liberty this moment; I will proclaim you a	460.5621797684255
piece of immaculate virtue; I will name you the Lucretia of England.’	341.28151989646875
“‘And I will say that you are the Sextus. I will denounce you before	426.0206042368464
men, as I have denounced you before God; and if it be necessary that,	401.66899406118597
like Lucretia, I should sign my accusation with my blood, I will sign	305.0932886447064
it.’	338.89057577705347
“‘Ah!’ said my enemy, in a jeering tone, ‘that’s quite another thing.	396.7573449642296
My faith! everything considered, you are very well off here. You shall	476.39457514724563
want for nothing, and if you let yourself die of hunger that will be	321.8629495189566
your own fault.’	383.208992029284
“At these words he retired. I heard the door open and shut, and I	315.0438951707367
remained overwhelmed, less, I confess it, by my grief than by the	454.29809852583367
mortification of not having avenged myself.	298.7263053116228
“He kept his word. All the day, all the next night passed away without	394.9682853147346
my seeing him again. But I also kept my word with him, and I neither	393.010125099226
ate nor drank. I was, as I told him, resolved to die of hunger.	343.8680638702266
“I passed the day and the night in prayer, for I hoped that God would	342.5343039810895
pardon me my suicide.	333.4752694158323
“The second night the door opened; I was lying on the floor, for my	324.48139179564475
strength began to abandon me.	356.5714501211204
“At the noise I raised myself up on one hand.	404.7316486197608
“‘Well,’ said a voice which vibrated in too terrible a manner in my ear	331.57287095280094
not to be recognized, ‘well! Are we softened a little? Will we not pay	422.98874374574336
for our liberty with a single promise of silence? Come, I am a good	463.7640489936623
sort of a prince,’ added he, ‘and although I like not Puritans I do	414.3186701589657
them justice; and it is the same with Puritanesses, when they are	468.48201574211976
pretty. Come, take a little oath for me on the cross; I won’t ask	440.73649220991507
anything more of you.’	425.0427308679375
“‘On the cross,’ cried I, rising, for at that abhorred voice I had	382.50124956513434
recovered all my strength, ‘on the cross I swear that no promise, no	404.67643424786
menace, no force, no torture, shall close my mouth! On the cross I	329.940848741482
swear to denounce you everywhere as a murderer, as a thief of honor, as	341.58490436725197
a base coward! On the cross I swear, if I ever leave this place, to	384.38887275665985
call down vengeance upon you from the whole human race!’	427.597096892359
“‘Beware!’ said the voice, in a threatening accent that I had never yet	458.00471540325196
heard. ‘I have an extraordinary means which I will not employ but in	426.1310989091969
the last extremity to close your mouth, or at least to prevent anyone	312.4417973066491
from believing a word you may utter.’	314.81312082967133
“I mustered all my strength to reply to him with a burst of laughter.	435.052673730365
“He saw that it was a merciless war between us—a war to the death.	370.2670981145301
“‘Listen!’ said he. ‘I give you the rest of tonight and all day	381.57891032661666
tomorrow. Reflect: promise to be silent, and riches, consideration,	323.30210224928
even honor, shall surround you; threaten to speak, and I will condemn	451.63300844002936
you to infamy.’	298.38932935916176
“‘You?’ cried I. ‘You?’	420.0834484108998
“‘To interminable, ineffaceable infamy!’	433.3922630036127
“‘You?’ repeated I. Oh, I declare to you, Felton, I thought him mad!	463.9543232592125
“‘Yes, yes, I!’ replied he.	436.6031436954835
“‘Oh, leave me!’ said I. ‘Begone, if you do not desire to see me dash	351.95955824119693
my head against that wall before your eyes!’	363.43139595661677
“‘Very well, it is your own doing. Till tomorrow evening, then!’	478.81454499187305
“‘Till tomorrow evening, then!’ replied I, allowing myself to fall, and	460.3224060760536
biting the carpet with rage.”	373.2534159733362
Felton leaned for support upon a piece of furniture; and Milady saw,	477.9003001554279
with the joy of a demon, that his strength would fail him perhaps	348.6498665137531
before the end of her recital.	412.3807160159183
Chapter LVII.	350.1775944101671
MEANS FOR CLASSICAL TRAGEDY	444.8517401409137
After a moment of silence employed by Milady in observing the young man	306.020559490673
who listened to her, Milady continued her recital.	418.3835865621581
“It was nearly three days since I had eaten or drunk anything. I	396.63039566813535
suffered frightful torments. At times there passed before me clouds	464.03778279332096
which pressed my brow, which veiled my eyes; this was delirium.	379.24352856679013
“When the evening came I was so weak that every time I fainted I	397.8799993236749
thanked God, for I thought I was about to die.	454.2722549891554
“In the midst of one of these swoons I heard the door open. Terror	472.2937066335811
recalled me to myself.	371.57123251380233
“He entered the apartment followed by a man in a mask. He was masked	429.2105775377712
likewise; but I knew his step, I knew his voice, I knew him by that	314.7292414923155
imposing bearing which hell has bestowed upon his person for the curse	453.84014280712205
of humanity.	417.81594931473415
“‘Well,’ said he to me, ‘have you made your mind up to take the oath I	292.87031405026954
requested of you?’	459.73868694593534
“‘You have said Puritans have but one word. Mine you have heard, and	472.0854109188962
that is to pursue you—on earth to the tribunal of men, in heaven to the	295.17025198249434
tribunal of God.’	350.9398109555182
“‘You persist, then?’	361.61863138996887
“‘I swear it before the God who hears me. I will take the whole world	306.49125878754336
as a witness of your crime, and that until I have found an avenger.’	381.25507549912174
“‘You are a prostitute,’ said he, in a voice of thunder, ‘and you shall	482.16125749446803
undergo the punishment of prostitutes! Branded in the eyes of the world	352.6547253829072
you invoke, try to prove to that world that you are neither guilty nor	338.99821725389324
mad!’	319.1420685986258
“Then, addressing the man who accompanied him, ‘Executioner,’ said he,	318.1974560605284
‘do your duty.’”	443.1533062083535
“Oh, his name, his name!” cried Felton. “His name, tell it me!”	302.5024094244798
“Then in spite of my cries, in spite of my resistance—for I began to	314.77616451090546
comprehend that there was a question of something worse than death—the	378.74455732483614
executioner seized me, threw me on the floor, fastened me with his	372.0671840965742
bonds, and suffocated by sobs, almost without sense, invoking God, who	399.1286637141726
did not listen to me, I uttered all at once a frightful cry of pain and	296.05481513931096
shame. A burning fire, a red-hot iron, the iron of the executioner, was	437.7167485147836
imprinted on my shoulder.”	309.6132141705516
Felton uttered a groan.	349.77767359611926
“Here,” said Milady, rising with the majesty of a queen, “here, Felton,	488.1056541800463
behold the new martyrdom invented for a pure young girl, the victim of	349.075559668021
the brutality of a villain. Learn to know the heart of men, and	343.3238465983461
henceforth make yourself less easily the instrument of their unjust	358.8830665116093
vengeance.”	375.41284747859095
Milady, with a rapid gesture, opened her robe, tore the cambric that	305.41436163451385
covered her bosom, and red with feigned anger and simulated shame,	490.51252040542425
showed the young man the ineffaceable impression which dishonored that	476.4079455562772
beautiful shoulder.	371.78986094298
“But,” cried Felton, “that is a _fleur-de-lis_ which I see there.”	432.1592466564929
“And therein consisted the infamy,” replied Milady. “The brand of	378.9604149742948
England!—it would be necessary to prove what tribunal had imposed it on	439.33506752493565
me, and I could have made a public appeal to all the tribunals of the	442.0069325371224
kingdom; but the brand of France!—oh, by that, by _that_ I was branded	321.0819717043327
indeed!”	422.2143189599816
This was too much for Felton.	337.69908994629975
Pale, motionless, overwhelmed by this frightful revelation, dazzled by	310.7286847301936
the superhuman beauty of this woman who unveiled herself before him	328.1664452800857
with an immodesty which appeared to him sublime, he ended by falling on	331.9206105640028
his knees before her as the early Christians did before those pure and	407.4108450526137
holy martyrs whom the persecution of the emperors gave up in the circus	341.4459154799501
to the sanguinary sensuality of the populace. The brand disappeared;	441.5790224386327
the beauty alone remained.	453.78667227396954
“Pardon! Pardon!” cried Felton, “oh, pardon!”	377.272296552119
Milady read in his eyes _love! love!_	309.73796374757575
“Pardon for what?” asked she.	393.4576962410793
“Pardon me for having joined with your persecutors.”	340.57775653580404
Milady held out her hand to him.	391.49417220880844
“So beautiful! so young!” cried Felton, covering that hand with his	459.2227226889578
kisses.	490.29995038812547
Milady let one of those looks fall upon him which make a slave of a	365.9534275281805
king.	412.5472130145771
Felton was a Puritan; he abandoned the hand of this woman to kiss her	490.9013525710477
feet.	430.24641334183855
He no longer loved her; he adored her.	355.57466101562267
When this crisis was past, when Milady appeared to have resumed her	379.5619012085975
self-possession, which she had never lost; when Felton had seen her	427.8804696768606
recover with the veil of chastity those treasures of love which were	339.98479860491
only concealed from him to make him desire them the more ardently, he	454.92415267849026
said, “Ah, now! I have only one thing to ask of you; that is, the name	444.8769665067319
of your true executioner. For to me there is but one; the other was an	324.8651630738384
instrument, that was all.”	451.10772626697843
“What, brother!” cried Milady, “must I name him again? Have you not yet	427.6238248734801
divined who he is?”	422.8669816154142
“What?” cried Felton, “he—again he—always he? What—the truly guilty?”	368.7868655051653
“The truly guilty,” said Milady, “is the ravager of England, the	385.7179204684354
persecutor of true believers, the base ravisher of the honor of so many	469.38158820404226
women—he who, to satisfy a caprice of his corrupt heart, is about to	311.0113387659878
make England shed so much blood, who protects the Protestants today and	292.10368930988085
will betray them tomorrow—”	436.74548951404597
“Buckingham! It is, then, Buckingham!” cried Felton, in a high state of	353.5666825328672
excitement.	330.75229124311466
Milady concealed her face in her hands, as if she could not endure the	399.2930246965031
shame which this name recalled to her.	300.4780788560683
“Buckingham, the executioner of this angelic creature!” cried Felton.	377.9676618021081
“And thou hast not hurled thy thunder at him, my God! And thou hast	350.6000268643799
left him noble, honored, powerful, for the ruin of us all!”	405.63475044417277
“God abandons him who abandons himself,” said Milady.	372.6928739352186
“But he will draw upon his head the punishment reserved for the	488.4562223824818
damned!” said Felton, with increasing exultation. “He wills that human	308.86105856803624
vengeance should precede celestial justice.”	469.0897019060154
“Men fear him and spare him.”	360.17533083461996
“I,” said Felton, “I do not fear him, nor will I spare him.”	480.6143944839808
The soul of Milady was bathed in an infernal joy.	355.24008699103996
“But how can Lord de Winter, my protector, my father,” asked Felton,	389.941516072347
“possibly be mixed up with all this?”	303.2324289927274
“Listen, Felton,” resumed Milady, “for by the side of base and	334.3645629684904
contemptible men there are often found great and generous natures. I	380.74853219190464
had an affianced husband, a man whom I loved, and who loved me—a heart	412.10182941681046
like yours, Felton, a man like you. I went to him and told him all; he	406.1959875891303
knew me, that man did, and did not doubt an instant. He was a nobleman,	377.0522937697407
a man equal to Buckingham in every respect. He said nothing; he only	330.49326781560114
girded on his sword, wrapped himself in his cloak, and went straight to	421.4744099678992
Buckingham Palace.	369.83114869477055
“Yes, yes,” said Felton; “I understand how he would act. But with such	319.63299491932133
men it is not the sword that should be employed; it is the poniard.”	379.9604122918733
“Buckingham had left England the day before, sent as ambassador to	437.0272568127034
Spain, to demand the hand of the Infanta for King Charles I., who was	346.5234340690516
then only Prince of Wales. My affianced husband returned.	336.1229771576482
“‘Hear me,’ said he; ‘this man has gone, and for the moment has	378.757657808139
consequently escaped my vengeance; but let us be united, as we were to	359.50000628998777
have been, and then leave it to Lord de Winter to maintain his own	408.16681863568306
honor and that of his wife.’”	447.49724531657796
“Lord de Winter!” cried Felton.	351.11569623671875
“Yes,” said Milady, “Lord de Winter; and now you can understand it all,	418.0616655937156
can you not? Buckingham remained nearly a year absent. A week before	409.91262751447636
his return Lord de Winter died, leaving me his sole heir. Whence came	297.4148799949423
the blow? God who knows all, knows without doubt; but as for me, I	364.1260448818003
accuse nobody.”	443.2948440489931
“Oh, what an abyss; what an abyss!” cried Felton.	459.8113429638787
“Lord de Winter died without revealing anything to his brother. The	442.9924914835978
terrible secret was to be concealed till it burst, like a clap of	355.6972798135856
thunder, over the head of the guilty. Your protector had seen with pain	336.093588790471
this marriage of his elder brother with a portionless girl. I was	481.9108417222186
sensible that I could look for no support from a man disappointed in	397.3655277316176
his hopes of an inheritance. I went to France, with a determination to	444.8380850967863
remain there for the rest of my life. But all my fortune is in England.	429.597875018838
Communication being closed by the war, I was in want of everything. I	305.30361320792014
was then obliged to come back again. Six days ago, I landed at	328.02795935023516
Portsmouth.”	340.46076615603
“Well?” said Felton.	325.55338798493403
“Well; Buckingham heard by some means, no doubt, of my return. He spoke	341.1616058878322
of me to Lord de Winter, already prejudiced against me, and told him	383.8870547954319
that his sister-in-law was a prostitute, a branded woman. The noble and	402.0141916473276
pure voice of my husband was no longer here to defend me. Lord de	315.3462729549178
Winter believed all that was told him with so much the more ease that	351.1925716368665
it was his interest to believe it. He caused me to be arrested, had me	368.5653187706221
conducted hither, and placed me under your guard. You know the rest.	403.2028476792857
The day after tomorrow he banishes me, he transports me; the day after	389.6227992263613
tomorrow he exiles me among the infamous. Oh, the train is well laid;	333.8942748322514
the plot is clever. My honor will not survive it! You see, then,	444.4831396623779
Felton, I can do nothing but die. Felton, give me that knife!”	460.3860587943258
And at these words, as if all her strength was exhausted, Milady sank,	470.285423454275
weak and languishing, into the arms of the young officer, who,	324.8186748907363
intoxicated with love, anger, and voluptuous sensations hitherto	416.8151855637975
unknown, received her with transport, pressed her against his heart,	300.7452468391664
all trembling at the breath from that charming mouth, bewildered by the	454.430212345438
contact with that palpitating bosom.	305.29541732116013
“No, no,” said he. “No, you shall live honored and pure; you shall live	314.628701117104
to triumph over your enemies.”	424.84198265985333
Milady put him from her slowly with her hand, while drawing him nearer	491.5928289985749
with her look; but Felton, in his turn, embraced her more closely,	394.44423385193033
imploring her like a divinity.	369.2975600537807
“Oh, death, death!” said she, lowering her voice and her eyelids, “oh,	445.7648691149129
death, rather than shame! Felton, my brother, my friend, I conjure	347.65723398366316
you!”	394.58876058479126
“No,” cried Felton, “no; you shall live and you shall be avenged.”	480.98649963490294
“Felton, I bring misfortune to all who surround me! Felton, abandon me!	370.7791254228329
Felton, let me die!”	464.0338228387683
“Well, then, we will live and die together!” cried he, pressing his	392.9818111678228
lips to those of the prisoner.	415.6144323828913
Several strokes resounded on the door; this time Milady really pushed	417.5512944895785
him away from her.	292.39414673190595
“Hark,” said she, “we have been overheard! Someone is coming! All is	469.38566186813193
over! We are lost!”	346.68137502078537
