“No,” said Felton; it is only the sentinel warning me that they are	396.7578141128178
about to change the guard.”	371.39119966959476
“Then run to the door, and open it yourself.”	401.3155949023014
Felton obeyed; this woman was now his whole thought, his whole soul.	455.2487132837542
He found himself face to face with a sergeant commanding a	316.1843601319244
watch-patrol.	397.1639377151126
“Well, what is the matter?” asked the young lieutenant.	407.63232946048896
“You told me to open the door if I heard anyone cry out,” said the	320.0053107497896
soldier; “but you forgot to leave me the key. I heard you cry out,	361.6793658605127
without understanding what you said. I tried to open the door, but it	476.3699204764443
was locked inside; then I called the sergeant.”	395.53762525723664
“And here I am,” said the sergeant.	380.9552670451185
Felton, quite bewildered, almost mad, stood speechless.	427.53901810239097
Milady plainly perceived that it was now her turn to take part in the	375.9327584222011
scene. She ran to the table, and seizing the knife which Felton had	302.07389206535186
laid down, exclaimed, “And by what right will you prevent me from	305.68775679543023
dying?”	479.99483685915175
“Great God!” exclaimed Felton, on seeing the knife glitter in her hand.	478.4768495697938
At that moment a burst of ironical laughter resounded through the	461.01166364727897
corridor. The baron, attracted by the noise, in his chamber gown, his	387.51156264821634
sword under his arm, stood in the doorway.	332.1281723282972
“Ah,” said he, “here we are, at the last act of the tragedy. You see,	401.72717490392114
Felton, the drama has gone through all the phases I named; but be easy,	328.5004758082829
no blood will flow.”	454.9096244317865
Milady perceived that all was lost unless she gave Felton an immediate	322.65999760576295
and terrible proof of her courage.	482.59980539811306
“You are mistaken, my Lord, blood will flow; and may that blood fall	442.1833976018267
back on those who cause it to flow!”	476.3731909951805
Felton uttered a cry, and rushed toward her. He was too late; Milady	308.02508407248655
had stabbed herself.	384.82017711592397
But the knife had fortunately, we ought to say skillfully, come in	482.8380053296688
contact with the steel busk, which at that period, like a cuirass,	488.27322642183026
defended the chests of women. It had glided down it, tearing the robe,	403.78529414545983
and had penetrated slantingly between the flesh and the ribs. Milady’s	404.157637288551
robe was not the less stained with blood in a second.	338.048075073466
Milady fell down, and seemed to be in a swoon.	318.3158646610672
Felton snatched away the knife.	412.70103776878204
“See, my Lord,” said he, in a deep, gloomy tone, “here is a woman who	448.19098990337
was under my guard, and who has killed herself!”	442.06450171133247
“Be at ease, Felton,” said Lord de Winter. “She is not dead; demons do	459.1262092192778
not die so easily. Be tranquil, and go wait for me in my chamber.”	350.15481769253375
“But, my Lord—”	417.3408858694219
“Go, sir, I command you!”	300.8948304990733
At this injunction from his superior, Felton obeyed; but in going out,	293.9141695371596
he put the knife into his bosom.	432.6842118173514
As to Lord de Winter, he contented himself with calling the woman who	301.77404961335355
waited on Milady, and when she was come, he recommended the prisoner,	451.6962885250254
who was still fainting, to her care, and left them alone.	458.84343504371645
Meanwhile, all things considered and notwithstanding his suspicions, as	422.9753444255999
the wound might be serious, he immediately sent off a mounted man to	402.34161033551186
find a physician.	301.27247999115747
Chapter LVIII.	453.2067728249574
ESCAPE	440.79901765892623
As Lord de Winter had thought, Milady’s wound was not dangerous. So	310.3266235286927
soon as she was left alone with the woman whom the baron had summoned	431.03108421501975
to her assistance she opened her eyes.	419.7965300795083
It was, however, necessary to affect weakness and pain—not a very	432.0737016372052
difficult task for so finished an actress as Milady. Thus the poor	326.76588528560296
woman was completely the dupe of the prisoner, whom, notwithstanding	491.3689100369959
her hints, she persisted in watching all night.	366.8218415318955
But the presence of this woman did not prevent Milady from thinking.	441.2142755328133
There was no longer a doubt that Felton was convinced; Felton was hers.	412.5300754618813
If an angel appeared to that young man as an accuser of Milady, he	437.5357559876114
would take him, in the mental disposition in which he now found	426.8319996906898
himself, for a messenger sent by the devil.	489.7877204526698
Milady smiled at this thought, for Felton was now her only hope—her	435.6394241777533
only means of safety.	316.7351975334285
But Lord de Winter might suspect him; Felton himself might now be	355.59836771908044
watched!	430.2990429439399
Toward four o’clock in the morning the doctor arrived; but since the	461.6156381456065
time Milady stabbed herself, however short, the wound had closed. The	293.53319953135616
doctor could therefore measure neither the direction nor the depth of	411.3284078145845
it; he only satisfied himself by Milady’s pulse that the case was not	345.92610572865516
serious.	354.3251187670778
In the morning Milady, under the pretext that she had not slept well in	422.54136763573877
the night and wanted rest, sent away the woman who attended her.	296.8615304295419
She had one hope, which was that Felton would appear at the breakfast	463.55902329644516
hour; but Felton did not come.	406.5178970600797
Were her fears realized? Was Felton, suspected by the baron, about to	443.9469840347868
fail her at the decisive moment? She had only one day left. Lord de	320.3077038134499
Winter had announced her embarkation for the twenty-third, and it was	327.1832578410822
now the morning of the twenty-second.	489.05947698633935
Nevertheless she still waited patiently till the hour for dinner.	367.0629778552259
Although she had eaten nothing in the morning, the dinner was brought	417.214114945
in at its usual time. Milady then perceived, with terror, that the	452.33305067584405
uniform of the soldiers who guarded her was changed.	364.27871326719145
Then she ventured to ask what had become of Felton.	324.8888012805488
She was told that he had left the castle an hour before on horseback.	367.65521091448875
She inquired if the baron was still at the castle. The soldier replied	361.6558210561536
that he was, and that he had given orders to be informed if the	339.059278426357
prisoner wished to speak to him.	328.10838894519884
Milady replied that she was too weak at present, and that her only	488.0403099535548
desire was to be left alone.	407.18556836892276
The soldier went out, leaving the dinner served.	318.30460910435727
Felton was sent away. The marines were removed. Felton was then	376.16539708345084
mistrusted.	400.356754341178
This was the last blow to the prisoner.	312.75679038466296
Left alone, she arose. The bed, which she had kept from prudence and	345.8652262398803
that they might believe her seriously wounded, burned her like a bed of	340.67569162915845
fire. She cast a glance at the door; the baron had had a plank nailed	444.39500409469497
over the grating. He no doubt feared that by this opening she might	455.8361190528671
still by some diabolical means corrupt her guards.	436.8862390039648
Milady smiled with joy. She was free now to give way to her transports	410.313538368581
without being observed. She traversed her chamber with the excitement	489.0826128724085
of a furious maniac or of a tigress shut up in an iron cage. _Certes_,	382.25366799242863
if the knife had been left in her power, she would now have thought,	332.40085579499
not of killing herself, but of killing the baron.	332.67627249629413
At six o’clock Lord de Winter came in. He was armed at all points. This	349.2499526991444
man, in whom Milady till that time had only seen a very simple	333.0434371183991
gentleman, had become an admirable jailer. He appeared to foresee all,	395.7168249684876
to divine all, to anticipate all.	445.061578731969
A single look at Milady apprised him of all that was passing in her	417.9924806997036
mind.	428.5700332722216
“Ay!” said he, “I see; but you shall not kill me today. You have no	301.5479719583144
longer a weapon; and besides, I am on my guard. You had begun to	327.0488313734019
pervert my poor Felton. He was yielding to your infernal influence; but	437.37119529577
I will save him. He will never see you again; all is over. Get your	378.75892497539803
clothes together. Tomorrow you will go. I had fixed the embarkation for	359.420569983909
the twenty-fourth; but I have reflected that the more promptly the	370.68204345802724
affair takes place the more sure it will be. Tomorrow, by twelve	432.04006946349267
o’clock, I shall have the order for your exile, signed, _Buckingham_.	368.251178927797
If you speak a single word to anyone before going aboard ship, my	430.68565140506416
sergeant will blow your brains out. He has orders to do so. If when on	436.6153644661193
the ship you speak a single word to anyone before the captain permits	338.78566198410016
you, the captain will have you thrown into the sea. That is agreed	399.1122430313535
upon.	386.5728464380417
“_Au revoir_, then; that is all I have to say today. Tomorrow I will	475.02946637352323
see you again, to take my leave.” With these words the baron went out.	386.570326276742
Milady had listened to all this menacing tirade with a smile of disdain	364.86656356827046
on her lips, but rage in her heart.	466.6434486917192
Supper was served. Milady felt that she stood in need of all her	433.73360333440434
strength. She did not know what might take place during this night	338.9418962273865
which approached so menacingly—for large masses of cloud rolled over	468.3521587855
the face of the sky, and distant lightning announced a storm.	466.571456719461
The storm broke about ten o’clock. Milady felt a consolation in seeing	413.5861229871501
nature partake of the disorder of her heart. The thunder growled in the	321.90964217246244
air like the passion and anger in her thoughts. It appeared to her that	299.35346288857176
the blast as it swept along disheveled her brow, as it bowed the	436.84656293551757
branches of the trees and bore away their leaves. She howled as the	373.0585380726802
hurricane howled; and her voice was lost in the great voice of nature,	303.3378700225086
which also seemed to groan with despair.	421.96419715307303
All at once she heard a tap at her window, and by the help of a flash	486.61468191031764
of lightning she saw the face of a man appear behind the bars.	397.6707611556693
She ran to the window and opened it.	422.1284115326232
“Felton!” cried she. “I am saved.”	389.55071198330575
“Yes,” said Felton; “but silence, silence! I must have time to file	433.21333746470714
through these bars. Only take care that I am not seen through the	451.33466980317644
wicket.”	311.5560922589709
“Oh, it is a proof that the Lord is on our side, Felton,” replied	312.0146264169358
Milady. “They have closed up the grating with a board.”	354.43140155456507
“That is well; God has made them senseless,” said Felton.	485.25367156782625
“But what must I do?” asked Milady.	381.67913187270506
“Nothing, nothing, only shut the window. Go to bed, or at least lie	394.0555422572985
down in your clothes. As soon as I have done I will knock on one of the	460.52042139893877
panes of glass. But will you be able to follow me?”	305.63342353894416
“Oh, yes!”	392.5431018449991
“Your wound?”	363.67477242782684
“Gives me pain, but will not prevent my walking.”	464.64859519745403
“Be ready, then, at the first signal.”	442.46379662482275
Milady shut the window, extinguished the lamp, and went, as Felton had	452.6739024438557
desired her, to lie down on the bed. Amid the moaning of the storm she	407.6237308747688
heard the grinding of the file upon the bars, and by the light of every	328.09234330002084
flash she perceived the shadow of Felton through the panes.	461.47164751173193
She passed an hour without breathing, panting, with a cold sweat upon	303.41929972254405
her brow, and her heart oppressed by frightful agony at every movement	310.9689947377594
she heard in the corridor.	403.19684056503
There are hours which last a year.	465.4575905558926
At the expiration of an hour, Felton tapped again.	327.13012725729317
Milady sprang out of bed and opened the window. Two bars removed formed	354.2631553083216
an opening for a man to pass through.	306.95866548939813
“Are you ready?” asked Felton.	315.24311565949904
“Yes. Must I take anything with me?”	306.4270694754251
“Money, if you have any.”	321.3181137211913
“Yes; fortunately they have left me all I had.”	454.38505954501
“So much the better, for I have expended all mine in chartering a	390.6519323117563
vessel.”	376.159059587871
“Here!” said Milady, placing a bag full of louis in Felton’s hands.	451.3080009361202
Felton took the bag and threw it to the foot of the wall.	447.31871535166647
“Now,” said he, “will you come?”	339.1458368026115
“I am ready.”	421.79380800528077
Milady mounted upon a chair and passed the upper part of her body	353.67951529319885
through the window. She saw the young officer suspended over the abyss	387.89336485755234
by a ladder of ropes. For the first time an emotion of terror reminded	319.7449145753244
her that she was a woman.	490.6979182978263
The dark space frightened her.	475.51664161481904
“I expected this,” said Felton.	465.20835816139225
“It’s nothing, it’s nothing!” said Milady. “I will descend with my eyes	474.8452447896019
shut.”	473.05828216788007
“Have you confidence in me?” said Felton.	455.9362665957042
“You ask that?”	391.12729332197375
“Put your two hands together. Cross them; that’s right!”	412.37807988072257
Felton tied her two wrists together with his handkerchief, and then	481.8034552007671
with a cord over the handkerchief.	410.31287182184263
“What are you doing?” asked Milady, with surprise.	298.3965578333558
“Pass your arms around my neck, and fear nothing.”	382.62640072480804
“But I shall make you lose your balance, and we shall both be dashed to	364.59441462856125
pieces.”	443.31004834020814
“Don’t be afraid. I am a sailor.”	482.7335796180357
Not a second was to be lost. Milady passed her two arms round Felton’s	432.8333028642649
neck, and let herself slip out of the window. Felton began to descend	435.7244178915634
the ladder slowly, step by step. Despite the weight of two bodies, the	396.0518761146097
blast of the hurricane shook them in the air.	366.28525976392405
All at once Felton stopped.	490.7040925364847
“What is the matter?” asked Milady.	319.09946382027357
“Silence,” said Felton, “I hear footsteps.”	474.90167342991214
“We are discovered!”	312.11089652727344
There was a silence of several seconds.	367.81408038824634
“No,” said Felton, “it is nothing.”	296.60290932100185
“But what, then, is the noise?”	377.88276923551336
“That of the patrol going their rounds.”	324.15312035996004
“Where is their road?”	443.1553219028455
“Just under us.”	381.62230237796456
“They will discover us!”	405.62958108517057
“No, if it does not lighten.”	416.18974945957746
“But they will run against the bottom of the ladder.”	445.47791141807653
“Fortunately it is too short by six feet.”	460.32144038184816
“Here they are! My God!”	418.37232935815433
“Silence!”	296.4724573380308
Both remained suspended, motionless and breathless, within twenty paces	450.12076081601487
of the ground, while the patrol passed beneath them laughing and	326.10204954808955
talking. This was a terrible moment for the fugitives.	361.5369789325945
The patrol passed. The noise of their retreating footsteps and the	414.80171008726654
murmur of their voices soon died away.	361.3130467533187
“Now,” said Felton, “we are safe.”	403.31878909411137
Milady breathed a deep sigh and fainted.	328.94210645771784
Felton continued to descend. Near the bottom of the ladder, when he	396.75134648160923
found no more support for his feet, he clung with his hands; at length,	463.0556435798423
arrived at the last step, he let himself hang by the strength of his	422.2688414779932
wrists, and touched the ground. He stooped down, picked up the bag of	411.06302336354673
money, and placed it between his teeth. Then he took Milady in his	320.5388083046392
arms, and set off briskly in the direction opposite to that which the	306.781875617403
patrol had taken. He soon left the pathway of the patrol, descended	403.8774539917981
across the rocks, and when arrived on the edge of the sea, whistled.	473.8540796898078
A similar signal replied to him; and five minutes after, a boat	348.8319745588675
appeared, rowed by four men.	437.7081395150941
The boat approached as near as it could to the shore; but there was not	392.27950235267895
depth enough of water for it to touch land. Felton walked into the sea	395.36448754878637
up to his middle, being unwilling to trust his precious burden to	424.8890087745848
anybody.	432.8935809488678
Fortunately the storm began to subside, but still the sea was	415.41875033387873
disturbed. The little boat bounded over the waves like a nut-shell.	372.6251308314512
“To the sloop,” said Felton, “and row quickly.”	427.9594136530666
The four men bent to their oars, but the sea was too high to let them	327.03991487177785
get much hold of it.	416.0536679390742
However, they left the castle behind; that was the principal thing. The	377.9386132702155
night was extremely dark. It was almost impossible to see the shore	450.8130269061233
from the boat; they would therefore be less likely to see the boat from	338.9666467026291
the shore.	394.2622159394748
A black point floated on the sea. That was the sloop. While the boat	425.3347023084932
was advancing with all the speed its four rowers could give it, Felton	475.37925958091813
untied the cord and then the handkerchief which bound Milady’s hands	423.7528273836066
together. When her hands were loosed he took some sea water and	430.29849688913237
sprinkled it over her face.	391.26134509720407
Milady breathed a sigh, and opened her eyes.	439.085446225458
“Where am I?” said she.	467.4240502240498
“Saved!” replied the young officer.	376.7558349731047
“Oh, saved, saved!” cried she. “Yes, there is the sky; here is the sea!	481.374960075157
The air I breathe is the air of liberty! Ah, thanks, Felton, thanks!”	456.07757398546187
The young man pressed her to his heart.	299.82560783970376
“But what is the matter with my hands!” asked Milady; “it seems as if	345.6775353691215
my wrists had been crushed in a vice.”	331.2504642015656
Milady held out her arms; her wrists were bruised.	346.366667160749
“Alas!” said Felton, looking at those beautiful hands, and shaking his	486.88507567380907
head sorrowfully.	357.61444161606136
“Oh, it’s nothing, nothing!” cried Milady. “I remember now.”	360.76897240336507
Milady looked around her, as if in search of something.	416.4061448964958
“It is there,” said Felton, touching the bag of money with his foot.	299.65932039403964
They drew near to the sloop. A sailor on watch hailed the boat; the	363.46121972289535
boat replied.	457.3972152965848
“What vessel is that?” asked Milady.	491.2868991097439
“The one I have hired for you.”	350.6170854220367
“Where will it take me?”	378.8936634486921
“Where you please, after you have put me on shore at Portsmouth.”	314.16605457582347
“What are you going to do at Portsmouth?” asked Milady.	351.9716510362779
“Accomplish the orders of Lord de Winter,” said Felton, with a gloomy	448.69058404114014
smile.	433.6962601247102
“What orders?” asked Milady.	441.33125977667055
“You do not understand?” asked Felton.	342.7861811872507
“No; explain yourself, I beg.”	374.7127393371125
“As he mistrusted me, he determined to guard you himself, and sent me	292.2297651977193
in his place to get Buckingham to sign the order for your	396.17301907312617
transportation.”	399.1977839374449
“But if he mistrusted you, how could he confide such an order to you?”	323.3995094678652
“How could I know what I was the bearer of?”	422.8260262625858
“That’s true! And you are going to Portsmouth?”	360.3225528962394
“I have no time to lose. Tomorrow is the twenty-third, and Buckingham	476.638688375375
sets sail tomorrow with his fleet.”	455.91799922702194
“He sets sail tomorrow! Where for?”	331.15093183365275
“For La Rochelle.”	445.75187710072333
“He need not sail!” cried Milady, forgetting her usual presence of	489.1302808013136
mind.	452.8306532560589
“Be satisfied,” replied Felton; “he will not sail.”	315.24845696717944
Milady started with joy. She could read to the depths of the heart of	358.71735099240055
this young man; the death of Buckingham was written there at full	422.1218987040881
length.	485.5792095566087
“Felton,” cried she, “you are as great as Judas Maccabeus! If you die,	458.4667330449475
I will die with you; that is all I can say to you.”	403.4313436664965
“Silence!” cried Felton; “we are here.”	351.86671928384055
In fact, they touched the sloop.	330.7798325321855
Felton mounted the ladder first, and gave his hand to Milady, while the	354.94151245395454
sailors supported her, for the sea was still much agitated.	422.0948306206046
An instant after they were on the deck.	408.0828763728993
“Captain,” said Felton, “this is the person of whom I spoke to you, and	429.2922212346044
whom you must convey safe and sound to France.”	431.85131352071966
“For a thousand pistoles,” said the captain.	296.71175002860514
“I have paid you five hundred of them.”	391.84551256333884
“That’s correct,” said the captain.	304.6490610092006
“And here are the other five hundred,” replied Milady, placing her hand	324.3862233899598
upon the bag of gold.	388.813458596547
“No,” said the captain, “I make but one bargain; and I have agreed with	320.7964941136113
this young man that the other five hundred shall not be due to me till	376.49602206903506
we arrive at Boulogne.”	402.3372637150297
“And shall we arrive there?”	349.74470886027774
“Safe and sound, as true as my name’s Jack Butler.”	298.4699186606979
“Well,” said Milady, “if you keep your word, instead of five hundred, I	378.71214293885237
will give you a thousand pistoles.”	465.217136774817
“Hurrah for you, then, my beautiful lady,” cried the captain; “and may	452.63980100195045
God often send me such passengers as your Ladyship!”	329.14443711608624
“Meanwhile,” said Felton, “convey me to the little bay of—; you know it	479.89762539897697
was agreed you should put in there.”	416.8673619718666
The captain replied by ordering the necessary maneuvers, and toward	297.6422414115386
seven o’clock in the morning the little vessel cast anchor in the bay	351.54880898356146
that had been named.	481.0394917925587
During this passage, Felton related everything to Milady—how, instead	358.1603109947553
of going to London, he had chartered the little vessel; how he had	433.85048051085465
returned; how he had scaled the wall by fastening cramps in the	456.3182452292963
interstices of the stones, as he ascended, to give him foothold; and	377.3906841554316
how, when he had reached the bars, he fastened his ladder. Milady knew	346.98043710744804
the rest.	440.44752485223876
On her side, Milady tried to encourage Felton in his project; but at	334.9200249077459
the first words which issued from her mouth, she plainly saw that the	386.2899538247732
young fanatic stood more in need of being moderated than urged.	294.8751731756086
It was agreed that Milady should wait for Felton till ten o’clock; if	471.68794683398403
he did not return by ten o’clock she was to sail.	434.21678842327907
In that case, and supposing he was at liberty, he was to rejoin her in	294.2854159897217
France, at the convent of the Carmelites at Béthune.	413.09868583579026
Chapter LIX.	433.01481314569645
WHAT TOOK PLACE AT PORTSMOUTH	446.69267655077533
AUGUST 23, 1628	475.2828492902225
Felton took leave of Milady as a brother about to go for a mere walk	303.4689735531152
takes leave of his sister, kissing her hand.	448.43950783143015
His whole body appeared in its ordinary state of calmness, only an	372.27257963197405
unusual fire beamed from his eyes, like the effects of a fever; his	414.60742662289687
brow was more pale than it generally was; his teeth were clenched, and	431.7288482004593
his speech had a short dry accent which indicated that something dark	304.7202660282012
was at work within him.	317.49889364253545
As long as he remained in the boat which conveyed him to land, he kept	434.23963961006143
his face toward Milady, who, standing on the deck, followed him with	457.3482370933915
her eyes. Both were free from the fear of pursuit; nobody ever came	443.4485064242763
into Milady’s apartment before nine o’clock, and it would require three	326.5904752170323
hours to go from the castle to London.	301.7104624304278
Felton jumped onshore, climbed the little ascent which led to the top	476.5931811981076
of the cliff, saluted Milady a last time, and took his course toward	442.44292683015783
the city.	474.81942097691325
At the end of a hundred paces, the ground began to decline, and he	429.80077829054983
could only see the mast of the sloop.	323.18824159087757
He immediately ran in the direction of Portsmouth, which he saw at	486.1011439739167
nearly half a league before him, standing out in the haze of the	440.63680761386195
morning, with its houses and towers.	312.4811497094056
Beyond Portsmouth the sea was covered with vessels whose masts, like a	451.14605913398
forest of poplars despoiled by the winter, bent with each breath of the	301.7127600777372
wind.	350.6518604338484
Felton, in his rapid walk, reviewed in his mind all the accusations	470.7209474510084
against the favorite of James I. and Charles I., furnished by two years	336.79591990028337
of premature meditation and a long sojourn among the Puritans.	434.10292710903036
When he compared the public crimes of this minister—startling crimes,	409.28694898483275
European crimes, if so we may say—with the private and unknown crimes	360.37955961865373
with which Milady had charged him, Felton found that the more culpable	426.0272659809856
of the two men which formed the character of Buckingham was the one of	476.7016943429513
whom the public knew not the life. This was because his love, so	329.9503544553586
strange, so new, and so ardent, made him view the infamous and	455.97796541290177
imaginary accusations of Milady de Winter as, through a magnifying	454.1859601280084
glass, one views as frightful monsters atoms in reality imperceptible	389.6565723818352
by the side of an ant.	351.3549317397708
The rapidity of his walk heated his blood still more; the idea that he	329.96979530509384
left behind him, exposed to a frightful vengeance, the woman he loved,	382.76757997299654
or rather whom he adored as a saint, the emotion he had experienced,	430.31328490636804
present fatigue—all together exalted his mind above human feeling.	426.6912082578249
He entered Portsmouth about eight o’clock in the morning. The whole	412.2555176357418
population was on foot; drums were beating in the streets and in the	344.9006064884243
port; the troops about to embark were marching toward the sea.	387.6694322069029
Felton arrived at the palace of the Admiralty, covered with dust, and	418.42042091909957
streaming with perspiration. His countenance, usually so pale, was	418.7425877026034
purple with heat and passion. The sentinel wanted to repulse him; but	407.7976757111277
Felton called to the officer of the post, and drawing from his pocket	424.28719470896755
the letter of which he was the bearer, he said, “A pressing message	340.64633440089005
from Lord de Winter.”	376.6071475203767
At the name of Lord de Winter, who was known to be one of his Grace’s	386.92453736329117
most intimate friends, the officer of the post gave orders to let	392.6243400213004
Felton pass, who, besides, wore the uniform of a naval officer.	375.08535988726294
Felton darted into the palace.	392.49603442982425
At the moment he entered the vestibule, another man was entering	300.3012379184582
likewise, dusty, out of breath, leaving at the gate a post horse,	403.45599683287986
which, on reaching the palace, tumbled on his foreknees.	481.44550471798823
Felton and he addressed Patrick, the duke’s confidential lackey, at the	318.98571480316144
same moment. Felton named Lord de Winter; the unknown would not name	473.58872226660947
anybody, and pretended that it was to the duke alone he would make	292.5829535618436
himself known. Each was anxious to gain admission before the other.	311.4351870153384
Patrick, who knew Lord de Winter was in affairs of the service, and in	364.0853159165151
relations of friendship with the duke, gave the preference to the one	451.7759122062467
who came in his name. The other was forced to wait, and it was easily	482.9521298688394
to be seen how he cursed the delay.	474.8780790443204
The valet led Felton through a large hall in which waited the deputies	391.63592111630703
from La Rochelle, headed by the Prince de Soubise, and introduced him	343.5752415780431
into a closet where Buckingham, just out of the bath, was finishing his	337.96914379583995
toilet, upon which, as at all times, he bestowed extraordinary	391.7783067919222
attention.	369.38565320710575
“Lieutenant Felton, from Lord de Winter,” said Patrick.	374.773151742858
“From Lord de Winter!” repeated Buckingham; “let him come in.”	423.71159523558333
Felton entered. At that moment Buckingham was throwing upon a couch a	315.61503344915616
rich toilet robe, worked with gold, in order to put on a blue velvet	427.30901914059314
doublet embroidered with pearls.	340.3922288748122
“Why didn’t the baron come himself?” demanded Buckingham. “I expected	419.21282072790643
him this morning.”	458.49806602376134
“He desired me to tell your Grace,” replied Felton, “that he very much	388.04563426759864
regretted not having that honor, but that he was prevented by the guard	426.14503644932574
he is obliged to keep at the castle.”	295.4220167966272
“Yes, I know that,” said Buckingham; “he has a prisoner.”	418.60778173875724
“It is of that prisoner that I wish to speak to your Grace,” replied	382.9102141333841
Felton.	421.8238202112672
“Well, then, speak!”	484.5585609729846
“That which I have to say of her can only be heard by yourself, my	377.9562500354083
Lord!”	315.0155103051614
“Leave us, Patrick,” said Buckingham; “but remain within sound of the	407.157219286462
bell. I shall call you presently.”	415.7375346620904
Patrick went out.	481.25393023030864
“We are alone, sir,” said Buckingham; “speak!”	380.48677010266465
“My Lord,” said Felton, “the Baron de Winter wrote to you the other day	437.45579491873104
to request you to sign an order of embarkation relative to a young	462.01540688597237
woman named Charlotte Backson.”	425.5289234756278
“Yes, sir; and I answered him, to bring or send me that order and I	459.5126613153839
would sign it.”	476.33877320775656
“Here it is, my Lord.”	295.19998085477226
“Give it to me,” said the duke.	344.03595217758124
And taking it from Felton, he cast a rapid glance over the paper, and	443.940876373422
perceiving that it was the one that had been mentioned to him, he	374.49387697155805
placed it on the table, took a pen, and prepared to sign it.	412.62980828816416
“Pardon, my Lord,” said Felton, stopping the duke; “but does your Grace	379.94127477754034
know that the name of Charlotte Backson is not the true name of this	434.8149397676635
young woman?”	362.96336101435327
“Yes, sir, I know it,” replied the duke, dipping the quill in the ink.	353.3227138393731
“Then your Grace knows her real name?” asked Felton, in a sharp tone.	328.619992632145
“I know it”; and the duke put the quill to the paper. Felton grew pale.	484.9463220799963
“And knowing that real name, my Lord,” replied Felton, “will you sign	388.472794355871
it all the same?”	472.9720138933672
“Doubtless,” said Buckingham, “and rather twice than once.”	453.4490541769112
“I cannot believe,” continued Felton, in a voice that became more sharp	297.2820600745826
and rough, “that your Grace knows that it is to Milady de Winter this	481.4802335482693
relates.”	475.32186297418184
“I know it perfectly, although I am astonished that you know it.”	430.23199250573634
“And will your Grace sign that order without remorse?”	330.5197215998271
Buckingham looked at the young man haughtily.	357.327430862258
“Do you know, sir, that you are asking me very strange questions, and	470.77086511884056
that I am very foolish to answer them?”	457.52236996806073
“Reply to them, my Lord,” said Felton; “the circumstances are more	384.9506587213876
serious than you perhaps believe.”	460.74491174228206
Buckingham reflected that the young man, coming from Lord de Winter,	317.75508308125495
undoubtedly spoke in his name, and softened.	425.8385448182106
“Without remorse,” said he. “The baron knows, as well as myself, that	312.1749807835035
Milady de Winter is a very guilty woman, and it is treating her very	462.6942271829989
favorably to commute her punishment to transportation.” The duke put	461.5762331505111
his pen to the paper.	477.79312423353946
“You will not sign that order, my Lord!” said Felton, making a step	356.3236159664505
toward the duke.	299.9601783693233
“I will not sign this order! And why not?”	480.65221874682254
“Because you will look into yourself, and you will do justice to the	462.13251743872684
lady.”	346.4336321589667
“I should do her justice by sending her to Tyburn,” said Buckingham.	468.78767282279637
“This lady is infamous.”	351.0308507012967
“My Lord, Milady de Winter is an angel; you know that she is, and I	418.18060936710594
demand her liberty of you.”	362.71833576662084
“Bah! Are you mad, to talk to me thus?” said Buckingham.	367.26641845145116
“My Lord, excuse me! I speak as I can; I restrain myself. But, my Lord,	297.86211009448243
think of what you’re about to do, and beware of going too far!”	340.68049151564935
“What do you say? God pardon me!” cried Buckingham, “I really think he	338.64196310776276
threatens me!”	454.81054090435725
“No, my Lord, I still plead. And I say to you: one drop of water	428.1596352079637
suffices to make the full vase overflow; one slight fault may draw down	456.3557269964325
punishment upon the head spared, despite many crimes.”	343.195918416026
“Mr. Felton,” said Buckingham, “you will withdraw, and place yourself	441.8459377669816
at once under arrest.”	313.2366036357333
“You will hear me to the end, my Lord. You have seduced this young	450.301944976782
girl; you have outraged, defiled her. Repair your crimes toward her;	361.76411555251696
let her go free, and I will exact nothing else from you.”	390.714967087476
“You will exact!” said Buckingham, looking at Felton with astonishment,	344.3802081534936
and dwelling upon each syllable of the three words as he pronounced	459.0133783729393
them.	463.99235654357864
“My Lord,” continued Felton, becoming more excited as he spoke, “my	322.54335027060597
Lord, beware! All England is tired of your iniquities; my Lord, you	482.6419194172639
have abused the royal power, which you have almost usurped; my Lord,	302.6060643017787
you are held in horror by God and men. God will punish you hereafter,	317.75420948453257
but I will punish you here!”	476.18980358432344
“Ah, this is too much!” cried Buckingham, making a step toward the	309.57626168402294
door.	444.78348823668586
Felton barred his passage.	466.7188574651567
“I ask it humbly of you, my Lord,” said he; “sign the order for the	350.85706753454247
liberation of Milady de Winter. Remember that she is a woman whom you	464.7782018805
have dishonored.”	342.131161011552
“Withdraw, sir,” said Buckingham, “or I will call my attendant, and	441.8523914719488
have you placed in irons.”	380.9286928064916
“You shall not call,” said Felton, throwing himself between the duke	292.8494173674593
and the bell placed on a stand encrusted with silver. “Beware, my Lord,	432.90864484550605
you are in the hands of God!”	476.8387212435116
“In the hands of the devil, you mean!” cried Buckingham, raising his	445.83195335380117
voice so as to attract the notice of his people, without absolutely	346.5022414005225
shouting.	486.3470500221067
“Sign, my Lord; sign the liberation of Milady de Winter,” said Felton,	417.4508815953586
holding out a paper to the duke.	318.0504062560084
“By force? You are joking! Holloa, Patrick!”	323.87696939156893
“Sign, my Lord!”	309.7548959466994
“Never.”	306.21244533878365
“Never?”	375.8735702472214
“Help!” shouted the duke; and at the same time he sprang toward his	490.30835659250556
sword.	438.7842964158469
But Felton did not give him time to draw it. He held the knife with	456.3979526365725
which Milady had stabbed herself, open in his bosom; at one bound he	374.0680524071786
was upon the duke.	435.4893381891693
At that moment Patrick entered the room, crying, “A letter from France,	454.0418348683495
my Lord.”	435.034785363718
“From France!” cried Buckingham, forgetting everything in thinking from	474.010295162717
whom that letter came.	481.03323141908743
Felton took advantage of this moment, and plunged the knife into his	374.17649654899805
side up to the handle.	311.73179676110834
“Ah, traitor,” cried Buckingham, “you have killed me!”	345.05445898616654
“Murder!” screamed Patrick.	301.7648406994546
Felton cast his eyes round for means of escape, and seeing the door	418.4271050725141
free, he rushed into the next chamber, in which, as we have said, the	385.53333806118303
deputies from La Rochelle were waiting, crossed it as quickly as	478.7974674498189
possible, and rushed toward the staircase; but upon the first step he	424.7958827733537
met Lord de Winter, who, seeing him pale, confused, livid, and stained	305.71855071340997
with blood both on his hands and face, seized him by the throat,	329.2390832946793
crying, “I knew it! I guessed it! But too late by a minute,	444.239474798273
unfortunate, unfortunate that I am!”	422.50214981664806
Felton made no resistance. Lord de Winter placed him in the hands of	447.0016291774499
the guards, who led him, while awaiting further orders, to a little	422.33574336059445
terrace commanding the sea; and then the baron hastened to the duke’s	452.94764193818276
chamber.	382.9977257894468
At the cry uttered by the duke and the scream of Patrick, the man whom	398.4258073911287
Felton had met in the antechamber rushed into the chamber.	343.7911475650364
He found the duke reclining upon a sofa, with his hand pressed upon the	478.41946416785237
wound.	363.6093429751803
“Laporte,” said the duke, in a dying voice, “Laporte, do you come from	334.71046546639474
her?”	403.0736861436142
“Yes, monseigneur,” replied the faithful cloak bearer of Anne of	491.97673467643773
Austria, “but too late, perhaps.”	324.0694200195048
“Silence, Laporte, you may be overheard. Patrick, let no one enter. Oh,	406.045165688129
I cannot tell what she says to me! My God, I am dying!”	401.880039976451
And the duke swooned.	343.26123825569266
Meanwhile, Lord de Winter, the deputies, the leaders of the expedition,	304.7475267603623
the officers of Buckingham’s household, had all made their way into the	353.1645635247045
chamber. Cries of despair resounded on all sides. The news, which	442.2480592743419
filled the palace with tears and groans, soon became known, and spread	311.26050715991727
itself throughout the city.	400.46967949470763
The report of a cannon announced that something new and unexpected had	355.15988028605216
taken place.	292.410232197338
Lord de Winter tore his hair.	355.30473006981595
“Too late by a minute!” cried he, “too late by a minute! Oh, my God, my	430.43243458718024
God! what a misfortune!”	293.60937104133717
He had been informed at seven o’clock in the morning that a rope ladder	440.86828309465545
floated from one of the windows of the castle; he had hastened to	307.5159756591488
Milady’s chamber, had found it empty, the window open, and the bars	399.83616197890314
filed, had remembered the verbal caution D’Artagnan had transmitted to	359.5432359529711
him by his messenger, had trembled for the duke, and running to the	419.95770618097055
stable without taking time to have a horse saddled, had jumped upon the	383.74257077138213
first he found, had galloped off like the wind, had alighted below in	426.89456192414775
the courtyard, had ascended the stairs precipitately, and on the top	490.4116230559819
step, as we have said, had encountered Felton.	377.05065090381936
The duke, however, was not dead. He recovered a little, reopened his	369.7878180491953
eyes, and hope revived in all hearts.	483.8741881316268
“Gentlemen,” said he, “leave me alone with Patrick and Laporte—ah, is	395.8207483695047
that you, De Winter? You sent me a strange madman this morning! See the	467.9730567273919
state in which he has put me.”	345.13925316866835
“Oh, my Lord!” cried the baron, “I shall never console myself.”	467.97492138718053
“And you would be quite wrong, my dear De Winter,” said Buckingham,	422.6594711670424
holding out his hand to him. “I do not know the man who deserves being	436.4833654774633
regretted during the whole life of another man; but leave us, I pray	295.11984605626117
you.”	293.62690232528143
The baron went out sobbing.	370.8817747723531
There only remained in the closet of the wounded duke Laporte and	399.93439846987735
Patrick. A physician was sought for, but none was yet found.	325.02799785809094
“You will live, my Lord, you will live!” repeated the faithful servant	341.5104523610661
of Anne of Austria, on his knees before the duke’s sofa.	484.5490177375489
“What has she written to me?” said Buckingham, feebly, streaming with	357.76849761667944
blood, and suppressing his agony to speak of her he loved, “what has	469.458699639799
she written to me? Read me her letter.”	474.01171993360197
“Oh, my Lord!” said Laporte.	319.0991521343581
“Obey, Laporte, do you not see I have no time to lose?”	308.6951277513549
Laporte broke the seal, and placed the paper before the eyes of the	401.4688181268926
duke; but Buckingham in vain tried to make out the writing.	414.0080760232686
“Read!” said he, “read! I cannot see. Read, then! For soon, perhaps, I	357.7149113998911
shall not hear, and I shall die without knowing what she has written to	363.62711484624015
me.”	456.37932302483
Laporte made no further objection, and read:	323.53072522008245
“MY LORD, By that which, since I have known you, have suffered by you	436.98735544284324
and for you, I conjure you, if you have any care for my repose, to	376.15327233866344
countermand those great armaments which you are preparing against	316.33177474095874
France, to put an end to a war of which it is publicly said religion is	294.6728590238206
the ostensible cause, and of which, it is generally whispered, your	453.17844019216864
love for me is the concealed cause. This war may not only bring great	349.99441562168283
catastrophes upon England and France, but misfortune upon you, my Lord,	381.01711729607274
for which I should never console myself.	412.6257764494709
    “Be careful of your life, which is menaced, and which will be dear	376.257491132921
    to me from the moment I am not obliged to see an enemy in you.	412.5056768017207
“Your affectionate	374.69111210200043
“ANNE”	423.03517544192914
Buckingham collected all his remaining strength to listen to the	477.6640694088242
reading of the letter; then, when it was ended, as if he had met with a	425.04362756921876
bitter disappointment, he asked, “Have you nothing else to say to me by	372.92228791673347
the living voice, Laporte?”	414.12769955685064
“The queen charged me to tell you to watch over yourself, for she had	375.31482773473135
advice that your assassination would be attempted.”	470.45970572926956
“And is that all—is that all?” replied Buckingham, impatiently.	386.7223084394231
“She likewise charged me to tell you that she still loved you.”	454.32046073585224
“Ah,” said Buckingham, “God be praised! My death, then, will not be to	372.81231111042996
her as the death of a stranger!”	405.71207708248124
Laporte burst into tears.	324.63315003872344
“Patrick,” said the duke, “bring me the casket in which the diamond	371.40723166162786
studs were kept.”	439.05957786054853
Patrick brought the object desired, which Laporte recognized as having	343.7250187106612
belonged to the queen.	396.8158970506599
“Now the scent bag of white satin, on which her cipher is embroidered	435.1488456459675
in pearls.”	437.92487932514246
Patrick again obeyed.	344.7235839025032
“Here, Laporte,” said Buckingham, “these are the only tokens I ever	467.09146866938534
received from her—this silver casket and these two letters. You will	318.07692222739854
restore them to her Majesty; and as a last memorial”—he looked round	351.98775512463044
for some valuable object—“you will add—”	401.08828198555904
He still sought; but his eyes, darkened by death, encountered only the	458.61405475604033
knife which had fallen from the hand of Felton, still smoking with the	468.39751727832663
blood spread over its blade.	461.25773141376817
“And you will add to them this knife,” said the duke, pressing the hand	483.10015246211077
of Laporte. He had just strength enough to place the scent bag at the	477.9015305550477
bottom of the silver casket, and to let the knife fall into it, making	428.6286226145111
a sign to Laporte that he was no longer able to speak; then, in a last	418.3720743137393
convulsion, which this time he had not the power to combat, he slipped	323.74043616865856
from the sofa to the floor.	300.0190595099151
Patrick uttered a loud cry.	442.2719054034184
Buckingham tried to smile a last time; but death checked his thought,	381.86553264578924
which remained engraved on his brow like a last kiss of love.	384.52133135243025
At this moment the duke’s surgeon arrived, quite terrified; he was	356.65571726662074
already on board the admiral’s ship, where they had been obliged to	448.54193869994026
seek him.	475.7829402035194
He approached the duke, took his hand, held it for an instant in his	298.12738371837247
own, and letting it fall, “All is useless,” said he, “he is dead.”	345.41187490917804
“Dead, dead!” cried Patrick.	385.00216136019446
At this cry all the crowd re-entered the apartment, and throughout the	399.10008678041316
palace and town there was nothing but consternation and tumult.	341.85757567473985
As soon as Lord de Winter saw Buckingham was dead, he ran to Felton,	337.9801069764275
whom the soldiers still guarded on the terrace of the palace.	443.7783431556411
“Wretch!” said he to the young man, who since the death of Buckingham	344.37804077756834
had regained that coolness and self-possession which never after	317.4493767978023
abandoned him, “wretch! what have you done?”	403.0826671735266
“I have avenged myself!” said he.	437.10562959941626
“Avenged yourself,” said the baron. “Rather say that you have served as	465.8314932155706
an instrument to that accursed woman; but I swear to you that this	422.8847104849293
crime shall be her last.”	404.16392189253423
“I don’t know what you mean,” replied Felton, quietly, “and I am	440.1838249293603
ignorant of whom you are speaking, my Lord. I killed the Duke of	361.3668733661534
Buckingham because he twice refused you yourself to appoint me captain;	467.76747025031034
I have punished him for his injustice, that is all.”	335.4427150048647
De Winter, stupefied, looked on while the soldiers bound Felton, and	316.93920630811664
could not tell what to think of such insensibility.	422.75016822384555
One thing alone, however, threw a shade over the pallid brow of Felton.	377.0485882557065
At every noise he heard, the simple Puritan fancied he recognized the	323.2921308799903
step and voice of Milady coming to throw herself into his arms, to	419.9323163699098
accuse herself, and die with him.	491.7777843316186
All at once he started. His eyes became fixed upon a point of the sea,	473.1575082406069
commanded by the terrace where he was. With the eagle glance of a	466.2472725191411
sailor he had recognized there, where another would have seen only a	428.5818706705579
gull hovering over the waves, the sail of a sloop which was directed	466.6121129492336
toward the coast of France.	352.5261131370199
He grew deadly pale, placed his hand upon his heart, which was	446.73693732407173
breaking, and at once perceived all the treachery.	341.6380138764831
“One last favor, my Lord!” said he to the baron.	455.1184933741765
“What?” asked his Lordship.	482.2739686945132
“What o’clock is it?”	427.11315855905167
The baron drew out his watch. “It wants ten minutes to nine,” said he.	428.8852193626698
Milady had hastened her departure by an hour and a half. As soon as she	367.93645922718
heard the cannon which announced the fatal event, she had ordered the	311.88878475226056
anchor to be weighed. The vessel was making way under a blue sky, at	400.35620648545563
great distance from the coast.	463.3457804865729
“God has so willed it!” said he, with the resignation of a fanatic; but	384.8117069464574
without, however, being able to take his eyes from that ship, on board	446.95652348217953
of which he doubtless fancied he could distinguish the white outline of	404.8247646017318
her to whom he had sacrificed his life.	425.983245300848
De Winter followed his look, observed his feelings, and guessed all.	409.55009026144745
“Be punished _alone_, for the first, miserable man!” said Lord de	337.43622174120935
Winter to Felton, who was being dragged away with his eyes turned	363.0588424358042
toward the sea; “but I swear to you by the memory of my brother whom I	448.4508237130334
have loved so much that your accomplice is not saved.”	384.0602873840879
Felton lowered his head without pronouncing a syllable.	342.11098062786584
As to Lord de Winter, he descended the stairs rapidly, and went	415.52062113287076
straight to the port.	378.47416231178056
Chapter LX.	415.7090618704043
IN FRANCE	419.05206344414916
The first fear of the King of England, Charles I., on learning of the	319.42776347959625
death of the duke, was that such terrible news might discourage the	363.85298882647976
Rochellais; he tried, says Richelieu in his _Memoirs_, to conceal it	340.5285504325347
from them as long as possible, closing all the ports of his kingdom,	323.3661766286767
and carefully keeping watch that no vessel should sail until the army	435.0969269510442
which Buckingham was getting together had gone, taking upon himself, in	350.21390450196947
default of Buckingham, to superintend the departure.	475.5469564481672
He carried the strictness of this order so far as to detain in England	418.2295622794561
the ambassadors of Denmark, who had taken their leave, and the regular	314.73123611240777
ambassador of Holland, who was to take back to the port of Flushing the	350.60205997712507
Indian merchantmen of which Charles I. had made restitution to the	297.81673591798517
United Provinces.	334.10876109304746
But as he did not think of giving this order till five hours after the	370.87014394235314
event—that is to say, till two o’clock in the afternoon—two vessels had	441.45447510693197
already left the port, the one bearing, as we know, Milady, who,	353.79205803109824
already anticipating the event, was further confirmed in that belief by	422.45496745871446
seeing the black flag flying at the masthead of the admiral’s ship.	297.1173734515953
As to the second vessel, we will tell hereafter whom it carried, and	356.927742110828
how it set sail.	385.18988426281044
During this time nothing new occurred in the camp at La Rochelle; only	315.0254088224083
the king, who was bored, as always, but perhaps a little more so in	330.6120340083064
camp than elsewhere, resolved to go incognito and spend the festival of	338.99304159858997
St. Louis at St. Germain, and asked the cardinal to order him an escort	480.6073933678234
of only twenty Musketeers. The cardinal, who sometimes became weary of	410.98125914048495
the king, granted this leave of absence with great pleasure to his	486.53864052360484
royal lieutenant, who promised to return about the fifteenth of	295.1799409108554
September.	307.4656015994936
M. de Tréville, being informed of this by his Eminence, packed his	419.7450785582333
portmanteau; and as without knowing the cause he knew the great desire	482.00278839878206
and even imperative need which his friends had of returning to Paris,	382.61048188591934
it goes without saying that he fixed upon them to form part of the	324.8506298155528
escort.	353.1198223905897
The four young men heard the news a quarter of an hour after M. de	313.25651986917813
Tréville, for they were the first to whom he communicated it. It was	461.8138902379529
then that D’Artagnan appreciated the favor the cardinal had conferred	301.78753061394247
upon him in making him at last enter the Musketeers—for without that	484.1075143669859
circumstance he would have been forced to remain in the camp while his	364.4046819751485
companions left it.	422.0515902443842
It goes without saying that this impatience to return toward Paris had	421.86424778512946
for a cause the danger which Mme. Bonacieux would run of meeting at the	305.32466297329773
convent of Béthune with Milady, her mortal enemy. Aramis therefore had	405.3218067104335
written immediately to Marie Michon, the seamstress at Tours who had	429.4280150647178
such fine acquaintances, to obtain from the queen authority for Mme.	477.71739885547436
Bonacieux to leave the convent, and to retire either into Lorraine or	377.74640324003366
Belgium. They had not long to wait for an answer. Eight or ten days	463.1996147921203
afterward Aramis received the following letter:	476.3109456357927
“MY DEAR COUSIN, Here is the authorization from my sister to withdraw	360.96046110680686
our little servant from the convent of Béthune, the air of which you	437.4724721928667
think is bad for her. My sister sends you this authorization with great	409.3643128194302
pleasure, for she is very partial to the little girl, to whom she	387.5658345458308
intends to be more serviceable hereafter.	404.5138581681708
“I salute you,	467.0839284133018
“MARIE MICHON”	471.4648170275613
To this letter was added an order, conceived in these terms:	357.4628957523493
“At the Louvre, August 10, 1628	468.7993411333051
“The superior of the convent of Béthune will place in the hands of the	404.64944530586735
person who shall present this note to her the novice who entered the	352.405032684324
convent upon my recommendation and under my patronage.	318.42149609601887
“ANNE”	314.0553032690859
It may be easily imagined how the relationship between Aramis and a	413.5871378823466
seamstress who called the queen her sister amused the young men; but	435.5168590643516
Aramis, after having blushed two or three times up to the whites of his	475.38100709384764
eyes at the gross pleasantry of Porthos, begged his friends not to	395.47497286348886
revert to the subject again, declaring that if a single word more was	346.7951581909248
said to him about it, he would never again implore his cousins to	477.5988446382263
interfere in such affairs.	442.3552469173824
There was no further question, therefore, about Marie Michon among the	300.86716168991984
four Musketeers, who besides had what they wanted: that was, the order	357.902660281496
to withdraw Mme. Bonacieux from the convent of the Carmelites of	408.5136240500183
Béthune. It was true that this order would not be of great use to them	415.0629870063324
while they were in camp at La Rochelle; that is to say, at the other	451.1639018570121
end of France. Therefore D’Artagnan was going to ask leave of absence	348.56443477685076
of M. de Tréville, confiding to him candidly the importance of his	361.5998384114289
departure, when the news was transmitted to him as well as to his three	406.3144431913248
friends that the king was about to set out for Paris with an escort of	481.6029527351317
twenty Musketeers, and that they formed part of the escort.	463.0699059746935
Their joy was great. The lackeys were sent on before with the baggage,	405.5679083732244
and they set out on the morning of the sixteenth.	330.08452281933984
The cardinal accompanied his Majesty from Surgères to Mauzes; and there	407.945313218541
the king and his minister took leave of each other with great	465.51041497434477
demonstrations of friendship.	382.51705130622815
The king, however, who sought distraction, while traveling as fast as	443.8256057989189
possible—for he was anxious to be in Paris by the twenty-third—stopped	454.9534799993316
from time to time to fly the magpie, a pastime for which the taste had	423.74903087329045
been formerly inspired in him by de Luynes, and for which he had always	365.5052149843821
preserved a great predilection. Out of the twenty Musketeers sixteen,	458.6657470883399
when this took place, rejoiced greatly at this relaxation; but the	452.22332043480674
other four cursed it heartily. D’Artagnan, in particular, had a	379.9204709652338
perpetual buzzing in his ears, which Porthos explained thus: “A very	303.7409780891952
great lady has told me that this means that somebody is talking of you	352.4863292886878
somewhere.”	330.3301032577698
At length the escort passed through Paris on the twenty-third, in the	303.9480411614273
night. The king thanked M. de Tréville, and permitted him to distribute	444.1033132807828
furloughs for four days, on condition that the favored parties should	397.2377875537013
not appear in any public place, under penalty of the Bastille.	298.9127704825975
The first four furloughs granted, as may be imagined, were to our four	488.99957306498834
friends. Still further, Athos obtained of M. de Tréville six days	433.99097781757166
instead of four, and introduced into these six days two more nights—for	436.99478653284325
they set out on the twenty-fourth at five o’clock in the evening, and	415.5871378269534
as a further kindness M. de Tréville post-dated the leave to the	417.77262300787635
morning of the twenty-fifth.	433.712110232084
“Good Lord!” said D’Artagnan, who, as we have often said, never	425.2951543536147
stumbled at anything. “It appears to me that we are making a great	449.6989567234011
trouble of a very simple thing. In two days, and by using up two or	489.6656792699753
three horses (that’s nothing; I have plenty of money), I am at Béthune.	367.94315144701125
I present my letter from the queen to the superior, and I bring back	471.83501510131873
the dear treasure I go to seek—not into Lorraine, not into Belgium, but	310.02068346062435
to Paris, where she will be much better concealed, particularly while	446.4192109528458
the cardinal is at La Rochelle. Well, once returned from the country,	488.5863454698632
half by the protection of her cousin, half through what we have	420.8230924466353
personally done for her, we shall obtain from the queen what we desire.	296.1481484900394
Remain, then, where you are, and do not exhaust yourselves with useless	332.05691215519977
fatigue. Myself and Planchet are all that such a simple expedition	386.7750714493897
requires.”	407.6176730177793
To this Athos replied quietly: “We also have money left—for I have not	362.5230502439865
yet drunk all my share of the diamond, and Porthos and Aramis have not	348.05169164751584
eaten all theirs. We can therefore use up four horses as well as one.	470.92275041197615
But consider, D’Artagnan,” added he, in a tone so solemn that it made	386.17896298906203
the young man shudder, “consider that Béthune is a city where the	374.17537373303696
cardinal has given rendezvous to a woman who, wherever she goes, brings	408.18662210449986
misery with her. If you had only to deal with four men, D’Artagnan, I	404.65553048812586
would allow you to go alone. You have to do with that woman! We four	433.6551240389149
will go; and I hope to God that with our four lackeys we may be in	430.20172891436073
sufficient number.”	404.4790211184522
“You terrify me, Athos!” cried D’Artagnan. “My God! what do you fear?”	487.85982869094744
“Everything!” replied Athos.	396.2718338663992
D’Artagnan examined the countenances of his companions, which, like	338.8837065389227
that of Athos, wore an impression of deep anxiety; and they continued	488.4655199799088
their route as fast as their horses could carry them, but without	294.4595722049035
adding another word.	465.26905491371775
On the evening of the twenty-fifth, as they were entering Arras, and as	348.2662454996332
D’Artagnan was dismounting at the inn of the Golden Harrow to drink a	377.54383527966377
glass of wine, a horseman came out of the post yard, where he had just	384.1114377051659
had a relay, started off at a gallop, and with a fresh horse took the	433.4112308487587
road to Paris. At the moment he passed through the gateway into the	435.1173711473881
street, the wind blew open the cloak in which he was wrapped, although	471.51901527186135
it was in the month of August, and lifted his hat, which the traveler	445.031429333035
seized with his hand the moment it had left his head, pulling it	346.6964600549077
eagerly over his eyes.	301.2008877531646
D’Artagnan, who had his eyes fixed upon this man, became very pale, and	393.99726344347425
let his glass fall.	298.318623403009
“What is the matter, monsieur?” said Planchet. “Oh, come, gentlemen, my	418.26700111261744
master is ill!”	366.08747946803095
The three friends hastened toward D’Artagnan, who, instead of being	348.5350895156734
ill, ran toward his horse. They stopped him at the door.	320.7582345842537
“Well, where the devil are you going now?” cried Athos.	397.3371040528343
“It is he!” cried D’Artagnan, pale with anger, and with the sweat on	480.2841816550014
his brow, “it is he! let me overtake him!”	345.16953035094525
“He? What he?” asked Athos.	379.5214434680778
“He, that man!”	317.22869604615727
“What man?”	342.8326074725066
“That cursed man, my evil genius, whom I have always met with when	455.6769290308631
threatened by some misfortune, he who accompanied that horrible woman	474.613669339421
when I met her for the first time, he whom I was seeking when I	484.45641060135813
offended our Athos, he whom I saw on the very morning Madame Bonacieux	419.0038822437085
was abducted. I have seen him; that is he! I recognized him when the	469.7372092381155
wind blew upon his cloak.”	491.184359049889
“The devil!” said Athos, musingly.	347.3748278713536
“To saddle, gentlemen! to saddle! Let us pursue him, and we shall	449.63596125143613
overtake him!”	336.02052412054553
“My dear friend,” said Aramis, “remember that he goes in an opposite	304.30965425592257
direction from that in which we are going, that he has a fresh horse,	454.8630267698444
and ours are fatigued, so that we shall disable our own horses without	438.4724562548911
even a chance of overtaking him. Let the man go, D’Artagnan; let us	357.0435178004062
save the woman.”	309.07309296027967
“Monsieur, monsieur!” cried a hostler, running out and looking after	391.755729499135
the stranger, “monsieur, here is a paper which dropped out of your hat!	416.99173929869914
Eh, monsieur, eh!”	337.03574453017086
“Friend,” said D’Artagnan, “a half-pistole for that paper!”	447.97850075081766
“My faith, monsieur, with great pleasure! Here it is!”	337.93549015019806
The hostler, enchanted with the good day’s work he had done, returned	335.6067806583368
to the yard. D’Artagnan unfolded the paper.	487.0011406528695
“Well?” eagerly demanded all his three friends.	337.4540048279639
“Nothing but one word!” said D’Artagnan.	374.4864011926899
“Yes,” said Aramis, “but that one word is the name of some town or	394.63953084057243
village.”	378.82592607481905
“_Armentières_,” read Porthos; “Armentières? I don’t know such a	440.0738165401424
place.”	327.74635954417977
“And that name of a town or village is written in her hand!” cried	459.05718612021866
Athos.	378.16768954091117
“Come on, come on!” said D’Artagnan; “let us keep that paper carefully,	445.88263650243823
perhaps I have not thrown away my half-pistole. To horse, my friends,	364.30316395407243
to horse!”	395.84753080347355
And the four friends flew at a gallop along the road to Béthune.	302.7209391768879
Chapter LXI.	428.85504803532876
THE CARMELITE CONVENT AT BÉTHUNE	427.17724430995565
Great criminals bear about them a kind of predestination which makes	354.61712081376334
them surmount all obstacles, which makes them escape all dangers, up to	461.1942736006148
the moment which a wearied Providence has marked as the rock of their	301.73201914267753
impious fortunes.	477.88390618582264
It was thus with Milady. She escaped the cruisers of both nations, and	429.4818123472603
arrived at Boulogne without accident.	295.2096821844621
When landing at Portsmouth, Milady was an Englishwoman whom the	429.4145221032978
persecutions of the French drove from La Rochelle; when landing at	463.89013070121234
Boulogne, after a two days’ passage, she passed for a Frenchwoman whom	339.91804076220177
the English persecuted at Portsmouth out of their hatred for France.	417.24999614479975
Milady had, likewise, the best of passports—her beauty, her noble	310.5844296816479
appearance, and the liberality with which she distributed her pistoles.	359.84094073265254
Freed from the usual formalities by the affable smile and gallant	479.51376676117434
manners of an old governor of the port, who kissed her hand, she only	374.19958948707676
remained long enough at Boulogne to put into the post a letter,	436.0329613856506
conceived in the following terms:	385.9802284215557
“_To his Eminence Monseigneur the Cardinal Richelieu, in his camp	365.9112240524925
before La Rochelle_.	457.2502114777002
“MONSEIGNEUR, Let your Eminence be reassured. His Grace the Duke of	294.05464592240645
Buckingham _will not set out_ for France.	359.8100140761417
“MILADY DE ——	410.76440360552704
“BOULOGNE, evening of the twenty-fifth.	470.9226872623326
“P.S.—According to the desire of your Eminence, I report to the convent	303.22583639386914
of the Carmelites at Béthune, where I will await your orders.”	323.838682431153
Accordingly, that same evening Milady commenced her journey. Night	418.64620170802283
overtook her; she stopped, and slept at an inn. At five o’clock the	461.3463549707434
next morning she again proceeded, and in three hours after entered	339.32526993403934
Béthune. She inquired for the convent of the Carmelites, and went	408.86079228631274
thither immediately.	360.89157837054495
The superior met her; Milady showed her the cardinal’s order. The	448.2225505297633
abbess assigned her a chamber, and had breakfast served.	374.19538814901057
All the past was effaced from the eyes of this woman; and her looks,	482.83672774480846
fixed on the future, beheld nothing but the high fortunes reserved for	364.993246852529
her by the cardinal, whom she had so successfully served without his	481.653605120172
name being in any way mixed up with the sanguinary affair. The ever-new	462.3132208682713
passions which consumed her gave to her life the appearance of those	305.7773410772736
clouds which float in the heavens, reflecting sometimes azure,	299.5404540031726
sometimes fire, sometimes the opaque blackness of the tempest, and	455.48056495135404
which leave no traces upon the earth behind them but devastation and	461.55427962071803
death.	401.5587505937012
After breakfast, the abbess came to pay her a visit. There is very	371.189488719515
little amusement in the cloister, and the good superior was eager to	365.161971641638
make the acquaintance of her new boarder.	350.134769138872
Milady wished to please the abbess. This was a very easy matter for a	298.6019225974526
woman so really superior as she was. She tried to be agreeable, and she	447.31859613457107
was charming, winning the good superior by her varied conversation and	374.1326146840447
by the graces of her whole personality.	447.93212594926206
The abbess, who was the daughter of a noble house, took particular	472.7209289857856
delight in stories of the court, which so seldom travel to the	484.8498252657495
extremities of the kingdom, and which, above all, have so much	431.52524530608474
difficulty in penetrating the walls of convents, at whose threshold the	349.49305104519203
noise of the world dies away.	429.3992250958731
Milady, on the contrary, was quite conversant with all aristocratic	355.3301914978355
intrigues, amid which she had constantly lived for five or six years.	338.9829894797165
She made it her business, therefore, to amuse the good abbess with the	401.28059475617613
worldly practices of the court of France, mixed with the eccentric	470.6596420300059
pursuits of the king; she made for her the scandalous chronicle of the	376.94393229884184
lords and ladies of the court, whom the abbess knew perfectly by name,	458.45387945647286
touched lightly on the amours of the queen and the Duke of Buckingham,	377.68664948484025
talking a great deal to induce her auditor to talk a little.	338.3048908357307
But the abbess contented herself with listening and smiling without	338.51393550934745
replying a word. Milady, however, saw that this sort of narrative	486.514895509335
amused her very much, and kept at it; only she now let her conversation	333.66287043410983
drift toward the cardinal.	296.00392864753866
But she was greatly embarrassed. She did not know whether the abbess	319.5702710891501
was a royalist or a cardinalist; she therefore confined herself to a	411.8637845644144
prudent middle course. But the abbess, on her part, maintained a	309.8845414914202
reserve still more prudent, contenting herself with making a profound	438.05520024127486
inclination of the head every time the fair traveler pronounced the	399.3322659430291
name of his Eminence.	355.27694911428506
Milady began to think she should soon grow weary of a convent life; she	456.7662517308336
resolved, then, to risk something in order that she might know how to	301.5433794968068
act afterward. Desirous of seeing how far the discretion of the good	320.4968059698631
abbess would go, she began to tell a story, obscure at first, but very	427.012775684874
circumstantial afterward, about the cardinal, relating the amours of	410.34725956365213
the minister with Mme. d’Aiguillon, Marion de Lorme, and several other	488.5535194144783
gay women.	447.206116902963
The abbess listened more attentively, grew animated by degrees, and	340.1678967628485
smiled.	472.31593291193167
“Good,” thought Milady; “she takes a pleasure in my conversation. If	338.29657187123667
she is a cardinalist, she has no fanaticism, at least.”	381.5469460452602
She then went on to describe the persecutions exercised by the cardinal	308.8416679934272
upon his enemies. The abbess only crossed herself, without approving or	400.41189473314387
disapproving.	454.0128117307871
This confirmed Milady in her opinion that the abbess was rather	367.948162891223
royalist than cardinalist. Milady therefore continued, coloring her	428.0875116757402
narrations more and more.	474.3471637364888
“I am very ignorant of these matters,” said the abbess, at length; “but	313.87256977305935
however distant from the court we may be, however remote from the	430.7303313080491
interests of the world we may be placed, we have very sad examples of	483.8819478307473
what you have related. And one of our boarders has suffered much from	336.39916607087133
the vengeance and persecution of the cardinal!”	394.00473152998995
“One of your boarders?” said Milady; “oh, my God! Poor woman! I pity	348.0265852347785
her, then.”	461.3857705642912
“And you have reason, for she is much to be pitied. Imprisonment,	341.60683594654046
menaces, ill treatment—she has suffered everything. But after all,”	390.2685325278541
resumed the abbess, “Monsieur Cardinal has perhaps plausible motives	305.0299616368807
for acting thus; and though she has the look of an angel, we must not	393.24138381124817
always judge people by the appearance.”	428.1136019285528
“Good!” said Milady to herself; “who knows! I am about, perhaps, to	356.52442960773976
discover something here; I am in the vein.”	372.74984395764125
She tried to give her countenance an appearance of perfect candor.	420.3726173630557
“Alas,” said Milady, “I know it is so. It is said that we must not	404.00933025424627
trust to the face; but in what, then, shall we place confidence, if not	378.95838957583646
in the most beautiful work of the Lord? As for me, I shall be deceived	382.9668251119518
all my life perhaps, but I shall always have faith in a person whose	412.2581223194024
countenance inspires me with sympathy.”	412.30944529891315
“You would, then, be tempted to believe,” said the abbess, “that this	436.4194176683709
young person is innocent?”	456.8962586870334
“The cardinal pursues not only crimes,” said she: “there are certain	338.4021254492866
virtues which he pursues more severely than certain offenses.”	450.0826645637935
“Permit me, madame, to express my surprise,” said the abbess.	437.34958081531795
“At what?” said Milady, with the utmost ingenuousness.	432.5896048692781
“At the language you use.”	441.39076494229073
“What do you find so astonishing in that language?” said Milady,	376.6205001313102
smiling.	442.47998360389875
“You are the friend of the cardinal, for he sends you hither, and yet—”	468.14751487051313
“And yet I speak ill of him,” replied Milady, finishing the thought of	451.64595606442333
the superior.	402.537436076572
“At least you don’t speak well of him.”	489.0865746231824
“That is because I am not his friend,” said she, sighing, “but his	296.68981842417924
victim!”	458.9672274485267
“But this letter in which he recommends you to me?”	359.19343660857476
“Is an order for me to confine myself to a sort of prison, from which	470.52647842494923
he will release me by one of his satellites.”	347.8057691297634
“But why have you not fled?”	456.2888200090566
“Whither should I go? Do you believe there is a spot on the earth which	446.14324839767335
the cardinal cannot reach if he takes the trouble to stretch forth his	326.716214584302
hand? If I were a man, that would barely be possible; but what can a	432.80880336639586
woman do? This young boarder of yours, has she tried to fly?”	343.28464106527804
“No, that is true; but she—that is another thing; I believe she is	330.74668492255796
detained in France by some love affair.”	313.9271498072008
“Ah,” said Milady, with a sigh, “if she loves she is not altogether	380.3555766115436
wretched.”	472.1418774306345
“Then,” said the abbess, looking at Milady with increasing interest, “I	355.0411085313593
behold another poor victim?”	425.109791223784
“Alas, yes,” said Milady.	462.7587780231212
The abbess looked at her for an instant with uneasiness, as if a fresh	356.8728701576719
thought suggested itself to her mind.	384.2105329772803
“You are not an enemy of our holy faith?” said she, hesitatingly.	385.4952414352087
“Who—I?” cried Milady; “I a Protestant? Oh, no! I call to witness the	327.6734968017616
God who hears us, that on the contrary I am a fervent Catholic!”	403.5133781723794
“Then, madame,” said the abbess, smiling, “be reassured; the house in	377.8673271584521
which you are shall not be a very hard prison, and we will do all in	302.7571901661747
our power to make you cherish your captivity. You will find here,	384.8902472577
moreover, the young woman of whom I spoke, who is persecuted, no doubt,	453.0809203325381
in consequence of some court intrigue. She is amiable and	480.8772569666738
well-behaved.”	351.7459692068093
“What is her name?”	450.01910091490385
“She was sent to me by someone of high rank, under the name of Kitty. I	426.0751352275505
have not tried to discover her other name.”	423.5605298932235
“Kitty!” cried Milady. “What? Are you sure?”	305.70496656189704
“That she is called so? Yes, madame. Do you know her?”	346.16140005573345
Milady smiled to herself at the idea which had occurred to her that	389.6392293910689
this might be her old chambermaid. There was connected with the	366.2879363061558
remembrance of this girl a remembrance of anger; and a desire of	443.6460351220612
vengeance disordered the features of Milady, which, however,	402.43532997416827
immediately recovered the calm and benevolent expression which this	358.78007879182474
woman of a hundred faces had for a moment allowed them to lose.	294.32711339658164
“And when can I see this young lady, for whom I already feel so great a	354.8075966271011
sympathy?” asked Milady.	394.9437019652776
“Why, this evening,” said the abbess; “today even. But you have been	396.1139102004238
traveling these four days, as you told me yourself. This morning you	422.3181076874241
rose at five o’clock; you must stand in need of repose. Go to bed and	316.4257609051548
sleep; at dinnertime we will rouse you.”	380.2957321980831
Although Milady would very willingly have gone without sleep, sustained	349.22082560290727
as she was by all the excitements which a new adventure awakened in her	342.675054281431
heart, ever thirsting for intrigues, she nevertheless accepted the	412.48505071428707
offer of the superior. During the last fifteen days she had experienced	399.83649832129964
so many and such various emotions that if her frame of iron was still	359.0754562190717
capable of supporting fatigue, her mind required repose.	310.15278796700284
She therefore took leave of the abbess, and went to bed, softly rocked	296.20901578191433
by the ideas of vengeance which the name of Kitty had naturally brought	300.1725365827359
to her thoughts. She remembered that almost unlimited promise which the	449.33559788795736
cardinal had given her if she succeeded in her enterprise. She had	378.29506545084195
succeeded; D’Artagnan was then in her power!	365.0922380770669
One thing alone frightened her; that was the remembrance of her	354.6091282034345
husband, the Comte de la Fère, whom she had believed dead, or at least	344.0243593397634
expatriated, and whom she found again in Athos—the best friend of	399.02574500851375
D’Artagnan.	322.00811653164055
But alas, if he was the friend of D’Artagnan, he must have lent him his	375.52274174397223
assistance in all the proceedings by whose aid the queen had defeated	384.81963441168057
the project of his Eminence; if he was the friend of D’Artagnan, he was	345.4838792030729
the enemy of the cardinal; and she doubtless would succeed in involving	395.4742249587516
him in the vengeance by which she hoped to destroy the young Musketeer.	326.32098540638765
All these hopes were so many sweet thoughts for Milady; so, rocked by	403.3732675180145
them, she soon fell asleep.	376.0479216195644
She was awakened by a soft voice which sounded at the foot of her bed.	320.1682121060051
She opened her eyes, and saw the abbess, accompanied by a young woman	491.6582114687526
with light hair and delicate complexion, who fixed upon her a look full	463.77827156916226
of benevolent curiosity.	410.0616850691024
The face of the young woman was entirely unknown to her. Each examined	390.2917573010053
the other with great attention, while exchanging the customary	379.2301090302222
compliments; both were very handsome, but of quite different styles of	386.00082127010563
beauty. Milady, however, smiled in observing that she excelled the	440.8784571831291
young woman by far in her high air and aristocratic bearing. It is true	402.59315602277945
that the habit of a novice, which the young woman wore, was not very	345.02373517304284
advantageous in a contest of this kind.	361.8953987147685
The abbess introduced them to each other. When this formality was	447.26757645853763
ended, as her duties called her to chapel, she left the two young women	360.6654433251066
alone.	375.1744238212124
The novice, seeing Milady in bed, was about to follow the example of	398.15095291522874
