the superior; but Milady stopped her.	385.9480822453927
“How, madame,” said she, “I have scarcely seen you, and you already	335.2243612779335
wish to deprive me of your company, upon which I had counted a little,	460.5902362232457
I must confess, for the time I have to pass here?”	340.07453588845533
“No, madame,” replied the novice, “only I thought I had chosen my time	326.8307477742154
ill; you were asleep, you are fatigued.”	381.2088185524144
“Well,” said Milady, “what can those who sleep wish for—a happy	439.6802310647578
awakening? This awakening you have given me; allow me, then, to enjoy	472.8468476477152
it at my ease,” and taking her hand, she drew her toward the armchair	346.9442940988008
by the bedside.	357.1571847808507
The novice sat down.	317.2132664499667
“How unfortunate I am!” said she; “I have been here six months without	437.87068355654117
the shadow of recreation. You arrive, and your presence was likely to	391.9902608419455
afford me delightful company; yet I expect, in all probability, to quit	333.75634999564573
the convent at any moment.”	362.76714709597314
“How, you are going soon?” asked Milady.	458.37327548747646
“At least I hope so,” said the novice, with an expression of joy which	422.1113077995303
she made no effort to disguise.	385.8649831112297
“I think I learned you had suffered persecutions from the cardinal,”	473.7626535936426
continued Milady; “that would have been another motive for sympathy	312.76222192584714
between us.”	324.55983060984863
“What I have heard, then, from our good mother is true; you have	435.2696393229742
likewise been a victim of that wicked priest.”	409.28814164604694
“Hush!” said Milady; “let us not, even here, speak thus of him. All my	483.32335221562255
misfortunes arise from my having said nearly what you have said before	312.9357723369701
a woman whom I thought my friend, and who betrayed me. Are you also the	316.0121463679192
victim of a treachery?”	357.14100391317083
“No,” said the novice, “but of my devotion—of a devotion to a woman I	396.96934161455715
loved, for whom I would have laid down my life, for whom I would give	463.265013289906
it still.”	417.005682847886
“And who has abandoned you—is that it?”	399.98290886789715
“I have been sufficiently unjust to believe so; but during the last two	402.1422879047917
or three days I have obtained proof to the contrary, for which I thank	351.38728315195794
God—for it would have cost me very dear to think she had forgotten me.	424.98032658208933
But you, madame, you appear to be free,” continued the novice; “and if	329.1395689153601
you were inclined to fly it only rests with yourself to do so.”	425.85399901299377
“Whither would you have me go, without friends, without money, in a	295.66632486681505
part of France with which I am unacquainted, and where I have never	344.67290167532445
been before?”	433.8737696352747
“Oh,” cried the novice, “as to friends, you would have them wherever	375.53073782436496
you want, you appear so good and are so beautiful!”	471.58170513200963
“That does not prevent,” replied Milady, softening her smile so as to	395.9618749196215
give it an angelic expression, “my being alone or being persecuted.”	337.2498357182622
“Hear me,” said the novice; “we must trust in heaven. There always	398.31577626229677
comes a moment when the good you have done pleads your cause before	317.5255798419072
God; and see, perhaps it is a happiness for you, humble and powerless	304.8103407331963
as I am, that you have met with me, for if I leave this place, well—I	487.11744041916313
have powerful friends, who, after having exerted themselves on my	431.8980725934951
account, may also exert themselves for you.”	441.5659755501355
“Oh, when I said I was alone,” said Milady, hoping to make the novice	433.6978123507832
talk by talking of herself, “it is not for want of friends in high	327.0000606327384
places; but these friends themselves tremble before the cardinal. The	437.5385715892314
queen herself does not dare to oppose the terrible minister. I have	389.6552959069245
proof that her Majesty, notwithstanding her excellent heart, has more	451.5338639138073
than once been obliged to abandon to the anger of his Eminence persons	468.43036262885573
who had served her.”	364.75558988810485
“Trust me, madame; the queen may appear to have abandoned those	421.5733873206755
persons, but we must not put faith in appearances. The more they are	478.9586984862776
persecuted, the more she thinks of them; and often, when they least	387.61661158624497
expect it, they have proof of a kind remembrance.”	415.4906608806154
“Alas!” said Milady, “I believe so; the queen is so good!”	393.3601723007063
“Oh, you know her, then, that lovely and noble queen, that you speak of	395.06321240789816
her thus!” cried the novice, with enthusiasm.	320.9239235154609
“That is to say,” replied Milady, driven into her entrenchment, “that I	337.93887470822085
have not the honor of knowing her personally; but I know a great number	438.56248336603767
of her most intimate friends. I am acquainted with Monsieur de Putange;	469.6461250491911
I met Monsieur Dujart in England; I know Monsieur de Tréville.”	490.9962809261603
“Monsieur de Tréville!” exclaimed the novice, “do you know Monsieur de	404.3812265843503
Tréville?”	381.941225162381
“Yes, perfectly well—intimately even.”	369.47714203422413
“The captain of the king’s Musketeers?”	349.784409784989
“The captain of the king’s Musketeers.”	465.3862118734572
“Why, then, only see!” cried the novice; “we shall soon be well	470.1616444531338
acquainted, almost friends. If you know Monsieur de Tréville, you must	485.7085250724785
have visited him?”	483.9241912983689
“Often!” said Milady, who, having entered this track, and perceiving	450.8673629408722
that falsehood succeeded, was determined to follow it to the end.	293.3583684328523
“With him, then, you must have seen some of his Musketeers?”	394.926252049788
“All those he is in the habit of receiving!” replied Milady, for whom	411.6448272067209
this conversation began to have a real interest.	480.8037435033892
“Name a few of those whom you know, and you will see if they are my	355.69146774988684
friends.”	453.5390730084225
“Well!” said Milady, embarrassed, “I know Monsieur de Louvigny,	421.24176365707365
Monsieur de Courtivron, Monsieur de Ferussac.”	325.68764927685027
The novice let her speak, then seeing that she paused, she said, “Don’t	444.57337950083627
you know a gentleman named Athos?”	311.34805019250797
Milady became as pale as the sheets in which she was lying, and	411.33209847704495
mistress as she was of herself, could not help uttering a cry, seizing	427.5764835904615
the hand of the novice, and devouring her with looks.	404.547933322034
“What is the matter? Good God!” asked the poor woman, “have I said	329.367840585641
anything that has wounded you?”	433.757768600305
“No; but the name struck me, because I also have known that gentleman,	488.5463577049467
and it appeared strange to me to meet with a person who appears to know	425.67804379672606
him well.”	354.4466166634879
“Oh, yes, very well; not only him, but some of his friends, Messieurs	382.32233363547874
Porthos and Aramis!”	304.83748558508506
“Indeed! you know them likewise? I know them,” cried Milady, who began	327.3633300981681
to feel a chill penetrate her heart.	400.3365950244368
“Well, if you know them, you know that they are good and free	439.2861270892247
companions. Why do you not apply to them, if you stand in need of	340.7616038589707
help?”	310.58720011181873
“That is to say,” stammered Milady, “I am not really very intimate with	442.893597810858
any of them. I know them from having heard one of their friends,	442.3283124284151
Monsieur d’Artagnan, say a great deal about them.”	408.3869425558978
“You know Monsieur d’Artagnan!” cried the novice, in her turn seizing	480.5773465006265
the hands of Milady and devouring her with her eyes.	344.9384197798583
Then remarking the strange expression of Milady’s countenance, she	435.7853863966293
said, “Pardon me, madame; you know him by what title?”	423.6959196594488
“Why,” replied Milady, embarrassed, “why, by the title of friend.”	417.0465816562147
“You deceive me, madame,” said the novice; “you have been his	340.9502615081638
mistress!”	360.88728107040464
“It is you who have been his mistress, madame!” cried Milady, in her	393.0549036733797
turn.	338.52018381887217
“I?” said the novice.	330.87821357664944
“Yes, you! I know you now. You are Madame Bonacieux!”	405.80530381602307
The young woman drew back, filled with surprise and terror.	449.7875957581972
“Oh, do not deny it! Answer!” continued Milady.	302.47990651271886
“Well, yes, madame,” said the novice, “Are we rivals?”	326.5243491843558
The countenance of Milady was illumined by so savage a joy that under	446.0387205525247
any other circumstances Mme. Bonacieux would have fled in terror; but	329.4100603789041
she was absorbed by jealousy.	298.6165220244404
“Speak, madame!” resumed Mme. Bonacieux, with an energy of which she	487.84611567700597
might not have been believed capable. “Have you been, or are you, his	376.11004686922047
mistress?”	294.81516871327005
“Oh, no!” cried Milady, with an accent that admitted no doubt of her	312.46020877705223
truth. “Never, never!”	413.09092429843884
“I believe you,” said Mme. Bonacieux; “but why, then, did you cry out	440.07360181339817
so?”	355.1131617483226
“Do you not understand?” said Milady, who had already overcome her	372.85171052692317
agitation and recovered all her presence of mind.	457.03891071766975
“How can I understand? I know nothing.”	315.5510985354339
“Can you not understand that Monsieur d’Artagnan, being my friend,	374.19979483219964
might take me into his confidence?”	320.788301056216
“Truly?”	297.97705813327
“Do you not perceive that I know all—your abduction from the little	317.10239421671054
house at St. Germain, his despair, that of his friends, and their	296.5973692034515
useless inquiries up to this moment? How could I help being astonished	357.2974486391142
when, without having the least expectation of such a thing, I meet you	364.88044186720515
face to face—you, of whom we have so often spoken together, you whom he	402.7292082768307
loves with all his soul, you whom he had taught me to love before I had	462.9122682145501
seen you! Ah, dear Constance, I have found you, then; I see you at	383.48108248129705
last!”	445.25117069506246
And Milady stretched out her arms to Mme. Bonacieux, who, convinced by	427.60810655402815
what she had just said, saw nothing in this woman whom an instant	397.3586568526249
before she had believed her rival but a sincere and devoted friend.	392.19665943003145
“Oh, pardon me, pardon me!” cried she, sinking upon the shoulders of	376.30484465643207
Milady. “Pardon me, I love him so much!”	475.58805842520206
These two women held each other for an instant in a close embrace.	334.3702203150133
Certainly, if Milady’s strength had been equal to her hatred, Mme.	480.90516455005434
Bonacieux would never have left that embrace alive. But not being able	326.3012997581807
to stifle her, she smiled upon her.	401.96347714162545
“Oh, you beautiful, good little creature!” said Milady. “How delighted	489.5922222237085
I am to have found you! Let me look at you!” and while saying these	425.51872603015005
words, she absolutely devoured her by her looks. “Oh, yes it is you	457.57390617607587
indeed! From what he has told me, I know you now. I recognize you	479.0889587812419
perfectly.”	331.85700108962504
The poor young woman could not possibly suspect what frightful cruelty	475.60723125632893
was behind the rampart of that pure brow, behind those brilliant eyes	324.9706755045329
in which she read nothing but interest and compassion.	409.4491865229983
“Then you know what I have suffered,” said Mme. Bonacieux, “since he	445.59007892669507
has told you what he has suffered; but to suffer for him is happiness.”	416.9767522324013
Milady replied mechanically, “Yes, that is happiness.” She was thinking	428.17035163928
of something else.	381.5586564621834
“And then,” continued Mme. Bonacieux, “my punishment is drawing to a	455.6599526079301
close. Tomorrow, this evening, perhaps, I shall see him again; and then	408.7543678561823
the past will no longer exist.”	315.47725218606877
“This evening?” asked Milady, roused from her reverie by these words.	408.82274703063877
“What do you mean? Do you expect news from him?”	322.7223069771802
“I expect himself.”	443.97597779241227
“Himself? D’Artagnan here?”	377.14435720121577
“Himself!”	477.41667239981007
“But that’s impossible! He is at the siege of La Rochelle with the	452.7468001160914
cardinal. He will not return till after the taking of the city.”	296.1001196203887
“Ah, you fancy so! But is there anything impossible for my D’Artagnan,	374.28065806781274
the noble and loyal gentleman?”	474.460349271283
“Oh, I cannot believe you!”	433.78231348947634
“Well, read, then!” said the unhappy young woman, in the excess of her	367.9095795107168
pride and joy, presenting a letter to Milady.	420.4254904870454
“The writing of Madame de Chevreuse!” said Milady to herself. “Ah, I	348.374804303955
always thought there was some secret understanding in that quarter!”	327.5339006022036
And she greedily read the following few lines:	399.6362143691062
MY DEAR CHILD, Hold yourself ready. _Our friend_ will see you soon, and	307.57674543039764
he will only see you to release you from that imprisonment in which	444.3123715322696
your safety required you should be concealed. Prepare, then, for your	420.2851627784818
departure, and never despair of us.	402.68609128052145
    Our charming Gascon has just proved himself as brave and faithful	299.3900527518277
    as ever. Tell him that certain parties are grateful for the warning	346.3806896109538
    he has given.	395.10929330685286
“Yes, yes,” said Milady; “the letter is precise. Do you know what that	442.2566259027561
warning was?”	362.3825191768521
“No, I only suspect he has warned the queen against some fresh	484.92259233706267
machinations of the cardinal.”	360.21292761788067
“Yes, that’s it, no doubt!” said Milady, returning the letter to Mme.	486.3458719734493
Bonacieux, and letting her head sink pensively upon her bosom.	343.93389678762867
At that moment they heard the gallop of a horse.	487.4763376550481
“Oh!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, darting to the window, “can it be he?”	326.7944548009097
Milady remained still in bed, petrified by surprise; so many unexpected	416.5228136270337
things happened to her all at once that for the first time she was at a	355.77070680159164
loss.	428.9870657882457
“He, he!” murmured she; “can it be he?” And she remained in bed with	314.7795554168626
her eyes fixed.	296.55428242588386
“Alas, no!” said Mme. Bonacieux; “it is a man I don’t know, although he	471.05499705214936
seems to be coming here. Yes, he checks his pace; he stops at the gate;	480.87338562340943
he rings.”	384.9417309814056
Milady sprang out of bed.	319.1283461985577
“You are sure it is not he?” said she.	407.8685600632291
“Yes, yes, very sure!”	333.4035714944253
“Perhaps you did not see well.”	339.1002999531406
“Oh, if I were to see the plume of his hat, the end of his cloak, I	304.93204414706764
should know _him!_”	469.1469909011569
Milady was dressing herself all the time.	414.2673473627116
“Yes, he has entered.”	475.68039480692
“It is for you or me!”	486.86867848486656
“My God, how agitated you seem!”	451.04984409564497
“Yes, I admit it. I have not your confidence; I fear the cardinal.”	467.6847990578722
“Hush!” said Mme. Bonacieux; “somebody is coming.”	349.1033559699258
Immediately the door opened, and the superior entered.	460.894178628371
“Did you come from Boulogne?” demanded she of Milady.	473.0769251266557
“Yes,” replied she, trying to recover her self-possession. “Who wants	354.5378625730176
me?”	310.487696294226
“A man who will not tell his name, but who comes from the cardinal.”	325.3442233983483
“And who wishes to speak with me?”	378.7092993367012
“Who wishes to speak to a lady recently come from Boulogne.”	408.22820205484106
“Then let him come in, if you please.”	293.15500610319145
“Oh, my God, my God!” cried Mme. Bonacieux. “Can it be bad news?”	313.48861699493676
“I fear it.”	359.3115334917007
“I will leave you with this stranger; but as soon as he is gone, if you	321.69232190130805
will permit me, I will return.”	428.0525966032659
“_Permit_ you? I _beseech_ you.”	489.20017855438005
The superior and Mme. Bonacieux retired.	349.1671502868236
Milady remained alone, with her eyes fixed upon the door. An instant	306.04962734435986
later, the jingling of spurs was heard upon the stairs, steps drew	393.9895166541637
near, the door opened, and a man appeared.	358.6901901088345
Milady uttered a cry of joy; this man was the Comte de Rochefort—the	311.14937198577735
demoniacal tool of his Eminence.	405.5940212066462
Chapter LXII.	352.2059288838182
TWO VARIETIES OF DEMONS	468.51362334607626
Ah,” cried Milady and Rochefort together, “it is you!”	362.2569338901216
“Yes, it is I.”	377.16797778836326
“And you come?” asked Milady.	304.649751651703
“From La Rochelle; and you?”	351.22728004043154
“From England.”	404.8569646056237
“Buckingham?”	324.987172905119
“Dead or desperately wounded, as I left without having been able to	386.19711674527593
hear anything of him. A fanatic has just assassinated him.”	386.24679538941615
“Ah,” said Rochefort, with a smile; “this is a fortunate chance—one	358.97625077237024
that will delight his Eminence! Have you informed him of it?”	302.1997622746173
“I wrote to him from Boulogne. But what brings you here?”	358.7332834499148
“His Eminence was uneasy, and sent me to find you.”	298.36886196094014
“I only arrived yesterday.”	340.3340326041788
“And what have you been doing since yesterday?”	393.80898694572403
“I have not lost my time.”	436.4386796256116
“Oh, I don’t doubt that.”	335.10441771930044
“Do you know whom I have encountered here?”	393.1574703033598
“No.”	488.52548785589795
“Guess.”	391.3436518959993
“How can I?”	425.7179924392361
“That young woman whom the queen took out of prison.”	444.5184404126645
“The mistress of that fellow D’Artagnan?”	394.7398663370477
“Yes; Madame Bonacieux, with whose retreat the cardinal was	429.9245823743373
unacquainted.”	408.33657680604244
“Well, well,” said Rochefort, “here is a chance which may pair off with	295.02389802915803
the other! Monsieur Cardinal is indeed a privileged man!”	302.19220540668897
“Imagine my astonishment,” continued Milady, “when I found myself face	468.770978532985
to face with this woman!”	384.5431437674191
“Does she know you?”	292.09934358491984
“No.”	431.7433940337283
“Then she looks upon you as a stranger?”	473.74744858999543
Milady smiled. “I am her best friend.”	403.1598692778314
“Upon my honor,” said Rochefort, “it takes you, my dear countess, to	464.37265018842663
perform such miracles!”	381.60449306177543
“And it is well I can, Chevalier,” said Milady, “for do you know what	433.839314653519
is going on here?”	479.7727294704357
“No.”	381.29451736765054
“They will come for her tomorrow or the day after, with an order from	350.31450207587176
the queen.”	317.9885679813429
“Indeed! And who?”	454.3638128344113
“D’Artagnan and his friends.”	381.5520075862488
“Indeed, they will go so far that we shall be obliged to send them to	425.8717792356042
the Bastille.”	345.33802521899463
“Why is it not done already?”	429.9495960826123
“What would you? The cardinal has a weakness for these men which I	319.88432782618713
cannot comprehend.”	357.3475076223648
“Indeed!”	400.8950955712867
“Yes.”	490.2236650490278
“Well, then, tell him this, Rochefort. Tell him that our conversation	443.9283655382073
at the inn of the Red Dovecot was overheard by these four men; tell him	354.8622863299656
that after his departure one of them came up to me and took from me by	339.64718111497837
violence the safe-conduct which he had given me; tell him they warned	478.7797779762138
Lord de Winter of my journey to England; that this time they nearly	350.05033378876226
foiled my mission as they foiled the affair of the studs; tell him that	309.86699757749045
among these four men two only are to be feared—D’Artagnan and Athos;	407.16939025947306
tell him that the third, Aramis, is the lover of Madame de Chevreuse—he	295.1137616743399
may be left alone, we know his secret, and it may be useful; as to the	322.5676733897839
fourth, Porthos, he is a fool, a simpleton, a blustering booby, not	467.3134490986938
worth troubling himself about.”	451.4609507683802
“But these four men must be now at the siege of La Rochelle?”	313.2179954883311
“I thought so, too; but a letter which Madame Bonacieux has received	296.1327134793128
from Madame the Constable, and which she has had the imprudence to show	371.56019855519224
me, leads me to believe that these four men, on the contrary, are on	417.4718413505847
the road hither to take her away.”	435.41472754471044
“The devil! What’s to be done?”	357.84986193704583
“What did the cardinal say about me?”	406.9621278657632
“I was to take your dispatches, written or verbal, and return by post;	295.8758044058488
and when he shall know what you have done, he will advise what you have	295.0927847489198
to do.”	311.5464016021904
“I must, then, remain here?”	447.80718630833985
“Here, or in the neighborhood.”	372.4723893424177
“You cannot take me with you?”	480.363562711608
“No, the order is imperative. Near the camp you might be recognized;	361.74499686637114
and your presence, you must be aware, would compromise the cardinal.”	426.9408732482897
“Then I must wait here, or in the neighborhood?”	483.93726265872743
“Only tell me beforehand where you will wait for intelligence from the	412.0156036974529
cardinal; let me know always where to find you.”	432.0567967219806
“Observe, it is probable that I may not be able to remain here.”	364.65922221639033
“Why?”	314.0174509340744
“You forget that my enemies may arrive at any minute.”	300.6476970051323
“That’s true; but is this little woman, then, to escape his Eminence?”	355.6281989261671
“Bah!” said Milady, with a smile that belonged only to herself; “you	334.432707141534
forget that I am her best friend.”	372.5836531110756
“Ah, that’s true! I may then tell the cardinal, with respect to this	363.0231746811005
little woman—”	461.0644093429967
“That he may be at ease.”	300.73997210156693
“Is that all?”	468.33425516830744
“He will know what that means.”	404.96824911668557
“He will guess, at least. Now, then, what had I better do?”	377.5172942597205
“Return instantly. It appears to me that the news you bear is worth the	459.3640118234522
trouble of a little diligence.”	329.0976148993592
“My chaise broke down coming into Lilliers.”	341.1186573092589
“Capital!”	356.9687322664688
“What, _capital?_”	302.14451534387433
“Yes, I want your chaise.”	469.13384207543515
“And how shall I travel, then?”	405.35239170898916
“On horseback.”	327.78633041891163
“You talk very comfortably,—a hundred and eighty leagues!”	470.21227573574595
“What’s that?”	463.3029407921364
“One can do it! Afterward?”	434.62461916755564
“Afterward? Why, in passing through Lilliers you will send me your	449.9519919329493
chaise, with an order to your servant to place himself at my disposal.”	347.199539299748
“Well.”	449.90354898375557
“You have, no doubt, some order from the cardinal about you?”	326.6743122439787
“I have my _full power_.”	378.49909857507043
“Show it to the abbess, and tell her that someone will come and fetch	394.4852137483841
me, either today or tomorrow, and that I am to follow the person who	484.7200166505295
presents himself in your name.”	343.82073245090356
“Very well.”	395.94566957532885
“Don’t forget to treat me harshly in speaking of me to the abbess.”	419.84671977626215
“To what purpose?”	491.6246812576561
“I am a victim of the cardinal. It is necessary to inspire confidence	310.6198442109376
in that poor little Madame Bonacieux.”	452.8611644796197
“That’s true. Now, will you make me a report of all that has happened?”	383.67855119731803
“Why, I have related the events to you. You have a good memory; repeat	302.27569053377493
what I have told you. A paper may be lost.”	292.54872180567935
“You are right; only let me know where to find you that I may not run	466.59958420474015
needlessly about the neighborhood.”	427.81251848914985
“That’s correct; wait!”	489.7895631296189
“Do you want a map?”	362.57320439407727
“Oh, I know this country marvelously!”	351.273056741458
“You? When were you here?”	359.7229884010061
“I was brought up here.”	478.91144888666133
“Truly?”	436.41178662956423
“It is worth something, you see, to have been brought up somewhere.”	401.30874383694714
“You will wait for me, then?”	473.2719961822273
“Let me reflect a little! Ay, that will do—at Armentières.”	474.4483405722765
“Where is that Armentières?”	426.09794162232697
“A little town on the Lys; I shall only have to cross the river, and I	399.30585219863497
shall be in a foreign country.”	403.3845882592575
“Capital! but it is understood you will only cross the river in case of	380.48502550381954
danger.”	328.17200939793713
“That is well understood.”	346.1797124664171
“And in that case, how shall I know where you are?”	486.0020636093906
“You do not want your lackey?”	381.872775186595
“Is he a sure man?”	380.3619837541126
“To the proof.”	485.07201292816484
“Give him to me. Nobody knows him. I will leave him at the place I	297.2509286007838
quit, and he will conduct you to me.”	336.88226137638895
“And you say you will wait for me at Armentières?”	373.595079687335
“At Armentières.”	332.40465993398396
“Write that name on a bit of paper, lest I should forget it. There is	356.05472750542083
nothing compromising in the name of a town. Is it not so?”	476.54954376181706
“Eh, who knows? Never mind,” said Milady, writing the name on half a	452.13327203422125
sheet of paper; “I will compromise myself.”	446.66684127257406
“Well,” said Rochefort, taking the paper from Milady, folding it, and	452.5975981608191
placing it in the lining of his hat, “you may be easy. I will do as	415.6958834055112
children do, for fear of losing the paper—repeat the name along the	463.1267140721992
route. Now, is that all?”	400.4984471580151
“I believe so.”	431.22511962830805
“Let us see: Buckingham dead or grievously wounded; your conversation	433.2697535379468
with the cardinal overheard by the four Musketeers; Lord de Winter	414.6442606667649
warned of your arrival at Portsmouth; D’Artagnan and Athos to the	301.7929198523688
Bastille; Aramis the lover of Madame de Chevreuse; Porthos an ass;	319.65821778469564
Madame Bonacieux found again; to send you the chaise as soon as	302.61963083767847
possible; to place my lackey at your disposal; to make you out a victim	340.6802060064585
of the cardinal in order that the abbess may entertain no suspicion;	310.58299014975233
Armentières, on the banks of the Lys. Is that all, then?”	422.3874523981817
“In truth, my dear Chevalier, you are a miracle of memory. _A propos_,	294.6540971000833
add one thing—”	308.3135544320633
“What?”	341.41780124911315
“I saw some very pretty woods which almost touch the convent garden.	470.6637558609957
Say that I am permitted to walk in those woods. Who knows? Perhaps I	360.7154855911394
shall stand in need of a back door for retreat.”	316.7299798109356
“You think of everything.”	294.82570943585694
“And you forget one thing.”	308.71468746201975
“What?”	378.2177598326112
“To ask me if I want money.”	441.13448223185776
“That’s true. How much do you want?”	391.9990428003265
“All you have in gold.”	490.8599519515265
“I have five hundred pistoles, or thereabouts.”	476.24818068411645
“I have as much. With a thousand pistoles one may face everything.	434.59735596752313
Empty your pockets.”	358.7806556869927
“There.”	358.1142389420979
“Right. And you go—”	423.71582797760766
“In an hour—time to eat a morsel, during which I shall send for a post	410.72677334597427
horse.”	467.5831444125715
“Capital! Adieu, Chevalier.”	404.6101838546489
“Adieu, Countess.”	479.97923652958826
“Commend me to the cardinal.”	443.4137351195053
“Commend me to Satan.”	478.3495489180569
Milady and Rochefort exchanged a smile and separated. An hour afterward	329.4344500845616
Rochefort set out at a grand gallop; five hours after that he passed	361.6010339977655
through Arras.	468.58431789612183
Our readers already know how he was recognized by D’Artagnan, and how	344.0869914227381
that recognition by inspiring fear in the four Musketeers had given	489.595109874404
fresh activity to their journey.	391.80743357777794
Chapter LXIII.	314.9001757925308
THE DROP OF WATER	422.82346094503487
Rochefort had scarcely departed when Mme. Bonacieux re-entered. She	448.00705524252794
found Milady with a smiling countenance.	348.1035013377408
“Well,” said the young woman, “what you dreaded has happened. This	444.40362960392906
evening, or tomorrow, the cardinal will send someone to take you away.”	363.89364901145314
“Who told you that, my dear?” asked Milady.	378.9891810958752
“I heard it from the mouth of the messenger himself.”	395.9992557906391
“Come and sit down close to me,” said Milady.	354.9934693686665
“Here I am.”	301.159582130715
“Wait till I assure myself that nobody hears us.”	409.1300877558575
“Why all these precautions?”	374.04320242294176
“You shall know.”	464.626632068376
Milady arose, went to the door, opened it, looked in the corridor, and	360.3463774663452
then returned and seated herself close to Mme. Bonacieux.	411.02140115283555
“Then,” said she, “he has well played his part.”	391.2360775092609
“Who has?”	328.81081962703746
“He who just now presented himself to the abbess as a messenger from	307.1649156378029
the cardinal.”	460.03445324374707
“It was, then, a part he was playing?”	298.12519858674045
“Yes, my child.”	343.5147684294637
“That man, then, was not—”	410.9677973621898
“That man,” said Milady, lowering her voice, “is my brother.”	463.8357688046913
“Your brother!” cried Mme. Bonacieux.	385.84621455978083
“No one must know this secret, my dear, but yourself. If you reveal it	342.52340584840357
to anyone in the world, I shall be lost, and perhaps yourself	371.83113083253374
likewise.”	397.5177635180548
“Oh, my God!”	296.05051376216016
“Listen. This is what has happened: My brother, who was coming to my	340.0750562157423
assistance to take me away by force if it were necessary, met with the	415.3173968880831
emissary of the cardinal, who was coming in search of me. He followed	489.41913535041795
him. At a solitary and retired part of the road he drew his sword, and	471.8340888908018
required the messenger to deliver up to him the papers of which he was	347.85781456970824
the bearer. The messenger resisted; my brother killed him.”	414.86016814108535
“Oh!” said Mme. Bonacieux, shuddering.	321.7091751369385
“Remember, that was the only means. Then my brother determined to	357.7948748947655
substitute cunning for force. He took the papers, and presented himself	348.86444377118596
here as the emissary of the cardinal, and in an hour or two a carriage	345.57877479291454
will come to take me away by the orders of his Eminence.”	370.8106163450969
“I understand. It is your brother who sends this carriage.”	345.63739897672167
“Exactly; but that is not all. That letter you have received, and which	295.89265312310107
you believe to be from Madame de Chevreuse—”	409.3343041309753
“Well?”	317.0430214740091
“It is a forgery.”	474.3304562975588
“How can that be?”	453.419047805764
“Yes, a forgery; it is a snare to prevent your making any resistance	407.0078912168443
when they come to fetch you.”	444.61254967708123
“But it is D’Artagnan that will come.”	405.7252287725319
“Do not deceive yourself. D’Artagnan and his friends are detained at	402.620494013374
the siege of La Rochelle.”	446.9535323019552
“How do you know that?”	314.29437835724394
“My brother met some emissaries of the cardinal in the uniform of	377.17353172897595
Musketeers. You would have been summoned to the gate; you would have	479.8767133138893
believed yourself about to meet friends; you would have been abducted,	447.5002427361999
and conducted back to Paris.”	447.13011038545784
“Oh, my God! My senses fail me amid such a chaos of iniquities. I feel,	474.64823288594846
if this continues,” said Mme. Bonacieux, raising her hands to her	356.7734779639146
forehead, “I shall go mad!”	365.5213093784357
“Stop—”	432.634721591259
“What?”	407.9443731583438
“I hear a horse’s steps; it is my brother setting off again. I should	403.167771865233
like to offer him a last salute. Come!”	432.42451185353735
Milady opened the window, and made a sign to Mme. Bonacieux to join	488.46307285304647
her. The young woman complied.	425.27161243321905
Rochefort passed at a gallop.	387.761484904225
“Adieu, brother!” cried Milady.	339.20290078749304
The chevalier raised his head, saw the two young women, and without	459.4863824176542
stopping, waved his hand in a friendly way to Milady.	354.5968790867458
“The good George!” said she, closing the window with an expression of	348.15771805598837
countenance full of affection and melancholy. And she resumed her seat,	413.47738585754644
as if plunged in reflections entirely personal.	430.59447867409386
“Dear lady,” said Mme. Bonacieux, “pardon me for interrupting you; but	293.16021685960214
what do you advise me to do? Good heaven! You have more experience than	424.47654675329454
I have. Speak; I will listen.”	381.1538126914787
“In the first place,” said Milady, “it is possible I may be deceived,	433.79485689967964
and that D’Artagnan and his friends may really come to your	325.35585166949056
assistance.”	313.0055319237554
“Oh, that would be too much!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, “so much happiness	295.06409272493823
is not in store for me!”	326.7512065276976
“Then you comprehend it would be only a question of time, a sort of	380.8088684288458
race, which should arrive first. If your friends are the more speedy,	449.4914317852589
you are to be saved; if the satellites of the cardinal, you are lost.”	486.5716606755017
“Oh, yes, yes; lost beyond redemption! What, then, to do? What to do?”	460.31511785449857
“There would be a very simple means, very natural—”	315.8162031885197
“Tell me what!”	431.43567508857217
“To wait, concealed in the neighborhood, and assure yourself who are	359.05419086436814
the men who come to ask for you.”	363.249989336708
“But where can I wait?”	445.6059131288723
“Oh, there is no difficulty in that. I shall stop and conceal myself a	322.341789589943
few leagues hence until my brother can rejoin me. Well, I take you with	448.27184801937966
me; we conceal ourselves, and wait together.”	332.9607574373373
“But I shall not be allowed to go; I am almost a prisoner.”	312.15462464149647
“As they believe that I go in consequence of an order from the	305.9070426711851
cardinal, no one will believe you anxious to follow me.”	481.3493104814547
“Well?”	394.67263345043375
“Well! The carriage is at the door; you bid me adieu; you mount the	429.73145413525776
step to embrace me a last time; my brother’s servant, who comes to	335.90608271486667
fetch me, is told how to proceed; he makes a sign to the postillion,	385.6440767962401
and we set off at a gallop.”	337.0584487935037
“But D’Artagnan! D’Artagnan! if he comes?”	381.24009510568015
“Shall we not know it?”	421.44540977770475
“How?”	298.17394927732795
“Nothing easier. We will send my brother’s servant back to Béthune,	420.9002851799733
whom, as I told you, we can trust. He shall assume a disguise, and	461.9290615522467
place himself in front of the convent. If the emissaries of the	448.36917598350095
cardinal arrive, he will take no notice; if it is Monsieur d’Artagnan	488.4450449641295
and his friends, he will bring them to us.”	408.3526321363527
“He knows them, then?”	301.599415746182
“Doubtless. Has he not seen Monsieur d’Artagnan at my house?”	384.8846963256861
“Oh, yes, yes; you are right. Thus all may go well—all may be for the	353.2483056932769
best; but we do not go far from this place?”	428.08025631062935
“Seven or eight leagues at the most. We will keep on the frontiers, for	430.67388188070896
instance; and at the first alarm we can leave France.”	414.7819793069608
“And what can we do there?”	434.6543791404522
“Wait.”	472.3198730950928
“But if they come?”	355.29780477717856
“My brother’s carriage will be here first.”	401.3210908199481
“If I should happen to be any distance from you when the carriage comes	408.7647421554957
for you—at dinner or supper, for instance?”	313.2258868381
“Do one thing.”	403.9886367382693
“What is that?”	336.0300898895036
“Tell your good superior that in order that we may be as much together	419.91207164295554
as possible, you ask her permission to share my repast.”	294.15524433382325
“Will she permit it?”	457.99594402693185
“What inconvenience can it be?”	457.7668496374255
“Oh, delightful! In this way we shall not be separated for an instant.”	364.91407186563384
“Well, go down to her, then, to make your request. I feel my head a	448.65545635231126
little confused; I will take a turn in the garden.”	394.06471864639883
“Go; and where shall I find you?”	478.78710197129425
“Here, in an hour.”	468.01262882989477
“Here, in an hour. Oh, you are so kind, and I am so grateful!”	380.63867042949886
“How can I avoid interesting myself for one who is so beautiful and so	302.25299171722554
amiable? Are you not the beloved of one of my best friends?”	333.09725422284777
“Dear D’Artagnan! Oh, how he will thank you!”	373.72298748490743
“I hope so. Now, then, all is agreed; let us go down.”	413.97344569627126
“You are going into the garden?”	417.61845649457865
“Yes.”	364.44049988971216
“Go along this corridor, down a little staircase, and you are in it.”	376.9240314444363
“Excellent; thank you!”	310.867750877963
And the two women parted, exchanging charming smiles.	301.0952918997259
Milady had told the truth—her head was confused, for her ill-arranged	414.2900434483494
plans clashed one another like chaos. She required to be alone that she	423.5611338817108
might put her thoughts a little into order. She saw vaguely the future;	473.1759222865033
but she stood in need of a little silence and quiet to give all her	312.96950083484387
ideas, as yet confused, a distinct form and a regular plan.	339.54452124378776
What was most pressing was to get Mme. Bonacieux away, and convey her	374.0277674960011
to a place of safety, and there, if matters required, make her a	305.26578235015006
hostage. Milady began to have doubts of the issue of this terrible	387.4983632325292
duel, in which her enemies showed as much perseverance as she did	372.3014958971302
animosity.	338.75677931326743
Besides, she felt as we feel when a storm is coming on—that this issue	330.7989411337149
was near, and could not fail to be terrible.	402.30158667062807
The principal thing for her, then, was, as we have said, to keep Mme.	364.37115435671086
Bonacieux in her power. Mme. Bonacieux was the very life of D’Artagnan.	341.4359364369892
This was more than his life, the life of the woman he loved; this was,	299.0692953345082
in case of ill fortune, a means of temporizing and obtaining good	322.4358993823946
conditions.	418.5636472807612
Now, this point was settled; Mme. Bonacieux, without any suspicion,	350.96017576102406
accompanied her. Once concealed with her at Armentières, it would be	345.082627008699
easy to make her believe that D’Artagnan had not come to Béthune. In	359.37232177398477
fifteen days at most, Rochefort would be back; besides, during that	314.94429214580623
fifteen days she would have time to think how she could best avenge	327.26336174548186
herself on the four friends. She would not be weary, thank God! for she	326.83917185284383
should enjoy the sweetest pastime such events could accord a woman of	453.52057433182586
her character—perfecting a beautiful vengeance.	443.36231067927565
Revolving all this in her mind, she cast her eyes around her, and	436.55120374948035
arranged the topography of the garden in her head. Milady was like a	397.2710656177732
good general who contemplates at the same time victory and defeat, and	458.60118303970376
who is quite prepared, according to the chances of the battle, to march	448.34689247255545
forward or to beat a retreat.	467.99079622206295
At the end of an hour she heard a soft voice calling her; it was Mme.	349.18152184733555
Bonacieux’s. The good abbess had naturally consented to her request;	354.63052776738704
and as a commencement, they were to sup together.	373.25972564210423
On reaching the courtyard, they heard the noise of a carriage which	462.07797196085994
stopped at the gate.	487.4808008234096
Milady listened.	302.6756019792141
“Do you hear anything?” said she.	441.83224691546957
“Yes, the rolling of a carriage.”	360.38127922785236
“It is the one my brother sends for us.”	308.58481816778
“Oh, my God!”	395.36844527304044
“Come, come! courage!”	422.3488707910849
The bell of the convent gate was sounded; Milady was not mistaken.	394.1654797482217
“Go to your chamber,” said she to Mme. Bonacieux; “you have perhaps	446.63663955383765
some jewels you would like to take.”	409.1746106364521
“I have his letters,” said she.	480.9958088463825
“Well, go and fetch them, and come to my apartment. We will snatch some	375.21816412471856
supper; we shall perhaps travel part of the night, and must keep our	471.62476280571263
strength up.”	320.00656333892044
“Great God!” said Mme. Bonacieux, placing her hand upon her bosom, “my	316.11637100220486
heart beats so I cannot walk.”	309.6087638129347
“Courage, courage! remember that in a quarter of an hour you will be	466.4052193202941
safe; and think that what you are about to do is for _his_ sake.”	365.36186535118014
“Yes, yes, everything for him. You have restored my courage by a single	358.165013521484
word; go, I will rejoin you.”	366.27340275555343
Milady ran up to her apartment quickly; she there found Rochefort’s	471.5135057210556
lackey, and gave him his instructions.	467.1507246324527
He was to wait at the gate; if by chance the Musketeers should appear,	358.4118656747352
the carriage was to set off as fast as possible, pass around the	375.80761474155446
convent, and go and wait for Milady at a little village which was	392.33028813013556
situated at the other side of the wood. In this case Milady would cross	359.352440144159
the garden and gain the village on foot. As we have already said,	379.2644636318717
Milady was admirably acquainted with this part of France.	491.3183794022059
If the Musketeers did not appear, things were to go on as had been	390.3200053003595
agreed; Mme. Bonacieux was to get into the carriage as if to bid her	440.99182291550284
adieu, and she was to take away Mme. Bonacieux.	465.10844793265875
Mme. Bonacieux came in; and to remove all suspicion, if she had any,	372.7340865127352
Milady repeated to the lackey, before her, the latter part of her	437.42542295809193
instructions.	323.84224934905075
Milady asked some questions about the carriage. It was a chaise drawn	360.38251673777313
by three horses, driven by a postillion; Rochefort’s lackey would	358.3342657994755
precede it, as courier.	335.5475842712156
Milady was wrong in fearing that Mme. Bonacieux would have any	484.17143719608714
suspicion. The poor young woman was too pure to suppose that any female	343.07584634469254
could be guilty of such perfidy; besides, the name of the Comtesse de	412.8674010258602
Winter, which she had heard the abbess pronounce, was wholly unknown to	350.778445937676
her, and she was even ignorant that a woman had had so great and so	417.996469855281
fatal a share in the misfortune of her life.	438.3553111826335
“You see,” said she, when the lackey had gone out, “everything is	472.63188414462024
ready. The abbess suspects nothing, and believes that I am taken by	364.0045627356328
order of the cardinal. This man goes to give his last orders; take the	301.69298934963734
least thing, drink a finger of wine, and let us be gone.”	412.30220985391065
“Yes,” said Mme. Bonacieux, mechanically, “yes, let us be gone.”	439.6676978915537
Milady made her a sign to sit down opposite, poured her a small glass	411.85489077509646
of Spanish wine, and helped her to the wing of a chicken.	474.5910609303055
“See,” said she, “if everything does not second us! Here is night	364.0561816160203
coming on; by daybreak we shall have reached our retreat, and nobody	414.08073362324717
can guess where we are. Come, courage! take something.”	442.6402923311345
Mme. Bonacieux ate a few mouthfuls mechanically, and just touched the	327.2590926133514
glass with her lips.	432.1370351678246
“Come, come!” said Milady, lifting hers to her mouth, “do as I do.”	424.6243342176535
But at the moment the glass touched her lips, her hand remained	311.10838765445396
suspended; she heard something on the road which sounded like the	415.5484283011408
rattling of a distant gallop. Then it grew nearer, and it seemed to	451.449153262934
her, almost at the same time, that she heard the neighing of horses.	450.21230956807244
This noise acted upon her joy like the storm which awakens the sleeper	436.90801681341475
in the midst of a happy dream; she grew pale and ran to the window,	325.3556134282518
while Mme. Bonacieux, rising all in a tremble, supported herself upon	318.00894689732525
her chair to avoid falling. Nothing was yet to be seen, only they heard	413.127804856759
the galloping draw nearer.	346.88951527832023
“Oh, my God!” said Mme. Bonacieux, “what is that noise?”	418.45343112222093
“That of either our friends or our enemies,” said Milady, with her	343.4327757722801
terrible coolness. “Stay where you are, I will tell you.”	343.0605971506446
Mme. Bonacieux remained standing, mute, motionless, and pale as a	402.64517896561335
statue.	443.54430429497717
The noise became louder; the horses could not be more than a hundred	470.8199723856452
and fifty paces distant. If they were not yet to be seen, it was	293.49421981266937
because the road made an elbow. The noise became so distinct that the	472.71011604672486
horses might be counted by the rattle of their hoofs.	293.773516636082
Milady gazed with all the power of her attention; it was just light	441.8962309926213
enough for her to see who was coming.	304.02059061273593
All at once, at the turning of the road she saw the glitter of laced	452.399479169125
hats and the waving of feathers; she counted two, then five, then eight	485.85227451526225
horsemen. One of them preceded the rest by double the length of his	486.33201430063014
horse.	302.01373183683097
Milady uttered a stifled groan. In the first horseman she recognized	347.3204922316529
D’Artagnan.	327.7269644695012
“Oh, my God, my God,” cried Mme. Bonacieux, “what is it?”	469.4010620281283
“It is the uniform of the cardinal’s Guards. Not an instant to be lost!	343.44762292288766
Fly, fly!”	378.9589882656968
“Yes, yes, let us fly!” repeated Mme. Bonacieux, but without being able	344.6071131940175
to make a step, glued as she was to the spot by terror.	454.87651483091105
They heard the horsemen pass under the windows.	398.2236114049114
“Come, then, come, then!” cried Milady, trying to drag the young woman	401.33013349440654
along by the arm. “Thanks to the garden, we yet can flee; I have the	485.68929269452394
key, but make haste! in five minutes it will be too late!”	476.912215593825
Mme. Bonacieux tried to walk, made two steps, and sank upon her knees.	377.47938273392305
Milady tried to raise and carry her, but could not do it.	459.58071270389087
At this moment they heard the rolling of the carriage, which at the	325.0733768505737
approach of the Musketeers set off at a gallop. Then three or four	354.06670867549485
shots were fired.	316.76558427644295
“For the last time, will you come?” cried Milady.	475.509963352054
“Oh, my God, my God! you see my strength fails me; you see plainly I	442.92862142903687
cannot walk. Flee alone!”	388.76868821567257
“Flee alone, and leave you here? No, no, never!” cried Milady.	383.4332363964252
All at once she paused, a livid flash darted from her eyes; she ran to	480.3327109404146
the table, emptied into Mme. Bonacieux’s glass the contents of a ring	363.75423104025367
which she opened with singular quickness. It was a grain of a reddish	408.86713096090807
color, which dissolved immediately.	414.76390372391495
Then, taking the glass with a firm hand, she said, “Drink. This wine	488.9240701130791
will give you strength, drink!” And she put the glass to the lips of	385.2464688258758
the young woman, who drank mechanically.	357.2493680346688
“This is not the way that I wished to avenge myself,” said Milady,	482.82838879715933
replacing the glass upon the table, with an infernal smile, “but, my	333.13600757702386
faith! we do what we can!” And she rushed out of the room.	350.67842249103194
Mme. Bonacieux saw her go without being able to follow her; she was	478.38287203426546
like people who dream they are pursued, and who in vain try to walk.	473.93015201799824
A few moments passed; a great noise was heard at the gate. Every	427.565974570388
instant Mme. Bonacieux expected to see Milady, but she did not return.	327.67332239549313
Several times, with terror, no doubt, the cold sweat burst from her	474.0181977383395
burning brow.	478.4587337157306
At length she heard the grating of the hinges of the opening gates; the	392.37815991004237
noise of boots and spurs resounded on the stairs. There was a great	318.04964242470186
murmur of voices which continued to draw near, amid which she seemed to	311.45209923730505
hear her own name pronounced.	431.3388733634466
All at once she uttered a loud cry of joy, and darted toward the door;	357.4893612066615
she had recognized the voice of D’Artagnan.	382.67682040079785
“D’Artagnan! D’Artagnan!” cried she, “is it you? This way! this way!”	453.96684367113085
“Constance? Constance?” replied the young man, “where are you? where	449.3435331167118
are you? My God!”	338.9303462115825
At the same moment the door of the cell yielded to a shock, rather than	407.46710189473526
opened; several men rushed into the chamber. Mme. Bonacieux had sunk	477.0010065914366
into an armchair, without the power of moving.	332.7092794323171
D’Artagnan threw down a yet-smoking pistol which he held in his hand,	429.1753324610353
and fell on his knees before his mistress. Athos replaced his in his	450.4867140816352
belt; Porthos and Aramis, who held their drawn swords in their hands,	467.31450771840093
returned them to their scabbards.	298.6840115879209
“Oh, D’Artagnan, my beloved D’Artagnan! You have come, then, at last!	357.2158136107155
You have not deceived me! It is indeed thee!”	414.46789223831
“Yes, yes, Constance. Reunited!”	365.2315092684055
“Oh, it was in vain she told me you would not come! I hoped in silence.	360.2241479738434
I was not willing to fly. Oh, I have done well! How happy I am!”	294.58023639616727
At this word _she_, Athos, who had seated himself quietly, started up.	307.248433221631
“_She!_ What she?” asked D’Artagnan.	439.4367686066231
“Why, my companion. She who out of friendship for me wished to take me	359.8079231589343
from my persecutors. She who, mistaking you for the cardinal’s Guards,	358.8771100214801
has just fled away.”	436.83872028813516
“Your companion!” cried D’Artagnan, becoming more pale than the white	488.3686823939957
veil of his mistress. “Of what companion are you speaking, dear	429.203138566846
Constance?”	476.82845701485485
“Of her whose carriage was at the gate; of a woman who calls herself	364.5405693219568
your friend; of a woman to whom you have told everything.”	331.0930052932385
“Her name, her name!” cried D’Artagnan. “My God, can you not remember	337.9042584966011
her name?”	463.6454574633484
“Yes, it was pronounced in my hearing once. Stop—but—it is very	361.80819269139266
strange—oh, my God, my head swims! I cannot see!”	457.895760512657
“Help, help, my friends! her hands are icy cold,” cried D’Artagnan.	386.5942579337756
“She is ill! Great God, she is losing her senses!”	377.4961337936219
While Porthos was calling for help with all the power of his strong	362.4935435561216
voice, Aramis ran to the table to get a glass of water; but he stopped	470.0373800712458
at seeing the horrible alteration that had taken place in the	378.0433271981884
countenance of Athos, who, standing before the table, his hair rising	357.360689783834
from his head, his eyes fixed in stupor, was looking at one of the	409.6027831311601
glasses, and appeared a prey to the most horrible doubt.	388.1673318779344
“Oh!” said Athos, “oh, no, it is impossible! God would not permit such	439.8740675519414
a crime!”	408.7768796963709
“Water, water!” cried D’Artagnan. “Water!”	298.1800227389771
“Oh, poor woman, poor woman!” murmured Athos, in a broken voice.	459.67016167860646
Mme. Bonacieux opened her eyes under the kisses of D’Artagnan.	451.2121334830056
“She revives!” cried the young man. “Oh, my God, my God, I thank thee!”	369.2497183505743
“Madame!” said Athos, “madame, in the name of heaven, whose empty glass	402.24893894246236
is this?”	457.6782511707921
“Mine, monsieur,” said the young woman, in a dying voice.	380.05489219185284
“But who poured the wine for you that was in this glass?”	450.744745370241
“She.”	408.8824671665093
“But who is _she?_”	351.72022419019095
“Oh, I remember!” said Mme. Bonacieux, “the Comtesse de Winter.”	341.89551650624827
The four friends uttered one and the same cry, but that of Athos	428.3292555727723
dominated all the rest.	320.30059721348795
At that moment the countenance of Mme. Bonacieux became livid; a	357.945918548608
fearful agony pervaded her frame, and she sank panting into the arms of	398.82573035235043
Porthos and Aramis.	355.3025026001157
D’Artagnan seized the hands of Athos with an anguish difficult to be	314.97456323472267
described.	437.8787131142792
“And what do you believe?” His voice was stifled by sobs.	433.04925162940987
“I believe everything,” said Athos, biting his lips till the blood	462.5408331428498
sprang to avoid sighing.	380.0670303371317
“D’Artagnan, D’Artagnan!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, “where art thou? Do not	419.047654373027
leave me! You see I am dying!”	408.0921717854192
D’Artagnan released the hands of Athos which he still held clasped in	411.13327336829764
both his own, and hastened to her. Her beautiful face was distorted	377.8763866606495
with agony; her glassy eyes had no longer their sight; a convulsive	294.7976921777535
shuddering shook her whole body; the sweat rolled from her brow.	391.70644370973366
“In the name of heaven, run, call! Aramis! Porthos! Call for help!”	362.2996140920775
“Useless!” said Athos, “useless! For the poison which _she_ pours there	397.86460430589455
is no antidote.”	463.64159455700417
“Yes, yes! Help, help!” murmured Mme. Bonacieux; “help!”	369.6102195996209
Then, collecting all her strength, she took the head of the young man	385.55648967276613
between her hands, looked at him for an instant as if her whole soul	337.92731197411354
passed into that look, and with a sobbing cry pressed her lips to his.	319.261428334194
“Constance, Constance!” cried D’Artagnan.	467.4805556308246
A sigh escaped from the mouth of Mme. Bonacieux, and dwelt for an	344.84394420440026
instant on the lips of D’Artagnan. That sigh was the soul, so chaste	399.3894933616069
and so loving, which reascended to heaven.	433.6789831889483
D’Artagnan pressed nothing but a corpse in his arms. The young man	417.3265298286227
uttered a cry, and fell by the side of his mistress as pale and as icy	460.74194821332117
as herself.	328.529531207436
Porthos wept; Aramis pointed toward heaven; Athos made the sign of the	364.0817602633389
cross.	372.2949081553518
At that moment a man appeared in the doorway, almost as pale as those	430.5983263255423
in the chamber. He looked around him and saw Mme. Bonacieux dead, and	314.0025929250049
D’Artagnan in a swoon. He appeared just at that moment of stupor which	448.3479548238052
follows great catastrophes.	336.9641123751908
“I was not deceived,” said he; “here is Monsieur d’Artagnan; and you	331.4779483832724
are his friends, Messieurs Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.”	379.69645785842863
The persons whose names were thus pronounced looked at the stranger	362.36572089737354
with astonishment. It seemed to all three that they knew him.	397.83871626366033
“Gentlemen,” resumed the newcomer, “you are, as I am, in search of a	453.8190009472894
woman who,” added he, with a terrible smile, “must have passed this	452.5279336884412
way, for I see a corpse.”	468.71391587881556
The three friends remained mute—for although the voice as well as the	435.7923156945103
countenance reminded them of someone they had seen, they could not	436.7070070408316
remember under what circumstances.	474.47651320456225
“Gentlemen,” continued the stranger, “since you do not recognize a man	407.67837184397547
who probably owes his life to you twice, I must name myself. I am Lord	441.9925619750526
de Winter, brother-in-law of that _woman_.”	292.29533602304394
The three friends uttered a cry of surprise.	360.91160077774396
Athos rose, and offering him his hand, “Be welcome, my Lord,” said he,	401.44432082298204
“you are one of us.”	321.9370179324684
“I set out five hours after her from Portsmouth,” said Lord de Winter.	442.711609205543
“I arrived three hours after her at Boulogne. I missed her by twenty	383.06495302520136
minutes at St. Omer. Finally, at Lilliers I lost all trace of her. I	438.1197512435146
was going about at random, inquiring of everybody, when I saw you	411.17568434318196
gallop past. I recognized Monsieur d’Artagnan. I called to you, but you	294.9776716838767
did not answer me; I wished to follow you, but my horse was too much	392.30302402199686
fatigued to go at the same pace with yours. And yet it appears, in	483.0642946340044
spite of all your diligence, you have arrived too late.”	344.9488647776135
“You see!” said Athos, pointing to Mme. Bonacieux dead, and to	312.643892696085
D’Artagnan, whom Porthos and Aramis were trying to recall to life.	411.7396630732397
“Are they both dead?” asked Lord de Winter, sternly.	388.9025319600897
“No,” replied Athos, “fortunately Monsieur d’Artagnan has only	399.7076534101926
fainted.”	487.78252109140954
“Ah, indeed, so much the better!” said Lord de Winter.	479.33150770660603
At that moment D’Artagnan opened his eyes. He tore himself from the	387.90112051238
arms of Porthos and Aramis, and threw himself like a madman on the	430.15966725838166
corpse of his mistress.	425.5166455260277
Athos rose, walked toward his friend with a slow and solemn step,	446.1476948497914
embraced him tenderly, and as he burst into violent sobs, he said to	387.84531608997315
him with his noble and persuasive voice, “Friend, be a man! Women weep	458.42315394434115
for the dead; men avenge them!”	353.5516352352215
“Oh, yes!” cried D’Artagnan, “yes! If it be to avenge her, I am ready	436.1147885429216
to follow you.”	447.72027270634015
Athos profited by this moment of strength which the hope of vengeance	468.80380895578844
restored to his unfortunate friend to make a sign to Porthos and Aramis	473.1444106770085
to go and fetch the superior.	460.6757918097461
The two friends met her in the corridor, greatly troubled and much	462.53619060301844
upset by such strange events; she called some of the nuns, who against	366.05364290153796
all monastic custom found themselves in the presence of five men.	388.3850632041359
“Madame,” said Athos, passing his arm under that of D’Artagnan, “we	293.33939868319493
abandon to your pious care the body of that unfortunate woman. She was	436.83283428519684
an angel on earth before being an angel in heaven. Treat her as one of	401.8225454882038
your sisters. We will return someday to pray over her grave.”	313.8734098797669
D’Artagnan concealed his face in the bosom of Athos, and sobbed aloud.	442.63164082632267
“Weep,” said Athos, “weep, heart full of love, youth, and life! Alas,	419.8225014299283
would I could weep like you!”	322.76004666444925
And he drew away his friend, as affectionate as a father, as consoling	418.6416729346756
as a priest, noble as a man who has suffered much.	316.7321093695483
All five, followed by their lackeys leading their horses, took their	413.92878966922467
way to the town of Béthune, whose outskirts they perceived, and stopped	354.7986689503411
before the first inn they came to.	306.60603478489367
“But,” said D’Artagnan, “shall we not pursue that woman?”	473.81178785120323
“Later,” said Athos. “I have measures to take.”	393.4805753024558
“She will escape us,” replied the young man; “she will escape us, and	339.89276281618993
it will be your fault, Athos.”	334.0490169638409
“I will be accountable for her,” said Athos.	441.80561707871095
D’Artagnan had so much confidence in the word of his friend that he	354.78512463304116
lowered his head, and entered the inn without reply.	308.1635454268127
Porthos and Aramis regarded each other, not understanding this	336.4661382798919
assurance of Athos.	465.1369052520725
Lord de Winter believed he spoke in this manner to soothe the grief of	304.7103674620082
D’Artagnan.	363.994254847568
“Now, gentlemen,” said Athos, when he had ascertained there were five	297.75773760489375
chambers free in the hôtel, “let everyone retire to his own apartment.	438.78941511191806
D’Artagnan needs to be alone, to weep and to sleep. I take charge of	358.09140208165144
everything; be easy.”	329.6050918500051
“It appears, however,” said Lord de Winter, “if there are any measures	361.8131087449796
to take against the countess, it concerns me; she is my sister-in-law.”	318.26725243972453
“And me,” said Athos, “—she is my wife!”	374.346919326919
D’Artagnan smiled—for he understood that Athos was sure of his	446.9177121282972
vengeance when he revealed such a secret. Porthos and Aramis looked at	454.8276547521833
each other, and grew pale. Lord de Winter thought Athos was mad.	333.04140702208707
“Now, retire to your chambers,” said Athos, “and leave me to act. You	391.228943481422
must perceive that in my quality of a husband this concerns me. Only,	346.0372709616287
D’Artagnan, if you have not lost it, give me the paper which fell from	473.7505894487946
that man’s hat, upon which is written the name of the village of—”	489.31324362207675
“Ah,” said D’Artagnan, “I comprehend! that name written in her hand.”	399.0572231012266
“You see, then,” said Athos, “there is a god in heaven still!”	368.2563235992557
Chapter LXIV.	421.6382073475082
THE MAN IN THE RED CLOAK	413.80612265761
The despair of Athos had given place to a concentrated grief which only	458.57612716642745
rendered more lucid the brilliant mental faculties of that	340.42290298555304
extraordinary man.	314.938690033144
Possessed by one single thought—that of the promise he had made, and of	459.94423367812476
the responsibility he had taken—he retired last to his chamber, begged	406.14132484204447
the host to procure him a map of the province, bent over it, examined	313.67099787753426
every line traced upon it, perceived that there were four different	444.81505337969503
roads from Béthune to Armentières, and summoned the lackeys.	302.9238401134926
Planchet, Grimaud, Bazin, and Mousqueton presented themselves, and	464.8051969944016
received clear, positive, and serious orders from Athos.	377.5173914742606
They must set out the next morning at daybreak, and go to	486.24036152036103
Armentières—each by a different route. Planchet, the most intelligent	429.2131175266346
of the four, was to follow that by which the carriage had gone upon	351.4192794501835
which the four friends had fired, and which was accompanied, as may be	451.15245083481614
remembered, by Rochefort’s servant.	407.2826632457922
Athos set the lackeys to work first because, since these men had been	425.56819894129205
in the service of himself and his friends he had discovered in each of	423.6650698044647
them different and essential qualities. Then, lackeys who ask questions	384.8535604613211
inspire less mistrust than masters, and meet with more sympathy among	385.6991863775239
those to whom they address themselves. Besides, Milady knew the	454.497271704341
masters, and did not know the lackeys; on the contrary, the lackeys	423.45500070658227
knew Milady perfectly.	486.97262548244623
All four were to meet the next day at eleven o’clock. If they had	478.6146467956037
discovered Milady’s retreat, three were to remain on guard; the fourth	425.854182804783
was to return to Béthune in order to inform Athos and serve as a guide	448.0715487296735
to the four friends. These arrangements made, the lackeys retired.	376.8826594765673
Athos then arose from his chair, girded on his sword, enveloped himself	380.3274886071313
in his cloak, and left the hôtel. It was nearly ten o’clock. At ten	304.52257800874156
o’clock in the evening, it is well known, the streets in provincial	449.2029117710524
towns are very little frequented. Athos nevertheless was visibly	449.10094853554745
anxious to find someone of whom he could ask a question. At length he	372.1981490953658
met a belated passenger, went up to him, and spoke a few words to him.	406.5434919908432
The man he addressed recoiled with terror, and only answered the few	316.9532364907573
words of the Musketeer by pointing. Athos offered the man half a	302.7569738964558
pistole to accompany him, but the man refused.	305.29571573522765
Athos then plunged into the street the man had indicated with his	462.7452775528911
finger; but arriving at four crossroads, he stopped again, visibly	445.29631747568675
embarrassed. Nevertheless, as the crossroads offered him a better	360.2704706101339
chance than any other place of meeting somebody, he stood still. In a	468.9842887792795
few minutes a night watch passed. Athos repeated to him the same	450.70344719942045
question he had asked the first person he met. The night watch evinced	350.74202784005337
the same terror, refused, in his turn, to accompany Athos, and only	455.4277596592327
pointed with his hand to the road he was to take.	316.06279779944833
Athos walked in the direction indicated, and reached the suburb	343.7697269057976
situated at the opposite extremity of the city from that by which he	427.18052997668036
and his friends had entered it. There he again appeared uneasy and	457.79717899733464
embarrassed, and stopped for the third time.	327.5889572785007
Fortunately, a mendicant passed, who, coming up to Athos to ask	340.78753445872246
charity, Athos offered him half a crown to accompany him where he was	438.29334587431083
going. The mendicant hesitated at first, but at the sight of the piece	475.16925749985074
of silver which shone in the darkness he consented, and walked on	294.6629867738862
before Athos.	377.64500863807876
Arrived at the angle of a street, he pointed to a small house,	467.8515929251355
isolated, solitary, and dismal. Athos went toward the house, while the	304.4044017099233
mendicant, who had received his reward, left as fast as his legs could	354.9272202011997
carry him.	442.21363955678186
Athos went round the house before he could distinguish the door, amid	491.21341105366366
the red color in which the house was painted. No light appeared through	300.9586139863979
the chinks of the shutters; no noise gave reason to believe that it was	320.600902556836
inhabited. It was dark and silent as the tomb.	465.4206522381499
Three times Athos knocked without receiving an answer. At the third	389.6637426243551
knock, however, steps were heard inside. The door at length was opened,	392.00327413597336
and a man appeared, of high stature, pale complexion, and black hair	357.7075968254298
and beard.	413.7432032899893
Athos and he exchanged some words in a low voice, then the tall man	372.90423478758987
made a sign to the Musketeer that he might come in. Athos immediately	368.7054900585495
profited by the permission, and the door was closed behind him.	363.1184754610578
The man whom Athos had come so far to seek, and whom he had found with	489.46223900689336
so much trouble, introduced him into his laboratory, where he was	352.38692105858803
engaged in fastening together with iron wire the dry bones of a	394.93331594129506
skeleton. All the frame was adjusted except the head, which lay on the	339.34037065438406
table.	358.30018977865114
All the rest of the furniture indicated that the dweller in this house	336.7464467674635
occupied himself with the study of natural science. There were large	407.8947743949773
bottles filled with serpents, ticketed according to their species;	466.27529880032137
dried lizards shone like emeralds set in great squares of black wood,	488.9412595831327
and bunches of wild odoriferous herbs, doubtless possessed of virtues	347.98816320799995
unknown to common men, were fastened to the ceiling and hung down in	457.20520723829816
the corners of the apartment. There was no family, no servant; the tall	484.3649579878175
man alone inhabited this house.	481.68295456077925
Athos cast a cold and indifferent glance upon the objects we have	469.98454188278964
described, and at the invitation of him whom he came to seek sat down	311.63256426253855
near him.	470.17103167749326
Then he explained to him the cause of his visit, and the service he	385.218617802927
required of him. But scarcely had he expressed his request when the	420.8167636490143
unknown, who remained standing before the Musketeer, drew back with	449.9671161392366
signs of terror, and refused. Then Athos took from his pocket a small	378.6545285743748
paper, on which two lines were written, accompanied by a signature and	437.00748087416923
a seal, and presented them to him who had made too prematurely these	367.5577308288198
signs of repugnance. The tall man had scarcely read these lines, seen	378.99858534153105
the signature, and recognized the seal, when he bowed to denote that he	396.2811736997562
had no longer any objection to make, and that he was ready to obey.	452.086392627424
Athos required no more. He arose, bowed, went out, returned by the same	303.93754178645366
way he came, re-entered the hôtel, and went to his apartment.	368.4918468615635
At daybreak D’Artagnan entered the chamber, and demanded what was to be	310.9596239289667
done.	476.6202979073478
“To wait,” replied Athos.	440.07470245420694
Some minutes after, the superior of the convent sent to inform the	421.03820786162635
Musketeers that the burial would take place at midday. As to the	379.44131239678626
poisoner, they had heard no tidings of her whatever, only that she must	467.59897065913515
have made her escape through the garden, on the sand of which her	348.4854653516672
footsteps could be traced, and the door of which had been found shut.	489.56557245242794
As to the key, it had disappeared.	411.0291040749274
At the hour appointed, Lord de Winter and the four friends repaired to	398.6649447464185
the convent; the bells tolled, the chapel was open, the grating of the	380.82261112752565
choir was closed. In the middle of the choir the body of the victim,	377.0854268328916
clothed in her novitiate dress, was exposed. On each side of the choir	381.57998219722856
and behind the gratings opening into the convent was assembled the	305.94387992253036
whole community of the Carmelites, who listened to the divine service,	298.21556059802356
and mingled their chant with the chant of the priests, without seeing	439.5474695284636
the profane, or being seen by them.	432.2540248933576
At the door of the chapel D’Artagnan felt his courage fall anew, and	472.8916716985477
returned to look for Athos; but Athos had disappeared.	467.98198003497964
Faithful to his mission of vengeance, Athos had requested to be	299.1571811908709
conducted to the garden; and there upon the sand following the light	296.949632312518
steps of this woman, who left sharp tracks wherever she went, he	462.06257309935154
advanced toward the gate which led into the wood, and causing it to be	471.8741544203417
opened, he went out into the forest.	365.24353398906453
Then all his suspicions were confirmed; the road by which the carriage	410.00316649858837
had disappeared encircled the forest. Athos followed the road for some	434.07622776928315
time, his eyes fixed upon the ground; slight stains of blood, which	355.3205810669613
came from the wound inflicted upon the man who accompanied the carriage	315.5481306787811
as a courier, or from one of the horses, dotted the road. At the end of	339.5356246247817
three-quarters of a league, within fifty paces of Festubert, a larger	310.73430106817744
bloodstain appeared; the ground was trampled by horses. Between the	387.2188615595921
forest and this accursed spot, a little behind the trampled ground, was	441.9236507377282
the same track of small feet as in the garden; the carriage had stopped	349.1488516189248
here. At this spot Milady had come out of the wood, and entered the	317.9848902491886
carriage.	314.25822466690863
Satisfied with this discovery which confirmed all his suspicions, Athos	406.53001828084746
returned to the hôtel, and found Planchet impatiently waiting for him.	311.6829988860095
Everything was as Athos had foreseen.	293.2535736717179
Planchet had followed the road; like Athos, he had discovered the	384.5206357291966
stains of blood; like Athos, he had noted the spot where the horses had	326.87752542873795
halted. But he had gone farther than Athos—for at the village of	483.4519285552967
Festubert, while drinking at an inn, he had learned without needing to	343.88855863088736
ask a question that the evening before, at half-past eight, a wounded	374.3621191043396
man who accompanied a lady traveling in a post-chaise had been obliged	340.6352922629933
to stop, unable to go further. The accident was set down to the account	309.8864891702895
of robbers, who had stopped the chaise in the wood. The man remained in	368.58916461342676
the village; the woman had had a relay of horses, and continued her	406.4273224357763
journey.	471.9004220872524
Planchet went in search of the postillion who had driven her, and found	365.1835816330657
him. He had taken the lady as far as Fromelles; and from Fromelles she	442.4997901838327
had set out for Armentières. Planchet took the crossroad, and by seven	379.3683816626577
o’clock in the morning he was at Armentières.	394.0259821704236
There was but one tavern, the Post. Planchet went and presented himself	374.4637675641006
as a lackey out of a place, who was in search of a situation. He had	361.6433191961192
not chatted ten minutes with the people of the tavern before he learned	345.83265890214824
that a woman had come there alone about eleven o’clock the night	306.79729583806886
before, had engaged a chamber, had sent for the master of the hôtel,	451.0501858346448
and told him she desired to remain some time in the neighborhood.	338.7326993541343
Planchet had no need to learn more. He hastened to the rendezvous,	467.9960246060303
found the lackeys at their posts, placed them as sentinels at all the	299.15907272252514
outlets of the hôtel, and came to find Athos, who had just received	331.9056474426345
this information when his friends returned.	465.5965140578919
All their countenances were melancholy and gloomy, even the mild	457.26010747150434
countenance of Aramis.	292.3207822440214
“What is to be done?” asked D’Artagnan.	397.3401962196436
“To wait!” replied Athos.	292.92879055303627
Each retired to his own apartment.	392.269206982577
At eight o’clock in the evening Athos ordered the horses to be saddled,	329.9516727527831
and Lord de Winter and his friends notified that they must prepare for	379.7240992592884
the expedition.	425.2557846391276
In an instant all five were ready. Each examined his arms, and put them	429.6395339030564
in order. Athos came down last, and found D’Artagnan already on	408.4924138743876
horseback, and growing impatient.	446.14481611693725
“Patience!” cried Athos; “one of our party is still wanting.”	403.2775844640836
The four horsemen looked round them with astonishment, for they sought	465.19732407470053
vainly in their minds to know who this other person could be.	404.10538772525274
At this moment Planchet brought out Athos’s horse; the Musketeer leaped	337.48650272525936
lightly into the saddle.	388.7602771207084
“Wait for me,” cried he, “I will soon be back,” and he set off at a	346.38948760060913
gallop.	407.41159576097454
In a quarter of an hour he returned, accompanied by a tall man, masked,	383.0399783850063
and wrapped in a large red cloak.	307.416825910396
Lord de Winter and the three Musketeers looked at one another	295.36284360568186
inquiringly. Neither could give the others any information, for all	466.8497853846095
were ignorant who this man could be; nevertheless, they felt convinced	337.42725190727333
that all was as it should be, as it was done by the order of Athos.	301.8860220376177
At nine o’clock, guided by Planchet, the little cavalcade set out,	378.07380153754144
taking the route the carriage had taken.	367.9714998922344
It was a melancholy sight—that of these six men, traveling in silence,	418.3128040432724
each plunged in his own thoughts, sad as despair, gloomy as	305.22233605180753
chastisement.	473.65635347864554
Chapter LXV.	410.7326630823899
TRIAL	328.9101624987996
It was a stormy and dark night; vast clouds covered the heavens,	384.0438386108835
concealing the stars; the moon would not rise till midnight.	467.9806306007382
Occasionally, by the light of a flash of lightning which gleamed along	383.68293980615914
the horizon, the road stretched itself before them, white and solitary;	423.8199595060189
the flash extinct, all remained in darkness.	310.7981338046987
Every minute Athos was forced to restrain D’Artagnan, constantly in	350.6985454637538
advance of the little troop, and to beg him to keep in the line, which	343.2701038664689
in an instant he again departed from. He had but one thought—to go	479.2480898720482
forward; and he went.	426.54057172108884
They passed in silence through the little village of Festubert, where	489.83313365710944
the wounded servant was, and then skirted the wood of Richebourg. At	351.8259581785602
Herlier, Planchet, who led the column, turned to the left.	429.12932601767784
Several times Lord de Winter, Porthos, or Aramis tried to talk with the	389.32968812517714
man in the red cloak; but to every interrogation which they put to him	410.13517882586996
he bowed, without response. The travelers then comprehended that there	300.32446902625946
must be some reason why the unknown preserved such a silence, and	455.63068496162407
ceased to address themselves to him.	401.99087359741725
The storm increased, the flashes succeeded one another more rapidly,	356.91764815340105
the thunder began to growl, and the wind, the precursor of a hurricane,	318.1237391058331
whistled in the plumes and the hair of the horsemen.	362.6346060179278
The cavalcade trotted on more sharply.	448.4731595088845
A little before they came to Fromelles the storm burst. They spread	473.5502857586189
their cloaks. There remained three leagues to travel, and they did it	375.70037296348426
amid torrents of rain.	340.3186809531749
D’Artagnan took off his hat, and could not be persuaded to make use of	378.3531612352648
his cloak. He found pleasure in feeling the water trickle over his	293.6112077974105
burning brow and over his body, agitated by feverish shudders.	339.3930947716476
The moment the little troop passed Goskal and were approaching the	393.54354759837923
Post, a man sheltered beneath a tree detached himself from the trunk	409.9538048328716
with which he had been confounded in the darkness, and advanced into	410.2470890829742
the middle of the road, putting his finger on his lips.	296.7421742074361
Athos recognized Grimaud.	358.00005455583823
“What’s the manner?” cried Athos. “Has she left Armentières?”	414.3201780602991
