Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative. D’Artagnan ground his teeth.	399.04132449627014
“Silence, D’Artagnan!” said Athos. “I have charged myself with this	372.62303867451976
affair. It is for me, then, to interrogate Grimaud.”	485.5423010388249
“Where is she?” asked Athos.	392.25001431501835
Grimaud extended his hands in the direction of the Lys. “Far from	301.39428247609493
here?” asked Athos.	473.5443446029395
Grimaud showed his master his forefinger bent.	480.7555003114187
“Alone?” asked Athos.	447.7893099739265
Grimaud made the sign yes.	387.14646369915454
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, “she is alone within half a league of us, in	315.1914128077853
the direction of the river.”	467.1272056196858
“That’s well,” said D’Artagnan. “Lead us, Grimaud.”	389.47145505225524
Grimaud took his course across the country, and acted as guide to the	440.205573145269
cavalcade.	460.3010514639013
At the end of five hundred paces, more or less, they came to a rivulet,	484.5561959289571
which they forded.	370.9439996476192
By the aid of the lightning they perceived the village of Erquinheim.	428.06382285801374
“Is she there, Grimaud?” asked Athos.	308.08448353126795
Grimaud shook his head negatively.	322.81086283495176
“Silence, then!” cried Athos.	390.1384451562473
And the troop continued their route.	468.1987036339018
Another flash illuminated all around them. Grimaud extended his arm,	454.0104462942637
and by the bluish splendor of the fiery serpent they distinguished a	378.50186995191655
little isolated house on the banks of the river, within a hundred paces	417.71807907606285
of a ferry.	407.51114693405617
One window was lighted.	374.7630362038312
“Here we are!” said Athos.	308.4107824880731
At this moment a man who had been crouching in a ditch jumped up and	416.75267487333105
came towards them. It was Mousqueton. He pointed his finger to the	321.95421041617004
lighted window.	452.4175265616632
“She is there,” said he.	337.1533509989726
“And Bazin?” asked Athos.	463.115240094432
“While I watched the window, he guarded the door.”	320.7125727072103
“Good!” said Athos. “You are good and faithful servants.”	457.3225549267124
Athos sprang from his horse, gave the bridle to Grimaud, and advanced	338.23765070026184
toward the window, after having made a sign to the rest of the troop to	356.70679551330306
go toward the door.	373.9141677316379
The little house was surrounded by a low, quickset hedge, two or three	448.1351895055759
feet high. Athos sprang over the hedge and went up to the window, which	323.05159576287826
was without shutters, but had the half-curtains closely drawn.	414.41821293533604
He mounted the skirting stone that his eyes might look over the	490.3313104901735
curtain.	312.1825930033985
By the light of a lamp he saw a woman, wrapped in a dark mantle, seated	315.4841972290485
upon a stool near a dying fire. Her elbows were placed upon a mean	457.0426119131841
table, and she leaned her head upon her two hands, which were white as	465.782681763214
ivory.	408.36898850537455
He could not distinguish her countenance, but a sinister smile passed	297.5831177915855
over the lips of Athos. He was not deceived; it was she whom he sought.	426.36046043598606
At this moment a horse neighed. Milady raised her head, saw close to	407.9521382926683
the panes the pale face of Athos, and screamed.	456.6593844583171
Athos, perceiving that she knew him, pushed the window with his knee	391.20186297618943
and hand. The window yielded. The squares were broken to shivers; and	389.0978994443542
Athos, like the spectre of vengeance, leaped into the room.	437.04759388197704
Milady rushed to the door and opened it. More pale and menacing than	414.3804906562171
Athos, D’Artagnan stood on the threshold.	456.59227962583907
Milady recoiled, uttering a cry. D’Artagnan, believing she might have	426.7560793184782
means of flight and fearing she should escape, drew a pistol from his	323.0375041847199
belt; but Athos raised his hand.	388.3578463825596
“Put back that weapon, D’Artagnan!” said he; “this woman must be tried,	319.4119222115862
not assassinated. Wait an instant, my friend, and you shall be	403.1482738120612
satisfied. Come in, gentlemen.”	443.325446168982
D’Artagnan obeyed; for Athos had the solemn voice and the powerful	412.004983462106
gesture of a judge sent by the Lord himself. Behind D’Artagnan entered	415.14443952183683
Porthos, Aramis, Lord de Winter, and the man in the red cloak.	372.5546778049581
The four lackeys guarded the door and the window.	440.9428898092228
Milady had sunk into a chair, with her hands extended, as if to conjure	416.79283772734107
this terrible apparition. Perceiving her brother-in-law, she uttered a	324.4125439066424
terrible cry.	368.075092225052
“What do you want?” screamed Milady.	298.9597437039584
“We want,” said Athos, “Charlotte Backson, who first was called	419.8089146654405
Comtesse de la Fère, and afterwards Milady de Winter, Baroness of	472.74624410170617
Sheffield.”	301.335773659969
“That is I! that is I!” murmured Milady, in extreme terror; “what do	478.0500212487251
you want?”	300.9924622987281
“We wish to judge you according to your crime,” said Athos; “you shall	389.3810053444515
be free to defend yourself. Justify yourself if you can. M. d’Artagnan,	378.653326552046
it is for you to accuse her first.”	310.0556098232474
D’Artagnan advanced.	460.4400752957158
“Before God and before men,” said he, “I accuse this woman of having	380.9472872052462
poisoned Constance Bonacieux, who died yesterday evening.”	341.77665146057205
He turned towards Porthos and Aramis.	318.5722268691998
“We bear witness to this,” said the two Musketeers, with one voice.	429.3624514137132
D’Artagnan continued: “Before God and before men, I accuse this woman	474.3434639007936
of having attempted to poison me, in wine which she sent me from	398.0250581915278
Villeroy, with a forged letter, as if that wine came from my friends.	461.89199978627005
God preserved me, but a man named Brisemont died in my place.”	478.2031422408181
“We bear witness to this,” said Porthos and Aramis, in the same manner	449.30274323377057
as before.	418.0461200533197
“Before God and before men, I accuse this woman of having urged me to	329.73724420373986
the murder of the Baron de Wardes; but as no one else can attest the	374.67104392530405
truth of this accusation, I attest it myself. I have done.” And	336.3252434844101
D’Artagnan passed to the other side of the room with Porthos and	341.4417911070949
Aramis.	341.086940135825
“Your turn, my Lord,” said Athos.	440.25470376155147
The baron came forward.	395.64351572686456
“Before God and before men,” said he, “I accuse this woman of having	351.31739792507784
caused the assassination of the Duke of Buckingham.”	466.3501254108412
“The Duke of Buckingham assassinated!” cried all present, with one	375.59118734116737
voice.	326.6959935456087
“Yes,” said the baron, “assassinated. On receiving the warning letter	446.193297533391
you wrote to me, I had this woman arrested, and gave her in charge to a	448.11907798326115
loyal servant. She corrupted this man; she placed the poniard in his	343.7493594522206
hand; she made him kill the duke. And at this moment, perhaps, Felton	471.6267829792828
is paying with his head for the crime of this fury!”	471.17759424158214
A shudder crept through the judges at the revelation of these unknown	415.6476004485921
crimes.	469.8067329444693
“That is not all,” resumed Lord de Winter. “My brother, who made you	430.5899353393154
his heir, died in three hours of a strange disorder which left livid	404.8345315259765
traces all over the body. My sister, how did your husband die?”	414.370403677174
“Horror!” cried Porthos and Aramis.	484.75967139996595
“Assassin of Buckingham, assassin of Felton, assassin of my brother, I	352.9718537133737
demand justice upon you, and I swear that if it be not granted to me, I	440.00047649272733
will execute it myself.”	490.45714490313765
And Lord de Winter ranged himself by the side of D’Artagnan, leaving	316.4102255714426
the place free for another accuser.	341.0436318492866
Milady let her head sink between her two hands, and tried to recall her	413.5419866305558
ideas, whirling in a mortal vertigo.	337.6657680723518
“My turn,” said Athos, himself trembling as the lion trembles at the	424.6023160333495
sight of the serpent—“my turn. I married that woman when she was a	454.0099246042722
young girl; I married her in opposition to the wishes of all my family;	423.20685851801113
I gave her my wealth, I gave her my name; and one day I discovered that	360.82825843480794
this woman was branded—this woman was marked with a _fleur-de-lis_ on	346.90767190173216
her left shoulder.”	332.72715915316655
“Oh,” said Milady, raising herself, “I defy you to find any tribunal	343.44130242904276
which pronounced that infamous sentence against me. I defy you to find	333.77611939152735
him who executed it.”	463.76853731673634
“Silence!” said a hollow voice. “It is for me to reply to that!” And	488.129052283915
the man in the red cloak came forward in his turn.	328.12829496510096
“What man is that? What man is that?” cried Milady, suffocated by	424.9485134101
terror, her hair loosening itself, and rising above her livid	385.7503154454523
countenance as if alive.	333.3140199762779
All eyes were turned towards this man—for to all except Athos he was	297.0604211945627
unknown.	370.33354334150226
Even Athos looked at him with as much stupefaction as the others, for	334.6738600235596
he knew not how he could in any way find himself mixed up with the	405.4148558191149
horrible drama then unfolded.	292.7697752007423
After approaching Milady with a slow and solemn step, so that the table	294.73864244782726
alone separated them, the unknown took off his mask.	475.73350466533617
Milady for some time examined with increasing terror that pale face,	327.31788179451314
framed with black hair and whiskers, the only expression of which was	373.3163518983952
icy impassibility. Then she suddenly cried, “Oh, no, no!” rising and	410.38836535683504
retreating to the very wall. “No, no! it is an infernal apparition! It	466.72218068154064
is not he! Help, help!” screamed she, turning towards the wall, as if	363.01443319702446
she would tear an opening with her hands.	475.4263590493149
“Who are you, then?” cried all the witnesses of this scene.	416.06232258115
“Ask that woman,” said the man in the red cloak, “for you may plainly	392.2457207841436
see she knows me!”	385.64944141943
“The executioner of Lille, the executioner of Lille!” cried Milady, a	409.9242815451851
prey to insensate terror, and clinging with her hands to the wall to	357.9342966560763
avoid falling.	491.1639173844178
Everyone drew back, and the man in the red cloak remained standing	356.9066637159191
alone in the middle of the room.	319.69302316661015
“Oh, grace, grace, pardon!” cried the wretch, falling on her knees.	348.44271042452857
The unknown waited for silence, and then resumed, “I told you well that	298.0355601525323
she would know me. Yes, I am the executioner of Lille, and this is my	300.7065953788449
history.”	441.78697706881235
All eyes were fixed upon this man, whose words were listened to with	414.5433889698119
anxious attention.	351.43442573505183
“That woman was once a young girl, as beautiful as she is today. She	332.42768003476186
was a nun in the convent of the Benedictines of Templemar. A young	374.4907755637954
priest, with a simple and trustful heart, performed the duties of the	452.0764031428881
church of that convent. She undertook his seduction, and succeeded; she	450.30267340619775
would have seduced a saint.	412.43203920407313
“Their vows were sacred and irrevocable. Their connection could not	310.2558305823002
last long without ruining both. She prevailed upon him to leave the	300.8099887705465
country; but to leave the country, to fly together, to reach another	474.6643929921685
part of France, where they might live at ease because unknown, money	428.6422270297369
was necessary. Neither had any. The priest stole the sacred vases, and	345.6883767153211
sold them; but as they were preparing to escape together, they were	467.93601794609117
both arrested.	337.72143534821686
“Eight days later she had seduced the son of the jailer, and escaped.	302.2745256079142
The young priest was condemned to ten years of imprisonment, and to be	332.49210139985775
branded. I was executioner of the city of Lille, as this woman has	360.225288986179
said. I was obliged to brand the guilty one; and he, gentlemen, was my	293.30872396787345
brother!	383.8032547787852
“I then swore that this woman who had ruined him, who was more than his	353.5223984036787
accomplice, since she had urged him to the crime, should at least share	376.1689555868612
his punishment. I suspected where she was concealed. I followed her, I	447.77366520552823
caught her, I bound her; and I imprinted the same disgraceful mark upon	309.8075199638805
her that I had imprinted upon my poor brother.	484.3332414817415
“The day after my return to Lille, my brother in his turn succeeded in	442.249863766815
making his escape; I was accused of complicity, and was condemned to	374.6322424371639
remain in his place till he should be again a prisoner. My poor brother	397.5633128024912
was ignorant of this sentence. He rejoined this woman; they fled	399.15904800917997
together into Berry, and there he obtained a little curacy. This woman	312.23333733191095
passed for his sister.	347.3449912469579
“The Lord of the estate on which the chapel of the curacy was situated	476.63564406534766
saw this pretend sister, and became enamoured of her—amorous to such a	393.41572176590245
degree that he proposed to marry her. Then she quitted him she had	412.62139250451645
ruined for him she was destined to ruin, and became the Comtesse de la	438.47945840164243
Fère—”	358.1925471979157
All eyes were turned towards Athos, whose real name that was, and who	452.42669342131285
made a sign with his head that all was true which the executioner had	481.9256564475137
said.	322.2669496161173
“Then,” resumed he, “mad, desperate, determined to get rid of an	378.05011667088496
existence from which she had stolen everything, honor and happiness, my	416.39460617520064
poor brother returned to Lille, and learning the sentence which had	399.37262921331114
condemned me in his place, surrendered himself, and hanged himself that	368.87757985614866
same night from the iron bar of the loophole of his prison.	294.2899215614377
“To do justice to them who had condemned me, they kept their word. As	367.32354188714834
soon as the identity of my brother was proved, I was set at liberty.	356.11383668797237
“That is the crime of which I accuse her; that is the cause for which	431.11848614881364
she was branded.”	336.2481089939927
“Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said Athos, “what is the penalty you demand	305.1280008348192
against this woman?”	461.30981814323036
“The punishment of death,” replied D’Artagnan.	342.71417005961166
“My Lord de Winter,” continued Athos, “what is the penalty you demand	350.4890026708316
against this woman?”	365.2238263429674
“The punishment of death,” replied Lord de Winter.	432.95851541448377
“Messieurs Porthos and Aramis,” repeated Athos, “you who are her	326.83592671019034
judges, what is the sentence you pronounce upon this woman?”	344.8242763251239
“The punishment of death,” replied the Musketeers, in a hollow voice.	392.57548507943505
Milady uttered a frightful shriek, and dragged herself along several	387.65110825036004
paces upon her knees toward her judges.	302.148213902385
Athos stretched out his hand toward her.	408.21734808494114
“Charlotte Backson, Comtesse de la Fère, Milady de Winter,” said he,	349.1516271102141
“your crimes have wearied men on earth and God in heaven. If you know a	380.9847731692398
prayer, say it—for you are condemned, and you shall die.”	433.3678770252285
At these words, which left no hope, Milady raised herself in all her	399.86056448935636
pride, and wished to speak; but her strength failed her. She felt that	350.42989671179663
a powerful and implacable hand seized her by the hair, and dragged her	340.02092277698415
away as irrevocably as fatality drags humanity. She did not, therefore,	454.38737236642714
even attempt the least resistance, and went out of the cottage.	331.199032655103
Lord de Winter, D’Artagnan, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, went out close	302.0432903086363
behind her. The lackeys followed their masters, and the chamber was	466.2926208339703
left solitary, with its broken window, its open door, and its smoky	407.82006027167137
lamp burning sadly on the table.	407.6946194570902
Chapter LXVI.	349.155381286935
EXECUTION	438.25584827397336
It was near midnight; the moon, lessened by its decline, and reddened	297.4668948092892
by the last traces of the storm, arose behind the little town of	430.220496288693
Armentières, which showed against its pale light the dark outline of	403.8354086183029
its houses, and the skeleton of its high belfry. In front of them the	327.8590717603841
Lys rolled its waters like a river of molten tin; while on the other	446.1068368420191
side was a black mass of trees, profiled on a stormy sky, invaded by	321.5120221732915
large coppery clouds which created a sort of twilight amid the night.	413.17437029253836
On the left was an old abandoned mill, with its motionless wings, from	354.8056443964135
the ruins of which an owl threw out its shrill, periodical, and	340.1755931036769
monotonous cry. On the right and on the left of the road, which the	444.4146577908115
dismal procession pursued, appeared a few low, stunted trees, which	362.6244738451176
looked like deformed dwarfs crouching down to watch men traveling at	365.10204816911994
this sinister hour.	414.08924820768783
From time to time a broad sheet of lightning opened the horizon in its	396.1151167601014
whole width, darted like a serpent over the black mass of trees, and	403.0803054730933
like a terrible scimitar divided the heavens and the waters into two	469.61999185895286
parts. Not a breath of wind now disturbed the heavy atmosphere. A	446.0577888502553
deathlike silence oppressed all nature. The soil was humid and	462.56457026186627
glittering with the rain which had recently fallen, and the refreshed	413.0383312741898
herbs sent forth their perfume with additional energy.	349.3897105482555
Two lackeys dragged Milady, whom each held by one arm. The executioner	428.98813659211794
walked behind them, and Lord de Winter, D’Artagnan, Porthos, and Aramis	299.1679403791687
walked behind the executioner. Planchet and Bazin came last.	313.1837875490759
The two lackeys conducted Milady to the bank of the river. Her mouth	309.9997415706749
was mute; but her eyes spoke with their inexpressible eloquence,	483.09018039339844
supplicating by turns each of those on whom she looked.	436.64771660136887
Being a few paces in advance she whispered to the lackeys, “A thousand	470.6605497892011
pistoles to each of you, if you will assist my escape; but if you	469.5214140288846
deliver me up to your masters, I have near at hand avengers who will	360.5071099049793
make you pay dearly for my death.”	475.90632789110896
Grimaud hesitated. Mousqueton trembled in all his members.	404.83580702518503
Athos, who heard Milady’s voice, came sharply up. Lord de Winter did	380.08647067603545
the same.	465.78695893860885
“Change these lackeys,” said he; “she has spoken to them. They are no	465.66081604800615
longer sure.”	336.1740366556182
Planchet and Bazin were called, and took the places of Grimaud and	317.1065880863417
Mousqueton.	356.0362786677182
On the bank of the river the executioner approached Milady, and bound	350.6447267323391
her hands and feet.	356.5157842408215
Then she broke the silence to cry out, “You are cowards, miserable	357.10613935309925
assassins—ten men combined to murder one woman. Beware! If I am not	452.10197016908086
saved I shall be avenged.”	408.444912935407
“You are not a woman,” said Athos, coldly and sternly. “You do not	381.79380096718927
belong to the human species; you are a demon escaped from hell, whither	421.4806199762154
we send you back again.”	358.49679963657934
“Ah, you virtuous men!” said Milady; “please to remember that he who	300.06526861130226
shall touch a hair of my head is himself an assassin.”	464.5430331873463
“The executioner may kill, without being on that account an assassin,”	350.2452552242582
said the man in the red cloak, rapping upon his immense sword. “This is	362.2770485628432
the last judge; that is all. _Nachrichter_, as say our neighbors, the	444.7089874227263
Germans.”	306.5341820277321
And as he bound her while saying these words, Milady uttered two or	376.0778585692658
three savage cries, which produced a strange and melancholy effect in	472.2379393871146
flying away into the night, and losing themselves in the depths of the	472.9248642609254
woods.	385.7638606768764
“If I am guilty, if I have committed the crimes you accuse me of,”	387.16752521168314
shrieked Milady, “take me before a tribunal. You are not judges! You	450.6168791293644
cannot condemn me!”	475.8991132243333
“I offered you Tyburn,” said Lord de Winter. “Why did you not accept	425.451726008081
it?”	339.5794863220835
“Because I am not willing to die!” cried Milady, struggling. “Because I	362.10543238915915
am too young to die!”	316.2883674661706
“The woman you poisoned at Béthune was still younger than you, madame,	338.4381261788848
and yet she is dead,” said D’Artagnan.	331.7901410771409
“I will enter a cloister; I will become a nun,” said Milady.	416.38856349455216
“You were in a cloister,” said the executioner, “and you left it to	357.1885924763691
ruin my brother.”	326.3764634744417
Milady uttered a cry of terror and sank upon her knees. The executioner	375.46006939123134
took her up in his arms and was carrying her toward the boat.	358.7690429112953
“Oh, my God!” cried she, “my God! are you going to drown me?”	488.05908582809036
These cries had something so heartrending in them that M. d’Artagnan,	313.3007679053091
who had been at first the most eager in pursuit of Milady, sat down on	313.86656772731857
the stump of a tree and hung his head, covering his ears with the palms	462.69104287902655
of his hands; and yet, notwithstanding, he could still hear her cry and	404.2650013000518
threaten.	425.9836361239412
D’Artagnan was the youngest of all these men. His heart failed him.	438.6756466733204
“Oh, I cannot behold this frightful spectacle!” said he. “I cannot	487.2503391445781
consent that this woman should die thus!”	383.9174973643528
Milady heard these few words and caught at a shadow of hope.	315.0926268795927
“D’Artagnan, D’Artagnan!” cried she; “remember that I loved you!”	354.88815440461286
The young man rose and took a step toward her.	399.63581163834414
But Athos rose likewise, drew his sword, and placed himself in the way.	310.55884999714385
“If you take one step farther, D’Artagnan,” said he, “we shall cross	390.4306152134358
swords together.”	419.23425182987245
D’Artagnan sank on his knees and prayed.	447.1667390559836
“Come,” continued Athos, “executioner, do your duty.”	482.11220356416254
“Willingly, monseigneur,” said the executioner; “for as I am a good	349.27660993343255
Catholic, I firmly believe I am acting justly in performing my	309.53558299348185
functions on this woman.”	309.56424293757766
“That’s well.”	433.6168185466438
Athos made a step toward Milady.	297.3950359373433
“I pardon you,” said he, “the ill you have done me. I pardon you for my	338.30018474580885
blasted future, my lost honor, my defiled love, and my salvation	414.70766517029335
forever compromised by the despair into which you have cast me. Die in	318.64025507208936
peace!”	413.3690792661266
Lord de Winter advanced in his turn.	382.57853036083975
“I pardon you,” said he, “for the poisoning of my brother, and the	459.9181511646203
assassination of his Grace, Lord Buckingham. I pardon you for the death	298.3081818255535
of poor Felton; I pardon you for the attempts upon my own person. Die	321.58426484472074
in peace!”	437.8669764050612
“And I,” said M. d’Artagnan. “Pardon me, madame, for having by a trick	328.911927377812
unworthy of a gentleman provoked your anger; and I, in exchange, pardon	362.32979771982974
you the murder of my poor love and your cruel vengeance against me. I	350.92278063465307
pardon you, and I weep for you. Die in peace!”	319.6691584206121
“I am lost!” murmured Milady in English. “I must die!”	343.569589956908
Then she arose of herself, and cast around her one of those piercing	299.72773540541687
looks which seemed to dart from an eye of flame.	342.5885819373204
She saw nothing; she listened, and she heard nothing.	331.4075392214541
“Where am I to die?” said she.	413.5263514116258
“On the other bank,” replied the executioner.	341.298049026965
Then he placed her in the boat, and as he was going to set foot in it	413.05643949342436
himself, Athos handed him a sum of silver.	477.313704562676
“Here,” said he, “is the price of the execution, that it may be plain	318.81637796405346
we act as judges.”	448.0614648137698
“That is correct,” said the executioner; “and now in her turn, let this	384.7600067761568
woman see that I am not fulfilling my trade, but my debt.”	410.0092210893225
And he threw the money into the river.	454.9827457904254
The boat moved off toward the left-hand shore of the Lys, bearing the	430.3850075203942
guilty woman and the executioner; all the others remained on the	449.1333140281409
right-hand bank, where they fell on their knees.	460.97690539330733
The boat glided along the ferry rope under the shadow of a pale cloud	370.3916148373024
which hung over the water at that moment.	382.81819450940753
The troop of friends saw it gain the opposite bank; the figures were	367.0245485861066
defined like black shadows on the red-tinted horizon.	383.3492784119288
Milady, during the passage had contrived to untie the cord which	386.7493708399041
fastened her feet. On coming near the bank, she jumped lightly on shore	310.13880363428694
and took to flight. But the soil was moist; on reaching the top of the	469.1225374348456
bank, she slipped and fell upon her knees.	412.8701616539741
She was struck, no doubt, with a superstitious idea; she conceived that	435.95720435164174
heaven denied its aid, and she remained in the attitude in which she	325.6945503016964
had fallen, her head drooping and her hands clasped.	371.5342036826129
Then they saw from the other bank the executioner raise both his arms	460.7075461397442
slowly; a moonbeam fell upon the blade of the large sword. The two arms	465.24780843305894
fell with a sudden force; they heard the hissing of the scimitar and	479.3161038566782
the cry of the victim, then a truncated mass sank beneath the blow.	410.99184040920375
The executioner then took off his red cloak, spread it upon the ground,	310.41068002860834
laid the body in it, threw in the head, tied all up by the four	383.1384322113847
corners, lifted it on his back, and entered the boat again.	435.0708421498626
In the middle of the stream he stopped the boat, and suspending his	311.53725489516404
burden over the water cried in a loud voice, “Let the justice of God be	344.5706438819712
done!” and he let the corpse drop into the depths of the waters, which	455.202948766096
closed over it.	364.2161007581316
Three days afterward the four Musketeers were in Paris; they had not	367.84751332256644
exceeded their leave of absence, and that same evening they went to pay	448.8572638807818
their customary visit to M. de Tréville.	447.9240597497435
“Well, gentlemen,” said the brave captain, “I hope you have been well	292.5999481297496
amused during your excursion.”	329.45432108881135
“Prodigiously,” replied Athos in the name of himself and his comrades.	448.1773489695706
Chapter LXVII.	303.11061852509624
CONCLUSION	325.69139171276845
On the sixth of the following month the king, in compliance with the	429.27494542382817
promise he had made the cardinal to return to La Rochelle, left his	315.95160260808467
capital still in amazement at the news which began to spread itself of	460.4910861852714
Buckingham’s assassination.	395.4259544841002
Although warned that the man she had loved so much was in great danger,	384.981955159634
the queen, when his death was announced to her, would not believe the	402.73490181394743
fact, and even imprudently exclaimed, “it is false; he has just written	378.7385151909649
to me!”	450.99063087312675
But the next day she was obliged to believe this fatal intelligence;	372.5613466953781
Laporte, detained in England, as everyone else had been, by the orders	446.14908965910547
of Charles I., arrived, and was the bearer of the duke’s dying gift to	319.91314489575785
the queen.	292.60356570399125
The joy of the king was lively. He did not even give himself the	439.06018163835097
trouble to dissemble, and displayed it with affectation before the	400.30438093592045
queen. Louis XIII., like every weak mind, was wanting in generosity.	475.5202171300444
But the king soon again became dull and indisposed; his brow was not	415.6899941135535
one of those that long remain clear. He felt that in returning to camp	459.4031262365305
he should re-enter slavery; nevertheless, he did return.	335.8776956405293
The cardinal was for him the fascinating serpent, and himself the bird	472.86155172486565
which flies from branch to branch without power to escape.	428.10354434290605
The return to La Rochelle, therefore, was profoundly dull. Our four	360.7056142863075
friends, in particular, astonished their comrades; they traveled	438.5036146923947
together, side by side, with sad eyes and heads lowered. Athos alone	400.9874597412961
from time to time raised his expansive brow; a flash kindled in his	435.89657242539
eyes, and a bitter smile passed over his lips, then, like his comrades,	411.41672912715194
he sank again into reverie.	320.8689804447167
As soon as the escort arrived in a city, when they had conducted the	451.84478897637405
king to his quarters the four friends either retired to their own or to	337.59264882731475
some secluded cabaret, where they neither drank nor played; they only	391.2497564887121
conversed in a low voice, looking around attentively to see that no one	445.37855822448205
overheard them.	333.4050621495552
One day, when the king had halted to fly the magpie, and the four	408.49479879181666
friends, according to their custom, instead of following the sport had	390.86470710183016
stopped at a cabaret on the high road, a man coming from la Rochelle on	409.0146033067626
horseback pulled up at the door to drink a glass of wine, and darted a	365.9277097613388
searching glance into the room where the four Musketeers were sitting.	471.36408069360675
“Holloa, Monsieur d’Artagnan!” said he, “is not that you whom I see	407.6184842310046
yonder?”	394.68246080557844
D’Artagnan raised his head and uttered a cry of joy. It was the man he	304.21167250201086
called his phantom; it was his stranger of Meung, of the Rue des	426.7782917253959
Fossoyeurs and of Arras.	467.30854020516125
D’Artagnan drew his sword, and sprang toward the door.	359.70356092412237
But this time, instead of avoiding him the stranger jumped from his	487.2790080257648
horse, and advanced to meet D’Artagnan.	387.8600591401981
“Ah, monsieur!” said the young man, “I meet you, then, at last! This	461.2894894008167
time you shall not escape me!”	377.955857153671
“Neither is it my intention, monsieur, for this time I was seeking you;	466.0395469136076
in the name of the king, I arrest you.”	390.4543965702945
“How! what do you say?” cried D’Artagnan.	460.6264891902022
“I say that you must surrender your sword to me, monsieur, and that	456.0031946857815
without resistance. This concerns your head, I warn you.”	373.3190927912664
“Who are you, then?” demanded D’Artagnan, lowering the point of his	377.9026475754144
sword, but without yet surrendering it.	456.49398331042676
“I am the Chevalier de Rochefort,” answered the other, “the equerry of	359.59021267641424
Monsieur le Cardinal Richelieu, and I have orders to conduct you to his	313.50329102253113
Eminence.”	392.52020413385264
“We are returning to his Eminence, monsieur the Chevalier,” said Athos,	326.23481485548774
advancing; “and you will please to accept the word of Monsieur	448.60028738395886
d’Artagnan that he will go straight to La Rochelle.”	371.8540285826323
“I must place him in the hands of guards who will take him into camp.”	437.8393720236708
“We will be his guards, monsieur, upon our word as gentlemen; but	423.748290819741
likewise, upon our word as gentlemen,” added Athos, knitting his brow,	415.42476448900857
“Monsieur d’Artagnan shall not leave us.”	428.56797873665107
The Chevalier de Rochefort cast a glance backward, and saw that Porthos	471.7505525515381
and Aramis had placed themselves between him and the gate; he	439.70751179495494
understood that he was completely at the mercy of these four men.	348.2495981530182
“Gentlemen,” said he, “if Monsieur d’Artagnan will surrender his sword	468.5445440465055
to me and join his word to yours, I shall be satisfied with your	396.3673466205779
promise to convey Monsieur d’Artagnan to the quarters of Monseigneur	313.724253222035
the Cardinal.”	436.1911985880196
“You have my word, monsieur, and here is my sword.”	452.84187437918155
“This suits me the better,” said Rochefort, “as I wish to continue my	332.97832050545463
journey.”	466.7411174298968
“If it is for the purpose of rejoining Milady,” said Athos, coolly, “it	330.908189131191
is useless; you will not find her.”	344.7170698245584
“What has become of her, then?” asked Rochefort, eagerly.	474.0816955169754
“Return to camp and you shall know.”	326.96463471848716
Rochefort remained for a moment in thought; then, as they were only a	460.9594716125614
day’s journey from Surgères, whither the cardinal was to come to meet	489.5135675555405
the king, he resolved to follow the advice of Athos and go with them.	444.99878510990305
Besides, this return offered him the advantage of watching his	404.99969433829364
prisoner.	312.79306382470156
They resumed their route.	393.80789248384724
On the morrow, at three o’clock in the afternoon, they arrived at	404.60823010570493
Surgères. The cardinal there awaited Louis XIII. The minister and the	482.00640684690904
king exchanged numerous caresses, felicitating each other upon the	452.9734840866678
fortunate chance which had freed France from the inveterate enemy who	348.578140036413
set all Europe against her. After which, the cardinal, who had been	315.46906537213675
informed that D’Artagnan was arrested and who was anxious to see him,	482.62426245158565
took leave of the king, inviting him to come the next day to view the	479.7017843034195
work already done upon the dyke.	370.53884738516786
On returning in the evening to his quarters at the bridge of La Pierre,	485.10927502419383
the cardinal found, standing before the house he occupied, D’Artagnan,	411.08000275331653
without his sword, and the three Musketeers armed.	449.9192236757917
This time, as he was well attended, he looked at them sternly, and made	482.1881095486723
a sign with his eye and hand for D’Artagnan to follow him.	328.07454150841585
D’Artagnan obeyed.	420.3970298431395
“We shall wait for you, D’Artagnan,” said Athos, loud enough for the	404.73883827707664
cardinal to hear him.	407.5894105645573
His Eminence bent his brow, stopped for an instant, and then kept on	394.9969175844204
his way without uttering a single word.	427.71195280033015
D’Artagnan entered after the cardinal, and behind D’Artagnan the door	331.5220522534311
was guarded.	415.628211097189
His Eminence entered the chamber which served him as a study, and made	355.5370099020488
a sign to Rochefort to bring in the young Musketeer.	470.2344451420455
Rochefort obeyed and retired.	394.32733642812
D’Artagnan remained alone in front of the cardinal; this was his second	335.4747003097568
interview with Richelieu, and he afterward confessed that he felt well	403.1478280694562
assured it would be his last.	330.7657645828092
Richelieu remained standing, leaning against the mantelpiece; a table	331.27773543001126
was between him and D’Artagnan.	335.8169032752649
“Monsieur,” said the cardinal, “you have been arrested by my orders.”	408.5223567559523
“So they tell me, monseigneur.”	312.0294736051039
“Do you know why?”	384.3175759634675
“No, monseigneur, for the only thing for which I could be arrested is	452.91509298278925
still unknown to your Eminence.”	350.44672281257726
Richelieu looked steadfastly at the young man.	473.87905955780604
“Holloa!” said he, “what does that mean?”	349.0095995470789
“If Monseigneur will have the goodness to tell me, in the first place,	489.91804243645055
what crimes are imputed to me, I will then tell him the deeds I have	460.94935787015265
really done.”	300.64736253367965
“Crimes are imputed to you which had brought down far loftier heads	462.0076005419041
than yours, monsieur,” said the cardinal.	434.4670726290882
“What, monseigneur?” said D’Artagnan, with a calmness which astonished	348.97790534448933
the cardinal himself.	303.2389178736607
“You are charged with having corresponded with the enemies of the	366.70977226256343
kingdom; you are charged with having surprised state secrets; you are	389.1965159586905
charged with having tried to thwart the plans of your general.”	430.8444212427868
“And who charges me with this, monseigneur?” said D’Artagnan, who had	359.2513000244297
no doubt the accusation came from Milady, “a woman branded by the	376.8574052967722
justice of the country; a woman who has espoused one man in France and	379.99405543706524
another in England; a woman who poisoned her second husband and who	434.56267909559915
attempted both to poison and assassinate me!”	488.83514304710616
“What do you say, monsieur?” cried the cardinal, astonished; “and of	369.45047328800086
what woman are you speaking thus?”	395.348779862065
“Of Milady de Winter,” replied D’Artagnan, “yes, of Milady de Winter,	321.4736334340296
of whose crimes your Eminence is doubtless ignorant, since you have	486.11104898957376
honored her with your confidence.”	319.46479554663233
“Monsieur,” said the cardinal, “if Milady de Winter has committed the	476.5536595768697
crimes you lay to her charge, she shall be punished.”	354.192858243411
“She has been punished, monseigneur.”	360.7217617707899
“And who has punished her?”	452.6092857648185
“We.”	313.7778927844443
“She is in prison?”	486.0945794559776
“She is dead.”	466.9866558637319
“Dead!” repeated the cardinal, who could not believe what he heard,	358.1060898087131
“dead! Did you not say she was dead?”	355.94661724069897
“Three times she attempted to kill me, and I pardoned her; but she	339.4027111035301
murdered the woman I loved. Then my friends and I took her, tried her,	307.10381772339167
and condemned her.”	475.40269518831525
D’Artagnan then related the poisoning of Mme. Bonacieux in the convent	410.81445581859094
of the Carmelites at Béthune, the trial in the isolated house, and the	427.5541656149983
execution on the banks of the Lys.	472.68270727307686
A shudder crept through the body of the cardinal, who did not shudder	311.8586513923381
readily.	314.74526997482485
But all at once, as if undergoing the influence of an unspoken thought,	404.96608092039196
the countenance of the cardinal, till then gloomy, cleared up by	326.7510364078047
degrees, and recovered perfect serenity.	396.60127144109185
“So,” said the cardinal, in a tone that contrasted strongly with the	351.4877956695866
severity of his words, “you have constituted yourselves judges, without	462.38479017069085
remembering that they who punish without license to punish are	321.3196775634763
assassins?”	377.8026111486572
“Monseigneur, I swear to you that I never for an instant had the	447.45540657471804
intention of defending my head against you. I willingly submit to any	466.8435814994954
punishment your Eminence may please to inflict upon me. I do not hold	447.12730136497487
life dear enough to be afraid of death.”	313.08560275246856
“Yes, I know you are a man of a stout heart, monsieur,” said the	429.9067076663713
cardinal, with a voice almost affectionate; “I can therefore tell you	419.97792513165166
beforehand you shall be tried, and even condemned.”	447.20223804487705
“Another might reply to your Eminence that he had his pardon in his	353.90056182335525
pocket. I content myself with saying: Command, monseigneur; I am	415.33143249137805
ready.”	359.1964571732712
“Your pardon?” said Richelieu, surprised.	381.21548867167485
“Yes, monseigneur,” said D’Artagnan.	292.49723407052835
“And signed by whom—by the king?” And the cardinal pronounced these	463.94152165655294
words with a singular expression of contempt.	479.8382516493103
“No, by your Eminence.”	448.14512273650246
“By me? You are insane, monsieur.”	380.6867802051361
“Monseigneur will doubtless recognize his own handwriting.”	389.22265338403264
And D’Artagnan presented to the cardinal the precious piece of paper	348.87665092874937
which Athos had forced from Milady, and which he had given to	344.4435916685607
D’Artagnan to serve him as a safeguard.	341.76291991157103
His Eminence took the paper, and read in a slow voice, dwelling upon	362.4277538849539
every syllable:	405.1887730008328
“Dec. 3, 1627	433.59442889203876
“It is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of	426.2585808552168
this has done what he has done.	394.9795562917745
“RICHELIEU”	441.4166342204637
The cardinal, after having read these two lines, sank into a profound	365.35598252739396
reverie; but he did not return the paper to D’Artagnan.	449.1688223243524
“He is meditating by what sort of punishment he shall cause me to die,”	325.288923020732
said the Gascon to himself. “Well, my faith! he shall see how a	292.18560946063525
gentleman can die.”	409.0221588968094
The young Musketeer was in excellent disposition to die heroically.	331.5329091560669
Richelieu still continued thinking, rolling and unrolling the paper in	429.2145573949608
his hands.	442.9962020186149
At length he raised his head, fixed his eagle look upon that loyal,	344.52827823889487
open, and intelligent countenance, read upon that face, furrowed with	345.1824632522786
tears, all the sufferings its possessor had endured in the course of a	350.1862404858734
month, and reflected for the third or fourth time how much there was in	420.253512903488
that youth of twenty-one years before him, and what resources his	416.9934226077952
activity, his courage, and his shrewdness might offer to a good master.	425.49897369882206
On the other side, the crimes, the power, and the infernal genius of	341.19616912344077
Milady had more than once terrified him. He felt something like a	472.6374953526297
secret joy at being forever relieved of this dangerous accomplice.	329.21972180360495
Richelieu slowly tore the paper which D’Artagnan had generously	401.75321805152015
relinquished.	307.655597067421
“I am lost!” said D’Artagnan to himself. And he bowed profoundly before	425.4474143882778
the cardinal, like a man who says, “Lord, Thy will be done!”	306.37356725591593
The cardinal approached the table, and without sitting down, wrote a	363.99552721681073
few lines upon a parchment of which two-thirds were already filled, and	443.7047174840741
affixed his seal.	399.4854172986661
“That is my condemnation,” thought D’Artagnan; “he will spare me the	399.3193369253013
_ennui_ of the Bastille, or the tediousness of a trial. That’s very	319.2095649727919
kind of him.”	412.03727682229623
“Here, monsieur,” said the cardinal to the young man. “I have taken	356.93708944023933
from you one _carte blanche_ to give you another. The name is wanting	378.9723133488094
in this commission; you can write it yourself.”	304.89195540814734
D’Artagnan took the paper hesitatingly and cast his eyes over it; it	409.1376418123606
was a lieutenant’s commission in the Musketeers.	327.816909066868
D’Artagnan fell at the feet of the cardinal.	324.99628146896566
“Monseigneur,” said he, “my life is yours; henceforth dispose of it.	376.91173888111143
But this favor which you bestow upon me I do not merit. I have three	405.5309951928272
friends who are more meritorious and more worthy—”	447.90993916956353
“You are a brave youth, D’Artagnan,” interrupted the cardinal, tapping	386.4150649818092
him familiarly on the shoulder, charmed at having vanquished this	400.1570618456477
rebellious nature. “Do with this commission what you will; only	457.26098899347164
remember, though the name be blank, it is to you I give it.”	466.6632758588719
“I shall never forget it,” replied D’Artagnan. “Your Eminence may be	480.5254758515388
certain of that.”	453.7376166751165
The cardinal turned and said in a loud voice, “Rochefort!” The	438.9562549846016
chevalier, who no doubt was near the door, entered immediately.	378.18479956564306
“Rochefort,” said the cardinal, “you see Monsieur d’Artagnan. I receive	386.24507360649784
him among the number of my friends. Greet each other, then; and be wise	374.3127763581763
if you wish to preserve your heads.”	315.1306197872787
Rochefort and D’Artagnan coolly greeted each other with their lips; but	330.21277996586394
the cardinal was there, observing them with his vigilant eye.	341.50948197930995
They left the chamber at the same time.	326.23370069718965
“We shall meet again, shall we not, monsieur?”	303.90687924032966
“When you please,” said D’Artagnan.	415.8950166685998
“An opportunity will come,” replied Rochefort.	355.6508876294818
“Hey?” said the cardinal, opening the door.	446.16430577881647
The two men smiled at each other, shook hands, and saluted his	436.97995969142164
Eminence.	489.32625401337214
“We were beginning to grow impatient,” said Athos.	475.5013590799052
“Here I am, my friends,” replied D’Artagnan; “not only free, but in	319.6128522253325
favor.”	463.59132094937706
“Tell us about it.”	390.668986837615
“This evening; but for the moment, let us separate.”	458.59574602490136
Accordingly, that same evening D’Artagnan repaired to the quarters of	474.4212210306537
Athos, whom he found in a fair way to empty a bottle of Spanish wine—an	441.5218524128687
occupation which he religiously accomplished every night.	353.3252362707704
D’Artagnan related what had taken place between the cardinal and	425.6472886785658
himself, and drawing the commission from his pocket, said, “Here, my	369.5538089734962
dear Athos, this naturally belongs to you.”	413.68154302057764
Athos smiled with one of his sweet and expressive smiles.	384.9862948972383
“Friend,” said he, “for Athos this is too much; for the Comte de la	388.46987491285006
Fère it is too little. Keep the commission; it is yours. Alas! you have	330.72585830808896
purchased it dearly enough.”	301.3715064096584
D’Artagnan left Athos’s chamber and went to that of Porthos. He found	440.51388454778197
him clothed in a magnificent dress covered with splendid embroidery,	430.0647475513169
admiring himself before a glass.	373.65153047193644
“Ah, ah! is that you, dear friend?” exclaimed Porthos. “How do you	426.4425033359996
think these garments fit me?”	388.1636058908716
“Wonderfully,” said D’Artagnan; “but I come to offer you a dress which	335.04404983825975
will become you still better.”	475.5940345092641
“What?” asked Porthos.	463.3503168507914
“That of a lieutenant of Musketeers.”	472.72983470424015
D’Artagnan related to Porthos the substance of his interview with the	391.6894347597032
cardinal, and said, taking the commission from his pocket, “Here, my	336.4460425620836
friend, write your name upon it and become my chief.”	355.60451354701496
Porthos cast his eyes over the commission and returned it to	355.40872436749277
D’Artagnan, to the great astonishment of the young man.	438.4636907879605
“Yes,” said he, “yes, that would flatter me very much; but I should not	334.76529273004047
have time enough to enjoy the distinction. During our expedition to	491.3768044412573
Béthune the husband of my duchess died; so, my dear, the coffer of the	412.8077909506361
defunct holding out its arms to me, I shall marry the widow. Look here!	380.2591334381845
I was trying on my wedding suit. Keep the lieutenancy, my dear, keep	344.07830389071523
it.”	341.4448097172389
The young man then entered the apartment of Aramis. He found him	392.80087812031064
kneeling before a _priedieu_, with his head leaning on an open prayer	344.78507134476087
book.	340.92925616030004
He described to him his interview with the cardinal, and said, for the	462.6332694228565
third time drawing his commission from his pocket, “You, our friend,	425.9825067267781
our intelligence, our invisible protector, accept this commission. You	462.15704563250677
have merited it more than any of us by your wisdom and your counsels,	460.71304533046646
always followed by such happy results.”	479.03212084890686
“Alas, dear friend!” said Aramis, “our late adventures have disgusted	438.20993566565147
me with military life. This time my determination is irrevocably taken.	316.97928950403013
After the siege I shall enter the house of the Lazarists. Keep the	308.76269011466127
commission, D’Artagnan; the profession of arms suits you. You will be a	369.3340728614861
brave and adventurous captain.”	321.6843345437405
D’Artagnan, his eye moist with gratitude though beaming with joy, went	412.7251208449373
back to Athos, whom he found still at table contemplating the charms of	378.0603417897721
his last glass of Malaga by the light of his lamp.	323.9996814018274
“Well,” said he, “they likewise have refused me.”	386.39935409320896
“That, dear friend, is because nobody is more worthy than yourself.”	365.0590135618478
He took a quill, wrote the name of D’Artagnan in the commission, and	371.737776315909
returned it to him.	365.09405378723153
“I shall then have no more friends,” said the young man. “Alas! nothing	479.4781661711956
but bitter recollections.”	317.0905340717194
And he let his head sink upon his hands, while two large tears rolled	424.8684079515823
down his cheeks.	461.77321328197775
“You are young,” replied Athos; “and your bitter recollections have	360.3364625543204
time to change themselves into sweet remembrances.”	392.9536184503859
EPILOGUE	304.8105600155139
La Rochelle, deprived of the assistance of the English fleet and of the	310.61111381170076
diversion promised by Buckingham, surrendered after a siege of a year.	327.39517065322315
On the twenty-eighth of October, 1628, the capitulation was signed.	387.2257819467029
The king made his entrance into Paris on the twenty-third of December	398.74118212306183
of the same year. He was received in triumph, as if he came from	299.9510118109261
conquering an enemy and not Frenchmen. He entered by the Faubourg St.	357.1829844620243
Jacques, under verdant arches.	347.55832907431704
D’Artagnan took possession of his command. Porthos left the service,	409.2942189758439
and in the course of the following year married Mme. Coquenard; the	463.9720999659261
coffer so much coveted contained eight hundred thousand livres.	381.73513336508563
Mousqueton had a magnificent livery, and enjoyed the satisfaction of	354.4299084345658
which he had been ambitious all his life—that of standing behind a	330.41541073530635
gilded carriage.	359.07940006549757
Aramis, after a journey into Lorraine, disappeared all at once, and	301.22970105042975
ceased to write to his friends; they learned at a later period through	433.38755929695134
Mme. de Chevreuse, who told it to two or three of her intimates, that,	405.75920016944923
yielding to his vocation, he had retired into a convent—only into	296.9023710308932
which, nobody knew.	378.49799041946574
Bazin became a lay brother.	377.6893336855843
Athos remained a Musketeer under the command of D’Artagnan till the	449.40430450132976
year 1633, at which period, after a journey he made to Touraine, he	449.9918676716752
also quit the service, under the pretext of having inherited a small	302.98857422068545
property in Roussillon.	359.6668910718299
Grimaud followed Athos.	455.92046915516676
D’Artagnan fought three times with Rochefort, and wounded him three	355.7359469838463
times.	417.0815486628568
“I shall probably kill you the fourth,” said he to him, holding out his	314.0543113291158
hand to assist him to rise.	487.4324287915011
“It is much better both for you and for me to stop where we are,”	416.9967689532764
answered the wounded man. “_Corbleu!_ I am more your friend than you	424.96887173431514
think—for after our very first encounter, I could by saying a word to	364.41176402857434
the cardinal have had your throat cut!”	365.25806721056296
They this time embraced heartily, and without retaining any malice.	488.5658803818784
Planchet obtained from Rochefort the rank of sergeant in the Piedmont	394.3391403501214
regiment.	450.37373803886993
M. Bonacieux lived on very quietly, wholly ignorant of what had become	301.10827792019364
of his wife, and caring very little about it. One day he had the	459.01580003143965
imprudence to recall himself to the memory of the cardinal. The	302.46556496971743
cardinal had him informed that he would provide for him so that he	409.100713479926
should never want for anything in future. In fact, M. Bonacieux, having	455.59286668049566
left his house at seven o’clock in the evening to go to the Louvre,	466.7729162969936
never appeared again in the Rue des Fossoyeurs; the opinion of those	390.274646572553
who seemed to be best informed was that he was fed and lodged in some	331.2907596194916
royal castle, at the expense of his generous Eminence.	385.91037998028753
        	459.2224681092084
